title: Dollars and the Democrats

The unions had contributed huge sums to the Democrats, and when an issue came along that seemed to threaten jobs and wages, they called in their chits. But in the cynical competition for Congressional votes, another familiar player -- private industry -- was absent. Businesses that would normally have promised big money to persuade Democrats to vote the other way were nowhere to be found. The reason, according to a new study, is that business is deserting the Democrats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTZER, JACK
description: WALTZER-Jack. Our father was a man of exceptional insight and empathy. He had more energy and vitality than most men half his age, and he was an eager and hearty participant in life-always welcoming opportunities and embracing challenges. His lust for life never flagged. His strength of character and generosity were hallmarks of his business and social relationships. And once you earned his friendship, he was always there when you needed him. He had great presence, even charisma. His emotional strength was impressive and his physical vitality and strength were imposing. He was a wonderful story teller, who took great pleasure in entertaining his family and friends. He thoroughly enjoyed his fishing, boating and trapshooting. We will miss him-and all of his countless qualities-dearly. We will miss the extraordinary love he had for our mother, to whom he had been married for 54 years, and for the family they had created together. Our children will miss their loving grandfather. We will miss the unabashed pride he took in our accomplishments, as well as his support and solace in our moments of difficulty and disappointment. We will miss a great man...a genuine mensch...our beloved father. Wayne, Paul, Lori, Alice

That was unfortunate, for the 47-piece orchestra thrived at the Y, which seats only 916 and seems more intimate than that. In comparison, Alice Tully Hall seats just 180 more, but feels vaster. Inevitably the orchestra did not have the presence there it used to have at the Y, and inaccuracies in the playing were more noticeable.

title: Editorial Observer; Collecting Three Centuries of American Slang
description: I have always been struck by the abundance of human speech and by its transience. Since humans first made sense out of sound, the quantity of conversation in the world has swelled relentlessly. We live now in an ocean of speech, a tide of talk that follows the arc of sunlight around the globe day by day. The amazing thing is this -- of all the sentences that have been spoken since the first intelligible syllables were uttered, nearly every one has been lost. The constructed environment in which we live, the work we do, the elaboration of our inner lives, the monuments of our culture -- these are signs that talk has been talked to a purpose. As for the things people have actually said to each other through history -- the conversations themselves -- they are gone.

title: Irish Girl, 13, To Abort Baby In England
description: After several days of emotional national debate on abortion, a volatile issue in this overwhelmingly Roman Catholic country, the Supreme Court affirmed today that a 13-year-old girl who said she became pregnant after being raped was free to travel to Britain for an abortion.

title: Leopold and Loeb as Everymen
description: In John Logan's remarkable play ''Never the Sinner,'' Clarence Darrow tells a judge that Richard Loeb and Nathan Leopold, who murdered a 14-year-old boy in their Chicago neighborhood in 1924, were ''much like all of us.'' Of course, he would say anything to save his clients from death, but the play -- based on years of research, including some into sealed family archives -- at least suggests he was not far off the mark.

This week a new version of ''The Diary of Anne Frank'' reaches Broadway on a wave of suspicion and controversy that provoked a major Jewish writer to make a pre-emptive strike in The New Yorker without even waiting to see it.

title: Old Records Reveal Clara Barton's Role as a Sleuth
description: For Clara Barton, the legendary war nurse, her work as the ''Angel of the Battlefield'' to the soldiers of the Civil War did not end with the last battle in 1865.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, NINA JOAN PYMER ''JODIE''
description: STONE-Nina Joan Pymer ''Jodie'' died Sunday, November 29, 1997, at her winter home in New Smyrna Beach, FL. Born in Baltimore, MD, January 7, 1929, she was a 1946 graduate of Friends School, Baltimore, and a 1948 graduate of Edgewood Park College. She was the widow of George Norton Stone, former master at The Hotchkiss School 1949-1986. A resident of Lakeville, CT., since 1949, Mrs. Stone worked at the Sharon Clinic 1952-1955, and again 1960-66. From 1956-60 she served as a research assistant for the Sharon Hospital Project on cholesterol. She became an employee of The Hotchkiss School in 1966 and worked there until she retired in 1986. Jodie Stone was a dedicated volunteer and among the groups she served are the Salisbury Association, Scoville Library, Sharon Hospital Auxiliary, Noble Horizons Auxiliary, OWL's Kitchen, and the Congregational Church in Salisbury, Connecticut. Mrs. Stone is survived by her sister-in-law, Mrs. Gregory Zilboorg of Seneca, SC, and her children, Caroline, John, and Matthew Zilboorg. A memorial service will be held at 2 P.M., Saturday, December 6, 1997, at the Salisbury Congregational Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Hotchkiss School, Lakeville, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARNES, IRMA SHONGUT
description: KARNES-Irma Shongut. I want to express my profound sadness at the death of my great aunt Irma. Born December 11, 1912 and died November 30, 1997. She was very special to me. I will miss the warmth, affection and kindness she has always shown me. I will remember her always with love. Michele Eva Enzer

title: With Caveats, U.S. Supports Israeli Decision on West Bank
description: The United States gave a tentative welcome today to Israel's decision in principle to pull out of parts of the West Bank, but said it would wait and see if the step satisfied the American call for ''significant and credible'' action in the peace effort.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Senator STROM THURMOND, the Republican of South Carolina who is the oldest person to serve in Congress, turns 95 on Friday, and it's just as well that the Senate is not in session, in view of the planned celebrations.

title: Disney Concert Hall Gets a Pledge
description: Over the past decade, the ambitious dream by Walt Disney's family for a grandiose Disney Concert Hall in downtown Los Angeles has turned bleak. Intended to reinvigorate downtown neighborhoods and even transform the entire city, the project stalled and almost collapsed under the weight of financial problems, red tape, bureaucratic bungling and artistic disagreements.

title: Ice Sheets Seem Unmoved by the Volcanic Eruptions Below
description: WHEN volcanoes erupt beneath thick sheets of ice, the resulting flash floods sometimes devastate communities, roads and farms. But there is new evidence that the effects of these eruptions are mostly local, with little overall effect on the ice sheets themselves.

title: 2-War Strategy Is Obsolete, A Defense Panel Contends
description: The cor nerstone of Pentagon policy its plans to fight two major wars at once -- is becoming obsolete, and increasingly serves only to justify the military's size and structure, a Congressionally chartered defense panel said today.

Since then, in almost every season, 14 of them in all, everyone has wondered, is this the year the A.F.C., the Susan Lucci of football, ends the streak?

title: USG to Buy Canada Plant
description: The USG Corporation agreed today to buy a Canadian gypsum-panel plant from the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation for undisclosed terms, marking Louisiana-Pacific's exit from that business. The plant, in Port Hawkesbury, Nova Scotia, employs about 85 people. The sale is part of Louisiana-Pacific's plan, disclosed in October, to sell about $1 billion in assets as it moves to cut costs, reduce debt and focus on its main building-products businesses such as oriented strand board, an alternative to plywood, and siding.

title: U.S. Selects Final Six for Olympic Hockey Squad
description: Coach Ron Wilson now has a full, 23-man roster for his United States Olympic hockey team. It includes center Pat LaFontaine of the Rangers, right wing Bill Guerin of the Devils and defenseman Bryan Berard of the Islanders. They were among the final six players named yesterday to the squad that will play in Nagano, Japan, in February when the National Hockey League shuts down for more than two weeks for the Winter Games.

title: After Bad Year for A.M.A., Doctors Debate Its Prognosis
description: THE patient has had a bad year: on that much the doctors all agree. But their opinions on the underlying diagnosis and prognosis differ radically.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, PAUL L., M.D.
description: GILBERT-Paul L., M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni records with sorrow the loss of their cherished colleague and friend. During his tenure at Mount Sinai, extending over four decades, Dr. Gilbert pioneered many teaching activities including the establishment of the first Women's Health Fellowship in the U.S. A devoted teacher and supportive mentor, he represented the best tradition of the Medical Center, exemplified by his dedication to teaching and commitment to clinical excellence. An outstanding and devoted clinician, Dr. Gilbert was admired and respected by his colleagues and patients, but above all, earned a special affection by his profound humanity, generosity, warm smile and gentle humor. Today the community is richly endowed with physicians in his specialty due, in large measure, to his efforts. His wisdom, judgement, energy and constant presence, were an inspiration to all who knew him. He will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, our dear friend and colleage, Dr. Harriet Gilbert, their children and grandchildren. Wayne S. Fuchs, M.D., President Avi Barbasch, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria Padilla, M.D., Secretary William G. Stein, M.D., Treasurer

title: Supreme Court Hears Test of 'Treasure' Law
description: Hundreds of shipwrecks have been lying off the coastal United States, some for centuries, only recently brought within the reach of treasure hunters by the new technology of deep sea exploration and recovery. With new technology comes new law, and an argument before the Supreme Court today on new rules for sorting out claims to shipwreck treasure suggested that it may prove to be as hard to determine the rules as to find the long-lost bounty itself.

title: Bailout for Korea Is Left Unresolved As Seoul Hesitates
description: An agreement for the economic rescue of South Korea unraveled Monday and negotiations began again, as Seoul resisted taking the severe steps, such as closing insolvent banks, that were advocated by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Div. I-AA Honors Go to Villanova
description: Brian Finneran, the Villanova wide receiver who has 80 catches for 1,209 yards and 17 touchdowns this season, received the Walter Payton award as the best player in Division I-AA yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Siemens and Newbridge Buy Radnet of Israel
description: The German engineering giant Siemens A.G. said yesterday that it and the Newbridge Networks Corporation of Canada had jointly acquired Radnet Ltd. of Israel for $75 million. Radnet makes switches for a type of communications network known as asynchronous transfer mode, or ATM.

description: Chubb & Son, the insurance company in Warren, N.J., has signed a 15-year lease for 58,490 square feet at 1251 Avenue of the Americas, between 49th and 50th Streets.

title: McKesson-Costco Accord
description: The McKesson Corporation said today that it had renewed a pharmaceuticals distribution agreement with the Costco Companies for three years, estimating the value of the contract at as much as $750 million, or an additional $50 million a year. McKesson, the world's largest drug distributor, said revenue from the previous agreement was $200 million a year. The increased revenue over the term of the new agreement reflects growth in sales and an increase in the number of Costco stores. Costco, based in Issaquah, Wash., operates 264 wholesale warehouses.

title: State Senate Approves Surcharge on Prisoners
description: The State Senate convened yesterday for the first time since the November election and approved a 10 percent surcharge on any item bought by a prisoner at a county jail or state prison commissary. Officials said the surcharge would raise up to $2.3 million a year for the state's Violent Crimes Compensation Board, which provides assistance to victims of violent crimes.

title: Libya's Vast Desert Pipeline Could Be Conduit for Troops
description: In the sandy expanse of Libya's desert, where temperatures climb above 100 degrees on a winter's day, an army of more than 12,000 foreign workers is toiling on one of the world's most audacious and mysterious public works projects.

title: Wilson Has Ugly Numbers; Mets Give Him Winter Off
description: Paul Wilson began winter ball bearing something of a pitching checklist, and though his stint has been ended prematurely by what the organization believes is inconsequential pain in his right elbow, the Mets' pitcher felt that his tenure in Puerto Rico was productive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARLMAN, BETTY L.
description: PEARLMAN-Betty L. Died November 19, 1997. A woman of courage and intelligence. Survived by daughter Donna and sister Freda. She will be greatly missed.

title: Lafayette, Here They Come
description: A seven-member delegation from the United States, led by Alan Rothenberg, the president of the United States Soccer Federation, will travel to France to witness Thursday's draw for next summer's tournament.

title: Canadian Gets Light Term In Child's Death
description: A Canadian farmer convicted of killing his disabled 12-year-old daughter was exempted today from the mandatory sentence for second-degree murder and instead given one year in jail plus 364 days of probation.

title: Agreement to Resolve Pakistan's Political Crisis Slips Away
description: Pakistan's monthlong political crisis moved today into the Supreme Court, where an agreement that would have been a major step toward defusing the tensions collapsed by day's end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COX, RONALD L.
description: COX-Ronald L. On November 26 at age 64. Of Sarasota, Florida, Union City, N.J. and Bennington, VT. Survived by his companion Russell Bagley, mother Arlene, brother Norbert, sister Catherine. Mr. Cox was a well known antiques dealer, President of Four Corners East, Inc. From the onset of the AIDS crisis, Mr. Cox devoted his energies to the plight of sufferers in New York City, serving as an early member of the Episcopal Diocese of New York's AIDS Committee and the Mayor's Task Force on AIDS. He spent the last years of his career as Director of AIDS Volunteers at St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Center where his tireless advocacy and compassion profoundly impacted the lives of many. Mr. Cox served as a member of the Board of Trustees of the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 145 West 46 Street. A Requiem Mass will be sung there on Wednesday, December 3, at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. Mary's Restoration Fund.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HOST MARRIOTT CORP. Bethesda, Md., the hotel real estate company, acquired a controlling interest in the Desert Springs Resort and Spa in Palm Desert, Calif., through a $60 million loan to the limited partnership that owns the resort.

title: PHARMACIA & UPJOHN TO EXPAND SALES FORCE BY 1,200
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. said yesterday that it would add 1,200 people to its sales force in the next two years, expanding it from the current 5,000 representatives as part of a turnaround program. The plan was disclosed at a meeting in New York with analysts and investors. Pharmacia & Upjohn has lagged behind its rivals since it was formed in a 1995 merger. In October, it said it would take charges of $450 million this year to streamline operations. These changes are expected to result in cost saving of $250 million a year by 2000. Shares of Pharmacia & Upjohn were unchanged yesterday at $33.75.

title: Klaus's First Goal May Be to Get A Loyal Party Core Behind Him : Czech Leader Looks To Opposition Bench
description: PRAGUE  Out but not down, Vaclav Klaus, who was forced to resign as the Czech prime minister over political finance scandals, is preparing for what could be a long campaign of guerrilla politics led from the opposition benches.

title: F.T.C. DROPS PLAN TO EASE STANDARD OF 'MADE IN U.S.A.'
description: The Federal Trade Commission retreated from fierce opposition today and declared that products labeled ''Made in U.S.A.'' must in fact be just that, with only ''negligible'' foreign content.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROFF, FRIEDA (NEE POMERANTZ)
description: OSTROFF-Frieda (nee Pomerantz). On December 1, 1997 at the age of 74. Cherished wife of Harold, beloved mother of Madelon and Philip Braun and Sandra Ostroff. Loving grandmother of Andrew, Kelli and Jessica Braun and Alison and Debra Gottlieb and treasured great-grandmother of Jeffrey Braun. We all had the benefit of her uncompromising love and the wisdom of her teaching. She was an active participant in the causes she held dear and in the lives of so many. Services will be held Wednesday, December 3, 11:15 AM at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC. Contributions may be made to Workmen's Circle Division of ORT, 817 Broadway, NYC 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYDAH, EDWARD K.
description: SAYDAH-Edward K. Husband of Lyra (nee Brzell), died Monday, December 1, 1997. A retired importer of embroidered linens, he moved from Brooklyn to Southbury, CT in 1981. Survived also by a son Charles E. Saydah of Monsey, NY, a daughter Marie L. Sherer of Middlebury, CT, a sister Lillian Saydah of New York and six grandchildren.

title: Preserving the Book of Hours for Centuries
description: For the first time since it opened to the public in 1924, New York's Pierpont Morgan Library is displaying the cream of its collection of medieval and Renaissance illuminated prayer books. The exhibition is appropriately titled ''Painted Prayers,'' but it also carries an intriguing subtitle: ''Medieval Best Seller: The Book of Hours.''

title: Sports of The Times; Brown Takes The What-Ifs In Stride
description: THIRTEEN games into the season, in the middle of his fast-food lunch, dialogue with Dave Brown resumed, like a dusty, half-read book, pulled from a shelf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, BERNARD K.
description: ROSE-Bernard K. Beloved husband of Esther, devoted father of Barry Charles and Thomas Andrew. Dear brother of Horace and Harvey. Services on Wednesday, 2 PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Japanese Domestic Auto Sales Slide
description: Japanese domestic automobile sales posted their steepest drop in more than 23 years in November, and with no consumer-spending recovery in sight, auto makers are likely to continue to rev up exports.

title: Political Wrangling Delays Selection of Medicare Panel
description: Congressional leaders named 10 people today to a new Federal advisory commission that will recommend ways of preserving Medicare for 76 million baby boomers, but President Clinton held up his selections because of wrangling with the Republican leaders over appointment of a chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGERLEIDER, PETER
description: UNGERLEIDER - Peter. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library mourn the untimely death of Peter Ungerleider an esteemed Honorary Trustee of the Library, a loyal and generous friend of this institution for many years, and an artist of orginality and imagination, Mr. Ungerleider was a cherished member of the Library family. We extend our deepest sympathies to Peter's wife, Katryn Scheel-Ungerleider, to his sister Jeanne, and to his brothers Steven and Andrew. Marshall Rose, Chairman Brooke Russell Astor, Honorary Chairman Elizabeth Rohatyn and Andrew Heiskell, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President

description: KOENIGSBERG-Helen. Nov. 30, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Devoted mother of Harold. Loving sister of Ruth Grossman. Services Tues., 12 noon, ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her memory to a charity of choice.

title: Going Home, American Shoots Film In Vietnam
description: Making the first American movie ever filmed entirely in Vietnam hasn't been a bed of lotus blossoms, say its producers and its young director, Tony Bui, 25.

title: U.N.'s Chief Offers Iraq Oil Compromise
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan recommended today that the Security Council consider increasing the amount of oil Iraq may sell to get food and medicine but stopped short of proposing a specific export figure.

title: Market Place; Warner-Lambert Shares Plunge on Glaxo Move
description: Shares of the Warner-Lambert Company plunged 18.5 percent yesterday after Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. halted British sales of Warner-Lambert's diabetes drug, troglitazone.

title: Journeying Into the Darker Recesses of Mind and Myth
description: Pam Tanowitz and Fiona Marcotty explored dark corners of the mind at Dance Theater Workshop on Sunday night when they shared a program as part of Splitstream, a series of performances featuring works by two choreographers. They brought imagination with them on their expeditions.

title: Tribe Apologizes to Developer For Accusations About Casino
description: The Spokane Tribe of Indians has apologized to a Boston developer for suggesting that he was involved in using political influence to help win approval for a casino project the tribe opposed.

title: When Refugees Settle In
description: Congress's recent decision to grant amnesty to more than 150,000 Central Americans has been hailed by many as a necessary correction of the 1996 immigration reform. But some people seem to have forgotten the true basis of American refugee policy: that the shelter the United States provides is not a right.

title: Stocks Surge As Fears Ebb About Asia
description: A sense that Japanese and Southeast Asian officials are moving quickly to address the financial problems in their economies fueled a rally in stock markets around the world yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 2.4 percent to above the 8,000-point level for the first time in more than a month.

title: City May Seek To Cut Size Of Balloons
description: A mayoral panel met yesterday to begin investigating a balloon accident that injured four spectators at the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, and one focus is whether the city should require smaller balloons for future parades, a city official said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: South Korea Resistance Delays I.M.F. Agreement

title: Fassel Puts Kanell on Notice: Step It Up or Sit Down
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel put Danny Kanell's starting job in jeopardy today because he was bothered by the poor passing-game choices his 24-year-old quarterback made in Sunday's loss to Tampa Bay. The choices had Fassel wondering whether Kanell had studied the game plan and all its options sufficiently.

title: In a Reversal, Child Welfare Hiring Methods Are Upheld
description: Reversing her own earlier decision, a state judge ruled yesterday that 735 caseworkers hired by the Giuliani administration to bolster its revamped child welfare agency could keep their jobs and that new caseworkers could be tested for proficiency in spoken and written English.

title: Global Warming Talks Open in Kyoto
description: A conference that is supposed to cap more than two years of negotiations on what to do about global warming opened here today amid widespread concern that too many hard issues remained to allow the completion of an effective agreement before the talks end in nine days.

title: F.B.I.'S CHIEF TRIES TO INFLUENCE RENO
description: In a last-ditch appeal for an independent prosecutor, the F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh, has written a long memorandum to Attorney General Janet Reno contending that the conflicts of interest for the Justice Department are so great that her department cannot credibly investigate the campaign finance issue, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Tight but Quirky Job Market As the New York Area Revives
description: A phenomenon absent from the New York regional economy for nearly a decade, and almost unthinkable through the grim recession years of the early 1990's, has suddenly re-emerged here: a shortage of workers.

title: Clinton Conditionally Supports U.S. Role in Bailout
description: President Clinton said today that the United States was prepared to contribute to the bailout of South Korea, but only if the South Korean Government agreed to the kinds of painful economic changes being demanded by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Rivera Sharpens His Focus on Title
description: The only thing that keeps the sparse boxing gym on the second floor of the Miguel Frau Gymnasium from being a blast furnace is the steady, albeit humid breeze that whips through the windows.

title: Dressing Up a Decade's Spareness
description: It has been nearly six years since fashion made as resolute a shift in style as it is undergoing now. The austere jackets, sharp slim trousers and pallid makeup of the last few years are yielding to the elegant ease of languorous ankle-brushing skirts, insouciant boas, luxurious brushes of fur, delicately embroidered sweaters, rose-blushed lips and glossy hair.

title: Profit Tripled for El Al In the Third Quarter
description: El Al Israel Airlines reported yesterday that its net income more than tripled in the third quarter, taking the state-owned carrier into profitability for the first nine months of the year. But the company said it would ''have difficulty'' breaking even for the year because of a decline in the number of tourists visiting Israel.

title: Hip Injury Sidelines Frerotte For Year
description: Washington Redskins quarterback Gus Frerotte has a broken hip and will miss the rest of the season, the team said yesterday.

title: Topics of The Times; Waiting for Janet Reno
description: Last weekend's Republican attacks on Attorney General Janet Reno's legal reasoning may have been politically motivated. They also happened to be true. Senators Orrin Hatch of Utah and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania criticized Ms. Reno's narrow approach to investigating the 1996 campaign fund-raising scandals in separate appearances on Sunday.

title: Metro Business; Chicago Company Buys Marriott Resort
description: The Marriott Seaview Resort, a fixture on the Jersey Shore 10 miles north of Atlantic City in Gallaway, has been acquired by LaSalle Partners, a real estate company in Chicago, the company said yesterday.

title: Jesse Jackson, in Kenya, Links Benefits to Fair Elections

title: Quick Action Alters 'Brain Attack' Effects
description: Two weeks after he had coronary bypass surgery, an 83-year-old man stopped at a bank in Warrensburg, Mo., about 40 miles southeast of Kansas City, and collapsed. The bank called 911, and an ambulance took the man to a hospital in Warrensburg. A CT scan showed that he had suffered an acute ischemic stroke: a blood clot had lodged in the artery feeding most of the right side of his brain.

title: GTECH TO FORGO A NEW BID FOR TEXAS LOTTERY CONTRACT
description: The Gtech Holdings Corporation said yesterday that it would not rebid its Texas Lottery contract, its single biggest, and might have to write off investments and costs associated with the contract. Gtech, a provider of electronic wagering systems based in West Greenwich, R.I., has had many ups and downs in the last year as details about its role in the bidding for the contract emerged. Texas decided last spring to end Gtech's contract early and to reopen bidding for a new state lottery operator because of questions raised by Gtech's payments to lobbyists. Gtech challenged the ending of the contract, which expires in August 2002, and said the new bidding was biased toward a competitor. Its shares fell 50 cents yesterday, to $31.6875.

title: The Shopping Season
description: As carols peal in malls everywhere, subliminally directing holiday shoppers toward vibrating foot baths and wool mufflers, there are indications that the post-Thanksgiving shopping experience is giving way to virtual forms of shopping. The Friday after Thanksgiving was once the day by which retailers gauged the commercial success of the Christmas season, as millions of shoppers -- mostly women -- dutifully braved stifling crowds to do the bulk of the gift-buying in their families.

title: For $999, an I.B.M. Machine Offers Many Features and Room to Grow
description: THE magic number is $999. Until a couple of weeks ago, that could buy you a computer with lots of frustrating compromises or one without a major brand name. But the new Aptiva E16 from the International Business Machines Corporation is a $999 unit that does almost everything right and has plenty of room to grow. The E16 will be available only in Officemax stores until early next year, but I.B.M.'s competitors clearly have some catching up to do.

title: DURA PHARMACEUTICALS ENDS DEAL TO BUY SCANDIPHARM
description: Dura Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it had ended its agreement to buy Scandipharm Inc. for $93 million to $139 million in stock. Officials were not immediately available for comment from either company. Scandipharm, a closely held company based in Birmingham, Ala., said only that it was ''reviewing various options'' after Dura's decision to end the agreement. Dura, which is based in San Diego, agreed in October to acquire Scandipharm to expand its respiratory business. Scandipharm's main product is Ultrase, a prescription for cystic fibrosis patients. Dura develops and sells drugs for asthma, allergies and other respiratory problems.

title: Indians' Williams Takes Pay Cut to Insure Trade
description: Matt Williams, voted four times his league's best fielding and best hitting third baseman, was so determined to play in Arizona that he agreed to a move unique in baseball history. Because the Cleveland Indians wanted $3 million to complete the deal with the Diamondbacks, Williams agreed to reduce his 1998 salary by $2.5 million.

title: SKIN CARE COMPANIES AGREE TO A $60 MILLION MERGER
description: The Medicis Pharmaceutical Corporation of Phoenix agreed yesterday to acquire the Genderm Corporation for $60 million. Medicis is a skin care company whose biggest product is an acne medication called Dynacin. The company had sales of $41.2 million for the year that ended on June 30. Genderm, a privately held company, is based in Lincoln, Ill. Its products include Zostrix, a topical analgesic; Occlusal, a topical wart remedy; Salac, an acne wash, and Pentrax dandruff shampoos. Under the agreement, Medicis will initially pay $60 million and then up to $20 million more if certain sales goals are reached in 1999. Shares of Medicis rose $1.50 yesterday, to $44.25.

title: Experts Testify on Composition Of Bomb in Oklahoma City Blast
description: The bomb that destroyed the Oklahoma City Federal Building was probably made with ammonium nitrate, explosives experts testified today in the trial of Terry L. Nichols.

title: Correction

title: Israel's Nebulous Land Plan
description: Movement in the glacial Middle East peace effort, when it comes these days, can be so finely shaded it is hard to tell if it represents progress. Such is the case with Israel's latest position on turning over more territory to the Palestinians. The plan may be a sign that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is moving his quarrelsome Cabinet toward honoring the terms of the Oslo peace agreements. That would be heartening. But the decision is laced with ambiguity, leaving uncertain whether it was fashioned to advance the peace talks or to satisfy Mr. Netanyahu's conservative allies.

title: COHO ENERGY IN $257.5 MILLION DEAL WITH AMOCO
description: Coho Energy Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire certain oil and gas properties in Oklahoma from the Amoco Corporation for $257.5 million plus stock rights. Coho, which is based in Dallas, is the largest producer of oil and gas in Mississippi. It said the acquisition would make it the largest crude oil producer in Oklahoma. Amoco, the oil, natural gas and chemical company, is based in Chicago. The acquisition includes interests in more than 25,000 acres in southern Oklahoma, including 14 principal producing fields and 722 producing wells. As part of the deal, Amoco received rights to purchase, over five years, one million shares of Coho common stock at $10.425 a share. Coho shares closed yesterday at $9.50, down 68.75 cents.

title: AIRTOUCH TO PURCHASE CELLULAR STAKES FOR $245 MILLION
description: Airtouch Communications Inc. agreed to acquire cellular phone operations from Telephone and Data Systems Inc. and a subsidiary, the United States Cellular Corporation, for more than $245 million. Airtouch, a wireless communications carrier based in San Francisco, was spun off from the Pacific Telesis Group in 1994. Telephone and Data, based in Chicago, provides cellular and local phone and radio paging services. United States Cellular, also based in Chicago, operates automobile and hand-held cellular phone systems. Under the agreement, Airtouch will pay $195.6 million in stock and $50 million in cash for cellular systems in Seattle and Olympia, Wash.; Tucson, Ariz.; Duluth, Minn., and rural areas in Arizona, Colorado and Idaho.

description: Howard Boyar, a stockbroker, pleaded guilty yesterday in Criminal Court in Manhattan to criminal possession of stolen property and admitted he had used inside information to make money from securities trades.

title: Endangered Mammals Go Home to a Land They Never Knew
description: Since 1968, the Duke University Primate Center has been breeding lemurs, primitive but often striking-looking primates, in the hope of reintroducing the endangered animals into the wild. Last month, five of Duke's black and white ruffed lemurs became the first captive-bred lemurs to be returned to the forests of their native Madagascar.

title: Dollar Up vs. Yen on Doubts About Japan's Overhaul Plan
description: The dollar surged to its highest level in five and a half years against the yen yesterday on speculation that Japan might not do enough to bail out ailing banks and securities firms.

description: Senior NATO officials here and in Brussels said today that they expected allied defense ministers to commission military plans this week for a continued peacekeeping mission in Bosnia after the middle of next year.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest on Saturday for an article about stock trading on Friday misstated the close of the Dow Jones industrial average that day. It was 7,823.13, not 7,794.78.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Thanksgiving diners at a coffee shop on the Upper West Side of Manhattan misstated the name of the Brooklyn neighborhood that is home to the cook, James Mallas. It is Dyker Heights, not Dykes Point.

title: ACTIVISION BUYS 2 GAME DISTRIBUTORS FOR $48.6 MILLION
description: Activision Inc. said it had acquired two closely held video-game distributors -- Centresoft Ltd. of Britain and NBG Distribution of Germany -- for $48.6 million in stock. Activision, an entertainment software developer in Santa Monica, Calif., issued 2.8 million shares valued at $44.2 million for Centresoft, which had sales of $70.2 million for the 12 months ended in April. It acquired NBG for 281,000 shares valued at $4.4 million. NBG had sales of $19.3 million for the 12 months ended in June. Activision shares rose 12.5 cents, to $16.125.

title: Why Piscataway Decided to Avoid Spotlight
description: Never mind that the Piscataway Board of Education could have played a prominent role in the fervent national debate on affirmative action. Or that the Supreme Court of the United States, weeks away from hearing a reverse-discrimination case against the board, could have used it to rewrite the rules for race-based hiring decisions.

title: Judge Rejects Giuliani's Attempt To Kill Bus Ads Using His Name
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's effort to remove bus advertisements that lampooned his style, saying that a Mayor who is in the headlines every day and who recently appeared in drag on national television ''cannot avoid the limelight of publicity -- good and bad.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUGHLIN, LAURA FRANCES BRENNAN
description: LOUGHLIN-Laura Frances Brennan, 86. Of Bradenton, Florida, formerly of Kew Gardens, NY, died November 27. Interment will be 2PM, Friday, December 5 at St. Charles Cemetery, New Highway & Conklin St., Farmingdale, NY, for her and the cremated remains of her late husband, Richard L. Loughlin, who died April 14, 1997. Born in Brooklyn, New York, Mrs. Loughlin was a graduate of St. Joseph's College in Brooklyn. She retired as Guidance Counselor and Office Practices Teacher for John Adams High School in Ozone Park, New York after 35 years. She was also a Brownie Leader. Survivors include her daughter Laurie Loughlin of Nashville, TN and several nieces and nephews. For info: Bernard F. Dowd Funeral Home in Jamaica, New York.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Yes, It's Live, With Give-and-Take
description: Since the late 1970's, hip-hop has hit funk like a combined demolition and salvage operation. By sampling favorite vamps and drumbeats, hip-hop producers built rhythm tracks without live musicians. They gained control, but traded away the give-and-take of a working band. The old symbiosis of band, singer and audience, forged in gospel churches and rhythm-and-blues clubs, eroded as machines took over. Yet hip-hop also preserved and rediscovered vintage funk riffs. During the 1990's, live bands have made a modest comeback, partly because sources began demanding payment for samples and partly because ballads demand a responsive band.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRANTZ, LINDA
description: KRANTZ-Linda. Beloved wife of Morry. Devoted mother to Todd and Lauren. Loving mother-in-law to David and Ligia and adoring grandmother to Matthew, Lindsay and Jessica. Passed away early on the morning of November 30, 1997 as she lived with great courage and dignity. Funeral services will be held today at Louis Suburban Chapels, Fairlawn, New Jersey at 12 noon. She surely was the angel's glow that lights a star and will forever live within our hearts. Contributions can be made in her memory to Johns Hopkins University Hospital, Cancer Research, Baltimore, Maryland.

title: International Team Inspects Ohio Nuclear Processing Plant
description: The United States today opened up a nuclear processing plant in Ohio to international weapons experts, complete with continuous videotaping and surprise inspections, in hope of inducing Russia to do the same.

title: Pataki Signs Bill Letting Hemophiliacs Sue Companies Over Blood-Clotting Products
description: Ending a fierce lobbying fight, Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation today that will allow people to sue the makers of blood-clotting products that are widely thought to have infected thousands of hemophiliacs with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, during the 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APSEY, LAWRENCE S.
description: APSEY-Lawrence S. Born in Cambridge, MA on November 14, 1902, passed away November 30, 1997. Lawrence is survived by his son Peter of Fresno, CA, grandsons Curtis and Louis Apsey and Mark and Keith Moulton and two great-granddaughters. After a distinguished legal career with the U.S. Government and private industry, Lawrence devoted his retirement years to Quaker endeavors including The Alternatives to Violence Project. Lawrence was an author of several books including ''Transforming Power for Peace'' and ''Following the Light for Peace''. Box 42976, Philadelphia, PA 19101.

description: * Slover & Co., New York, was awarded four assignments with combined billings estimated at $1.5 million: Pierce Martin, Atlanta, a home furnishings company, which had been handled in-house; Sirmos, Long Island City, Queens, as the first agency for the lighting company, and Robert Allen Inc., New York, a fabric maker, as the first agency to handle its Robert Allen and Ametex divisions. Slover already handles Allen's Beacon Hill division.

title: By Design; Some Chokers That Don't
description: The chokers John Galliano likes to show with his Edwardian-inspired evening dresses are so wide that only a swanlike neck like Queen Alexandra's could carry them off. But there are many more wearable versions with a suitably vintage air to dress up holiday raiment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAINER, JOHN N.
description: TRAINER-John N. Of Southbury, Connecticut and Pubnico, Nova Scotia. Died Novemeber 30, at The Pomperaug Woods Health Center after a short illness. He is survived by his wife Alice (Stone) and two sons, John N. Trainer, Jr. of Nashville, TN. and Edward S. Trainer of Evanston, Illinois, by five grandchildren: David Browning, John N. III, Matthew Stone, John Booth and Kirsten Brooke and by his brother Robert Browning Trainer of New York. Mr. Trainer was born in NYC where he attended Horace Mann School in Allen Stevenson School. He prepared at Phillips Exeter Academy and graduated from Harvard College in 1931. He joined the Investment Counsel firm of Trainer and Associates in NYC in 1931 and became President when it incorporated into Trainer Wortham and Company, Inc. in 1954. In World War II, Mr. Trainer was on active duty in the Pacific Theater from 1941-1945. He retired as Commander, US Naval Reserve in 1951. Mr. Trainer was a resident of Mount Kisco, New York for 50 years. He was a long time board member of the Northern Westcheter Hospital and of the Boys Club of Mt. Kisco. He was significantly involved in the major expansion of both institutions and received national recognition from the Boys Club of America. He was a member of the Metropolitan Squash Racquet Association of New York and served as its President in 1947. He was also a member of the Jesters Club, the Racquet and Tennis Club and the Harvard Club of New York City. Mr. Trainer had a life-long interest in sailing and was active in the formation of The Sea Education Association which offers to young people Seafaring and Ocean Science programs. He was a member of the Wianno Yacht Club and the Cruising Club of America. Memorial service Thursday, December 4 at 1 P.M., at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Main Street South, Woodbury, Conn. In lieu of flowers, the family request that donations be made to the Boys and Girls Club of Northern Westchester, 351 Main Street, Mt. Kisco, New York 10549 or to the Sea Education Association, POB 6, Woods Hole, Mass. 02543.

title: Bionic Chip Built to Aid Brain Study
description: THE brain is a crowded place, with nerve and supporting cells wedged in elbow to elbow, so to speak, as electrical and chemical signals go zipping by. Not an easy place to get a handle on the actions of individual nerve cells and how those cells form networks to process information.

title: Metro Business; Utility to Sell Plants
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation said yesterday that it had filed a plan with state utility regulators to auction off its fossil-fueled and hydroelectric generating plants, whose book value is about $1 billion.

title: Bail Set at $10,000 For a Youth Leader
description: A youth leader at a Washington Heights evangelical church who has been accused of sodomizing a 14-year-old boy was ordered held on $10,000 bail by Judge William Mogulescu of Manhattan Criminal Court.

title: Guerin Gets His Chance At a Medal
description: Bill Guerin was just one of the members of the Devils who received good news about the Olympics this afternoon, but Guerin will be the only one actually playing for the United States. All the others will be working for the American team behind the scenes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DUNPHY, MARIE
description: DUNPHY-Marie, February 18th, 1912-December 2nd, 1996. No more tears in heaven. Love, Lanny

title: Unfinished Czech Reforms
description: Vaclav Klaus, the elegant, arrogant Czech Prime Minister, resigned last weekend over a campaign finance scandal. Mr. Klaus was already weakened by unpopular new austerity measures and reforms that followed a financial crisis in May. The irony is that these painful changes were necessary because in his first few years in office, Mr. Klaus often bought his popularity by avoiding reform.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLIKIN, JOHN H.

title: Crew Says Tenure for Principals Hurts Schools
description: In a year-end assessment of New York City's new school governance law, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that the law had led to greater accountability and parent involvement in the school system, but insisted that the ''chief impediment'' to school reform continued to be tenure for principals.

description: In banking's latest mega-merger, the National City Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the First of America Bank Corporation in a $6.7 billion deal that would create the 13th-largest bank in the country.

title: Bridge Title Strikes Twice
description: One of the great veterans of the game won a major title here on Sunday night at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals. Capturing the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship as part of a four-man squad that led the final stage from start to finish, was 67-year-old Sidney Lazard Sr. of New Orleans, who won the same event 37 years ago. His teammates here were Bart Bramley and Howard Weinstein, both of Chicago, and Steve Garner of Northfield, Ill.

title: Here's the Movie. Now Where's The Theater?; For the British, the Trick Isn't to Get a Film Made, But to Get It Distributed
description: Lynda Myles, a producer whose credits include ''The Snapper'' and ''The Commitments,'' describes her new film, ''The Life of Stuff,'' as a ''psychotic comedy'' about a group of ineffectual gangsters in Scotland. It was shown for the first time at the London Film Festival last month, and Ms. Myles, while hopeful, is unsure about its future. Like many newly minted British films, ''The Life of Stuff'' does not yet have a distributor.

description: Post-game rhetoric included, Charles Oakley remains one of Jeff Van Gundy's favorite players. The Knicks' coach wishes more players would stop fraternizing with opponents and have no qualms about knocking over patrons who happen to be in the path of a loose ball.

title: Campbell's Messages Unanswered in a Long, Strange Loss
description: Long after the Rangers lost by 3-2 in overtime to the Washington Capitals last night, Coach Clin Campbell stood in a hallway at Madison Square Garden, between large photographs of the 1940 Stanley Cup winners and the champions of 1994. His 1997-98 Blue Shirts - who have lost four and tied two in their last six - might not contend for the cup. Four games below .500, they might not make the playoffs if their ennui continues. And who can say who will play for them or even coach them come playoff time?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, GERTRUDE BATES
description: FOSTER-Gertrude Bates, 77. On November 29, 1997. Born on November 17, 1920 at Morristown, N.J., daughter of Putnam Asbury and Emeline Goold Vernam Bates. Beloved wife of Philip W. Foster, with whom she established Laurel Hill Herb Farm in Morristown in 1942. In 1946 they moved the business to Connecticut, settling in Falls Village. The following year they started The Herb Grower magazine, for which she served as editor and writer, her husband as publisher. She wrote extensively for horticultural and popular publications, including the garden section of The New York Times. She traveled widely, lecturing on herbs, their culture and uses. She was an Honorary Life Member of the Herb Society of America, and received its Helen DeConway Little Medal of Honor, for outstanding contributions to horticulture in 1975. She was also a Fellow of the Royal Horticultural Society, member of the American Horticultural Society, and the Connecticut Botanical Society. Survived also by son Christopher G. Foster of Gales Ferry, Connecticut, daughter Rosemary F. Louden of Old Greenwich, Connecticut, sister Marie Louise Emory of Santa Barbara, CA, and five grandchildren. Memorial service at a time and place to be announced. Donations in her memory to a charity of the donor's choice.

title: MOFFATT COMMUNICATIONS ADDING CABLE-TV SYSTEMS
description: Moffat Communications Ltd. of Winnipeg, Manitoba, agreed yesterday to buy the Alberta cable-television systems of Groupe Videotron for $295 million (Canadian), or $209.5 million (United States), almost doubling the number of its subscribers. The purchase will add 152,000 cable subscribers to the 228,000 that Moffat already has in the United States and Canada. Moffat will also get 2,220 Internet-access customers from Groupe Videotron, which is based in Montreal.

description: For months, while several candidates battled among themselves for the privilege of finishing second on Election Day in November, nary an unkind word was uttered about Lee P. Brown, the front-runner in the race for mayor of Houston.

title: Bows, Tears And Bailouts
description: We Japanese bow on three occa sions when greeting, parting and apologizing. The last, if done publicly, usually follows the revelation of past indiscretions. These often include graft, collusion, breach of trust, mismanagement caused by greed or poor judgment, and misappropriation of public money.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film Score CD's; A Lush Classical Sound in Movies
description: Anyone who loves sweepingly Romantic late-19th-century symphonies and piano concertos should be grateful to Hollywood for perpetuating a heroic, accessible style of music that contemporary composers have largely abandoned. Musical snobs might argue that the film score is a shamelessly manipulative, commercially tainted pastiche of something pure and highbrow, and perhaps they're right. But for better or worse, film scores provide our most vital link to a late-Romantic musical tradition that extends from Chopin through Shostakovitch. Similarly, the Disney-style animated musical perpetuates the use of large-scale theater orchestrations that for reasons of cost are more available in the movies than on Broadway.

To the writer that's often true abandonment; it's always ''Who is going to take care of me?'' time.

title: AGOURON STOCK FALLS 22%; DRUG DEVELOPMENT DROPPED
description: Shares in Agouron Pharmaceuticals Inc. fell 22 percent yesterday after the company said it had dropped development of a new cancer drug and ended a cancer research collaboration with F. Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd. Agouron, a biotechnology company based in La Jolla, Calif., said human clinical trials of the drug, Thymitaq, did not show a sufficient improvement over existing therapies to warrant proceeding. The company's shares fell $8.50, to close at $31, in heavy trading.

description: Prosecutors in the second Oklahoma City bombing trial rested their case against Terry L. Nichols today, after 20 days of testimony, and lawyers for the defense began their effort to show that Mr. Nichols was not involved in the bombing conspiracy.

title: Yamaichi Securities Said To Be Able to Pay Debt
description: The Bank of Japan's governor, Yasuo Matsushita, said yesterday that the assets of the failed Yamaichi Securities Company exceeded its liabilities and that the brokerage firm would be able to pay back special loans that it had taken out from the bank, which is Japan's central bank. As of Nov. 23, the Bank of Japan had provided about 760 billion yen ($5.92 billion ) of special loans to Yamaichi.

title: Yanks Are Near Agreement On Making Deal for Davis
description: Although neither the Yankees nor Chili Davis's agents would acknowledge that they had reached agreement on a contract, a person in baseball with knowledge of the negotiations said that it would be an ''upset'' if the designated hitter did not sign with New York in the near future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  XUEREB, JEAN PIERRE
description: XUEREB-Jean Pierre, 65. Died after a valiant struggle with a Parkinson's/Alzheimers disease on November 27 in Rochefort, France. In the 1960's he went to Paris where he joined Olivetti and attained a managerial position and then entered the world of fashion. Seeing opportunities in the U.S., he moved to New York where he was a driving force in the development of Createurs Industriels, a group of designers which included Yves St. Laurent, Issey Miyake, J.C. de Castelbajac, Emmanuel Kahn, Jean Muir, Mark Held and others. A man of dreams and vision, he founded Ensuite, Inc, the company responsible for launching and developing the lingerie trademark Fernando Sanchez. A man of charm, kindness and generosity, a gentleman always, he is survived by his wife Bobbie Sioux and their son Cody, his sons Cyril, Salvator and Emmanuel and their mother Sophie, his brother Marc and wife Minette and his granddaughter Clea.

title: Wine Talk; In Quest of a Restaurant With an Ideal Wine List
description: IN some restaurants, the most important wine list is one the customers never see. It's a blackboard just inside the kitchen, and it directs the staff to ''push the Cotes-du-Rhone'' or ''move the Beaujolais.''

description: Residents of New York and other great metropolises who assume that the glories of their cities will last forever might take a cautionary lesson from this remote provincial outpost.

description: In her first public appearance in New York since her story of rape, abduction and hatred opened deep racial divisions a decade ago, a confident and defiant Tawana Brawley told a roaring audience of supporters last night the same thing she did then: that she had told the truth.

description: Wading into a contentious statewide battle over how best to teach math, the California Board of Education has endorsed a set of standards for elementary- and middle-school students that emphasizes the more traditional drill-and-practice approach over a newer method characterized by complex word problems.

title: State Asks Court to Force Transfer of Fifth Graders

The school district's superintendent has twice defied state officials, who have demanded the pupils' transfer from the Albany Avenue School because of concerns for their safety.

title: Yen Is Lower Still, and Japanese Exports Cheaper

title: In Search of the Ideal Roast Duck
description: THE perfect Chinese duck -- a duck with rich and tender meat and mahogany skin so crisp that it crackles -- is difficult to prepare at home. At least for me it is. Even after a course of intense study with Virginia Lee, the late doyenne of Chinese cooking teachers, I have never mastered the art of perfect roast duck in the Chinese style. Several times, I attempted to make Cantonese roast duck, using the classic procedure, a centuries-old technique.

title: In Emergency, Judge Stalls Two Changes In Rent Laws
description: In an unusual emergency court session held last night in her Upper West Side apartment, a State Supreme Court justice put on hold two of the most bitterly contested changes made by the New York State Legislature during last summer's rent regulations battle.

title: 200 TO LOSE JOBS AS UNIFI SHUTS TWO FACTORIES
description: Unifi Inc. said it would dismiss 200 employees, or 3.5 percent of its work force, when the company closes two yarn factories to cut operating costs. After the job cuts, Unifi will have 5,500 employees, the company said. Unifi, which is based in Greensboro, N. C., said it would close two older yarn plants in Graham and Lincolnton, N.C., by Feb. 1 to concentrate on running its 14 remaining plants more efficiently. Unifi took ownership of the two factories, which make yarns used in socks, women's hosiery and waistbands, when it acquired Spanco Yarns last month. Unifi also makes textured polyester and nylon. The company had revenues of $1.70 billion for the year ended June 29. Its shares rose 18.75 cents yesterday, to $37.75.

title: The Precooked Masterpiece: How Chefs Create Grand Illusions
description: LUNCH at Le Cirque 2000. A blur of courses swings by: oysters, ravioli in a fresh tomato sauce, crab salad -- all simple dishes, prepared minutes before.

title: Hardship Followed Glory for a Champion

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGERLEIDER, PETER
description: UNGERLEIDER-Peter. As a member of the Center for Defense Information (CDI) Board of Advisors, Peter Ungerleider was a trusted counselor and supporter. He was the catalyst encouraging CDI to establish a site on the Internet to make CDI's information available in seconds around the world. This award-winning site is a living memorial to his enthusiastic guidance and keen judgement. CDI's officers, directors and staff extend their heartfelt sympathy to the members of his family. We have lost a good friend.

title: In the Old Neighborhood With: Julie Dash; Home Is Where the Imagination Took Root
description: The garbage was in the same spot, but the Beacon Theater down the street, where her mother took her to see a Brigitte Bardot film in the 1950's, was gone, as was the Loft's candy factory and its delicious perfume. The six-story brown buildings all looked smaller than she remembered, and the fences encircling the neat plots of grass weren't there in the old days.

title: Test Kitchen -- For Cooks, Gifts That Earn Their Keep; An All-Purpose Toaster With an English Accent
description: NO matter how well equipped their kitchens may be, cooks are always happy to be given something new, especially if it's more than a novelty that will be gathering dust by January. Each of the tools here -- some new, some classic -- beg to be used. They are all luxurious but not extravagant; regardless of price, each outperforms the others in its field.

description: A 36-year-old Wildwood man could face the death penalty after being convicted yesterday of murdering a bar patron during a botched robbery at a bar in Wildwood.

description: Missoni, the Milan-based women's fashion designer, is moving its Manhattan store up Madison Avenue from 69th to 78th Street, leaping over an invisible barrier that has kept the pinnacle of Madison haute couture south of 72d Street. And with annual retail rents on Madison below 72d rising to $400 a square foot, many real estate professionals believe more high-fashion boutiques will follow Missoni to its new neighborhood, where the rent is about half.

description: ONCE, only Chinese restaurants delivered. Now, of course, hundreds of places do. The trick is to determine which one you want to come knocking at your door. Here are four laudable places that will deliver, within limits.

title: In Dark Times, Russia's Economic Chief Looks on Bright Side
description: Looking confident and self-possessed, Anatoly B. Chubais, the chief overseer of Russia's economic changes, said today that he had a plan to shore up the country's battered economy and get international loans, currently stalled, back on track.

title: U.S. Links Staying in Bosnia to NATO's Role
description: Hoping to fend off Congressional opposition to a new commitment of American forces in Bosnia, the Clinton Administration is urging its NATO allies to support an expanded international police force that could take over tasks now done by NATO troops.

title: Mr. Freeh's Truth Grenade
description: There was nothing unexpected in Attorney General Janet Reno's refusal yesterday to appoint an independent counsel on the issue of telephone solicitation by President Clinton and Vice President Gore. Indeed, Ms. Reno's choice of such a narrow legal issue guaranteed the outcome she announced. What was unexpected was the dramatic way in which Louis Freeh, the F.B.I. Director, rebelled against her persistent blindness to the conflict of interest this case presents to her and the Justice Department. By doing so, he exposed the emptiness of Ms. Reno's interpretation of the Independent Counsel Act, and practically guaranteed that demands for a counsel will persist, despite her desire to smother them.

title: $25 and Under; Neighborhood Place, Warmed by Hospitality
description: WARMTH and generosity of spirit are what you crave in a neighborhood Italian restaurant, as my friends and I were reminded on a recent cold and windy night. We had just arrived on time for our reservation at Piccolo Angolo, a little Italian restaurant in Greenwich Village, to find a line spilling outside. The people seated on either side of the door stared angrily every time it opened as they were hit with a chilly blast, but that was nothing compared with the freezing glare of the host, who seemed to think it was our fault the restaurant had overbooked.

title: Russian Magazine Deal By Dutch Publisher
description: VNU N.V., a Dutch publisher, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire 35 percent of the shares of Independent Media of Russia by Jan. 1. The financial terms of the share purchase were not disclosed.

title: U.S. Coach's Pact Extended Through Cup
description: As expected, the United States soccer federation yesterday extended Coach Steve Sampson's contract through the 1998 World Cup, while America's possible first-round opponents for next summer's world championship were narrowed.

title: Edwin Rosario Is Dead at 34; Troubled Boxing Champion
description: Edwin (Chapo) Rosario, a three-time world champion boxer whose career inside the ring was marked by brilliance and whose later life outside the ring was marred by drug abuse, died Monday night at his parents' home in Toa Baja, P.R. He was 34.

title: TV Notes; Tree City, U.S.A.
description: A distinctly New York Christmas tradition, the lighting of the tree in Rockefeller Center, will be televised nationwide for the first time this year. Although the live show was reserved for New Yorkers last night on Channel 4, the taped version, sold in syndication by Universal Television, has been snapped up by 89 percent of the nation's stations. (Channel 4 will also rerun it on Dec. 11 at 7 P.M.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LELEIKO, MAX

Our thoughts and prayers are with him and his family.

title: A Death and 4 Injuries As Aerosol Cans Explode
description: A man was killed on Monday and four co-workers were injured after two cardboard boxes containing aerosol cans were crushed in a paper compactor at a recycling plant in Paterson, setting off a fire and an explosion, officials said yesterday.

description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu sent envoys abroad today and telephoned Yasir Arafat to promote the Cabinet's provisional approval of a further withdrawal in the West Bank as an ''important decision.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PACELLA, LOUIS
description: PACELLA-Louis. Although you were not always around, you are always in our hearts. Love from your true family. Marie, Debbie, Corrinda & Louis

title: Places Where Western Palates Go for an Education in Sake
description: TWO red paper lanterns glow in front of Decibel, a sake bar in the East Village. A sign proclaims the name, but the entrance is down a flight of stairs, where there is a door with a peephole. To the left, a sign says PRESS BUTTON . Moments pass, and a Japanese face appears at the peephole, fixes his or her attention on you and invites you in.

title: The Dream Of a Poet For Italy
description: It was an old dream of Joseph Brodsky, the Russian-born poet, American Nobel laureate and Italophile, that Russian scholars, artists and writers should have a chance to live and work in Italy, to draw inspiration from a culture that for half a century lay beyond their reach.

title: Do Good Deeds and Add Them Up, Students Urge
description: A group of students from this city, better known for car thefts and poverty than for civility, is attempting to go national with efforts to perform acts of kindness and justice.

description: * Sawtooth Group, Woodbridge, N.J., acquired MRB Public Relations, North Brunswick, N.J., which was renamed Sawtooth Public Relations. Terms were not disclosed.

title: TV Notes; No Mere Hat Trick
description: The final tally from the November sweeps left the main results intact. CBS won, by virtue of pulling in the most viewers, edging out NBC in that category, with 15.1 million viewers to 14.8 million for NBC.

description: The lawyer for the man accused of murdering 8-year-old Justina Morales urged a Brooklyn jurv yesterday to acquit his client, contending that the girl might not even be dead, but htat if she were, her mother had killed her.

title: By the Book; A Book for Pastry Chefs, And for Amateurs Who Dare
description: YES, you can make strudel dough. And Sacher torte. And Dobos torte. Though a new book, ''The Classic Art of Viennese Pastry'' (Van Nostrand Reinhold, $39.95), was written mainly for professional pastry chefs, its author, Christine Berl, takes the amateur baker by the hand and clearly explains how to prepare these classics.

title: Statement by Reno on Why She Did Not Seek an Independent Counsel
description: Following are remarks today by Attorney General Janet Reno explaining why she chose not to appoint an independent counsel to investigate possible campaign finance violations by high Government officials and her replies to reporters' questions, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company:

title: BRAZILIAN FASTENER MAKER TO BE ACQUIRED BY TEXTRON
description: Textron Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Brazaco Mapri Industrias S.A. of Brazil, a maker of fasteners for the automobile industry, for $70 million. Textron, based in Providence, R.I., makes E-Z-Go golf carts, aircraft, car parts and industrial products, and also provides financial services. The company had sales of $9.3 billion last year. Brazaco, which is based in Sao Paulo, has $100 million in annual sales. Its operations will be combined with Camcar Textron, a division of Textron's fastening-systems unit based in Rockford, Ill., that has annual sales of $1.5 billion. At full capacity, Brazaco can generate $150 million in sales, Textron said.

title: High Court Strikes Down Voting Rules In Louisiana
description: The Supreme Court today struck down Louisiana's method of conducting House and Senate elections, ruling unanimously that the state's unusual open primary violates Federal law by picking a winner a month ahead of what Congress has designated as a nationally uniform November election day.

title: Miles Davis Disciple Evokes Sensuality With a Hint of a Moan
description: Cassandra Wilson's opening concert of a six-night stand at Alice Tully Hall was a mess, but a good-hearted, amiable mess. Ms. Wilson is one of the better things to have happened to jazz in the last part of the century, a singer with an almost violently attractive voice and clearly a natural.

title: School Rightly Curbed Student Speech, State's Highest Court Rules
description: In a case with First Amendment implications, New York's highest court ruled today that high school administrators in Sullivan County acted appropriately when they suspended a senior for distributing articles urging students to urinate in hallways, scrawl graffiti on walls and smoke in bathrooms.

title: Iraq's Innocent Victims
description: The United Nations Security Council is considering whether to let Iraq keep selling limited amounts of oil to buy food and medicine and tend to other humanitarian needs. At first glance, that seems an odd step while Saddam Hussein is still shutting U.N. arms inspectors out of government buildings and palaces where chemical and biological weapons and the means to manufacture them may be housed. Yet these supervised oil sales, conducted under strict monitoring safeguards, make good policy and can ease some of the hardships on the Iraqi people that have accompanied international economic sanctions.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HILTON KRAMER, who wrote an acerbic weekly column in The New York Post lambasting the press for what he deemed excessive liberalism, has been let go by the newspaper.

title: About New York; A City's Heart Seen Through Its Bare Edges
description: LARRY RACIOPPO looks downright calm for a guy who is always on the edge. He finds serenity on the margins of the city -- whether it is among the physical limits on the abandoned waterfront or the temporal boundaries commemorated by spray-painted memorial walls in rundown neighborhoods. They are all secret spaces whose ruins spark rumination and inspire his photographs.

title: The Rap Tao Of Success By Age 26
description: Sean (Puffy) Combs was a rapper, a dancer, a mourner, a preacher, a trash-talking homeboy, a mogul and a ringmaster at Madison Square Garden on Monday night. ''He's a complicated man,'' his backup group sang to introduce him. The 26-year-old Mr. Combs, a k a Puff Daddy, has built a full-service hip-hop empire since 1991 as the chief executive officer of Bad Boy Entertainment, with tough guys, heartthrobs and a bawdy female sex symbol. Beyond his own label, he is a producer with the most consistent commercial touch of 1997. ''Everything's platinum with my name attached,'' he rapped.

title: From Merely Loving Sushi, to Knowing It
description: THE line outside Tomoe Sushi begins to form well before the restaurant opens at 5 P.M. Periodically, an employee pops out the front door and makes sure that the swelling ranks of diners arrange themselves into neat files along Thompson Street in Greenwich Village. At 7 P.M. last Saturday, nearly 30 sushi lovers stood outside the restaurant, resigned to an hour's wait.

title: Metro Business; Stock Offering Is Sluggish
description: U.S. Vision, an optical products and services retailer in Blackwood, N.J., said yesterday that it had sold 2.5 million shares for $22.5 million, or $9 each, in a sluggish initial public offering of stock.

description: Ending an inquiry that has haunted the Clinton Administration for months, Attorney General Janet Reno today rejected the appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate fund-raising telephone calls by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore.

description: Bobby Muller was blown up from the earth by a land mine once and recalls it as a kind of ludicrous tumbling, for he landed uninjured -- propelled off a Vietnamese road by the shock wave, not the shrapnel of the infernal thing.

title: The Chef
description: THE tamarind tree produces a gnarled pod that hides within it a marvelous pulp with a taste reminiscent of sour plums. In various tropical places, it is commonly used in soups or on fish or meat. The rich sourness is so appealing that I wanted to devise my own uses for tamarind pulp, which is readily found in Asian and Hispanic stores and in many produce markets.

title: Decaf Connections
description: When did the men I'm attracted to begin drinking decaf? It seems that only yesterday, these rugged individualists could enjoy a cup of strong coffee -- sometimes even two or three -- and suffer no ill effects. Now, they're all taking antacids and stacking bricks under the headboard to prevent acid reflux.

title: Food Safety Through Irradiation
description: The Food and Drug Administration's decision yesterday to approve the use of irradiation on red meat to kill disease-causing micro-organisms in beef, lamb and pork is an important and overdue step toward improving food safety for consumers. After three years of study, the F.D.A. has concluded that irradiation effectively kills bacteria, such as E. coli and salmonella, but does not make the food radioactive or change its taste, texture or nutritional content.

description: Adell Swiggett begged the two police officers to arrest her husband, saying that he had ransacked her home, violating a court order to stay away from her and the house. But the officers drove off as Anthony Swiggett watched from the house next door. Minutes later, he stabbed his wife to death.

DeBartolo Jr. resigned as chairman of the San Francisco 49ers yesterday amid reports that a Federal grand jury in Louisiana may be close to indicting him along with a former Governor of the state, Edwin E. title: TV Notes; More From Spielberg
description: Steven Spielberg's children's shows ''Animaniacs,'' ''Pinky and the Brain'' and ''Tiny Toon Adventures'' all appear on the WB network, and his ''Toonsylvania'' is scheduled to go on the Fox Kids Network early in 1998. Now Mr. Spielberg is spreading his animated adventures farther afield: This week he and his company, Dreamworks, signed a co-production deal for several series with Nickelodeon, the cable network that is the most-watched network among children.

title: Newsprint Stakes Are Sold
description: Dow Jones & Company and the Washington Post Company said that they have sold their matching 35 percent stakes in two newsprint and timber companies to their partner, Brant-Allen Industries, for a total of $226 million. Dow Jones and Washington Post said that the sales of their interests in the Bear Island Paper Company and the Bear Island Timberlands Company would result in fourth-quarter gains of $28 million. The Bear Island companies produce 225,000 metric tons of newsprint annually and own 130,000 acres of timberland in Virginia.

title: Forgiveness, After 3 Die in Shootings in Kentucky
description: Today, this small town awoke to confront the worst and the best of itself: the bright, relatively unremarkable 14-year-old who fired a .22-caliber semiautomatic pistol into a prayer circle at Heath High School on Monday, wounding eight students, of whom three died, and the football-playing preacher's son who talked him into giving up.

title: Palestinians Free a Critic From Prison
description: After nearly five grueling months in the prisons of the Palestinian Authority, Fateh Sobeh returned last week to his wife and five children, in their home among the sandy alleys and cinder-block dwellings of the Tufah neighborhood of Gaza.

M. Warburg, Pincus & Co. and the General Electric Co., for an undisclosed amount of cash.

description: Staking out what he called a new vision for the Democratic Party, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri tonight portrayed the Clinton Administration and leaders of the party's moderate wing as content to govern with small ideas while neglecting the nation's problems.

title: Class Notes
description: On a chilly fall afternoon, six red traffic cones stood sentry in the schoolyard of Public School 329, a three-story building at the foot of several housing projects on the western tip of Coney Island. On one side, about 20 children in puffy, brightly colored parkas played with balls and a jump rope after lunch. On the other side of the cones was a pristine basketball backboard, donated to the elementary school by Footlocker. No students, however, were driving toward the basket. Like tenacious guards, 100 or so parked cars belonging to the school staff were blocking all access to the hoop.

title: Metro Business; Average Hotel Rate Tops $200 in City
description: The average cost of a hotel room in New York City in September set a record high of $204.19 a night -- the first time ever over $200 -- as the millions of tourists flooding the city allowed hotels to raise their rates, New York City's Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, said in a report yesterday.

title: Sultans Who Swat: D.H.'s Are Well Paid
description: The owners have proposed dumping the designated hitter; the players have said forget about it. The best reason for each side's argument emerged yesterday. The average salary for designated hitters in 1997, as determined by the players association, was $3,583,788, highest for any position in the American League.

title: Cindy Sherman Turns to Movies
description: What is Cindy Sherman trying to get at in ''Office Killer,'' a crude, laugh-free horror spoof about a mousy copy editor named Dorine (Carol Kane), who becomes unhinged when threatened by company downsizing and murders several co-workers? After killing them, Dorine hauls their bodies back to the house she shares with her aged, infirm mother and arranges them in a grisly familial tableau around a basement television set. Once installed in this homemade mortuary, the corpses bear a distant resemblance to the more ghoulish figures in Ms. Sherman's haunting collection of photographs called ''Untitled Film Stills,'' which the Museum of Modern Art has bought for a million dollars.

title: Business Travel; Those who want to attend the Winter Olympics while in Japan had better start making plans.
description: IT'S a good idea to nail down hotel space and tickets for the Winter Olympics now if you want to see the action in the Japanese Alps during a business trip to Tokyo. Though there are still plenty of tickets available, the Games, which run from Feb. 7 until Feb. 22, are only two months away.

title: PATRIOT AMERICAN IN $1.3 BILLION HOTEL DEAL
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc., one of the nation's biggest real estate investment trusts, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $1.3 billion in cash and stock for the Interstate Hotels Corporation, the nation's biggest independent hotel management company. It will also assume $785 million of Interstate debt. With Interstate's 40 owned hotels and 182 leased or managed properties, and after Patriot American's pending $1.1 billion acquisition of the Wyndham Hotel chain, Patriot American's hotel portfolio will total 455 properties with about 103,000 rooms. Patriot American shares fell 75 cents yesterday, to $30.8125.
