description: FIELDS-Edward. Remembered with deep affection on his birthday. The Family

title: QUEBECOR'S UNSOLICITED BID FOR WATMOUGHS IS REJECTED
description: Quebecor Inc., Canada's largest printing company, made an unsolicited bid of $:188.3 million ($316.8 million) yesterday for Watmoughs Holdings P.L.C., which rejected the proposal. Quebecor offered 257 pence for each share. Shares of Watmoughs jumped 92.5 pence, or 47 percent, to 290 pence, suggesting that investors think a higher bid is likely. Sales and profits for Watmoughs, a printing company based in London, have fallen in recent years, pushing its stock to a six-year low. For the Montreal-based Quebecor, the deal would be the third major acquisition this year.

title: Washington to Directly Contribute $5 Billion, at the Low End of Expectations
description: The Clinton Administration said today that it would make as much as $5 billion available for the international bailout of South Korea, hoping to stabilize a country where the United States has considerable economic and security interests.

title: As U.S. Looks On, 120 Nations Sign Treaty Banning Land Mines
description: Declaring a ''victory for humanity,'' leaders from around the world gathered here today to sign a comprehensive ban on the global production and use of the deadliest of land mines.

title: Index Move Lifts Stock
description: The stock of the BB& T Corporation rose 16 percent yesterday after it was disclosed that the company would move to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. BB& T, a savings and loan holding company, was added to the index at the close of trading. It replaced Beverly Enterprises, a nursing home operator in Fort Smith, Ariz. Before the disclosure, shares of BB& T, of Winston-Salem, N.C., rose $8.9375, closing at $65, on the New York Stock Exchange. Stocks that are added to an index like the S.& P. 500 typically get at least a short-term rise in their share price.

title: Mets Fading on Johnson
description: Time and again, Steve Phillips is reminded that the Mets lack attractive commodities for a trade. Following a conversation with the Seattle Mariners yesterday, the Mets' general manager said that he probably can't meet the demands for the star pitcher Randy Johnson.

title: Reno Decision Bares Rifts on Clinton Team
description: Attorney General Janet Reno's refusal to seek an independent prosecutor to investigate fund-raising telephone calls by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore has revealed a surprising fissure of dissent running through her inner circle, Government officials said today.

title: Immigrant Refugees Improve U.S. Quality of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Look to D.C. for Subway Answers
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Now Projects Much Larger Budget Surplus for Fiscal Year
description: The state could end the fiscal year with a surplus of more than $1 billion, Gov. George E. Pataki said this week, nearly double earlier estimates. The surplus would allow him to enter election-year budget negotiations flush with money for popular programs and with little need to make unwelcome cuts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLE, ELAINE. (NEE BROWN)
description: MOLE-Elaine. (Nee Brown) of Summit, New Jersey, November 26, 1997, wife of Harvey E. Mole; mother of Elaine M. Taggart of Summit, NJ, Harvey E. Mole, III, of Tainan, Taiwan, and Matthew C. Mole of Madison, NJ, also survived by eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held Saturday, December 6, 1997, 10:30AM, Calvary Episcopal Church, corner of DeForest and Woodland Avenues, Summit, NJ. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations to one of the following would be appreciated: The Elaine B. Mole Memorial Fund of Calvary Church Chorale or Kent Place School, Elaine B. Mole Memorial Library Fund, both of Summit, New Jersey 07901.

title: INSIDE
description: Images of the Virgin Mary assembled in Newark.

title: Van Gundy Puts the Focus on Execution
description: It seems as if all the psychobabble that has emanated from Coach Jeff Van Gundy has just beaded up on the minds of the Knicks like raindrops.

title: Foreign Affairs; Bibi's Playbook
description: For the past year Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has sent out two messages: (1) I am the only leader in Israel today who can carry the ball over the goal line -- who can produce a stable majority of Israelis for a final peace deal with the Palestinians; and (2) I can't move the ball downfield now because my hard-line coalition won't let me.

title: South Bronx Churches Will Expand Affordable Housing
description: Although she owns a four-story building with a park view, Zoraida Burgos said she has not enjoyed looking out her window in the last 30 years. Too often, her view of St. Mary's Park is marred by prostitutes, gang members, drug dealers and abandoned buildings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANNENBERG, MYRA
description: DANNENBERG-Myra. In her 98th year, on December 3, 1997, residing for the past twenty years at the Alexander Towers, Hollywood, Florida, loving mother and mother-in-law to Richard and Barbara Dannenberg; adored grandmother to Susan J.D. Randoing and Olivier Randoing of Melbourne, Florida, and David Dannenberg of Cincinnati, Ohio; great grandmother of Jason Randoing; adopted grandmother of Catherine Parker; sister of the late Aaron and Joseph Lipper and late Carl Lippert; aunt of Barbara Lipper Heizer and Bennett Lipper. For 28 years, from 1939 to 1967, a successful real estate broker in the Five Towns (Dannenberg Realty, Cedarhurst, New York), for her many customers for whom she found residences. After retiring to Florida, she devoted her early retirement to her husband Edwin, who passed away in 1969. For many years she was active in ballroom dancing. In her last twelve years she was cared for and her life extended by the devoted and loving care of Icolene Edwards, Esmie Carter, and Dorothy Chisholm, angels from the island of Jamaica, to whom the family is most grateful. Private internment at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y. Contributions in her memory may be made to charity of choice or to the Susan Dannenberg Endowment (for financial aid), Duke University, ATT: N. Allison Haltom, Secretary of the University, 215 Allen Building, Box 90030, Durham, N.C. 27708.

title: Currents; PARK OR RIDE -- Aluminum Trike to Bike
description: The aluminum Convert-o-Bike, $295, seen in the Smith & Hawken Christmas catalogue, switches from tricycle to bicycle and looks good in a living room or on a lawn. Does this mean toys in the yard can be garden ornaments? To order: (800) 776-3336.

title: In Akron, Dialogue but Few Changes
description: It is hardly surprising that President Clinton chose this industrial city 50 miles south of Cleveland as the site of his first ''town hall'' meeting on race. For the last three years, Akron has been undertaking the kind of racial dialogue that the President has said he would like to foster nationally.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Paterson Schools Remain Under State Supervision
description: The Paterson school district, which has been under state control since 1991, improved significantly during the last school year but not enough to end the takeover, state officials said yesterday.

title: Thai Reports Loan Renewals
description: About 90 percent of Thailand's $7 billion in foreign-currency loans due in October were renewed by creditors, the central bank's governor said today. The official, Chaiyawat Wibulswasdi, also said Thailand had its first current-account surplus in 11 years in October. The surplus, and some financial transfers, reduced borrowing needs.

title: Currents; THE EASTERN ART OF GETTING THERE -- I. M. Pei Designs the Anti-Getty: An Art Museum Under a Mountain
description: Once a visitor gets to Kyoto, a lot of traveling is still required to reach the Miho, Japan's new art museum, designed by I. M. Pei. It's 20 miles to the winding roads of the town of Shigaraki and the museum's 247-acre site within a nature preserve. Cars are stashed at the Miho's roadside pavilion, and visitors transfer to little electric cars or walk through a mountain tunnel and across a deep gorge via a 400-foot-long cable bridge. (Mr. Pei designed both bridge and tunnel.) The bridge goes to the main plaza, which leads to the museum's glass-roofed interior, 80 percent of which has been painstakingly hidden underground.

title: Campaign Finance Inquiry on 2 Paths
description: Attorney General Janet Reno has insisted that her decision not to seek an independent prosecutor to investigate President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore should not be interpreted as the conclusion to the Justice Department's year-old campaign finance investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISSIN, FLORENCE
description: KISSIN-Florence. On Dec. 3, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Malcolm. Devoted mother of Karen Marshall, Warren, Joel, Robin and Roger Kissin. Loving grandmother of Megan, R.J., Jennifer, Adam, Matthew and Zachary. Dear sister of Syd Liebowitz, Pearly Klass, Dotty Lawrence, Lillian Fersko, Belle Kaufman and the late Morris and Benny Marshall. Services Friday, Dec. 5, 12:30 PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOBERMAN, HERMAN E.
description: HOBERMAN-Herman E. Dear Poppa, always remembering and loving you. Your grandchildren & great grandchildren

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, GRACE INGE IVERSON HOLLIS
description: KATZ-Grace Inge Iverson Hollis. On November 30, 1997 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Born on May 10, 1906 in Floral Park, NY. Devoted wife of the late Bernard Katz. Cherished mother of Joseph Hollis, Jr. (Ann), the late Jay Gordon Hollis, Michael Katz (Maria) and Patricia Goodstein (Martin). Adored and adoring grandmother of Joseph III, Jeffrey, David, Nancy, Michele, Aaron, Max, Geoffrey and Shari. Great Grandmother of Matthew, Michael, Nicholas, Lindsey and Justin. Loving sister of Anne Thomsen and the late Nancy Simonsson. Funeral Services at 3PM on Thursday, December 4th in Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Endicott Peabody, 77, Dies; Governor of Massachusetts in 60's
description: Endicott Peabody, the scion of two old American families who served just one term in a major elective office but ran frequently for others and led a quixotic campaign to elevate the importance of the Vice Presidency, died on Tuesday at his home in Hollis, N.H. He was 77.

title: TECHNOLOGY IN WAITING: A special report.; Long Quest for Safer Food Revisits Radiation Method
description: Five years ago, Harley Everett envisioned a burgeoning industry that would rid meats, fruits and vegetables of harmful bacteria by bathing them briefly in gamma rays. His company built an irradiation plant, tucked away on a dusty road in the phosphate mining town of Mulberry, Fla. But business is hardly thriving.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Former New York Chief Is Hired as a Consultant
description: Jack Maple, the former New York Police Department strategist credited with helping to reduce the city's crime rate, begins a new job today as a consultant for the police in Newark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISHNEW, JACK
description: WISHNEW-Jack. Beloved husband of the late Zelda. Loving father of Warren. Dear grandfather of Steven, Elisabeth and Jill. Great-grandfather of Lindsay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAGER, JOHN W.
description: FAGER-John W. Of Garden City, New York, age 82, on December 2, 1997. Survived by his beloved wife of 56 years, Melva Clark, MD. Distinguished graduate of Colgate University and Harvard Law School. Retired partner of Hughes, Hubbard and Reed. Adored father of John, Diane, Melva and Russell and cherished grandfather of Will, Jessamay, Clark, Joe, Caitlin, Casi & Russell. Services 2PM, Saturday, Dec. 6, the Community Church of Garden City, 245 Stewart Avenue, Garden City. In lieu of flowers donations should be directed to Pat Caprio at Colgate University, Hamilton, New York 13346, in the name of Colgate University/John W. Fager Scholarship Fund.

title: Hijacking the City's Lawyers
description: The recent three-day vacation Rudolph Giuliani took was obviously too short. No sooner had New York City's Mayor returned from his rare weekend off than he resumed his legally wrongheaded and politically frivolous war against the ads for New York magazine that take his name in vain. We suggest he rest longer, and let the city attorneys get back to their real jobs.

title: Prisoner of Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Nanny Accused of Abuse After Child's Father Videotapes Her
description: After hearing that the nanny who was taking care of his 2-year-old daughter had verbally abused the child at a playground, a Long Island father set up a video camera in his home to tape the woman at work.

title: Rise in Auto Sales in November Spurred by Demand for Trucks
description: Auto sales strengthened last month, rising 3.8 percent for the industry as a whole, compared with the similar period a year ago. Strong demand for trucks propelled the sales, which reached a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 15.2 million units in November.

title: Nike Selects Agency For Thai Operation
description: Dentsu Young & Rubicam in Singapore, the joint venture of Dentsu Inc. and Young & Rubicam Inc., said yesterday that it had joined the Nike Inc. agency roster by being awarded the account of a new subsidiary, Nike (Thailand) Ltd. in Bangkok. Billings have not been determined.

title: No Holds Barred, Unfortunately
description: Just before Congress adjourned, the Senate quietly killed a proposal that would have ended a cherished but indefensible senatorial prerogative -- the ability of individual lawmakers to block action on bills and nominations by imposing a secret ''hold.'' The practice has grown beyond control in recent years, with groups of senators collaborating to place a ''revolving hold,'' so that even the majority leader, Trent Lott, can have trouble figuring out exactly which senator is really causing the gridlock.

title: New Publisher for Wired
description: Further scaling back his role in the company he founded five years ago, Louis Rossetto, chairman of Wired Ventures Inc., plans to step down as publisher of Wired magazine. He will be replaced by Dana Lyon, who previously served as the magazine's vice president. Mr. Rossetto said the move, which was unexpected, was ''part of the process of this magazine growing up.'' In July, he said he would relinquish his role as chief executive. Katrina Heron will become the new editor in chief.

title: Pointing The Way to 'Annie Hall' And Beyond
description: Let's be realistic about ''Men of Crisis: The Harvey Wallinger Story,'' the newly resurfaced mock documentary written, directed by and starring Woody Allen as a Kissingeresque aide to Richard M. Nixon. It is not the Rosetta Stone of Woody Allen studies. It is not a lost masterpiece, either. (It wasn't even lost, just neglected for 26 years.)

title: Skis Rossignol Denies Takeover Speculation
description: The shares of Skis Rossignol S.A. closed little changed yesterday after the company said it was not the target of a takeover. Earlier, the shares had jumped 7.9 francs, to 123.9, an eight-week high. The closing price was 117 francs, up 1 franc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, PAUL
description: GILBERT-Paul. The entire staff of the Internal Medicine Associates of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the loss of Dr. Paul Gilbert, the Division Chief of the Section of General Internal Medicine, who passed away suddenly. Recognizing his foresight, creativity, and influence on Internal Medicine Associates and its patients, and remembering his warmth, guidance, and encouragement, we join in offering our condolences to Harriet and the entire family. His memory will not be forgotten. Internal Medicine Associates Staff

title: New Mad Cow Alert
description: Responding to a new report warning that so-called mad cow disease might be carried by beef bones and bone marrow, the British Government has banned the sale of most cuts of beef on the bone, including ribs, T-bone steaks and oxtails.

title: Carquest Bowl Invites Ga. Tech
description: Georgia Tech will play in the Carquest Bowl on Dec. 29 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., the school's first bowl appearance in six years, following a 6-5 season in which four losses were by 4 points or less. Tech's opponent will likely be either West Virginia or Virginia Tech, who are being considered by the Gator Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGIN, MAXWELL, M.D.
description: BOGIN-Maxwell, M.D. December 2, 1997 in Bridgeport, CT. Devoted husband of Edith and beloved father of Deborah and Abby. Funeral Services 12 noon Friday, December 5, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, Park and Capitol Avenues, Bridgeport, CT. Beloved and conscientious physician to thousands of children. Donations may be sent to the Maxwell Bogin, MD Lectures, Bridgeport Hospital Foundation, 267 Grant Street, Bridgeport, CT. 06610.

description: Impressive Ivy Geraniums

title: U.N. Troops to Leave Haiti As Feeble as They Found It
description: When 20,000 American troops landed here in September 1994 to restore the elected President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to power after three years of military dictatorship, they were greeted rapturously. To the average Haitian, the arrival of soldiers and a phalanx of donors promising aid seemed to signal the dawn of a new era of political stability and economic growth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JIN, MORGAN
description: JIN-Morgan. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Morgan Jin associated with The Times from 1967, until retiring in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, HAL
description: ROSENTHAL - Hal. Dearest Mucka, 4 years, my pain will never end. Breaks my heart that you are not here for our twins Zoe and Max and to see how wonderful Jesse has grown up. I know your sons need you and miss you so very much. I'll love you forever. Your Hon, Joy

title: ABLE TELCOM CONSIDERS OFFER FROM APPLIED CELLULAR
description: The Able Telcom Holding Corporation said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer from Applied Cellular Technology Inc. worth $12 a share, or nearly $100 million. Able Telcom, which installs and maintains telecommunications networks, said it would review the offer with its financial advisers and declined to comment further. Shares of Able Telcom rose $1.3125, to $9.6875, while Applied Cellular shares rose 3.125 cents, to $6. Applied Cellular, based in Nixa, Mo., installs and services cellular phone and wireless networks.

title: At Troubled Brookhaven Lab, Priority Now Is Safe Science
description: As the new director of the troubled Brookhaven National Laboratory, Dr. John Marburger is taking inventory and pursuing a new priority: safe, environmentally clean science.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUNKE, VINCENT J.
description: FUNKE-Vincent J. The board of trustees and staff at the Brooklyn Academy of Music sadly mourn the passing of Vincent Funke, BAM's Vice President for Finance and Operations. Vincent was a valued member of the executive staff, and will be truly missed. We wish to extend our sincere condolences to his wife and family. Bruce C. Ratner, Chairman Harvey Lichtenstein, President Brooklyn Academy of Music

title: Market Place; Warner Bros., In Film Slump, Under Scrutiny
description: Warner Brothers, once the most stable and successful studio in Hollywood, is in the grip of a box office slump that has stirred concern on Wall Street, left the movie studio in turmoil and raised questions about the expanding roles of its two bosses, Robert A. Daly and Terry Semel.

title: Isles Can't Recover From Tepid Start
description: Perhaps it's being comfortable with quietude, with performing before crowds so sparse the voices of players and the scrape of skates are clearly audible from the upper deck of the Greensboro Coliseum. The Carolina Hurricanes, last in the National Hockey League in attendance, continued their dominance before small crowds, defeating the Islanders, 5-3, in front of 5,651 tonight.

title: Carolina's New Faces Get Same Old Results
description: The faces change, even the coach's face at the University of North Carolina, but the routine remains the same. Four fingers are raised, another generation operates with precision, and another victory is secured.

description: FORBES-Frances. Of Southport, CT., died December 1, 1997. Funeral services and burial will be private. Donations may be made in her memory to: Norwalk Hosp. Oncology Dept, 34 Maple Street, Norwalk, CT 06856.

title: Hambros Confirms Talks on Sales of Units
description: Hambros P.L.C. confirmed yesterday that it had negotiated with ''a number of companies'' about selling some or all of its banking businesses. Earlier yesterday, Generale Bank N.V., Belgium's largest lender, said it had made preliminary contacts with Hambros. Hambros did not identify any of the suitors but said the talks did not involve its Hambro Countrywide, Hambro Insurance Services or Hambro Group Investments units, or its stake in Guiness Flight Hambro Asset Management Ltd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILCHEK, STELLA
description: WILCHEK-Stella. On December 3, 1997. Beloved wife of the late William Wilchek. Loving sister of William Kullman. Compassionate and committed friend. Many had the benefit of her uncompromising love, wisdom and teaching. She was an active participant in the causes she held dear and the lives of many. Services Friday, 12 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: NEWBRIDGE NETWORKS TO CUT 280 JOBS IN ENTERPRISE UNIT
description: The Newbridge Networks Corporation, a Canadian maker of computer networking products, said yesterday that it would cut 280 jobs, mainly at its UB Networks business. Newbridge said the cuts were the first step in a restructuring of the company's struggling enterprise business, which supplies corporations with local area communications networks. Last month, Newbridge, based in Kanata, Ontario, blamed disappointing results from the enterprise business for a 7.6 percent decline in second-quarter profits. Newbridge said at the time that the company was examining various options to deal with its enterprise business, including the possible sale of UB Networks. Newbridge acquired the unit in January from Tandem Computers.

title: Rangers Put Campbell Back on Hot Seat
description: Suddenly, the season is not so young anymore. It's early December and only three teams in the Eastern Conference have a record worse than the Rangers'. So, Colin Campbell is again answering questions about job security.

title: First Pacific Selling Pacific Link Stake
description: The First Pacific Company agreed yesterday to sell a mobile telephone business to Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd. for $4.84 billion (Hong Kong), or $625.3 million (United States). First Pacific owns 65 percent of the business, Pacific Link Communications Ltd., which is the No. 4 mobile phone service provider in Hong Kong. Hong Kong Telecommunications is No. 1.

title: 2 Prosecutors, State and U.S., Fight Over Plea
description: In a rare public confrontation between the two top prosecutors in New York, aides to Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, went into Federal District Court yesterday and accused Federal prosecutors in Manhattan of trying to take over and damage a major state-run insider trading investigation.

title: After Nearly Winning, Nets Wind Up Demoralized
description: Three chances.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday and one on Aug. 13 about a Palestinian professor who was detained by the Palestinian Authority misspelled his name. He is Fathi Sobh, not Fateh Sobeh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KADIN, THEODORE
description: KADIN-Theodore. Dec. 3, 1997 at home, White Plains, NY. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Loving father of Paul (Marcy) of Short Hills, NJ, Richard (Liz) of Scarsdale, NY. Cherished grandfather of Andy, Michael, Allison and Peter. Services will be held Friday, December 5, 1997, 11:30AM at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, Westchester Avenue, Rye. Interment to follow at Mt. Hope Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Edith Dickstein Cancer Treatment Center, C/O White Plains Hospital Center, Development Office, Davis Avenue, White Plains, N.Y. 10601. Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, New York.

title: Personal Shopper; Gifts, $25 and Under: The Nifty and Neat
description: THIS year, even Scrooge can find gifts for everyone on his list, without having to hit the sales or discount stores. Here are 25 finds for $25 or less. Some are quirky, like tea bags to soothe tired eyes, but others, like a silver-plated card case, are elegant and universally useful, too. (Filled with a Metrocard or a phone card, it will warm the pocket as well as the heart.) And most stores gift-wrap, too.

title: Arguments, and Tirades, Begin in Brawley Defamation Suit
description: Opening arguments in the defamation lawsuit against three former advisers of Tawana Brawley began today amid sharply raised voices, badly frayed tempers and a profound, almost surreal sense of deja vu.

title: Filmmakers Of 'Amistad' Rebut Claim By Novelist
description: With Steven Spielberg's film ''Amistad'' set to open next week, lawyers for the director have filed a set of court documents strongly attacking the credibility of an author who filed a plagiarism suit and tried to halt the film's distribution.

title: Sports of The Times; You Cross The Line, And You Pay
description: THE Golden State Warriors, who understand they cannot get close to equal value for their coach-choking best player anymore, said last night that they were invalidating Latrell Sprewell's contract on a vague moral turpitude clause. They will clear Sprewell from their memory bank and their salary cap. They will go on losing without him.

title: Currents; TAKING COVER -- Toward Warmer Wrists
description: Closure at last for that nasty sleeve-to-glove gap. ''I got cold,'' said K-K Gregory, who invented Wristies -- Polartec tubes with thumb holes -- four years ago at age 10 in Bedford, Mass. She first sold them to her Girl Scout troop. Her ambition: ''Once I become 18, I'd like to run the business and be on the board of directors.'' Available in five sizes and nine colors, they are $5 to $10 a pair from Wristies, (800) 811-8290.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGERLEIDER, PETER
description: UNGERLEIDER-Peter. We have been blessed to work with Peter Ungerleider. His critical analysis, his creative imagination and his commitment to Jewish culture profoundly shaped the Israel Cooperative Program, a partnership of the Dorot and Nathan Cummings Foundations to support pluralism and environmental sustainability in Israel. His spirit will continue to guide our work. Nathan Cummings Foundation

title: In Cambodia, Wars End, But the Dying Continues
description: The smallest rubber foot at the prosthetics center here is a size five. But it is not in high demand; few children survive the blast of a land mine.

title: Alvarez Joins Hernandez as Tampa Opens Vault
description: Expansion money gushed again yesterday. Two days after the Arizona Diamondbacks acquired Matt Williams and signed him to a five-year, $45 million contract extension, the Tampa Bay Devil Rays signed Wilson Alvarez to a five-year, $35 million contract.

title: Pressure On Chaebol:Change Now Or Break Up
description: SEOUL  From the black-suited executives in lavish suites of South Korea's leading conglomerates to the white-shirted salarymen working at the seas of desks on the floors below, the reaction Wednesday to news of the IMF emergency loan was the same: How could a group of foreigners here for just a few days dare challenge all they had fought to build for two generations since the Korean War?

title: Weak Demand Forces Down Copper Prices
description: Copper prices tumbled yesterday as weak demand from Asia and rising mine output pushed stockpiles close to 20-month highs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROFF, FRIEDA
description: OSTROFF-Frieda. The Amalgamated Bank of New York notes with deep sorrow the passing of Frieda Ostroff, activist, leader and beloved wife of our friend, Harold Ostroff. We extend our sympathy to Harold and the Ostroff family. Jay Mazur, Chairman Gabriel P. Caprio, President John J. O'Connor, Executive Vice-President Leonard Maisel, Senior Vice President

title: Japan Grew 0.8% in Quarter, Suggesting a Flat '97 Economy
description: In the latest indication Japan is edging toward full recession, the Government said Wednesday that economic growth totaled less than 1 percent for the third quarter and that the economy would have trouble growing more than 1 percent for the year.

title: A Hit Song Gives a Lift To Others
description: Ann Hampton Callaway recently realized a dream that is a fantasy of virtually every aspiring pop songwriter. A song she wrote 10 years ago, ''At the Same Time'' -- a sort of musical greeting card exhorting global togetherness -- was recorded by Barbra Streisand on ''Higher Ground,'' her new Columbia album of spiritually uplifting songs. In its first week of release, the album entered the pop album chart at No. 1.

title: The South Korean Bailout
description: With South Korea's plummeting currency and rising bankruptcies threatening to spread financial turmoil to Japan, Russia and beyond, Washington wisely added up to $5 billion of its own to yesterday's international bailout of Korea. The $55 billion package, put together by the International Monetary Fund, is large enough to stanch further contagion and presumably comes with strict conditions calculated to keep South Korea out of trouble.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Record $55 Billion Bailout Set for South Korea

title: O'Donnell Gets His Wish: The Pressure
description: With Glenn Foley unlikely to take even one snap in practice this week, Neil O'Donnell has the responsibility he says he has wanted since becoming a Jet: leading the team in December in a big game.

title: Mexican Traffickers Recruiting Killers in the U.S.
description: When authorities examined the corpse of the killer who died in an attack on a prominent Mexican journalist, they found that he had turned much of his body into a menacing homage to death, with dozens of tattoos portraying blood and bones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLGER, HENRY, M.D.
description: DOLGER-Henry, M.D. On Dec. 3, 1997 after a long illness. Adored husband of Laura. Devoted father of Jonathan Dolger and Judith Widmann. Cherished grandfather of Daniel and Kenneth Widmann and Emily Widmann McBurney. Loving father-in-law of Jane Isay Dolger and Roger M. Widmann. Dear brother of William Dolger and Vera Rosen. Friends may call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Thursday 7-9 P.M. Services Friday, Dec. 5, 9:30 AM, Temple Israel, 112 East 75 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Henry Dolger Endowment Fund, Department of Endocrinology, Box 1055, Mount Sinai Hospital, 1 Gustave Levy Place, NYC 10029.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADY, ELLEN
description: BRADY-Ellen. Died December 2, 1997. Loving friend, with a warm loving family. Roslyn Bremer Spielvogel's family will miss your love and sharp sense of humor.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL-PRIME HOSPITALITY 20-HOTEL DEAL
description: The American General Hospitality Corporation agreed yesterday to buy a 20-hotel portfolio from the Prime Hospitality Corporation for $360 million. American General, a real estate investment trust in Dallas, will acquire the portfolio in two phases. First, it will buy nine hotels, valued at $150 million, in New Jersey, Connecticut, New York, Nevada and Oregon. This is expected to close on Dec. 29. In the second phase, it will buy 11 hotels, valued at $210 million, in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, New York and Connecticut. This is expected to close between September 1998 and March 1999. The hotels include a Ramada Inn, Holiday Inn, Crowne Plaza Hotels, Sheraton Hotel, Radisson Hotel and Suite, Four Points Hotel and St. Tropez Suites-franchise affiliations.

title: AST PLANS TO LAY OFF UP TO 37% OF WORK FORCE
description: AST Research Inc. said yesterday that it planned to lay off up to 37 percent of its work force worldwide in an effort to return to profitability. Up to 1,120 employees of AST, now a subsidiary of the Samsung Electronics Company of South Korea, could be laid off under the plan. The reorganization includes a reduction of manufacturing capacity at its Fort Worth plant and a phasing out of its sales operations in Southeast Asia and Australia. AST, a personal computer maker based in Irvine, Calif., is expected to start the first round of layoffs later this month. The remaining layoffs will be phased in over the next several months, eventually reducing AST's work force to 1,900 employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIRGILIO, LUCILLE
description: VIRGILIO-Lucille. December 14, 1917-November 27, 1997. Wife of the late Edward J. Virgilio. Survived by five children: Edward, Fredric (deceased), Peter, Ray (deceased) Martina; six grandchildren: Stephen, Ric, Rachel, Ray, Michelle. Lucille was born in Brooklyn, married Edward in 1938 and raised her five children in Brooklyn and then Queens. She was known for her generosity in many ways, always giving to her family and her community. She had many foster children, was a Den mother, Girl Scout Director and a volunteer worker in New York's Sloan-Kettering Hospital and The Foundling Hospital where she was given the award of ''Woman of the Year''. Her helping and giving did not stop in her later years. Both in East Hampton and Florida she helped many seniors enjoy the day by sharing slides of her world travels. She did this with a detailed narration. She truly enjoyed her six grandchildren, giving them memories to last forever. Ironically some of those memories are wonderful Thanksgiving weekends in East Hampton. Little did we know she would leave us on this 1997 Thanksgiving, but the word ''Thanksgiving'' does describe her perfectly. So if it was her time, the day itself says volumes about her. She will be missed in many ways, by many people, especially her family. Visitation Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 at the Williams Funeral Home of East Hampton, 99 Newtown Lane, East Hampton, NY. Funeral Service Saturday 11 AM Most Holy Trinity RC Church, East Hampton. Interment of cremains following Parish Cemetery.

title: COMPUWARE IS IN $115 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR NUMEGA

Compuware will issue 3.3 million common shares to Numega's stockholders and 900,000 options to current Numega option holders. Shares of Compuware rose $2.125, to $37. Numega, based in Nashua, N.H., has more than 100 employees in the United States and Britain, and performs error detection and debugging services for professional Windows software developers. Compuware, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., is a software developer that has more than 4,600 employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAINER, JOHN
description: TRAINER-John. Trainer, Wortham & Company mourns the passing of our colleague John N. Trainer. Former Chairman of the Board of Trainer, Wortham, prominent member of the financial community of New York and active in civic affairs for fifty years, died on November 30 after a short illness at the Pomperaug Woods Health Center, Southbury, Conn. He was born in New York City, where he attended Horace Mann and Allen Stevenson Schools. He prepared at Phillips Exeter Academy and graduated from Harvard College in 1931. He joined the firm of Trainer and Associates, second oldest investment counseling firm in the United States and became president of Trainer, Wortham & Co., Inc., in 1954. In World War II Mr. Trainer was on active duty from 1941 to 1945 and retired as Commander in the U.S. Naval Reserve in 1951. He was a resident of Mount Kisco for fifty years, where he was board member of the Northern Westchester Hospital & the Boys Club. He was significantly involved in the major expansion of both institutions and received national recognition of the Boys Club of America. He was President of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association of New York and member of the Jesters Club, the Racquet and Tennis Club and Harvard Club of New York City, also the Wianno Yacht Club and the Cruising Club of America. He had a lifelong interest in sailing and was active in the formation of the Sea Education Association, which offers young people seafaring and ocean science programs. After his retirement, Mr. Trainer resided in Southbury, Conn., and Pubnico, Nova Scotia. He is survived by his wife, Alice (Stone) and two sons, John N. Trainer of Nashville, TN., and Edward S. Trainer of Evanston, IL, and by five grandchildren: David Browning, John N. III, Matthew Stone, John Booth & Kirsten Brooke and by his brother Robert Browning Trainer of New York. Memorial services will be held Thursday, December 4, at 1:00 P.M., St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Main Street South, Woodbury, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Boys & Girls Club of Northern Westchester, 351 Main Street, Mount Kisco, New York 10549 or to the Sea Education Association, PO Box 6, Woods Hole, Massachusetts 02543.

title: The Pop Life; Granting Wish Lists For Record Sales

According to Soundscan, a company in Hartsdale, N.Y., that monitors retail sales, 16.1 million records were sold. Not only is this an increase of 2 million records from the week before, but it tops figures from the Thanksgiving period in 1996 and 1995 as well.

He completed a residency in Orthopedic Surgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, a fellowship in surgery of the hand and upper extremities at The New York University Medical Center & was affiliated with The Hospital For Joint Diseases. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSMAN, KAREN HYMAN
description: SUSMAN-Karen Hyman, 55. Of Houston, Texas, died on December 3, 1997 in New York City. Daughter of Dorothy Jean Hyman and the late Paul Hyman of Austin. Karen was born and raised in Austin, where she graduated from Austin High. At the University of Texas, from which she graduated in 1964, she met Stephen D. Susman, and they married in 1965. Once their children began school, Karen entered law school, receiving her J.D. from the University of Houston Law Center in 1981. Karen became board certified as a family law specialist and practiced law in Houston for many years. Karen's great love of contemporary art permeated her life. She was a friend and supporter of many artists and an avid collector. Karen served on the board of Houston's Contemporary Arts Museum and the Yale Art Gallery in New Haven, Connecticut. Karen was deeply devoted to her religion. A member of Congregation Beth Israel, she held leadership positions in many local and national Jewish organizations. Most recently she served as Chair of the Anti-Defamation League's Southwest Region, as a member of the ADL's National Board of Directors, and as a founding director of the National Jewish Democratic Council. Karen was active in politics for many years. Upon learning of her death, President Clinton called Karen's family from Air Force One to express his condolences and tell them how much he had liked and admired her. Karen is survived by her devoted husband Steve; their daughter Stacy, of New York City; their son Harry, of Washington, DC; her mother Dorothy Hyman, of Austin; her brother and sisterin-law Paul and Laura Hyman, of Austin; her brother-in-law and sister-in-law Tommy Susman and Susan Braden, of Washington, DC; and nieces and nephews Tara Susman of New York City, Shana Susman of Los Angeles, Micah Susman of Austin, Daily Susman of Washington, DC, and Amy, Lindsay and Marissa Hyman, all of Austin. In lieu of flowers, Karen's family requests that she be remembered by her many friends through contributions to the ADL Karen Susman Memorial Fund, 4635 Southwest Freeway, Suite 400, Houston, Texas 77027. A funeral service will be held at Congregation Beth Israel, 5600 North Braeswood in Houston at 11:00 AM on Sunday, December 7. Burial will follow at Beth Israel Cemetery, 1101 Antoine. The pallbearers will be Scott Atlas, Russell Deutsch, Parker Folse, Lee Godfrey, Marc Grossberg, Gary Jacobs, Terry Oxford, and Tommy Susman.

title: SINGER SAYS IT WILL DISMISS 28% OF ITS WORKERS
description: Hurt by the weak economies of Southeast Asia, the Singer Company named a new chief executive yesterday and said it would close some plants and dismiss 5,968 workers, or 28 percent of its labor force. Singer, which makes sewing machines and other household products, will take a charge in the fourth quarter of $186 million. The company, which is based in Hong Kong and trades on the New York Stock Exchange, named Stephen H. Goodman as chief executive and president. Mr. Goodman, 53, had been a managing director in corporate strategy at the Bankers Trust New York Corporation. Singer plans to shift sewing-machine manufacturing to lower-cost areas. Singer's shares rose $1.296875 yesterday, to $13.984375.

title: From Sacred to Silly: Chestnuts Roasting on the CD Player
description: Christmas albums start to trickle out around Labor Day, are flowing steadily by October and turn into a deluge in November. Like the season, the albums offer comfort and glitz, raw commercial ambition and good intentions, novelties and would-be traditions. Stars, past and present, make Christmas albums or contribute songs to compilations; some unknowns try Christmas music to get noticed. In a music business dedicated to niche marketing, seasonal albums provide sonic accessories for every attitude an executive or musician can imagine: sentimental or cynical, awestruck or earthy, aggressive or hushed. Old carols bear up under interpretations from bluegrass to punk rock; new songs aim for a quick laugh or for heartwarming durability. On this page, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times dig into the giant pile of this year's seasonal album releases to find the most noteworthy ones. (Compact disks range in price from $15.99 to $18.)

The case raises the question of what a marital partnership means.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a planned recycling plant in the Bronx designed by the architect Maya Lin misstated the location of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, which she also designed. It is on the Mall in Washington, not at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: SPLIT COURT BACKS PATAKI'S DECISION IN A CAPITAL CASE
description: Though deeply divided, New York's highest court today upheld Gov. George E. Pataki's right to remove the Bronx District Attorney from a murder case because of the prosecutor's opposition to the death penalty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYSON, JOHN J.
description: TYSON-John J. Friends of John Tyson wish to announce his demise on December 2. A memorial service will be held on Saturday December 5 at 2pm at St Peter's Episcopal Church, 346 West 20th St. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the John Tyson Memorial Foundation, C/O AmFAR, 733 Third Avenue, NY, NY 10017.

title: In West Bank, 'Time' for Settlements Is Clearly Not 'Out'
description: If there is any serious talk of a ''timeout'' in settlement construction, it sure hasn't reached Ofra. On one hillside, 27 houses stand in various stages of completion, while bulldozers shift boulders on another hill to make room for 24 more.

title: Atlantic City and State Battling on Crowded Schools
description: When H. Benjamin Williams became the Superintendent of Schools here last spring, he expected to contend with crumbling buildings, jam-packed classrooms and some of the lowest-achieving students in New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a proposed purchase of the radio and television stations of Max Media Properties by the Sinclair Broadcast Group misstated the number of stations involved. The deal is for nine television stations and eight radio stations -- not two stations.

title: Governors I. Urged as Site For a Casino
description: After spending more than a year trying to determine how to make use of the Federal Government's offer to turn over Governors Island to the city, a top Giuliani administration official said yesterday that it was exploring the possibility of using part of it for ''a major casino and five-star hotel.''

title: German Growth Slowed in Third Quarter
description: German economic growth slowed slightly in the third quarter but continued to benefit from surging exports, which outweighed weak consumer demand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAYER, DR. RICHARD W.
description: SCHAYER-Dr. Richard W. Of Spring Valley, N.Y. died at Good Samaritan Hospital, Suffern, N.Y. He was 82. Dr. Schayer earned a Doctorate in Biochemistry from Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Before his graduate studies, he was a professional trombonist in the Army Band and served in the Infantry from 1940-1945. He reached the rank of Captain. He was the President of the International Histamine Society for many years. His contributions to brain histamine research earned him a Medicine Doctorem Causa, an honorary medical doctorate, in 1975 from the Karolinska Institute in Sweden. The award was given in the name of Carol XVI Gustav, King of Sweden. Dr. Schayer served as Principal Biochemist for 19 years at the Nathan Kline Institute, Orangeburg, N.Y. He was the first honorary member of the Polish Academy of Science. He is survived by his wife Lillian, a daughter Paula Schayer Garrett of Houston, a son Richard Eric Schayer of New York City and a grandson Matthew Joseph Garrett. Memorial contributions may be made to the First Unitarian Society, Concklin Rd., Pomona, New York 10970.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOCK, IRENE
description: BOCK-Irene. On December 4, 1997. Mother of Marilyn Sittner and Debbie Nochella. Grandmother of six. Great-grandmother of five. Visitation on Friday from 3-5 and 7-9 P.M., at Fairchild's, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset. Religious services Friday 8 P.M. Funeral Saturday 9:15 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHMELA, DOROTHY (NEE ROANTREE)
description: CHMELA-Dorothy (nee Roantree). A former librarian, died of multiple myeloma on December 2 at her home in Larchmont, NY. She will be remembered for her devotion to friends, her love of animals, especially Honey and Pussycat, her warmth, enthusiasm, and smiling good humor despite a most difficult life.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When STAN FISCHLER was a reporter on the transportation beat for The New York Journal-American, he wanted to do an article on ELLEN HART, Miss Subways of March-April 1959. His editor turned down the idea, and Mr. Fischler never did get to meet Miss Subways -- now ELLEN HART STRUM, a restaurateur -- until Wednesday evening.

title: Differences Between President and Top House Democrat Deepen After a Speech by Gephardt
description: It sounds like children playing, badly, in a sandbox. But the venues are the White House and the United States Congress. And the combatants are President Clinton and the top House Democrat, Representative Richard A. Gephardt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENENSON, SYLVIA
description: BENENSON-Sylvia. December 4, 1997. Loving and loved wife of the late Charles. Cherished mother of Abbe Franklin and Walter Benenson and wonderful Bobby to four grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. We will miss you. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., (at 81 St.), Fri. 7-9 PM and Sat. 4-6PM. with service Sunday 11:30 AM.

title: The Modes of a Pianist, Wild and Thoughtful
description: The brilliant young pianist Yefim Bronfman has shown no lack of enterprise in his rapidly developing career. When last encountered, in the spring, he was presenting a series of concerts at Alice Tully Hall devoted to a seemingly odd couple of composers, Schumann and Prokofiev, with thoroughly engaging results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLSTEIN, MALVINE
description: BERLSTEIN - Malvine. Died peacefully December 3, at the age of 101. Wife of the late Alfred. Beloved mother of George and daughter-in-law, Sandy. Devoted grandmother of Ann Berlstein and husband, David Peck, Jim Berlstein and wife, Chaya, and Ted Berlstein. Great-grandmother of Adam and Elana Peck and Griffin Berlstein. Service Friday, December 5, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paintings and Photos With Tales to Tell, Often About the Oddities of Growing Up
description: Several young artists are making strong impressions in SoHo, in solo and group shows so near one another that it's hard to look at one without thinking of the others. Of course, these artists share more than local geography. They are all women, their work is figurative and it often involves self-portraiture. It also gives pride of place to narrative, frequently of a coming-of-age variety that may make use of familiar children's tales. In each case, there is a noticeable display of traditional skill and even beauty, words that are more and more in use these days.

title: U.S. Urges Prompt Action On Nazi Gold
description: At the close of the first major international conference on the Nazi gold affair, the United States sought today to increase pressure for having compensation paid to hundreds of thousands of aging Holocaust survivors during the next two years.

title: Japan Car Deal Pressed by U.S.
description: The Clinton Administration complained today that Japan was not honoring a 1995 automotive trade agreement and requested intensified efforts by Japan to open its market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENHOLTZ, MILTON J.
description: SCHOENHOLTZ-Milton J. Passed away Wednesday, December 3. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle and brotherin-law. Services today at the Louis Hirsch & Sons Chapel, 1225 Jerome Avenue (corner 167th Street, Bronx) with burial to follow at the Old Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, Queens.

title: Productivity Strong, Although Revised
description: Worker productivity during the third quarter grew more slowly than previously estimated but still increased at the best rate in five years, the Labor Department said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  XELOWSKI, MARY LOUISE
description: XELOWSKI-Mary Louise. Born in Chicago, Illinois on August 11, 1912, died November 30, 1997 in San Jose, California. Daughter of the late Thaddeus Zigmund Xelowski and Lina May (Bliss) Xelowski. She attended Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, 1931-32 and Loyola University-Chicago, PhD. 1935, M.A. 1941. Senior social worker at Chicago Relief Administration, 1936-40; psychiatric social worker, Guidance Center, New Orleans, 1943-46; supervisor Catholic Charities Guidance Institute, New York, 1946-69; director and supervisor of Three Schools Project, New York, 1949-58; supervisor of casework child care for Catholic Charities, New York, 1958-61; Director of Social Service at Community Mental Health Center of Staten Island, New York, 1961-1982. Patron of the Arts-active supporter of the Opera Guild of New York, Metropolitan Museum, Wagner Society, Tucker Foundation, Opera Orchestra of New York, Opera Index, Opera Manhattan, photographer of the Prima Donnas of the New York Metropolitan Opera. Beloved sister of the late Thaddeus Zigmund Xelowski, Jr. Beloved aunt of Judith Xelowski of San Jose, CA, Jeanne Xelowski Smith of Buffalo Grove, IL, Joanie Xelowski Vrbanic of Oro Valley, AZ, Jamie Xelowski of South Lake Tahoe, CA, Tom Xelowski of La Jolla, CA, Jan Porges of Phoenix, AZ, Tracey Xelowski of Chicago, IL, Julie Xelowski of Tucson, AZ, Jacqueline Xelowski of Tucson, AZ and Terry Xelowski of Chandler, AZ. Beloved greataunt of Brie Arnette of Reno, NV, Timothy Alston and Christopher Alston of San Jose, CA, Daniel Redline of Berkeley, CA, Kenneth Redline of Sacramento, CA, Jennifer Campbell of South Lake Tahoe, CA, Nigel Vrbanic and Damion Vrbanic of Oro Valley, AZ, James Porges of Phoenix, AZ, Christina Burns and Sarah Burns of Tucson, AZ, Mark Wright of Tucson, AZ, Stephanie Xelowski and Todd Xelowski of Chandler, AZ. Services will be held at Bethel Lutheran Church, 10181 Finch Avenue, Cupertino CA, Dec. 6, 1997 at 11:00 AM. A memorial service will also be held at Jean Baptiste Church, 184 East 76th Street, New York, NY on December 17, 1997 at 11:00 AM. Interment will be at Calvary Cemetery in Evanston, IL.

title: Before the Flowers Fade: The Eden of Childhood
description: On the subject of children, even a curmudgeon who sides with Scrooge and W. C. Fields could be stirred a little by ''Fair and Free: Images of Childhood, 1824-1992.'' Taking a frankly approving approach to an unneutral topic, this pleasant if minor (no pun intended) winter show at the National Academy Museum presents some 65 views of the blissful stage of life before pimples, hormones and guilt.

title: At the Creation, a Tender Adam as Eve's Rescuer
description: When Eiko and Koma presented the world premiere of ''River'' in 1995, they immersed themselves in the Delaware River. But when it received its New York premiere on Wednesday night, the Japanese-born dancers performed in shallow water on the stage of the Majestic Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: BOSTON PROPERTIES FILES TO SELL 14 MILLION MORE SHARES
description: Boston Properties Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 14 million additional common shares. The Boston-based real estate investment trust, one of the largest owners and developers of office properties in the United States, expects the stock sale to raise about $441.1 million, according to a registration statement filed yesterday. The sale would increase the number of Boston Properties shares outstanding by about 36 percent, to 52.69 million. It plans to devote some of the proceeds toward the acquisition of Riverfront Plaza in Richmond. Boston Properties, whose chairman is Mortimer Zuckerman, said yesterday that it was buying Riverfront from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for about $174 million.

title: Rare Teamwork, For Education
description: Executives at rival studios rarely work together. Talent agents, who are often at war with one another, barely speak. And movie and television stars usually reside in a peculiarly stratified and isolated world that rarely seems to collide with real life.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology and Design; Kicking Digital Tires On Cars of Tomorrow
description: CHANGE comes ever more quickly to the auto industry. Spurred by intense competition and the need to develop models fast, before fickle tastes change and existing products grow stale, auto makers have turned to computer technologies that help bring all-new vehicles to market in as little as 28 months, compared with up to 39 months in 1993 and 60 months in 1990.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORO, JACK E.
description: FLORO-Jack E. Of Wantagh, LI, Dec. 3, 1997. Beloved husband of Jeanne Anne. Devoted father of J. Douglas and Allan. Loving grandfather of Christopher, Matthew, Nicole, Elizabeth, Joshua and Andrew. Dear brother of Patty Mehl and Gene Floro. Reposing at the Wantagh Abbey Funeral Home, corner of Park Avenue and Beech Street, Wantagh, Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Religious service Sunday, 8 PM. Burial private.

description: LOGOTHETIS-Mingo V. Roslyn, NY, Dec. 3, 1997. Beloved husband of Marie, loving father of Karen L. Dissinger (Phillip) and Nancy Logothetis, dear grandfather of Kathryn M. Dissinger, dear brother of Vasiliki Papadimitriou. Visiting Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM, Whitting Funeral Home, Inc., Glen Head, NY. Contributions may be made to St. Francis Hospital or American Diabetes Assoc.

description: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC., Cincinnati, said its Rich's/Lazarus/Goldsmith unit planned to close five stores in Pennsylvania and Ohio and cut 385 jobs.

title: TV Weekend; In Old West, It's Blacks Vs. Indians
description: In a brutally explicit opening sequence, Indian children are being hanged by Texas Rangers, one by one, because the adults will not lead them to the Apache warrior Victorio. From a distance, the United States cavalry rides to the Indians' rescue. Gradually the riders come close enough for viewers to see that the unit is composed entirely of black men. When Danny Glover, as Sgt. Washington Wyatt, arrests the Rangers, he momentarily turns race relations in the Old West upside down.

title: Memo From Moscow; When Yeltsin Talks, Nobody Listens (Aides Hope)
description: First, he named Japan as one of the world's nuclear superpowers. The Japanese have no nukes. Then he stunned his aides at a meeting in Stockholm by announcing -- without a word to any of them -- that Russia would disarm unilaterally. There are no such plans.

description: The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission has accused KPMG Peat Marwick, the major accounting firm, of violating Federal securities laws by auditing a company that was being managed by a KPMG consultant.

title: Neighborhood Favorites
description: The local hangout has become a cliche, ''where everybody knows your name,'' but that doesn't make such places less important to the life of a neighborhood. Here are a dozen such places, reflecting many different kinds of New York neighborhoods. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGERLEIDER, PETER
description: UNGERLEIDER - Peter. The Pardes Institute of Jewish Studies in Jerusalem and the American Pardes Foundation mourn the passing of Peter Ungerleider who supported the study of the great classics of our tradition by the finest graduates of American universities within a context of free inquiry and diversity. As President of the Dorot Foundation, he continued the tradition of his late mother, Joy Gottesman UngerleiderMayerson. Condolences from Zion to his family. Rabbi Danny Landes, Director Moshe Werthan, Chairman Pardes Institute of Jewish Studies Selig Sacks, Chairman Rae Janvey, Executive Director The American Pardes Foundation

title: Investigators Press Search For 2 Sought In Tax Case
description: Two men accused of helping to promote a tax evasion scheme that so far has led to the arrest of 88 current and former city employees have failed to surrender as promised, and investigators widened their search for the men yesterday.

title: Adelma Grenier Simmons, 93, Authority on Herbs, Is Dead
description: Adelma Grenier Simmons, the author of dozens of books on herbs, died on Wednesday at her home on the Caprilands Herb Farm in Coventry, Conn., which she founded in 1929 and developed into a teaching center and a business. She was 93.

title: Lawmakers to Establish Panel on Auto Insurance
description: Some New Jersey residents may think that the State Legislature has done enough talking about auto insurance rates, which are among the highest in the nation. Nevertheless, the State Assembly gave final approval yesterday to a resolution establishing a committee to -- you guessed it -- discuss ways to lower insurance premiums.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Restores Bus Ads With Mayor's Name
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan cleared the way yesterday for New York magazine to resume its bus-advertising campaign lampooning Rudolph W. Giuliani as a self-aggrandizing Mayor who wants credit for everything good about the city. Within hours, the ads that have piqued Mr. Giuliani were back on the buses.

description: WECHSLER-Philip. SCORE Chapter 1000 mourns the passing of our counselor Philip Wechsler. As Vice Chairman and organizer of our workshops, Philip rendered great service to the small business community. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his family. Ivan Szanto, Chairman

title: Kanell's Cavalier Style Is Put Aside in Practice
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers not only toppled the Giants last weekend, but they also knocked the smile off the face of the Giants' happy-go-lucky quarterback, Danny Kanell.

title: Dispute Escalates Between 2 Top Prosecutors in Manhattan
description: In the escalating dispute between the two top prosecutors in Manhattan, senior aides to Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, yesterday accused Federal prosecutors of pursuing a major insider trading case only after the District Attorney's office had first brought public charges.

title: Judge Rules Jersey City Must Remove Displays
description: Reversing a ruling he made two years ago, a Federal judge decided Tuesday that Jersey City cannot display a menorah and creche in front of City Hall, even if they are flanked by plastic figures of Santa Claus and Frosty the Snowman.

title: The Eye of Fate
description: Did New Yorkers look completely different 50 years ago than they do today? Where have those kinds of faces gone? These are questions that come to mind while walking through the exhibition of Weegee's photographs now showing at the International Center of Photography's midtown gallery.

title: Was It An Unfair Penalty?
description: The termination of Latrell Sprewell's $32 million contract with Golden State and his one-year suspension from the National Basketball Association sent shivers through some of the league's players today.

title: A Specter Of Dickens In a World Of Hustlers
description: One sure sign that you've entered the kingdom of movie hokum is when the characters start portentously blathering on about their dreams. And in Seth Michael Donsky's confused adaptation of ''Oliver Twist,'' updated to the New York demimonde of male street hustlers and drug addicts, there is no end of icky philosophizing. One character even gives another an actual container in which to hold his dream for safekeeping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, DR. WALLACE L.
description: JONES-Dr. Wallace L. Former CEO of Consortium for Graduate Study in Management, died Dec. 2nd at his home in Chillicothe, Ohio at the age of 63 from a sudden heart attack. Dr. Jones served CGSM for 30 years before retiring in January 1997. He is survived by three brothers, Lloyd D. Jones, Omer A. Jones and Beecher A. Jones; and a host of other family and friends. Funeral services will be held Monday, December 8th, at Zion Baptist Church in Chillicothe. In lieu of flowers donations to the Wallace L. Jones Fellowship Fund can be sent to CGSM, 200 South Hanley Road, Suite 1102, St. Louis, Missouri 63105.

title: Records Undercut Waiver for Arlington Grave
description: Congressional investigators said today that they could find no evidence that the late Ambassador to Switzerland, M. Larry Lawrence, served in the United States merchant marine or was wounded in a torpedo attack on a ship in World War II. The wartime injury and his ambassadorship were cited as the primary reasons special permission was granted to bury Mr. Lawrence at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Reno to Withhold Freeh Memo From House
description: Setting up a showdown with Republican lawmakers, Attorney General Janet Reno insisted tonight that she would not let a House committee see a confidential memorandum in which the F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh, argued in vain for the appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate campaign fund-raising abuses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPROW, MOLLIE
description: KAPROW-Mollie. Dec. 4, 1997. Beloved wife of Jack. Devoted mother of Bryna (Alan) and Mark (Inez). Loving sister of Esther, Fred, Pearl and Abe. Cherished grandmother of Paul, Benjamin, Daniel and Shira. Services Friday, 12 Noon, at ''Gutterman's, Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Nelson, Back As a Coach, Beats Knicks
description: The Knicks appeared distracted by the tanned, well-rested gentleman roaming the Dallas Mavericks' sideline.

title: Spelling Out Foreign Policy In Street Signs
description: ONLY in New York'' can be such a dreary cliche, but it may apply in this case. Where else do human rights issues and international incidents get wrapped up in something as prosaic as putting up a street sign?

title: Advocacy Groups Offer 'Awards'
description: Advertisers including the Sprint Corporation and the Anheuser-Busch Companies were among those singled out for criticism yesterday when the Center for Science in the Public Interest presented its 13th annual Harlan Page Hubbard Lemon Awards. The ''awards,'' which are designated by a group of national consumer, environmental and health advocacy organizations, mock marketers for advertisements that are considered misleading. They are named for Harlan Page Hubbard, a 19th-century adman.

description: As the year draws to a close, Christmas and Hanukkah do not seem to be foremost in the thoughts of people on Wall Street. They are jousting over money, their own money.

description: MCNAMEE-Margaret Ellen. The people of Tishman Realty and Construction Co, Inc. mourn the loss of our respected and dear colleague, Margaret McNamee, and extend our sincere sympathy to her parents, sisters, and family. She was totally dedicated to helping people in her position of Benefits Manager, had a wonderful sense of humor, and was a humanist in every sense of the word. We will miss her deeply.

title: Sculpture In a Movie Leads to Suit

description: WILCHEK-Stella. On December 3, 1997. Beloved wife of the late William Wilchek. Loving sister of William Kullman. Compassionate and committed friend. Services Friday, 12 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL TO BUY AUTO LEASING OPERATION
description: The Associates First Capital Corporation, one of the largest finance companies in the United States, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the commercial auto fleet leasing operation of the AT&T Capital Corporation, to expand its existing fleet management unit. Terms were not disclosed. The acquisition adds about $334 million in receivables to Associates First. AT&T Capital owns the fourth-largest commercial auto fleet leasing operation in Canada, which is a new auto fleet management market for Associates. AT&T Capital provides consumer and commercial financing, leasing and related services through 2,223 offices in the United States and internationally.

title: U.S. Banks Still Face Risk, But Bailout Eases Pressure
description: South Korea's rescue package orchestrated by the International Monetary Fund removes an enormous weight from some of the largest American banks, which could have suffered heavy losses if borrowers had failed to repay loans.

description: PRINCE CHARLES had an unexpected reunion in London yesterday with a prep school classmate he had not seen in four decades, and it was an enlightening encounter for both of them, The Evening Standard of London reported.

title: Bungled JonBenet Case Bursts a City's Majesty
description: A quarter of a century ago, as antiwar protests convulsed this college town, voters first elected an amiable criminal defense lawyer to be prosecutor for what some Coloradans called ''the People's Republic of Boulder.''

Things happen; the refurbishment wasn't completed on time. But the museum decided to go ahead with the show, and that was a smart idea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LE FEVRE, WILLIAM M.
description: Le FEVRE-William M. December 4th, 1997. Beloved husband of Mathilda B. Le Fevre. Devoted father of Maria Le Fevre Keidel, Jeanne Van Vlandren, William M. Le Fevre, III and Suzanne Goldman. Loving grandfather of Caitlin and Christopher Keidel. Family will receive friends today 3-5 and 7-9PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Service on Saturday, 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Beth Israel Hospital, Milton and Carol Petrie Division, 1st Avenue at 16th Street, NY, NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREUHOLD, KERSTIN M. (KRIS)
description: TREUHOLD-Kerstin M. (Kris). Dec. 4, 1997. Beloved wife of Charles, mother of Robert and grandmother of Christine Treuhold; sister of Barbro Wenngren & Inger Hanson. Memorial service Thursday, December 11, 4:30PM, Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave, 81 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Publicis-True North battle heats up as lawsuits are supplemented by plans for a hostile takeover.
description: THE slow-motion takeover battle that has embroiled two giant agency companies for a month gained momentum yesterday as one, Publicis S. A. in Paris, announced plans for a hostile tender offer to gain control of the other, True North Communications in Chicago.

title: Man Guilty in Death of Girl School Aides Did Not Miss
description: The former boyfriend of Justina Morales's mother was convicted of manslaughter yesterday in the death of the 8-year-old girl, whose 1995 killing went unreported for 13 months as school administrators failed to detect her absence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODRIGUEZ, EDWARD
description: RODRIGUEZ-Edward. Of 349 W. 85 St., NYC, passed away suddenly Dec. 3 at age 46. A warm, caring and loving man, he leaves behind his devoted wife Lucia Bennett, mother Carmen, sisters Maria, Nora, and Sandra, brothers Norbert and Tito. He will be sorely missed by his extended family of nieces, nephews, brothers and sisters-inlaw as well as many fine friends and co-workers. All are invited to a memorial mass on Saturday, December 6, at 7:30 PM, at Holy Trinity Church, 213 West 82nd Street (between Broadway and Amsterdam). Goodbye, my love.

title: Planet Hollywood Signs for Times Sq. Hotel and Restaurant
description: Despite last-minute problems and the high drama that has come to characterize the development of a resurgent Times Square, Planet Hollywood closed a deal on Wednesday to move its flagship restaurant to Broadway and build a 50-story hotel with a movie-star theme.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLGER, HENRY, M.D.
description: DOLGER-Henry, M.D. On Dec. 3, 1997 after a long illness. Adored husband of Laura. Devoted father of Jonathan Dolger and Judith Widmann. Cherished grandfather of Daniel and Kenneth Widmann and Emily Widmann McBurney. Loving father-in-law of Jane Isay Dolger and Roger M. Widmann. Dear brother of William Dolger and Vera Rosen. Friends may call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Thursday 7-9 P.M. Services Friday, Dec. 5, 9:30 AM, Temple Israel, 112 East 75 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Henry Dolger Endowment Fund, Department of Endocrinology, Box 1055, Mount Sinai Hospital, 1 Gustave Levy Place, NYC 10029.

description: In an interview about the campaign finance storm that has enveloped him for nearly a year, Vice President Al Gore made no concessions that he had made mistakes in raising campaign money or how he handled the political accusations against him.

title: CITIZENS BANCSHARES AGREES TO BUY CENTURY FINANCIAL
description: Citizens Bancshares Inc. said late on Wednesday that it would buy the Century Financial Corporation for about $140 million in stock as it expands in Pennsylvania. Century's shareholders would receive 0.425 share of Citizens for each Century share. That values Century at $26.56 a share. Citizens Bancshares' stock was unchanged at $62.50 yesterday. Century Financial rose 43.75 cents, to $25. Century, based in Rochester, Pa., operates 13 banking offices, 12 in Beaver County and one in Butler County. Citizens, based in Salineville, Ohio, is a $1.1 billion bank and the parent of Freedom Financial Life Insurance, Freedom Express, Citizens Banking and First National Bank of Chester.

title: A Microsoft Browser Deal With @Home
description: The Microsoft Corporation appeared to have won another skirmish in the World Wide Web browser wars, announcing today that @Home Network would develop special versions of its software to work with @Home's cable-based Internet services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PISTO, BERNADETTE
description: PISTO-Bernadette. December 2, 1997. Survived by her loving husband Jerry Liddell, her brother Jim, her sister Donna. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held Monday, December 8th at the United Nations Chapel, 44th and 1st Avenue, NYC, 2PM. The family request that no flowers be sent. In lieu of, donations may be made in her honor to the National Alliance of Breast Cancer Organizations, 9 East 37 St, New York, NY 10016.

title: The Missing Modernization
description: Since I was released from a Chinese prison a few weeks ago, I have heard the same statement over and over. ''At least in China's special situation,'' people say to me, ''there's no need for democracy in order for modernization to be realized.''

description: The National Basketball Association suspended Latrell Sprewell of the Golden State Warriors for one year without pay yesterday, three days after the 27-year-old All-Star guard physically assaulted his coach, P. J. Carlesimo.

title: Joseph Kahn, 84, Reporter for Post
description: Joseph Kahn, who won awards for reporting at The New York Post, died on Tuesday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in Manhattan, where he had lived for three years. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANNENBERG, MYRA
description: DANNENBERG-Myra. In her 98th year, on December 3, 1997, residing for the past twenty years at the Alexander Towers, Hollywood, Florida, loving mother and mother-in-law to Richard and Barbara Dannenberg; adored grandmother to Susan J.D. Randoing and Olivier Randoing of Melbourne, Florida, and David Dannenberg of Cincinnati, Ohio; great grandmother of Jason Randoing; adopted grandmother of Catherine Parker; sister of the late Aaron and Joseph Lipper and late Carl Lippert; aunt of Barbara Lipper Heizer and Bennett Lipper. For 28 years, from 1939 to 1967, a successful real estate broker in the Five Towns (Dannenberg Realty, Cedarhurst, New York), for her many customers for whom she found residences. After retiring to Florida, she devoted her early retirement to her husband Edwin, who passed away in 1969. For many years she was active in ballroom dancing. In her last twelve years she was cared for and her life extended by the devoted and loving care of Icolene Edwards, Esmie Carter, and Dorothy Chisholm, angels from the island of Jamaica, to whom the family is most grateful. Private internment at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y. Contributions in her memory may be made to charity of choice or to the Susan Dannenberg Endowment (for financial aid), Duke University, ATT: N. Allison Haltom, Secretary of the University, 215 Allen Building, Box 90030, Durham, N.C. 27708.

title: An Evening of Informality and Grand Romantic Gestures
description: The Festival Chamber Music Society was started in the late 1980's by Ruth Sommers, an enterprising cellist who has assembled a roster of fairly well-known chamber players, and presents a handful of programs at Merkin Concert Hall every season. By marketing the concerts to alumni associations and school groups, Ms. Sommers is able to fill the house, and her practice of having the musicians introduce each work with amusing but generally informative commentary gives the evenings an inviting informality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAHL, NORMAN, MD.
description: STAHL-Norman, MD. It is with heartfelt sadness the New York Kerato-Refractive Society records the passing of our recent esteemed past President and Charter Member as well as past president of The New York Intra-Ocular Lens Society. Norman, an early pioneer in Refractive Surgery, leaves us a legacy of unqualified courage, strength and dedication. We wish Carol and Adam, Tonya and Addison our deepest sympathy and love. Sol Liebowitz, MD Acting President NY KeratoRefractive Society

title: Williams Not Going
description: George Steinbrenner said yesterday that he expected center fielder Bernie Williams to be in the Yankee lineup next season, while dismissing the notion of any imminent trade and showing little hurry in meeting with Williams, something Steinbrenner has said he might do to end the deadlock in negotiations on a long-term deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEREDITH, ERLENE
description: MEREDITH-Erlene. Wife of Metropolitan Opera Baritone, Morley Meredith, of Scarsdale, New York. Died of cancer at St. Agnes Hospital on December 3, 1997. Born in Winston-Salem, NC. She graduated from Greensboro College and later obtained her M.A. at Columbia University. Upon graduation she was engaged as an executive with the Barbizon Corporation for three years before deciding to join her husband in his operatic career. During Mr. Meredith's stay of thirty-one years at the Met, she proudly boasted that she had never missed one of his performances. An ardent and enthusiastic booster of the opera company, she was famous for the colorful and exciting gala parties she hosted for artists and friends. Mrs. Meredith was also active as a founding member of the AGMA Relief Fund and affiliated with Parkinson Disease Foundation. A memorial service will be held at a later date. She is survived by her husband and brother O.P. Greene of Blaine, WA.

description: Christmas albums start to trickle out around Labor Day, are flowing steadily by October and turn into a deluge in November. Like the season, the albums offer comfort and glitz, raw commercial ambition and good intentions, novelties and would-be traditions. Stars, past and present, make Christmas albums or contribute songs to compilations; some unknowns try Christmas music to get noticed. In a music business dedicated to niche marketing, seasonal albums provide sonic accessories for every attitude an executive or musician can imagine: sentimental or cynical, awestruck or earthy, aggressive or hushed. Old carols bear up under interpretations from bluegrass to punk rock; new songs aim for a quick laugh or for heartwarming durability. On this page, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times dig into the giant pile of this year's seasonal album releases to find the most noteworthy ones. (Compact disks range in price from $15.99 to $18.)

title: PHELPS DODGE BEGINS TENDER OFFER FOR COBRE MINING
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation said yesterday that it had begun a formal tender offer for the Cobre Mining Company, valued at $105 million. Phelps Dodge, a Phoenix mining concern, said it was offering $3.85 a common share and 10 cents each for series A and B stock warrants. The offer, which will expire on Feb. 3, is conditional on shareholders' tendering at least 90 percent of Cobre Mining shares and warrants. Cobre Mining's assets include the Continental Mine and its surrounding 11,000 acres in southwestern New Mexico. The land is next to Phelps Dodge's Chino Mines. Cobre Mining, based in Albuquerque, N.M., had sales of $56.1 million for the first nine months of 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIMAN, DR. SILVIA
description: HEIMAN-Dr. Silvia. Died peacefully Thursday, December 4, in her 88th year. Born in 1910 in the Austro-Hungarian empire, she earned her M.D. degree in Vienna in 1936. Along with her husband, the late Dr. Marcel Heiman, she left Vienna in 1938, eventually settling in New York in 1944. She began a psychotherapy practice in 1950 that continued until one year ago. She was an unfailing source of care, support, and advice to patients, friends, and family, particularly Peter, Marsha, Mark, and Erica Heiman. A memorial will take place at a later date.
