title: NINE WEST SAYS EARNINGS WILL FALL SHORT OF FORECASTS
description: Nine West Group Inc. said late yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings would be 35 to 40 cents a share, well below analysts' forecasts. Nine West, which is based in Stamford, Conn., makes and sells women's shoes and accessories. It was expected to earn 56 cents a share in the quarter ending Jan. 31, according to analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc. Earnings of Nine West have been reduced by its mistiming of fashion footwear trends, weak demand for products, shipping problems and weakness in the Asian economy, where it operates stores. The company also said third-quarter earnings fell 2 percent to $34.6 million, or 95 cents a share, for the quarter ended Nov. 1, from $35.3 million, or 96 cents, in the period a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, HENRY C.
description: BERNSTEIN-Henry C. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Henry C. Bernstein, cherished father, beloved husband, cham pion of Jewish causes. His dedication to those who needed help was as passionate as his devotion to communal service. From 1942-1970, he served with distinction as executive vice president of United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, a forerunner of UJAFederation. To his son, Dr. Alan Bernstein, and his entire family, we send our deepest sympathies. May you be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: SOUTHTRUST TO BUY 27 MORE HOME SAVINGS BRANCHES
description: The Southtrust Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the remaining 27 Florida branches from a unit of H. F. Ahmanson & Company for $300 million. The branches, which have deposits of $3.4 billion, are part of H. F. Ahmanson's Home Savings of America unit. Ahmanson operated 39 branches in Florida until June, when Southtrust acquired 12 branches with deposits of $974 million. Southtrust, based in Birmingham, Ala., is a bank holding company. After the deal closes, it expects to have $10 billion of deposits in Florida. Southtrust's shares rose $1.4375 yesterday, to $58.6875. Ahmanson, based in Irwindale, Calif., gained $1.1875, to $63.3125.

title: Winnie Mandela's Shame
description: In perhaps the saddest testimony yet heard by South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, 30 people have given evidence of serious crimes, including several murders, allegedly condoned or ordered by Winnie Madikizela-Mandela. While virtually every victim's statement to the commission has been heartbreaking, there is special sorrow in credible testimony that a hero of the anti-apartheid struggle used her power against her own people.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Katana was a tiny and exquisite restaurant in SoHo that served kaiseki cuisine, the most rarefied food in Japan. title: Logarithms and Biorhythms Test a Young Janitor
description: Everybody loves a Cinderella story and ''Good Will Hunting'' has two of them: one on screen and one behind the scenes. That's why this film's single sweetest moment comes during its opening titles, as the new stars and old friends Ben Affleck and Matt Damon walk proudly toward the camera while their writing credit appears. Two young actors with soaring reputations have written themselves a smart and touching screenplay, then seen it directed with style, shrewdness and clarity by Gus Van Sant. There couldn't be a better choice than the unsentimental Mr. Van Sant for material like this.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRALEM, PIERRE
description: STRALEM-Pierre, 88. Born on October 17, 1911, in Chappaqua, N.Y., died Wednesday, December 3, 1997, in Houston, TX. Mr. Stralem attended Princeton University where he recently attended his 65th reunion, class of 1932. He was a longtime supporter of the George Junior Republic, Inc. of Freeville, N.Y., Kips Bay Boys' Club, Inc. of Bronx, N.Y. and Newcastle Historical Society, Inc., Chappaqua, New York. Mr. Stralem was an investment banker, member of the New York Stock Exchange and partner of the former Moseley, Estabrook & Hallgarten, Co. He was preceded in death by wife, Nancy Lou Stralem and sister, Marjorie Stralem Schwob. Survived by nieces, Anne-Marie Stehlin, Paris, France and Diane H. Strong, Houston, TX; great-nieces and nephews, Marc P. Stehlin, Paris, France, Gregory I. Strong, Dallas, TX., Penelope Strong-Ellis, Arlington, TX., Hilary Strong-Purcell and Andrew L. Strong, both of Houston, TX; eight great - great - grandnephews and nieces. Private services will be held. title: A Plan to Stop Video Shortages
description: Will you be able to lay your hands on that hot new title this weekend? Video renters may not be aware of it, but when they find stores all out of ''Face/Off'' or other big current releases, the shortage is more or less by design. It's not that dealers enjoy depriving people. Let's just say that prices made them do it.

title: Curbs on Ads For Tobacco Gain in Council
description: After making last-minute changes to toughen penalties against tobacco companies, two City Council committees unanimously approved a bill yesterday that would ban outdoor cigarette advertising within 1,000 feet of schools and playgrounds.

title: If Characters Complain, Who Needs More Critics?
description: For nearly 30 years now, Richard Foreman has built a career on inexplicable and nonsensical plays staged mostly by his Ontological-Hysteric Theater. It was disconcerting, then, to open the program to his latest concoction, ''Pearls for Pigs,'' and find that Mr. Foreman had written notes purporting to explain what actually happens in the 80 minutes of traffic on the stage.

title: Market Place; Wincing at an Asia crisis tactic, S.E.C. backs fund 'fair pricing.'
description: A SURPRISINGLY large number of investors used mutual funds to speculate on short-term swings in the Asian markets during market turmoil in October, the mutual fund industry's chief regulator said yesterday.

title: Cancer Rate Reported High In Eastern L.I.
description: Breast cancer rates on the East End of Long Island, an area including the Hamptons and the semirural North Fork, are significantly higher than in other parts of Long Island and the state, according to figures released today.

title: Winnie Mandela Is Defiant, Calling Accusations 'Lunacy'
description: A defiant Winnie Madikizela-Mandela testified for more than 10 hours today, dismissing all evidence that she had ordered murders and taken part in beatings in the late 1980's as ''lunacy'' and ''ridiculous lies.''

title: Excerpts From Appeals Court Opinions
description: Following are excerpts from the Court of Appeals decision yesterday upholding the removal of the Bronx District Attorney from a death penalty case. Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye wrote the majority opinion; Judges Vito J. Titone and George Bundy Smith wrote dissents.

title: From Sacred to Silly: Chestnuts Roasting on the CD Player
description: Christmas albums start to trickle out around Labor Day, are flowing steadily by October and turn into a deluge in November. Like the season, the albums offer comfort and glitz, raw commercial ambition and good intentions, novelties and would-be traditions. Stars, past and present, make Christmas albums or contribute songs to compilations; some unknowns try Christmas music to get noticed. In a music business dedicated to niche marketing, seasonal albums provide sonic accessories for every attitude an executive or musician can imagine: sentimental or cynical, awestruck or earthy, aggressive or hushed. Old carols bear up under interpretations from bluegrass to punk rock; new songs aim for a quick laugh or for heartwarming durability. On this page, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times dig into the giant pile of this year's seasonal album releases to find the most noteworthy ones. (Compact disks range in price from $15.99 to $18.)

description: Returning Via the East . . .

title: Residential Real Estate; Market Brings a Lift to a Town-House Development in Queens
description: A town-house community in an affluent section of Queens that struggled to get started during the recession has received a lift from New York City's strengthening housing market.

title: Newark Catholic Church Is Damaged in Explosion
description: One of the largest churches in Newark was damaged on Wednesday when an explosion set off a fire that burned for about an hour, city fire officials said yesterday.

title: National News Briefs; Analysis Shows Chips Are Not From Stolen Art
description: Federal authorities said last night that paint chips said to be from two Rembrandt paintings stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston in 1990 were ''not what they purport to be.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STECHER, HON. MARTIN B.
description: STECHER-Hon. Martin B. On December 4, 1997. Devoted husband of Judith Stolitzky Stecher. Beloved father to Jamie and Esta, and Joseph and Lizbeth. Adored grandfather to Michael, Emily and Ryan. Loving uncle to Jo and Madelaine. Brother of the late Phillip Stecher, brother-in-law of Hermine Brucker and Bernice Stecher. For nearly thirty years, a model judge on the State Supreme Court and the New York City Civil Court. Services at The Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Friday, 11:15AM. Contributions may be made to the West End Synagogue, New York University Medical Center or Lenox Hill Hospital, all of which sustained him spiritually and physically.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAWFORD, MICHAEL ROBERT
description: CRAWFORD - Michael Robert. Born December 5, 1943. Youngest ever Deputy Director of Indian Affairs in Maine. Co-Director of TRIBE, an experimental program in Indian education. Consultant to the New England Equal Education Center, the Boston Public Schools and the Ford Foundation. Worked with the American Indian Community House and many other community-based organizations in New York. A passionate advocate for Native Americans, he worked on the Land Claims Project and many other projects to improve housing, education and the standard of living for Native Americans. Husband, father, grandfather and loyal friend. Teacher, fighter, champion, and hero to many. Your flame continues to burn within us, Mike-and your inspiration will never die. Funeral on Saturday, December 6, 1997, Church of the Ascension, 5th Avenue and 10th Street, New York City, 2 PM.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jose Bedia

title: Talking About Race in Akron
description: Candid discussions about race are difficult even in intimate settings among well-acquainted people. For that reason alone, President Clinton's national town meeting on race, held in Akron, Ohio, on Wednesday evening, was an important contribution to the national debate. The discussion lacked focus and spark, but the President showed courage, skill and persistence in probing the most problematic social issue of the day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELFER, MAX
description: HELFER-Max. Beloved husband of Rose. Cherished father of Steve, Jerry, Eileen and Allen I. Scherl. Adored grandfather of Brett, Lindsay and Todd Mitchell, Alexis and Jason Scherl. Former owner of Chelsea and Signature Sportswear. Funeral services today, 2 PM, ''Schwartz Bros,'' 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills, New York.

title: This Time, Another Anne Confronts Life In the Attic
description: To see Natalie Portman on the stage of the Music Box Theater is to understand what Proust meant when he spoke of girls in flower. Ms. Portman, a film actress making her Broadway debut, is only 16, and despite her precocious resume, she gives off a pure rosebud freshness that can't be faked. There is ineffable grace in her awkwardness, and her very skin seems to glow with the promise of miraculous transformations.

title: Metro Business; Executives Upbeat About New Jersey
description: In a survey released yesterday, small-business owners in New Jersey said they were optimistic about the state economy, with more than half of them saying they expected sales and profits to rise next year.

title: Slumping Rangers See Flyers as a Test
description: The Rangers are host to the Philadelphia Flyers on Friday night, and it will be a critical game in Wayne Gretzky's view. But Gretzky said it should be a critical test for the players, not for Coach Colin Campbell.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The snakes of Washington beware. The snake eater has arrived.''

title: Britain Presses U.S. for Pledge On Bosnia G.I.'s
description: Meeting with Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen here, Britain's Defense Minister, George Robertson, chided the Clinton Administration today for so far refusing to commit American troops to Bosnia beyond the middle of next year.

title: Abortions Fell Again in 1995, U.S. Says, but Rose in Some Areas Last Year
description: The number of women having abortions has declined steadily since 1990, a Federal agency said yesterday, but some state figures show that, for reasons as yet unknown, the numbers began rising last year in many parts of the country.

title: A Desirous Queen, Toasting Reggae
description: In reggae's commercial heyday 20 years ago, its female artists occupied a delicate position. They were the queens, majestic and maternal, who spoke for feminine strength and virtue. Yet they were also second-comers, making money from versions of American hits while their male counterparts were lionized as originals.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a fund-raising effort to create fellowships for Russians at the American Academy in Rome as a tribute to the poet and Nobel laureate Joseph Brodsky misstated the month of his death and the nature of his interment in Venice. It was January 1996, not April. He was not cremated.

title: Honda Is No. 2 in Japan
description: For the first time in its 49-year history, the Honda Motor Company can claim to be Japan's second-largest auto maker after the Toyota Motor Corporation. Last month, Honda overtook the Nissan Motor Company to sell more vehicles in Japan. Honda sold 74,706 autos in its domestic market in November, 4.3 percent more than Nissan's 71,593 units, according to figures released today.

title: Discount Stores Helped Fuel Strong November Retail Sales
description: American shoppers sent a resounding message to retailers last month that they were mostly interested in things offered cheaply, upholding a sentiment that has dominated the holiday selling season for the last few years.

title: Royal Opera Chairman Resigns After Criticism
description: The chairman of the board of the Royal Opera House resigned today, the day after Parliament issued a scathing report attacking the opera house management and calling for the immediate departure of its board and its chief executive.

title: SOCCER: It's a Draw: Politics Aside, the Pieces Fall in Place; Group Hug? Doubtful When It's U.S.-Iran
description: The most intriguing first-round opponent for the United States in the 1998 World Cup has little to do with sport and everything to do with politics.

title: Rights Group Assails U.S. on Land Mines and Ties With China
description: The Clinton Administration was accused of arrogance and ''active obstruction'' today in its policies toward international human rights in the annual report of Human Rights Watch.

title: Devils Shut Down Penguins
description: DEVILS 4, PENGUINS 0

title: From Capote's First Novel, the Murky Ambiguity of Southern Gothic
description: ''Other Voices, Other Rooms,'' David Rocksavage's intensely moody screen adaptation of Truman Capote's first novel, is steeped in such a heady atmosphere of Southern Gothic ruination that by the end of the film you've begun to share its narrator's uneasy sense of being trapped in a decaying rural paradise that is really a prison.

title: Manhattan's Late Rally Topples the League Favorite
description: Picked by the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference coaches to win the title for the third year in a row, Iona seemingly would have little trouble with a Manhattan team chosen to finish eighth in the 10-team league.

title: 201, Pioneer Area Code, Covers Less Area
description: When it comes to seniority among the nation's area codes, perched gloriously at the top of the heap is not the cherished 212 of Manhattan or the quintessentially bureaucratic 202 of Washington but the industrious yet noble 201 of northern New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARROW, MERCURY MARC
description: BARROW-Mercury Marc. Brilliant musician and artist died suddenly on December 3, 1997. The loss of such a profound and good human being leaves an empty space in the hearts of his mother, sister, daughters, Kiara and Kalia, and in the rest of the family and friends. He will be missed. Memorial services to be announced later.

title: S.E.C. Title Game Has Bowdens Interested
description: Terry Bowden has a chance to get an ideal early Christmas present for his father. Not to mention himself.

title: 16 Evicted as City Closes Building It Calls a Firetrap
description: The Brooklyn building was a hunting ground for rats, not to mention dangerous -- the stairs were rotting, the wiring exposed, the fire escape a ladder to nowhere. But for 15 adults and one child it was still home, something they now lack after being abruptly evicted by the city this week.

title: Terms of Bailout Vague on How Reluctant Koreans Will Enforce It
description: Details of South Korea's record bailout agreement released today depict a broad and bold attempt to reform the world's 11th-largest economy, but the agreement also contains vague provisions that are raising doubts about how it will be enforced.

title: For New York Landlords, Eviction Can Be Costly
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawrence Perkins, 90, Architect Who Loved Building Schools
description: Lawrence B. Perkins, a prolific architect whose firm, Perkins & Will, grew into one of the nation's largest practices, died on Wednesday at Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 90 and lived in Evanston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, MARGARET (NEE MCNAMARA)
description: DALY-Margaret (nee McNamara). Native of Scarriff Co. Clare, Ireland. On December 4, 1997. Wife of the late John. Mother of William Daly and Brigid Ryan. Grandmother of Kerry, Heather and Thomas. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Sunday and Monday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joan of Arc Church, Jackson Heights, New York, on Tuesday, December 9 at 11 AM.

title: Quietly, Jones Has Remained Both Healthy And Productive
description: His coach likes to knock on wood and worries about black cats crossing in front of him. Perhaps some of Bill Parcells's superstitions have rubbed off on Marvin Jones.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Munich Re and Allianz Discussing Stock Swap
description: Munich Re, the world's largest reinsurer, said yesterday that it was in talks with the German insurer Allianz A.G. about a possible share swap as a tax hedge for both.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, JOSEPH L.
description: MENDELSON-Joseph L. The faculty, administration and board of directors of the Jewish Theological Seminary record with sorrow the passing of Joseph L. Mendelson. An honorary and former long-time board member and a member of the Seminary's Society of Fellows, he was a staunch JTS supporter. He and his late wife, Martha, endowed the Joseph and Martha Mendelson Professorship in American Jewish History and they underwrote the creation of the Seminary's Mendelson Convocation Center. He was active in local affairs and at Adas Israel Congregation in Washington, D.C., where he worshipped and will be sorely missed by his community. May his memory be for a blessing. Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman

title: The Rangers Tie Again, But This Time It's Good
description: With a league-high 10 ties in 30 games, the Rangers can start sorting their deadlocks into the good, bad and ugly. Last night's 4-4 result with the Philadelphia Flyers at Madison Square Garden will be classified as one of their best. After falling behind by 4-1 midway into the second period, they rallied in entertaining fashion, riding the roar of the crowd as if they were surfing a big wave.

title: To the Needy, Prime Cuts; Venison Donated by Hunters Is Filling Extra Plates
description: The morning phone calls were coming in steadily at the Fishkill Food Pantry. On the line now was Mary Klump, who was fighting cancer, was out of work and had two hungry children. She needed groceries.

title: About New York; His Daughter Has Santa's Job On Her List
description: PASSING through Herald Square recently, Apryl Rivera ducked into Macy's and squeezed through the crowds waiting to visit Santa. She once hoped they would be lined up to see her, and not as Mrs. Santa. Forget about cookies and aprons -- Ms. Rivera is Ms. Santa Claus, the old guy's liberated daughter.

title: Financial Details Are Revealed In Affirmative Action Settlement
description: The civil rights groups that paid most of the settlement in an affirmative action case against the Piscataway Board of Education made the money available four days before the case was settled, a lawyer for the school board said today.

title: As Older Cuban Exiles Die, Young Pragmatists Emerge
description: At least once a week as he has done for the past 36 years, Andres Nazario-Sargen, head of the Cuban exile organization Alpha 66, goes to a paramilitary training camp where members dress in camouflage and train with semiautomatic weapons for the day Cuba erupts into armed insurrection against Fidel Castro.

title: Morgenthau v. White
description: With a rich array of criminals to go after, you would think that the two leading prosecutors in New York City had better things to do than engage in a nasty turf battle. But this week Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney, muscled her way into an insider trading case that had already been developed by Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney. The result was a disservice to the public. By seizing the case after Mr. Morgenthau had already gotten an indictment and then striking a plea bargain with the defendant, Ms. White disrupted Mr. Morgenthau's efforts to crack down on securities fraud.

title: Swiss Banks Pay First War Account Claims
description: With pressure growing to pay billions of dollars in a comprehensive settlement of their disputes with Holocaust survivors, Swiss banks announced today that they had begun to pay claims to dormant accounts dating back to World War II.

title: Adult Video Store Vows A Court Fight to Operate
description: A new adult video store was shut down by North Plainfield officials Thursday, but it reopened yesterday in defiance of the order, and its lawyer vowed to take the borough to court.

title: Student, 16, Is Stabbed In a Brawl in the Subway
description: A 16-year-old high school student was stabbed in an after-school brawl on a subway platform in lower Manhattan yesterday, and four other teen-agers were arrested, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KADIN, THEODORE
description: KADIN-Theodore. The Board & Staff of Common Cents extend heartfelt condolences to Paul Kadin and his family on the passing of his beloved father Theodore Kadin. He was a true friend.

title: A Good Fit Is Starting to Pinch; Nine West Tries to Fend Off Investigations and Debt
description: Jerome Fisher and Vincent Camuto founded their shoe company in 1977 on a simple but brilliant idea: spot the hottest designs on the fashion runways and quickly make the shoes affordable for the middle-class masses by manufacturing them in Brazil.

title: Hong Kong Journal; New Lesson for Students: Use the Mother Tongue
description: A simple letter, flimsy on translucent fax paper, shook the beige tile walls of St. Louis Secondary School this week, and those of 23 other high schools in Hong Kong.

title: Split Over Poorer Countries' Role Puts Cloud on Global-Warming Talks
description: Elements of a possible agreement on cutting industrialized countries' emissions of heat-trapping waste gases have begun to emerge from intensive negotiations here, and today it was widely believed that the countries could reach agreement on this central issue next week.

title: Plenty of Tritium
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROFF, FRIEDA
description: OSTROFF-Frieda. The Board and Management of The National Cooperative Business Association, previously known as The Cooperative League of the U.S.A., deeply mourn the passing away of a great cooperator, a person who dedicated her life to helping others less fortunate without regard to national origin, skin color or religious belief. Our heartfelt condolences to Harold, our past Chairman, and the entire family. Russ Notar, President & CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERESS, BERNSTEIN, ELSIE
description: PERESS-BERNSTEIN-Elsie. December 3, 1904-December 4, 1997. Adored wife of Murray, beloved mother of Maurice and Herbert, cherished grandmother of Tamara, Lorca, Mark, Paul, Anika and Hunter, loving great-grandmother of Nicole, and dearest mother-inlaw and grandmother-in-law to Ellen, Bruce, Leonard and Teresa. Funeral service at the Park Avenue Synagogue, Madison Avenue and 87th St, this Sunday morning (December 7) at 10:30.

title: For Survivor's Story, End Is Amazing, Too
description: ''So many wonders,'' mused Edith Hahn in Netanya, Israel. A former Jewish law student in Vienna who survived Hitler's Germany by assuming an Aryan identity and marrying a Nazi, Ms. Hahn had a new wonder to ponder yesterday. A collection of personal papers documenting her astonishing wartime escapes and loves sold at auction in London for $169,250, almost five times the top estimate by Sotheby's.

title: Ex-Gloucester Coroner Is Sentenced to Probation
description: A former Gloucester County coroner who was convicted in October of tampering with a witness in a criminal investigation against him was sentenced yesterday to two years of probation.

title: Parents Still Called Suspects In Death of Beauty Princess
description: Almost one year after the killing of JonBenet Ramsey, the new commander of the police investigation said today that the little girl's parents remain under ''an umbrella of suspicion.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STECHER, MARTIN B.
description: STECHER-Martin B. On December 4, 1997. Devoted husband of Judith Stolitzky Stecher. Beloved father to Jamie and Esta, and Joseph and Lizbeth. Adored grandfather to Michael, Emily and Ryan. Loving uncle to Jo and Madelaine. Brother of the late Phillip Stecher, brother-in-law of Hermine Brucker and Bernice Stecher. For nearly thirty years, a model judge on the State Supreme Court and the New York City Civil Court. Contributions may be made to the West End Synagogue, New York University Medical Center or Lenox Hill Hospital, all of which sustained him spiritually and physically.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAISON, JOHN WILLIAMS
description: FAISON-John Williams. On December 5, 1997, in his 80th year. Beloved husband of Grace Gray Faison. Devoted father of Sandy Faison and Jeff Stockly Faison. Dear brother of Seth Shepard Faison, Sr. Adored grandfather of Jeneve Noel Pendleton, John Richard Faison, Jeffrey Shepard Faison, Molly Remsen Brush and Lucy Gray Brush. Memorial service onTuesday, December 9, 11 AM, at Plymouth Church of The Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn Heights. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, or the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, 285 Schermerhorn St., Brooklyn, NY 11217.

title: S.& P. 500 Hits a High; Dow Finishes Ahead 98.97
description: Stocks surged yesterday, with the Standard & Poor's index of 500 issues closing at a high in a rally that was largely led by technology and oil shares.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Thursday with an article about European efforts to reduce emissions of heat-trapping ''greenhouse'' gases showed erroneous figures for per capita emissions of carbon dioxide in the United States and Europe in 1995. A corrected chart appears today on page A10.

title: Computers Won't Make Students Antisocial
description: To the Editor:

title: Complex Bargaining On Global Warming
description: There was optimism at the global-warming talks in Kyoto that industrial countries might reach an agreement next week setting targets and timetables for the central issue of cutting their emissions of heat-trapping waste gases. Pieces of an agreement ''are beginning to take shape,'' an American negotiator said.

title: School Buses to Try a Soybean Fuel
description: At the Haines School in Medford, N.J., students can glance out the window at several hundred acres of soybeans across the street. Soybeans are the leading field crop in New Jersey, surpassing corn, wheat, hay and potatoes.

title: Kodak Is Loser In Trade Ruling On Fuji Dispute
description: The World Trade Organization stunned the United States and the Eastman Kodak Company yesterday by vindicating Japan in a protracted dispute over whether the Japanese unfairly protect their photographic film market.

title: Turmoil in the Subcontinent
description: Four months after celebrating the 50th anniversary of their independence and partition, India and Pakistan are in political chaos. India's third Government in the last two years has collapsed, forcing new elections. In Pakistan, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has won a constitutional battle with the President and supreme court chief justice, but he had to get the army's support to prevail. The common theme in both countries is that their political leaders are not yet accustomed to sharing power with others in a system of constitutionally protected checks and balances.

title: Markets Feel Minor Impact From Job Data
description: The stock and bond markets broke with convention yesterday, as they both shrugged off unexpectedly strong November employment data.

title: A Spirited 'Elijah' Emerges Under Masur's Baton
description: Some of Kurt Masur's transplants in his six and a half seasons at the New York Philharmonic have taken better than others, and from the outset, Mendelssohn has thrived in his hands. If there is a more rewarding place than Avery Fisher Hall to hear this composer's music today, it can only be the Leipzig Gewandhaus, Mendelssohn's, and Mr. Masur's, old haunt.

title: Dublin Says It Might Drop Claim to North in Future
description: Prime Minister Bertie Ahern said today that the Irish Republic was prepared eventually to drop its constitutional claim to sovereignty in the British province of Northern Ireland.

title: Hard Questions on Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico's Vulnerable Workers
description: When Congress debated the North American Free Trade Agreement, President Clinton won over some critics by including a side agreement that guarantees labor rights in Mexico, including the right of workers to choose their own unions. But the struggle for a free union at a Tijuana, Mexico, plant that makes truck chassis for Hyundai Precision America in San Diego shows that the agreement is little more than cosmetic. Three workers dismissed from the plant for organizing a union election are now in their 16th day of a hunger strike, hoping to persuade Mexico's Government to recognize the independent union the workers selected.

title: SUMITOMO STUDIES SALE OF ITS CALIFORNIA BANK
description: Sumitomo Bank Ltd. is considering selling Sumitomo Bank of California, the state's fifth-largest bank, and has retained Goldman, Sachs & Company and several other companies as advisers, the bank said yesterday in a statement. Makiko Tanaka, a spokeswoman for Sumitomo in Tokyo, declined to say whether Sumitomo had actually entered into negotiations. Sumitomo is Japan's second-largest bank, with assets of $426 billion as of March. Sumitomo's possible sale of its United States operations, which was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal, is the first sign of a Japanese retreat from the California banking market -- a state in which the third- and fourth-largest banks are also owned by Japanese institutions. Sumitomo Bank of California has assets of $5.2 billion.

title: Defendant's Age at Issue In the Killing of a Cabby
description: A defendant's age remained a central issue as two young women were arraigned yesterday on second-degree murder charges in the killing of a livery cab driver during a robbery attempt last month in East Harlem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARK, SEYMOUR
description: MARK-Seymour. Beloved husband of Arleen. Devoted father of Amy and Robert. Cherished grandfather of Devon, Jordan, Bryan and Alex. Services Sunday, 2PM at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREUHOLD, KERSTIN M. (KRIS)
description: TREUHOLD-Kerstin M. (Kris). The directors, officers, friends and colleagues of Arnhold and S. Bleichroeder, Inc., mourn the passing of Kris Treuhold. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Chuck, son Robert and all members of her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENENSON, SYLVIA
description: BENENSON-Sylvia. December 4, 1997. Loving and loved wife of the late Charles. Cherished mother of Abbe Franklin and Walter Benenson and wonderful Bobby to four grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. We will miss you. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., (at 81 St.), Fri. 7-9 PM and Sat. 4-6PM. with service Sunday 11:30 AM.

title: Hard Questions on Race; Powell's Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Religion Journal; Poll Looks at Innermost Feelings About Life's End
description: When they think about dying, what sort of comforts do Americans hope they will have in their final hours? What do they worry most about? And do they believe in an afterlife?

title: Journal; Slavery Is Bad
description: Since we live in a country governed by entertainment, Presidential sermons can never compete with those handed down by Steven Spielberg, the Hollywood Sun King, and his theatrical counterpart, George C. Wolfe, the director of Broadway's ''Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk.'' As Bill Clinton played Oprah in his belated town hall meeting on race in Akron, Ohio -- on a weekday morning when few would watch it -- these two show-biz powers launched their own race initiatives, both of them lavish productions titled ''Amistad.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEREDITH, ERLENE
description: MEREDITH-Erlene, on December 3, 1997, our family lost our cherished friend after her long and valiant battle with ovarian cancer. She was an unforgettable presence in the lives of all who knew her. With love and enthusiasm, she dedicated her life to the operatic career of her husband, Morley Meredith, distinguished baritone with the Metropolitan Opera for over thirty years. With her dynamic personality and dramatic flair, she brought friends and colleagues, artist and impresarios into her family circle. Erlene brightened every operatic occasion, backstage and off-stage, and at home in Scarsdale at ''Villa Voce,'' where she entertained in great style. Her generosity of heart and indomitable spirit remain forever with us. Emily and Eugene Grant Terry, Andrea and Carolyn Grant

title: Boy, 11, Dies Playing With Gun
description: The 11-year-old son of two New York City police officers was killed yesterday in a quiet corner of Staten Island when a playmate accidentally shot him with a pistol the two boys found, the police said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BAYER CORP., Pittsburgh, a unit of Bayer A.G., said it was reducing its focus on arthritis to pursue new drugs to treat diabetes, cancer, obesity and osteoporosis.

title: Swiss Banks Up On Merger Talk
description: Shares of the Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation rose today after a newspaper article increased speculation that the banks would merge or would unite some of their operations.

title: NETANYAHU WANTS MORE TIME TO ACT ON ANY PULLBACKS
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said today that he wanted to wait at least five months before handing the Palestinians any more territory. That dealt an apparent rebuff to Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, who had urged him to speed up the Middle East peace effort.

title: Striking State Workers Tightening Their Grip on Israelis
description: A three-day-old strike of public-sector workers, which has already disrupted Israeli life, is expected to widen on Sunday: The unions pledged today to continue their walkout despite an expected court order to union leaders to honor back-to-work orders or face stiff fines.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Giants Under Pressure To Put Hits on Hoying
description: When the Giants nailed Philadelphia Eagles quarterbacks for nine sacks in the season opener, Bobby Hoying was an observer on the sideline, wincing in empathy for his battered teammates.

title: Nichols's Lawyers Try to Show McVeigh Was an Extremist
description: Lawyers for Terry L. Nichols tried today to paint Timothy J. McVeigh as an anti-government zealot who frequently handed out extremist literature and even wore a T-shirt showing a wanted poster for Abraham Lincoln to a child's birthday party.

title: Fingerprinting Is Urged In Domestic Abuse Cases
description: State officials recommended yesterday that the police begin fingerprinting people charged with disorderly persons offenses in domestic violence cases.

title: The Fight Over 'Amistad'
description: The Steven Spielberg film ''Amistad,'' due to open next week, deals with a true-life episode -- the revolt of 53 Africans on a Spanish slave ship, La Amistad, off Cuba in 1839. After being tricked into returning to the Connecticut coast, they were seized by an American Navy ship and put on trial for the murder of La Amistad's crew. In the ensuing legal battle, former President John Quincy Adams represented the Africans before the Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOELL, KERMIT
description: GOELL-Kermit. Noted song writer of Hunter, New York, age 82, died December 4 in Portland, Maine. Husband of Cathy Goell of New York City, father of Julie Goell of Portland and Jonathan Goell of Takoma Park, Maryland, grandfather of Zev Goell Eisenberg of Portland, brother of the late Eva Godfrey, Theresa Goell, Milton Goell and Fay London. Graveside services are December 7 in Hunter. We will always feel near you.

title: A Mandela Ordeal: Testimony Changes Few Minds
description: It took more than 30 witnesses, and an Archbishop begging and in tears, but Winnie Mandela finally apologized.

title: Mets Say Ticket Prices Will Rise Once Again
description: The Mets have raised ticket prices across the board for next season, with the new scale ranging from $9 to $35 a seat. The increases, specified in a letter mailed to season-ticket holders this week, range from 40 percent for the most expensive seats to 15 percent.

title: Judge Orders Fifth Graders Relocated From School
description: A Superior Court judge ordered school officials in Atlantic City today to remove fifth-grade students from a middle school where there have been dozens of fistfights and two stabbings since the school opened in September.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MESSINA, FRANK
description: MESSINA-Frank Your 90th birthday. Lovingly remembered. Always in my thoughts. Rest in peace. S.

title: Heroin and Red Herrings
description: The recent deaths of 10 young people in Plano, Tex., who had overdosed on heroin seems further evidence that more members of the middle class are using the drug.

title: CORRECTION: Carbon Dioxide Emissions
Times Printing Plates Auctioned for $8,050
description: The last black-and-white front page off the presses of The New York Times and the metal plates used in the production of the newspaper's first color front page were auctioned at Christie's yesterday to benefit New York City charities, officials from the auction house announced.

title: Report Finds Persistent Health Ills Among Young Blacks
description: A group of black academics and community leaders said yesterday that despite the citywide economic progress in recent years, the social and economic conditions among the city's blacks, especially black children and teen-agers, still lag behind those of other groups.

title: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL: The Courting of a Star Schoolgirl; Niesha Butler: Student, Athlete, Model, but Not Yet an Autobiographer
description: In the corner of her room in the apartment in Co-op City where Niesha Butler lives, there is a three-foot-high mesh wastebasket overflowing with white envelopes and manila envelopes -- enough, if shredded, to contribute nicely to a ticker-tape parade. It is correspondence from hundreds and hundreds of colleges, each piece of mail proclaiming virtues and seeking Niesha to enroll in its institution of higher learning. In other words, they are dying to have her play on their basketball team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ROSE KERSTEIN
description: FISHER-Rose Kerstein. Passed away on the eve of her 92nd year. Beloved mother of Sarah Fisher Gillman and son-in-law Neil Gillman. Loving grandmother of Abigail Gillman and Michael Prince and Deborah Gillman. Proud great-grandmother of Jacob Samuel Prince. Devoted wife of the late Harry Fisher and sister of the late Solomon Kerstein. Funeral services on Sunday, December 7, at 11 A.M., at Norman L. Jeffer Community Chapels, 4620 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: Abracadabra And Beyond
description: No secrets of the conjurer's art are revealed in ''The Story of Magic,'' but it abounds in playing cards and chess machines, cups and balls and rope tricks, disappearing coins and suddenly appearing animals, women levitating and being sawed in half and other alluring items and marvels.

title: John E. Moss, 84, Is Dead; Father of Anti-Secrecy Law
description: John E. Moss, the dogged California Congressman whose long, lonely fight against Government secrecy led to the landmark Freedom of Information Act in 1966, died early yesterday at a hospital in San Francisco. He was 84 and had represented Sacramento in the House of Representatives from 1953 to 1978.

title: Liberties; Dig Him Up
description: It almost makes me feel sorry for the Clinton folks.

title: When Athletes Run Amok
description: Hedonism, racism, cynicism, and narcissism all permeate professional sports today. There has been no clearer manifestation of this truth than the shocking incident involving Latrell Sprewell. He is the Golden State Warriors guard who was suspended on Thursday for a year without pay by the National Basketball Association for assaulting his coach, P. J. Carlesimo. And the Warriors terminated the remainder of Sprewell's $32 million contract.

title: Spano Is Indicted By a Grand Jury
description: A Federal grand jury in Boston indicted John Spano yesterday on charges of defrauding Fleet National Bank out of $80 million to finance his $165 million purchase of the Islanders earlier this year, a deal later aborted.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: At Nationals, Rosenkranz Nearly Tops a Jacoby Record
description: In 1983 the great Oswald Jacoby, already suffering from the cancer that killed him the following year, won the prestigious Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship just as he reached his 81st birthday. He is the oldest player, before or since, to win a major national title.

title: NEXTLEVEL SYSTEMS TO SHUT PUERTO RICO OPERATIONS
description: Nextlevel Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would close its manufacturing operations in Barceloneta, P.R., at the end of the year, resulting in a loss of 1,100 jobs, about 13 percent of its work force. Nextlevel makes communications network products. The Barceloneta plant makes analog and digital television satellite receivers, which after the closing will be produced at Nextlevel's plant in Nogales, Mexico, and by a United States subcontractor. The plant closing is part of the company's plan to reduce costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, LOUIS
description: SNYDER-Louis. On December 4, 1997. Devoted husband of Helen. Loving father of son Bernard, daughters Ellen, Diane (Don Berliner) and Berta Davis (Ben Nitzberg). Beloved grandfather to Faye, Peter, Hersh and Hillary. Also survived by two brothers William and Paul and sister Anne Steiber. Funeral service will be held at I.J. Morris. Hempstead, L.I. at 12:30PM, Sunday December 7. In lieu of flowers, please send conributions to the Morse Geriatrics Center in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Members of Medicare Panel
description: Members of the National Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare were appointed by President Clinton; Speaker Newt Gingrich; Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader; Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, and Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader. One more member, the chairman, is still to be appointed jointly by Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Lott. Here are the 16 members named so far and the official who appointed them:

description: Rivalries Sharpen in Mexico

description: SIEGEL-Joanne Hope. 39 today. Happy Birthday. Mom, Jay and Rochelle

title: How a Fierce Backlash Saved The 'Made in U.S.A.' Label
description: New Balance Athletic Shoe Inc. wanted to sell more sneakers to Americans who coveted the ''Made in U.S.A.'' label. Trouble was, many of the shoes New Balance made at its factories in this country used outer soles from China.

title: How Oedipus Is Losing His Complex
description: ''We cannot begin to appreciate the meaning of Oedipus if we continue to think that Oedipus was oedipal.'' This statement by the philosopher Jonathan Lear captures the rebellious aim of Oedipus' newest analysts: they want Oedipus to lose his complex.

title: S.E.C. Says Stock Plan Violated Law
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused three former executives of Spectrum Information Technologies of violating Federal securities laws and charged two of them with violating insider trading laws.

title: 100 Arrested as a 'Speed' Ring Is Broken Up
description: The Federal and local authorities around the nation announced today that they had smashed one of the largest methamphetamine networks in the United States. They also said the operation had resulted in the arrest of 100 suspects and the breaking up of a ring that had been a major American contractor of Mexico's largest methamphetamine gang.

title: Barney's May Get New Bidder, DFS, as Business Strengthens
description: The DFS Group, the world's largest chain of duty-free shops, is preparing to make a bid for Barney's Inc., the New York luxury retailer now in bankruptcy, executives involved in the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Gordon Collects Another Check After a Very Good Year
description: He cannot speak for the other 39 guys on the list, but Jeff Gordon can tell you that the figure appearing under his name on the Forbes magazine roll of the world's 40 top-earning athletes for 1997 is sound, almost uncannily so.

title: Rays Sign Sorrento
description: The Tampa Bay Devil Rays, reached agreement yesterday with another free agent, Paul Sorrento, who will be their designated hitter next year.

title: Museums, Not Movies
description: My favorite item in all of the Smithsonian's museums is the 100,000-year-old Stone Age ax that sits behind a counter in one of the rooms at the National Museum of Natural History. It is unique not only because it was expertly shaped and balanced for a left-handed human ancestor, but also because anyone can touch it -- a piece of ancient history that's not locked up in a case.

title: In Mexico City, Elected Mayor Opens New Political Era
description: In an inauguration that greatly broadened the reach of democracy in Mexico, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, a veteran opposition leader, was sworn in today as the first elected Mayor of Mexico's vast and tumultuous capital city.

title: John N. Trainer, 88; Led Investment Firm
description: John N. Trainer, a former president of Trainer Wortham & Company, an investment counseling firm, died on Sunday at the Pomperaug Woods Health Center in Southbury, Conn. He was 88.

title: Sports of The Times; The N.B.A.'s Welfare State For Coaches
description: DAVID Stern proved convincingly and fittingly this week that the National Basketball Association knows how to deal with jerk players. For an encore, Stern should find a way to deal with jerk coaches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHLER, JEAN (SALITAN)
description: MAHLER-Jean (Salitan). Died Dec. 3, 1997 at 102 years of age. Devoted wife of the late Samuel Mahler, cherished sister of Henry Salitan and the late Rose Weiner and Samuel Salitan. Beloved sister-in-law, aunt, great-aunt and dear friend to many. Jean, before retirement, had been for many years an administrative assistant at St. Luke's Hospital. A warm and gracious woman who will be missed by family and friends. Graveside services on Sunday, December 7, 1997, 9:30 A.M., New Mt. Carmel Cemetery, GlendaleRidgewood, Queens, New York.

title: Young Denies Agreeing to Go
description: General Manager George Young denied again yesterday that he has agreed to leave the Giants to take a National Football League administrative post, despite a report in which a team co-owner, Bob Tisch, confirmed his departure.

title: Tales Twice, Indeed Thrice: Rereading Personal Classics
description: ''It is tedious to tell again tales already plainly told,'' Odysseus remarks in ''The Odyssey.'' But many book lovers would disagree, so The New York Times asked writers and readers about the last book they read twice. Here are their responses, compiled by Mary B. W. Tabor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEYNER, KALMAN F.
description: WEYNER-Kalman F., 82. Of Ansonia, CT., died on November 27, of chronic pulmonary disease. Mr. Weyner was born in Brooklyn, October 1915. His photographic career included positions at The New York Times, Associated Press, Acme News, United Press and twenty-five years of self-employment as a commercial photographer. Specializing in interiors, his clients included U.S. Plywood, Tiffany's, Steinway & Co. After retirement, he taught as an adjunct professor of photography at Brooklyn College, took sculpting and art classes, and served on the Board of Directors of the Public Library in Ansonia. Mr. Weyner was predeceased by his wife, Lila Gillan and his sister, Reta Sickles and is survived by his children, Julie Drennan of Ansonia, CT., and David Weyner of Upper Montclair, N.J., and grandchildren Timothy, Megan, Emily and Benjamin.

title: Time for the Knicks To Panic? Not Just Yet
description: The Knicks have been on an egg hunt for inspiration, wandering aimlessly in search of a reason to care about this season, hoping to stumble upon it by happenstance.

title: De La Hoya's Latest Mark: Younger, Tougher, Riskier
description: After two fights against opponents whose better days were in the rearview mirror, Oscar De La Hoya tonight will fight someone young and skilled enough to hurt him. When De La Hoya, the World Boxing Council welterweight champion, steps into the ring against Wilfredo Rivera at the Atlantic City Convention Center, he will also step up in competition from David Kamau and Hector Camacho, his last two opponents.

title: T.W.A. Pilot Stole a Piece Of Flight 800
description: A high-ranking Trans World Airlines pilot involved in the investigation of the Flight 800 crash has admitted stealing pieces of the reassembled wreckage and giving them to an author who contended that a missile downed the jetliner, the pilot's lawyer said yesterday.

title: 5 Dead in Yonkers in Apparent Murder-Suicide
description: A 53-year-old Yonkers man described by neighbors as quick tempered and troubled by health problems, finances and a failing marriage apparently shot his wife and three children to death and then killed himself in the family's apartment before dawn yesterday, the police reported.

title: Fire Causes Evacuations at Chrysler Building
description: A score of early-to-work employees had to be evacuated from the Chrysler Building yesterday when electrical equipment near the silvery tip of the landmark Art Deco skyscraper caught fire. No one was injured, fire officials said.

title: House Panel Subpoenas Memo From Justice Dept. and F.B.I.
description: Ratcheting up a battle with the Clinton Administration, a House committee today subpoenaed the F.B.I. Director's memorandum to Attorney General Janet Reno urging her to seek an independent prosecutor in the campaign finance inquiry.

title: Fleet Group Stock Offering
description: Fleet Financial Group Inc. sold 10.7 million common shares yesterday for $70.375 each, or $752.9 million, in a public offering of stock. The proceeds will be used for general purposes and to acquire the credit card business of the Advanta Corporation, a credit card and financial services company based in Spring House, Pa. Fleet, which is based in Boston, has $55 billion in assets under management.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, FLORENCE
description: BLOCK-Florence. December 4, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Norman Louis Block. Dear mother of Dr. Leonard Block, Hon. Frederic Block and the late Sheldon M. Block. Adored grandmother of Patricia, John, Neil, Nancy and great grandmother of Stacy, Robin, Jordan, Kyra, Kelsey, Brandon and Ryan. Mother-in-law of Naomi and Estelle. Services are on Sunday, December 7th, at 10:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: The defamation lawsuit against three advisers of Tawana Brawley lurched to an early halt today as objections echoed through the courtroom, the judge fretted openly about the elusiveness of progress and the defendants pressed harder to reopen a case that was closed almost a decade ago.

Loving father of Judith Ellis, stepfather of Joan Lasker Sobel and John Harris Lasker. Survived by three grandchildren, a sister Eva Ellis Mandel and a brother Kenneth Ellis. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to ''Section of Cardiology'', Lenox Hill Hospital, 130 East 77 Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: White House Drops Plan for Medicaid to Cover Cost of AIDS Drugs for Poor
description: Less than six months after announcing that it hoped to expand Medicaid to cover all low-income people who are infected with the AIDS virus, the Clinton Administration has backed away from the plan, saying it cannot be done nationwide without increasing spending.

title: ARMSTRONG WORLD RAISES ITS BID FOR DOMCO
description: Armstrong World Industries raised its bid yesterday for the Domco Company, a floor-covering concern, and extended its offer until the end of December, continuing its effort to wrest it from a European rival. Armstrong increased its offer to $26.50 (Canadian), or $18.62 (United States), a share, for a total of about $399 million. Armstrong's first hostile offer for Domco, in June, was for $23 (Canadian) a share, or about $351 million. Discussions between Armstrong, a floor covering maker in Lancaster, Pa., and Domco, of Quebec, have been difficult from the start and complicated by the role of the French plastics company Sommer Allibert S.A.. which has a 69 percent stake in Domco.

description: BOCKMUZ-Ada. Beloved mother of Helen Stein (David). Loving sister of Lillie and Julie. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Sunday, 1PM, Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

Lofts Seed and its affiliated companies, which include Sunbelt Seed and Budd Seed, have combined annual sales of about $75 million.

description: After Shira A. Scheindlin was appointed to the Federal District Court in Manhattan a few years ago, she told an interviewer for a legal newspaper that she expected to be more of a ''settling judge than a brilliant opinion writer.''

title: Heart, and a Kind Crossbar, Put UConn in Title Game
description: Early this season, Coach Len Tsantiris of Connecticut decided to move Sara Whalen, a two-time all-America sweeper, to a forward position. Whalen responded by pacing the Huskies in points.

title: Chief of Credit Unit at Sears Resigns
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that the head of its credit division, Steven Goldstein, 45, had resigned to start his own business. He was replaced by the company's chief financial officer, Alan Lacy.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a plan to save what remains of the Civil War ironclad Monitor misspelled the middle name of a naval historian who wrote a popular history of the ship. He is James Tertius deKay, not Fertius.

description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide when school districts can be found liable under Federal law for a teacher's sexual abuse of a student.

description: If you need further evidence that track and field on an elite level is a professional sport, look at the prize money structure for the Goodwill Games.

description: As new questions emerged about the life of the late United States Ambassador to Switzerland, M. Larry Lawrence, President Clinton ordered an investigation into whether Mr. Lawrence had lied about his service in the merchant marine in World War II and was inappropriately granted a waiver to be buried at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Michael Hedges, 43, a Guitarist Flamboyant and Experimental
description: Michael Hedges, a guitarist whose distinctive style meshed folk music, jazz and an exploration of the guitar's sonic capacity, was found dead on Tuesday of injuries suffered in an car accident near Boonville, Calif., in Mendocino County. He was 43, said his manager, Hillary Burgess.

description: The American economy showed surprising strength last month by creating 404,000 new jobs, as the unemployment rate edged down to another 24-year low and wages surged, the Government reported today.

description: Kathy Herrera had just given her son Lian Jhonathan Caceres money for a haircut. He set off armed with a document assuring whoever asked that he had no identity card because of bureaucratic inefficiency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAFTON, SAMUEL
description: GRAFTON-Samuel. Age 90. On December 2, 1997. Beloved husband of Edith Kingstone Grafton. Devoted father of Abigail, John, and Anthony. Loving grandfather of Sam and Anna. A Memorial service will be scheduled at a later date.

title: Partisanship Imperils Advisory Panel on Medicare
description: Medicare is such a hot political potato that politicians here realized long ago that using normal legislative procedures, they would never be able to agree on measures to make the program financially secure for baby boomers when they retire.

title: Anonymity in a Polyphonic Tapestry
description: In the first of two concerts at St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue, the Tallis Scholars on Thursday evening displayed all the qualities for which they have won, through their recordings, an unrivaled reputation in Renaissance polyphony: lines and skeins of lines that stay in motion through the long spaces before the rare full cadences in this music, clear nonvibrato tone in the top parts, satisfying chords and, in general, blendings that keep the voices in balance.
