title: MICROPROSE AND GT INTERACTIVE END MERGER TALKS
description: Microprose Inc. and the GT Interactive Software Corporation said yesterday that they had mutually agreed to end their merger agreement, saying ''the time is simply not right'' for the deal. In early October, the companies said that GT would pay about $250 million in stock to acquire Microprose. In a joint statement, GT Interactive and Microprose said they would continue to work together on a number of marketing and distribution projects. GT Interactive will continue to distribute Microprose products in certain chains in the United States as well as Macintosh versions of Microprose products. GT Interactive plans to continue to focus on expanding its publishing business, which the company said accounted for more than 60 percent of its total revenues.

title: Ladies' Man Theory: A Kennedy Tour Stop
description: In one of the few startling episodes in the documentary ''Dangerous World: The Kennedy Years,'' Judith Campbell Exner is interviewed on camera. She steps out of the past like some dark icon from the Kennedy years, her brown hair framing a face that is older and fuller but still strikingly attractive and familiar. As she recalls her days as John Kennedy's lover and, she says, his courier to the mob, her words no longer shock. But her living, breathing presence does. Isn't she supposed to be frozen in history, in all those black-and-white photographs from the 60's? The jolt a viewer gets from seeing Ms. Exner on screen goes to the heart of ''Dangerous World,'' and of the power, danger and possibilities of television documentaries themselves.

title: Van Horn Makes Debut, and Nets Look Healthy
description: It felt a little like opening night. For Keith Van Horn, it was.

title: INTERFACE TO BUY CARPET BUSINESS IN EUROPE
description: Interface Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy Readicut International P.L.C.'s European carpet business for about $50.3 million to expand sales in Europe and Asia. Atlanta-based Interface said it would buy Firth Carpets Ltd. and Joseph, Hamilton & Seaton Ltd., both based in England, and Netherlands-based Vebe Floorcoverings B.V. The companies to be acquired make and distribute woven, tufted and needle punch carpet. Interface said it planned to sell one of Firth's installation service providers and other assets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWICKER, SALLY
description: ZWICKER-Sally, December 2, 1997. A sweet and gentle woman who left an indelible mark upon her family who treasured her company, respected her counsel and never stopped appreciating her love and devotion. Her respect for others' feelings, her selflessness and humility, her lively intelligence and her courage in the face of great tragedy will always inspire us. Predeceased by her husband Benjamin and daughter Naomi, she is lovingly remembered by her daughter Phyllis and sister Anne, grandchildren Ellen (Mark), Randi (Howie), Paul (Jackie), Barry (Laurie) and Bradley (Patti), and great-grandchildren Alexander, Joshua, Adam, Alixandra, Nicole, Risa, Sam, Rachel and Zachary.

title: 2 Queens Men Arrested In Massage Parlor Holdup
description: Tipped off by an employee of a methadone clinic who had seen a television news report about a series of robberies at New Jersey massage parlors, police detectives in Manhattan arrested two men yesterday and charged them in one of the holdups, the authorities said.

title: New Turn in a Twisted Tale of Stolen Art
description: One might think this was the end of the twisting, turning, tortuous plot.

title: RALSTON-PURINA TO ADD BRITISH PET FOODS MAKER
description: The Ralston-Purina Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Edward Baker Petfoods of Britain from Harrisons & Crosfield P.L.C. for $180 million. Ralston-Purina, based in St. Louis, is a pet-food and battery concern with full-year sales of $2.3 billion. Edward Baker, based in Suffolk, England, operates two manufacturing plants in Britain and one in the Netherlands. It had full-year sales of $120 million in 1996. The sale will allow Harrisons & Crosfield to concentrate on its specialty chemicals business. Ralston-Purina's stock gained $1.875 a share, to $96.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, MAE
description: HOFFMAN-Mae. On Dec. 5, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Adrienne Weinberger & Frances Harkavy. Dear mother-in-law of Bud Harkavy. Adoring grandmother of Neil Poppel, Stephen, John and Leslie Harkavy. Great grandmother of Nina, Ali and Amanda. Service Sunday 11:45AM, the ''Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Reno's Decision May Spur Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, LEO
description: LEVY-Leo. On December 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Shirley; devoted father of Howard (Garth) and Ronald (Arlyne); loving grandfather of Farron, Stacey, Joshua and Rowell. Services Sunday 1:30 PM ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' 76th Road and Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills.

title: European Trade Inquiry To Focus on Aid to Dow
description: The European Commission will investigate subsidies that the German Government paid Dow Chemical when the company bought three eastern German chemical factories, a commission official said yesterday.

title: Tobacco Companies Give Subpoenaed Documents to Congress
description: Four giants of the tobacco industry ended a fight with a loyal friend in Congress today when they turned over more than 800 internal documents that some investigators suspect hold clues to criminal wrongdoing.

title: Giuliani Says City Must Plan For Gambling
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he is convinced that casino gambling is coming to New York City, and he took two major steps to cement the city's control over gambling, insuring that the city benefits from every hand of blackjack and pull of a slot-machine lever.

title: COMCAST SET FOR EXPANSION IN DELAWARE AND MARYLAND
description: The Comcast Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Marcus Cable Company's Delaware and Maryland cable television assets for $65.5 million in cash to expand its coverage in the two states. Dallas-based Marcus said the systems serve about 26,500 people on the eastern coast of Maryland, along the Chesapeake Bay, eastward to the Atlantic Ocean and through central Delaware. Marcus said the sale was part of its plan to sell nonstrategic assets to focus on its main cable areas. Philadelphia-based Comcast said the systems give the company greater coverage in areas between systems it already owns in Dover and Rehoboth Beach, Del., and Salisbury, Md. Marcus is the nation's 10th-largest cable operator, serving 1.2 million customers in 18 states.

title: Artistic Director Named At Washington Theater
description: After a 13-month search, the Arena Stage in Washington yesterday announced the appointment of Molly D. Smith as its new artistic director.

title: A New Journal: A Digest That Feeds on Digests
description: Caught the article about Heidegger's craving in Diacritic's special fall issue about addiction? How about that piece on Dutch Domestic Realism in the spring issue of Representations? Or Critical Inquiry's page-turner on the trauma of Dada montage?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Joblessness at 24-Year Low In Strong Sign of Vitality

title: Nov. 30-Dec. 6; They're in the Money
description: South Korea, the world's 11th-largest economic power, will get the largest international rescue ever: a $55 billion loan package from the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank, the United States and several other nations. Though the first signs of change will be severe cuts in public spending and a retrenchment that would double, perhaps triple, unemployment, the bailout is expected to restore the value of the Korean won and pay off foreign debt. Apologizing to Koreans last week in a nationally televised speech, the Minister of Finance, Lim Chang Yuel, said, ''Please understand the necessity of the economic pain we must bear and overcome.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, BETTY
description: SHAPIRO-Betty. Devoted wife of the late Albert. Beloved mother of Seena Grant and Robert Shapiro. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Roughing it, in the spirit of Frank Lloyd Wright
description: On the November morning my husband, James, and I set out to explore the trails at Canoe Bay, a small, elegantly rustic hideaway on 280 acres of Wisconsin woods, a light snow was falling. Walking quite slowly -- the paths of sodden leaves were slippery with new snow -- we circled past Lake Wahdoon and quickly found ourselves alone in a silent, whitening forest. Through spiky trees and brush, we could easily see the glaciated contours of the land, dipping hills, deep ravines and two other tiny, pristine lakes.

title: New Nuclear Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: When Vandals Attack Lampposts, That's a Bad Sign
description: Pity the humble traffic signs. They are defaced with graffiti or covered with promotional stickers. They are stolen by thieves who sell them for scrap (at about 30 cents a pound), souvenir hunters looking for urban art for their homes, and motorists seeking free parking. In one case, said the city's Transportation Commissioner, a no-parking sign in downtown Manhattan was melted with a blowtorch.

title: Disabled on the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Graduate From Jazz's Underground
description: IN 1992, THE TRUMPETER Dave Douglas was on a tour of one-nighters with a band led by the clarinetist Don Byron, and the group came through Florence. The day of the concert, Mr. Douglas visited the Santa Maria del Fiore Cathedral, in the center of town, and later that day read the tale of its construction.

title: Faith is a Compromise; What Does The Koran Say About Nasreen's Nose Ring?
description: On a Saturday night in suburban Virginia, Sharifa Alkhateeb is putting on a purple head scarf before rushing out for a potluck dinner at the local mosque. Meanwhile, her 16-year-old daughter, nose pierced, baggy jeans dangling from her hips, hangs out with her non-Muslim girlfriends. Returning home after 10, Sharifa finds a note pinned to the living-room door.

title: Sending a Message, Bumper to Bumper
description: WHO -- Cara Altman, who recently founded A Safer Highway, a group dedicated to bringing more civility to the road -- specifically, to those behind the wheel.

title: Turkey May Free Activist Before Prime Minister Visits U.S.
description: Less than two weeks before Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz's planned visit to Washington, the Turkish Government seems to be moving toward freeing the country's most prominent prisoner, but she says she will not accept a pardon.

title: The View From/Harrison; Collector of 6,000 Snow Domes Knows Kitsch From Priceless
description: THE song says ''Let It Snow.'' This is the time for snow and other things, like stocking stuffers. What could be a more appropriate trinket than snow under glass, like a snow dome, those little globes with figures inside that are surrounded by a swirl of flakes at the flick of a wrist?

title: Torquay
description: To the Editor: Iris Ihde Frey's article ''Tracing Agatha Christie in Torquay'' (Nov. 9) sent me to ''Harbors and High Seas'' by Dean King and John Hattendorf (Henry Holt, 1996), an atlas of the journeys of Jack Aubrey and Stephen Maturin in the early 19th century, as chronicled in Patrick O'Brian's 18 novels. I located ''Tor Key'' close to ''Shelmertson,'' the home port of Aubrey and Maturin's ship Surprise. The atlas authors mention that this fictitious port seems to rove a bit in O'Brian's novels, which is perhaps fitting since it is ''a smuggling base and shifty by nature.'' They quote O'Brian as stating Shelmertson is the nearest thing to a Caribbean pirates' base that any English countrywoman was likely to see. Two other fictitious ports in O'Brian's novels are nearby. All are near O'Brian's prep school.

title: Middle-Aged, Single, Looking for a Life
description: SOME men and women married soon after high school or college. Others continued to date for another decade before saying ''I do.'' Still others ended an early first marriage only to wed again with equally unhappy results. Whatever their story, the number of Connecticut residents divorced in their middle years has become increasingly visible in the last decade.

title: THEATER; A Couple of Veteran Funnymen And Their Alter Egos
description: ''THE SUNSHINE BOYS'' IS the ''King Lear'' of Broadway comedy. Young actors need not apply. The play, about two aging former vaudevillians, is a vehicle for actors to grow into as they get older. Jack Klugman, 75, and Tony Randall, 77, are about to go forth on Neil Simon's heath. With John Tillinger directing, the National Actors Theater production opens at the Lyceum Theater tomorrow night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELER, WYNN (NEE WINIFRED M. BREIMER)
description: WHEELER-Wynn (nee Winifred M. Breimer). Of Southampton and Douglaston, NY. Beloved Wife of Dick. Loving Mother of Greg, Terri and Jeff. Devoted Grandmother of nine. Celebration of Life in the Community Church of Douglaston on Friday, December 26, 1997 at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, gifts to the Leukemia Society of America (New York City) would be appreciated.

title: POSTINGS: Coldwell Banker Hunt Kennedy Expands; Across the River Into Brooklyn
description: Since its inception in 1988, the realty agency now known as Coldwell Banker Hunt Kennedy has expanded its name while confining its operations to Manhattan. Now, with the purchase of Cranford Inc., it is expanding its territory into Brooklyn.

title: Endpaper; The Afterlife, As I See It
description: According to a recent study by the National Opinion Research Center in Chicago, 74 percent of all Americans believe in an afterlife. With that in mind, the Magazine asked some forward-thinking folks to ponder where they might expect to find themselves after they're gone.

title: The World of His Imagination
description: AS an artist roaming his own imagination, Gennady Spirin, who was born and came of age in Russia, creates a world for children that is make-believe yet realistic.

title: Sharon Isaak and Lee Hoffman
description: Sharon Elizabeth Isaak and Lee James Hoffman, segment producers for ''Dateline NBC,'' the television program, were married last evening. Rabbi Stephen C. Listfield performed the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Culture Zone; To Hell With Him
description: How far the devil has fallen! In the new Al Pacino movie, ''Devil's Advocate,'' the Prince of Darkness -- Milton's majestic archangel whose ''stature reached the Sky'' -- has devolved into a slick Manhattan fixer, the head of a law firm that does things like get rich murderers off the hook. Whereas Lucifer once waged an all-out war in heaven against God Himself, he now has his hands full seducing ambitious yuppies, who are happy to sell out -- not for knowledge or creative powers, like earlier Fausts, but for cushy apartments on Fifth Avenue and some corporate perks.

title: Public Nuisance: Media Copters
description: To the Editor:

title: Life off Campus, and on the Alert
description: Like the city for which it is named, New York University has enjoyed an improving reputation in recent years. With U.S. News and World Report now ranking it 34th among all American universities (only Columbia, in 9th place, has a higher rating among colleges in the city), students from all over the country have begun flocking to Washington Square, drawn by the school's new stature and the allure of Manhattan life.

title: The Two Hollywoods
description: 'The Two Hollywoods'' (Nov. 16) was insightful. Your contributors, especially Art Linson, Walter Kirn and Neal Gabler, did an outstanding job of analyzing facts and figures, and putting their meaty findings into perspective.

title: Outlet Center Proves Hit With Bargain Hunters
description: ON a recent drizzly Sunday, after spending the weekend in Montauk, Pat and Joe Schweitzer, a couple from Westbury, decided to leave early and stop at Tanger II, the new section of the Tanger Factory Outlet Center in Riverhead, for the first time.

title: Indies Sprout Wings
description: For frequent fliers tired of mass-market films on airplanes (how many times have you seen the same Arnold Schwarzenegger movie?), Northwest Airlines has an alternative: independent films. Its ''Independents in Flight'' series, running for nearly a year in first and business classes on international flights, is such a hit that the selection has expanded. This month's picks include ''In the Company of Men'' (left), a Sundance Film Festival award winner.

title: Amid Some Dross, a Vein of Schumann Gold
description: FROM HELICON COMES AN unusual ''Schumann Salon Concert,'' including the composer's Violin Sonata in D minor (Op. 121), and anyone who knows that work will know that it takes up most of the CD (HE1018).

title: State or Towns: Who's Better at Caring for the Poor?
description: THE quiet, orderly office of the Department of Social Services in Norwich bears no resemblance to the chaos in the lives of the people who pass through the door seeking help.

title: Another Giant South Korean Conglomerate Falls
description: South Korea's 12th-largest conglomerate collapsed today, spurring new fears of a wave of corporate bankruptcies under strict financial rules dictated by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Nov. 9 about ''The Right to Learn: A Blueprint for Creating Schools That Work,'' by Linda Darling-Hammond, misstated the author's affiliation. She is a professor of education at Columbia Teachers College, not the Bank Street College of Education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORMS, CARL
description: WORMS-Carl. December 5, 1997 at the age of 91. Beloved husband of the late Gretl. Devoted father of Jon Warms and Dr. Tom Warms. Dear brother of Richard Worms. Adored grandfather of Susan Golden, and Mark, Alan, and Rebecca Warms. Proud great-grandfather of Leslie, Benjamin, and Michael. Services Sunday 12:30 PM at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, MARTIN P. PH.D.
description: MEYER-Martin P. Ph.D., noted mountain climber, a man whose wisdom, wit and humanity enriched the lives of all he touched. He was very much loved and will be missed and mourned by his wife, stepchildren and his friends.

title: The View From: Fourth and Fifth Grade; Between City and Suburb, Helping Children Make New Friends
description: ONE HUNDRED fourth graders sat at long tables in the auditorium of the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford, intent on the action taking place on a small stage. The antique tavern signs lining the walls spoke of the Historical Society's dedication to the past, but the program being presented to the students was headline fare: skits that dramatize issues like stereotyping, prejudice and the isolation of one ethnic group from another.

title: Essay; Huey, Dewey, Louie and Other Classics
description: Axiom 1: The writing of fiction is done in memory of the earliest experiences of life and in something resembling, however faintly, that trance, or stunned daze, with which for some few years we looked about us. Put differently, whatever else literature may be, it is also a recapitulation of the chief dramas of childhood -- including the struggle with pictures, alphabets and texts. Each act of writing, then, is to some degree both a reverie and a rereading. All of which is to explain why I shall, in thinking about the books that most influenced me, begin (and probably end, too) at the beginning.

title: New Technology Center At Fordham Helps Out
description: A SEEMINGLY effortless Jesuit tradition of community service and intellectual enlightenment is the driving force behind Fordham University's latest community outreach project.

title: The Nation; Don't Taxi From Reagan To Dallas
description: IT is a jet-age twist on Shakespeare's what's-in-a-name question. Of course, the playwright wasn't thinking about changing planes at O'Hare or shuttling to Logan when he wrote ''Romeo and Juliet.''

title: Does It Come With a Moat?
description: The large yellow banner draped across the ornate castlelike building at 140th and Riverside Drive announcing that it is for sale has caught the eye of many a motorist on the Henry Hudson Parkway.

title: Faith Is a Fraud; Godless And Proud of It
description: Talladega, Ala., a town of 19,000 about 40 miles east of Birmingham, is the kind of little world Southern Baptists dream about. Churches, it seems, are on every street corner; their flick-knife spires jut through the humid air, a warning to transgressors. Just about any building can be jumbled or cajoled into being a church. One house of worship is clearly a converted gas station: traces of pump stands are still visible on the concrete out front.

title: Americans Can Use the Law to Control Cloning; Romance of Childbirth
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Female Officer, New Job Is Another First
description: By now, Inspector Jane Perlov should be used to the phrase that always seems to follow her name: ''The first woman to become . . .'' There is plenty to choose from to complete the line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHT, DR. SIDNEY E.
description: LICHT-Dr. Sidney E. On December 5. Loving and devoted Minna. Loving uncle of Marlene and Al Nussbaum, and Marty and Rona Licht, Robert Licht and Andrew Licht. Great-uncle to Aimee and Alan, Mellissa and Steven, Marcie and Barry, Rebecca, Alyssa and Leon, Michelle and Greg, and Evan and Lisa, and Samantha and Greg. Services today, 11 AM, at ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 312 Coney Island Ave. at Prospect Park Circle.

title: FILM; The Film That Shattered the Mystique of French Cinema
description: HE WAS A SURPRISING apparition, a Proust with a camera, tracking memories of time past by filming the story of his life and loves in the present tense. Jean Eustache, who came from a working-class family in the south of France, surged upon the Paris scene during the 1960's, almost a decade younger than New Wave directors like Jean-Luc Godard and Francois Truffaut. And in 1972, nine years before he died at the age of 42, he made ''La Maman et la Putain'' (''The Mother and the Whore''), a 16-millimeter post-New Wave marathon of a movie that became one of the cultural phenomena of his generation.

title: About Seed: Miracles in Small Packages
description: WHAT is to be done with those left-over seed packets? The first inclination is to toss them out. But wait, this could wasted effort.

title: Yikes! That Famous Old Boat Is Sinking Yet Again
description: EMILY RYERSON RARELY emerged from her first-class cabin during the voyage. She and her husband, Arthur, were on a sad mission, going to the United States to recover the body of their son, who had been killed in a car accident. So they set out on the maiden voyage of a glamorous ocean liner called the Titanic.

title: Van Horn Makes Debut, And Everyone Is Happy
description: In the final minute of the Nets' 107-88 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers on Friday night, John Calipari pulled Keith Van Horn out of the game, allowing him to soak in a well-deserved bit of applause from what little remained of the Continental Arena crowd. But more satisfying than the applause was what awaited him on the bench.

title: 2 Adults Held After Boy, 11, Kills Playmate
description: A man and woman arrested in the accidental shooting death of an 11-year-old Staten Island boy by a playmate had left a loaded semiautomatic pistol in easy reach of the youngsters, the police said yesterday.

title: Wiring Outlets Correctly
description: THERE are some things in the house that may need repair even though they do not appear to be broken. This is often the case with electrical outlets.

title: Role Player Looms Large For Islanders
description: For much of this season, Todd Bertuzzi has been a faint blip on the Islanders' radar screen. But, lately, the hulking right wing has been hard to miss.

title: U.S. Shifts A-Bomb Readiness to Smaller Wars
description: President Clinton has issued new guidelines for the use of nuclear weapons, ordering the Pentagon to focus less on planning a prolonged nuclear fight with a superpower like Russia and more on focused attacks to deter smaller powers from using chemical or biological weapons, Administration officials said tonight.

title: Backlash; In Medicine, Government Rises Again
description: HILLARY was right about health care. Well, not quite: Hardly anybody expects Congress to micro-manage medical services or to cap the maximum amount Americans are permitted to spend on insurance. But confidence that the health care system can solve its problems without a lot of help from Washington is rapidly evaporating.

title: Q. & A.
description: When Is a Foreclosure Final?

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Everything Comes Up Oranges for Nebraska, and Perhaps Tennessee; Frost Engineers Rout of A&M
description: It was over long before oranges started rolling on the Alamodome field in the fourth quarter today. It was over at halftime. Maybe it was really over last week when the Nebraska Cornhuskers realized they were destined to finish a perfect season as the nation's No. 2 team unless they got some help.

title: Wallace Clark, Melanoma Expert, Dies at 73
description: Dr. Wallace H. Clark Jr., a skin pathologist at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston who devised the first widely used scale for assessing the seriousness of skin cancers called melanomas, died on Nov. 28 at his home in Kennebunk, Me. He was 73.

title: Stefanie Miller, M. J. Jacobowitz
description: Stefanie Fran Miller and Marshall Jay Jacobowitz were married last evening at the View on the Hudson, a restaurant in Piermont, N.Y. Rabbi Marcelo Bronstein performed the ceremony.

title: Serb's Oratory Is Hate-Filled But No Hurdle In Election
description: A few days ago, Vojislav Seselj, a former paramilitary leader and front-running candidate for President of Serbia in Sunday's election, presented his chief exhibit in his trial on assault charges.

title: Israelis Given False Reports By Syria Spy, Study Says
description: In a case certain to further discredit the Israeli intelligence service, revelations have surfaced that a Mossad spy master responsible for watching Syria apparently invented his reports for several years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORNSTEIN, JANE S.
description: BORNSTEIN-Jane S. Of New York City, on Friday December 5, 1997. Devoted mother of Ronald Bornstein of San Francisco, CA and Stanley Bornstein of Newton, MA. Proud grandmother of Alison, Amanda, Daniel and Sabrina. Services 11 AM Monday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Memorial donations may be made in memory of Jane S. Bornstein to the 92nd Street Y, c/o Friends of the Y, 1395 Lexington Ave., NY NY 10128.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, MARGARET
description: DALY-Margaret. The Board of Trustees of Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System, Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center, and Saint Agnes Hospital, deeply mourn the death of Margaret Daly. We extend our deepest sympathy to her son, William and his sister Brigid as they mourn the loss of their beloved mother. Edwin S. Mruk, Chairman Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System Gary S. Horan, FACHE President and CEO Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System William F. Harrington, Jr., Esq. Chairman, Saint Agnes Hospital

title: TELEVISION VIEW; Word-Perfect Women: Out of the Mouths of Babes
description: IT IS A TRUTH UNIVERSALLY acknowledged that a single man in possession of a television must be in love with Jenna Elfman or Calista Flockhart. Or both.

title: Woody Allen and Martin Scorsese
description: Woody Allen maintains that students today don't know the history of film, but how are they to learn it (''Woody Allen and Mar-tin Scorsese'')? When I moved to the Boston area in 1974, there were nearly a dozen theaters that featured older films; now there is one. Video has made many movies available, but the space in the rental shops allotted to foreign films and the older domestic classics is often embarrassingly stingy. And in any event, watching a wide-screen epic like ''Lawrence of Arabia'' on video is like studying a Hieronymus Bosch painting on a matchbook-cover reproduction.

title: New York By the Hour
description: IT'S that time of year again, when the glitter in store windows and the throngs of people lining up to whip out their wallets magnify what seems to be a fundamental fact of New York life: We were put here to part with our money, and the city is set up to make us do just that.

title: Sue Birnbaum and Jeffrey Rosenwald
description: Sue Ellen Birnbaum and Jeffrey R. Rosenwald were married last evening in Charleston, S.C. Randolph Hille, a nondenominational chaplain, officiated at the Mills House Hotel.

title: The War of the Film Worlds
description: FOR the most part, Maurice Kanbar was in a good mood. He had flown in from San Francisco to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Quad Cinema, the multiplex he founded on 13th Street west of Fifth Avenue, which is now operated by his younger brother, Elliott.

title: Troupe of Actors Leads Children to Reading
description: ASIA BLUE and Onika Palmer each had one, Miguel Perez had three and Amanda Duffy had none. The stars of the day had the letter ''E'' in their names, which they proudly pointed out on their name tags.

title: All Fired Up
description: VESTAL FIRE

title: From Canapes to Dessert, Dried Fruit Adds to Holiday Dishes
description: THE smart cook keeps dried fruit of all kinds on hand during the holiday season to dress up an array of dishes. These days it is not difficult to find organic dried fruit in particular -- even in the supermarket -- and it pays to look for them.

title: State Plans to 'Calm' Traffic on Route 114
description: STATE engineers are planning an experiment to ''calm'' traffic on five miles of Route 114 in North Haven and Sag Harbor.

title: The Nation; Looking for a Needle, Can't Find the Haystack
description: ANOTHER serious political scandal seems be to sputtering sloppily to a close without anyone being held accountable, without anyone being exonerated and without any real prospect that anything will be done at all. Last week Attorney General Janet Reno rejected the appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore for their White House fund-raising calls. Last month a Senate committee dropped its own campaign finance inquiry after weeks of inconclusive hearings. And outside the capital, many people tuned out and moved on.

title: Gun Lessons Mandatory for Sixth Graders at Pennsylvania School
description: The lesson for today was foxes, the difference between reds and whites. But this was also one of those occasional afternoons that a wildlife conservation officer was visiting the sixth-grade class on wildlife appreciation that is taught twice a week here at New Freedom Christian High School. So it was a good chance to talk about the deadly accident that occurred nearby over the Thanksgiving Day holiday.

title: Word for Word / Girl Trouble; Sugar and Spite And a Legal Mess Not Nice
description: THIS much is clear: Kytan Schultz and Cassandra Reibel, both 10 years old, do not get along. Fifth-grade classmates at Harry W. Miller Elementary School in Center Line, Mich., a suburb of Detroit, the girls have a stormy history that includes name-calling, hair-pulling, harassing phone calls and threats.

title: The Shoes of the Fishermen
description: LIVES OF THE POPES The Pontiffs From St. Peter to John Paul II. By Richard P. McBrien. Illustrated. 520 pp. San Francisco: HarperSanFrancisco. $29.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, BERNARD H.
description: MORRIS-Bernard H. On December 5, 1997. Devoted husband of Ruth Katharine (nee Batchker). Loving father of Amy Morris Hess and Roberta Jean Morris. Dear father-in-law of Philip Bucksbaum. Beloved grandfather of Carlos Alberto Hess and Caroline Beatrice Bucksbaum. Loving brother of Fred H. Morris and the late Beatrice Black. Interment private. Memorial Service to be announced at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOHNSON, LAWRENCE H.
description: JOHNSON-Lawrence H. December 8, 1970. Gone 27 years, but remembered with love forever. Your son, Robbie

title: Plotting A Strategy for San Francisco
description: MANY moons ago, first as impecunious students and then as impecunious married students, Tom and I hung out in San Francisco. Then, as now, the city offered maximum fun for reasonable, if not altogether minimum, price.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIEDER, COL. WILLIAM ANDREW
description: LIEDER-Col. William Andrew. In loving memory. Your wife, Mary

title: Highway Patrol; The Self-Appointed Cops of the Information Age
description: AT a conference last week on protecting children from on-line pornography, Floyd Abrams, the First Amendment lawyer, was asked his view of the problems with software programs that screen out objectionable material. ''The only problem with private filters,'' Mr. Abrams replied, ''is to make sure they don't become public filters.''

title: Mediterranean In the West 50's
description: ARTUSI** [rating: two stars]

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: QUEBEC, California, Turkey and a small Swedish village provide the backdrops for some choice movies on television this week.

title: The Power of Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A review on Nov. 23 about ''The Corner: A Year in the Life of an Inner-City Neighborhood,'' by David Simon and Edward Burns, misstated the name of the woman who runs a community center in the Baltimore neighborhood where the authors did their research. She is Ella Thompson.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: STOP IN SOUTH AFRICA -- African Travel, a Los Angeles tour company, is offering a three-night stopover in Cape Town at no extra charge to those buying one of four designated departures of its 12-day Kenya Explorer safari. The departures are March 11, April 15 and 22 and Dec. 2. (November and December and March to May are generally the rainy seasons in Kenya.) The trip must be booked in conjunction with South African Airways flights from New York or Miami to Kenya via South Africa. The safari includes accommodations with meals at the Mount Kenya Safari Club, Aberdare Country Club and Sweetwaters Tented Camp, with a safari by plane to the Mara Safari Club. The stopover in South Africa includes three nights at the Table Bay Hotel with breakfast. The price, including round-trip air fare from the United States, starts at $3,690 a person, double occupancy. Information: (800) 421-8907 or (818) 507-7893.

title: In Middle Age and Suddenly Single
description: SOME of them married soon after high school or college. Others continued to date for another decade before saying, ''I do.'' Still others ended an early first marriage only to wed again with equally unhappy results. But whatever their particular story, the number of Westchester residents who became divorced in their middle years has been on the rise in the last decade.

title: The Steak Choice Is Prime Porterhouse
description: DINING meccas like Roslyn, Cedarhurst and Huntington jump to mind when Long Islanders are thinking of a night out. Now insert Bay Shore. With the opening of Candles Steakhouse, just a half block from Siam Lotus, the best Thai restaurant on the island, Bay Shore has doubled its drawing power.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Million Dollar Delusion
description: I'M increasingly alarmed by how much financial-planning advice these days says you'll need to have saved at least $1 million before you can enjoy a secure retirement.

title: Robert Redford Has This Problem
description: As the writer of several straight-to-video features, I thoroughly enjoyed your special issue. However, I would like to clear up one small misconception. In your profile of Robert Redford, he complains that ''Reagan was like a panzer division rolling across the country.'' He cites ''Popeye'' and ''Dick Tracy'' as examples of the ''huge, expensive cartoons'' Hollywood churned out in the dark years of Reagan's tenure. Now I'm not much of a Republican, or a conservative, or a Reaganite, but Carter was to blame for ''Popeye'' (1980) and Bush for ''Dick Tracy'' (1990). Let's cut the Gipper some slack!

title: For a Jolly Old Elf
description: Black designer boots with elegant braiding at the ankle aren't exactly what one would expect of Santa Claus. But that's what the shoe designers Joan & David delivered when they and scores of other fashion designers came up with tiny outfits for Santa and Mrs. Claus as Christmas tree ornaments at the White House.

title: Seashells as Symbols in Mesoamerican Society
description: Conchas Precolumbianas

title: Woody Allen and Martin Scorsese
description: On the same day Iread Martin Scorsese's statement ''It isn't why the bad guy dies now. It is how he dies,'' I happened to watch Kenneth Branagh's ''Hamlet.'' In the finale, Hamlet flings his foil across an entire ballroom, impaling the fleeing Claudius; then the prince releases a giant chandelier that sails across the room and pins the king to his throne. Only then does Branagh return to Shakespeare's text. So when Woody Allen replies to Scorsese, ''But that stuff is for kids,'' he may be unaware of how pervasive the ''pummeling'' mentality has become in films, even in one like ''Hamlet.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAUS, JAMES ARTHUR, JR.
description: VAUS-James Arthur, Jr. Internationally-known electrical wizard and worker with youth, died December 1, 1997, at Augusta Medical Center, Fisherville, VA after an illness of several years. Vaus was born into a minister's family in Los Angeles, California, on February 17, 1919, and grew up in Texas. Following a military career he became a wiretapper for organized crime, but in 1949 at age 30 he became Christian, committing his life to Christ at the Greater Los Angeles Billy Graham crusade. For the next nine years, with his wife Alice, he traveled on four continents witnessing with the aid of electrical inventions to the change Christ had made in his life. A film ''Wiretapper'' resulted. In 1958 he launched Youth Development, Inc., a ministry to troubled youth in Spanish Harlem of New York City, where he was used to lead many gang members into Christian service. In the years that followed he established numerous youth services around the country, moving his headquarters to San Diego, CA where he established a nationwide youth crisis hotline, 1800-HIT-HOME, that still receives thousands of calls monthly. Vaus' latest ministry originated from a donated property in the mountains of Virginia in 1995. He established a retreat center for youth and was there at the time of his death. He is survived by his wife, Alice (whose book described their early travels), five children, ten grandchildren, all of Virginia, and two sisters, Elizabeth Rothenberger and Virginia McLaughlin of California. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial contributions be sent to Youth Development, Inc., Head Waters Lodge, Head Waters, Virginia 24442. A farewell service was held at Head Waters Lodge on Thursday, December 4, with burial at Head Waters Cemetery.

description: A CHRISTMAS STAR By Linda Oatman High. Illustrated by Ronald Himler. Unpaged. New York: Holiday House. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: From a Paradise Found and Then Colonized
description: AFTER 270 YEARS, SOME OF the most evocative works of art to survive from colonial America, the exuberant watercolors of Southern birds, plants and animals by the English naturalist Mark Catesby, are having an overdue homecoming.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Musical 'Christmas Carol'

title: In the Region/Long Island; For Riverhead, a Mall to Join Its Huge Outlet Center
description: THE arrival of the Tanger Factory Outlet Center on Route 58 in Riverhead in 1994 thrust a sleepy East End town -- until then better known for its agriculture than its shopping -- prominently on the retail map.

title: Jones Equals Record
description: Kent Jones shot an 8-under-par 64 yesterday to tie the course record on the West course of Grenelefe Golf and Tennis Resort and move into second place at the PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUSID, ALTA BUTKUS
description: CHUSID-Alta Butkus. Of Goshen, a 39 year resident of Mt Vernon, NY, died December 2. Daughter of the late Paul and Anastasia Butkus, she was born May 24, 1920 in Linden, NJ. She was the widow of Dr. Emanuel Chusid. Survivors include a sister Viola Stanislowski, children Michael Chusid of Lithuania, Nancy Chusid of Neversink, NY and Barbara Chusid of Wisconin and grandchildren Emily and Sonia Ruscoe. She was preceded in death by a brother Peter Butkus and grandchildren Eli and Max Chusid-Jacklitz. Alta studied art at Cooper Union and received her BA from College of New Rochelle. She had a lifelong involvement in movements for peace and justice including Women's Strike for Peace, and the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom. She dedicated many years to working with her husband in his pediatric practice. The family wishes to thank the staff at Arden Hill for their kindness in her last months. A private gathering will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations in Alta's name may be sent to WILPS at 339 Lafayette St., New York, NY 10012. Alta's strength, generosity and loving heart will always be remembered.

title: Two New York Hotels To Close for Renovation
description: The search for a hotel room in Manhattan is going to get a shade harder next year, when two hotels -- with a combined 470 rooms -- will close for renovations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISENBERG, CHARLES
description: ISENBERG - Charles. Professor Charles Isenberg died of cancer at his home in Milford, CT on Dec. 4, at the age of 53. He is survived by his wife, Rhea Paul; children, William, Martin and Aviva; parents, Marcia and Arnold Isenberg of Pompano, FL; and brother, David of Fairfield, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to the Charles Isenberg Memorial Fund at Reed College, Portland, OR 97202.

title: Vic Lombardi, 75, a Pitcher On '47 Dodger Pennant Team
description: Vic Lombardi, who was part of a pitching staff that carried the Brooklyn Dodgers to one pennant and part of a trade that helped them win three others, died Wednesday at Community Hospital in Fresno, Calif., following heart surgery. He was 75.

title: Stalled Escalators, for a Year
description: Mary Spilotro has been a teacher at the High School of Graphic Communication Arts since 1963 and can remember distinctly when the escalators in the seven-story school all worked properly. It was during the Reagan Administration, more than a decade ago. ''They weren't too great back in those days, either,'' she said.

title: Learning From 'The Lion King'
description: One child counted down the seconds until the 2 o'clock matinee began. A little girl stared, as did her mother, at the walls and ceiling of the New Amsterdam Theater, whose ornaments intertwined like a jungle of architectural marzipan. One evil parent turned to her son -- or was it to his father? -- and said, ''I want you to know, a ticket to this costs as much as a ticket to Disney World for the whole day.'' But then the lights fell, and within moments the aisles and stage had filled with the animals of invention. Adults gasped, and every child in the audience began to reread an old, familiar text -- the one inscribed on worn videos of Disney's animated ''Lion King'' -- now brought to life by Julie Taymor on Broadway.

title: It Took One to Tango: Piazzolla
description: THE MAN ON THE telephone, 10 years ago, spoke Spanish with a Rioplatense accent. (The Rio de la Plata separates Argentina and Uruguay.) ''This is Astor Piazzolla, and I would like you to conduct my next musical in New York,'' he said. ''Sure,'' I answered, ''this is Christopher Columbus.''

title: Editors' Choice
description: On the 1997 list of best books of the year, chosen by the editors of the Book Review, are five novels, one volume of stories (more or less), two biographies, one history, one volume of science and one true account of a tragic adventure. Of the fiction writers -- four men and two women -- only one, an Englishwoman who began writing novels 20 years ago, when she was 60, has never appeared on this list before. Of the nonfiction authors -- two women and three men -- only one has appeared on the best books list before. In a year that was not notable for translation of new work, eight of the 11 authors are Americans and three are British.

title: Toss Your Hat: Mary and Rhoda Return
description: IN the seemingly ceaseless 1970's revival, it was only a matter of time before television went back to that converted Victorian at 119 North Weatherly for inspiration. Next fall, ABC will reunite Minneapolis's favorite downstairs-upstairs neighbors, Mary Richards and Rhoda Morgenstern, and hurl them into premillennial prime time with a new series that updates both ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' (1970-77) and Valerie Harper's hit spinoff, ''Rhoda'' (1974-78). It'll be interesting to see how our girls turned out.

title: Schedule Shift Throws School Off Balance
description: Packed with approximately 2,000 sixth, seventh and eighth graders, Intermediate School 90 on 168th Street and Jumel Place is among the largest and most crowded schools in the city. In its short three-year life, it has developed coping mechanisms. It is organized into three mini-schools, each with a different academic focus, and the school is on what is called split session, meaning that the sixth and seventh graders arrive at 7:30 A.M. and leave at around 2 P.M. and the eighth graders arrive about 10 A.M. and leave at 4:30.

title: Erin Callahan, Steven Fainaru
description: Erin Lee Callahan and Steven Mark Fainaru were married last evening in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. Judge Rosalba Hurtado Palomera of Puerto Vallarta City Court officiated at Le Kliff, a restaurant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, DORIS A.
description: THOMAS-Doris A. Formerly of Lewisboro, NY died peacefully at home in Norwich, VT., December 2, 1997. Beloved wife of Gordon A. Thomas, devoted mother to Krista Lynn Thomas and Alix Elizabeth Jenkins. Her love of life, generosity, and compassion enriched a wide circle of family and friends. She will always be cherished by the Dartmouth class of 1949 for her many contributions to its activities. In lieu of flowers a memorial gift may be made to Friends of Hopkins/Hurd at 6041 Wilson Hall, Hanover, New Hampshire, 03755 Attn: Chris Larabee or Hospice Vnh-20 South Main Street, White River Junction, Vermont 05001.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: You Say You Didn't Buy It. But Did You Read the Tiny Type?
description: MARY P. BEGGS, a 71-year-old computer enthusiast from Winter Park, Fla., was bargain-hunting at a computer fair with her two daughters during the summer, when a display for the Veterans of America Association caught their eye.

title: Deaths of Students Ring an Old Alarm on Flooding in Los Angeles
description: Despite fences, warning signs and schoolroom lectures indicating that the 470 miles of concrete-lined flood control channels that run through Los Angeles County can turn from dry to deadly in minutes, about six people a year, on average, are caught in the channels and swept to their deaths.

title: Correction
description: A front-page picture caption last Sunday about a Chinese-language class misidentified the teacher. She was Julie Wei, not Huang Chao-Chih. The picture also carried an incorrect credit. The photographer was Maxine Hicks for The New York Times.

title: Architecture
description: LIVING ARCHITECTURE: A Biography of H. H. Richardson. By James F. O'Gorman. Photographs by Cervin Robinson. (Simon & Schuster, $50.) Even during his short life it was commonplace to say that Henry Hobson Richardson (1838-86) made architecture in his own image -- expansively unconventional and warmly welcoming. That close conjunction of the personal and the professional makes the vivid biographical approach of James F. O'Gorman, a professor of art at Wellesley and a leading Richardson scholar, the ideal way to understand this contradictory figure, part Romantic and part Rotarian, who redirected the mainstream of American architecture in the two decades after the Civil War.

title: Prelude to a Film, With a Violin in the Title Role
description: LONG before moving pictures could talk, they were accompanied by music. It sets moods, enhances the story and looms large in filmed biographies of performers and composers. Recent films that experimented with an even more prominent role for music have turned into surprise successes.

title: The Art of R. Crumb. Or at Least Work by Him.
description: ''THE R. CRUMB COFFEE table Art Book'' weeds out the rubberneckers early. If your primary knowledge of the underground cartoonist is through Terry Zwigoff's 1995 documentary, ''Crumb,'' you may leaf through the pages of the lavish tome with a growing sense of disappointment. Where's the wacky, dysfunctional family circus, the suicidal older brother upstairs, the younger brother on a bed of nails in an S.R.O. hotel, the carnal comedy of Crumb's ex-girlfriends discoursing on his sexual dimensions?

title: Study Finds Legality Spreads The Compulsion to Gamble
description: Compulsive gambling among adults increased sharply in the last two decades and was even higher among teen-agers as legalized casinos and lotteries proliferated across the United States and Canada, says a study conducted by the Harvard Medical School and financed by the gambling industry.

title: Henry Dolger, 88, Whose Work Improved Treatment of Diabetics
description: Dr. Henry Dolger, a diabetes expert who was one of the first to document that insulin injections were not in fact a miracle cure for diabetes because of the long-term complications of the disease, died on Wednesday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 88 and lived in Manhattan.

title: On CD's, Instant Cheer And Humbug
description: THE LARGE PILE OF CHRISTMAS CD'S ON MY desk is a reminder that Christ was born to serve people with bad taste as well as good. What a polyglot mix of godly ether and marketing opportunity they are! Sincerity, effeteness and vulgarity are neighbors in my considerable mound of plastic. In it you will find a Christmas for every home and every sensibility, and this may be the point: the church is no longer the magnet for our merriest of holidays; the home entertainment center is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, DR. HARRY M.
description: GLASS-Dr. Harry M. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman Prof. William Schwartz, Pres.

title: God Decentralized
description: For half a century, religion has seemed to be losing its grip on America. This evident development has provoked two quite different responses. Some people have welcomed the erosion as a triumph of rationalism; others have denounced it as the root of mounting social evil.

title: Leon Goldman, 91, A Research Leader In Laser Treatment
description: Dr. Leon Goldman, a pioneer in laser surgery and a leading educator in the field, died on Tuesday in San Diego. He was 91.

title: VIEW; His Way, in His Words
description: FRANK SINATRA knew this long ago: Men had become a mess. They looked like bums and acted like Clydes; had no self-confidence, no swagger, no style; were second-guessing themselves into oblivion, like a bunch of hapless Harveys. (''Harvey,'' or ''Harv,'' he once translated from his patois of ring-a-ding-ding, is ''the typical tourist who goes into a French restaurant and says, 'What's ready?' '' Clydes were no better.)

title: Ramapo Avenges Loss in State Title Game
description: Quarterback Chris Simms, the wound on his chin still fresh from a hard-fought championship victory, stood in the middle of a wild celebration at Kennedy Stadium today, looking and sounding every bit the way his father did after guiding the Giants to a Super Bowl victory after the 1986 season.

title: Notable Books of the Year 1997
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Holiday Books issue of December 1996. It is meant to suggest some of the high points in this year's fiction, poetry, nonfiction, children's books, mysteries and science fiction. The books are arranged alphabetically under genre headings.

title: Nov. 30-Dec. 6; Death at an Early Age
description: Saying only that he acted ''like I was in a dream,'' a 14-year-old boy shot to death three classmates and wounded five others as they gathered for a morning prayer Monday in a high school in Kentucky. Michael Carneal, a smallish, bespectacled ninth-grader at Heath High in West Paducah, fired 10 shots before Benjamin Strong, a football player and preacher's son, told him to stop. The prosecutor said the boy saw the 1995 movie, ''Basketball Diaries,'' in which students were shot to death in a dream scene. RICK BRAGG

title: GENERATIONS ; Leaping Through the Years With Grace and Discipline
description: Time passes, for mortals and fairies alike. One day the Sugarplum Fairy is being squired around the stage by a handsome Cavalier, and then the curtain falls. Suddenly it's 40 years later. Sugarplum has hung up her pointe shoes and retired into the role of party guest. So has the Mouse King, after incarnations as Drosselmeier and Mother Ginger along the way. But Irine Fokine is still counting out their steps.

title: Q&A: Fred Spivak ; Adding Polish to the Image of Wall Street
description: AFTER 13 years with a company that sells housewares and knives, Fred Spivak is taking a stab at a new career. He is getting out of the frying pan business and into the fire.

title: VIEWPOINT; A Race Against the Calendar
description: THE ''year 2000'' problem poses a serious threat that could disrupt the United States economy and bring about a yearlong global recession beginning in January 2000. Such a recession could be as severe as the 1973-74 global downturn that was caused by the OPEC oil embargo -- a useful analogy for the economic consequences of the current situation.

title: Please Hold for Ms. Euphemism
description: You're on the phone, trying to complain to the company about that new gizmo you just bought. But the switchboard operator puts you on hold, asking you to wait to speak to ''the chairman's office.'' Or, if you're trying to obtain account information, you're told to wait for your ''personal care representatives.'' Companies come up with all kinds of confusing titles for the people you need to reach. What are these labels, and what do these workers really do? Send your best stores to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or sent them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Caught on the Sidelines At a Sensational Trial
description: There is no longer any chanting, no longer any marching. The placards that were present on the opening day of jury selection are absent, and the sidewalk outside State Supreme Court here is tranquil for the most part.

title: Land Purchase To Help Restore The Everglades
description: The Clinton Administration and the State of Florida agreed today to buy more than 50,000 acres of sugar cane fields on the outskirts of Everglades National Park, the latest step toward rescuing the endangered ecosystem from polluted runoff.

title: FILM; At the Center of 'Amistad,' A Determined African Actor
description: IN THE EARLY 1970'S, WEDNESDAY was movie day for thousands of children at the Vogue Theater in Cotenou, Benin. School let out at noon, and students could trade five empty sacks of Omo laundry detergent for a free ticket. All week, children rooted through garbage and went door to door to collect the precious bags.

title: Can You Park There? The Fine Points of Signs and Fines
description: You're driving on a crowded midtown street, losing hope of ever finding a parking spot. Then, lo and behold, a spot appears, with no meter and no sign telling you not to park. If you do, is it legal?

title: A Mellow Clinton at Ease in His Role
description: President Clinton's friends and associates marveled for years at the zest with which he delved into the minutiae of policy and the latest blips of opinion polls. Now, major figures in Government say they are struck by the degree that Mr. Clinton drifts into soliloquies about another longtime passion, golf.

title: Of Clothes, Sing Heavenly Muse!; The enigmatic women who inspire the creations of fashion's top designers.
description: DURING the 12 years that Amanda Harlech worked for love, not money, alongside John Galliano, the meeting of the minds was so instinctive that she would just say, ''I like red,'' and the maverick designer would be off on a creative tear. She would change clothes ''four, five, six times a day,'' she said, ''because great ideas would come from nowhere, and suddenly everything you were wearing would be completely wrong, and you'd have to reinvent yourself.''

title: SOAPBOX; The New Jersey Angle
description: HE was physically and personally unassuming, and the squeaky voice reminded you of Mickey Mouse.

title: CHATTER ; Holiday Food Temptations
description: Do you try to resist all the food temptations that appear around the holidays? If so, what are your strategies?

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'Nutcracker' in Stamford

title: Americans Can Use the Law to Control Cloning; Second-Class Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, RUTH
description: MEYER-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Harry. We deeply mourn the passing of our dear aunt Ruth. Graveside service today, at Maimonides Cemetery, at 1 PM. All the Nieces, Nephews, Grands and Greatgrands

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: I must take issue with two of the letters (Nov. 16) responding to Lisa Belkin's ''Pregnant With Complications.'' Lise Chase writes that ''a child should not be created to make his mother happy.'' But every child is created because the mother believes that it will make her happy. Otherwise, what woman would have one?

title: The Card, at Least, Isn't Torn in Half
description: IT was a divorce ruling that upper-crust America eagerly awaited. Last week, a Connecticut judge awarded the wife of the chief executive of GE Capital Services half the couple's cash, stocks and other hard assets -- along with his Macy's credit card and its lifetime 45 percent discount.

title: A Corps Feeling Unwanted
description: Bob Germino sat in the kitchen of the Greenpoint Volunteer Ambulance Corps sipping coffee and nibbling on doughnuts to pass the time. The dispatcher phone was silent. Mr. Germino has stood ready to respond to accidents and ailments since the corps was founded in 1964, but now his services are rarely called upon.

title: Sweet and Salty
description: ATLANTIC CITY without saltwater taffy?

title: Doctor Infected With H.I.V. Blames Her Training by Yale
description: Seven weeks into her medical residency at Yale-New Haven Hospital in 1988, a 25-year-old doctor was asked to put a catheter into an artery of a terminally ill AIDS patient.

title: Continuing Education Plan Lacks Supporting Data
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pop Perfectionist on a Crowded Stage
description: I dislike reading interviews with Paul Simon as much as he professes to detest giving them. Why not make both of us happy and spare us any future profiles?

title: Robert Redford Has This Problem
description: As a longtime admirer of Robert Redford's active environmentalism, I read Walter Kirn's article ''Robert Redford Has This Problem'' with interest. But my heart sank when I learned that not only does Redford drive a 4-by-4, but his concern for the threats to Western wilderness has not stopped him from building on the land he wanted to keep safe from developers. He is sending the message that if you have enough money to make it esthetically pleasing, build away.

title: Running the F.B.I.
description: In Bruce Porter's article ''Running the F.B.I.'' (Nov. 2), I was inaccurately portrayed. I am not now nor have I ever claimed to be a spokesman for any current or former agents' network and certainly not for ''retired members of the bureau's 'good ol' boy' set.''

title: Mental Health, and Help
description: The problems of the neediest New Yorkers are often compounded by mental illness, which can mean a lonely, constrained life in a hospital or shelter, or on the streets. But with help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, more of these people are finding their balance, as well as jobs, apartments and second chances.

title: Gulf War's First U.S. Casualty Leaves Lasting Trail of Mystery
description: Four years ago, a hunter looking for wild game in western Iraq stumbled across the ruins of an American fighter jet.

title: Lisa Cannon and Stuart Ramson
description: Dr. Lisa Marie Cannon, a daughter of Anne and James Cannon of Wyckoff, N.J., was married yesterday to Stuart Veitch Ramson, a son of Janet and John Ramson of Masterton, New Zealand. The Rev. Walter Modrys performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RABIN, THOMAS D.
description: RABIN-Thomas D. 5/29/63-12/7/87 You're in our hearts and thoughts forever. Love, Mom, and Dad, Ruth and Steve Rabin; sister and brother-in-law, Betsy and Shimshon Gabay; nephews you never knew, Thomas and Benjamin Gabay.

title: Blunt Reason For Enlarging NATO: Curbs On Germany
description: Using an argument little heard in the debate over NATO expansion in the United States, Zbigniew Brzezinski, the former national security adviser to Jimmy Carter, said today that the absorption of three Central European nations into NATO resolved a problem that was considered ''impolite'' to mention: the ''disproportionate power'' of Germany.

title: New Kids Making More Enemies Than Friends
description: These are not your father's expansion teams. Or as Chuck LaMar said: ''Everybody thinks expansion is long term. Building is long term. Because of finances, demands are placed on us to be competitive. The word expansion creates a misnomer.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Nov. 23, with an article about the wedding of the model Kristen McMenamy, carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Eric Robert, for the Sygma agency.

title: In Child Abuse Cases, Greater Empathy Espoused for Victims
description: IN her lectures to Suffolk County lawyers on how to deal with victims of child abuse, Eileen Treacy, a psychologist routinely begins her talk with this question: ''How would you like to get up before an audience and describe your last consensual sexual experience?''

title: Faith Is a Moving Target; When Is a Catholic Not a Catholic?
description: It is Sunday evening on the campus of Purdue University, and students fill the chapel of the St. Thomas Aquinas Center for a late Mass. The airy, bright church seats 1,200 people, and it's the third time this Sunday that the pews have been filled to capacity. In fact, the total number of weekend worshipers at St. Tom's, as the Catholic Center is universally called, is seldom less than 3,500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSMAN, KAREN
description: SUSMAN-Karen. We are stunned and saddened by the death of our friend Karen Susman. On behalf of the students and alumni of Yale and the Founders of Joseph Slifka Center for Jewish Life at Yale, we extend our condolences to Karen's husband, Stephen, and to their children, Harry and Stacy. Yale Hillel Board of Trustees

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: T.G.I. Fifth Avenue Fills a Hungry Hole

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKERMAN, SAM
description: BECKERMAN-Sam, beloved husband of Eszter Gyory, past president of Young Men's Philanthropic League NYC, Chairman Emeritus of Designcraft Industries, Inc. has departed on December 1, 1997. His generous charitable and philanthropic endeavors had touched the hearts of those he had known personally, as well as those whom he did not know. All of them have benefited from his generous giving and care. He created Designcraft Industries in the early sixties. Through acquisitions and internal growth, Designcraft had emerged as the leading precious metal jewelry manufacturing company of the eighties. Under his guidance, Designcraft successfully completed the public offering of its shares, culminating in the listing on the American Stock Exchange. He is survived by his wife Eszter, his two sons Larry and Daniel and his daughter Ann, his brother Sidney and his sisters Zelda, Sharon, Adele and Ethel and two grandchildren. The Memorial Service will be held on December 11th at Gyory Art Studio, 40 NE 40th Street Miami Art and Design District 5-7 PM, Telephone: 305575-6587.

title: On the Horns Of a Golden Dilemma
description: THE opening in 1955 of Istanbul's first modern luxury hotel, the Hilton, is now considered a landmark in the city's development. It signified a somewhat belated recognition that new generations of Western tourists were discovering this ancient metropolis, and that they needed some of the creature comforts offered by other European cities.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MELCER, CARRIE
description: MELCER-Carrie. December 11, 1940. The noiseless foot of time steals swiftly by, but thoughts of you are always nigh. Rest well, dear mother. Herbert

title: Backtalk; Good Sports Are Harder To Find
description: Just when it seemed as though sportsmanship was finally dead and buried, thank goodness, along came Long Island University's basketball team to beat Medgar Evers College by 117 points. Other coaches thought this was ''not sportsmanship,'' and the winning coach actually thought he needed to offer an apology. He said that he regretted it had happened, and that he was sorry.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Winning Coach Set to Retire
description: WHEN Ed Bengermino first began his coaching career, Richard Nixon was President, the high school he taught at was called Andrew Warde, and it had yet to form a girls' volleyball program.

title: The Nation; The Honest Dialogue That Is Neither
description: HERE we go again.

title: Baymen Offer to Modify Seining for Stripers
description: THE East Hampton Marine Museum on Bluff Road in Amagansett sits on the double dunes, east of Indian Wells beach and west of Atlantic. It is a fitting spot for the East Hampton Baymen to gather as they did on the Thursday before Thanksgiving to discuss the political progress of haul seining, a form of fishing used by baymen for centuries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARNEY, PETER
description: CARNEY-Peter. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Peter Carney, associated with The Times from 1957, until retiring in 1991.

title: When Parting Is Such Strange Sorrow
description: Losing a job is never fun. Some dismissals are handled with tact; others with a heavy hand. Sometimes, in retrospect, there is cause for laughter. Sometimes the sting lingers. And sometimes losing a job can be a healthy lesson in life.

title: Ideas & Trends; Ethical Fears Aside, Science Plunges On
description: WITH the prospect of human cloning becoming less unthinkable by the day, it seems almost quaint that a mere decade ago people were up in arms over the perils of spraying strawberries with bacteria genetically altered to prevent frost.

title: 'An Exhibit Denied'
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Moscow's Gain Be a Loss For Investors?
description: LENIN must be spinning in his tomb. The city of Moscow, once the capital of global Communism, could soon be the parent of an American mutual fund.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS/INWOOD; Community Urges City to Beat Back a Club
description: Beginning in 1956, Joseph Lechle ran a no-frills tavern called Joe L's on Broadway and West 192d Street. It was a mainstay of the neighborhood. When drug dealers began making the place their own three years ago, Mr. Lechle added some frills and turned it into a gay bar.

title: Faith Is an Option; Belief by the Numbers
description: Just How Religious Are We?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAISON, JOHN WILLIAMS
description: FAISON-John Williams. On December 5, 1997, in his 80th year. Beloved husband of Grace Gray Faison. Devoted father of Sandy Faison and Jeff Stockly Faison. Dear brother of Seth Shepard Faison, Sr. Adored grandfather of Jeneve Noel Pendleton, John Richard Faison, Jeffrey Shepard Faison, Molly Remsen Brush and Lucy Gray Brush. Memorial service onTuesday, December 9, 11 AM, at Plymouth Church of The Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn Heights. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, or the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, 285 Schermerhorn St., Brooklyn, NY 11217.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: LONG WAS THE WINTER ROAD THEY TRAVELED: A Tale of the Nativity. By J. Patrick Lewis. Illustrated by Drew Bairley. Dial. $14.99. (All ages) A contemporary retelling of the Nativity in appealingly simple verse that a very young child might understand, with illustrations in oil painting.

title: Quality Child Care Comes at a Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Relaxing with monkeys and birds in a rain forest
description: Lapa Rios is not actually a treehouse, but that's what this immense thatched lodge in the jungle presiding over 14 elegant aerielike bungalows feels like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLING, MILDRED
description: KLING-Mildred. Beloved wife of the late Albert, devoted mother of Ellen and Stephen Leifer and Jason and Randi Kling. Cherished grandmother of Margot Leifer, loving sister of Frances Sharkey. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday, 1:30 PM.

title: Why They Kill Their Newborns
description: In ''Why They Kill Their Newborns'' (Nov. 2), Steven Pinker writes that ''the right to life must come . . .from morally significant traits that we humans happen to possess.'' He includes a list of traits like dread of death, which should determine whom we can kill and whom we must let live. He thus bids us throw out the principle of human equality that is the bedrock of justice in America. And so, suddenly, we find ourselves discussing the legitimacy of infanticide -- euphemistically couched as ''neonaticide.''

title: 11 Deaths in 3 Train Blasts Fan Indian Fears of Election Violence
description: Three bombs killed 11 people and injured 54 on trains in southern India today, raising fears that the campaign for a general election in February could be marred by violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUB, MURRAY
description: LAUB-Murray. Of New Rochelle. Passed away December 5 in Delray Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Diana. Loving father of Sandra Chodos and David Laub. Caring brother of Miriam Zweig and the late Julian. Adored grandfather of Paulina, Simon and Emma. Services Monday, 1:30 PM, at the Westchester Riverside, 21 Broad Street, Mount Vernon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Cancer Foundation.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chevrolet Express; Berthing Those Babies
description: CHEVROLET has presented Kenny and Bobbi McCaughey a 1998 Chevy Express van so they can fetch home their septuplets, Iowa's neo-natal celebrities. My wife said it best: ''There must be easier ways to get a free van.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRATTY, HOWARD J.
description: McGRATTY-Howard J. On December 5, 1997, of Garden City. (Attorney-at-law). Memorial Mass Wednesday, 10:00 AM, St. Joseph's RC Church, Garden City, LI.

title: Two Pairs in Lead

title: Travel
description: People used to travel to visit holy shrines, to brood on romantic ruins and scenic vistas, to discover ''new'' flora and fauna, to benefit from encounters with other cultures -- and with themselves. But now, if some writers are to be believed, one leaves home in order to have terrifying experiences, perilous near misses from which one barely escapes with one's life. The authors of this season's travel books represent the whole range -- from explorers of yesteryear to modern daredevils facing exotic natural disasters and confronting (or provoking) the ire of justifiably suspicious locals, unaware that they are about to wind up as characters in a book.

title: A Scaled-Down City Government Has Fewer Jobs for the Hopeful

description: HUNDREDS of thousands of American workers use deferred-pay arrangements that let them leave part of their salaries and bonuses on deposit with their employer so that the money will grow untaxed in investments until they cash out, usually after retirement.

With all those bright kids out there who don't know about Truffaut and Fellini, I just may have a chance in this industry.

title: Essay; American Dreamers: Melville and Kerouac
description: In the autumn of 1957 I was 19 years old, in the Navy and also more or less permanently in the grip of romantic adolescent impulses. That year, I rashly volunteered to serve with the last of the Byrd expeditions to the Antarctic continent aboard the U.S.S. Arneb. The Arneb would depart New England in December for the bases Adm. Richard E. Byrd had established at Little America on McMurdo Sound in Antarctica. It would then proceed to circumnavigate the globe, steaming outside the shipping lanes and tracking solar storms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMENS, THEODORE
description: KAMENS-Theodore. Of Tamarac, FL. Passed away on December 5, 1997. Ted was a practicing attorney. Graduate of Columbia University and Brooklyn Law School. Member of Trial Lawyers Association in New York City. He maintained an active law practice after retiring to Florida. He was a member of the Woodlands Country Club for many years. He is survived by his beloved wife Minna. Devoted father of Karen and Dr. H. Kenneth Jackier, Roberta Eden, Peggy Kamens and Jim Mendell. Adored grandfather of Eric Jackier, Diane Jackier, Douglas and Marie Eden, Russell Mendell, Jake Mendell and MollyRose Mendell. His family mourns his death and celebrates his long and fruitful life. Services will be held at the Riverside Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY on Monday at 10 AM.

Sweeny, the new president of the College of New Rochelle, what he thinks about the efforts of women to get into formerly all-male schools like the Citadel and he will concede that he has mixed feelings. The College of New Rochelle is a women's college, and Dr. Sweeny says he believes strongly in the benefit of one-sex schools. title: Saves the Crystal

At a party for Vibe magazine's spring fashion issue at Twirl, a club in Chelsea, below, guests sipped from splits of Taittinger on Wednesday. They're not alone. Emmanuelle Chiche, the managing director of the Bubble Lounge in TriBeCa, said that small splits of Champagne are selling briskly and that a lot of people are drinking it with straws, a practice that she said started to take off a few months ago. ''Mind you, these are not Champagne connoisseurs,'' she said. ''They are trying to be cute and add an edge to the drink.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WABER, MORRIS
description: WABER-Morris. The oldest active member of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, died on December 2, 1997, at the age of 97. A man universally loved, admired and respected, he was a mentor for many generations of members of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange where, on the occasion of his 95th birthday, he was honored by a testimonial dinner lauding him as the patriarch and elder statesman of the exchange. He was a principal in the stock brokerage firm of Dackerman & Waber, Inc., which, with Harry Dackerman, he helped found over 65 years ago. A kind and gentle man, he was known for his ethics and integrity. He cherished his family, young and old. He loved large and small family gatherings, over which he presided with great humor and wonderful stories of his travels and experiences. He was beloved by all who knew him for his ready friendship, great generosity of spirit and his philanthropy, both personally and through his foundation. A veteran of World War II, he was a world traveler who loved his country as the land of freedom and opportunity. He was the last member of a family of seven brothers and sisters. His nephews and nieces, Harry Waber, Morton Waber, Alfred Waber, Judy Ackerman, Bernard Friedman, Phyllis Treusch, Tanya Corbin, Irwin Jacobs, their spouses, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren mourn his death. A private service was conducted on December 5, 1997.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW ; A Rap Pioneer Defies the Odds
description: RAKIM IS TO RAP WHAT Mick Jagger is to rock: an artist who helped give birth to a musical genre and yet remains relevant and popular today. Eleven years ago Rakim led a quiet musical revolution, introducing a soft-spoken rapping style. His raps were built on complex rhyming schemes, and while his Long Island neighbors in Public Enemy were bringing black nationalism to rap, Rakim, a member of the Nation of Islam, made allusions to a thoughtful spirituality.

title: Photography
description: The territory of books devoted to fine photography is expanding in a late-20th-century photographic version of Manifest Destiny. Publishers, like museums, are widening their purview beyond the self-conscious art of photography to encompass police mug shots, rock-and-roll publicity pictures, snapshots of art gallery openings and portraits from commercial studios. Some of these ventures prove unsatisfying both as art and as books, but the effort to avoid deja vu also has turned up interesting and overlooked work. ''Seydou Keita'' (Scalo), which features striking studio portraits by a self-taught photographer from Mali, is one example; another is ''John Deakin: Photographs'' (Vendome), which is noteworthy primarily because Deakin's pictures were once used as references for paintings by Francis Bacon.

title: Cooking

In a purely utilitarian world it would exist to perform one task only: provide instructions on how to make things, the culinary equivalent of a furniture-refinishing manual. Some cookbooks are like that, but many are not -- certainly not the best ones, which open a window on a different way of life or a new way of thinking. They could, with some justice, be shelved in one of the bookstore sections assigned to travel, biography, history or the personal essay, which is why cookbook fans often spend less time at the stove than stretched out on the sofa, turning the pages and letting their imaginations wander to that happiest of places, the culinary Elysium where all food is perfectly prepared and all settings are romantic, where no bill arrives and no one gains weight.
