title: Gardening
description: What is a garden for? ''Pleasure'' is the obvious answer, though you'd never know it from reading Americans on the subject. We have an old habit in this country of weighing down our gardening -- indeed, all our commerce with nature -- with barrowfuls of moral and political significance, an inheritance, no doubt, from the Puritans and probably also the Transcendentalists. When Allen Lacy was combing American garden writing for his anthology a few years back, he reported he was unable to find a single discussion of scent or color until the turn of this century. Historically we gardened for many reasons -- nutrition, health and even moral betterment -- but not often for the sheer sensual and esthetic delight of it.

title: Imagining the Disappeared
description: TALES FROM THE

title: Where Performers Fill Every Seat in the House
description: WHAT POSSESSED Anna Deavere Smith, the ingenious theater performer who mines verbatim monologues from life, to imagine drama could be found in the utterances of this city's political stock company of hopelessly self-referential performers?

title: Donald Carnegie McKenna, 90, Philanthropist
description: Donald Carnegie McKenna, a retired Pennsylvania industrialist, a philanthropist and the namesake of Claremont McKenna College in California, died on Nov. 26 at his home in South Laguna, Calif. He was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDMAN, AARON
description: SCHNEIDMAN-Aaron. Beloved husband of the late Anna (Polivy). Devoted father of Marcia and Arthur Brody. Loving grandfather of Laurence and Phyllis Brody and Carol and Robby Morris. Adored great grandfather of David, Rebecca, Brian, Evan and Hayden. Funeral Service on Sunday, 1 PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Faith Is a Revelation; A Voice In the Wilderness
description: It was on a sharp, cold night in the Wisconsin woods that I heard the Voice. I was on a retreat at Womanquest, a Unitarian Universalist gathering on Lake Geneva. The following day, I was set to be one of the meeting's two keynote speakers. The other speaker was Starhawk, a leader of the feminist spirituality movement who had brought us to the woods to participate in a spiral dance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIMOWITZ, LOUIS
description: HEIMOWITZ-Louis. Age 82, of Miami Beach, formerly of Boro Park, passed away Tuesday, December 2, 1997; survived by his beloved wife Rose, children Stanley and Eileen, grandchildren Marc (Miriam), Jill and Erica, and brother Ben. He is loved and will be missed by many.

title: Orthodox Jewish Group Plans a $2 Million Advertising Drive
description: One of the nation's most influential Orthodox Jewish organizations plans to spend $2 million in coming weeks on advertisements to counter public statements by Reform and Conservative groups that have been working to gain official recognition for non-Orthodox rabbis in Israel.

title: The Mother Of All Independents
description: Everybody, just hold your schnecken. Jesse Green's endearing piece on the Weinstein brothers' mother overlooked one subtle detail. While Miriam Weinstein distributes rugelach and gift baskets throughout her sons' studio, the boys are conveniently out of town. Coincidence? Hardly. They're probably across the street at a coffee shop, waiting for Mom to finish feeding and schmoozing. From one Jewish son to another, it's not easy having a Jewish mother, especially when she's sitting across from you at work, gossiping with your secretary about your dermatological records, prolonged bachelorhood and poor spelling.

title: Editorial Observer; Waking Up -- Too Late -- in the Token Role
description: The conservative revolution started with the premise that a liberal orthodoxy had hijacked the culture and muzzled public debate. In truth, the architects of the right -- Irving Kristol, Paul Weyrich, Pat Robertson, William Buckley -- were advancing an orthodoxy of their own, one that cast liberalism as an evil to be wiped out at any cost. With conservatives controlling the national agenda -- and the word liberal reduced to a slur -- the goal is clearly within reach.

title: Soup Kitchens Fill After Idaho Welfare Cuts
description: As Idaho's new welfare law nears the five-month mark, the number of people on welfare has fallen sharply, but the lines at soup kitchens are stretching into the streets.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a typographical error, a letter to the editor on Nov. 16, about a taxi fare dispute in Rome, misstated the amount the driver paid the letter writer to withdraw his charges of being grossly overcharged for a trip from the airport. It was 500,000 lire, not 50,000 (about $30.60, not $3.06). (The letter writer said the payment was made after a police sergeant told him that the charges could be withdrawn if a private agreement was reached.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ELSIE PERESS
description: BERNSTEIN-Elsie Peress. The Officers, Trustees and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to her husband Murray Bernstein, her sons Herbert and Maurice Peress and their families our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Alan Levine, Chrmn of the Board Robert P. Antler, President

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 31 about Halifax, Nova Scotia, misstated the relative size of a munitions ship explosion in the city's harbor in 1917. A reader's letter received on Nov. 21 points out that the blast was the largest of its kind until the atomic bomb test in New Mexico in 1945, not the largest until the bombing of Hiroshima itself, three weeks later.

title: $100 Million Bill to Clean East End Dumps
description: TAXPAYERS on the East End will have to pay more than $100 million to seal or mine former dumps. Officials estimate the cleanup bill for two dumps in East Hampton alone at nearly $80 million.

title: In Boom Times, Restaurants Offer Luxury
description: THE stock market is booming and so is the Long Island restaurant scene. The improved business climate has encouraged local restaurateurs to take a plunge back into palatial luxury dining spots that have a French rather than Italian spin and stress elegance and excellence rather than economy. The first of them, the magnificent chateau-like Louis XVI on the Great South Bay in Patchogue, opened recently to raves from critics and diners alike. Now comes Enoteca.

title: A SUSPENDED PLAYER, A SHAKEN LEAGUE
description: James Gordon first encountered Latrell Sprewell 10 years ago in a crowded corridor between classes. The varsity basketball coach at Washington High School in Milwaukee stopped the 6-foot 5-inch sinewy senior and asked if he would come out for the team.

title: MUSIC ; With Holidays, Free Concerts Come as Bonus
description: BUDGETS tend to get strained as the holidays approach, so it is comforting to note that several of this week's concerts are free. At 10 this morning, for instance, the St. Andrew's Singers will be at White Plains Presbyterian Church, with David Ralph conducting the chorus and assisting instrumentalists in Britten's ''Ceremony of Carols'' along with other music appropriate for this first Advent Sunday.

title: Maintaining the Model Train Tradition in a Digital World
description: The once-proud miniature metal steam and diesel train engines are coming in at the rate of seven a day. They arrive in parcels, bags and the hands of children, tenderly holding trains bought years ago by their parents and grandparents and now scratched, bent, broken or snarled in cat hair and needles from Christmas trees now long dead.

title: Walter J. Addems, 98, Aviation Pioneer, Barnstormer and Airline Official, Is Dead
description: Walter J. Addems, a pioneering aviator who built his first plane in 1916 and his last one in the 1960's, but only after he had barnstormed across the nation and flown the mail in the 1920's, trained pilots in the 1930's and served as director of flight operations for United Airlines until the 1950's, died on Nov. 21 at a hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 98 and for all his love of aviation, had not flown since the 1980's.

title: Torquay
description: To the Editor: After reading Iris Ihde Frey's article, I was reminded of an incident Agatha Christie might have experienced in childhood.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Less Density Helps Sell West Orange on 2 Projects
description: THE future of two of the last large parcels in West Orange, put on hold by the real estate recession of the early 90's, now appears to be set.

title: QUICK BITE/Chatham; Serving Up Italian Food and Conversation
description: From national chains to mom-and-pop pizzerias, Italian food is never hard to find in New Jersey.

title: Foes of a Tower May Have Only Themselves to Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Holidays, a Gardener's Fancy Turns to Tools
description: NO doubt there's at least one gardener on your gift list this holiday season, and the nation's merchandisers have a multitude of items aimed at the hoe-and-humus set.

title: Going Postal
description: A CERTAIN JUSTICE

title: In a Game Built on Fantasy, the Perennials Win
description: Toy testers and publishers of the Oppenheim Toy Portfolio newsletter call certain toys ''the blue chips.''

title: Nov. 30-Dec. 6; A Landmark for Land Mines
description: Most nations of the world -- but not the United States, China or Russia -- signed a treaty banning the manufacture, use and stockpiling of the anti-personnel mines that kill or maim 26,000 people yearly. Jody Williams, the Nobel Peace laureate who led the anti-mine campaign that propelled nations to the treaty, said efforts to get the United States to sign would continue. The 100 million mines buried around the world will not disappear immediately, nor will the ban do much for an estimated 250,000 amputees. But the 122 nations that signed the pact considered it an important beginning. ANTHONY DePALMA

title: Cynthia Zarin and Joseph Goddu
description: Cynthia Rebecca Zarin, a poet and writer, and Joseph George Goddu, an art dealer, were married last evening at their home in New York. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, the dean emeritus of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, officiated. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel assisted in the ceremony.

title: Love and Dreams In Harlem
description: THE palpable buzz of anticipation that precedes curtain times at the Long Wharf in New Haven affirms that audiences are catching onto vital signs of renewed life and malleable intelligence in a theater rediscovered.

title: Office Murders, Fantasy of Course
description: THE SETTING: The premiere of ''Office Killer,'' an independent film about the Machiavellian side of a magazine. It is a devastating sendup of fashionista writers and editors, portrayed mostly as chain-smoking, backstabbing and opportunistically sexually promiscuous types. (A nerdy copy editor, Dorine, played by Carol Kane, kills most of them.)

title: Lost in Translation; South Africa's American Romance
description: NEXT month, choirs from the mixed-race neighborhoods of Cape Town will put on the city's best-known annual event: the Coon Carnival. They will paint their faces black with big white lips, pop on straw boaters, pluck banjos and parade through the streets singing what they call ''coon classics'' like ''Daar Kom die Alabama,'' a paean heralding the Confederate raider that defeated two Union warships off Cape Town in 1863.

title: Huskies Smother Scarlet Knights
description: The Connecticut Huskies carried four scenarios into their first Big East road game today. Three involved offensive schemes they hoped would outstrip a struggling Rutgers team. The fourth was more elemental: just keep the shorthanded Scarlet Knights from scoring.

title: Radio's Renegade
description: For most of his life, Stephen Dunifer did not hesitate to speak out or become involved in causes, from saving redwoods to protesting the Persian Gulf war. But the only cause that has put him in the limelight is his current one: the battle to open the nation's airwaves to small, low-power stations like his Free Radio Berkeley.

title: Capital Looks Outside For New Police Chief
description: With crime rates rising, case closure rates falling and the fear of violence pervasive around the District of Columbia, local officials last year chose the Metropolitan Police Department as the first of many troubled municipal agencies to get overhauled.

title: Cargo Planes Grounded, Moscow Seeks Crash's Cause
description: Russia grounded its fleet of AN-124 transport planes today as investigators searched for the cause of a devastating plane crash in Siberia.

title: Denied Food Stamps, Many Immigrants Scrape for Meals
description: In Manhattan, a 53-year-old workfare participant from the Dominican Republic sweeps the city streets, searching for a glimmer of silver amid the trash. And he pockets the dirty nickels and dimes for food with a desperation that leaves his cheeks burning with shame.

title: Schubert, In the Fond Hands Of a Friend
description: A recent bout with pneumonia has forced the pianist Andre Watts to cancel some performances. Reportedly, he was still recovering on Saturday night, when he presented an all-Schubert recital in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He did seem to be fatigued, for in places his playing lacked incisiveness, and his tone was sometimes pallid. But in a program that was demanding technically and intellectually, he mostly played with his characteristic fluidity and lyricism.

title: Grooves And Poems To Fire Up Devotees Of Funk
description: The best funk has a martial aspect to it; it declares itself independent, with its own way of thinking and living and riles up the troops to send them off to fight whatever wars have to be fought. It has power and skill, and in its exhilaration takes a back seat to no one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEREDITH, ERLENE
description: MEREDITH-Erlene, on December 3, 1997, our family lost our cherished friend after her long and valiant battle with ovarian cancer. She was an unforgettable presence in the lives of all who knew her. With love and enthusiasm, she dedicated her life to the operatic career of her husband, Morley Meredith, distinguished baritone with the Metropolitan Opera for over thirty years. With her dynamic personality and dramatic flair, she brought friends and colleagues, artist and impresarios into her family circle. Erlene brightened every operatic occasion, backstage and off-stage, and at home in Scarsdale at ''Villa Voce,'' where she entertained in great style. Her generosity of heart and indomitable spirit remain forever with us. Emily and Eugene Grant Terry, Andrea and Carolyn Grant

title: Joel Barlow, 89, Expert on Tax Law
description: Joel Barlow, a Washington tax lawyer and former treasurer of the United States Chamber of Commerce, died Tuesday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 89.

title: Faulk Finds Holes In the Jets' Defense
description: Marshall Faulk played his eighth game against the Jets yesterday, and it turned out to be his biggest: 133 yards on 23 carries. And don't forget that his 58-yard reception set up one touchdown, while he ran for another.

title: Dario Fo Thanks Academy For Ennobling the Jesters
description: Clearly relishing the controversy his Nobel Prize has provoked, Dario Fo, the Italian comic actor-playwright, delivered an off-the-cuff performance today before the Swedish Academy in Stockholm, trumpeting the virtues of jesters through the ages.

title: 10 Years Later, Brawley Saga Stirs Fewer Passions
description: For 20 minutes last Tuesday night, Tawana Brawley stood on the altar of Bethany Baptist Church, the overflow crowd chanting, ''We believe you Tawana'' and ''Keep the pressure on,'' and, suddenly, the minutes seemed to erase the 10 long years since her story had first convulsed New York.

title: Mr. Cohen's Caution on Bosnia
description: Through a series of suggestive hints, the Clinton Administration is sidling toward a decision to keep American forces in Bosnia beyond their scheduled June 1998 departure date. The latest pronouncement came from Defense Secretary William Cohen, who met with other NATO defense ministers in Brussels last week. Mr. Cohen chose his words on Bosnia more carefully, and wisely, than Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and the national security adviser, Samuel Berger, have in the recent past.

title: Why Irradiated Food Isn't Consumers' Choice; Ozone Is Superior
description: To the Editor:

title: Many PC Buyers Prefer Power to Sub-$1,000 Tag
description: The ballyhooed sub-$1,000 personal computer could prove to be a disappointment for the computer industry this holiday season, according to a recent survey of consumers.

title: Two Swiss Banks Plan a Merger, Forming Global Financial Giant
description: Two banking giants, Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation, announced early today that they planned to merge, creating the world's second largest bank.

title: True North Pushes Fight With Publicis
description: There have been further developments in the takeover and legal battles between True North Communications and Publicis S. A. concerning True North's proposed acquisition of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Other Invasion
description: Watching the latest go-round with Saddam Hussein, it would be easy to conclude that in the Middle East nothing ever changes. Things just go round and round. In fact, though, just beyond the headlines there are some intriguing forces at work. Saddam Hussein is not the only agent of change in this region.

title: As Memory or as History, Pearl Harbor Is Recalled
description: ''This is my last hurrah,'' Hank Lachenmayer said today before stepping out to lead a Navy band in ceremonies marking the 56th anniversary of the surprise attack on Pearl Harbor by the Japanese.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Sports of The Times ; A Season's Work Goes Out the Window
description: IN the final minutes of the Jets' 22-14 loss to the Indianapolis Colts yesterday, none of Bill Parcells's players were standing near him on the sideline. They knew better. They didn't need an interpreter to translate his body language.

title: Defense (Yes, Defense) Rallies Round Kanell, and the Giants Roll
description: The coach issued the challenge to the quarterback, but all the Giants responded today.

title: Coats Wanted
description: The annual New York Cares Coat Drive, just beginning its ninth year, is a valued tradition that literally brings warmth to the holidays. Before the drive ends on Dec. 31, its organizers hope to collect 85,000 ''gently used'' adult- and kid-sized winter coats for distribution to the homeless, the elderly poor and needy youngsters in New York and New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTON, OLGA
description: MARTON - Olga. Congregation Ohab Zedek Belle Harbor mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our esteemed member, Florence Ness. May the bereaved family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob Reiner, Rabbi Mendy Bauman, Stanley Liker, Presidium

title: Self-regulation in cyberspace: the Web site for Beanie Babies undergoes several changes.
description: THE company that sells the successful Beanie Babies line of stuffed toys is making several significant modifications to its popular World Wide Web site -- addressing concerns about children and privacy issues -- under the advertising industry's voluntary self-regulatory process to resolve disputes.

title: Romme Sets Record
description: The Dutch skater Gianni Romme set a speedskating world record at 5,000 meters in Heerenveen, the Netherlands, yesterday, winning the World Cup event in 6 minutes 30.63 seconds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, OWEN MILTON
description: SCOTT-Owen Milton, 72. On December 5, 1997. Retired architectural graphic designer with Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Born November 22, 1925, in Cozad, NE. He served in U.S. Navy during World War II, received his BA from University of Nebraska, and his MA from Cranbrook Academy. Survived by his sister, Donna Swezy of Albuquerque; nephews Scott and Grant Swezy; niece Anne Mallory; and his companion of many years, Anthony H. Holten. Honoring Owen's request, there will be no services.

title: Congo's Opposition Pays Price of Defying Kabila
description: When Arthur Z'Ahidi Ngoma decided last week to test the waters in the new Congo to see just how much space there was for opposition politicians, the answer he got was as swift as it was brutal.

title: Market Place ; Silence from Oxford Health is making investors nervous.
description: STEPHEN F. WIGGINS was the kind of chief executive who knew how to work a room. Never one to forget a name and face, he would charm the analysts who flocked to hear him expound on Oxford Health Plans Inc., the company he founded, and on the state of managed care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELER, WYNN (NEE WINIFRED
description: WHEELER-Wynn (nee Winifred M. Breimer). Of Southampton and Douglaston, NY. Beloved Wife of Dick. Loving Mother of Greg, Terri and Jeff. Devoted Grandmother of nine. Celebration of Life in the Community Church of Douglaston on Friday, December 26, 1997 at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, gifts to the Leukemia Society of America (New York City) would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, H. BROADMAN
description: EPSTEIN-H. Broadman. On December 6, 1997. Prior to opening his own practice in 1946, he was acting Corporate Counsel for NYC. He retired in 1982 and became honorary Trustee of the Union Temple in Brooklyn, where he had been Chairman of the Social Action Committee. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Devoted father of Sylvia Cuomo and Lois Bianchi. Cherished grandfather and greatgrandfather. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Bukhara Journal; Uzbek Magic: Bringing Dead Crafts Back to Life
description: For more than half a century, it has been all but impossible to buy any of the magnificent crafts for which this part of the world was once famous. But thanks to the breakup of the Soviet Union, they are suddenly flowing from the hands of young artisans.

title: Woman Is Set on Fire In a Harlem Apartment
description: A woman died yesterday after being bound by the wrist and set on fire inside an apartment in Harlem, the police said.

title: Stocks Tumble in Japan and South Korea
description: Japanese stocks fell, as a weakening South Korean currency threatened to erode Japanese competitiveness.

title: Playing Fast and Loose With the Venus de Milo
description: Few modern-dance choreographers can be as playful as Murray Louis, and even fewer can invest that playfulness with a degree of profundity. ''Venus,'' the latest work Mr. Louis has created for his company, Murray Louis and Nikolais Dance, is fun, theatrical and an illuminating lesson in how to live one's life.

title: Diary That Opened Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGERLEIDER, PETER
description: UNGERLEIDER-Peter. Three generations of Scheuers express profound sorrow to Steve, Jeanne and Andrew and their children at the loss of your brother and uncle. He was a gifted artist, sailor and concerned citizen. Richard and Joan Scheuer Marian Scheuer Sofaer Daniel and Shelley Scheuer Jonathan S. Scheuer and Debra Granik

title: Manhattan Is the Top Lure For Students From Abroad
description: Uyen Nguyen, a Fulbright scholar from Norway, came to the New School for Social Research to study Vietnamese refugees in New York. Peter Jacobs came from South Africa for graduate work in economics at Fordham University. Rie Akazawa, a 35-year-old graduate student from Japan, is focusing on speech and communications at New York University.

title: A Happily Baffled Director Lets His Cast Find Its Own Way
description: James L. Brooks, one of Hollywood's most successful writers, producers and directors, had spent more than an hour at L.A. Farm, a popular show business restaurant here, cutting the air with his hands and spewing out a passionate narrative on his new movie, ''As Good as It Gets.'' Despite the flood of words, however, he was not able to put his finger on just how the audience was supposed to perceive the tone of this complex comedy, which wavers from insults to laughs to sentimentality.

title: Once a Pop Star, Now He Sings Softly of Tragedy
description: Music on Yusuf Islam's new album is nothing like the music his old fans might have hoped for when he was the pop superstar known as Cat Stevens and not the Muslim educator and spokesman he is today. The new style comes out of Bosnia's long musical tradition, with most lyrics written and performed by Bosnians. Only two were written by Mr. Islam, and he sings just one.

title: Dr. Joseph Wolpe, 82, Dies; Pioneer in Behavior Therapy
description: Dr. Joseph Wolpe, a South African-born psychiatrist who was a pioneer in behavior therapy, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 82.

title: Why Irradiated Food Isn't Consumers' Choice; Dangerous and Costly
description: To the Editor:

title: Reports on T.W.A. Crash Released on Eve of Hearings
description: On the eve of a week of hearings on the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, the National Transportation Safety Board today unveiled the haystack it has painstakingly assembled over the last 17 months, and a list of witnesses who will help it look for needles.

title: Basketball Assault
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL: EXTRA POINTS ; Look for Hampton To Play Saturday
description: The Giants' starting running back Tyrone Wheatley will probably miss one game and could be out for the rest of the regular season with a sprained left ankle. Wheatley's injury moves Tiki Barber back into the starting lineup and should mean that Rodney Hampton will be activated for Saturday's game with the Washington Redskins at Giants Stadium.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWICKER, SALLY
description: ZWICKER-Sally. We join the Lubin and Vecker families in mourning a truly beloved woman. Adored great aunt of Deanne and Jerry, Barry and Carole, Janice and Mike, and David. Cherished great great aunt of Karen and Mike, Pam and Tom, Craig, Debbie, and Jeffrey. She will always remain in our hearts and in our prayers.

title: M.T.A. to Sell Pass Providing Limitless Rides
description: For the first time in the 93-year history of New York City's subway and bus system, mass transit riders will be able to buy a monthly or weekly pass good for unlimited rides, transit officials and others familiar with the plan said last night.

title: Violet Carlson, 97, Actress in Musical Comedy
description: Violet Carlson, who amused vaudeville with a comic kid act in the 1910's, then helped keep Broadway musical-comedy audiences laughing through the Roaring Twenties and into the Depression and created the role of Gretchen in the original production of ''The Student Prince,'' died on Wednesday at a hospital near her home in Los Angeles. She was 97.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WANG, ESTHER
description: WANG-Esther Beloved wife of the late Sol. Devoted mother of Beverly Stichman. Dear sister of Lewis Gottlieb. Loving grandmother of three grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Services were Sunday. For information Gutterman-Musicant 800-EST-1892

title: Treasury Sets Sale Of Short-Term Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Metro Matters; Island Fantasy That Rivals Fantasy Island
description: FOR months, New York City officials have treated a standing offer to reclaim Governors Island with a tentativeness bordering on indifference. Without saying so, they have made it clear that thinking up a new use for the old base seemed more trouble than it was worth.

title: An Intense and Joyful Tribute to a Father of Modern Dance
description: Deborah Carr's Theater Dance Ensemble honored one of the founding fathers of American modern dance when it presented three works by Charles Weidman on Saturday night at the Joyce SoHo. Weidman was a leading New York choreographer in the 1930's and 40's. Then, after a period of relative obscurity, he returned to prominence in the 60's and continued to teach and choreograph until his death in 1975.

title: Stewart's Accurate Passing Sparks a Steeler Comeback
description: Pittsburgh Coach Bill Cowher sometimes makes a face only a mother -- or his players -- could love. In the middle of the Steelers' emotional comeback against the Denver Broncos today, Cowher's rock-solid jaw was jutting out, his face red. The Steelers' players were getting roughed up more by his power hugs than by the Broncos' hits.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Top Swiss Banks Expected To Announce Consolidation

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAISON, JOHN WILLIAMS
description: FAISON-John Williams. On December 5, 1997, in his 80th year. Beloved husband of Grace Gray Faison. Devoted father of Sandy Faison and Jeff Stockly Faison. Dear brother of Seth Shepard Faison, Sr. Adored grandfather of Jeneve Noel Pendleton, John Richard Faison, Jeffrey Shepard Faison, Molly Remsen Brush and Lucy Gray Brush. Memorial service onTuesday, December 9, 11 AM, at Plymouth Church of The Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn Heights. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, or the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, 285 Schermerhorn St., Brooklyn, NY 11217.

title: Seeking Violin's Secrets With CAT Scan
description: Is the secret to the heart-rending sonority of a Stradivarius in its finish?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUSSBAUM, BERNARD M.
description: NUSSBAUM-Bernard M. Age 75, died suddenly on December 6, in the midst of a disabling illness. He was a very creative, kind, loving and proud man. Bernard worked until the end of his life in advertsing and sales. During his lifetime he also wrote a body of literary works, and was an avid bridge player. He will be deeply missed by daughters and sons-in-law Robin and Robert Phillips, and Amy and Roland Gell, and his grandchildren Daniel and Eric Phillips, and Dara Gell. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St., on Tuesday, December 9, at noon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUGAN, RICHARD M.
description: DUGAN-Richard M. Of New York City and Shelter Island, NY, passed away December 6, 1997. The cause was cancer. Mr. Dugan was a retired corporate vice president of Alexander & Alexander Services, Inc. He was a member of the Union League Club, Shelter Island Yacht Club and the Sommelier Society of America. He is survived by his beloved wife, Catherine N. Dugan. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church at a future date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. James' Church, 865 Madison Ave., NY, NY 10021 for the pastoral apartment for cancer patients and their families or to the Municipal Art Society of New York, 475 Madison Ave., NY, NY 10022 (Attn: Jean Tatge), for its preservation and planning activities for New York City.

title: Tiny Stretch of Border, Big Test for a Wall
description: When the United States Government decided to build a new barrier against the flow of illegal immigrants and drugs across the border between Mexico and this Arizona desert town, it drew up a list of official specifications. The barrier, it said, must be resistant to ''repeated physical assault by means such as welding torches, chisels, hammers, firearms, climbing over or penetration with vehicles.''

title: Love-In Goes On the Road As Packers Win Division
description: The Green Bay faithful just can't get enough of the Packers.

title: Abroad at Home; The Road To Asylum
description: To protect the dignity she still has, I shall call her Fatima Kwakuud. She is a Somali woman who fled rape and threatened murder in her terrorized country to seek asylum in the United States. Her story has a happier ending than many, but what happened along the way shows how difficult the asylum process can be under the 1996 immigration law.

title: Bringing Sibelius Out of Bleak Oblivion
description: Opinions on the music of Jean Sibelius, when arranged chronologically, pretty much tell the story of 20th-century music. For those who love him, Sibelius has triumphantly endured the shifting politics of style. Even when dismissed, he becomes important historical anti-matter, a shadow against which the ''real'' happenings of modern music can be measured.

title: Why Irradiated Food Isn't Consumers' Choice; For Full Disclosure
description: To the Editor:

title: Ousted Editor Sees Bias At Gay-Lesbian Monthly
description: Sarah Pettit says she did not see the end coming.

title: High-Rise Wall Breaks Loose, Raining Debris On Shoppers
description: A section of a Madison Avenue office tower's side wall suddenly peeled off yesterday, raining debris on holiday shoppers and tourists, snapping a hanging work platform in two and dangling a ton of bricks from a torn safety net.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the celebration of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Hackers of a different stripe go keyboard to keyboard.
description: IT is not too late to influence the outcome of Slate magazine's first annual Hackathlon, a contest that seeks to separate the hacks from the mere journalists and to provide a showcase for the unsung art of doing the most with the least in the shortest period of time. At stake: bragging rights only.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MARY JANE

title: Editorial Observer; Biotechnology and the Future of Agriculture
description: Not long ago a cotton crop failed in the Mississippi Delta. For the farmers, it was an economic disaster. For Monsanto and the Delta and Pine Land Company, the developers of Roundup Ready cotton, it was a local public relations disaster -- the result, they allege, of bad weather, insects and human error. Roundup Ready cotton incorporates a gene that is supposed to allow a cotton plant to withstand the effects of a widely used weed killer called Roundup -- Monsanto's brand of a glyphosate herbicide. Monsanto has also developed strains of Roundup Ready soybeans and corn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELICOFON, EDWARD I.
description: ELICOFON-Edward I. Attorney and art collector. In his 94th year, on December 8, 1997. Loving husband of the late Diana Preiser Elicofon, devoted proud father of Alan and Harriet Elisofon, Carol and Joel Matcovsky, Barry Elisofon, Francine and Robert Follick, and great friend of many. He is also survived by his grandchildren, David, Michael, Danielle, Peter, Diana, Laura and Benjamin, and great-granddaughter Margaret. Son of the late Sam and Sarah, he is predeceased by his brothers and sister Eliot Elisofon, the noted Life Magazine photographer, and George and Belle Elicofon. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, December 9, at 12:45 P.M., at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan. Burial at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont. Shiva will be observed at the home of Alan Elisofon at 2 Sunset Lane, Harrison, New York.

title: What Matters in the Board Game Is Skill, Money and Glamour
description: THE story, not altogether apocryphal, goes like this: A new-moneyed Wall Street tycoon asked his 6-year-old son what he wanted to be when he grew up. ''A museum trustee like you, Daddy,'' chirped the child.

title: As Election Approaches, Pataki Moves to Appease His Transit Critics
description: Until today, Gov. George E. Pataki's most obvious legacy to mass transit in New York City consisted of reduced state support, the first service cuts in two decades, dirtier trains and a 25-cent fare increase.

title: Gore Walks a Political Tightrope at Kyoto Talks
description: Toward the end of his whirlwind 16-hour visit here at the international negotiations on global warming, Vice President Al Gore met tonight with representatives of oil, coal and electric companies, assuring them that he would respect their interests.

title: The Can
description: WHAT. The canister. When George Soros gives billions to Eastern Europe, that's charity. When a customer puts change left over from a cup of coffee into a canister by the cash register, that's charity too. And the quarters add up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACDOUGALL, RELLA GAMMON
description: MACDOUGALL-Rella Gammon. Beloved widow of Allan MacDougall, October 27, 1906-November 26, 1997, from Keokuk, Iowa to New York City, a lifespan of helping and encouraging others. You helped thousands of Bronx children to fuller, more enriching lives through Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club and the Decorators' Show Houses, always nurturing family, friends and strangers. Rella, your example of a life lived large and exceedingly well will always be with us. The Gammons and MacDougalls your family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, EDMUND, M.D.
description: ROSENBAUM - Edmund, M.D. Died December 7, 1997, the day before his 86th birthday. Family physician for 40 years. Survived in sorrow by his sister, Lilly Kellner, his daughter, Eleanor, his son and daughter-in-law, David and Catherine and his grandsons. Funeral services at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, Tuesday, at 11:15 A.M.

title: Mr. Pataki's Fair Fares
description: Gov. George Pataki put himself behind imaginative discounts in transit fares yesterday when he endorsed unlimited-ride monthly, weekly and daily passes and other breaks for New York City's subway and bus riders. The Governor's plan is sensible and superior to that proposed by city officials. He needs to insure that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board, which he dominates, approves the development of discount options and gives transit executives freedom to experiment and fiddle with fares at the M.T.A.'s next board meeting later this month.

title: Mets Trying to Trade for Marlins' Brown
description: After weeks of haggling to no good result, the Mets may finally have a major trade in sight, for Florida pitcher Kevin Brown. Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager, is discussing a deal that could involve as many as six players, including Jason Isringhausen.

title: 3 Companies In U.S. Share Asia's Pain
description: Several American companies in widely different industries -- aerospace, soft drinks and computer software -- but with big global presences are beginning to feel negative effects from Asia's financial crisis.

title: Kermit Goell, 82, Songwriter
description: Kermit Goell, a songwriter, died on Thursday in Portland, Me. He was 82.

title: LITTON TO ACQUIRE PRIMARK UNIT FOR $432 MILLION
description: Litton Industries agreed yesterday to acquire TASC Inc., the Primark Corporation's information systems unit, for $432 million. TASC, based in Reading, Mass., provides information technology and services to the Defense Department and to other Government and commercial customers. It is expected to have revenue of $433 million this year. Litton, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., is a military electronics company that also builds surface combat ships. It had sales of $4.18 billion for the year ended July 31. Primark shares jumped $2.9375, to $38.8125, and Litton rose $1.8125, to $52.75.

title: Health Care Company Says It Will Raise Rates
description: A company founded by doctors and hospitals in 1993 to provide low-cost health insurance said yesterday that financial trouble would force it to cut benefits and raise rates for 12,500 Medicare customers as of Jan. 1.

title: Flight 800 Families Take Varied Issues to Hearings on Crash
description: At the opening of hearings by the National Transportation Safety Board on Trans World Airlines Flight 800, some 75 relatives of victims of the disaster sat silently today as engineers and scientists described in wrenching detail the destruction of the jumbo jet and its 230 passengers. Every detail except the critical one: what sparked the explosion in the center fuel tank that split the plane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, REBECCA
description: KRAUSS-Rebecca. Beloved wife of the late Moe, devoted mother of Harvey Krauss and Dena Fagen, dear sister of Bessie Smith, loving grandmother of Jeffrey, Stuart, Brian, Audrey, and Jonathan. Services Tuesday. For info, ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Chief Accountant at S.E.C. Announces Plans to Quit Post
description: Michael H. Sutton, the chief accountant for the Securities and Exchange Commission, who had worked to protect investors by trying to insure the independence of the accounting firms that audit public companies, said yesterday that he would resign in early January.

title: Marco Polo: Is a Rivalry Just Fiction?
description: The academic attacks on a tale of a medieval voyager who apparently beat Marco Polo to China are widening, with more scholars dismissing the newly published book as a clever forgery.

title: CENTRAL GARDEN IN PET SUPPLY DEAL FOR $135 MILLION
description: The Central Garden and Pet Company said yesterday that it would acquire three closely held pet-supply companies for a total of about $135 million in cash. Central Garden, based in Lafayette, Calif., will pay $70 million for TFH Publications Inc. of Neptune City, N.J., the largest producer of pet books in the United States and the maker of Nylabone dog chews and edible bones. Central Garden also said it would acquire a related company for $12 million to be paid out over four years, but it did not disclose the name of that company. In its third acquisition, Central Garden will pay as much as $53 million for Kaytee Products of Chilton, Wis. Kaytee, which produces Kaytee and Amazon Smythe bird food, had sales of about $103 million in its 1996 fiscal year.

title: Willie Pastrano, 62, Boxing Champ in 1960's
description: Willie Pastrano, who went from a chubby adolescent to a world light-heavyweight boxing champion, died of cancer in New Orleans on Saturday night. He was 62.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, FAYE
description: ROSE-Faye. December 4, 1901December 7, 1997. Faye was loved by everyone for her warm generous personality. She was a musical talent who loved to entertain. We will all miss her. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Devoted mother of Allan and Jeanette Zimmerman. Dear mother-in-law of Howard Zimmerman. Loving sister of Hyman and Morris Schneider and Esther Davis. Cherished grandmother of Briana, Patricia, Marisa, David, Jonathan, David and two great-grandchildren. Also survived by nieces and nephews. Services Tuesday 10:45AM, ''The Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Of Timbral Variations, Ignored or Underrated
description: You can't, in theory, tell a story with timbral variations alone, or get people dancing with it. But it's an often undervalued x-factor in jazz. We notice when we hear textural experiments in the best jazz improvisations: it can be the one element of a solo that makes it great. Yet we tend not to miss it when it's completely absent. It's always been a special trump card of the music's artier side streams, however, and there were heaps of it at Merkin Hall on Thursday night, in a concert bill (part of the Interpretations series, co-produced by Merkin and the World Music Institute) pairing two unconventional jazz groups. One was led by the pianist Myra Melford, and one led by the bassist Reggie Workman.

title: ALLIED SIGNAL TO BUY 2 AEROSPACE UNITS FOR $345 MILLION
description: Allied Signal Inc. said yesterday that it would buy two units from Banner Aerospace Inc. for about $345 million in common stock. Joe Leonard, president of aerospace marketing, sales and service at Allied Signal, which is based in Morristown, N.J., said his division's annual sales would more than double, to $400 million from $150 million, after the transaction. Banner, which is based in Washington, expects to realize a pretax gain of more than $100 million from the sale of the two units: its aerospace hardware group, which distributes airframe fasteners and bearings, and Pacaero, a distributor of adhesives, lubricants and other chemicals used on airframes. Allied Signal shares fell 81.25 cents, to $38.75, while Banner jumped $1.4375, or 14 percent, to $11.375.

title: Fallon Sets Up Interactive Agency
description: Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis is opening Revolv, a stand-alone unit specializing in interactive advertising, by spinning off a department that creates World Wide Web sites for clients.

title: A Rock Missionary Bent On Dance-Floor Ecstasy
description: Moby

description: STURGES-Benjamin R. Dec. 6, 1997. Husband of Barbara L. Tate and the late Sandol Stoddard Sturges, and father of Rush Sturges, Dorothy Sturges and Sandol Harsch. Residence Saunderstown, R.I. Memorial service Wednesday 2 P.M. in Saint Peter's By The Sea Church, Narraganset, R.I. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Endowment Fund of South County Hospital Foundation, Kenyon Avenue, Wakefield, R.I., would be appreciated.

title: The Bomb and the Button
description: The Clinton Administration has sensibly revised America's nuclear warfare guidelines to catch up with the diplomatic and military changes since the end of the cold war. The new doctrine, approved by President Clinton last month, marks an important step toward a world in which the United States relies on fewer nuclear weapons for its defense.

title: A Hands-On Generation Transforms the Landscape of Philanthropy
description: PAUL TUDOR JONES 2d, 43, came to New York in 1978 with $1,700 and a determination to make it big in the commodities markets; he did. Peggy Dulany, 50, who does not use her surname, Rockefeller, always had wealth, but she also had profound convictions about the debilitating effects of poverty, injustice and racial hatred.

title: A Cloud, a Ray, It's Gone: Capturing Sibelius
description: That Sibelius has won an ardent following was clear on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall. One of the most attentive audiences I have been part of in a long time turned out for the London Symphony Orchestra concert with Colin Davis conducting, part of a two-week Sibelius festival called ''Northern Lights.'' The all-Sibelius program offered a craggy short work, ''Lemminkainen's Return,'' and the Third and Fifth Symphonies.

title: 2 of the Big 3 Swiss Banks To Join to Seek Global Heft
description: In deciding to merge and form the world's second-largest bank, the Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation appear to be reasoning that if they are going to remain players globally during a time of ever-larger mergers, they, too, must take on the necessary critical mass.

title: INSIDE
description: An unstable wall continues to disrupt Madison Avenue. PAGE B3

title: A Night at The Opera, for Deconstructionalists
description: The New York City Opera opening-night benefit has been a perennial also-ran in the glitzy gala sweepstakes, raising relatively small amounts and attracting few big names on the social circuit. Well, no this year, its fund-raisers decided, not with a hot, new director and a high-profile event planner in place. But in a social season that crams 300 benefits into three months, turning City Opera's gala, a lavish dinner following a new production of ''Macbeth,'' into a Cinderella of fund-raisers took more than the wave of a wand. The strategizing involved everything from the timing of the benefit, the naming of chairmen and selection of an honoree to the recruiting of benefit committee members and the raising of a well-heeled army of benefactors, sponsors and patrons. Choosing a Sept. 11 date, for example, was gamble, since the social lions are just returning to the city from their summer homes. On the other hand, there is little competition. A lot hinged on the invitation, in which strategically placed names are supposed to have a come-hither, come-donate effect. Invitations speak to those who can decipher them. Here is how:

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Judah Folkman; A Lonely Warrior Against Cancer
description: THERE are few greater hazards to a scientist's career than perceiving a truth before the means exist to test it. Repeated assertion of one's insight will first invite insistent demands for proof, then skepticism, followed by silence, ridicule and often the loss of research funds.

title: Defense Will Keep Carrying Giants
description: The evolution of a defense, Stage I. The Giants' defensive players held a meeting before Sunday's Philadelphia game. They wanted to erase any doubt from people who still did not think they were a top defense. They got fired up about Eagles quarterback Bobby Hoying, the boy wonder, and were determined not to let him light them up the way he had three previous teams.

title: Clinton Ready To Defy Senate Over Rights Job
description: Clinton Administration officials said today that if Senate Republicans continued to block the nomination of Bill Lann Lee to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, the President would appoint him anyway while the Senate is in recess.

title: RENO AND FREEH SPURN SUBPOENA ON COUNSEL ISSUE
description: In an unusual joint letter, Attorney General Janet Reno and the F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh, defied a House committee today, refusing to comply with a subpoena to turn over a memorandum written by Mr. Freeh two weeks ago that had urged her to allow an independent prosecutor to investigate campaign fund-raising.

title: Sort-Of Rich Guy Admits To Serial Philanthropy
description: IF I were really rich I'd have titled my book ''Memoirs of a Guy With a Couple of Bucks.'' Instead, it's merely a tongue-in-cheek fortune, which means I have to work at stretching it. I don't own an island in the Caribbean, I own half an island. And it's very small. And at low tide you can sort of wade from it to downtown industrial North Eleuthera. All in all, my share cost less than a fancy New York studio apartment.

title: Barry S. Brook, Musicologist And Educator, Is Dead at 79
description: Barry S. Brook, an internationally renowned musicologist who established and led a doctoral program in music at the City University of New York Graduate School, died on Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 79 and lived in New York City.

title: How Did the Chimp Get the Deductions?
description: GENE study and philanthropy have always been grafted into a weird hybrid science for me. My biology classes in Catholic high school were dependent on the success of the sale of chocolate ingots. If the door-to-door fund-raising sale went well that year, and there was money left over after the purchase of a pagan baby or two, we got lab equipment. Otherwise, it was one microscope and two worms, and you had to put everything back.

title: Bosnia II?
description: Ministers and ambassadors from 51 nations gather in Bonn today for their annual review of how successfully the Dayton agreement on unifying Bosnia is being carried out. They will hear complaints that local leaders and international officials have been stalling, sowing confusion, missing deadlines and just plain acting ineptly.

title: India's New Election: Old Political Indecision Is Likely
description: With new elections set for early next year, India faces a bleak prospect: a second vote in just two years in which a fractured electorate seems unlikely to give any party or combination of parties enough support to provide the bold government many Indians say the country needs.

title: County Medical Center Preparing for New Independence
description: A year after New York State lawmakers gave their blessing to the plan, the Westchester County Medical Center is prepared to transform itself from a government-run hospital to a quasi-independent entity, a move that officials hope will make the hospital stronger and more competitive in the world of managed health care.

title: Spectacles From Nikolais, a One-Man Theater
description: Alwin Nikolais made choreography resemble conjuring. From the 1950's until his death in 1993, he devised multimedia works in which he combined virtuoso dance steps with technological wizardry. A one-man theater, he created his own scenery, costumes, lighting and electronic music for his spectacles, which could be dazzling in their overall effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JANET STEINBERG
description: GREENE-Janet Steinberg. Age 88. On December 7, 1997 at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in NYC. Beloved wife of the late Wilfred and beloved mother of Dorothy Alexis. For more than three decades, as school psychologist for the Dalton School, teacher, and psychotherapist, she gave unstintingly of her time, energy and insight. She was a pioneer. Services private. Memorial contributions may be made either to Radcliffe College, Ten Garden Street, Cambridge, MA. 02138 or to Community Access, Inc., 666 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10009.

title: French Retailer May Buy British-Owned Chain
description: The French retailer Promodes S.A. acknowledged yesterday that it was in talks with Tesco, a British supermarket chain, about buying its French unit, Catteau, but denied that any deal had been signed. The Sunday Telegraph in Britain reported that Tesco had agreed to sell Catteau to Promodes for $:225 million ($375 million) and that the deal would be announced shortly.

title: DEDUCTIONS; Schedule A
description: WHAT. Schedule A. It's a page in an unpleasant little book from an out-of-favor little agency in Washington. Why is it called a schedule when it lists neither ''Seinfeld'' nor train arrivals? Don't ask; men carrying file folders and wearing shiny shoes might knock on your door. But if you want to itemize deductions, charitable and otherwise, this is the place to do it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, JAYNE D.
description: FRANKLIN-Jayne D. Devoted mother of the late Jill Franklin, woman of valor who faced the tragedies in life with spirit and fortitude, died December 7, 1997. Her generosity, kindness, humanity and joy of life enriched the lives of her family and friends. She will be missed and mourned by all who knew her. Contributions may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 1166 Avenue of the Americas, NY NY 10013. Service Tuesday, December 9, 1997, 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a new fiber optic network in Palo Alto, Calif., misstated the age of California's historic Spanish missions, which were cited by a Palo Alto scientist as inspirations for his vision of the network. Most missions were built in the 18th century, not the 16th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINERNEY, JOAN B.
description: McINERNEY-Joan B. On Dec. 7, 1997, beloved wife of the late Patrick J., devoted sister of Mary Sonnenberg and Therese Hartel. Loving aunt of Mary Hartel Semack. Visiting at the Chas. Peter Nagel Inc. Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street Tuesday, Dec. 9, from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday 11 A.M. at Saint Joseph's Church.

title: Corporations Adopt a Different Attitude: Show Us the Value
description: AVON PRODUCTS used to support causes that alleviated human suffering. Today, it gives only to programs that relate specifically to women, its primary customers. So March of Dimes and lung cancer associations are out; scholarships for women, and breast and ovarian cancer groups are in. ''Our giving has to be in line with our vision for the business,'' said Marcia L. Worthing, the senior vice president for human resources.

title: In a World of Good Causes, Beware Waste and a Few Crooks
description: EACH quarter, the American Institute of Philanthropy publishes a guide that ranks charities' financial performances in an effort to expose abuses in the philanthropic sector. So imagine the institute's surprise when it learned in June that the guide itself had become a tool in an ambitious charity-based fraud.

title: In Search of a Cause: Volunteering Dos and Don'ts
description: RACHEL LEVINE wanted to help New York's homeless, so she went to the Mayor's Voluntary Action Center earlier this year looking for an organization to work with. She was referred to a women's shelter, where the volunteer coordinator welcomed her and told her to show up whenever she wished.

title: The Modern Picks Taniguchi's Expansion Plan
description: The Museum of Modern Art announced yesterday that it had selected the design of Yoshio Taniguchi, an architect based in Tokyo, for its expansion. The plan will double the midtown museum's exhibition space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELLIN, NEIL ROBERT
description: SELLIN-Neil Robert. Dec. 7, 1997. Beloved husband of June Sellin. Loving father of Kenneth Sellin, Alison Weiskopf and Thomas Sellin, and father-in-law of Lynn Sellin and Dan Weiskopf. Adored grandfather of Olivia Sellin. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) today, Tuesday, at 10:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

title: Fire, Water and, Maybe, Life in Jupiter's Realm
description: LOOKING into the heavens with his new telescope in 1610, Galileo caught sight of ''four stars that wander around Jupiter as does the moon around the earth.'' They were not stars, he soon realized, but satellites that orbit the giant planet in much the same way the planets themselves travel around the Sun. The discovery finally demolished the human conceit that Earth is the center of the solar system, even the universe.

title: Body of Envoy To Be Removed From Arlington
description: Confronted with mounting evidence that M. Larry Lawrence, the late Ambassador to Switzerland, had fabricated a heroic World War II record, his widow decided today to have his remains exhumed from Arlington National Cemetery, where he was granted burial under an unusual waiver.

title: Talk in Japan of Selling U.S. Bonds Has Little Effect
description: Once again, talk of a Japanese selloff of United States Treasury bonds has been heard, briefly raising the possibility of new market tremors, but this time few investors seemed rattled.

title: Churches Find New Ways, and Old, to Pass the Plate Around
description: WHEN the Rev. Robert Farr preaches to his congregation in Lee's Summit, Mo., about donating money to the church, he speaks about giving as a form of spiritual discipline.

title: INTEL TO ACQUIRE 4.9% STAKE IN CMG INFORMATION SERVICES
description: The Intel Corporation agreed to buy a 4.9 percent stake in CMG Information Services Inc., a direct marketing concern that also invests in Internet companies. Terms were not disclosed, but the stake would be worth about $13.5 million on the open market. CMG shares surged 19 percent, gaining $4.625, to $28.50. Shares of Intel rose 87.5 cents, to $78.4375, as almost 10.1 million shares were traded. CMG, based in Wilmington, Mass., has a majority stake in Lycos Inc., which makes a widely used Internet browser. Intel, the semiconductor giant, is based in Santa Clara, Calif. CMG said the two companies would explore Internet business opportunities.

Devoted father of Richard J. Jr., Susan A., Joan B. Riley, Mary Ann Nason, Raymond V., Patricia B. Burke and Peter D. Burggraf. Adored grandfather of ten. title: AMERICAN GENERAL TO BUY ANNUITY UNIT FOR $58 MILLION
description: The American General Corporation said it would pay $58 million for the retirement savings plan business of the Provident Companies in a move to bolster its direct sales to individuals and sales to groups through tax-advantaged plans. The deal will give American General annuities business with statutory reserves of $2.4 billion. American General, based in Houston, wants to increase its revenue from ''one of the fastest-growing segments of the financial services,'' Robert M. Devlin, the company's chairman, said. Its Valic unit was the third-biggest seller of variable annuities last year. Provident, of Chattanooga, Tenn., is getting out of annuities to focus on disability insurance.

title: Battered Cowboys' Playoff Hopes Crushed
description: The Dallas Cowboys won't win the National Football Conference East. They will probably not even make the playoffs.

title: Don't Gamble With Governors Island
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's trial balloon about casino gambling on Governors Island deserves to be punctured quickly. But deflating the idea of a Monaco-in-the-harbor is not enough. New York's Mayor needs to revise his attitude both toward casinos in general and toward the wholesome opportunity that this 172-acre historic island represents for the city.

title: U.N. Prosecutor Urges New Criminal Court
description: The chief prosecutor for the war crimes tribunals in the Balkans and Rwanda spoke out strongly today for a permanent international criminal court with considerable independent prosecutorial power, a position that puts her at odds with the Clinton Administration.

description: ''Years ago we used to blame our secretaries. Now we blame computers.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTSON, DR. SUSAN
description: ROBERTSON-Dr. Susan. Died on December 6th, 1997. Born 1943 in Detroit to Dorothy and the late Albert Robertson. Educated at Bryn Mawr College and Yeshiva University (Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology). Dr. Robertson was a psychotherapist with a private practice in N.Y. She is survived by her beloved husband William G. Eggers, her mother, her sister Mary Ellen, cousins Thomas, James and Charles and her faithful dog Harley. She will also be deeply missed by her many friends and colleagues. A memorial service will be held at St. Michael's Episcopal Church, 225 West 99 Street at Amsterdam, 10 A.M., Saturday, December 13. In lieu of flowers the family suggest a donation in her memory to the charity of the donor's choice.

title: Auto Business Sold to Rival In Korea Crisis
description: The Ssangyong Group, one of Korea's biggest family-run businesses, has sold off its automobile company to the rival Daewoo Group in what executives described as the first friendly takeover in the history of Korea's largest conglomerates.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Closing up the home of one's parents and getting rid of a lifetime's worth of possessions is not easy, as JAMIE BERNSTEIN THOMAS, a daughter of Leonard Bernstein, learned when she recently sorted through personal mementos and pieces of musical history.
