description: SEAMAN-Burton S. Beloved husband of Lee. Devoted father of Margie, Alex and Diane. Loving grandfather of Kevin, Brian, Mitchell and Jeffrey. Funeral services Wednesday, December 10, 1997, 9:45am, Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Rd. Great Neck, N.Y.

title: N.A.S.D. Moves To Fight Fraud
description: The unit boards of the National Association of Securities Dealers have approved proposals to combat manipulation of tiny, thinly traded stocks on the over-the-counter bulletin board, N.A.S.D. officials said today.

title: A Former Headmistress Is to Head Spence School
description: The Spence School, one of New York's most prestigious private girls' schools, named Arlene Joy Gibson yesterday to replace its retiring head, Edes P. Gilbert.

title: Metro Business; Group to Renovate Bloomingdale's Site
description: For several months now, the old Bloomingdale's merchandise warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, has been a hulking, vacant eyesore, abandoned and seemingly unwanted.

title: Daiwa Securities Sets Buyback of Its Stock
description: The Daiwa Securities Company said yesterday that it would spend up to 25 billion yen ($192 million) to buy back 50 million of its shares, which have plunged 35 percent since the collapse of the Yamaichi Securities Company on Nov. 24. Daiwa, Japan's second-largest brokerage firm, has been the object of persistent speculation that it was hiding losses similar to those that brought down Yamaichi, the country's fourth-largest securities firm. Yamaichi acknowledged 265 billion yen of unreported losses.

title: Wei Reportedly Tells President That Release of One Prisoner By Beijing 'Is Not Enough' : Clinton Meets With Dissident Despite Chinese Denunciations
description: WASHINGTON  Wei Jingsheng, the recently released Chinese dissident, met Monday with President Bill Clinton at the White House, four days after the Beijing authorities demanded that U.S. officials not grant an audience to a man they consider a common criminal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGERLEIDER, PETER
description: UNGERLEIDER - Peter. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University mourns the passing of a true humanitarian, Peter Ungerleider. The generousity of the Ungerleider family, throught the Dorot Foundation was instrumental in the establishment of Tel Aviv University's Moshe Dayan Center for Middle Eastern and African Studies. The Dorot Foundation also supported at Tel Aviv University the work of Prof. Clinton Bailey and his book on Bedouin Law and Dr. Bilhah Nitzan's book ''Qumran Prayer & Religious Poetry''. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University Bernard Rapoport, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvin S. Taub, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Topchik, President Jules Love, Executive V.P.

title: More on Global Business
description: Business Day is expanding its coverage of international business. The enlarged report, appearing Tuesdays through Saturdays, begins today with articles about American-Russian oil ventures winning back benefits from Moscow and about whether bigger is better for the Swiss bank merger. Pages 7 and 8.

title: From Europe, Invasion of the Donor Snatchers
description: WHEN Contessa Simonetta Brandolini d'Adda came to New York last month, it was to lay the groundwork for a nonprofit foundation to be called Friends of Florence. Its goal is to lure contributions to shore up the vast but deteriorating artistic heritage of her city.

title: A Plan to Ban Door-to-Door Sales by Schoolchildren Is Praised by Educators
description: Educators from around the state heaped praise today on a bill that would ban public schoolchildren from selling candy and other items door to door.

title: THEATER REVIEW: 'Doctor, My Life's Just a Joke.' 'So Laugh.'; A Couple of Young Septuagenarians Bask in Simon 'Sunshine'
description: ''You know what your problem was, Willie? You always took the jokes too seriously.'' So says one aged ex-vaudevillian to another in Neil Simon's ''Sunshine Boys,'' a comedy in which living for punch lines has nearly fatal consequences. It's obvious that Willie Clark, the character played by Jack Klugman in the revival of the play that opened last night at the Lyceum Theater, would be a healthier man if he could just uncoil a little. But aren't we lucky he can't?

title: Giants' Title Cry: Redskins Must Fall
description: The carton containing the videotapes of the Giants' victory over the Philadelphia Eagles remained unopened at the edge of Jim Fassel's desk early this morning at Giants Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERCURIO, JOSEPHINE C.
description: MERCURIO-Josephine C. On Dec. 6, 1997. Beloved daughter of the late late Domenick and Grace. Loving sister of Rose DeBenedictis, Susan Bovenzi and Dolores Costanza. Cherished aunt of Joseph, Robert, Theresa, Laura, Roseann, David, Gina, Lauren and Anthony. Devoted great-aunt of Victoria, Dominick and Julia. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193 Street. Visiting hours 2 to 5 and 7 to 9:30PM. Funeral Mass on Wednesday, 10:15 A.M., St. Fidelis R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Straphangers Find a Friend In an Old Foe
description: WHO'D have thunk it?

title: The Collector Who Is Breaking a Thousand Curators' Hearts
description: TO be a prominent art collector is to lead a charmed life. Collectors hobnob with artists, attend A-list parties at museums and appear in design magazines, smiling in front of their Frank Stellas.

title: Judge Calls Sweatshop Charges Too Lenient
description: A Manhattan judge chastised the state's chief labor prosecutor yesterday over his decision to charge a woman accused of operating a lower Manhattan sweatshop with only a misdemeanor despite evidence showing she had underpaid workers by more than $300,000.

title: While Other Europeans Downsize, German Military Moves Into Lead : Armed Forces Surpass Expectations
description: BONN  Germany's armed forces continue evolving to fulfill their role as Europe's largest army, perhaps faster than most observers had expected.

title: Journal; Moses Hits the Bull's-Eye
description: The Kennedy Center hypes its annual Honors as ''America's equivalent of a knighthood in Britain, or the French Legion of Honor.'' Just don't tell that to Sotheby's, the New York auction house. Tomorrow night it puts Leonard Bernstein's estate on the block, and the catalogue assigns the composer's personal collection of Kennedy Center Honors memorabilia -- he won in 1980 -- one of the lowest estimates: $100 to $150, with Lucite frames thrown in.

title: Energen Buying Reserves
description: The Energen Corporation said today that it agreed to buy energy producing properties in West Texas for $44 million from B. C. Oil and Gas Ltd. and its affiliates. The deal, for 81 billion cubic feet equivalent of oil and gas reserves, is expected to close this month. Energen said its Taurus Exploration unit would spend an additional $17 million in the next two to three years to develop the properties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYER, GERALD R.
description: FLYER-Gerald R. Suddenly, on December 6, 1997. Loving husband of Joan. Devoted father of Nancy and Barbara. Beloved father-inlaw of Tee and Alan. Adoring grandfather of Philip and Elizabeth. Cherished brother of Rosalie Garren and brother-in-law of Murray Garren, and Betty and Larry Newman, and dear uncle. Service was held Monday at 12 noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Moscow Restores Benefits to 3 U.S.-Russian Oil Ventures
description: When Vice President Al Gore came to Moscow in September he took up the cudgel for American oil companies. The Americans complained that billions in new investment were in jeopardy because of obstreperous local leaders, unreliable Russian partners and a lethargic bureaucracy.

title: Of Mice and Memory
description: FROM research comes a mouse that cannot remember its history -- even particularly unpleasant history -- and is doomed to repeat it.

title: The Neediest Cases; Patience, Plus Help, Rescues a Family
description: To understand the depths of Marcia Senior's patience, one need only sit through a meal in her narrow kitchen while her son, Marcus, yelps and stomps his way from one end of the room to the other, flipping off the lights and persistently turning on the faucet.

title: California G.O.P. Faces a Crisis As Hispanic Voters Turn Away
description: The California Republican Party, the mighty army that helped propel Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan to the White House, now finds itself facing a big problem: It is rapidly losing ground among the fastest-growing group in the electorate of the nation's most-populous state, Hispanic voters. Expressed in either English or Spanish, the arithmetic is clear.

title: Sprewell's Punishment Fits
description: The National Basketball Association had little choice but to deal harshly with Latrell Sprewell of the Golden State Warriors, who last week choked, punched and threatened to kill the Warriors' coach P. J. Carlesimo. The Warriors terminated the remainder of Sprewell's four-year contract, causing him to lose $25 million, and Converse has canceled his endorsement contract. The league's decision to suspend the All-Star guard for a full year sends a strong message to players and fans that it will not tolerate thuggery.

title: Fliers Beat Airlines at Their Own Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISENFELD, MILDRED
description: WEISENFELD-Mildred. Died on December 6, 1997. The members and officers of Fight For Sight Manhattan League deeply regret the passing of Mildred Weisenfeld. Miss Weisenfeld was the pioneer in eye research philanthropy. For the past 50 years Miss Weinsenfeld's energy, persistence and leadership helped build and establish Fight For Sight and its numerous leagues. This organization is dedicated to the prevention of eye impairment through research grants, fellowships and eye clinics. Miss Weisenfeld's work shaped and implemented the goals of Fight For Sight. Eye research is better because of her work. Eleanor Boren, President Elsie K. Sloate, President Emeritus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIESEN, JOSEPHINE SCHWARTZ
description: PIESEN - Josephine Schwartz. Died on December 7. Widow of Herbert Schwartz and Pete Piesen. Beloved mother of Joan and Jerry Brod of Villanova, PA. Grandmother and great-grandmother. Sister of Rosalind Kay of Atlantic City. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOK, BARRY S.
description: BROOK-Barry S. The faculty, students and staff of The Graduate School and University Center of CUNY are deeply saddened by the loss of Barry S. Brook, internationally renown musicologist and architect of our highly esteemed Doctoral Programs in Music. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. A memorial concert in tribute to Dr. Brook will be held at The Graduate School in February. Frances Degen Horowitz, President

title: 30-Year Bond's Yield Climbs To 6.13% on Signs of Growth
description: Treasury prices fell yesterday, sending the long bond's yield to the highest level in a month.

title: Two forecasters predict spending on Madison Avenue should remain robust next year.
description: TWO executives whose twice-yearly forecasts of advertising spending are closely followed along Madison Avenue see 1998 as a year of somewhat slower -- but still strong -- growth.

title: A Video Explorer Who Sees Links to the Renaissance
description: Bill Viola vividly remembers his childhood in Queens watching ''King Kong,'' ''The Little Rascals'' and Humphrey Bogart films on television. ''By the time I started making video, I had this film vocabulary in my bones without even thinking about it; by the time I began working, it made me realize how strongly the craft of filmmaking is connected to Renaissance painting,'' said Mr. Viola, 46, a celebrated pioneer in the field of video art.

title: Ace Hardware Selects Bozell Unit
description: The Ace Hardware Corporation has consolidated its account, with billings estimated at $22 million, at the Chicago office of Bozell Worldwide. The account had been divided between Bozell, for media services, and Impact Communications in Chicago, a unit of True North Communications, for creative duties. Bozell, part of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, was awarded the consolidated account without a review.

title: A Code of Conduct To Rein In Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: Subsidy Cuts Threaten To Darken Opera Houses
description: MUNICH  A high regard for music in general and opera in particular runs clear across the political spectrum in Germany, and both sides of the once-divided nation used to spend very substantial sums subsidizing concert halls and opera houses. Opera companies could routinely expect 80 percent or more of their budgets to come from government subsidies.

title: Where Image Prevails, Talk About Race Turns Bland
description: Who could fault the outpouring of virtue from President Clinton's town hall on race last week? It was a lesson in gentility for afternoon television, a show without raunch or rant, insults or inanities, crackpotism or kookery. One wanted to like it. But when it comes to race, television has moved much beyond the sound bites that filled those two hours of C-Span.

title: Race Panel Shunned Real Dialogue; Army Insists on Merit
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an article about the search for a new police chief in Washington misstated a crime statistic. Reported rapes increased 85 percent, not 8 percent -- to 133 in the first six months of 1997 from 72 in the first six months of 1996. (As noted on the chart, overall crime declined 16 percent.)

title: A Volunteer Spirit Asks, Where's the Fire?
description: WHEN my radio pager went off, I was in the middle of a long, meandering run through the back roads near my house. It was a gray Saturday morning, and the alert was for the volunteer firefighters of Randolph Center, a neighboring town. As a volunteer firefighter myself, I listened with some curiosity to these tones meant for others.

title: Hospital Worker Held in Sexual Abuse Case
description: A nurse's aide at Metropolitan Hospital Center was arrested yesterday on charges that he sexually abused three teen-age girls who were being treated for depression in the psychiatric ward, the police said.

title: Cut in Interest Rates Is Expected in China
description: China is likely to cut interest rates within weeks to bolster an economy headed for its slowest year since 1990, economists and bankers said yesterday. The state-run Shanghai Securities News joined a growing chorus yesterday calling for a cut in official lending rates. Some economists say rates may be reduced as much as two percentage points.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, ANNETTE B.
description: WEINER-Annette B. New York University mourns the passing of Annette B. Weiner, former dean of the Graduate School of Arts & Science. First and foremost an internationally noted anthropologist renowned for her keen eye, Dr. Weiner was also a brilliant educator and researcher, an accomplished and innovative administrator, and a much-valued member of the NYU community. L. Jay Oliva, President Philip Furmanski Dean, Faculty of Arts & Science

title: Market Place; A Greenspan Refrain: That Was Then . . .
description: If you had listened to Alan Greenspan just two months ago and then considered what has happened in the American economy since, you would have to conclude that a Federal Reserve tightening was a sure thing. The fact that few expect it now is a tribute to how rapidly the world can change, and to how fast seers can change their minds.

title: Myers Beats Obstacles In Her Life and in Golf
description: To her peers on the L.P.G.A. Tour, Terry-Jo Myers is courageous, an inspiration, an example of how to overcome obstacles not only in sports, but in life. Myers is too modest to describe herself that way. But considering what she has endured, it is remarkable that at the age of 35, Myers has emerged as one of the top players on tour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, LESTER J.
description: MORRIS-Lester J. Beloved husband of Gladys. Devoted father of Beth and Bruce Smith, and Steve and Sherry Morris. Dear brother of Edna Licht. Adored grandfather of Michael, Stacy, Howard, Jonathan and Andrew. Cherished great grandfather of Molly. Services Tuesday, 1:30PM at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLAS, LILA
description: BALLAS-Lila. Age 89, passed away in Manhattan on Saturday December 6, 1997. Born in Brooklyn, she was a long time resident of Surfside, FL. Beloved wife of the late Thomas, loving mother of Dianna de Martino and Virginia Marcus, dear mother-in-law of Leonard de Martino and Leonard Marcus, cherished aunt. Her vivacious spirit and caring ways will be remembered by family and friends. The warmth, wisdom and kindness she imparted will be greatly missed. Memorial service 1:30 P.M. Wednesday, Dec. 10 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, gifts to The Lighthouse, 111 East 59th Street, NYC, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Logging On To Baby's Day; Internet Services Let Parents View Children as They Attend Preschools and Care Centers
description: Amy Manning had forgotten to place the daily handful of imaginary kisses in her 3-year-old son's pocket. She had forgotten to draw his start-of-the-day cowboy and Indian. In her rush to get to work, she had broken their fragile parting ritual and had not said a proper goodbye to Henry when she left him here at the Children's Corner.

title: Man Dies After Crashing Into Newark Firehouse
description: A Newark man died yesterday when he lost control of his car and crashed into a firehouse after being chased by the police, officials said. The man, Jean Henaud Charles, 25, had been pursued to the Newark line by the Irvington police for speeding and was apparently still being chased when he crashed through the door of the firehouse and into a firetruck, said Ray Weiss, a spokesman for the Essex County Prosecutor's office. He said Mr. Charles's license had been suspended for driving without insurance.

title: Fire in Power Lines in Queens Knocks Out Homes and Schools
description: Nearly 4,000 households and two elementary schools in Queens were without power for about two hours yesterday after a set of frayed underground electric cables caught fire and blew the lid off a manhole cover.

title: Siberia Tests Russia's Ability To Profit From Privatization
description: Hardship is second nature for the residents of this Siberian enclave.

title: 56 Troubled Lenders Closed by Thailand
description: This country drew cheers from economists today by closing all but two of 58 ailing finance companies, the toughest step yet to address economic problems.

title: U.S. Aides Urge Easing of Holocaust Sanctions on Swiss Banks
description: Key American state and local government officials yesterday supported a temporary easing of the sanctions they had imposed on Swiss banks, hoping that the move would help clear the way for a settlement with the heirs of Holocaust victims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CABRAL, OLGA KURTZ
description: CABRAL-Olga Kurtz. Friends and family sadly report her death on December 6, 1997 at age 88. Renowned poet and author, she enriched the lives of all she touched. A memorial will be held January 18, 1998, 3 P.M., at Westbeth, 55 Bethune Street, New York City.

title: State Says Schools Plan Could Cost $811 Million
description: The State Department of Education said yesterday that a plan to help students in poor urban school districts could add an estimated $811 million to the annual cost of education in New Jersey.

title: Shanghai G.M. Selects Bates
description: The General Motors Corporation added Bates Worldwide to its agency roster yesterday as Shanghai General Motors, a joint venture of G. M. and the Shanghai Automobile Industrial Corporation, named Bates China in Shanghai as the first shop to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: People
description: * Charles Hall was named to the new position of senior vice president and creative director at Spike DDB, New York, owned by the film director Spike Lee and the DDB Needham Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group. He had been a creative director at the Venice, Calif., office of the TBWA Chiat/Day unit of Omnicom.

title: Unabom Trial May Prove Landmark on Illness Plea
description: If they are able to present a psychiatric defense for the man accused of being the Unabomber, lawyers for Theodore J. Kaczynski may reopen a divisive debate about when people who claim mental illness should be held criminally responsible, some psychiatric and legal experts say.

title: A Sweetened Bid For Wheelabrator
description: Waste Management Inc. raised its bid for Wheelabrator Technologies Inc. to $16.50 a share today after investors sued to block the purchase, saying the original $15- a-share bid was not enough.

title: Balloon Teams Begin Countdown For Risky Dash Around the Planet
description: HOPING to become the first balloonists to circle the world nonstop and win a $1 million prize, five competing teams of aeronauts are fine-tuning their complex balloons for a dangerous race expected to begin soon.

title: PATAKI ANNOUNCES UNLIMITED PASSES FOR CITY TRANSIT
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced a program of monthly, weekly and daily passes yesterday that will give mass transit users unlimited trips for a fixed price and drastically change one of the central aspects of public transportation in New York City.

title: Devils Are Hoping Trade Helps MacLean, and Them
description: John MacLean is happy, and now so are the Devils.

title: Safety Board Offers View Of the Flight 800 Explosion
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, in its first thorough presentation of the last moments of T.W.A. Flight 800, displayed its own video animations today and painted a picture with significantly different details from the one laid out by the C.I.A. two weeks ago.

title: Frazier Doesn't Make Himself Clear
description: Walt Frazier was a great player. But as the Knicks' radio analyst, his ability to provide cogent, blunt insights is obscured by chronic thesaurus hoopus scoopus -- the gaudy overuse of synonyms for rhyming purposes.

description: To the Editor:

title: Politics as Usual With a Snappy Beat
description: For rock bands that survive beyond a decade, youthful rebellion usually gives way to introspection and cynicism and sometimes, as musicians settle down and tune in the news, to social and political concerns. The Australian band Midnight Oil skipped the intermediate stages. After its youthful bravado in the late 1970's, it turned to political issues and never let go.

title: In Spirit of Reconciliation, Dresden Recasts Its Past
description: DRESDEN, Germany  Concealed behind veiled cathedral-sized scaffolding, masons are building a bold new national symbol here. Stone by hand-chiseled stone, they are creating a replica of the majestic Frauenkirche, the Church of Our Lady, in the heart of this once-resplendent city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, BRIGADIER GENERAL FREDERICK VICTOR, JR.
description: AUSTIN-Brigadier General Frederick Victor, Jr. Yale, 1928. C.O. 5th Engineers, U.S. Army. Headed Budget Division American Electric Power System. Tenor soloist Yale Glee Club. Survived by his beloved wife Odette Jung Austin, two daughters Alix Kendall, Ghislaine Belcak, one daughter-inlaw Wilhamina Austin, and three grandchildren. Son Roger deceased 1994. Services Wednesday, December 10th, St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, New York. Contributions may be sent in lieu of flowers to Yale University or St. Matthew's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRISCHMAN, REGINA
description: FRISCHMAN-Regina. For 72 glorious years devoted wife of, and sweetheart of, Sol who watched over and loved her tenderly. Caring mother of Elaine and Sandra, grandmother of Denise, Juliet, Rebecca, Diana and Eric. Greatgrandmother of Sara, Amelia and Elizabeth. Loving sister of Charlie, Annie, Flo and Babe. She dedicated many years to Hadassah as President of The Eleanor Roosevelt Chapter in the Bronx and then headed The Hativkvah Chapter of Miami Beach, Florida. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, December 9, 1997 (today) at 12 noon at The Riverside-Garlick Memorial Chapels, 1439 Union Port Road, Bronx, NY. Interment will follow in the family plot in Cedar Park Cemetery Paramus, N.J.

title: Evangelical Protestants Giving Less to Churches, Study Says
description: Evangelical Protestants, whose churches have historically urged members to tithe their incomes, are placing a decreasing percentage of their personal incomes in the collection plate, according to a wide-ranging study released yesterday of giving patterns in 29 Protestant denominations.

description: SHEPLER-Donald. On December 6, 1997. Brother of Robert of Meade, WA. Also survived by many nieces, nephews and dear friends. Memorial gathering on Sunday, December 14 11-1 PM, at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, New York City.

title: High Court Weighs 'Gray Market' Legality
description: For years, American manufacturers of copyrighted products have been fighting against the multibillion-dollar ''gray market,'' the unauthorized importation of American consumer goods, originally sold at a discount overseas, for resale in the United States.

title: Coaches Say 4 Quarters Was a Half-Baked Idea
description: John Halpert of Yeshiva University yesterday spoke for many New York-area coaches on the four-quarter experiment in college basketball this season. ''It stinks,'' he said. ''I just hate it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURNEY, JOHN KIRKMAN
description: GURNEY-John Kirkman of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, died December 7, 1997. Formerly of Garden City, NY, he graduated the Choate School and Princeton University, Class of 1934. He was Managing Partner of Estabrook and Co., a Board Member of GreenPoint Financial Corp. and Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn. Survivors include his wife, Jane Peterkin Gurney; one daughter; two sons; two sisters; five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

description: Before the season, they were traded for each other. Now, after the season, one was traded because the other came back.

title: In Folk Music, Who's New Depends on Who's Judging
description: The nature of an introduction depends on the parties at either end. The Required Listening Series at the Bottom Line, sponsored by WFUV (90.7-FM), is intended to acquaint folk fans with new singer-songwriters. Yet in the up-and-down world of popular music, artists can be deemed new at nearly any point in their careers. The Required Listening show on Friday grouped one alternative-rock veteran, one longtime New York musician-for-hire, one elusive cult figure and one genuine neophyte with the poise and creative ambition of an adept.

description: Give all thou canst;

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHICCO, MERILYN CRIENE
description: CHICCO-Merilyn Criene. Of East Stroudsburg, PA. Formerly of Sucasunna, NJ. Born June 27, 1936 in Scranton, died December 6 at Mt. Sinai Hospital, NYC of a stroke. With her first husband, Leonard D. Chicco, Merilyn founded Web Dynamics, Inc., developing novel machines to manufacture face masks from microfibers. Leonard died in 1995 and Merilyn sold the business to Johns Manville, Inc. In June of 1997 she married Richard Leshko who survives. Merilyn was deeply loved by her son, Leonard, Jr., her daughters, Kathleen Seagraves and Cynthia Driskil, and her sisters, D'Orsay Mancuso and Donna Samsell. Funeral is 10 AM Wednesday at DeGraw Roever Funeral Home, Dunmore, PA. Merilyn collected antique airplanes and was preparing to solo in an ultralight aircraft at her private airport, Eagles Nest. Donations may be made to Mid Atlantic Air Museum, Reading Regional Airport, PA 19605, where she served on the advisory board. Merilyn's spirit was always buoyant. Now she has forever taken wing.

title: Starwood Capital Selling Some Assets
description: Starwood Capital Group, an investment fund headed by the financier Barry Sternlicht, agreed today to sell $1 billion of mortgage assets to Angeles Participating Mortgage Trust for cash and securities.

title: Avian Flu Strain Spreads to Humans
description: A deadly influenza virus previously known to afflict only poultry has spread to humans and is causing alarm in the medical and scientific community here. Four people have been infected and two have died, one last Friday.

title: Direct-Mail Guru Tells (Almost) All
description: MOST Americans have never heard of Jerry Huntsinger, but they have probably heard from him. Mr. Huntsinger, 64, is a direct-mail fund-raiser, one of the best in the business by most accounts, and he spends much of his energy devising ways to keep people from tossing their junk mail into the wastebasket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOGAN, HELEN STOEFFEL
description: LOGAN-Helen Stoeffel. On Dec. 7, 1997. Widow of George. Formerly of Hartsdale, NY. Survived by son and nine grandchildren. Information and condolences can be sent to Donald J. Logan, 465 Churchill Drive, Berwyn, PA. 19312.

title: AFFILIATED COMPUTER UNIT TO PAY $52 MILLION FOR A FIRM
description: Technical Directions, a unit of Affiliated Computer Services of Dallas, plans to buy a professional services firm for $52 million in stock and the assumption of $10 million in debt to expand its information technology staffing business. It said it would not disclose the name of the firm before it received regulatory approval. Affiliated had sales of $48 million for the 12 months ended in October.

title: Blocks Still Closed After Wall Peels Off
description: More than two dozen city employees worked into the small hours of the morning today preparing for what the city's Buildings Commissioner called a ''tricky'' procedure to repair the damaged wall of an office building on Madison Avenue.

title: A BBC Cable Channel Is on the Way to the U.S.
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation, widely recognized for the quality of its television programs and news reporting, will start up a commercially supported cable channel in the United States early next year to bring its dramas, comedies, documentaries and World News service directly into American homes for the first time.

title: Ice Cap Shows Ancient Mines Polluted the Globe
description: SAMPLES extracted from Greenland's two-mile-deep ice cap have yielded evidence that ancient Carthaginian and Roman silver miners working in southern Spain fouled the global atmosphere with lead for some 900 years.

title: Disney Plans to Start A Cartoon TV Network
description: A 24-hour Disney cartoon television network will be introduced in April by Disney/ABC Cable Networks, capitalizing on the more than 2,200 cartoon episodes in the Walt Disney Company library.

title: Big Gifts Are Growing, and So Are the Lists of Big Givers
description: When Ted Turner griped to Maureen Dowd of The New York Times last year about the need for a list of ''most generous Americans,'' he said he thought that such a ranking would egg the rich on to greater feats of competitive philanthropy. The immediate effect was to spur the media on to a flurry of competitive list making. Three lists -- compiled by Slate, The American Benefactor and Fortune for 1996 -- have emerged as the ones to watch. Naturally they differ because their criteria for inclusion differ. Here is a key to the lists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, IRVING SHERWOOD, M.D.
description: WRIGHT-Irving Sherwood, M.D. 96, died suddenly at home on December 8, 1997. He was the husband of the late Lois Elliman Wright, father of Barbara Wright Gatje, of New York City, and Alison Wright Cameron, of Bronxville; grandfather of Alexandra Lord Gatje, Douglas Wright Cameron, Marianna Gatje Perrier, Laura Howell Cameron, Margot Kim Gatje, and great-grandfather of Lucas Wright Perrier. He was Emeritus Clinical Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Medical College, and Honorary Attending Physician at the New York Hospital. Dr. Wright was born in New York City on October 27, 1901. He was a direct descendant of Wolphert Gerritsen van Couwenhoven whose family settled in Nieuw Amsterdam in 1630. He was nationally and internationally known for his research and leadership in the fields of cardiovascular disease and geriatrics. He served as President of the American Heart Association, the American College of Physicians, the American Geriatric Society, and in 1979, founded the American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Irving Sherwood Wright Center on Aging, Department of Medicine, New York Hospital-Cornell University Medical Center, 1300 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021, or to AFAR, 1414 Avenue of the Americas, 18th Floor, New York, New York 10019. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Mexico Shift by Goodyear
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today that it would shift production of power transmission products to Mexico in an effort to cut costs. The move will eliminate about 150 jobs at the plant in Lincoln, Neb., where the products are now made. Goodyear, based here in Akron, said it would invest $15 million to build a plant at an undetermined site in northern Mexico.

title: MacArthur 'Genius' Grants Get Some Heat and a New Head
description: IT has become an annual summer ritual: the announcement of the list of MacArthur Fellows, the breathless newspaper articles scoured for the winners' accomplishments (and ages), the unchosen left brooding, What about me?

title: Talking Business With: Philip K. Howard; Municipal Art Society Regroups Under a Hater of Red Tape
description: Having made his name in literary circles as a staunch foe of legal red tape -- his 1995 book ''The Death of Common Sense: How Law Is Suffocating America'' elevated that theme to the New York Times best-seller list -- Philip K. Howard may seem an unlikely figure at the helm of the Municipal Art Society, one of the city's most powerful civic groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIS, ELI
description: ELLIS-Eli. The Officers of Amerada Hess Corporation express their deep sorrow at the loss of their esteemed outside counsel and close friend, Eli Ellis. His guidance and advice have been of great value to the Corporation and will be missed. We express our deepest sympathy to his wife Suzanne, his daughter Judith and his step-children Joan and John.

title: Doing Well by Doing Good: Uncle Sam Can Help
description: FOR those who want to help out a charity, there are many ways to do so while you also cut your taxes. The 1997 tax act, along with pending Internal Revenue Service regulations, has blocked some of the more aggressive tax-saving techniques, but many remain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FABIAN, TIBOR, PH.D.
description: FABIAN-Tibor, Ph.D. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopaedic Institute and the Officers of the HJD Research & Development Foundation mourn the passing of Dr. Tibor Fabian, distinguished Honorary President and Chairman of the Board. Dr. Fabian was a committed friend and loyal benefactor of the hospital. With great foresight, together with his devoted wife Dorothy, he established the Drs. Dorothy and Tibor Fabian Prize Award in 1983. This award, presented annually to an academic member of the hospital for the most outstanding and innovative research publication, continues to stimulate the excellent research work accomplished at HJD. Dr. Fabian has left an indelible mark on the hospital through his encouragement and philanthropic support of our major initiatives. He will be sadly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Dorothy, his sons Timothy and Jonathan, and to the entire family. William A. Perlmuth Chairman of the Board George M. Jaffin Honorary Chairman R & D Foundation Victor H. Frankel, MD President John N. Kastanis, FACHE Chief Executive Officer Joseph D. Zuckerman, MD Surgeon-In-Chief

title: Drag Queens Sip of the Mainstream
description: It's an all-star cast: Lypsinka! Lady Bunny! Varla Jean Merman! Jem Jender! Candis Cayne! Joey Arias! Charles Busch! Charles Pierce! All right, so maybe they are not household names, but such are the queens of the drag circuit celebrated on ''Dragtime.'' Tonight's HBO camera tracks a giggle of female impersonators or ''gender illusionists'' on visits to New York City last Christmas, New Orleans at Mardi Gras, a Gay Pride parade in Philadelphia and clubs here and there that are generously described as becoming ''mainstream culture.''

title: Knicks, a Recent Bust, Forgo Boasts for Bulls
description: This is the scheduled springboard for bravado, a time when the Knicks typically puff out their chests and proclaim themselves ready to challenge the world champion Chicago Bulls.

title: Schwab Name Used in Fraud, U.S. Says
description: In a new twist on an old swindle, a Brooklyn man raised $195,000 from investors by falsely contending that the brokerage firm Charles Schwab & Company was selling shares in his computer software company, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SILBERMAN, DAVID
description: SILBERMAN-David. December 9, 1996. It's been a year, but we see you every day. Your mother, father and sister

title: Obscure President. Great Team.
description: There is no escaping dynasties in the women's game.

title: Blair, Hoping to Disarm Critics, Creates Agency to Work for Poor
description: The Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair went on the offensive today to convince doubters that in pushing for tight spending restraints and toughened welfare standards it was not ignoring the disadvantaged.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Friday with a review about the rock band Spiritualized misidentified the musician shown. He was the bass player Sean Cook, not the guitarist J. Spaceman.

title: Court Hears Appeal in Encryption Case
description: The power of the Internet to transcend national borders pitted personal rights against national security today when a Federal appeals court heard arguments in a suit contending that Government export controls on data-scrambling software illegally restrict free speech.

title: Muslim Leaders' Talks Hailed by Iran as Rebuff to U.S.
description: Leaders representing the world's one billion Muslims poured into this capital today for a conference that Iran is hailing as evidence that it has overcome American-led attempts to isolate it as an international pariah.

title: Justice Declines to Extend Ban on 'Megan's Law' Notices
description: A United States Supreme Court Justice refused today to extend a 17-month-old lower-court order that has prevented New Jersey from implementing a key provision of ''Megan's Law'': the notification of schools, youth groups and women's organizations about paroled sex offenders living in their towns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEILER, PAULA, M.D.
description: SEILER-Paula, M.D. On April 9, 1997 in Gothenburg, Sweden at the age of 100 years. Dr. Seiler was a native New Yorker born on December 7, 1896. She graduated from NYU Medical School in 1922 and was in general practice over forty years at 15 West 11th Street in Greenwich Village. She was involved with Planned Parenthood and family planning work throughout her career. She leaves a loving family of son James and his wife Barbro and grandchildren Bjorn and Annica, all of Sweden.

title: GATX to Take 4th-Quarter Charges
description: The GATX Corporation said today that it would take fourth-quarter charges of $150 million to pay for job cuts, write-downs and asset sales at two units, in moves prompted in part by reduced use of its petroleum terminals.

title: Cleaning up The Midwest
description: NAME: Deborah Leff

title: A Vry Brf Hstry of Phlnthpy
description: Like any other activity, philanthropy has had its share of saints and rascals, some pursuing utopian visions, others cloaking self-interest in ennobling rhetoric. What follows are some hysteric, er, historic moments in the roadshow of American philanthropic life.

title: Florida Starts Agency Search
description: The State of Florida said yesterday that it had begun a nationwide search for an agency to develop an anti-smoking campaign to be supported by $70 million in spending during the next 18 to 24 months.

title: Federal Judge Once More Rules Gigante Competent
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Vincent Gigante, the Mafia boss, was mentally fit to be sentenced to prison for his conviction on murder-conspiracy and racketeering charges.

title: Automaker Confounds Its Critics by Streamlining and Making Money : Leaner Volkswagen Has Last Laugh
description: FRANKFURT  Few companies have been shackled with as many of the disadvantages of operating a business in Germany as Volkswagen AG.

title: Pilots Train Cranes to Fly Away Home
description: IN mid-October, Kent Clegg, a biologist and veteran pilot of ultralight aircraft, was leading a small flock of juvenile whooping cranes and sandhill cranes on a 700-mile migration flight from Idaho to New Mexico when a golden eagle, soaring high overhead, folded its wings, locked on one of the cranes like an air-to-air missile -- and missed!

title: A SPECIAL SECTION: Giving
description: With philanthropy, it's all personal: Who gives (and doesn't), who gets and why, plus the how-tos of donating and volunteering, the ''hot boards'' game and the ups and downs of the ''genius grants.'' Section G.

title: PRO BASKETBALL ; The Nets Are Not Yet At Level Of Heat
description: Nets Coach John Calipari used tonight's game against the Miami Heat as a barometer of his team's progress. And Calipari's assessment made for a lively, yet sobering, post-game meeting.

title: Brawley Adviser Testifies on His Motives
description: One of three former advisers of Tawana Brawley testified today that a chain of events preceding their first public branding of Steven A. Pagones as a rapist provided both a reason to suspect him and a basis for believing that law enforcement officials needed prodding to make arrests.

title: Hilton Predicts Disappointing Earnings
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said late today that its fourth-quarter operating earnings would be below analysts' expectations because of sluggish growth in its casino business.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A court in Athens ruled last weekend that ELENA FORD, a granddaughter of Henry Ford 2d and an heiress to the Ford automobile fortune, has no claims on the estate of her father, the shipping magnate Stavros Niarchos, Reuters reported yesterday.

title: Designers' Council Opens Door a Bit
description: Like people everywhere, fashion people like to complain. One of their pet gripes in recent years has been the C.F.D.A. Awards, which became known irreverently as the C.R.D.A. -- or Calvin Ralph Donna Awards -- because of the frequency with which those designers were recipients. But this year, a new generation is being recognized, signaling that the Council of Fashion Designers of America has taken a positive step to answer its critics and to shine its image.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERFEL, ARTHUR A.
description: WERFEL-Arthur A., 87. December 5, 1997. Survived by his wife of 51 years Phyllis, son Steven, grandson Jeffrey, sisters Dorothy and Esther. He touched many lives and we will miss his kindness, love and inner strength. Shiva Wednesday and Thursday 6 P.M., at 1 Carlton Street, Malverne, NY.

title: Metro Business; Con Ed in Lighting Venture
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York said yesterday that it had formed a joint venture with Remote Source Lighting International to sell fiber-optic lighting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENTRITT, PETER A.
description: LEVENTRITT-Peter A. On December 6 at age 82. Survived by his wife, Faith, two stepdaughters, Hope and Cary Igleheart, and his niece Ann and Paul Bschorr, and their children, Sharon, Molly and Katherine.

title: Study on Using Magnets to Treat Pain Surprises Skeptics
description: NO ONE was more skeptical about using magnets for pain relief than Dr. Carlos Vallbona, former chairman of the department of community medicine at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston. So Dr. Vallbona was amazed when a study he did found that small, low intensity magnets worked, at least for patients experiencing symptoms that can develop years after polio.

title: Victory Drought Finally Ends for Rangers
description: First things first: the Rangers won their first game of the month last night, a 3-1 victory over the Phoenix Coyotes in Madison Square Garden. It was their first victory after four ties and four defeats in their previous eight games. They had not won since Nov. 21, at Carolina, and it was their first victory at home since Nov. 16. The winning goal was by Aleksandr Karpovtsev, his first of the season. And the clinching goal was scored by Vladimir Vorobiev, also his first of the season.

title: INSURER IN AGONY: Behind the Bleeding at Oxford -- A special report; Giant H.M.O. Becomes the Victim of Its Own Ambition
description: Over the last year, Oxford Health Plans Inc. has fallen seriously behind in paying doctors and hospitals, owing hundreds of millions of dollars. Blaming its new computer system, Oxford counseled patience and made repeated assurances that the snarls were being addressed.

title: Sprewell Talks To Carlesimo
description: Latrell Sprewell apologized to P. J. Carlesimo in a 5- to 10-minute telephone conversation on Sunday, said a lawyer for Sprewell, the former Golden State Warriors guard. It came seven days after Sprewell attacked Carlesimo, his coach, in two altercations at practice.

title: NAGANO 1998: OLYMPIC PROFILE -- Groundbreaker in the Nets; A Pioneer Female Goalie Fights to Make the U.S. Team
description: On Saturday night, Erin Whitten suffered a rare deflating moment. After surrendering four goals in the second period, she was pulled from the net against Canada, the one team that stands between the United States and a gold medal at the inaugural Olympic women's ice hockey tournament.

title: Doctors Urged to Admit Mistakes
description: WHEN doctors make a mistake that harms a patient, they should tell the patient what happened, apologize and do whatever it takes to repair the damage, researchers are urging, in a stance that is drawing mixed reviews from the medical community, insurance companies and lawyers.

title: Observer; Wish You Were Here
description: I wanted to write something about the breathtaking beauty of Manhattan in December. And what is the result? A roundup of the usual cliches. The evening light becomes ''magical.'' Christmas lights in trees, windows and hotel lobbies ''sparkle like diamonds'' against ''the black velvet night.''

title: First American Sets $2.4 Billion Bank Acquisition
description: The First American Corporation said today that it had agreed to pay $2.44 billion in stock to acquire the Deposit Guaranty Corporation, which had been the subject of recent takeover speculation.

title: Clinton Lobbies for Treaty by Telephone
description: President Clinton telephoned the leaders of Argentina, Brazil, the Philippines and Tanzania on Sunday to press for a new treaty to fight global warming, the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said today.

title: Executives Named To New Posts
description: Two prominent agency executives have been named to new posts.

title: INTERNATIONAL GAME MAKES A MOVE IN AUSTRALIA
description: International Game Technology said it had agreed to buy Olympic Amusements, a casino equipment maker based in Melbourne, Australia, for about $170 million (Australian), or $114 million (United States). Olympic Amusements provides electronic gaming machines, equipment and related services. International Game, based in Reno, also makes gaming products and software systems.

title: Safe Needles in Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, JAMES J. JR.
description: McCARTHY-James J. Jr. age 89, of Fairfield, CT. formerly of NYC died December 7, 1997. He was a graduate of Regis H.S. Class of 1925, Fordham University class of 1929 and The Fordham Law School class of 1932. He was an Attorney for the Immigrant Savings Bank, New York City. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Mooney McCarthy; one son and his wife, Stephen and Rosemary McCarthy of Binghamton, NY; one daughter and her husband, Peggy and Larry Puzzo of E. Hampton, CT. and eleven grandchildren. Funeral services will be Wednesday at 10:00AM, at St. Thomas Aquinas Church, Fairfield, CT. Interment in Calvary Cemetery, NY. Wake services will be held on December 9 at 4 PM-8 PM, at Shaughnessey Brothers Funeral Home, 50 Reef Rd., Fairfield, CT. It would be appreciated if donations be made in his memory to: St. Thomas Aquinas Capitol Fund, 1719 Post Road, Fairfield.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAS, KAMLESHWAR
description: DAS-Kamleshwar. Died on November 6 in Bradenton, FL. Former Deputy Director, Division of Human Rights, United Nations. Beloved husband of Jean and father of Shyam, Arun, Kamala and Raj. He also is survived by seven grandchildren.

title: Raines Will Join Chili Davis As Yankee
description: As expected, the Yankees will finally welcome a new Yankee when they officially announce the signing of designated hitter Chili Davis as early as tomorrow. But, in an unexpected move, the Yankees will also welcome back an old Yankee when they sign outfielder Tim Raines to a deal sometime this week.

title: Whitman's Inaugural Is Inviting Unlimited Corporate Contributions
description: The inaugural committee for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced today that it would raise unlimited contributions from corporations to help pay for next month's inauguration festivities by having them make their donations through charitable groups. Organizers said that they had not decided whether the amount of the donations would be disclosed.

title: Performance Of New Bank Relies on U.S.
description: The prospects for the United Bank of Switzerland, the combination of two leading Swiss banks that was proposed yesterday, rest heavily on whether it can be successful in the North American investment, securities and banking businesses.

title: Riders Face a Beggar and Themselves
description: LIKE many New Yorkers, I don't give to beggars on the streets or in the subway -- except when I do. I made my most recent donation to a man with no legs as he propelled himself, using his arms and a wheelboard, through a Lexington Avenue IRT car. As soon as he left, I asked my fellow passengers why they had chosen to give, or not.

title: Sports of The Times; The Consequences Of Behaving Badly
description: THE basketball player was deeply unhappy when the coach told him what he expected from him -- particularly in the way of comportment, on and off the court.

title: New Horn Trio Receives Premieres in Eight Places
description: 'Horntrio'

title: New Yorker, Out of G.O.P. Post, Plans His Return
description: More resolute than penitent, Representative Bill Paxon is plotting his return from exile.

title: On My Mind; Killing Iraqi Children
description: For seven years Saddam Hussein has murdered Iraqi children, thousands. He refuses to provide the foreign food and medicine they must have.

title: HUD Has An 800 Line To Give Aid To the Needy
description: With expectations of a colder winter than usual in many parts of the country, the Department of Housing and Urban Development today announced the creation of a toll-free telephone number to summon aid for homeless people caught without food and shelter.

title: Big H.M.O. a Victim Of Its Own Ambition
description: Oxford Health Plans grew as it promised the convenience and savings of a health maintenance organization with the freedom to see any doctor by agreeing to share the cost.

title: Your Money, Their Views: Playing Partisan Politics With Nonprofits
description: A YEAR has passed since Calvin Dooley, a third-term Democratic representative from the Central Valley in California, was blindsided by some $250,000 worth of negative television advertising in the final days of his re-election campaign. And he still isn't certain who paid for it.

title: Accounts
description: * Chandon Estates, Napa Valley, Calif., the sparkling and still wines division of Moet Hennessy, part of LVMH, to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Los Angeles, part of MacManus Group, as the first agency to create a worldwide campaign. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: Discouraged Parcells Has Few Answers
description: The confusion was evident everywhere on the Jets today, especially with Coach Bill Parcells, who said he thought he had understood his players better.

title: Sports of The Times; One Coach Needs Class, Another Ego
description: THE coach meant to say he was ''disappointed or disgusted'' with himself. Ten minutes after a harrowing defeat, that's not the way it came out.

title: Helping Children Avoid Depression
description: FEW if any youngsters get through childhood without experiencing a trauma that can trigger depression. Distressing circumstances can range from difficulties with friends or school to physical, emotional or sexual abuse or losing a parent through divorce or death. Yet some children are highly resilient, able to weather any storm and emerge emotionally intact, while others fold like a tent in a strong wind at the slightest upset.

title: Austrian Joins the Parade of Marvelous Mezzos
description: Nature seems to be playing out a whim at the expense of the opera world. At a time when a shortage of great young tenors and sopranos leaves company directors scrambling to cast repertory staples persuasively, there seems no end to the parade of superb mezzo-sopranos. Angelika Kirchschlager, the 30-year-old Austrian mezzo who sang an appealingly varied recital program at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, is a relative newcomer to American audiences, having just made her debut at the Metropolitan Opera. Yet recordings have brought advance word of the warm tone and interpretive subtlety that have driven her career in Europe.

title: Safe Needles in Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Foamex to Acquire Crain
description: Foamex International Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the Crain Holdings Corporation, a maker of flexible polyurethane foam, for about $113 million in cash. It will also assume $100 million in debt. Crain is the holding company for Crain Industries, which is based in St. Louis. Both are owned by the Dallas-based buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst and the St. Louis-based Mills & Partners Inc.

title: By Design; Nighttime Frivolity in Handbags
description: Women may carry practical leather handbags by day, but nighttime calls for a bit of frivolity, especially for holiday festivities. So think silk, think velvet, think beads.

title: Counting the Change: Happy Riders
description: Maura Zoeller's eyes lighted up with the triumphant look of someone who had hit the jackpot in a game of marital one-upmanship. A new transit pass, she said, would mean that she and her husband could shop in Manhattan rather than Long Island by taking the subway practically for free.

title: Court Asked to Reinstate Gay Scout Leader
description: James Dale had received more than 30 merit badges and rose to Eagle Scout with his troop in Matawan before he was expelled from the Boy Scouts in 1990, when officials learned he was gay. More than five years after Mr. Dale first sued the Scouts unsuccessfully, a lawyer for the Manhattan-based Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund told a State Appellate Division panel in Hackensack that his expulsion violated the state's law against discrimination. Mr. Dale, 27, then an assistant scoutmaster, wants the panel to reinstate him and to block the Scouts from expelling gay members in the future, said the lawyer, Evan Wolfson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, PHILIP
description: KLEINMAN-Philip. Beloved husband of Mildred. Devoted father of Robert and Richard and fatherin-law of Pam and Ginny. Cherished grandfather of Jaime, David, Jared and Evan. Loving son of Anna. Service is on Tuesday, at 1 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Patterns
description: It's Milan for Calvin Klein

title: Heavenly Voices Above, Birdcalls Below
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic's thoughtful, well-played evening of Arvo Part and Olivier Messiaen on Saturday tried to make mysticism its common denominator. Yet halfway through this concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music one was more struck by the utter concreteness of their devotionals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAX, JULES
description: SAX-Jules.We share with Helen Potaznik, our Executive Committee member, the loss of her beloved father. Our sincere sympathies to her family. America-Israel Cultural Foundation. Vera Stern, President Romie Shapiro and Jan Prokop Co-Chairs Executive Committee

title: National News Briefs; Judge Rejects Request To Block Spielberg Film
description: A Federal judge today rejected an author's request to halt the release of the Steven Spielberg movie ''Amistad'' in New York and Los Angeles on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, SAMUEL
description: EISENBERG - Samuel. Beloved husband of Lynn. Loving father of Joel (Taryn), Neil (Hyun Mi), Richard (Wendy) and adoring grandfather of Lyndsay, Kevin, Jason, Samantha, Emily, Jared. Also survived by brother-in-law Bruce and sister-in-law, Annette.

title: Packers Are the Waltons in Pads
description: When Robert Brooks was considering colleges back in 1988, his choice was simple. Though powerhouse football schools such as U.C.L.A., Ohio State, Nebraska and Florida State might have been tempting, there was one clear choice -- South Carolina.

title: Barry Named Coach Of New Jersey Team
description: Rick Barry, a member of the Basketball Hall of Fame since 1987, has been hired as coach of the New Jersey Shorecats expansion franchise in the United Basketball Association. The franchise, based in Asbury Park, begins play May 1.

title: In Congo, Province's Dreams of a Better Life Fade
description: Barely a year ago, the people of this long-neglected area stood confidently on the verge of what was widely viewed here as a creeping form of independence.

title: Essay; Byzantine Alliance
description: Two meetings are taking place this week that will affect the power balances of tomorrow's Middle East.

title: Now Only Two Can Top Jordan
description: There was another milestone tonight for Michael Jordan.

title: Trizec Hahn Buys Building
description: The Trizec Hahn Corporation said today that it had bought the 42-story Metropolitan Square office building in downtown St. Louis for $137 million, or $145 a square foot. The purchase extends a buying spree by the Toronto-based company, which has spent more than $1.7 billion for properties across the United States. Metropolitan Square contains 948,000 square feet of space. Trizec Hahn estimates it bought the property from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company at a price 35 percent below what it would cost to develop a similar St. Louis building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLEBERG, RABBI LOUIS
description: ENGLEBERG-Rabbi Louis. We express our Kos Tanchumim to Gertude Herlands Engleberg on the passing of her beloved husband, Louis. Mrs. Engelberg, a sister of the late Charles H. Bendheim, past president of the Medical Center's American Committee, is a Founder and long time supporter. She has played a vital role in helping the mission of the Hospital with a Heart'' to heal the sick and ease the pain of the people of Jerusalem and Israel. We extend our sincerest condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chairperson of the Board Menno Ratzker, President Lee Weinbach, President Women's Division Sidney Adler, Treasurer Dr. Stuart Tauber, Exec. Dir.

title: About New York; At N.Y.U., Languages Si, Elitism Non
description: THE world is a little like New York, where English exists alongside most any other language. But some New Yorkers still think English alone will be enough to handle any situation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, HELEN
description: STERN-Helen. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member, and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAEL, CATHERINE BARBARA WHITTEN
description: MICHAEL - Catherine Barbara Whitten. The Brooklyn Hospital Center expresses deepest sympathy to the family of Catherine Michael who for seven years directed our Department of Nursing with great warmth and professionalism. A fellow of Wharton School, Catherine was an accomplished nurse, writer, lecturer and speaker, who rose to a position of prominence in her chosen profession, having served on numerous national, regional and city-wide healthcare and nurisng policy committees. Despite her busy and demanding professional and personal life, she always kept an open door to all members of her staff and gained respect through her warmth and friendliness towards all. We will greatly miss her. Seth S. Faison Chairman, Board of Trustees Frederick D. Alley President and CEO The Brooklyn Hospital Center

title: Van Dyke Wins a Round In His Fight to Be Fourth
description: No matter how ineptly the Jets played in Sunday's 22-14 loss to the Indianapolis Colts, there was at least a sliver of light. Alex Van Dyke, an almost forgotten wide receiver who had not played for two months, caught two touchdown passes and made good kickoff returns, and that may have made a strong enough impression on Coach Bill Parcells to earn Van Dyke more playing time and perhaps turn him into a major contributor.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Monday about a performance of ''Venus'' by the Murray Louis and Nikolais Dance company at the Joyce Theater on Thursday night misidentified a dancer in a sequence involving Kimberly Gibilisco. Ms. Gibilisco sat on the lap of Peter Kyle, not Eric Dunlap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMING, JOHN JOSEPH
description: FLEMING-John Joseph. On December 9th, 1997. Native of County Galway, Ireland. Retired Detective, NYPD. Cherished husband of the late Jean. Devoted father of Maura, Sally, Geraldine and John, Jr. Loving grandfather of Stephen F. and Daniel M. Etna. Proud father-in-law of Daniel A. Etna and Joseph D. Gross. Also survived by his beloved sisters Bridie F. Geraghty and Sr. Mary Rita Fleming and his sisters-in-law Mary Hannon Fleming and Mary M. Fleming. Pre-deceased by his siblings Sr. Mary Agnes, Frank, Patrick, Thomas, Kathleen and Mary Fleming Doyle. Funeral on Thursday, at 9:30 A.M., from the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Avenue, Bklyn. Funeral Mass 10:15 A.M., Good Shepherd R.C. Church. Visiting Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Stolid Reno Douses Fire On G.O.P.'s Day of Rage
description: Not least among the talents that Attorney General Janet Reno brings to the table at a Congressional hearing is her sheer ability to de-energize a stormy situation by simply absorbing long bolts of speechifying and criticism.

title: Making Books; Celebrity Books Lose Panache

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, IRVING SHERWOOD, M.D.
description: WRIGHT-Irving Sherwood, M.D. 96, died suddenly at home on December 8, 1997. He was the husband of the late Lois Elliman Wright, father of Barbara Wright Gatje, of New York City, and Alison Wright Cameron, of Bronxville; grandfather of Alexandra Lord Gatje, Douglas Wright Cameron, Marianna Gatje Perrier, Laura Howell Cameron, Margot Kim Gatje, and great-grandfather of Lucas Wright Perrier. He was Emeritus Clinical Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Medical College, and Honorary Attending Physician at the New York Hospital. Dr. Wright was born in New York City on October 27, 1901. He was a direct descendant of Wolphert Gerritsen van Couwenhoven whose family settled in Nieuw Amsterdam in 1630. He was nationally and internationally known for his research and leadership in the fields of cardiovascular disease and geriatrics. He served as President of the American Heart Association, the American College of Physicians, the American Geriatric Society, and in 1979, founded the American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Irving Sherwood Wright Center on Aging, Department of Medicine, New York Hospital-Cornell University Medical Center, 1300 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021, or to AFAR, 1414 Avenue of the Americas, 18th Floor, New York, New York 10019. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend on Friday about the Murray Hill neighborhood in Manhattan misspelled the surname of an author of the book ''New York 1960,'' which includes pictures of the area. He is Thomas Mellins, not Mellians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, BERNARD SHAW
description: FEINBERG-Bernard Shaw. On December 8, 1997, beloved husband of Etta, father of Nina, grandfather of Jessica and Sophie; son of Leon and Ella, brother of Beatrice and Seymour. A graduate of Tulane Medical School, 1931; interned at Montefiore Hospital, fifty years on staff at Mount Sinai Hospital, New York. A wise and gentle man, a gifted and dedicated physician, a loyal friend; a student of history, a lover of art, music, and literature. Requiescat. Friends and family may pay their respects at the home of Nina and Marshall Brickman, Thursday, December 11, from 6 to 9 P.M.

title: Survey Shows Manufacturers Optimistic
description: United States manufacturers are optimistic about the coming year despite uncertainty over Asia's financial crisis, expecting stronger revenues, increased employment and stable prices, a group of factory purchasing executives said yesterday.

title: Ssangyong to Sell Resort and Other Assets
description: The Ssangyong Group, South Korea's sixth-largest conglomerate, said yesterday that it would raise 800 billion won ($522 million) by selling its ski resort and other assets and by cutting 30 percent of its managers. The company, which sold its flagship automobile company to the Daewoo Group on Monday, plans to sell the Ssangyong Precision Company, which produces automobile engines and other industrial equipment, and parts of the Ssangyong Heavy Industrial Company and the Ssangyong Engineering Company.

title: U.S. Presence in Gulf Is Denounced in Iran
description: Iran opened a world Islamic conference today with a harsh denunciation of the West, urging Muslim countries to resist what it called ''persistent and cunning enemies'' led by the United States and Israel.

title: Liberties; Janet, Louis And Bill
description: I watched Louis Freeh carefully. I was afraid that, at any moment, the diminutive F.B.I. Director was going to spring into Janet Reno's lap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLOKE, ALFRED
description: KLOKE-Alfred. Passed away on November 17. He was 75 years old and is survived by his wife Ingrid, his daughter Renate Wiedemann, his son Daniel, his sister Helga Grundmann, his sister-in-law Helga Haniel, his niece Marion and three grandchildren. He was a chief architectural designer, graphic artist, painter, photographer and sculptor, and pursued interests in all the fine arts. He will be missed by many; the inspirations he shared survive him. A private family service was held. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Dorland Mountain Arts Colony, POB 6, Temecula, CA. 92593.

title: Civility in Politics: Going, Going, Gone
description: During a fiery debate on financing education, the president of the school board here recently chose a rather dramatic way to express his disagreement with a fellow board member. He grabbed him by the throat.

title: Metro Business; Kiwi Cuts Fares to Boston
description: Kiwi International Air Lines, the discount carrier based in Newark, has cut all its fares between New York and Boston.

title: Calendar
description: All Dressed Up

title: Correction
description: A recipe for Pear Pecan Tart with the Chef column on Nov. 5 included a superfluous item in the ingredients list. A reader's letter dated Dec. 2 points out that the dessert contains no melted butter.

title: Qualified to Serve
description: Forty years ago this week, only a short time after he desegregated Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., President Dwight Eisenhower signed the Civil Rights Act of 1957. The act created one of the country's most important forces for equality -- the civil rights division of the Justice Department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GHENTS, RUTH OLIVIA HEIG
description: GHENTS-Ruth Olivia Heig. Of New Canaan, CT. Formerly of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn on December 8, 1997. Wife of John H. Ghents. Mother of Pamela May Ness, Bonnie Ruth Flaherty, and Michelle Ann Cappellieri. Sister of Naomi Drew and five grandchildren also survive. Funeral mass on Friday, December 12 at 10 A.M., at St. Aloysius Church, New Canaan. Visitation Hoyt Funeral Home, Main Street, New Canaan, Thursday from 5-8 P.M. Contributions to St. Aloysius School Library, 40 Cherry Street, New Canaan, CT. 06840 or The American Cancer Society.

title: BOMB TRIAL FOCUS ON JOHN DOE NO. 2
description: Morris John Kuper Jr. was late for work. Mary Martinez was stopped at a red light. Shane Boyd had just bought a soda. Darvin Bates had just hired a dishwasher at his waffle shop.

title: Ozawa Acts To Calm Tanglewood Faculty Friction
description: Hoping to staunch a flow of faculty resignations and public rancor, Seiji Ozawa, music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, released a six-page statement yesterday spelling out his vision for the 57-year-old Tanglewood Music Center and explaining what he thinks has caused the recent strife there.

title: Transit Pass Plan to Put City in Step With Others
description: The New York City transit agency, in moving toward a system of monthly, weekly and daily passes, is about to join the mainstream of North American cities and, transportation officials said yesterday, confront a new array of challenges and opportunities undreamt of under the single fare system.

title: Art(?) to Go: Museum Shops Broaden Wares, at a Profit
description: Rodin had pasta first. Now Warhol has pasta, too. Monet has Provencal soup, olive oil and absinthe. Rauschenberg has no food, but he has dinner plates.

title: KOREANS PRESSING U.S. AND JAPANESE FOR SPEEDIER AID
description: With investor confidence again starting to erode despite the international rescue of its economy, South Korea's Government called on the United States and Japan today to quickly provide some money that they had pledged only as a last resort.

title: Why Dine Alone? There's Room at the Bar
description: WHEN I walk into a restaurant I head for the bar -- not for drinks but for dinner. If you enter a restaurant alone and eat at a table, you eat in your own world. When you sit at the bar, the world's at your table.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEAMAN, BURTON S.
description: SEAMAN-Burton S. Beloved husband of Lee. Devoted father of Margie, Alex and Diane. Loving grandfather of Kevin, Brian, Mitchell and Jeffrey. Funeral services Wednesday, December 10, 1997, 9:45am, Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Rd. Great Neck, N.Y.

title: INSIDE
description: Sterling Forest is a big winner as the Doris Duke foundation awards grants. PAGE B2

title: Sibelius, Recorder Of Winter
description: There is something intriguingly peculiar about ''Northern Lights,'' the two-week exploration of Sibelius's music at Lincoln Center, and it is a peculiarity that seems suited to the subject at hand.

title: 2 Swiss Executives Talk Of Benefits of Bank Merger
description: The two Swiss executives who will run the world's second-largest bank were all smiles in New York yesterday as they began a day of meetings to talk up their new creation, the United Bank of Switzerland.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the labor movement incorrectly said that Ron Carey resigned as president of the teamsters' union. Mr. Carey took a leave of absence.

title: Wooten Charged With Assaulting Woman
description: Giants safety Tito Wooten has been charged with assaulting a woman in a New Jersey hotel room, but he practiced today with the team and Coach Jim Fassel said the team did not plan any immediate disciplinary action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, BETTY
description: HOFFMAN-Betty. Loving aunt and loving sister of Edith Chernack and Alexander Hoffman and the late Sally Hoffman, Barney Hoffman and Nathan Hoffman. Always in our hearts and minds.

title: Fight Heroin's Source
description: To the Editor:

title: National Origins: South Florida; In Sour Splendor, The Real Key Lime Still Rules
description: THE land is as flat as a flight deck here in the Redlands. You can still see the scars of Hurricane Andrew, whose 200-mile-an-hour winds lashed this fertile countryside in August 1992: boughless pine trunks rising forlornly above clumps of young vegetation, coconut palms amputated 10 feet from the ground, boarded-up buildings, fields waiting to be replanted.

title: Pataki Receives $17,000 For Talk to Corporation
description: Gov. George E. Pataki went to Milwaukee last night to give his fifth paid speech of the year, receiving about $17,000 for a talk to a mutual fund management company about the post-industrial economy.

title: L. Poliakov, 87, Historian of Anti-Semitism
description: Leon Poliakov, a historian of anti-Semitism who testified at major war crimes trials, died Monday in France, where he lived, leaders of Jewish groups said. He was 87.

title: Prague Journal; The Czechs' New Haunt, Hauntingly Like the Old
description: The old smoke-wreathed chairs have gone, the green marble interior from Comrade Castro's Cuba is now a slab of memorabilia and the sallow ambiance has been replaced by the megawatt white light of a sleek brasserie.

title: 50% STAKE IN AMERICAN REF-FUEL GOES FOR $237 MILLION
description: The Duke Energy Corporation and the United American Energy Corporation paid $237 million in cash to acquire a stake in a waste-to-energy company from Air Products and Chemicals Inc. of Allentown, Pa. The Duke Energy Power Services unit and the closely held United American formed a partnership to buy a 50 percent stake in the Houston-based American Ref-Fuel. Browning-Ferris Industries owns the other half. Duke, based in Charlotte, N.C., and United American, of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., announced the purchase on Oct. 13 without disclosing a purchase price. American Ref-Fuel is the third-largest generator of electricity from waste in the United States, with most of its plants in New York and New Jersey. It had $350 million in revenue in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30.

title: Rural School Districts Sue Whitman, Asserting State Aid Is Inadequate
description: A group of mostly rural school districts filed a lawsuit against Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today, charging that her school financing plan does not give them enough money to provide the ''thorough and efficient education'' required by the State Constitution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMACH, MANFRED
description: TOMACH-Manfred. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved past President and former member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Mildred, Marva and George Ged, and the entire family. Stanley Plonchak, President

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Stocks were lower this morning. At the midday recess, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 196 points, or 1.17 percent, at 16,490.51. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 554.94 points, or 3.44 percent. In Hong Kong, stocks were down more than 1 percent in early trading.

title: Arts Abroad; Always Something New in This Mexico City Museum
description: When I first went to Mexico City I had barely heard of the Cultural Center for Contemporary Art, which had been established there in 1987 and was directed, then as now, by an American museum man, Robert Littman.

title: Sports of The Times; Stern Makes Sprewell The Victim
description: ALL around the Knicks' pre-game locker room here last night were reminders of why David Stern turned into Rudolph Giuliani last week and kicked Latrell Sprewell out of his league for a year.

title: Oxford Says It Misjudged Cost of Care
description: Oxford Health Plans, a managed care company that enjoyed running advertisements questioning why competitors were not matching its consumer-friendly brand of health care, acknowledged yesterday that it had sorely underestimated the cost of that care.

title: TV Notes; Coup for CBS News
description: For the first time in more than five years, CBS's ''Evening News With Dan Rather'' finished in a tie for first place with NBC's ''Nightly News With Tom Brokaw'' in the Nielsen ratings last week, continuing a climb that had CBS News employees feeling elated and their competitors baffled.

title: Whoops, More Evidence to Ignore
description: The campaign finance story is not breaking, like some Washington news. It is oozing. That is why Janet Reno was back on Capitol Hill carrying out her role in the Clinton Cabinet: ooze control. But Ms. Reno's specious testimony about actual and apparent conflicts of interest should not detract us from the more important events going on outside the hearing room, where Congressional Republicans joined F.B.I. Director Louis Freeh on the long and honorable list of those who have failed to explain the Independent Counsel Act to Ms. Reno.

title: Sips; Winterizing an 1890's Classic to Bring Back Its Warmth
description: LIKE food and clothing, cocktails have their seasons. A frozen banana daiquiri in January is perverse. You don't have to be in Singapore to order a Singapore sling, but a sultry breeze is absolutely mandatory. Unfortunately, most winter holiday drinks require a lot of ingredients and a lot of prep time. Even worse, most of them are painfully precious. There are a thousand reasons to look forward to Christmas. Glogg, the pointless Swedish punch, is not one of them.

title: Former Partner of Milbank, Tweed Indicted
description: A former partner of the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy was indicted today on charges of perjury in connection with the 1994 bankruptcy of the Bucyrus-Erie Company, a mining equipment manufacturer.
