title: U.S. Turns to Pakistan for Help In Resolving Afghan Civil War
description: In the last two months, three senior State Department officials have visited here -- the Assistant Secretary of State for Asia, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright herself.

title: Consumer Group Quits Power Industry Talks
description: The American Association of Retired Persons withdrew today from talks on reshaping New York State's electric power industry, charging that the Pataki administration was stifling dissent and giving only token rate reductions to ordinary customers.

title: Free Press Invoked in Flight 800 Part Case
description: The lawyer for a 52-year-old Virginia-based writer who was charged with illegal possession of pieces of the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 tried yesterday to portray the matter as a free press issue.

title: SNYDER COMMUNICATIONS ACQUIRES 2 SALES BUSINESSES
description: Snyder Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had bought two pharmaceutical contract-sales organizations for a total of $58.5 million. The company said it would buy Pharmflex for $34 million and Rapid Deployment Group Ltd. for $24.5 million. Pharmflex, of Malvern, Pa., and Rapid Deployment, of Winchester, England, provide sales services to pharmaceutical companies. Snyder, a marketing concern based in Bethesda, Md., said the transactions would enable it to provide contract pharmaceutical sales services worldwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISENFELD, MILDRED
description: WEISENFELD-Mildred. Prevent Blindness America mourns the passing of Mildred Weisenfeld, founder of Fight For Sight. In 1988 Prevent Blindness America and Fight For Sight affiliated in mutual support of Mildred's unswerving fight against vision loss. Since 1946, Mildred raised millions of dollars to bring bright young scientists into the field of research. Considering all the discoveries made by the thousands of investigators who received their initial support from Mildred, hers was a life of incalculable achievement. The 35,000 volunteers of Prevent Blindness America, its staff and the people whose lives she touched will miss Mildred deeply. Kent D. Stuckey Chairman of the Board Prevent Blindness America

title: Investigators Missed Clue To Lie Told By an Envoy
description: Investigators vetting M. Larry Lawrence's nomination to be ambassador to Switzerland in 1993 apparently overlooked a clue in State Department files that he had invented a heroic World War II record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILGALLEN, MARGARET H.
description: KILGALLEN-Margaret H. On December 7, 1997. Formerly of Brooklyn. Devoted wife of the late Dr. John J. Kilgallen, MD. Beloved mother of Dr. John D., M.D., of Cape Elizabeth, ME., Elaine of Blue Point, N.Y., Kevin P. of Westbury, N.Y., and the late Robert C. Loving grandmother of six. Fond great grandmother of two. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 11 AM St. Brigid's R.C. Church, Westbury, New York. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, N.Y. For information, contact Donohue Funeral Home, Westbury, NY.

title: 4 Teen-Agers Wounded In Queens Shootout
description: A dispute that began in a Springfield Gardens, Queens, restaurant ended last night in gunfire that wounded four teen-agers, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WAGMAN, JOSEPH
description: WAGMAN-Joseph 10/6/22-12/10/96 Beloved husband, father, and grandfather. Loved by all and always remembered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHICCO, MERILYN CRIENE
description: CHICCO-Merilyn Criene. Of East Stroudsburg, PA. Formerly of Sucasunna, New Jersey. Born June 27, 1936 in Scranton, died on December 6 at Mt. Sinai Hospital, NYC of a stroke. With her first husband, Leonard D. Chicco, Merilyn founded Web Dynamics, Inc., developing novel machines to manufacture face masks from microfibers. Leonard died in 1995 and Merilyn sold the business to Johns Manville, Inc. In June of 1997 she married Richard Leshko who survives. Merilyn was deeply loved by her son, Leonard, Jr., her daughters, Kathleen Seagraves and Cynthia Driskil, and her sisters, D'Orsay Mancuso and Donna Samsell. Funeral 10 A.M., on Wednesday at DeGraw Roever Funeral Home, Dunmore, PA. Merilyn collected antique airplanes and was preparing to solo in an ultralight aircraft at her private airport, Eagles Nest. Donations may be made to Mid Atlantic Air Museum, Reading Regional Airport, Pennsylvania 19605, where she served on the advisory board. Merilyn's spirit was always buoyant. Now she has forever taken wing.

title: Findings We Never Found
description: Last May, the National Academy of Sciences released a long-awaited report on the economic impact of immigration. As members of the panel that wrote the report, we have been distressed to hear public officials repeatedly misrepresent its findings as the immigration debate has evolved in the last seven months.

description: BASEBALL

title: Woodrow Wyatt Dies at 79; Laborite Turned Thatcherite
description: Woodrow Wyatt, a high-living onetime Socialist politician and journalist who later turned abrasively against the left as a television presenter and conservative tabloid newspaper columnist, died on Sunday in London. Created Baron Wyatt of Weeford in 1987, he was 79.

description: An Asian Empire

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINGSTED, MARGARET JO
description: RINGSTED-Margaret Jo. The managers and staff of Novo Nordisk of North American, Inc. mourn the passing of our former colleague, Margaret Jo Ringsted, in Paris, France, on December 4, after a long illness. Margaret Ringsted was Director of Corporate Communications for Novo Nordisk A/S and worked for the company over twenty years. From 1991-96 Margaret lived in New York City heading up Novo Nordisk's communications activities in North America. Her enthusiasm, commitment and sense of style will be deeply remembered. Our heartfelt condolences to Margaret's family and many close friends. A service will take place December 19, Hellerup Kirke, Hellerupvej 5750, Ringe, Denmark.

title: Boeing Says Vapor Threat Requires a Tank Redesign
description: In an effort to prevent explosions like the one that caused the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, Boeing officials said today that the design of the company's jetliners needed to be changed to guard against the build-up of flammable fumes.

title: The Neediest Cases; Therapy and Tutoring Help Troubled Child in His Second Crumbling Family
description: Clarence used to run to the window whenever he heard a motorcycle roar past. ''Motor! Motor!'' he would shout, following it with his eyes, ears and imagination as it sped down the block and carried him away from the chaos of his home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONAVENTURA, BROTHER, FMS
description: BONAVENTURA-Brother, FMS. Aged 79, born James Joseph Schreiner, adoptive name John Joseph Cocco, December 8, 1997. Administrator - teacher, Philippines and New York, St. Ann's Academy and Archbishop Molloy High School, Jamaica, New York. No immediate family. Survived by many relatives. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc., Ascan Ave. (Cor. Metropolitan Ave.) Forest Hills, Wed 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of the Cenacle Church Thursday, December 11, 1997, at 9:45 AM. Interment Marist Bros. Cemetery, Esopus, NY.

title: Barnard Students Show Method and Flair
description: ''Barnard Dance,'' presented on Friday night at the Miller Theater at Columbia University, was a savvy showcase for its young performers, all students in the dance department based at Barnard College.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASSOE, JOHN VAN PELT, JR.
description: LASSOE-John Van Pelt, Jr. Died of cancer on December 9, 1997 in his 72nd year. A graduate of Yale with a Master's Degree from the University of Chicago, Mr. Lassoe worked for many years in race relations, community organization and social action programs. His final 31 years were spent as a lay professional at the Episcopal Church National Headquarters and the Episcopal Diocese of New York as legislative representative, program coordinator, writer, editor and corporate secretary. He was the owner of Greenwood Farm, Sheffield, MA., and a summer resident there for many years. He is survived by a nephew, Ward Van Buren Lassoe, a niece, Allison Greenwood Lassoe, his sister-in-law, Caroline R. Lassoe, and a close friend of forty-six years, James L. Curran. He also leaves a loving family of cousins and their children and a host of friends throughout the U.S. and the world. In lieu of flowers the family requests memorial gifts in John's name to the Heights and Hill Community Council, Meals on Heels Program, 160 Montague Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201. Funeral services will be held at 6PM Friday, December 12, at Grace Church, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights.

description: The owner of a Morris Plains printing company was sentenced yesterday to 17 1/2 years in prison for embezzling $4 million from the company's pension fund, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, MILDRED K.
description: EDWARDS-Mildred K. Beloved wife of Jerome. Loving mother of Susan (Steven Levey) EdwardsLevey. Services scheduled on Thursday, December 11, 1997, at Mount Sinai Memorial Park in Los Angeles, California.

description: When the chef Patrick Clark checked into Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center the day after Thanksgiving for a long-awaited heart transplant, he knew dining would be an issue.

title: The Bank Of America
description: South Korea's call today for billions of dollars in direct financial help from the United States and Japan, and the immediate rejection by Washington, was the latest example of the brewing tensions between the United States and its ailing Asian allies over how to quell a financial crisis that refuses to be tamed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATTIE, JOSEPH NATHAN, DR.
description: ATTIE-Joseph Nathan, Dr. Dearest husband Muriel; adored father of Jeanie, Alice, Ilana, Kenny and Heliana; and precious grandfather Justine and Gideon. You were our anchor and our inspiration. It is hard to imagine how we will go on without your joyous presence and loving embrace. We love you. Funeral service: Wednesday, December 10, 11:15 A.M., Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 St.

title: Nextel Purchases 475 Phone Licenses
description: Nextel Communications Inc. has won 475 United States wireless phone licenses for $89 million, dominating the auction of 525 licenses that ended late on Monday.

title: Limit Sought On Donations For Inaugural
description: Responding to criticism that corporations were buying access to her inaugural festivities next month, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that all donations to her inaugural committee would be fully disclosed. She also said that she had asked the committee to place a $50,000 cap on individual and corporate contributions.

title: TV Notes; Shuffling For Position
description: The annual mid-season television game of programming shuffleboard has commenced, with several network maneuvers and counter-maneuvers afoot.

title: With Central Banks Selling, Gold Falls to 18-Year Low
description: The plunge in the price of gold, which fell to an 18-year low yesterday, is a tribute to the power of the world's central banks.

title: Court Considering Whether a Police Chase Violated Rights
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether a high-speed police chase that results in accidental -- although perhaps foreseeable -- injury or death violates the Constitution.

title: The Family Truck
description: Every suburban parking lot is stacked with minivans and sport utility vehicles that do nothing remotely connected with commercial hauling or farming. Yet these vehicles of choice for a multitude of families and commuters are classified as light trucks by Federal regulators, allowing them to escape the Federal pollution and fuel economy standards that apply to cars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, JAYNE D.
description: FRANKLIN-Jayne D. Devoted mother of the late Jill Franklin, woman of valor who faced the tragedies in life with spirit and fortitude, died December 7, 1997. Her generosity, kindness, humanity and joy of life enriched the lives of her family and friends. She will be missed and mourned by all who knew her. Contributions may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 1166 Avenue of the Americas, New York NY 10013. Service Tuesday, December 9, 1997, 1:30 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

description: VAADIA-Yoash. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem and the American Friends of the Hebrew University mourn with great sadness the passing of Professor Yoash Vaadia, former Vice-President and Director-General of the University and a Founder of the US-Israel Binational Agricultural Research and Development Fund. Professor Vaadia served the University with distinction providing wisdom and leadership throughout his career. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife, Professor Deborah Delmer, his children and the entire family. The Hebrew University of of Jerusalem Menachem Magidor, President Alex Grass, Chairman of the Board The American Friends of The Hebrew University Keith L. Sachs, President Lawrence Newman, Ch. of Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive VP

title: The Minimalist; Blue Cheese Enlivens Gratin
description: ''GRATIN'' has come to mean a kind of macaroni-and-cheese affair, a gooey dish in which the main foodstuff -- whether potatoes, noodles or vegetables -- is dominated by a mass of white sauce, cheese and butter. But the word really refers to the crust that forms on the top and sides of a dish that has been browned under a fire.

title: Market Place; Oracle Stock Hit by 29% Loss as Profits Disappoint
description: Shares of the Oracle Corporation took a pounding today, losing 29 percent of their value in record volume in Nasdaq trading and slicing the company's market capitalization by $9.44 billion. The plunge followed a second-quarter earnings report, issued after the markets closed on Monday, that was far short of analysts' estimates.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICK JAGGER, 54, became a father for the sixth time yesterday when his wife, JERRY HALL, gave birth to a son shortly after midnight in London. GABRIEL LUKE BEAUREGARD JAGGER, who weighed 8 pounds 3 ounces, is the couple's fourth child. ''They are both very excited,'' Fran Curtis, Mr. Jagger's spokeswoman, said.

title: Around the World in 23 Aisles
description: FOR Manhattan residents accustomed to supermarkets where the aisles are barely an arm's length wide, Foodmart International in Jersey City may cause some kind of shopper shock. Foodmart, which opened on Monday in the Lefrak Organization's Newport complex, dwarfs even the huge stores outside the city, where shoppers fill their 4-by-4's with a week's worth of groceries at a clip. It not only is the biggest food market in the New York region but also offers an unrivaled variety of international products.

title: Class Notes; Rejection? Pressure? Don't get these tutors started: Actors work as coaches for S.A.T.'s.
description: The master tutor knows all the answers but one: how to realize her dream of becoming a successful actress. She can't work any harder. As it is, Lisa Heilbrunn puts in a 10-day workweek, tutoring students for college admission tests full time and pursuing acting jobs full time.

title: MATTEL AGREES TO SELL SPORTS DIVISION TO WHAM-O
description: Mattel Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its sports division to Wham-O Inc. for an undisclosed price as the company continues to shed noncore businesses. Wham-O, a closely held toy company formed to acquire and reinvigorate classic toy brands, is majority-owned by the investment firm Charterhouse Group International Inc. Mattel said the brands acquired by Wham-O, which is based in San Francisco, include Frisbee, Hacky Sack, Hula Hoop, Street Jam, Trac-Ball and Wham-O. Mattel will still own brands that include Fisher-Price, Hot Wheels and Matchbox cars, Barbie and Cabbage Patch Kids dolls, Uno and Scrabble.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report yesterday about a Newark man who died after his car crashed into a firehouse misstated the official account of the accident, which occurred after a police chase of his speeding car. Officials said the man, Jean Henaud Charles, was no longer being chased by the Irvington police when the crash occurred.

title: Briton's Dream of Glory Is Gone With the Wind
description: Richard Branson and two fellow crew members awoke in Marrakesh yesterday hoping to begin the first non-stop, round-the-world balloon voyage ever made. Instead, they looked out a hotel window and beheld the balloon, freed by a violent gust of wind, ascending crewless into the skies over Morocco.

title: Funk Mantras That Echo On and On
description: The old-school funk extravaganza at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night, the Kiss Cares Classic Soul Concert (sponsored by the radio station KISS-FM), showed once again -- amid coos, imprecations and declarations of love and hope -- that virtuosity isn't the all-conquering quality it's cracked up to be.

title: Television in Review
description: Like most everything this time of year, television is glutted with festivities destined to evoke either pure joy or severe holiday depression. Here are reviews of some new holiday-themed works: three television specials to be shown this week and two best-selling home videos. CARYN JAMES

title: Vietnam War Museum Shifts Focus to Soldiers
description: Officials of the country's only Vietnam War museum began making changes yesterday to an exhibit that has been criticized for emphasizing the antiwar movement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, MARION (MIMI) ZIMMERMAN DAVIS
description: BECKER-Marion (Mimi) Zimmerman Davis. A founding member of the United Choral Society of Nassau County and the Friday Woodmere Music Club of Woodmere, New York, both of which honored her this past year. She died in her 93rd year, December 9, 1997 - at 3030 Park Health Center, Bridgeport, CT. Born October 4, 1904 at home in Manhattan to Rebecca and Maurice Zimmerman, she graduated with high honors from Hunter High School in 1922, attended Columbia College, and directed advertising and public relations for the I. Miller Shoe Company and Van Cannell Elevators. She was married to Charles Davis, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, from 1931 until his death in 1967. Her second husband, Irving Becker, died in 1980. She is survived by a daughter, Rosalind Davis Friedman, and her husband, Arthur, of Trumbull, Connecticut, three grandsons, Roger Friedman and Mark Friedman, both of New York City, Paul Friedman and his wife, Lori, of Alexandria, Virginia, a son, Arthur Davis of Manhattan, a brother, Walter Zimmerman and his wife, Verena, of Winter Park, Florida and many nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by a brother, Leonard Zimmerman. A resident of Woodmere for fifty years, she participated in many community activities and was a member of Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst. She retired in 1991 to Connecticut. In the early 1960s, she helped to create the Woodmere Music Club's Young Artists Competition, which gives prizes for excellence in piano, woodwinds, voice and strings biannually to classical music students between the ages of 14 and 18. As well as receiving cash prizes, winners of the contest perform on WQXR and in a concert held in Hewlett, Long Island. Past winners include Andrew Litton, conductor of the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, Stephen Masi, Andrew Armstrong, youngest winner of the Van Cliburn Competition, and Jeffrey Biegel. Despite many illnesses, she remained sparkling and vivacious, following with interest and pride her family's and friend's daily plans. Beloved by all, she will be irreplaceable. Services will take place on Thursday at 11:00 A.M., from the Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Road, Fairfield, CT., with interment following at Mt. Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, New York. Donations in her name to the Friday Woodmere Music Club Young Artists Competition; The United Choral Society; Hospice-At-Home; BPT; Hadassah, or Congregation B'Nai Torah, Trumbull, would be greatly appreciated.

DeMille, Tyrone Power, Rudolph Valentino, Douglas Fairbanks Sr. and even Mel Blanc, the inimitable voice of Porky Pig, whose headstone proclaims with wry finality, ''That's All Folks.''

title: Remembering One Who Remembered; Eugen Zuckermann, Survivor, Kept The Ghosts of the Holocaust Alive
description: Eugen Zuckermann died on Nov. 24, the cancer finally accomplishing what the Nazis did not. His passing was hardly a surprise. For 10 years, the doctors had opened and closed him, piped and drained him, set his insides on fire with chemotherapy. Still, Mr. Zuckermann, 71, rarely spoke of dying, and it was easy for friends to forget that even survivors do not survive forever.

This T-shirt is truly one-size-fits-all, because while not everyone here was getting rich, millions of Thais were soaring up the economic ladder and whatever rung they've reached is now ''former.''

title: MMMPop Payback Time: Bands Say and Play Thanks
description: For bands with Top 40 pop hits, this is payback season. Across the country, radio stations present concerts like the annual Z100 Jingle Ball, which filled Madison Square Garden with squealing girls on Tuesday night for a 10-act bill. Hit makers appear as an act of fealty to their so-called friends in broadcasting, dutifully thanking the radio stations that along with MTV control their commercial fates. Even Celine Dion, whose last album reportedly sold 25 million copies worldwide, showed up unannounced, lavishing lung power on ''The Christmas Song.'' (She was in town for the Unicef benefit at the Beacon Theater the next night.)

These ''power bulges'' or ''power domes,'' the company's merchandise catalogue declares, are the convertible's ''signature design motif.'' Their shape is echoed in official Mercedes products from jewelry to luggage.

title: The Limits of Nation-Building

The mission's problems, however, offer lessons for future programs and for the multinational police trainers and civilian advisers still in Haiti. They can see progress if they avoid unrealistic promises and cosmetic solutions.

title: Painting by the Polls
description: What kind of art do Americans really want? The question prompts a bilious sigh. But two Russian emigre conceptual artists, Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid, have proposed an answer, for painting at least, that unites careful polling, statistical analysis and a scathing sense of humor. In 1993, aided by polling experts, Mr. Komar and Mr. Melamid queried a sampling of Americans about their artistic preferences. Using the results, they created two paintings -- ''America's Most Wanted'' and ''America's Most Unwanted,'' which were shown in 1994 at the Alternative Museum in SoHo. These are participatory works, rather like the 1996 painting the two did with Renee the elephant, who wielded a brush with her trunk, except that in this case the elephant is public opinion.

title: Dominican Sex Scandal Mars Big League Dreams

title: Currents; MEMORABILIA -- Le Corbusier: In Currency And Colors

In April, his image appeared on the Swiss 10-franc note, left, as part of a series celebrating 20th-century artists and cultural figures. With more than 31 million of the notes in circulation, Le Corbusier is omnipresent. And those who want to delve deep into Le Corbusier's mind can now duplicate in paint the exact colors the architect designed for two wallpaper collections produced by Salubra.

Even getting the two Koreas to meet together for the talks, mediated by China and the United States, was a breakthrough. The previous attempt in 1954, also in Geneva, collapsed. The agenda for the March talks will be hammered out in February at a meeting in Beijing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESTON, WILLIAM SANFORD, JR.
description: PRESTON-William Sanford, Jr. 78. Died on Sunday, December 7, at his home in Burlington, VT. Born in 1919, he attended Burlington schools and graduated from the University of Vermont. After serving in the army during World War II, Mr. Preston joined his father in the family's Burlington jewelry business. He was active nationally in the jewelry industry as a pastpresident of the Retail Jewelers of America, chairman of the Jewelers' Conference Group, and a long-time member and past-President of the American Gem Society. In 1974, he was awarded the American Gem Society's Robert M. Shipley Award for exemplifying the high purposes, objectives, and ideals of the Society. Additionally, he served as president of the Jewelers' Vigilance Committee and as a result of his tireless work with the JVC, was appointed to oversee the revision and updating of the Jewelry Trade Practice Rules of the Federal Trade Commission. As was noted in the Jewelers' Circular-Keystone, a trade journal for the industry, in July 1996: ''This revision could not have happened without the incredible dedication and hard work of Vermont jeweler Bill Preston in his role as JVC's point man in the Guides project. In his career Bill won many industry honors but none approaches this crowning achievement. The industry is and always will be in his debt. And so will the millions of consumers who'll benefit from Bill's efforts when they buy a piece of jewelry.'' Mr. Preston is survived by his wife of fifty-four years, Janet Clark Preston; four children, William ''Sandy'' Preston III; Elizabeth ''Betsy'' Preston, Burlington, VT; Suzanne Preston Blier, Cambridge, MA; Wright C. Preston, Richmond, VT; five grandchildren, a sister, Janice P. Stafford, Richmond, VT., and many nieces, nephews and cousins.

description: An American who is a leading hotel executive in Mexico has been abducted in the beach resort of Acapulco, the first publicly known kidnapping of an American citizen in the crime wave that has terrorized Mexico.

title: Economic Scene; A new look at bank reforms to cut inefficiencies and risk.
description: JAPAN'S financial system, built around giant banks with fingers in every economic pie, is collapsing along with real estate and stock markets -- and in the process dragging Japan to the brink of depression. Why, then, should America abandon the legal barricades that have separated banking from other financial services and inhibited the rise of nationwide branch banking since the New Deal?

title: Justice Dept. Reopens Campaign Plot Case
description: In the last two weeks, the Justice Department has revived its inquiry into whether the Democratic Party illegally funneled millions of dollars into a television advertising campaign for President Clinton's re-election, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Ignoring the Affluent Is Bad Strategy on Heroin; Use Starts in Teens
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Burning The Victim
description: I called Brian Soucie, chief of the Gothenburg, Neb., Police Department, which has six officers, and asked him how the crackdown was going.

title: Treasury Securities Rise in Price
description: Treasury securities, particularly shorter maturities, moved higher for the second consecutive day yesterday on a flight to quality by investors concerned over Asian market turmoil and Federal Reserve activity in the market.

title: Takeover by Travelers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tribute to Leon Edel
description: Friends and colleagues of Leon Edel, a noted biographer and Henry James scholar, will take part in a tribute to the writer today at 6 P.M. at New York University, Jurow Lecture Hall, 100 Washington Square East.

title: Critic's Notebook; Now, the 'Cough' Cantata By the Bored and Restless
description: The first voice is from the rear, a soft, sharp report that is both introduction and request. The answer is quick and comes from above, a broader, deeper, stronger effusion. The duet serves as trigger: now a sudden burst of voices arrives from every side. The entrances are staggered, but the unity of purpose almost regimental. Then silence.

title: Bridge; A Leader Who Grew Into a Top Player
description: One of America's greatest bridge players, forgotten by the younger generation, died on Saturday in Manhattan at the age of 82. Peter Leventritt, a lifelong New Yorker, had a glittering bridge career that took an unusual course: His results as a player boomed after he had been a successful administrator.

title: Swiss Bank Says Big Merger Won't Affect Stamford Office
description: When United Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation announced a merger on Monday, forming the world's second-largest bank, the news shook not only Wall Street, but also Stamford, Conn., where the corporation recently opened a $200 million main office for North American operations.

title: Nets Add Gatling to Their List of Losses
description: The Nets, whose loss in Washington on Tuesday was easily their worst performance of the season, got some sobering news yesterday when they learned that Chris Gatling would miss two to three weeks with a stress fracture in his lower right leg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, IRVING SHERWOOD, M.D.
description: WRIGHT-Irving Sherwood, M.D. 96, died suddenly at home on December 8, 1997. He was the husband of the late Lois Elliman Wright, father of Barbara Wright Gatje, of New York City, and Alison Wright Cameron, of Bronxville; grandfather of Alexandra Lord Gatje, Douglas Wright Cameron, Marianna Gatje Perrier, Laura Howell Cameron, Margot Kim Gatje, and great-grandfather of Lucas Wright Perrier. He was Emeritus Clinical Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Medical College, and Honorary Attending Physician at the New York Hospital. Dr. Wright was born in New York City on October 27, 1901. He was a direct descendant of Wolphert Gerritsen van Couwenhoven whose family settled in Nieuw Amsterdam in 1630. He was nationally and internationally known for his research and leadership in the fields of cardiovascular disease and geriatrics. He served as President of the American Heart Association, the American College of Physicians, the American Geriatric Society, and in 1979, founded the American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Irving Sherwood Wright Center on Aging, Department of Medicine, New York Hospital-Cornell University Medical Center, 1300 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021, or to AFAR, 1414 Avenue of the Americas, 18th Floor, New York, New York 10019. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Currents; OUTDOOR SCENES -- Planting Lights Among the Trees
description: Cross a French topiary garden with a Japanese Zen garden, and the result is the Glowing Topiary Garden, which opens Monday at Liberty Plaza Park in Manhattan. Translucent ''topiary'' cones -- 16 feet tall and glowing orange, yellow or magenta -- will cover two parallel lines of existing light fixtures. In the center will be a cone 25 feet high, which will pulse with colored light, including magenta, green and yellow. Each cone is an abstraction of the traditional lighted holiday tree.

title: Rudolf Bahro Is Dead at 62; Dissident in Both Germanys
description: Rudolf Bahro, who wrote a book that instantly made him one of East Germany's most prominent dissidents and later became an equally iconoclastic figure in West German politics, died on Friday in Berlin after a long battle with cancer. He was 62.

title: Sports of The Times; Jordan Could Afford To Cheer Up Pippen
description: ON the far end of the Chicago bench here Tuesday night, handsomely dressed in sports coat and slacks, Scottie Pippen cheered as the Bulls punished the Knicks, applauded as they returned to the bench and whispered confidentially into Michael Jordan's ear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAISTED, JOHN M. JR.
description: BRAISTED-John M. Jr., Esq. Of Staten Island, on December 9, 1997. Husband of the late Helen P. Braisted. Dear father of John M. III and James P. Braisted. Brother of Wesley W. Braisted. Adored grandfather of nine grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. Funeral from Meislohn-Silvie Funeral Home, 1289 Forest Ave., S.I., Saturday at 9:30 AM. Service Reformed Church of S.I., 10 AM. Interment Moravian Cemetery. Visiting Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Metro Business; Restaurant Planned At Trade Center Site
description: Richtree Inc. of Toronto has signed a deal with the Port Authority to lease 38,000 square feet of space at 4 World Trade Center that will be used as a restaurant, filling the last big block of retail space in the complex.

title: Jailed Mother Left Son to Die, Police Say
description: A Harlem woman with a long record of prostitution arrests was charged in the death of her infant son yesterday after she left him unattended while she served a nine-day jail sentence, the police said.

title: Prospect Park Tries to Reduce Vehicle Traffic
description: Prospect Park was conceived as an idyllic retreat, with people basking in the sun as their carriages rolled around the drive. But around 1900, cars arrived, and today's rush hours have more in common with a speedway than with a promenade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, PHILIP
description: KLEINMAN-Philip. Temple BethEl of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its long time member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: CHRONICLE
description: In June 1964, EDDIE CANTOR wrote a letter to his 12-year-old grandson, BRIAN GARI, who liked making eight-millimeter movies, saying, ''From all appearances, it seems to me you'll be the only one to carry on the tradition of show business in the family.''

title: Head of Amtrak Quits After Railroad Endures a Fall of Troubles
description: The head of Amtrak resigned today near the end of an autumn in which the passenger-railroad network was beset by labor unrest, political battles and deep financial troubles.

title: Sports of The Times; Hoss Returns to Role Of a Sudden Starter
description: WHEN Jeff Hostetler was informed that it was starting to snow at Giants Stadium yesterday, he laughed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARR, ELLIOTT
description: GARR-Elliott, 81. On December 10, of cancer. Beloved husband to Hannah; father to Andrew and Douglas; grandfather to Justin, Jennifer, Ethan, Glenn, Jake, and Gabriella; uncle to Peter and Vita. Funeral services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York at 11 A.M., Friday, December 12.

title: G.E. Plans to Take a $2 Billion Charge
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would be reduced by about $2 billion before taxes.

title: Clinton Praises Bronx Renewal As U.S. Model
description: Sweeping through a sodden New York yesterday, President Clinton visited a South Bronx neighborhood risen up from despair, then roared into Manhattan for a pastrami on rye, a Christmas shopping excursion and two evening fund-raisers that produced as much as $1.55 million.

title: Market Place; Oxford Health Share Price Takes Another Beating
description: Already down, the stock of Oxford Health Plans, the troubled managed care company, was battered again yesterday.

title: In Continuing Auction Frenzy, Bernstein Scores
description: Arlette Snyder grabbed her husband's wrist, preventing him from raising his blue bidder's paddle yet again and trying to top his rival in the bidding for Leonard Bernstein's piano last night. This was the instrument Bernstein called his B-52, the big Bosendorfer with the extra bass keys that could rattle the windows, the shiny grand at which Bernstein composed his opera ''A Quiet Place.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, IRVING
description: BERNSTEIN-Irving. December 10, 1997. Beloved husband of Judith. Loving father of Robert and Joseph. Grandfather of Shira, Roshelle, Jared and Carl. Dear brother of Frances Kaplan and loving uncle of seven nieces and nephews. Services Friday, 12 Noon, Garlick-Hellman Funeral Home, 1091 Yonkers Ave. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Dunham Arrives in Goal, and Devils Show Up With Gifts
description: The secret of success for a backup goaltender is to keep sharp by working hard in practice and be ready when called upon. Mike Dunham of the Devils has played that role well behind Martin Brodeur, but his success this season is hardly reflected by his record because the Devils rarely produce goals while he is in the net.

title: Breezy Abstraction and Intractable Reality
description: At two performances at City Center, the members of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater proved they could portray both moving forms in an abstract design and real people with serious problems.

title: National News Briefs; Unabom Jury Selection Finishes Its First Phase
description: The first phase of jury selection in the case of Theodore J. Kaczynski, who is charged with being the Unabomber, ended today.

title: At Carnegie Hall, Purity Becomes Tyranny
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Get Their D.H. By Signing Chili Davis
description: Chili Davis was the only designated hitter George Steinbrenner ever wanted and the only designated hitter the Yankees ever seriously considered signing for next season. So, even though the Yankees made the official announcement about a three-year contract for a guarantee of $9.8 million yesterday, the deal had essentially been in place since last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASSOE, JOHN V.P.
description: LASSOE-John V.P. The Board and Staff of Forestdale Incorporated mourn the passing of their long-time Director, John V.P. Lassoe. Mr. Lassoe served on the Board for many years, demonstrating his unfailing concern for children and families. His death is a tremendous loss to all of us.

title: TI Group to Sell Landing-Gear Interests
description: TI Group P.L.C. agreed yesterday to sell its landing-gear interests to Snecma, the French aerospace company, for $:207.5 million ($345.8 million). TI, a British maker of aircraft landing gear, auto brake parts and industrial seals, said it expected the transaction to be completed by the end of the first quarter next year and that it would use the proceeds to finance further acquisitions.

title: Council to Vote on Broadening Landlords' Say on Violations
description: In a measure that has set off a furious debate between landlords' groups and tenant advocates, the City Council will vote next week on whether to give privately hired engineers and architects -- instead of city inspectors -- the power to certify that landlords have corrected building violations like frayed wiring or lack of heat.

title: About Section B
description: The Metro Section is printed in two parts today. Part 2, including holiday season fashion news, begins on page B15.

title: Injured Arms Play Part of Scrooge
description: The season's best-dressed elf stood at Santa's right on the fourth floor of Shea Stadium yesterday, wearing slacks and a shirt, and passed presents to schoolchildren. His one-hour shift complete, the elf -- Bobby Valentine, manager of the Mets -- then doled out information to reporters, naughty and nice.

title: Won Continues to Plummet Despite Government Efforts
description: The Government struggled on Wednesday to stem the free fall of South Korea's currency and prevent a chain reaction of bankruptcies as the country's financial markets moved closer to desperation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZIFF, CHARLIE
description: ZIFF-Charlie. 12/11/49 to 7/4/92. You're always in my heart and the holiday lights. Stephen

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, CARL
description: GREENBERG-Carl. Died peacefully at home at the age of 87. Beloved husband of sixty-four years of Sylvia. Devoted father of Herbert and Judy, daughter-in-law Barbara and son-in-law Shep. Loving grandfather of Gabrielle and Danny, Seth and Ilene, Eric and Elissa and Adam and Lauren. Cherished great grandfather of Avital, Bentzi, Meira, Calev and Maital. A true friend to all who knew him. He spent a long lifetime spreading happiness and joy to everyone he met.

title: 'Shareholder' Model Demeans Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: FLUOR CHIEF TO RETIRE EARLY AFTER DISAPPOINTING YEAR
description: The Fluor Corporation said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Leslie G. McCraw, would take early retirement, effective Jan. 1. His retirement follows a year of disappointing earnings for the construction and engineering company, which is based in Irvine, Calif. The company also faces uncertain prospects in Asia as a result of the economic turmoil there. Mr. McCraw, 63, recently underwent surgery for the removal of bladder polyps, which were diagnosed as malignant. A director, Peter J. Fluor, who is chairman and chief executive of Texas Crude Energy Inc., will serve as nonexecutive chairman of Fluor. Fluor said it had hired an executive search firm to seek candidates to replace Mr. McCraw.

title: Espy Prosecutor Says Inquiry Was Impeded
description: The independent counsel appointed to investigate former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy told a Congressional panel today that his inquiry had been impeded by senior Justice Department officials who tried for months to prevent him from examining Mr. Espy's former chief of staff.

title: Mrs. Whitman's $49,500 Dodge
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's scheme to raise unlimited inauguration contributions from individuals and corporations by routing the money through charities was an atrocious idea from the start. It is only slightly mitigated by her announcement, after sharp criticism of the plan, that she would cap the donations at $50,000 and would disclose the source and amount of all inaugural gifts.

title: Growth of Unit Sales Slows at Volkswagen
description: Volkswagen A.G. said yesterday that its unit sales in the first 11 months of 1997 rose 7.8 percent, less than the rate of growth in previous months, amid slowing economic growth in South America and Asia. Unit sales rose to 3.9 million cars, but growth slowed from an 8.5 percent rise in the first 10 months.

title: Hartmann Account Goes to Select
description: Hartmann Inc., the luggage and leather goods division of the Brown-Forman Corporation, said yesterday that it had named Select Communications in New York to handle its account, which had been handled by Hill, Holliday/Altschiller, the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos. Billings for 1998 have not been determined.

title: Defendant at Brawley Defamation Trial Cites Early Assault Reports
description: Testimony in the defamation lawsuit against three former advisers of Tawana Brawley focused today on inconsistencies, idiosyncrasies and enigmas in Ms. Brawley's medical records from the first hours after she was found in a plastic garbage bag, her skin smeared with feces and marked with racial epithets.

title: Currents; INTERIORS -- Modern Warmth: Layering Paint With Silvery Luminescence
description: When Jonas and Ursula Hegewisch, husband-and-wife designers of evening dresses and wedding gowns, were creating their store, Wearkstatt, in SoHo, they wanted a place that was modern yet warm.

title: VIVUS STOCK TUMBLES AFTER 4TH-QUARTER FORECAST
description: The stock of Vivus Inc. tumbled more than 31 percent yesterday after the company said it would not meet its production goals for the fourth quarter. Vivus, which develops products to treat male impotence, said it expected fourth-quarter revenue to be 25 percent lower than third-quarter figures. For the third quarter, which ended on Sept. 30, Vivus had $39.1 million in revenue. Stock of Vivus, which is based in Menlo Park, Calif., fell $6.3125 to close at $13.8125 on the Nasdaq stock market. The company attributed the lower revenue and production shortfall to its efforts to increase capacity at its new plant in New Jersey, to which it is shifting equipment and personnel.

title: At Carnegie Hall, Purity Becomes Tyranny
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column on Wednesday, about works by and about celebrities, misspelled the name of the author of the best seller ''Making Faces.'' He is Kevyn Aucoin, not Kevin Auchoin.

title: Times Names Editor for Arts and Leisure
description: John Rockwell, director of the Lincoln Center Festival since 1994 and a former New York Times music critic and European cultural correspondent, will return to The Times in February as editor of the Sunday Arts and Leisure section.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Marc Salem; He Knows If You've Been Good, for Goodness' Sake
description: ''The word psychic troubles me, because it carries so much emotional weight,'' Marc Salem said. ''People don't go for advice unless they have a problem. Remember the beginning of 'The Wizard of Oz,' when the professor reads the crystal ball while Dorothy has her eyes shut, and he goes through her pocketbook? There are mental pocketbooks we carry with us.''

title: Fans and Coach Turn Against Rangers as Their Dark December Continues
description: When the Rangers take the ice at Madison Square Garden, the speaker system emits a current rock hit about getting knocked down and getting back up again. That message of resiliency is somewhat contradicted by the song's chorus, which translates politely to ''wasting the night away.''

title: INSIDE
description: Question of Obstruction

title: W. R. Grace Develops Asbestos Treatment
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it had developed a chemical foam that can turn the asbestos fibers in fireproofing material into various minerals. The company says the substances that remain after the chemical has been sprayed on the material are fireproof but harmless, unlike asbestos, which has been linked to lethal lung diseases.

title: Encounters of the Sexual Kind
description: If you thought the Mir space station had problems, check out the jalopy of a star ship that is piloted into the heavens by the Five Lesbian Brothers. An hour into their voyage to a far-off ''moon system,'' where they are to be conjugally matched to a team of male astronauts, their ship takes a calamitous detour into a celestial belt of orbiting garbage and collides with the wreck of an old Winnebago.

title: A Match Made in 1800's Paris
description: At each succeeding concert by Da Camera of Houston, music arrives with a new fiance. On Monday night at the Walter Reade Theater, Sarah Rothenberg and her imaginative little band of matchmakers brought us ''Music and the Literary Imagination.'' In this evening of words and music, Baudelaire held hands with contemporaries like Chopin, Wagner and Debussy.

title: Tamara Geva Is Dead at 91; Ballet Dancer and Actress
description: Tamara Geva, a Russian-born dancer and actress who was the first wife of the choreographer George Balanchine, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: UST TO PAY $93.7 MILLION IN STOCK FOR SOMERSET SAVINGS
description: The UST Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Somerset Savings Bank for $93.7 million in stock. Shareholders of Somerset, which is based in Somerville, Mass., and has four branch offices there and one in Burlington, Mass., will receive 0.19 UST share for each Somerset share. The exchange rate values Somerset shares at $5.63 each at Tuesday's closing price for UST. Somerset's stock rose 15.625 cents, to $5.03125, while UST closed unchanged, at $33.1875. UST will record a pretax charge of $7.5 million in connection with the merger. The purchase will add $520 million in assets and $458 million in deposits to UST, a $3.7 billion Boston-based bank with 66 branches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPEN, MADELEINE
description: KOPPEN-Madeleine. Of Mount Vernon, New York, December 9, 1997. Wife of the late Richard Paul Koppen, mother of Carolyn Hansen of Hilton Head, South Carolina. Service and interment private.

title: CBS aims to lure fans to the 1998 Winter Games with a tug at their heartstrings.
description: IF button-pushing were an Olympic sport, CBS would be likely to garner more gold medals than have been won by all the Wheaties eaters since Jack Armstrong, the all-American Boy, first tucked into a bowl.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about turning the Westchester County Medical Center over to a public benefit corporation referred incorrectly to similar plans in Nassau County. Dave Vieser, a spokesman for the County Executive, said the transfer of the County Medical Center would be completed within 12 months -- not ''at least'' a year.

title: At the Met, a Golden Melting Pot
description: As Oscar de la Renta remembers it, the first Metropolitan Museum of Art party for the Costume Institute was a fund-raiser to gather money for Diana Vreeland's salary as adviser. (Five socially prominent women including Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, Jayne Wrightsman and Jane Englehard, had donated the money for Mrs. Vreeland's first year.) That was two decades ago.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CREATIVE TECHNOLOGY LTD., Singapore, a maker of multimedia software, will buy Ensoniq Corp., of Malvern, Pa., a maker of computer audio chips and electronic musical instruments, for $77 million.

title: New York Undercounted Civilian Complaints About Police
description: City officials undercounted by a wide margin the number of civilian complaints of police misconduct filed after the Abner Louima case, obscuring a sharp increase in the number of such complaints this fall, officials acknowledged yesterday.

title: Watts Recital Delayed
description: The pianist Andre Watts has postponed the second of his all-Schubert recitals, which was to be on Saturday at 8 P.M. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, because of illness. The new date is March 3, 1998. Tickets for Saturday's concert will be honored then. Tickets may also be returned for a refund by mail, to John Loder, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y., 10028, attention: Concerts and Lectures. Information: (212) 570-3949.

title: Room on the Tree For Idylls and Egos
description: THIS year's Christmas ornaments are magnets for images in popular culture. The two strains of American tree decorating -- the sacred and the profane -- are duking it out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAX, JULIUS M.
description: SAX-Julius M. The Board of Trustees of Sanz Medical Center/ Laniado Hospital expresses deep sorrow on the passing of Julius Sax, generous benefactor, respected businessman, scion of a most illustrious family. Our heartfelt condolences to his esteemed children Helen and Dr. Daniel Potaznik, grandchildren Yehuda, Arye and Rina Margolit. May you be comforted amongst all mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Henry Spitzer, Secretary Mordecai Schreiber, MD Chairman, Pediatric Dept

title: Olongapo Journal; Traffic in Children Is Brisk (Legacy of the Navy?)
description: Marlyn Capio brushed a strand of hair from her eyes and remembered the day she became a prostitute. She was 11.

title: Yeltsin Enters A Sanitarium, The Victim Of a Virus
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin has a respiratory infection and will stay at a sanitarium for 10 to 12 days, the Kremlin said today.

title: House Weighs Limit on Fees In Lawsuits On Tobacco
description: A House subcommittee today began considering whether Congress should -- or even could -- limit fees paid to the lawyers who initiated the lawsuits against the nation's tobacco companies that resulted in a proposed nationwide settlement.

title: Metro Business; Tower Above Saks Is Sold
description: The Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation has acquired Swiss Bank Tower, the 29-story office building above the Saks Fifth Avenue department store.

title: SOROS FUND ACQUIRES 5.58% INTEREST IN NINE WEST
description: Soros Fund Management L.L.C. and affiliates have acquired a 5.58 percent stake in Nine West Group Inc., the largest United States maker of women's casual and dress shoes. The Soros investment group purchased two million shares at $25.93 to $29.52 a share between Nov. 13 and Tuesday, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Nine West's shares closed at $27.3125, down $1.125. The shares have fallen 34 percent since Sept. 23. Nine West, which is based in Stamford, Conn., is under investigation by the S.E.C. for its policies of importing shoes and other products from Brazil.

title: Casino Island
description: Now that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York has suggested that a casino be built on Governors Island, it seemed only appropriate to check the project's early betting line.

title: Telesoft to Sell Its Internet Unit
description: The Telesoft Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Internet subsidiary for more than $20 million. It said that a phone company based in the New York area had agreed to acquire its Goodnet unit and that the deal would be announced this morning at the Internet World convention in Manhattan.

title: Runaway British Balloon Lands in Algeria
description: With the help of the Moroccan and Algerian armed forces, Richard Branson corraled his runaway balloon yesterday and said he hoped to launch it on Sunday -- this time with a crew -- in an attempt to fly around the world nonstop.

title: Personal Shopper; New Ways to Light the Lights
description: THE festival of Hanukkah may take on a new spin this year with fresh interpretations of dreidels and menorahs.

title: Broadest Measure of Trade Deficit Widens
description: The nation's deficit on the current account, the broadest measure of international trade, widened in the third quarter as Asia's economic crisis weakened United States exports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIF, SYLVIA
description: REIF-Sylvia. Beloved wife of Sidney, cherished mother of Les and Lea, Paul and Jane, adored grandmother and great grandmother of Mitchell and Leslie, David and Iris, Alison, Michele, Alyssa, Ryan, Alec, Jason, and Zoey. And loving sister of Jack Stein. Services December 11, at Schoem's Chapel, West 150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ.

title: At Carnegie Hall, Purity Becomes Tyranny
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULLEN, TERRY
description: CULLEN-Terry. On December 5, in his beloved New York City. Born in Dungannon, County Tyrone, Ireland. Longtime resident of Greenwich Village, independent, and one of the first computer programmers. A lover of literature, conversation and New York City. Survived by his sisters, Mary and Margaret, residents of Britain. A memorial service will be held at Holy Trinity Chapel, 58 Washington Square South, NYC, Monday, December 15, 11 a.m. Donations to Speech and Language Clinic, New York University, C/O Amy J. Danielsen, Director, 719 Broadway, Suite 200, New York, NY 10003.

title: Keith Piper, 76, Football Coach Who Restored the Single Wing
description: Keith Piper, who as the coach at Denison University in Ohio perpetuated the single-wing football formation three decades after it had been discarded by just about everyone else, died Monday aboard a cruise ship off Florida. He was 76.

title: Tibor Fabian, 74, Institute Founder
description: Tibor Fabian, a founder of Mathematica Inc., a leading economics and public policy research institute in Princeton, N.J., died on Saturday at the age of 74. The cause of death was heart failure after a long illness, his son, Jonathan Fabian, said.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Care for Climbing Roses

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULTZ, SAMUEL M.
description: SCHULTZ-Samuel M. Formerly of Miami and West Palm Beach, at the age of 90, passed peacefully in his daughter's home December 8, 1997. He was the beloved husband of Anne, father of Heather Greenfield and Carol Schulz, grandfather of Jennifer, Eden, Noah, and Jonah, and also survived by many loving family members and friends.

title: New Challenges to Prosecution in Bomb Trial
description: Marife Nichols, wife of the Oklahoma City bombing defendant Terry L. Nichols, defended her husband on the witness stand today, but it was two strangers who gave Mr. Nichols his strongest challenges so far to the Government's outline of the bombing plot.

title: Justices Back Government On Civil-Criminal Penalties
description: Disavowing one of its own recent precedents, the Supreme Court ruled today that the Government was generally free to impose both civil fines and criminal punishment for the same conduct without violating the Constitution's prohibition against double jeopardy.

title: Residential Resales
description: Big Deals

title: 3 Are Chosen For Hall of Fame
description: The American Advertising Federation in Washington has selected three executives to be inducted into the Advertising Hall of Fame.

title: GENERAL MOTORS MAKING OFFICIAL RETURN TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a 49 percent equity stake in the Delta Motor Corporation of South Africa for an undisclosed price, signaling the world's largest auto maker's return to South Africa after 11 years. Delta was formed in 1986, when G.M. managers bought out G.M.'s South African manufacturing and marketing operations. G.M. left South Africa to protest the Government's apartheid racial policies, which have been abolished. Delta, which has 4,500 employees, assembles G.M.'s Opel-brand Corsa and Astra cars, Isuzu light pickups and other models and exports finished vehicles.

title: Large Damage Award to Black Whom Store Suspected of Theft
description: Continuing a trend of high-profile lawsuits claiming discrimination by stores, restaurants and other retail establishments, a Federal jury in Kansas City, Kan., today awarded $1.56 million to a black woman who said she had been stopped and searched by department store security guards because she is black.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Representative JON CHRISTENSEN of Nebraska, who is seeking the Republican nomination for governor, proposed to TARA DAWN HOLLAND, Miss America 1997, Monday at the ultimate seat of political power: the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUBB, CORINNE (NEE ALSOP)
description: CHUBB-Corinne (nee Alsop). On December 9, 1997 of Chester, NJ. Widow of Percy Chubb 2nd and mother of Hendon, Percy, Joseph, James and Caldecot Chubb and Corinne C. Zimmermann. Also survived by twelve grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Services at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Main Street, Gladstone, New Jersey, 11 AM, Saturday, December 13. Contributions in lieu of flowers to St. Vincent's Academy, 228 W. Market Street, Newark, NJ 07103.

title: Group Tries to Show Students The Good Side of Race Relations
description: In a wood-paneled Federal courtroom usually reserved for narcotics trials and securities fraud cases, three dozen high school students sat before three judges the other day and explored the thorny issues of race relations.

title: With Pockets of Gridlock, a Sea of Traffic Is Clogged
description: At 3:15 yesterday afternoon, Sammy and Roman Lopez's less-than-whirlwind tour of midtown, now well into its fourth hour, was going great. They had seen Radio City, Times Square and, of course, the Tree. And they had not even got out of the car yet.

title: U.S. Says China Isn't Helping Others Build Nuclear Bombs

title: HFS TO ACQUIRE PROVIDIAN FROM AEGON FOR $219 MILLION
description: HFS Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Providian Auto and Home Insurance Company from the Dutch insurer Aegon N.V. for about $219 million in cash. Providian, based in Frazer, Pa., sells automobile and home insurance to consumers through direct marketing. It generates annual premium revenue of about $150 million. The deal adds Providian to the growing list of service brands owned by HFS, which includes Avis rental cars, Century 21 and Coldwell Banker real-estate brokerages, and Howard Johnson hotels. HFS, based in Parsippany, N.J., had net income of $170 million, or $1.29 a share, on sales of $799 million in 1996.

title: Shoes, Melons and Love
description: ''La Rencontre'' is an unfortunate example of the visual limitations of movies made with small video cameras. Its beautifully composed shots of everyday objects that have acquired a luminous significance in the mind of a filmmaker, because of their association with a woman he loves, look terrible in video. The colors are washed out, and the resolution is fuzzy. As the movie displays its catalogue of personal effects, you feel cheated, then numbed.

title: Switzerland Economy Grows as Exports Soar
description: Switzerland's economy grew at an annualized rate of 1.7 percent in the third quarter as exports soared, highlighting the extent to which the recovery that began this year depends on a falling Swiss franc. The economy grew for the third consecutive quarter as a 14.8 percent rise in exports and a 1.4 percent increase in consumer spending offset a continuing decline in capital investment. In the second quarter, the economy grew 2.2 percent, revised from the initial estimate of 1.9 percent, the Government said.

title: Discovery of Frayed Wire to Gauge Is Cited at Crash Hearing
description: Federal safety investigators said today that they had found a frayed wire from a fuel gauge in the tank that exploded on Trans World Airlines Flight 800, leading them to search for ways in which the wire -- combined with other problems -- could have caused the explosion that took the lives of 230 people in July 1996.

title: The Pop Life; Enya, Healer Of the Soul
description: In the past year, Enya has performed for the Queen of England, the King of Denmark and the Pope. In a previous century, she could have been a court musician. But over the last 11 years she has become better known as a universal musician, the 33 million albums she has sold around the world testifying to the wide spectrum her lush, layered, beautifully melancholy music reaches. Unlike Ireland's other major pop export, U2, Enya doesn't like to brag, talk about her personal life, perform, make public appearances or even grant interviews. Instead, she locks herself up in a countryside studio with the producer Nicky Ryan and his lyricist wife, Roma, and can take months to write a single melody and even longer to record a version of it that she is satisfied with. After a month of requests and delays, Enya consented to an interview to discuss her fifth album, ''Paint the Sky with Stars'' (Reprise), a compilation of her favorite and best-known songs along with two new ones.

title: Corrections Department Is Warned on Detention
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ordered state corrections officials yesterday to stop ignoring their own department's rules against keeping juvenile offenders in county detention centers for more than three days after they have been sentenced. The Department of Corrections was given 60 days to find space in its already overcrowded institutions for the 84 inmates currently being held in detention centers.

At the end of a dirt road on a treeless plain 40 miles south of Salt Lake City, the house is dwarfed by the steep, snow-covered Wasatch Mountains. It appears typically suburban, with its backyard trampoline. There's even a barbecue gazebo out back, where on a bright fall day Mr. Baker was showing his son how to use a circular saw.

description: For Sandy Chilewich, the former co-owner of the leg-wear company Hue, dishes need not be solid and boring. Instead, they can be as soft and changeable as slipcovers. Her Raybowls are made with bright Lycra and nylon mesh over frames that look like the molded wire chairs of Harry Bertoia. The bowls, which come as tripods, disks and ellipses and measure 9 to 16 inches across ($30 to $45), are at the MOMA Design Store, 11 West 53d Street, and at Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (Horatio Street).

title: SEAGATE SAYS IT WILL CLOSE DISK-DRIVE PLANT IN IRELAND
description: Seagate Technology Inc. said yesterday that it would close a disk-drive manufacturing plant in Clonmel, Ireland, eliminating all of the plant's 1,100 full-time jobs. The company attributed the closing, which will also result in the elimination of 300 temporary jobs, to overcapacity and the pricing pressures that have been plaguing the disk-drive industry. The plant will close in early 1998, Seagate said. The company said it would supply severance packages, as well as a small number of relocation opportunities. Seagate, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., said it would continue to make disk drives at its other plants worldwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, IRVING SHERWOOD, M.D.
description: WRIGHT-Irving Sherwood, M.D. 96, died suddenly at home on December 8, 1997. He was the husband of the late Lois Elliman Wright, father of Barbara Wright Gatje, of New York City, and Alison Wright Cameron, of Bronxville; grandfather of Alexandra Lord Gatje, Douglas Wright Cameron, Marianna Gatje Perrier, Laura Howell Cameron, Margot Kim Gatje, and great-grandfather of Lucas Wright Perrier. He was Emeritus Clinical Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Medical College, and Honorary Attending Physician at the New York Hospital. Dr. Wright was born in New York City on October 27, 1901. He was a direct descendant of Wolphert Gerritsen van Couwenhoven whose family settled in Nieuw Amsterdam in 1630. He was nationally and internationally known for his research and leadership in the fields of cardiovascular disease and geriatrics. He served as President of the American Heart Association, the American College of Physicians, the American Geriatric Society, and in 1979, founded the American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Irving Sherwood Wright Center on Aging, Department of Medicine, New York Hospital-Cornell University Medical Center, 1300 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021, or to AFAR, 1414 Avenue of the Americas, 18th Floor, New York, New York 10019. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

And that even if he wreaks havoc, maybe he thinks he has no choice. Like the man almost said, the art wants what it wants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTT, DAVID
description: OTT-David. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend and esteemed colleague David Ott, Vice President, Ambulatory Operations, The Mount Sinai Hospital. David joined Mount Sinai in 1993 following five years as a senior administrator at The Brooklyn Hospital Center and played a pivotal role in reorganizing and revitalizing outpatient programs and services. A respected expert in healthcare administration, his earlier career included positions at the United Hospital Fund, the Hospital Research and Education Trust, the National Academy of Sciences, and the National Institutes of Health. He was a member of numerous health policy advisory committees and served as chairman of the Planning Committee of the Health Research Symposium of the Greater New York Hospital Association for the past eight years, and as a member of the Health Decisions USA National Advisory Council of the National Health Council for the past decade. Beloved as much for his personal warmth as he was admired for his professional expertise, he will be remembered most fondly for his compassion and dedication, and he will be sorely missed. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Carol, to his daughters, Haley and Leslie, and to the entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, MD, President Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice President Wendy Z. Goldstein, Director

And although this flighty comic allegory about love and death in contemporary Los Angeles is wildly overacted, with loose ends flying everywhere, it still conveys an antic poignancy.

title: The G-Rated Russian Revolution
description: My grandmother met Rasputin. He came to her family's house for dinner in Kazan in 1905. He was slovenly, grandiose, and was wearing two silk Russian blouses, one over the other, to proclaim his prosperity.
