title: Suffolk Man Charged in Scheme To Defraud Clothing Suppliers
description: A three-month investigation called Operation Grinch by the Suffolk County District Attorney's office ended with the arrest of a Long Island man who was charged today with stealing tens of thousands of dollars from suppliers of children's clothing and women's apparel and accessories.

title: Son of Cab Driver Is Among 40 To Win Marshall Scholarships
description: One is the son of a New York City cab driver, who dreams of becoming an investigative journalist. Another is a budding composer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUPPLEE, SARAH
description: SUPPLEE-Sarah. In Cambridge, MA., on December 8. Wife of Fred Faudie and daughter of Grace (Linzey) and the late William Carlton Supplee. Sister of Mary Lindsey and aunt of Thomas, William and Robert Gattin of New Mexico. Calling hours at the Watson Funeral Home, 11 Magazine Street, Cambridge, on Sunday, December 14 from 2 to 6 PM. A funeral service will be held during calling hours at 3 PM. Donations in Sarah's name may be made to ALS/MA Chapter, 7 Lincoln Street, Wakefield, MA. 01880.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPLER, CAROL S.
description: KUPLER-Carol S. On December 10, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence. Loving mother of Alice and Ralph. Cherished grandmother of Sandy, Lauren and Kate. Graveside service today, 11:30 AM at Linden Hill Cemetery, Ridgewood, Queens.

title: MELLON BANK TO ACQUIRE FOUNDERS ASSET MANAGEMENT
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Founders Asset Management Inc. in a transaction that was estimated to be worth about $275 million. Founders, based in Denver, would give Mellon $4.8 billion more in stock assets. The move, which follows months of talks, is an effort by the Pittsburgh-based Mellon to bolster its Dreyfus Corporation mutual-fund unit, which has long been regarded as slow in building its equity business. The closely held Founders would remain in Denver and would operate as a subsidiary of Mellon Bank N.A., alongside Dreyfus. Mellon's shares fell $1 each yesterday, to $59.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATTIE, JOSEPH N., MD.
description: ATTIE-Joseph N., MD. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center records with sorrow the death of Dr. Joseph N. Attie. Dr. Attie was a renowned head and neck surgeon. He was a consultant emeritus with the Division of Head and Neck Surgery at Maimonides Medical Center serving as Director many years ago. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. Warren Wexelman, MD. Pres. Jacob Shani, MD. Pres. Elect David Feldman, MD. Secy. Sal DeGliuomini, MD. Treas.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Korea Delays Bond Sale, Rattling World Markets

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In the corporate world, women are great as 'seconds', but when they pick the top leadership, somehow those women become invisible.''

title: CLINTON ADAMANT ON 3D WORLD ROLE IN CLIMATE ACCORD
description: The White House, beginning the arduous task of selling an accord to reduce emissions of climate-altering gases, said today that it would not submit the proposed treaty for Senate ratification until developing countries agree to participate in the global environmental effort.

title: APPLIED CELLULAR ENDS ATTEMPT TO ACQUIRE ABLE TELECOM
description: Applied Cellular Technology Inc. said yesterday that it had ended talks on its unsolicited offer to acquire the Able Telecom Holding Corporation because of shareholders' concern about Applied Cellular's falling stock price. Applied Cellular, a telecommunications software company based in Nixa, Mo., made an offer last week of $100.4 million in stock. Able Telecom, based in West Palm Beach, Fla., provides design, engineering, installation, maintenance and systems integration services. Applied Technology's stock has fallen steadily since reaching a 52-week high of $9.75 on Oct. 10. Its stock fell 15.625 cents a share yesterday, to $4.9375, while Able fell $1.125 a share, to $7.875.

title: Los Angeles Subway Head Suggests Cutbacks
description: In a move that could spell the beginning of the end for Los Angeles's long-troubled subway project, the head of the agency that oversees it proposed today to finish the underground line from downtown through the hills to North Hollywood, and then suspend work indefinitely on all other rail projects.

title: Just About Anything Goes, Including Santa
description: The first set by George Coleman's quartet on Wednesday night at the Jazz Standard had barely started, the four of them approaching liftoff on a vamp, when the pianist Harold Mabern thunderously worked ''Santa Claus Is Coming to Town'' into the tune they were playing. It set a tone: they were going to see how far they could let their guard down, and were willing to leave decorum behind if it meant more relaxation, more individual freedom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, ANITA
description: JAFFE-Anita, 90, Of Camp Hill, PA, formerly of Jersey City, New Jersey died December 9, 1997 in Camp Hill. She was the widow of Dr. Benjamin Jaffe. Surviving are a daughter, Deborah J. Cohen, of Camp Hill; a son, Dr. Julius Jaffe, of Santa Rosa, CA; a sister, Naomi Asnes, Leonia, NJ; five grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Burial will be 2:00 P.M., Dec 12 in Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ. For additional information, contact Reese Funeral Home, Harrisburg, PA, 717-234-7233.

title: 747 Fleet's Age at Issue During Flight 800 Hearing
description: Dozens of Boeing 747's are flying far longer than the manufacturer anticipated, with only limited attention to the aging of their components, according to testimony at a hearing today into the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800. But making changes to the planes or even just inspecting them more intensively could damage wiring and thus increase risk, some experts said, casting doubts on what should be done next.

title: Korea Situation Deteriorates, Raising Specter of a Default
description: South Korea plunged deeper into crisis yesterday when its largest state-owned bank abruptly postponed an effort to raise $2 billion to help pay billions of dollars in debts due in the next few weeks.

title: Pragmatic Poet of Sofa Beds, Father of the Folding Chair
description: Although the name George Hunzinger will probably not be heard on Jeopardy anytime soon, the legacy of this forward-looking 19th-century furniture designer is an inescapable fact of American life. Convertible couches, the folding metal chairs of school-auditorium memory, daybeds, adjustable lawn chairs and the redoubtable Barcalounger -- these all descend from designs that Hunzinger helped invent or refine. So does the freedom to choose fabrics and finishes, priced accordingly, for identical pieces of furniture and other household furnishings at businesses like the Door Store and its progeny.

title: Nichols's Wife Seems to Weaken His Case
description: The defense rested its case today in the bombing trial of Terry L. Nichols, calling as its last witness Mr. Nichols's wife, who, instead of exonerating her husband, seemed to confirm some of the strongest evidence against him.

title: Many Voices in 'Messiah' Performances
description: Here is a sampling of performances of Handel's ''Messiah'' in New York City. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: Metro Business; City to Sell Parcels of Land
description: New York City is about to sell a little bit more of itself.

title: Melting-Pot Menus
description: No longer are chefs bound by region or ethnicity. Whether called fusion, pan-Asian, nuevo Latino or simply Continental, these 12 restaurants know no borders. (Here are summaries, written by Eric Asimov, taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: At the Movies
description: Supernovas With Limits

title: Holiday Fever Grips the Clam Market and Attracts Poachers
description: If the holiday season in New York City heats up the market for toys, menorahs and diamonds from Tiffany's, demand also invariably spikes for some type of contraband.

title: Avon Calls On a Man to Lead It; Female Cosmetics Executives Passed Over for Top Post
description: Avon Products Inc. may be filled with women who sell its products to women all over the world. But it has decided not to be run by one.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: Isles Show Toughness But Lindros Is Too Much
description: The Islanders did not advance in the standing tonight. But their gritty effort against the Philadelphia Flyers tonight showed some progress.

title: Shares of Chip-Equipment Maker Plunge
description: Shares of Kulicke & Soffa Industries plunged 27 percent today after the company said that earnings for the current quarter would not meet expectations because South Korean chip makers were delaying orders.

title: And Eagerly Awaiting That Part About Death
description: As art forms go, comedy is so demanding that practitioners probably should be required to pass a licensing examination before they are loosed on the public.

title: New Airport Entrance Opens on Monday
description: With more than 4,300 cars an hour passing through its main entrance at the busiest parts of the evening, Newark International Airport can be a motorist's nightmare. In an effort to reduce congestion, a new entrance will open on Monday.

title: Bombshell From Low-Profile Prosecutor
description: In the two and a half years that he has been investigating former Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros, David M. Barrett has been among the most private of public figures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUCE, BETTY K.
description: BRUCE-Betty K. Of Boca Raton, FL. December 10. Beloved wife of Martin, loving mother of Barbara, and Laurence. Devoted grandmother to Rebecca, David, Dara and Katharine. Funeral Sunday, December 14 at United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: I.R.A. Figure Meets Blair at No. 10 in 'Moment in History'
description: Gerry Adams, the Irish nationalist leader, came to 10 Downing Street today and emerged from an hourlong meeting with Prime Minister Tony Blair saying, ''Usually moments in Anglo-Irish relationships in history are bad, but today was a significantly good moment.''

title: Judge's Ruling Is a Setback For Microsoft
description: In a significant setback for the world's most powerful software company, a Federal judge ruled last night that the Microsoft Corporation must separate its Internet browser software from its industry-dominating Windows 95 operating system.

title: Devils Give Brodeur Extension
description: Last week, Martin Brodeur recorded his 25th shutout and yesterday the Devils rewarded him with a four-year contract extension.

title: As Albright Starts a Peace Visit, Rebels Kill 231 in Rwanda Raid
description: Just hours before Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright arrived in this ethnically divided nation to promote peace, Hutu guerrillas attacked a Tutsi refugee camp today with grenades, guns and machetes, killing at least 231 people and wounding more than 200 others, United Nations officials and aid workers said.

title: Chamber Music Meets The Boston Symphony
description: Mahler's arrangement of Schubert's ''Death and the Maiden'' Quartet has very little Mahler in it, and in Wednesday's performance by the Boston Symphony under Seiji Ozawa, at Carnegie Hall, it did not have too much Schubert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEAVENY, JEAN D.
description: KEAVENY-Jean D. December 11, 1997, of New York City, New York. Associated with IT & T for over 35 years. Retired as Assistant Secretary. Dear sister of Jan Kyhl of Wisconsin. Services Fox Funeral Home, Ascan Avenue (corner Metropolitan Avenue), Forest Hills, New York, Monday, December 15 at 10:30AM. Visiting Monday 910:30 AM prior to funeral service. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery, Kew Gardens, New York.

title: Talking ads may be coming soon to a gas pump or automated teller machine near you.
description: FIRST there were advertisements in leaflets, newspapers and magazines, then on billboards, radio and television, even in skywriting and eventually on the feet of sports stars. Now full-motion, talking ads are invading neighborhood gas pumps and cash machines.

title: GREIF BROTHERS TO BUY SONOCO'S CONTAINER OPERATIONS
description: The Greif Brothers Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the industrial shipping container operations of the Sonoco Products Company for $225 million. The operations to be acquired had combined annual sales of about $210 million last year. The deal includes Sonoco's interest in Total Packaging Systems L.L.C. It also includes Sonoco's KMI Continental Fibre Drum Inc., Fibro Tambor and Sonoco Plastic Drum Inc. Greif Brothers, based in Delaware, Ohio, makes industrial packaging products and has annual sales of $649 million. Sonoco, based in Hartsville, S.C., makes industrial and consumer packaging goods. Sonoco also said it would buy back up to $150 million of its stock. It had 95.7 million shares outstanding as of Nov. 2.

title: MASCOTECH WILL MAKE A BID FOR THE REST OF TRIMAS
description: The auto parts supplier Mascotech Inc. said yesterday that it would offer to buy the remaining 63 percent of the Trimas Corporation that it does not already own for $900 million. Trimas, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., makes steel and alloy fasteners and specialty products. Mascotech is based in Taylor, Mich. Mascotech already owns about 15.2 million shares, or 37 percent, of Trimas's 41 million shares outstanding. It plans to offer $34.50 a share for the remainder in a direct offer to Trimas shareholders. Shares of Trimas rose 11.6 percent yesterday, gaining $3.5625, to $34.1875, while shares of Mascotech gained $1.625, to $19. The combined company would have sales of $1.6 billion.

title: Apparently Fearing Poor Grade, Student Jumps From a Window
description: A 12-year-old student jumped out of a third-story bathroom window at a Washington Heights public school yesterday afternoon in an apparent suicide attempt, school officials said.

title: Irving Bernstein, 76, Fund-Raiser Who Helped Refugees to Israel
description: Irving Bernstein, who was active in Jewish causes since the flight of Holocaust survivors to what became the State of Israel, died Wednesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 76.

title: Killing of 4 Beggars Shocks Rio And Recalls Earlier Massacre
description: Four beggars sleeping under the awning of a furniture store were shot dead shortly before dawn here on Tuesday, in a killing that has shocked the country and raised memories of an earlier massacre of eight street children sleeping in the doorway of Candelaria Cathedral.

title: Master of an Unruly Musical Universe
description: After two months on the road, Kurt Masur is back in town conducting the affairs of his New York Philharmonic. Last week it was Mendelssohn's ''Elijah,'' this weekend it's Dvorak, next week Shostakovich and Prokofiev. He is in the middle of his seventh season here. The 26-year directorship of the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra is at an end. The guest appearances in Israel, London and Berlin go on. There is opera, too, though Mr. Masur looks wistfully at the Metropolitan Opera across the plaza at Lincoln Center and wishes there was more of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDRIX, ELLIS H.
description: HENDRIX-Ellis H. Services for Ellis H. Hendrix, 81, of Lexington, S.C. will be held at 2:00 p.m. Saturday at St. John's Lutheran Church with burial in Arlington National Cemetery. Caughman - Harman Funeral Homes, Lexington Chapel is in charge. Memorials may be made to the Church. Mr. Hendrix served in the U.S. Navy during World War II and received the Bronze Star for Meritorious Service. He worked on the White House Staff as Personal Physical Therapist for Presidents Kennedy and Johnson. He worked for Dr. Hans Kraus in New York City, retiring in 1990.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKENNA, PADRAIG
description: McKENNA-Padraig. On December 9, 1997. Native of Ballinamore, County Leitrim, Ireland. Beloved son of Patrick J. and Breda (nee McCartin) beloved brother of Pete, Siobhan, Aisling and Aoife. Close friend of Antonio Raimondo. Family will receive friends at John J. Fox and Sons, Inc. 201 Street & Grand Concourse, Bronx, Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian burial, Monday 9:45AM St. Barnabas Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Gay Culture, Redefined
description: The facts: enough gay men are once again having enough unsafe sex that the rates of H.I.V. infection, gonorrhea and syphilis are returning to frightening heights.

title: Drug Czar Tells of New Efforts As Clinton Trumpets Successes
description: Seeking to underscore his Administration's war on drugs, President Clinton took his first ride on a Coast Guard cutter today and had his drug czar join him here to discuss the use of cold-war technology to help stymie narcotics trafficking along the border with Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, JOHN F., JR.
description: WHITE-John F., Jr. The Board of Directors, Administration, Medical and Dental Staff of Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center express their profound sorrow on the death of John F. White, Jr., former President of the Board of Directors and Founding Board Member of the Medical Center. Mr. White served the Medical Center in its formative years as Secretary of the Board of Directors and from 1963 to 1968 held the office of President. In 1990 he was elected Director Emeritus. His vision and wise counsel commanded our highest respect and his continued dedication to the health of our community resulted in the prestigious ''TR'' award from the Nassau/Suffolk Hospital Council in 1968. His leadership and devotion set an example for us all to follow. We extend our deepest sympathy to his entire family. Fredric Rose, Chairman, Board of Directors Gopal A. Bhandarkar, MD, President, Medical and Dental Staff Thomas Ockers, President and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWNEY, JAMES STANLEY
description: DOWNEY-James Stanley, who served almost three decades in the Army Nurse Corps and retired as a Lieutenant Colonel. Died on December 7 at age 69 in San Francisco. Mr. Downey worked as Chief Personnel Officer for the Surgeon General of the Army assigning nurses to posts around the world and guiding their careers. After retiring in 1979, Mr. Downey served as President of the Retired Army Nurse Corps Association. He is survived by his sister Jane Emery of Pittsboro, North Carolina, & his partner Charles Eissfeldt of San Francisco. A Memorial Mass will be held Dec. 18 at 11AM, at St. Dominic's. Contributions may be sent to St. Dominic's Community Service, 2390 Bush Street, San Francisco, California 94115, or the Family School, 548 Fillmore Street, San Francisco 94117.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUBB, CORINNE (NEE ALSOP)
description: CHUBB-Corinne (nee Alsop). On December 9, 1997 of Chester, NJ. Widow of Percy Chubb 2nd and mother of Hendon, Percy, Joseph, James and Caldecot Chubb and Corinne C. Zimmermann. Also survived by twelve grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Services at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Main Street, Gladstone, New Jersey, 11 AM, Saturday, December 13. Contributions in lieu of flowers to St. Vincent's Academy, 228 W. Market Street, Newark, NJ 07103.

title: 'Twas the Lights Before Christmas
description: Across the street from an art museum, near a city park designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, shines the annual creation of Rita Giancola, ballroom dancing instructor, grandmother of 16, lover of Christmas.

title: Home Video
description: Testing The Limits

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Toll-Free Browsing On Broadway
description: A national toll-free telephone service was inaugurated yesterday by the League of American Theaters and Producers to help people find out what's playing on Broadway and connect them with a ticket sales agent.

title: Yeltsin's Surgeon Says His Illness Is a Cold, Not More Heart Trouble
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin's chief heart surgeon said today that the Russian leader was not experiencing a new bout of heart disease but was suffering from a respiratory infection.

title: Kwan Withdraws From Munich Event
description: Michelle Kwan, not in top condition and still feeling pain from a stress fracture in her foot, has withdrawn from an international figure skating competition next week in Munich, Germany.

title: Error Prompts Steps by Police Review Board
description: A day after announcing that they had undercounted complaints of police misconduct this fall, officials at the Civilian Complaint Review Board installed a new fax machine yesterday so that the problem would not happen again and said that they would review their records to insure that no other complaints had been mishandled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUKOVIC, EVELYN
description: DUKOVIC-Evelyn. December 8. retired Vice Pres. of Morality in Media. Sister of Edw. J. Dukovic, Jr. and Elma Jane Greco of Pittsburgh. Memorial mass Saturday 11:00 AM, Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Ave. Memorial donations may be made to Morality in Media, 475 Riverside Drive, New York, New York 10115.

title: Help! He's Back! Run! Shriek! Tempt Fate!
description: It looks as if the ''Scream'' franchise has staying power. In fact, the sneaky ''Scream 2'' has so much tongue-in-cheek trickery that it virtually escapes the horror genre, the one it so happily lampoons. This ''Scream,'' once again directed by Wes Craven and written by Kevin Williamson, almost works as straight satire. It's so sharp -- pardon the expression -- that no pretty young things absolutely had to die.

title: Man on Routine Visit to U.S. Held in 1969 Hijacking of Jet
description: For the last seven years, Felix Rolando Peterson-Coplin led a rather unremarkable life in Canada, not far from the United States border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, MARK F.
description: HUGHES-Mark F. Of Elberon, NJ also of New York City, N.Y., on December 10, 1997. Husband of the late Annette (nee Morgan) Hughes. Father of Mark F. Hughes, Jr., John J. Hughes, Annette ''Toni'' Hillary and Mary Jane Moeller. Brother of Paul Hughes and Jack F. Hughes. Grandfather of eight. Great-grandfather of three. Visitation Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, NJ. Funeral Mass Monday 10:30 AM at St. John the Baptist R.C. Church, 272 Willow Avenue, Long Branch, New Jersey. Interment to follow in Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, NJ.

title: FILM REVIEW ; Of Course He's Still Beating the Bad Guys
description: It was a shrewd studio executive who decided that the ''Home Alone'' series didn't require the towheaded, hooded-eyed screen presence of Macaulay Culkin to stay alive and kicking. As ''Home Alone 3'' vigorously demonstrates, all the franchise really needs to keep going is a charismatic child (Alex D. Linz has replaced Mr. Culkin) with no great acting skills but loads of pseudo-innocent chubby-cheeked adorability.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth last weekend for last Friday and Saturday nights' performances.

title: Metro Business; Trade Center Lands Empire Blue Cross
description: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has signed an agreement with the Port Authority to lease 461,000 square feet on 10 floors on the north tower at the World Trade Center, the agency said yesterday. It said the signing was the largest lease transaction at the Trade Center in 10 years.

title: The Vineyard, Dressed in Its Holiday Best
description: As the temperature falls and the wintry ocean seethes and churns along its shoreline, Martha's Vineyard seems to turn inward. In the small towns scattered across the island, the coals on the barbecue have given way to logs in the fireplace, and everywhere there are signs that Christmas is coming.

title: TV Weekend; A Young Girl's Long Road to a Family
description: Sometime soon, Jena Malone will be featured in a comedy, or in a drama that at least assigns her to a happy home. For the time being, though, she must continue to be known as a young actress who is astonishing in her portrayals of children buffeted by abuse and the early loss of parents.

title: U.S. Ends Rights Case On Police Killing of Youth
description: Federal prosecutors announced yesterday that they would not bring civil rights charges against a police officer who fatally shot a 16-year-old in the back in April in Washington Heights because the officer, the prosecutors said, did not intend to ''inflict excessive and unjustified force.''

title: For 30 Minutes, Elderly Callers Get Best-of-All Long-Distance Rate
description: When Moysey and Fenya Saponar, both 68 and recent emigrants from Moldova, arrived at Brooklyn Borough Hall yesterday morning, they came prepared with lists of eight friends and relatives in their homeland and Israel. ''We've been waiting for this for the last year,'' Mrs. Saponar said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARR, ELLIOTT
description: GARR-Elliott, 81. On December 10, of cancer. Beloved husband to Hannah; father to Andrew and Douglas; father-in-law to Audrey and Meg; grandfather to Justin, Jennifer, Ethan, Glenn, Jake, and Gabriella; uncle to Peter and Vita. Funeral services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York at 11 A.M., Friday, December 12.

title: Canadian Court Ruling Broadens Indian Land Claims
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the claims of native peoples to vast areas of Canadian territory -- and the natural resources they contain -- are far broader than current law recognizes even without written treaties, complicating concessions for mines, timber and other resources throughout the country.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International; Sports Cars Europe Keeps for Itself
description: NOT long after it was invented, the automobile became a prime instrument of human expression. For almost a century, motorists have selected personal transportation in the belief that what they drove held meaning beyond its function.

title: Worry on Asia Sends Stocks Down Again
description: The stock market tumbled for the fourth straight session yesterday as worries spread that the economic slowdown in Asia would depress corporate earnings. But some stock analysts argued that other, potentially bigger problems were beginning to arise in the United States.

title: Whether It Creates Jobs or Joblessness, the Agreement Will Affect Everyone
description: To Scott Sklar, the executive director of the Solar Energy Industries Association, nothing could be better for business than an agreement on controlling gases that contribute to global warming.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: METROPOLITAN HEALTH NETWORKS INC., Boca Raton, Fla., has an agreement to acquire Trident Medical Concepts Inc., West Palm Beach, Fla., in a stock deal valued at $38 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERIDAN, TERESA
description: SHERIDAN-Teresa. 89. On December 11th, 1989. Mother of Elizabeth Gallagher, Cecelia Kane, Ellen, Marita and Loretta Sheridan. Information Horn & Thomes, Pawling, New York.

title: The Mind Of a Genius At Work
description: Anyone who has commissioned a house knows that the client's biggest thrill is the first glimpse at his architect's presentation drawings, the magical culmination of years of dreams put to paper, beautifully rendered by a master's hand.

title: On Madison Avenue, a Cat Waits to Be Found
description: When loose bricks from a nearby office tower pelted the roof of his Madison Avenue apartment building on Sunday afternoon, Tim Curran didn't have time to collect many of his belongings during the evacuation. He left behind his wallet. His credit cards. His appointment book. His jacket.

title: Legality Wouldn't Protect Cloned Children; If Organ Donors Balk
description: To the Editor:

title: On My Mind; From Scorsese to Tibet
description: Tibet has no army, no weapons. Tibet has no money. In all the world no nation speaks a word for its freedom from captivity. Tibet cannot speak for itself; its representatives are not even allowed to enter the United Nations.

title: Asian Import Prices Plunge By Extremely Strong 1.2%
description: As holiday shopping reaches full swing, the Asian financial crisis is helping drive down the price of imports to this country, with goods from South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore dropping by an exceptionally strong 1.2 percent in November, the Government reported today.

title: ABC Analyst To Join CNN
description: Jeff Greenfield, who has been ABC News's best-known political analyst for 14 years, is leaving ABC next month to join the Cable News Network, CNN's new president, Richard Kaplan, announced yesterday.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 11.

title: Manning and Senior Sensations
description: If it's Sunday -- very early Sunday -- it must be Atlanta, where Peyton Manning and friends, newly crowned Southeastern Conference football champions, have decided to do a victory lap. Not around the Georgia Dome, where the Tennessee Volunteers had defeated Auburn in the next-to-last game of Manning's college career. Their lap is around Atlanta, searching for orange noise and one more chance to sing ''Rocky Top,'' Tennessee's anthem, with voices growing more and more hoarse.

title: Abroad at Home; 'Now We Are Ashamed'
description: Attila Hegyi, a 26-year-old Hungarian, arrived at Kennedy Airport in New York on the afternoon of Sept. 6. He had a visitor's visa, issued at the U.S. Embassy in Budapest, but he was not admitted. Instead he found himself badgered into signing documents he did not understand, then sent back to Hungary and barred from the United States for five years -- without explanation.

title: Clarson in Line To Head WTA
description: If Ric Clarson accepts the job, women's professional tennis has apparently found itself a new chief executive officer. Clarson is a public relations and marketing veteran from the front office of the men's professional golf tour.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times, or by contributors, of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: It's a Struggle, but Knicks Are Just Tough Enough
description: Patrick Ewing tilted back his head to gulp down the last drop of orange juice. He had not found a cure for his cold, but he had discovered some soothing nourishment. The same went for the Knicks. They did not find an elixir for their recent funk last night, but they left behind the suffocating criticism that had dogged them through their 2-5 slump.

title: About Section B
description: The Metro Section is printed in two parts today. Part 2 begins on page B17.

title: Accounts
description: -- 800-4-Referral, Ramsey, N.J., to Lois/EJL, New York, part of Lois/ U.S.A., to introduce a telephone referral service linking consumers to service professionals like doctors and electricians. Billings were estimated at $3 million for an initial campaign in metropolitan New York.

title: Sports of The Times; Old Guys Hold Back Young Guys
description: THESE are not cheery days in Madison Square Garden. The matchup in the Garden last night looked suspiciously like the future against the past, even though the Knicks managed to push back the tide, 107-103.

title: Peugeot Unit to Buy A Car-Seat Maker
description: Ecia S.A., a unit of the French company PSA Peugeot Citroen, said yesterday that it would buy all of Bertrand Faure S.A. in a bid that values Faure, a car-seat maker, at 8.4 billion francs ($1.4 billion). Ecia's offer of 430 francs a share for the 83.3 percent of Faure it does not own is an 11.6 percent premium over Faure's closing price of 385.4 francs on Tuesday. Shares of both companies were suspended on Wednesday.

title: Brawley Case Judge in Unfamiliar Spotlight; Questions Raised About His Accommodating Style in Defamation Trial
description: Talk to any lawyer who has appeared before Justice S. Barrett Hickman of State Supreme Court and the word patience, or some synonym for it, is mentioned quickly and repeatedly. These lawyers agree: if patience is indeed a virtue, Justice Hickman is a remarkably virtuous man.

title: Repairs to Lenox Ave. Tunnel To Affect Many Subway Lines
description: The rebuilding of a quarter-mile section of subway tunnel in Harlem will mean longer rides and detours for hundreds of thousands of riders from the Bronx to Brooklyn during most of next year, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Watching the Construction
description: Rain and snow fall during the early-morning walk to Times Square, where cement trucks are lined up, idling, at the high-rise construction site on the corner of 43d and Broadway. One at a time they pull into position and empty their slurry into the cement pump, which probes the gaps in a skeletal upper story. The drivers carefully hose down their vehicles, from whose flanks hang five-gallon plastic buckets. The water hisses against the tires and undercarriage and echoes hollowly off the cement trough -- all of it nearly inaudible because this corner, where the Conde Nast building is rising, is the nucleus of noise in Manhattan.

description: Markus Lupertz was one of the group of German artists aggressively promoted under the rubric of Neo-Expressionism in the early 1980's. But his endeavors have never had the same acclaim in this country as those of, say, his compatriots Anselm Kiefer, A. R. Penck and Georg Baselitz.

description: Vova Malofienko, now 13, was living in Ukraine when the Chernobyl nuclear disaster struck in 1990. He and seven other Ukrainian children were brought here to be treated for leukemia. All but Vova, who was given the best chance of surviving, eventually returned to Ukraine, where they died.

title: Asthma in City Is New Target For First Lady
description: Casting a light on what is believed to be one of the major health problems confronting poor urban neighborhoods, Hillary Rodham Clinton, the First Lady, went to the South Bronx yesterday to inaugurate a project to fight asthma in the inner city.

description: Detectives investigating the mysterious disappearance of a Manhattan couple last month want to exhume the body of an unidentified man buried in potter's field in 1991 to determine whether his death might somehow be linked to the case, the police said.

description: I wonder if anyone has noticed that many of the museums in Manhattan serve not just acceptable but truly delicious food, a far cry from my recollection of years ago when cafeteria-style lunches were served to hordes of schoolchildren or to avid museumgoers who were about to faint.

description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto spent most of today trying to persuade skeptics of the virtues of a plan to raise 10 trillion yen in life support for the Japanese banking system.

title: Winning Is Hook That Landed Davis
description: Chili Davis knows that his career has grown better with age. Yesterday, Davis, the latest player to take on the role as designated hitter for the Yankees, expressed hope that his prospects for winning one more championship before the end of his career have also improved.

title: People
description: -- Don Hintze was named to the new position of advertising director at Sport magazine, New York, a publication of Petersen Publishing Co. He had been national advertising sales manager at Major League Baseball, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, IRVING
description: BERNSTEIN-Irving. The Board, Officers, and Staff at United Israel Appeal, Inc., mourn the passing of our chaver Irving Bernstein. He tirelessly dedicated his life to the reemergence of the State of Israel onto the stage of history. Irving was one of the early leaders who truly brought the Jews of Israel an America together. He worked for and eventually stood at the professional helm of our partner organization, the United Jewish Appeal. He helped to raise massive resources to bring Jews home to Israel through the work of the Jewish Agency for Israel. His invaluable ''blue letters'' helped educate a generation of American Jewish leadership about these noble goals. As the volunteer Chairman of the Communications Committee at United Israel Appeal and the Jewish Agency for Israel he created new ways to help the American Jewish communities to appreciate and support the heroic work of the continuing rescue and aliyah of our people. The Jerusalem Talmud teaches: ''Monuments need not be built for the righteous; their deeds are their memorials.'' Our sincere condolences to his wife Judith. May she and the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jersusalem. Shoshana S. Cardin, Chairman United Israel Appeal, Inc. Rabbi Daniel R. Allen, Executive Vice Chairman, United Israel Appeal, Inc.

title: Philharmonic's Musicians Negotiate a 6-Year Contract
description: The management of the New York Philharmonic and representatives of its musicians have quietly negotiated an unprecedented six-year labor contract that experts say may point the way to new harmony in a strike-prone industry.

title: Hal Lipset, Private Detective With a Difference, Dies at 78
description: Hal Lipset, a storied San Francisco sleuth who helped elevate, or rather reduce, electronic surveillance to a miniature art, died on Monday at a San Francisco hospital. He was 78 and was best known as the man who put a bug in a martini olive.

title: Residential Real Estate ; Co-op Refinancing Easier in New Market
description: A four-year effort to refinance the mortgage of the 65-unit prewar cooperative building in the Midwood section of Brooklyn had been unsuccessful. Like many other buildings that were converted to co-ops at the end of the mid-1980's real estate boom, the Brooklyn co-op had more renters than owners.

description: It doesn't take much prodding to get the American pianist Alan Feinberg to talk about what's wrong with the field of classical music. His only request? ''Promise me that the article won't be just my rantings,'' he said.

description: BARR-Samuel. On December 10, 1997, at Schenectady, NY. Son of the late Philip and Katherine Barr. He was pre-deceased by four brothers, Irving, Isadore, Louis and Joseph Barr, and a sister Sarah Barr. Services 12:15 PM Sunday at the Beth Israel Cemetery, Rotterdam, NY. description: A trust fund created with a settlement paid by the Exxon Corporation will be used to help clean up a salt marsh that was contaminated when an Exxon oil pipeline burst in 1990.

title: Spicy Salsa to Make the Temperature Soar
description: Over the last three decades, the salsa bandleader Larry Harlow has put together hard, raw and unpolished groups that press sound to the limit. Mr. Harlow is now leading a group of Fania-era musicians, calling the band the Latin Legends, and on Monday night at S.O.B.'s, he and the group went through a series of standards, waiting for the moment when the music lifted off.

title: Dickson Concepts Says Earnings Fell 76%
description: Dickson Concepts (International) Ltd., a Hong Kong-based retailer with a knack for turning around department stores, said its earnings for the six months that ended on Sept. 30 fell 76 percent and full-year earnings could suffer more.

description: IN the Wildest Westernmost part of the stock market, the sheriff has just vowed to clean up Dodge City. And investors should probably applaud, even if they suspect that the criminal element may simply mosey on down to El Paso.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEVA, TAMARA
description: GEVA-Tamara. How sorry I am to lose a friend, a person of joy, elegance and glamour. Her loyalty to George Balanchine never waned, and after his death she embraced his memory and gave inspiration and support. Barbara Horgan The George Balanchine Trust

title: Malaysia Levels Charge Against Credit Lyonnais
description: Malaysia charged Credit Lyonnais's Singapore unit with short selling in the country's first legal action against a foreign securities house since the slide of the region's stock markets began in July. The action culminates a campaign by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, above, against foreign investors, whom he has charged with destroying the region's economies by dumping shares. Short selling -- selling shares one does not own in the hope of later buying them back for less -- is illegal in Malaysia.

title: Debtor's Dogs, Landlord's Headache
description: Until May of last year, block 7206, lot 259, was just a garbage-strewn half-acre in Staten Island's Industrial Loop. But then it became home to a woman, her three trailers and her dogs -- more than 50 at last count, and multiplying.

description: There are no strangers among the final four teams that will clash in today's semifinals of the men's collegiate national tournament. The elite quartet has won the championship 20 of the last 38 tournaments. This is the first time in the history of the tournament that the semifinalists have been former champions.

description: Cuauhtemoc Cardenas had exactly one weekend to savor the afterglow of his rapturous inauguration last Friday as Mexico City's first opposition mayor in seven decades. Then the honeymoon ended.

title: WINSTAR SAYS IT IS BUYING GOODNET FROM TELESOFT
description: Winstar Communications Inc. said yesterday that it was the buyer of Goodnet, an Internet access provider, from the Telesoft Corporation for $22.5 million. Winstar will pay $3.5 million in cash and the rest in common stock. Winstar, a wireless telecommunications provider, said it expected Goodnet's 1998 revenues to be double its current annual revenues of about $8 million. Winstar, based in New York, had 1996 revenues of $68 million. Telesoft, a Phoenix-based telecommunications systems services company, said on Wednesday that it was selling Goodnet but did not disclose the buyer.

title: An Instructor At St. John's Is Attacked
description: A professor at St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, was viciously attacked in a campus parking lot sometime after dark on Wednesday, the police said, and by the time she arrived at a nearby hospital early yesterday morning she recalled nothing about the assault.

title: Korean Quicksand
description: The International Monetary Fund's $57 billion bailout package for South Korea looked workable last week, but it has already been overtaken by economic and political developments. First came news that Korea's foreign reserves were smaller than previously admitted, and its foreign debt much larger. Next the Korean Government dawdled at instituting the tough conditions imposed by the fund. Then a leading candidate in next week's presidential election threatened to renegotiate the accord. The bad news scared foreign lenders, who withdrew their money and sent the Korean currency and stock markets plummeting again.

title: In a Major Policy Change, Britain Moves to Ease Official Secrecy
description: Saying that it wanted to make itself more accountable to the people, the British Government introduced a proposal today that would, for the first time, require government agencies to release official documents and information to the public.

title: Portrait of the Machine Age, With Guessing Game
description: The exhibition ''Images From the Machine Age: Selections From the Daniel Cowin Collection,'' at the International Center of Photography, opens with a photograph of one large-toothed gear attempting to mesh, improbably, with a small-toothed gear. The picture, ''Out of Mesh,'' taken by Mannie Lovitch, an amateur photographer from the Bronx, serves as a metaphor for the whole show: here is a machine whose parts do not fit together but that is nonetheless intriguing in its misfitting parts.

description: There is a reason the financial district has more food carts per square block than any other area in Manhattan: it is very short on restaurants. Fortunately, a new restaurant called 14 Wall Street has just eased the pressure a bit.

title: Father, on Sledding Trip, Is Killed by Vehicle
description: When the first significant snow of the season fell on Wednesday, Felipe Restrepo went to take his 3-year-old sledding. They never made it. Mr. Restrepo, 40, was killed after having pushed his son Louis out of the path of a careering vehicle.

title: Inflows to Taiwan Ahead of Outflows
description: The net inflow of investment in stocks in Taiwan by foreigners amounted to $364.48 million in the first 10 days of December, according to statistics released yesterday by Taiwan's Central Bank of China. If the trend for December continues, it would be the first month since April that foreign inflows exceeded outflows. The statistics also showed that foreigners removed a net $416.18 million of funds in November. For 1997 to date, foreigners have remitted out a net $856.59 million of stock investment funds. (Bridge News)

title: Nets, Lukewarm to Start, Go Icy Cold
description: The Nets promised to be a better shooting team this season. But 21 games in, they are shooting almost as poorly as they did all of last season, when they set the franchise record for field-goal futility.

description: Muslim leaders from around the world wrapped up a three-day meeting here today by criticizing Israel for what they called ''state terrorism'' and demanding that Israel stop building settlements on Arab land.

description: Tinseltown is trying to become museum town.

title: AIDS a Major Threat / Some Progress in Family Planning : In Tanzania, Many People and Many Woes
description: NG'IRESI, Tanzania  Sareyo Lothi struck a match and held it close to the single, tiny lamp that hung over his dirt-floored living room. As the room brightened, so did his face. A wide smile of caramel-colored teeth said it all: See, it works!

title: Chaos and Ruthlessness in Liberty's Wake
description: For anyone harboring the illusion that the nations that once formed the Soviet Union ever shared a monolithic political and cultural outlook, the films being shown at Film Fest, the Museum of Modern Art's second annual celebration of recent films from former Soviet states should dash that fantasy once and for all. In all four films screened for this critic of the 15-film series, which begins today and runs through Dec. 22, the mood is one of fragmentation, confusion and, in two of the four, lawlessness and near-chaos.

title: Blood Center Warns Of Possible Shortage
description: The New York Blood Center, the largest independent blood supplier in the country, issued an appeal yesterday for blood donations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORRINGTON, JOHN W. JR.
description: CORRINGTON - John W. Jr. Passed away peacefully on December 8, 1997 after a brief illness. Devoted father and father-in-law to Lady Cynthia Jaffray and Sir William Jaffray of London and Prior's-Dean, Hampshire, England. Beloved grandfather of Nicholas, Alexandra, William and Jack Jaffray. Brother of Richard Corrington of Lexington, VA. Burial at Prior's-Dean in Hampshire will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Vallone Tries to Score Against Pataki With Subway Discount
description: The Speaker of the New York City Council, Peter F. Vallone, renewed his push yesterday for a plan that would give subway and bus riders 12 trips for the price of 10, trying to regain political momentum on the potent issue of discount fares from the man he hopes to run against next year, Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: FMC SAYS ITS EARNINGS WILL FALL SHORT OF ESTIMATES
description: The FMC Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit would fall below analysts' estimates because of weak sales in Southeast Asia and Brazil, a strike at a major customer and start-up problems at a plant. FMC said it expected profits of 45 cents to 55 cents a share, below the $1.01 average estimate of seven analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International. The company earned $1.17 a share a year ago. FMC, a Chicago-based maker of insecticides, herbicides and food additives, will take a $180 million gain for the sale of its United Defense unit. In addition, it will take charges of $181 million for restructuring and $27 million for environmental costs at discontinued operations. FMC shares fell $3.375 yesterday, or 5 percent, to $65.5625.

title: For a Rising Star of Politics, a Precipitous Plunge
description: It would be hard to overstate just how high Henry Gabriel Cisneros's political star seemed to be rising at one point in his life. Elected mayor of San Antonio at the age of 33, he was a dynamic, telegenic, articulate spokesman for the nation's cities -- and for its fast-growing Hispanic population.

title: Bond Prices Rally Further On Asia Woes
description: Treasury securities rallied for a third day yesterday as investors concerned about the crisis in Asia sought quality and as a report of slower-than-expected growth in retail sales last month eased inflation fears.

title: Taking Cue From Trial Of Au Pair
description: The lawyer for a former New York City police officer who is to be sentenced on Monday for killing a man in a dispute over a delicatessen parking space has asked the trial judge to set aside the officer's second-degree murder conviction.

title: THEATER REVIEW ; Stowe's 'Cabin,' Reshaped as a Multistory Literary Home
description: The smoke has never cleared from around ''Uncle Tom's Cabin.'' Harriet Beecher Stowe's monumental best seller about the curse of American slavery was greeted with a deafeningly mixed chorus of hosannas and jeers when it was published in 1852. And while the nature of its defenders and detractors has since varied wildly, its reputation is still more deeply divided than that of any other American literary classic.

title: Now Marlins Don't Want Isringhausen
description: After examining the results of Jason Isringhausen's recent medical exam, the Florida Marlins told the Mets yesterday that they have no interest in trading for the pitcher in a deal that would bring Kevin Brown to the Mets. Isringhausen has an elbow condition that may eventually require surgery.

title: CHRONICLE
description: VICTOR BORGE had a dozen oysters on Wednesday evening in the Oyster Bar of Grand Central Terminal, not in itself a remarkable occasion. But the symbolism behind the plate was rich, indeed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMPOL, BERNICE
description: JAMPOL-Bernice. Anthony L. Watson, Chairman and CEO of HIP Health Plans, HIP'S Boards of Directors and its Medical Groups are deeply saddened by the passing of Bernice Jampol. Devoted wife of Dr. Jesse H. Jampol, former Medical Director for HIP. Mrs. Jampol was a loving wife, mother and grandmother. We extend our deepest sympathy to Dr. Jampol and his entire family.

title: Glitch Forces Rescheduling of Examination
description: A software problem prevented about 1,400 students from taking the Graduate Management Admissions Test yesterday, according to a vice president of the nonprofit Educational Testing Service, which administers the G.M.A.T. and nearly 100 other standardized tests.

title: Versace's Styles: Telling Tales Of Hedonists
description: Why must some people believe in alien visits when there's such a thing as fashion? Surely nothing that ever landed in Roswell, N.M., could be half as startling as the show of Gianni Versace clothes that opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute. To judge from these racy garments, the earth has lately been visited by an advanced race of sex kittens from the distant galaxy of Desire.

Cisneros, President Clinton's first Housing Secretary, was indicted today by a grand jury here that said he had lied in his confirmation proceedings to Federal agents and Congress about payments he had made to discourage a mistress from jeopardizing his nomination nearly five years ago.

title: Judge Warns KPMG Partners of Risk
description: A California Superior Court judge has ordered that notices be sent to all partners with KPMG Peat Marwick in California, saying that their personal assets are at risk in two lawsuits that seek more than $100 million against the firm.

Chase, six grandchildren, two great grandchildren and sister-inlaw Maureen Orcutt. Contributions in her memory may be made to the East End Hospice, Westhampton Beach, New York, or to a charity of your choice.

title: Acquisition in 1999 Suggested by Times
description: Flush with cash after selling off several assets this year, The New York Times Company said yesterday that it was ''counting on an acquisition to provide considerable future growth'' sometime in 1999.

description: All eyes are now on the United States, as negotiators from more than 100 countries try to hammer out a global trade agreement here to remove national barriers in banking, insurance and securities by midnight Friday.

title: Talk of Tougher Medicine for Korea's Ills
description: A week after the world came to South Korea's rescue with $57 billion in emergency aid, the country's economic troubles have worsened so rapidly that officials here fear that far more drastic steps may be needed to stop financial hemorrhaging that is already threatening world markets.

description: The Golden State Warriors are prepared to use a history of Latrell Sprewell's behavior at a grievance hearing to review the player's punishment for attacking Coach P. J. Carlesimo.

title: Mildred Mosler Weisenfeld, 76; Supported Groups for the Blind
description: Mildred Mosler Weisenfeld, who helped build an organization for researching blindness, died last Saturday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 76.

title: At Hearing, a Calm Account Of a Slaying, on Videotape
description: Calm and self-possessed, as if he were interviewing for a job, John J. Royster held his head high and his chin out as he described how he walked up behind Evelyn Alvarez, 65, on a June morning 18 months ago while she fumbled with the keys to her Park Avenue dry-cleaning shop.

title: Holiday Harmony to Gild These Not-So-Silent Nights
description: This is a sampling of the musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted (churches accept donations). This selection, compiled by Anthony Tommasini, represents what caught this critic's eye and excited his expectations. Unless otherwise noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.

title: Diamond District Tries to Dispel Its Private Bazaar Image
description: It is just a block of 47th Street, between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, but its importance in the international diamond trade has been equated for 50 years to that of Wall Street in stocks and bonds and Broadway in the musical theater. So is the luster of 47th Street fading?

title: Transformation in the Bronx
description: The new South Bronx was on display this week when President Clinton visited spanking-clean neighborhoods that were burnt-out relics as recently as 15 years ago. Dismembered by highway construction in the 1950's, abandoned by the middle class in the 60's and torched by arsonists in the 70's, the Bronx was salvaged by community groups that rousted drug dealers and reclaimed the borough street by street. Nonprofit organizations then developed thousands of affordable homes and apartments, using state, city and Federal funds in concert with programs that allow corporations to reduce tax liabilities by contributing to projects for the poor.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about an auction of Leonard Bernstein's possessions misstated the dimensions of a Bosendorfer grand piano that was auctioned for $350,000. Seven feet 4 inches is its length, not its height.

Regions, based in Birmingham, has more than 430 branches in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana and Tennessee. It will have more than $24 billion in assets when it completes these purchases. The stock of First State, based in Albany, Ga., rose $2.75, or 14 percent, to $22, in Nasdaq trading, while Regions rose 25 cents, to $42.

The faculty of the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine of the Mount Sinai Medical Center mourns the tragic and premature loss of our dear friend and colleague, Mr. David R. Ott. David was a brilliant and innovative medical administrator, who devoted his career to improving the quality and efficiency of medical care for all patients, establishing the highest possible single standard of care. A scholar himself, he was equally committed to medical education and scholarship. We will dearly miss his vision and creativity, and most especially, his commitment to helping the medically underserved.
