The Harris affiliates Harris Specialty Chemicals and the U.S. Silica Company are not part of the acquisition. But IMC said it would soon agree to acquire Harris Chemical's Australian affiliate, Penrice Soda Products. IMC, based in Northbrook, Ill., had sales of $2.98 billion for the year that ended on June 30. Its stock fell $2.4375 a share, to $30.125, on the Big Board

title: U.S. Women Defeat Brazil
description: Julie Foudy scored on a header in the 90th minute to give the United States women's national team a 2-1 victory over Brazil on Thursday night in Taubate, Brazil, in the opening match of a two-game series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, WALTER JAMES
description: LEVY-Walter James, 86, died peacefully, Wednesday, December 10, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Augusta. Devoted father of Susan and the late Robert. Dear brother of Kate Freyhan and Hertha Grove. Esteemed uncle of many nephews and nieces. Services were held.

title: Our Hungry Legal Immigrants
description: Close to a million legal immigrants across the country have had food stamps revoked under the 1996 welfare law, 50,000 in New York City alone. The city's food distributions to soup kitchens and food pantries are soaring, and some are reportedly running out of food each month. But statistics mask the individual tragedies. As reported by Rachel Swarns of The Times, a mother of four from Trinidad has been forced to use her rent money for food and substitute Kool-Aid for orange juice. A Peruvian mother spends her days pleading for groceries in one food pantry after another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLIN, ESTHER
description: BERLIN-Esther. Beloved wife of Nathan. Dear sister of Dorothy Jacobs and Morris Shilane. Loving aunt. Graveside services Sunday, December 14th, 10:30 AM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery. For information, call Weinstein-West End Funeral Chapel: 1-800-452-9597.

title: Defenders of Promiscuity Set Back AIDS Fight; Sign of Low Self-Esteem
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Judiciary Chief to Query Reno Aides on Counsel Decision
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, who heads the Senate Judiciary Committee, said today that he would summon top aides to Attorney General Janet Reno to testify about how she reached her decision to reject an independent prosecutor in the campaign finance case.

title: Inquiry on Trading In Fine Host Corp.
description: The decline in the shares of the Fine Host Corporation, which plunged 64 percent this week, have prompted the National Association of Securities Dealers to investigate the unusual trading, an association official said today.

title: Lighting Up the Zoo
description: The Bronx Zoo can seem empty and bleak in the winter. But this year the zoo has opened its doors at night, presenting a dazzling display of lights and animals in what could become a new holiday tradition. On a recent Saturday evening the zoo was teeming with families, their breath frosting as they passed animals real and manufactured.

title: SYBRON CHEMICALS ACCEPTS SWEETENED OFFER
description: Sybron Chemicals Inc. accepted a sweetened offer of $34.50 a share yesterday, or about $107 million, made by a group of major shareholders and management for shares of the specialty chemicals company it does not already own. The price is higher than the $32 to $33 a share the group offered in October for the remaining 55 percent of the company's shares. The investor group, led by Sybron Chemicals' chief executive, Richard M. Klein, and John Schroeder, an executive vice president, includes Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd., Sybron's largest shareholder. The company makes chemicals used in water treatment, textile dyes and printing. Shares in Sybron, which is based in Birmingham, N.J., fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $33.50, on the Big Board

title: Van Horn Adjusting to Rookie's Hard-Knock Life
description: The long red scratches that line Keith Van Horn's long pale arms could be viewed as the stripes he has earned four games into his rookie season in the National Basketball Association.

title: Milestone Within Sandpit's Reach
description: Sandpit will attempt to become the 14th horse in North American thoroughbred racing history to surpass the $4 million mark in career earnings in the $500,000 Hollywood Turf Cup tomorrow in Inglewood, Calif.

title: About New York; In Hard Lives Of Mexicans, Day of Mercy
description: OUTSIDE Nativity Roman Catholic Church yesterday, the predawn streets were rain-slicked and empty, save for a few cars cruising down Second Avenue. But dozens of people -- cooks, laborers, parents and children -- already filled the quiet sanctuary in the East Village where the air was moist and sweet from hundreds of red roses set before a painting of Our Lady of Guadalupe.

title: Some Unions Have Little Use for Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Suspect Professor Was Beaten in Off-Campus Robbery
description: Two days after a St. John's University professor was beaten and left for dead, unable even to remember what had happened to her, the police yesterday began to unravel some of the mystery surrounding the case, calling it an apparent robbery that probably did not occur on campus, as first reported.

title: Defenders of Promiscuity Set Back AIDS Fight; Extremists Both
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: An Accord to Open Up World's Financial Markets

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHAK, MARY FRANCES
description: LICHAK-Mary Frances. On December 10, 1997. Beloved daughter of Mary Ellen Lichak. Sister of Thomas and the late Ruth Ann. Sister-in-law of Mary K. Also survived by six nieces and nephews. Mary worked at CBS as a researcher for thirty years. She was also a member of the Writers Guild and the Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

title: Poor Nations Reject Role on Warming
description: While the Clinton Administration has said it will not submit a landmark environmental agreement for Senate approval unless developing countries also do more, the world's poor argue that cost and fairness dictate that the sacrifices needed to preserve the globe's climate should not be heaped on them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, IRVING SHERWOOD, M.D.
description: WRIGHT-Irving Sherwood, M.D. 96, died suddenly at home on December 8, 1997. He was the husband of the late Lois Elliman Wright, father of Barbara Wright Gatje, of New York City, and Alison Wright Cameron, of Bronxville; grandfather of Alexandra Lord Gatje, Douglas Wright Cameron, Marianna Gatje Perrier, Laura Howell Cameron, Margot Kim Gatje, and great-grandfather of Lucas Wright Perrier. He was Emeritus Clinical Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Medical College, and Honorary Attending Physician at the New York Hospital. Dr. Wright was born in New York City on October 27, 1901. He was a direct descendant of Wolphert Gerritsen van Couwenhoven whose family settled in Nieuw Amsterdam in 1630. He was nationally and internationally known for his research and leadership in the fields of cardiovascular disease and geriatrics. He served as President of the American Heart Association, the American College of Physicians, the American Geriatric Society, and in 1979, founded the American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Irving Sherwood Wright Center on Aging, Department of Medicine, New York Hospital-Cornell University Medical Center, 1300 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021, or to AFAR, 1414 Avenue of the Americas, 18th Floor, New York, New York 10019. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Longtime Giuliani Assistant Will Lead Tourism Bureau
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gained extensive control over the marketing of the city to tourists yesterday -- and solved a personnel problem at the same time -- when the private New York Convention and Visitors Bureau agreed to appoint as its president Fran Reiter, formerly his Deputy Mayor and campaign manager.

title: Vincent Is Going To the Grass Roots
description: Fay Vincent, the former commissioner of Major League Baseball, has a new position with a different baseball league -- the New England Collegiate Baseball League. Vincent yesterday was named the league's president and chairman of the board of directors.

title: Robert Frost's Poetic Underpinning: Conversation
description: In an essay in the most recent issue of the quarterly journal Modern Age, Peter J. Stanlis, Distinguished Professor of Humanities, Emeritus, at Rockford College in Illinois, argues that conversation was the critical element in Robert Frost's poetry and was the basis for his theory of language. Rather than conventional literary usage, he contends, Frost was after a ''poetry that talked.'' Here are excerpts from Professor Stanlis's essay.

title: From Close Family to World of Hate
description: In a sedate, upper-middle-class neighborhood here, where streets carry the names of Methodist bishops, young Mat thaeus Reinhart Jaehnig grew up in a large neo-Georgian brick house and attended a private school that nurtured freethinking. The household was headed by his father, a cerebral pastor whose pacifism dated from a childhood in war-ravaged Germany.

title: For Juilliard's 'Hansel,' National Exposure on TV
description: The Juilliard Opera Center's presentation of Humperdinck's ''Hansel und Gretel,'' which opened on Thursday night at the Juilliard Theater, has to be counted a missed opportunity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZANE, ANNA E.
description: ZANE-Anna E. Dec. 12, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Louis Ira Zane. Mother of Frances Louie Zane, Eliabeth Zane Malsky, Gloria Zane Gross, and James B. Zane. Survived by her four children, six grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren. Services Sunday, December 14, at 11:30 A.M., at West End Temple, 147-02 Newport Avenue, Neponsit, New York. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Long Island. Please omit flowers.

title: From Flat, Small and Big to EEE and Off the Charts
description: Dr. Kevin Saunders (David Schwimmer) is the good guy. He invented modern breast-augmentation surgery only for the good of humankind, always advocated saline over silicone, and if he became a disgusting, cocaine-snorting, gold-chain-wearing poor man's Hefner with bunny types around the pool at his 30,000-square-foot house, that was only because he'd been through so much. Dr. William Larson (Chris Cooper), you see, takes credit for Kevin's feels-like-the-real-thing implant and pockets all the royalties. Kevin gets even by specializing in monster-size breasts, which makes him bundles of money, turns him into a folk hero at lap-dancing bars and earns him a reputation for creating ''circus freaks.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEVA, TAMARA
description: GEVA-Tamara. How sorry I am to lose a friend, a person of joy, elegance and glamour. Her loyalty to George Balanchine never waned, and after his death she embraced his memory and gave inspiration and support. Barbara Horgan The George Balanchine Trust

title: Vocal Again, Childs Questions Knicks' Approach
description: The typically animated and often camera-friendly Chris Childs had begun to look like an extra on the set.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 3 about efforts to create fellowships for Russians at the American Academy in Rome as a tribute to the poet and Nobel Laureate Joseph Brodsky misstated the name of the organization behind the campaign. It is the Joseph Brodsky Memorial Fellowship Fund, not the Brodsky Association.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED TO LOWER BARRIERS IN GLOBAL FINANCE
description: Under the darkening clouds of Asia's financial crisis, the United States and more than 100 other countries signed a global trade agreement early this morning to open up the world's financial markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, MARIE D.
description: ANDERSON-Marie D. Recently of Essex, Connecticut, former long time resident of Douglaston Manor, New York. Widow of Charles G. Anderson, Sr., Mother of Charles G. Anderson, Jr. of Killingworth, CT. Sister of Edna Lapham of Wellealey, MA. Also survived by four grandchildren. Services Tuesday 11AM, at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, Manhasset, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Congregational Church of Manhasset, 1845 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York 11030.

title: Tensions Reach New High at Sharpton Defamation Trial
description: Tensions at the defamation lawsuit against three former advisers to Tawana Brawley reached their fullest, most furious boil today as one of the defendants, Alton H. Maddox Jr., sent loud, repeated accusations of racism flying through the courtroom.

title: North Korea And China Qualify
description: North Korea and China became the first to qualify for the 1999 women's World Cup of soccer, scoring victories over Japan and Taiwan in the semifinals of the Asian women's championship yesterday in Canton, China.

title: Will Transit Pass Make New Yorkers Flabby?; Let Drivers Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Republican Threats In Nomination Battle
description: Senate Republicans threatened to freeze money for Clinton Administration programs and block its nominees if the President uses his constitutional power to name Bill Lann Lee to the nation's top civil rights post without Senate approval while Congress is in recess.

title: Soccer Player Tries Running, and Races to the Top
description: When Erin Sullivan of Jericho, Vt., lined up for the first big high school cross-country race of her life in early October, she was matched against Tara Chaplin of nearby Middlesex, the defending state champion.

title: Abby Lewis, 87, Stage and Screen Actress
description: Abby Lewis, an actress whose long career embraced theater, films, television and radio, died on Nov. 27 at her home in Manhattan. She was 87.

title: Lloyd Likely Will Not Play
description: Greg Lloyd, the Pittsburgh Steelers' five-time Pro Bowl linebacker, will likely miss the remaining two games of the regular season with a staph infection in his right ankle, the club said yesterday

title: William Winpisinger, 73, Machinists' Chief
description: William W. Winpisinger, a fiery, left-leaning labor leader who battled management, politicians and sometimes his fellow unionists as president of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, died on Thursday at a hospital in Howard County, Md. He turned 73 on Wednesday and lived in Ellicott City, Md.

title: Saudi Bombing Still a Mystery, U.S. Officials Tell Victims' Relatives
description: A year and a half after 19 American airmen were killed in Saudi Arabia, officials have told the victims' relatives that investigators still do not know who carried out the truck bombing of the American barracks.

title: Mets Deal Ochoa for Twins Outfielder
description: Alex Ochoa was once part of a collection of supposedly can't-miss Mets prospects. Now he is a member of the Minnesota Twins, after being traded yesterday for Rich Becker, a left-handed-hitting outfielder.

title: And They Call It Puppy Love
description: So Bill Clinton is taking that dog after all. ''It's the President's desire to have one loyal friend in Washington,'' Mike McCurry, the White House press secretary, said in making the announcement this week. Such a compliment!

title: Carlos Rodriguez, Castro Ally And Leftist Leader, Dies at 84
description: Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, a Communist intellectual who forged a crucial alliance between Fidel Castro's bearded followers and Cuba's Moscow-line Communists and later served on the Politburo and as Deputy President, died Monday in Havana. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMISON, MARGARET M. (NEE FLAHERTY)
description: JAMISON-Margaret M. (nee Flaherty). Beloved wife of Joseph; loving mother of Joseph, Thomas, Mary Ellen Fitzsimons, Christopher, Ann Marie Schlosser, Kevin, Kathleen Meyer and Brian. Beloved grandmother of fourteen. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing, New York. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 9:30 AM, at Our Lady of Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's. Visiting hours Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday listing top women executives of Fortune 500 companies misspelled the name of the company headed by Jill Barad. It is Mattel, not Mattell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, JOHN F.
description: WHITE-John F. Age 82, of Sayville, LI, on December 11, 1997. Survived by his wife Jeanne H. White; his daughters Susan Callahan, Janet Foster and Rosemary White-Trout; his sisters Jeanne Ehrhardt, Catherine Thom and Nancy Meyer and ten grandchildren. Reposing at Raynor & D'Andrea Funeral Home, 245 Montauk Highway, West Sayville on Sunday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30PM. Funeral mass Monday 10:30 A.M., at Cenacle Chapel, 310 Cenacle Road, Lake Ronkonkoma. Interment in Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Coram. Memorials may be sent to Cenacle of St. Regis or to Brookhaven Memorial Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTINGER, LOUISE L.
description: OTTINGER-Louise L., 98. Died peacefully in her Hampshire House apartment on December 12, 1997. Major philanthropist and political activist for progressive social change causes, particularly for homeless and poor people in New York City. Curious about life, caring friend, involved citizen, proud mother, unconditionally loving and supportive grandmother and great grandmother, whose elegance, laughter and charm will always be remembered and cherished. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in the name of Louise Ottinger to Planned Parenthood of New York City, Development Office, 26 Bleecker Street, New York, New York 10012.

title: Journal; Who Stole History?
description: ''Is this Hollywood's Watergate?'' asked a screenwriter friend who admires Steven Spielberg but still wouldn't mind seeing him caught with a smoking gun.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Already, The Getty Has a Full Agenda
description: Barry Munitz has what might seem an enviably easy job. When he takes over as the president and chief executive officer of the J. Paul Getty Trust in January, he will inherit the recently completed product of more than a decade of efforts, a pristine, $1 billion art museum and research complex on a hilltop here that will celebrate its grand opening with ceremonies on Saturday.

title: Schools Chief Gives State Plan for Moving Pupils
description: Just in time to meet a court-ordered deadline, the Superintendent of Schools for Atlantic City gave the state a plan yesterday outlining how he intends to move 465 fifth graders from a troubled middle school to neighborhood elementary schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENS, CARRIE (NEE SCHWARZSTEIN)
description: RUBENS-Carrie (nee Schwarzstein), age 94, on December 11, 1997 of Branford, CT and Ft. Lee, NJ. Cherished widow of Charles A. Rubens, beloved mother of Rhoda Russota Berman, Stanley Rubens, the late Dorothy Arnstein and their spouses. Adored grandmother of Judith Siegel, Laurence Arnstein, Lisa Gant, Linda Soffer, and Ellen Schlesinger and their spouses, eight great-grandchildren, two great-great grandchildren. Service will be held at 11AM, Sunday, December 14 at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, NJ. 201843-7600. Contributions may be made to Swim-In Multiple Sclerosis National Society of Greater New Jersey, 1 Kalisa Way, Paramus, New Jersey 07652 or Connecticut Hospice, Branford, CT. 06405.

title: Russia Reaches I.M.F. Accord To Free Loans
description: Russia reached agreement today with the International Monetary Fund on a plan that would open the door for a quick infusion of $1.7 billion in Western loans.

title: Lowering the Credit Fence; Big Players Are Jumping Into the Risky Loan Business
description: Beatrice Smith has refinanced the mortgage on her small Atlanta home six times in the last decade. As a result, her monthly payment rose from $267 to $417 -- before she defaulted on the loan late last year.

title: Another Dip In Prices Paid To Producers
description: Prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers dropped an unexpected two-tenths of 1 percent in November, the Labor Department said today. The economy now appears likely to record its first yearly decline in producer prices since 1986.

title: E.P.A. Threatens Cuts Over Emissions Testing
description: In a strongly worded warning to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday that some highway funds could be lost if New Jersey did not speed up its plans for an enhanced auto emission testing program.

title: Company Briefs
description: CONRAIL INC., Philadelphia, the railroad company, purchased 39 SD-70 locomotives from General Motors Corp., for $66.3 million.

title: All for Love, or Is It Lust?
description: Hans van Manen is a European ballet choreographer with some 40 years of experience. Ulysses Dove, an American, began to choreograph modern dance in 1979. But there is a mutual concern with plotless, stylishly designed movement containing buried emotional subtexts in Mr. van Manen's ''Polish Pieces'' and Mr. Dove's ''Bad Blood,'' presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Tuesday at City Center.

title: 'Problems' Vowed on Rights Appointment
description: Senate Republicans threatened today to block nominees from the Clinton Administration and freeze money for its programs if the President made a temporary appointment next week without Senate approval to name Bill Lann Lee to the nation's top civil rights enforcement post.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, MARK F.
description: HUGHES-Mark F. Of Elberon, NJ, also of New York City, N.Y., on December 10, 1997. Husband of the late Annette (nee Morgan) Hughes. Father of Mark F. Hughes, Jr., John J. Hughes, Annette ''Toni'' Hillary and Mary Jane Moeller. Brother of Paul Hughes and Jack F. Hughes. Grandfather of eight. Great-grandfather of three. Visitation Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, NJ. Funeral Mass Monday 10:30AM, at St. John the Baptist R.C. Church, 252-262 Morris Ave., Long Branch, New Jersey. Interment to follow in MT. Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, NJ.

title: Regulators Chide Utility Over Problems At Power Site
description: Two days after claiming to have turned the corner on its troubles, Northeast Utilities was reminded today that it had still not fully resolved the problems that led the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to close down three of its nuclear reactors in Connecticut within the last two years.

title: Heisman Hopefuls Gather For an Intriguing Choice
description: Ryan Leaf's journey to the Downtown Athletic Club was the longest of the four finalists for the Heisman Memorial Award, so the junior quarterback from Washington State University was given the first choice. Before the finalists hear one name called shortly before 8:30 this evening, if they were to be paired in a touch football game somewhere in lower Manhattan, who would be his teammate?

title: IMPACT SYSTEMS TO BE ACQUIRED BY GERMAN CONCERN
description: Impact Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired by a division of the German manufacturer J. M. Voith A.G. for $2.75 a share, or about $30 million. Shares of Impact Systems rose 84.375 cents, to $2.59375, in Nasdaq trading. Voith Sulzer Paper Technology North America Inc., the unit that will acquire Impact Systems, said it was purchasing the company, which is based in Los Gatos, Calif., to broaden its line of paper technology products and services. Impact Systems' products, primarily measurement and control systems, allow paper manufacturers to improve paper quality and reduce waste. Voith Sulzer Paper is based in Appleton, Wis.

title: When Declarer Sees Red, It Might Be a Freak Hand
description: True freak hands, in which at least one player has either two voids or a void and a singleton, rarely produce problems in the play. The diagramed deal is an exception. Before reading on, consider the prospects of game contracts for North-South.

title: KELLOGG AUTHORIZES REPURCHASE OF SHARES
description: The Kellogg Company said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of $400 million of common stock after the cereal maker completed a $415.1 million buyback plan. The move comes as Kellogg shares are trading near their 52-week high of $50.50. The shares rose 56.25 yesterday, to $48.875. The company, based in Battle Creek, Mich., the maker of Corn Flakes and Froot Loops, said it will repurchase the shares through the end of 1998. The company has about 410.9 million shares outstanding. It has repurchased 214.1 million shares since 1984.

title: State Department Concedes Flaws in Investigation of Envoy
description: The State Department today admitted that it had mishandled the vetting of M. Larry Lawrence's 1993 nomination as Ambassador to Switzerland. But officials denied that contradictions in his record were overlooked by investigators because he was a leading Democratic fund-raiser.

title: Defenders of Promiscuity Set Back AIDS Fight; Reject False Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUPPLEE, SARAH
description: SUPPLEE-Sarah. In Cambridge, MA., on December 8. Wife of Fred Faudie and daughter of Grace (Linzey) and the late William Carlton Supplee. Sister of Mary Lindsey and aunt of Thomas, William and Robert Gattin of New Mexico. Calling hours at the Watson Funeral Home, 11 Magazine Street, Cambridge, on Sunday, December 14 from 2 to 6 PM. A funeral service will be held during calling hours at 3 PM. Donations in Sarah's name may be made to ALS/MA Chapter, 7 Lincoln Street, Wakefield, MA. 01880.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERELS, EUGENE
description: SERELS-Eugene. Beloved husband of Sondra. Loving father of Roseanne Serels and Dr. Scott Serels. Grandfather of Gillian. Services 11:30 AM Sunday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, New Jersey.

title: Once-Buoyant Hopes Sink in Indonesia's Slump
description: When economists worry about Indonesia's slump its sinking currency, its ailing banks and its nearly $40 billion bailout package -- they worry about people like Jumaluddin, a low-paid factory worker with a ready smile and a precarious future.

title: Defenders of Promiscuity Set Back AIDS Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Harada Takes Event Again
description: Masahiko Harada of Japan soared 95 1/2 and 94 meters yesterday in Harrachov, the Czech Republic, to capture his second straight ski jumping event and take the lead in World Cup standing.

title: John Fitting Jr., 81, Executive At Dreyfus and a Fund Pioneer
description: John Fitting Jr., a Dreyfus Corporation executive and pioneer in the creation of no-load mutual funds in the early 1970's, died Wednesday at his retirement home on Marco Island, Fla. He was 81.

title: Autumn Jackson Receives 26-Month Term in Cosby Case
description: A Federal district judge in Manhattan sentenced Autumn Jackson to 26 months in prison yesterday after she tearfully apologized for trying to extort millions of dollars from Bill Cosby and pleaded with the judge to spare her a prison sentence.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Dec. 3 isting the business interests of Francois Pinault, the French financier, and his family included outdated information about one American company, Artemis America, which they control. The company does not own Furniture Brands International; almost all of the 38 percent stake it once held through an affiliate, Apollo Investment Fund, was sold in the spring.

title: Will Transit Pass Make New Yorkers Flabby?
description: To the Editor:

title: English Goalies Cleared to Play
description: Goalkeepers Bruce Grobbelaar and Hans Segers, acquitted earlier this year on criminal match-fixing charges, were cleared yesterday to continue playing soccer in England.

title: I.R.S. Admits Taxpayers' Rights Are Abused by Improper Tactics
description: Citing an internal audit it conducted this fall, the Internal Revenue Service admitted today that taxpayers' rights are abused by a systemwide climate of high pressure that encourages I.R.S. auditors to go to improper lengths to meet statistical benchmarks.

title: Unbundling Microsoft
description: The fast-spreading field of information technology represents what its proponents call ''the new economy,'' an increasingly affluent incubator of innovative products, business practices and work habits. In the new economy, its advocates insist, none of the old rules apply -- and certainly not the old antitrust ground rules that date to the late 19th century and smoke-filled rail cars.

title: Carlos the Jackal on Trial For French Killings in 1975
description: The international terrorist known as Carlos, gray-haired but proudly boasting of being ''a professional revolutionary in the old Leninist tradition,'' went on trial here today on charges of killing two French security officials and a Lebanese informant 22 years ago.

title: Rev, Rev, Rev Your Boat: The Evolution of an Ungentle Weekend Sport
description: When Trey and Jennifer Urbahn moved from Washington, D.C., to a house dotting one of the many inland waterways here in the self-styled ''Venice of America,'' they expected a year-round cool breeze and a view of cruising boats.

title: Belarus Blocks Bid for a Human Rights Office
description: The Government of Belarus, which has grown increasingly totalitarian in the last year, is preventing the establishment of an office there that would monitor human rights and assist in democratic development, European and American diplomats said today.

title: Steinbrenner and Cone Look Beyond '98
description: George Steinbrenner and David Cone came together yesterday to encourage fans who gathered at Yankee Stadium to buy single-game tickets, an indication that the 1998 season is very much on their minds. Yet as both spoke, it was also obvious that Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, and Cone, the club's premier pitcher, were looking beyond next year as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, PHILIP
description: HELLER-Philip. On Dec. 10, 1997. Beloved husband of Julia. Devoted father of Marsha Feris and Myra Linker. Loving brother of Libby Cohen and the late Mary Farber and Jake Heller. Cherished grandfather of Stephanie, Alison, Sachi and Danielle. Adored greatgrandfather of Danielle and Stephen. Services Sunday 10:30 a.m. at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: A Consensus, but No Conclusions, on Flight 800
description: The National Transportation Safety Board wound up a week of hearings on the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 today without uncovering what made the plane explode shortly after takeoff, but with something that its top officials say was almost as good: a consensus that steps should be taken to cut the risk of fuel tank explosions in all planes, perhaps eliminating it entirely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, IRVING
description: BERNSTEIN-Irving. I was deeply saddened to learn of the untimely passing of my dear friend Irving Bernstein. This marks the end of an era of great Jewish leaders. Since 1946, Irving worked tirelessly, devoting his life to ensuring the welfare and survival of the Jewish people. I had the privilege of knowing and working with Irving throughout his years working with the United Jewish Appeal and for other causes. Irving was one of a kind. It will be a long time before there will be another one like him. My wife Jean and I send our heartfelt sympathies to Judith and the family. Sam Rothberg

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, BELTON
description: CUNNINGHAM-Belton. The President and the Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center note with profound sorrow the death of Belton Cunningham, beloved husband of Dr. Anita Cunningham, an esteemed member of our Board of Trustees. We extend our sincere and heartfelt condolences to his wife, entire family and friends. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Muni Bonds: You Can Take Them With You
description: Q. I'm retiring and moving to Florida. Do I have to sell my New York State municipal bonds and replace them with Florida bonds?

title: Revels With the Pump Boys, the People of Tuna and the Gentleman Caller
description: ''SEAL it with feasts,'' King Cymbeline decrees in the joyful reconciliation scene at the end of Shakespeare's play. Can high spirits be more felicitously ordained?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, SALLY
description: ROBINSON-Sally. On December 10. Wife of Alvin. Mother of Joel and Ann. Finally at peace.

title: Pop/Rock/Soul; A Flurry of Boxed Sets Wraps Up the Year
description: Boxed sets were once among a music fan's most prized possessions -- beautifully packaged, exhaustively chronicled career retrospectives. But nowadays the sets have become almost as commonplace as albums, with young bands putting them out after only a few releases, older musicians boasting as many as five, and others compiling them on a single theme. With the gift-giving season upon us, here is a selection by New York Times critics. The sets average $12 to $16 per disk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELICOFON, EDWARD I.
description: ELICOFON-Edward I. My dearest second Daddy, my Mr. E. I miss you. I love you. L.

title: UP AND COMING: Hazelle Goodman; Seriously Set On Being Funny

title: Robust Flavors in Heart of Burgundy
description: BREATHES there a wine lover immune to the lure of Beaune? A town of roughly 22,000 inhabitants in Burgundy, its world renown is based on its location in the heart of the wine region known as the Cote d'Or. Some 190 miles southeast of Paris, it is easily reachable for a long weekend. With such mythic appellations as Gevrey-Chambertin, Chambolle-Musigny and Vosne-Romanee to the north and Meursault, Puligny-Montrachet and Pommard to the south, Beaune is the center of Burgundy's wine trade.

title: THE VIEW FROM/A Catholic Worker House ; Where Nonviolence and Commitment to the Community Rule
description: KEELEY COLVILLE had quite a seventh birthday party at her home in New Haven a few weeks ago, even though her father was in jail in Maine and several other members of her collective household were at an anti-military demonstration in Georgia. That kind of disruption is par for the course when you live in a Catholic Worker house, a place where people believe in doing the works of mercy and justice, as enumerated in the Sermon on the Mount of Jesus.

title: Dropping In On The Literary Lions
description: PULSING with ex-pats and nouveau riche Russians, the Hungry Duck is a raffish, hang-loose Moscow hangout that frisks customers for weapons at the front door, then invites them to indulge their Dionysian instincts. Fueled by vodka, maddened by music, exhibitionists clamber atop the bar and dance. Some strip. Others trip, take headers onto the beer-flooded floor, and are crowned members of the Hungry Duck Diving Club.

title: Plugging In While Dropping Out

Roland had no trouble doing it in China, although in Beijing he had to do it on the toilet. Lately when I'm with my husband, Mike, I find myself trapped in conversations like this in which adventure E-mailers thrill one another with tales of their exploits on laptops while traveling.

title: Odd Man In
description: Frank Capra's sunny but soulful comedy MR. DEEDS GOES TO TOWN (1936), about Longfellow Deeds, the tuba-playing poet laureate of Mandrake Falls, Vt., who inherits a fortune and comes to Manhattan, was a huge Depression-hit and an instant classic. Gary Cooper as the naive but noble provincial protagonist proves his mettle, charming a formidable city and a cynical reporter (Jean Arthur) who comes to love him. Mr Capra and his wise scene writer, Robert Riskin, explore human nature with delightful, quirky surprises, and the two stars are entirely pervasive -- TUESDAY at 7 P.M. and MIDNIGHT on AMC. Howard Thompson

title: As Rangers Slip, the Devils Surge
description: The Devils' coach, Jacques Lemaire, has never seemed more sure and secure. His boss, General Manager Lou Lamoriello, has signed defenseman Scott Stevens and goaltender Martin Brodeur in the last week. Center Doug Gilmour could be next. When the veteran John MacLean demanded a trade, Lamoriello swiftly exiled him to San Jose, hockey's Alcatraz. With young players like Petr Sykora, Patrik Elias and Brendan Morrison moving up, veteran Devils know their playing minutes depend on individual effort and group success. Their methodical, disciplined style has produced a 21-9-0 record. Friday night's 5-2 victory over Montreal gave the Devils four straight victories heading into last night's game in Toronto.

title: Clarifying the Purchase Of a Golf Club

The village paid I.B.M. $12,700,000. As I have said repeatedly, there were acquisition costs and property taxes required to be paid in the amount of $675,000, which were not part of the price paid to I.B.M. No ''outside auditor'' divulged these figures. The village trustees have made this clear, and no resident has questioned this other than Mr. Blankman.

title: Outside In
description: In my frequent visits to Israel, most lately, just before and after the last election, I could not fail to notice the trend of young Israelis to disassociate themselves from the ''old'' Zionism. Most of this generation travel widely, and are not easily swayed by slogans. They view the world realistically, more so because they live in constant danger. The influence of the Orthodox minority, which is obnoxious to liberal American Jews, is reduced to just that, a minority. It's important to note that Netanyahu is secular in his beliefs, and the Orthodox know it.

title: Editorial Observer; Now Playing: Waiting for Ferraro

Thousands of politicians have used a similar test over the last 220 years. Remarkably few have ever wound up concluding that there are probably other people who could do the job better.

description: THE ''Black and Whites'' -- four modest walkups at 72d Street and the East River -- are not typical of most riverfront development in Manhattan, where luxury town houses or apartment buildings seem to be the rule. But this curious 1894 complex made its own panache when it was rebuilt in 1938 by Carmel Snow, the trend-setting editor of Harper's Bazaar, and her husband, George Palen Snow, a lawyer and real estate investor.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/ Alpine, N.J.; Lavish Homes in a Millionaire's Borough
description: ALPINE is one of the few municipalities in New Jersey where residents do not complain about their property taxes. Because of high property values and a small number of school-age children, they pay 94 cents per $100 of assessed valuation, one of the lowest rates in the state.

title: The Nation; Clinton Can Now Sing, 'Me and My Shadow President'
description: VICE PRESIDENT AL GORE swept into the international talks on global warming here last week and, with a bit of drama, added a passage to his speech that was not in the prepared text. He told the delegates from about 160 nations that after conferring with President Clinton by telephone, he was instructing the American delegation ''to show increased negotiating flexibility.''

title: Egypt Tours in Flux After Luxor Killings
description: Most tour operators canceled or suspended their trips to Egypt after last month's massacre at the Temple of Hatshepsut in Luxor, where 58 foreign tourists were murdered by Muslim militants. No Americans were killed or wounded, but the United States State Department recommended that private citizens not travel to the area, then within days advised travelers there to ''exercise greater than usual caution.'' The Embassy in Cairo subsequently advised Americans in Egypt to ''exercise vigilance'' and urged them to register at the embassy.

title: VIEW ; Accessory After The Fact
description: ON a trip to Paris late last month, I spent my first day meandering through the narrow streets of St.-Germain-des-Pres, the quaint section of the Left Bank chock-full of inviting boutiques. Standing before a large glass storefront, I caught a glimpse of myself in the window reflection.

title: The Fencing in of Africa
description: There is no more truly wild land in Africa. No matter how far you go into the scrubland of Botswana and Namibia, you will run into barbed-wire fences. No matter how deep you go into the Congo jungle, you will see dirt roads and airstrips. The pressure on wild game -- both from decreasing habitat and poachers -- is enormous, but salvation may be coming from an unexpected source. Crass and unromantic as it sounds, game ranching may be the best hope for many of Africa's threatened animals.

title: Lynda Sheeler and Damian Laugher
description: SOME people believe that keeping up a long-distance romance is like trying to ride a bicycle through snow: a doomed, wobbly enterprise. When Damian Adrien Laugher, a native of Brisbane, Australia, and Lynda Eleanor Sheeler, a New Yorker, started dating four years ago, friends told them they would end up with broken hearts and huge phone bills.

He is a tall, thin man with a pale, hard-edged face and a brutal haircut, and he is a supremely focused taskmaster who speaks so fast that his associates can scarcely apprehend one of his ideas before he has moved to the next.

That compares to what is in fact an unusually high total of eight currently on Broadway, which has long since abandoned straight plays to the more adventurous, somewhat less economically pressed Off Broadway producers.

title: If Only One East Coast Port Can Be No. 1, Which One Will It Be?
description: The year is 2030. Broad floating behemoths, eight stories high and nearly five stories deep, chug into an East Coast port, carrying 8,000 standard shipping containers filled with European exports, everything from computers to beer. Robotically unloaded, the cargo is shifted onto smaller ships, for delivery to other East Coast ports, onto railroads for delivery to the Midwest, and onto trucks for local delivery. American exports are loaded on, and the mighty ships take off for foreign ports, all in the service of a booming international economy.

title: The Fall After the Fall
description: James Traub's sympathetic portrait of Webster Hubbell is an example of why white-collar crime provokes so little moral outrage in this culture (''The Fall After the Fall,'' Nov. 23). Traub's allusion to Dreiser confers a pathos to Hubbell's criminal behavior and abuse of power in a manner that would have been inconceivable in an article about ''inner city'' crime.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE; In the Battle of Curries, Music Is Raising the Stakes
description: In India or Pakistan, it is not uncommon for a well-executed raga to inspire tears or religious ecstacy. But Bakul Miah, the owner of Raj Mahal restaurant on East Sixth Street, is not sentimental about his reasons for hiring musicians to play Indian classical songs each night in his establishment. ''It improves business,'' he says simply.

title: Commercial Property; Stores, Landlords Seek Profits Above and Below
description: WHEN the owners of the Tourneau company decided to establish a flagship store in Manhattan, they realized they would not be likely to find all the space they needed on one floor in a prime location. So they decided to look up and down as well as around.

title: MUSIC ; Sounds for a Season of Harmony
description: THE Christmas shopping season has brazenly pushed Thanksgiving into partial eclipse, and each year its premature kickoff better positions it to threaten Halloween. But musical manifestations of Christmas are confined to December and remain traditional in nature, rather than subject to fads. That is, sober adults tend not to pummel one another over concert tickets the way they might over, say, a Sing and Snore Ernie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, COHEN, FRANCE
description: BAKER-COHEN-France. Friends, colleagues and students mourn the death of Dr. France Baker-Cohen on November 23 at age 73. A graduate of Columbia University, she worked at the American Museum of Natural History and for many years as Assistant Professor of Anatomy at Albert Einstein Medical School. Donations in her memory may be sent to The Wildlife Conservation Society, Bronx Zoo, Bronx, NY 10460.

title: TELEVISION VIEW; Shaping Up to Be Funny At Sitcom Boot Camp
description: AS A LITTLE GIRL IN QUEENS IN the 1960's, I watched a lot of sitcoms. There was something comforting about those nice, functional families. The worst thing that ever happened on ''The Brady Bunch'' was that Greg got caught with a cigarette, and it even turned out that it wasn't his. You knew a character was in love if she did something dumb like sticking a schoolbook in the refrigerator. Plus, television was educational. My English teacher was very impressed when I used the words ''adversarial relationship'' in a composition; I explained that I had learned the term watching Adam West on ''Batman.''

title: The Population Explosion Is Over

title: Really Big Football Players
description: It's Sunday in America, and size still matters. Dad's out on the golf course, swinging an extra-long driver with a head the size of a cantaloupe. Mom's on her way to the price club, up behind the wheel of a two-ton sport-utility vehicle that can withstand a rhino attack. The kids are gathered in front of a TV set with a screen as wide as a picture window. The family pet, a 150-pound Rottweiler, is out in the backyard, chewing on an old snow tire. Down at the local gargantuplex, crowds of people wearing heavy, thick-soled boots are lining up to see Hollywood's latest batch of kazillion-dollar, effects-bloated extravaganzas. And in pro-football stadiums from coast to coast, a new generation of massive offensive linemen is coming of age. Scores of players weighing 300 pounds and more are taking the field, shaking the earth and changing the way the game is played.

title: Commuter Artist
description: THE walk to Robert Birmelin's studio in Manhattan is a plunge into the rough-and-tumble urban scene that for many years was the recurrent subject of his paintings, drawings and prints. Faces, bodies, cars, even buildings pass by in a blur as you join the world's fastest-walking population in registering its environs without actually looking at them. The street has a rumpled, unceremonious yet sometimes threatening vitality; where anything resembling eye contact can be taken as a challenge, an invitation or an admission of naivete, visual reality is likely to be something constructed out of glimpses of movement, snatches of color and shape caught on the fly.

title: Yellowstone and the Winter Ahead
description: Winter weather has barely come to Yellowstone yet. There is only a foot of snow in the town of West Yellowstone, where the fly-fishing shops are hoping for a dry season and the snowmobilers are hoping for a deep one. Late autumn is a time of migration in Yellowstone. Brown trout move out of Hebgen Lake and up into the Madison River. Perhaps half the park's 38,000 elk remain in Yellowstone all winter, but as snow accumulates the rest of the herds begin to drift their separate directions in search of food and favorite calving grounds. This fall there has been so little snow and so much grazing in Yellowstone that the elk have just begun to move. The animals are fat and healthy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSH, ROBERT EDWARD, JR.
description: MARSH-Robert Edward, Jr. Died suddenly at age 83 at his home in Forest Hills, New York, on December 11, 1997. Born on June 6, 1914, the son of Robert Edward Marsh and Grace Sophronia Marsh, nee Rollinson. Served in the U.S. Army during World War II on the staff of General Douglas MacArthur. Following his military service, joined the Arabian American Oil Company (Aramco), serving that organization and its affiliate, the Trans Arabian Pipe Line Company (Tapline), for 30 years, primarily in Saudi Arabia and Lebanon. Following his retirement and until his death, was associated with The Olayan Group in Beirut, London, Athens, and, in recent years, New York. Reflecting his long experience and interest in the Middle East, was a devoted memeber of several non-profit oranizations based in Washington, DC and New York, among them: the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee; the Arab American Institute; American Near East Refugee Aid, where he was a director from 1980 to 1986 and 1988 to 1992; Americans for Middle East Understanding, where he was a founding director from 1978 until his death; and The Middle East Institute, where he served on the Board of Governors from 1990 to 1996. Also a long-time member of the Union League Club of New York and the West Side Tennis Club of Forest Hills. Survived by a sister, Mrs. Roslyn Rollinson Marsh Steinbach, of La Jolla, CA. Beloved uncle of six nieces and nephews: Roslyn Steinbach Tate of Philadelphia, PA; Sandra Rollinson Freiburg of San Diego, CA; Henry Hof of Hackensack, NJ; Robert Marsh Hof of Forest Hills; Nancy Hof Georgia of Long Island, NY; and Philip Marsh Hof of Easton, PA. Great uncle of 16. Visiting hours: 2-6 P.M. Sunday, December 14, and 10 A.M.-noon Monday, December 15, at Fox Funeral Home, 98-07 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY (Telephone: 718-268-7711). Funeral service: 1 P.M., Monday, Dec. 15, at the Church-in-the-Gardens, 50 Ascan Ave, Forest Hills, NY. Interment Rosedale Cemetery, Linden, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Americans for Middle East Understanding, Room 245, 475 Riverside Drive, New York, NY 10115-0245

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMB, BEATRICE PITNEY
description: LAMB-Beatrice Pitney. Wife of the late Horace R. Lamb of New Canaan, Conn, and New York City, died peacefully December 9, 1997, at Meadow Lakes retirement community, Hightstown, N.J. Born in Morristown, N.J., in 1904, she graduated from Westover School, Middlebury, Conn and Bryn Mawr College. Served as editor of the United Nations News 1945-49 before being invited to be a delegate to a conference on Indo-American Relations in New Delhi, India. Made nine lengthy trips to India observing and taking photographs and wrote four books on India. Exhibits of her photographs on Indian architecture and village life were shown at libraries and educational institutions around the country. Survived by two daughters, Barbara L. Johnson of Princeton, N.J. and Dorothy L. Crawford of Cambridge, Mass; six grandchildren and eight greatgrandchildren. Memorial service Saturday, January 10, 1998 at 2 P.M. at First Presbyterian Church, Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, CT.

They gave him a choice of two more: one that ended in 2463 -- a stately, even-numbered staircase cut short by an odd 3. No, thanks. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Where Sorrow Never Came
description: Never has the leisure of the privileged class seemed more appealing than in the photographs of Jacques-Henri Lartigue (1894-1986). Born to a French family of talented amateurs with the means to indulge every amusing hobby, he was given his first camera at the age of 8. By his early teens, he had produced virtuoso images of such wit, charm and seemingly effortless technique that few have ever surpassed them. Lartigue focused his camera on family, friends and the fashionable strangers he saw on outings; he took photos for his own pleasure that he kept in special albums. Only after a lifetime working as a moderately successful painter did his photography career flourish, with a solo show at the Museum of Modern Art in 1963, when he was 69. The images in LARTIGUE'S RIVIERA (Flammarion, $35) show a place of civilized leisure, energized by a sense of novelty still possible in the 1920's and 30's, when most of these pictures were made. Lartigue shows a land where a benevolent sun shines on women and water, cars, painted fingernails, tennis champs, swimmers -- a sensual topography of blonde and brunette. Those familiar with Lartigue's early work will recognize the sensibility driving the images of water-ski jumping, of exercises on the beach, and of Noisette, a small black poodle depicted hurtling itself toward the lens. Lartigue has created a world like that of the 18th-century painter Fragonard -- enchanting and frivolous, with life's disappointments and sorrow well out of frame. Mary Blume, a journalist who has written a history of the Cote d'Azur, provides an interesting and sympathetic text. Rosemary Ranck

He was Emeritus Clinical Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Medical College, and Honorary Attending Physician at the New York Hospital. Dr. Wright was born in New York City on October 27, 1901. He was a direct descendant of Wolphert Gerritsen van Couwenhoven whose family settled in Nieuw Amsterdam in 1630. He was nationally and internationally known for his research and leadership in the fields of cardiovascular disease and geriatrics. He served as President of the American Heart Association, the American College of Physicians, the American Geriatric Society, and in 1979, founded the American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR). title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Missing Digit
description: Though it's set in the month before Christmas, Shena Mackay's novel AN ADVENT CALENDAR (Moyer Bell, $19.95) immediately subverts any expectation of holiday coziness. The book opens with a butcher accidentally chopping off his finger, which drops unseen into a mincer and disappears into the meat that John, a central character, takes home for his Uncle Cecil. Such a devilish fusion of tragedy and black humor is one way that Mackay continually renews this tale of crushing poverty and lonely domestic life in a British working-class town. Another is her spare yet wildly evocative prose, which shapes the dreary milieu with a startling, cut-crystal sharpness as it swiftly constructs two interlocking stories. The first involves John and Marguerite, a young, unemployed, unhappily married couple who avoid homelessness by moving in with John's elderly uncle. John worries about making amends to the fingerless butcher while Marguerite cares for their two young children and indulges in a secret affair. Meanwhile, from across town and a loose family connection comes the dire story of Joy Pickering, a 15-year-old outcast whose unhappiness renders her easy sexual prey for a humorously pompous poet. Originally published in Britain in 1971, ''An Advent Calendar'' has a plot that's more roughly hewn, more glaring and strange, than Mackay's recent work. Nevertheless, once the last double doors of the calendar are opened she deftly reveals a moving and inventive redemption. Megan Harlan

Normally the denizens of ''E.R.,'' the NBC medical thriller and most-watched show on television, don't stray far from the hospital emergency room where they conduct business. In one episode last month, however, Doug Ross (George Clooney) travels to Arizona to bury his father and bond with his colleague Dr. Mark Greene (Anthony Edwards). Not a stethoscope in sight.

title: Getty Center Inaugurated in Los Angeles
description: On a brilliant, cool morning, dignitaries and celebrities including the Mayor of Los Angeles and the rock group Los Lobos presided over the inauguration of one of the largest arts centers in the country, the $1 billion Getty Center here.

title: Co-ed Masters School Draws Praise
description: Two years ago, we read with interest an article in the Westchester section on the decision by the Masters School to become coeducational. In the absence of a follow-up article, we are writing to let you know, from the perspective of a ''pioneer'' boy's family (our son is a charter member of the class of 2000), how successful the transition has been.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, ELIZABETH
description: GROSS-Elizabeth. On December 13, 1997. Beloved wife of Harry, loving mother of Daniel, dear mother-in-law of Linda, adoring aunt of many nieces and nephews. Graveside service Sunday, 1 PM at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, Queens.

title: Acts of Faith
description: On Paul Moore's mission to save the world, the first stop was Jersey City. The year was 1949.

title: Public Eyesore to Private Park; Can Golf Rescue a Dreary Slab of Brooklyn?
description: It was to have been a grand swath of trees and songbirds and beachfront promenades, a ribbon of green on the gray, dreary southwestern fringe of Brooklyn.

title: Flouting Law, Hospitals Overwork Novice Doctors
description: Hospitals in New York City often rely on exhausted and poorly supervised medical residents, flouting laws enacted eight years ago to protect patients and compromising patient care, according to interviews with dozens of young doctors training in hospitals around the city.

title: High Schoolers Become Teachers (of CPR)
description: ON Sept. 17, 1979, the first day of the scalloping season, Susan Remkus Denis tried in vain to revive her father, Joseph Remkus, a bayman, who had died in his driveway. Although she is a registered nurse, Ms. Denis had virtually no training in cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

title: Buenos Aires
description: To the Editor: I was surprised that in ''What's Doing in Buenos Aires'' (Nov. 9), Kevin M. Gray mentions Avenida 9 de Julio only in passing, as the site of Colon Theater.

title: Ranchers Back Ruling On Wolves Out West
description: Two years after the first wolves were reintroduced into Yellowstone National Park, a Federal judge has ruled the Government's wolf recovery program is illegal and has ordered the wolves removed from the park and from central Idaho.

title: It Is Better to Give Than to Receive
description: On a recent saturday, vartan gregorian, the president of the Carnegie Corporation, pointed to a solid wall of books in his new office that had just arrived from his old one. ''For the first few months I was here, I had empty shelves,'' Gregorian said. ''All my books were still at Brown University. It was unnerving to greet people in such a bare room. But now I can settle in. Even the most elegant room feels empty without books.''

title: BENEFITS
description: Spreading Music Around

title: December 7-13; Here's Johnnie. Again. And Again.
description: Johnnie Cochran took another giant step last week down a road leading as far away as possible from That Client -- O. J. Simpson, the one who nonetheless made him the most famous lawyer in America. Tuesday, he showed up on a dream team advising Latrell Sprewell, the Golden State Warriors guard whose $32 million contract was canceled by the National Basketball Association after Mr. Sprewell's choking attack on his coach, P. J. Carlesimo. After Mr. Sprewell publicly apologized to Mr. Carlesimo, Mr. Cochran criticized the punishment imposed by the league, which included a year's suspension, saying the basketball commissioner had rushed to judgment -- a charge he leveled so memorably against the Los Angeles police.

description: Boxed sets were once among a music fan's most prized possessions -- beautifully packaged, exhaustively chronicled career retrospectives. But nowadays the sets have become almost as commonplace as albums, with young bands putting them out after only a few releases, older musicians boasting as many as five, and others compiling them on a single theme. With the gift-giving season upon us, here is a selection by New York Times critics. The sets average $12 to $16 per disk.

title: Elaborate Purveyors Of European Culture
description: IN 1715, AFTER CENTURIES OF FAILED attempts at making porcelain, Europeans finally mastered it at Meissen in Saxony. Rulers throughout the continent proceeded to build or buy factories to make their own porcelains. And then they dazzled their dinner guests with the most spectacular color-splashed tureens and figurines -- status symbols of the ancien regime.

title: Mitchell Gould and Julie Brecher
description: Julie Brecher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Brecher of Kings Point, N.Y., was married last evening to Mitchell Keith Gould, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Gould of Manhattan. Rabbi Robert S. Widom officiated at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, N.Y.

title: People's Pie
description: To the Editor: Paul Hofmann writes, ''Scholars dispute whether the word pizza is derived from Greek, Hebrew or Arabic terms for flat bread (pita) or from the Latin picea, meaning 'of pitch' and referring to the texture and color of the well-baked pie.''

title: Studying for a Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Store Owner Shoots One Of 4 Robbery Suspects
description: An attempted robbery of a Harlem sporting goods store ended with the store owner's shooting one of the assailants twice after gaining control of the man's gun, the police said. The unidentified suspect was in critical condition last night in Harlem Hospital Center.

title: December 7-13; Flight 800 Mystery
description: What happened to T.W.A. Flight 800? There were still more theories than concrete answers -- and some disturbing questions -- as the National Transportation Safety Board completed a week of hearings in Baltimore. The hearings were adjourned indefinitely with more questions for investigators about what ignited the center fuel tank of the 25-year-old Boeing 747, which exploded shortly after takeoff from John F. Kennedy International Airport in 1996.

title: Backtalk; Ball of Confusion: That's What the Sports World Is Today
description: By now, Latrell Sprewell should be in jail for assault or out on bail. And we should be celebrating him as a martyr to the new SportsWorld order in which the modern athlete is trapped in the post-modern shoe store. P. J. Carlesimo should be shipped off to a sensitivity spa and the owner of the Golden State Warriors should be suspended for a year for having hired him in the first place. The commissioner of the National Basketball Association, the bulletproof David Stern, should be our next President.

title: The Population Explosion Is Over
description: What seems to worry Wattenberg most are the demographic changes that must inevitably accompany reducing population growth: an older population and a higher proportion of single people and an end to the chain-letter economics that he has promoted over the years. (Existing businesses tend to do better when their potential customer base grows. ... Try building new houses in a depopulating country.)

title: Broadway's Neo-Rat Pack Finds the Neo-China Club
description: THE SETTING: It was a notorious hangout for strippers, a place where members of New York sports teams could drink (and pick up the scantly clad). It got a reputation as a rock club where David Bowie or Iggy Pop might jam. Parties were rowdy, fights broke out and neighbors of the China Club, at Broadway and 75th Street complained. So Danny Fried, the owner of the club, moved it downtown to 268 West 47th Street, at Eighth Avenue, cleaning up the club's act, so to speak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, ADOLPH B. (ED)
description: HOROWITZ-Adolph B. (Ed). Of Seminole, FL. Formerly of Merrick. On Sunday, December 7, 1997 at age 89. Devoted husband of the late Kathryn. Founding partner of the law firm of Goldman, Horowitz and Cherno of Mineola. Former Exalted Ruler of Freeport Elks. Quiet benefactor to many. Survived by a niece Sheila Horowitz Cohen of Freeport.

title: The Capitalist; Heartless Donors
description: Earlier this month george Soros announced his plans to give four and a half million of his own dollars to the Robin Hood Foundation, a charity created to help the poor of New York City by Soros's fellow Wall Street speculator Paul Tudor Jones. It was a good thing to do. It was also a trendy thing to do, but Soros can be forgiven that. He has more or less created the trend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRICH, MAX H.
description: KRICH-Max H. On December 13, 1997. Devoted husband of the late Ruth Weil Krich. Loving father of Edith K. Comins of Briarcliff Manor, NY, and Claire Hooton of East Hampton, NY. He is also survived by four grandsons and five greatgrandchildren. Interment private.

title: Cold Snap
description: This winter's best antifreeze is an opulent wardrobe of creamy wool and cashmere accessorized with fur.

title: The Population Explosion Is Over
description: After arguing for years that societies have little trouble adjusting to rapidly growing populations, Ben J. Wattenberg is worrying that aging populations and slower growth are obstacles to human well-being (''The Population Explosure Is Over,'' Nov. 23). What delicious irony!

title: Film on TV Showing Abortion Criticized
description: IT is late at night. You finally have the remote control all to yourself. You are happily channel surfing when an image of a bloody lump appears, along with an announcement that it is someone's baby, after an abortion.

title: Gilmour Scores a Quick Goal in His Return to Toronto
description: The deposed prince of Maple Leaf Gardens returned tonight.

title: Venezuelans Confronting Democracy's Dire State
description: The betrayed hero of this nation's birth gazes up from his prison bed, pondered by the children of his revolution. Here, where people speak openly of a crisis of democracy, a painting of Sebastian Francisco de Miranda has become an ink blot revealing shadows of their own disillusionment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASSLER, SEY
description: CHASSLER-Sey. December 11, 1997. Wonderful husband of Natalie, loving father of Joseph, Philip and Deborah. Caring father-in-law of David Lucal and Louise Cody. Adored grandfather of Zach, Nora, Ben, Daniel and Hannah. Devoted twin brother of Vivienne Schwartz. Good friend and mentor to many, he was so loving and so loved. Services Sunday at 11:15 A.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in Sey's memory may be made to the Child Care Action Campaign. The family will be sitting Shiva 20 Sutton Place South through Wednesday.

title: Persian Gulf; Iran's Venture in Image Rehab
description: IT was a kind of coming-out party, with all eyes focused on Iran as it stepped forward after nearly two decades mostly shrouded from world view. What guests glimpsed at an international Islamic conference here was in some ways infuriatingly contradictory: a poised, gracious Iran eager to leave a good impression, but one also still burning with old resentments.

description: Cold Blood

title: Town-Building Is No Mickey Mouse Operation
description: The sun was barely up over the brand-new town of Celebration, Fla., and the Rotarians had gathered in the clubhouse at the golf course for their weekly breakfast meeting. I'd come fully expecting to meet a bunch of white guys in polo shirts who'd remind me of my father, and there were quite enough of them. And yet right there across the table sat several other Celebration Rotarians who, in age and outlook and appearance, reminded me a whole lot more of, well, me.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCAVOY, ALFRED F.
description: McAVOY-Alfred F. How I miss you. Love and miss you every moment. Charlotte and Janis

title: PULSE ; Blow-Dry and Run
description: Thanks to women like Julia Roberts and Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy, the hair look of the moment is straight and sleek. Now, fashionable women have figured out the best way to achieve the look: by heading to salons for so-called blow-outs, or professional blow-dries. The practice is so popular among women on the go that Frederic Fekkai's Beaute de Provence salon, 15 East 57th Street, is offering six blow-dries for the price of five: $225 to $325, depending on hair length. ''For special events, it's nice to have your hair sleek and under control,'' said Lora Phillips, an associate stylist at Elle magazine, who splurged on a package. ''I could never get those same results at home.''

title: Buenos Aires
description: To the Editor: The writer of ''What's Doing in Buenos Aires'' has had limited exposure walking on streets there. We were there for three weeks without jewelry and purse and were harassed day and night.

title: Jane A. Steinberg, Richard Wagman
description: Jane Ann Steinberg and Richard Wagman were married last evening at the Plaza in New York. Dr. Michael Shmidman, the rabbi of Congregation Orach Chaim in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: High-Fives: The Latest Hand Sign Raises the Roof
description: NO one seems to know precisely when or where it began. But few self-styled arbiters of what passes for cool would dispute that the gesture for ''raise the roof'' -- a celebratory pumping of the hands with palms up and elbows out -- was born for millions of Americans this summer when a new television talk show adopted it.

title: Author of 'Love Story' Disputes a Gore Story
description: Erich Segal, author of the weeper ''Love Story,'' said today that only the emotional family baggage of the romantic hero in his novel was inspired by a young Al Gore.

title: December 7-13; Closer Look at a Jupiter Moon
description: For the last two years, the Galileo spacecraft has been orbiting Jupiter, weaving among the planet's four large moons: Io, Europa, Ganymede and Callisto. Photographs and other data reveal them to be surprisingly disparate worlds, but none is more fascinating to scientists than Europa. Though covered with ice, it appears to have two essential conditions for life: heat and liquid water.

title: Self-Remade Man
description: George Bush

title: Shattering The Age Mystique
description: Sure, older married women are continuing to work after their husbands retire. They took jobs later and are not done yet. But that is a passing phenomenon, Betty Friedan says, and really off the point. A decade or two from now, a much healthier phenomenon will kick in, she hopes. Older men and women will both skip retirement, which in Ms. Friedan's vision will become passe.

description: Mary Anne Taylor and William Dickerman Vogel 2d were married last evening at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Right Rev. Craig B. Anderson, the rector of St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., and the former president and dean of the General Theological Seminary in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: Our Towns; 24 Detectives In Search Of a Mission
description: FORTY-THREE years with the New Jersey Detective Agency and Matthew Donohue, 74, is still sleuthing, crisscrossing the state in his Tempo, sniffing out fraud cases, going undercover, too. ''I've been in some rough situations,'' he said, back home after driving to Metuchen and back, about an hour, to serve a subpoena in a civil case. ''Very rough.''

title: Ethnicity and Disney: It's a Whole New Myth
description: IN JULIE TAYMOR'S TRIUMPHANT Broadway reinterpretation of the Walt Disney Company's ''Lion King,'' the movie's shamanesque baboon, Rafiki, is transmuted into a Zulu-chanting priestess, an African griot-storyteller, hooting and hollering, grunting knowingly and guiding the young lion Simba to his destiny. In the show, Rafiki is thrust to the story's center, just as the generic African background of the animated feature film is thrust into the foreground by Ms. Taymor, with muscular dance and music, ritualistic images and carnivalesque ensemble pieces.

title: It's a Doll's Life In New Hampshire
description: The Strawbery Banke Museum in Portsmouth, N.H., is inviting young owners of five American Girl dolls to bring their dolls -- Felicity, Addy, Kirsten, Samantha and Molly -- to special Christmas openings of a few houses in the historic village this month. The dolls, products of Pleasant Company in Middleton, Wis., come with a set of historical-fiction paperbacks about girls' lives in Colonial times, on the frontier, after the Civil War, in Victorian times and during World War II.

title: Getting Down With the Subway Sage
description: SOME days, my Metrocard is a subscription to the symphony, a pass to an amusement park, an invitation to be dazzled. This is because the subway sage, Stan Fischler, took me on a ride through the system two years ago that opened my mind, eyes and ears to the sensual joys underground.

description: It is a chronic lament of life on the Upper West Side: Why doesn't the neighborhood have truly great restaurants? After all, many West Siders appreciate good food; they love their Zabar's and their Citarella.

title: Ideas & Trends; One Casualty of the Women's Movement: Feminism
description: IF time has won anything for feminism, it appears to be ingratitude. Three quarters of the women who responded to a recent CBS News poll said that the status of women had improved in the last 25 years, but fewer and fewer women want to call themselves feminists. Why?

description: LOCAL efforts to preserve one of the last remaining estates in southern Westchester County have heated up in the last few weeks as negotiations for a possible purchase of the property by New York State moved a step closer to reality.

Memorial service on Saturday, Jan 10 at 2PM at The John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York.

title: Society, Meet 24 Young Women: A Newark Cotillion
description: This is debutante season, the time of year when young women from the right families are presented to society in grand ballrooms in big cities. Add Newark to the list of cities, as 24 high school juniors and seniors made their debut, not in a ballroom but at Prudential Hall at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. And these weren't so much the right families as the right debutantes. The sponsors of the Emerald and Ivory Debutante Cotillion, the Essex County chapter of Links, a service organization made up of professional women, predominantly black, chose the participants a year ago. Links contacted high school principals, who along with guidance counselors, decided which girls would be given applications. In the year leading to the event, the debutantes took part in such community activities as reading to children in library programs and helping out with a health fair. They also attended workshops on college admission, financial planning, public speaking, teen-age health issues and the ''social graces.''

title: In America; The Success Taboo
description: Somehow over the past two or three decades a lot of black kids absorbed the message that academic achievement was something to be shunned. Excellence in sports or the various entertainment fields was one thing, a good thing, but high marks and academic honors were something else. Academic achievement, according to this mind-bogglingly destructive way of thinking, was a white thing, and thus in some sense contemptible. The tragic result has been that in many schools across the country black kids who apply themselves to their studies are often ridiculed and at times ostracized.

description: A YEAR ago Linda and Russell Gee sold the roomy home in suburban Newton where they raised their two children and bought a Victorian house on a marginal block dense with housing in Cambridge.

title: Mind if I Read?
description: To the Editor: I was recently a captive audience on a three-hour domestic flight on American Airlines, during which a lawyer spent the entire time on the phone reviewing legal documents line by line. I could not concentrate on my reading and was forced to listen to him.

title: Miracle on the Remote: Tales of Triumph
description: WITH FAMILIES SCATTERED across hundreds and thousands of miles, with divorce and remarriage and joint custody rampant, watching a classic Christmas movie may be the most unchanging holiday tradition left. No matter what happens in the real world, Jimmy Stewart and Donna Reed will go on glowing monogamously in ''It's a Wonderful Life.'' Little Natalie Wood will go on being the skeptical innocent in ''Miracle on 34th Street.'' Alastair Sim will still quake with fear before the last spirit in the 1951 British version of ''A Christmas Carol.'' And Bing Crosby will still sing ''White Christmas'' beside the fireplace in ''Holiday Inn.'' And as usual, they'll be turning up on the schedule again and again (but ''It's a Wonderful Life'' is now only on NBC). Even the plots have a reassuring sameness, as this guide suggests. ANITA GATES

title: Modest Start For Options On Funds
description: MUTUAL fund investors had new options, literally, to consider last week, as Lipper Analytical Services and Salomon Brothers introduced option contracts on open-end mutual funds for the first time on Monday.

This year the school, at 133 West 21st Street in Manhattan, received nearly 100 Web-site entries from all over the world for its annual on-line exhibition of computer art. But in 1995, when web sites were first solicited, barely 20 applied and the deadline had to be extended.

title: The Neediest Cases; When Lavish Meals Are a Dream and Sustenance Is a Struggle
description: Gustine Wilkins is a wily hunter. Armed with a wad of coupons and a rickety shopping cart, she can turn $80 in food stamps into three weeks' worth of groceries. Her quarry is elusive and it takes an entire day to chase down the bargains, but Ms. Wilkins, 32, is motivated by a single, all-consuming objective: ''to stretch every dollar so my son won't go hungry.''

title: Q&A;: Michelle Joy Levine; Exploring the Motives for Overeating
description: AS a child, Michelle Joy Levine observed how obesity had shaped her mother's life. Visibly ashamed of her figure, her mother declined most social invitations and suffered from weight-related illnesses like high blood pressure. Growing up around her mother and her overweight siblings, Ms. Levine often wondered why her family didn't lose weight, despite the burdens they experienced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKER, MATHILDE
description: DRUCKER-Mathilde. Died November 11, Fort Lauderdale, FL. Beloved widow of Joseph, devoted mother to Mitzi and Sterling Jonas of NY, John and Jacquie Drucker of Atlanta, cherished grandmother of Donna, Glenn and Andrew and great-grandmother of Morgan and Hayley Goldberg. The memories of your musicianship, intelligence, wisdom and strength sustain us. Contributions to the Fort Lauderdale Symphony or the Jewish Federation of Broward County.

title: Bikers Find the Inner Child
description: Sometimes big boys do cry. So it was hard to tell if Anthony Brounelli was blubbering last Sunday morning because he loves children so much or because he had had one too many bourbons or because his Harley wouldn't start before the Toys for Tots motorcycle rally in Richmond Hill, which organizers said drew 10,000 bikers, each with a toy for a handicapped child.

title: December 7-13; New Fees for Pay Phones
description: People who call toll-free numbers from pay phones soon may have trouble getting a dial tone. Some owners of ''800'' telephone numbers are shutting access to their lines from pay phones rather than pay a new fee of 28.4 cents to pay-phone operators each time their numbers are called.

title: Tar Heels Rise Up, But Not So Easily
description: Princeton's patient approach to basketball may be simple and familiar, but that does not mean it is easy to combat.
