title: Beyond Prayer; Testing Faith in Their Own Hometowns, Congregations Offer Hands-On Help
description: LAST July, the mens' club of the First United Methodist Church in the impoverished Cumberland County town of Port Norris merged with the mens' club of the John Wesley United Methodist Church a few blocks away. One of the first questions the new group examined was how to create a much-needed recreation center for young people.

title: Forest Trails, Mapped on Foot for Hikers
description: THE quietude on Cobble Brook Vista trail in Kent is interrupted only by the click, click, click of a survey wheel passing over hills, a brook, by a 150-year-old sugar maple, and on up through sinuous terrain. Using a pencil attached by string to a clipboard, Al Goodrich, an amateur cartographer, carefully notes all the field information he needs to create a map for hikers: topography, natural features, landmarks and trail direction.

title: Essay; Here Come the Indys
description: My status as Certified Social Pariah has just been confirmed by the White House, which has again stricken my name from the list of invitees to the Clinton media Christmas party. Also disinvited from this taxpayer-supported stroking function is my colleague Maureen Dowd, which leaves her devastated, as she had already beribboned a puppy biscuit for the new First Dog.

title: A Gallery Sampler at the Aldrich
description: THE Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield has always been perched on what is called the cutting edge. The museum's founder, Larry Aldrich, maintained an alternative space in Soho in Manhattan from the late 1970's and into the 80's, and these days several artists featured in the Aldrich's theme shows have turned up in major exhibitions of the latest thing, such as the Whitney Biennial.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column on Nov. 30, about Beekman Place, referred incorrectly to a house visited by Buddy Radische, now the president of the Beekman Place Association, when he was a boy. No. 29, the former William S. Paley house, was never owned by the showman Billy Rose; he lived at No. 33.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mazda 626; A Dash of Spice in the Midsize Stew
description: POOR Mazda. Every model it has introduced in recent years (with the exception of the underpowered, overpriced MPV mini-van) has drawn raves from reviewers. But the financially challenged Japanese auto maker, now controlled by Ford, hasn't been able to make a dent in the sales of competing models from Honda, Nissan and Toyota.

title: Dostoyevsky's City on the Neva
description: RUSSIAN literature really did not exist until -- through a singular act of will, cruelty and imagination -- Peter the Great summoned St. Petersburg, this strange, beautiful city, from the sea. Somehow, by inventing a new city in an old country, Peter created for Russia not just a fortress but also a soul.

title: Asia's Surrender
description: For a decade, Asia's rising wealth has given the region's leaders the confidence to shrug off American demands that Wall Street powerhouses, huge foreign banks and insurance companies be granted full access to their markets.

title: The Population Explosion Is Over
description: Somewhere deep in Wattenberg's missive is a monumental story of vision and hope that he has wrongly framed as a jeremiad.

title: Preservation Pays, A Rutgers Study Finds . . .
description: The $60 million raised in the past 10 years through three bond issues for preservation of historic sites has generated many times that amount of money and created more jobs than new construction projects costing the same amount of money would have, according to a study by the Center for Urban Policy of Rutgers University.

title: A New, New 'Boris': Applying Makeup To a Genius's Flaws
description: WHEN THE Metropolitan Opera revives Modest Mussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov'' on Friday evening under the baton of Valery Gergiyev, it will be introducing a new orchestration by Igor Buketoff to supersede the composer's original scoring, reinstated at the Met with a great deal of ''authentistic'' fanfare under Thomas Schippers in 1973. Why the backsliding? Is it backsliding? We are probably in for a new installment of an endless debate.

title: Christmas Music: Traditional and New
description: WHILE Handel's ''Messiah'' dominates the holiday music scene -- the classic oratorio will be heard in at least 12 concerts this week -- there are a few events that go beyond tradition.

description: THE recently opened Branson in Oceanside may be the only barbecue restaurant in the world with a pastry chef.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Rock of Ages

title: A Fairy Tale, but Hold the Gingerbread
description: ABUSIVE mothers. Alcoholic fathers. Abandoned children. Topics for this week's ''Oprah'' show? While certainly the stuff of today's headlines, these themes are also at the hear of ''Hansel and Gretel,'' the Grimm Brothers' fairy tale and the inspiration for Engelbert Humperdinck's opera of the same name.

title: Will GTE, Long Seen as the Tortoise, Win the Race?
description: ALTHOUGH the GTE Corporation made a bold, if unsuccessful, bid for MCI Communications earlier this fall, Wall Street has remained largely unimpressed by the company. So far this year, GTE shares have risen just 8.1 percent, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has surged 28.7 percent.

description: Brace yourself for several years' worth of bad puns about hot air. The Clinton Administration took up a Herculean political task by embracing a treaty negotiated in Kyoto, Japan, to cut emissions that lead to global warming.

title: A Call to Thin The Ranks of Hunters
description: In response to ''Ravaging Deer Herd Leads to Fences and Loss of Forests'' [Nov. 9]: Doesn't it seem odd that in 1942 there were only about 500,000 white-tailed deer in the United States and that now there are an estimated 27 million?

title: An Old Tale Of Swindle Resurfaces In Bosnia
description: The secret weapon that cost the Bosnian Serbs $6 million in cash was handed over by somber men in a clandestine meeting on a windswept bridge in the closing months of the Bosnian war two years ago. In return, they were passed a brass container the size of a suitcase that they were told contained a football-sized nuclear weapon, or so the story goes.

title: Crime
description: The saddest crimes in Archer Mayor's rawboned mysteries set in Vermont are the slow deaths of those hard-working mill towns that were once the backbone of the industrial Northeast. Its factories closed and its spirit broken, the worn-out specimen that Mayor mourns so eloquently in BELLOWS FALLS (Mysterious Press/Warner, $22) has already deteriorated into a welfare town plagued by crime and burdened with social problems. But a reclamation movement is also afoot in this picturesque village, so the last thing it needs now is a new drug merchant -- or a sex scandal in the already demoralized Police Department.

title: She's Wound Up in Her Career, but He's Ready to Wind Down
description: AFTER a career as a salesman, Ruth Cambron's husband retired, and she thought she might, too. She took a leave from her job as a health care specialist in California, and the couple traveled on cruise ships. ''That convinced me not to retire,'' Mrs. Cambron said. ''I did not want to feel useless.'' She also wanted to build her pension. And 12 years later, at 73, she still draws a paycheck -- a stalwart in the growing ranks of older women who continue to work after their husbands stop.

description: Urban Oracles By Mayra Santos-Febres. Lumen Editions, paper, $15.95.

description: New Jerseyans have already seen their banks and supermarkets consolidated under fewer and fewer corporate owners, and in recent months the same trend has affected several of the state's most prominent daily newspapers.

title: Here a 'Nutcracker,' There a 'Nutcracker'
description: TODAY'S concert calendar is about as crowded as it gets. At noon at the Palace Theater in Stamford, local children will dance along with major stars of the New York City Ballet and the American Ballet Theater in the George Balanchine production of Tchaikovsky's ''Nutcracker.'' The New Haven Ballet's ''Nutcracker'' is at 1:30 in the Paul Mellon Arts Center in Wallingford, and at 3 o'clock the Danbury Music Center's ''Nutcracker'' can be seen at the high school.

title: Feasting on Six Decades of the Philharmonic's Past

But the most venerable ensembles may have the last laugh, for as the labels fret over consumers' appetite for reissues and indifference to new recordings, the orchestras find themselves sitting on an eminently marketable resource: their broadcast archives, troves of concert recordings with fabled conductors and soloists.

description: ''TONY, ARE THEY GOING to pour the orchestra Thursday?'' Peter H. Kofman asked one morning last February, the edge in his voice suggesting that there was only one answer he wanted to hear.

description: Doctors at the University of Minnesota plan to begin tests this summer of a new form of gene therapy in people with leukemia.

title: 'God Created Me To Be a Slave'
description: The letters (Nov. 23) responding to Elinor Burkett's article 'God Created Me to Be a Slave' reminded me of when I used to work in Mauritania in the early 1980's and the Government tried to abolish slavery by changing the name by which slaves were called. In a typically Orwellian fashion, slaves were suddenly called ''gens libres,'' or free men, in all Government directives. Like a good little Government functionary, I, too, went around using the term gens libres, in the hope that by using the term one could make the ugliness go away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, JOHN F.
description: WHITE-John F. Age 82, of Sayville, LI, on December 11, 1997. Survived by his wife Jeanne H. White; his daughters Susan Callahan, Janet Foster and Rosemary White-Trout; his sisters Jeanne Ehrhardt, Catherine Thom and Nancy Meyer and ten grandchildren. Reposing at Raynor & D'Andrea Funeral Home, 245 Montauk Highway, West Sayville on Sunday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30PM. Funeral mass Monday 10:30 A.M., at Cenacle Chapel, 310 Cenacle Road, Lake Ronkonkoma. Interment in Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Coram. Memorials may be sent to Cenacle of St. Regis or to Brookhaven Memorial Hospital.

title: 4 Top Retailers Are Linked to 2 Factories Said to Be Sweatshops
description: Federal investigators have linked four of the nation's leading retailers -- Wal-Mart, Kmart, Nordstrom and the Limited -- to two Chinatown clothing factories the Government said were sweatshops that had flagrantly violated minimum-wage and overtime laws.

title: ART REVIEW ; One Venerated Figure in a Multitude of Images
description: NO other country has extolled and depended on the Virgin Mary as much as Portugal. Her role has grown and deepened over the centuries, and her many aspects are illuminated in ''Crowning Glory: Images of the Virgin in the Arts of Portugal,'' a quietly epic show at the Newark Museum. In the course of this exhibition of 80 works from six centuries, all lent by collections in Portugal, the Virgin is liberated from the confines of doctrine in favor of both her human and her regal sides. She may remain wrapped in mystery, but, movingly, she is also never out of reach.

title: A Full (and Spicy) Menu From Vietnam
description: SINCE its 1986 opening, La Maison Indochine in Greenwich has demonstrated amazing staying power for a restaurant in an upstairs location. And one that despite having a Greenwich Avenue address, has as its only entrance one from a parking lot in the rear of the building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ALFRED
description: COHEN-Alfred. Of Scarsdale, NY, and Pompano Beach, Fla. On December 6, 1997. Born September 15, 1911 in NYC, the first born of Mary and Irving Cohen, beloved husband of Yvette Marcus and the late Irma Doris, loving father of Edward and Michael, grandfather of Ian, and brother of Dr. Leonard Cohen; dearly beloved by the Coopers, Freedmans, and all others who knew him; retired former Chairman of the Board and President of Metal Purchasing Company, Inc., a giant in the tin mill steel service center industry, and a strong supporter of the Jack Martin Fund and Larchmont Temple.

title: Making the Extraordinary Out of Practically Nothing
description: THE second biennial competition at the Silvermine Guild galleries in New Canaan, which can be seen through Dec. 24, has stimulated a dialogue. The first year, Kate Carmel, senior curator at the American Craft Museum in Manhattan was juror. This year, Kenneth Botnick, director of the Penland School of Crafts in Penland, N.C., was selected as juror.

title: Scenes from the Malls: Megastores and Mini-Bazaars

title: The Population Explosion Is Over
description: Analysts and policymakers in the industrialized North tend to see reduction of populations in the North as a detriment to global economic prosperity and political democracy. They are increasingly calling for pronatalist policies in the North while at the same time continuing to support strong anti-natalist policies for the poor countries in the South.

title: That's Pronounced Chitter-lings. Not Chitluns.
description: Richard Gregory has always had a thick Southern accent, but when his own wife chided, ''You're smarter than you sound,'' he decided to act. Gregory, a 58-year-old real-estate broker from Memphis, enrolled in ''Developing Your Speaking Voice,'' a night class at the University of Memphis, where adults learn, among other things, how to neutralize their drawls and y'alls. The instructor, Michael Hall (author of ''Twelve Secrets of a Great Voice''), works on eliminating Southernisms (''fixin' to,'' ''ain't got no'') and developing a stronger, clearer, more Midwestern speaking voice. The course, created in 1995, has been so popular that this year two additional classes have been added. Here's a look.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, JEAN WARE
description: BLAKE-Jean Ware. May 1, 1906December 10, 1997. Devoted mother of James King Hoyt and the late Margaret Hoyt Schifter. Beloved grandmother of Lisa Greenberg, Timothy Schifter, Mark Hoyt, Carol Henderson and Grier Hoyt. Great grandmother of Luke, Emma, Julia, Benjamin, Storey, Will and Sophie. Memorial service on Tuesday, December 16 at 2:30PM, First Presbyterian Church of Stamford, CT. Contributions may be made to Bread for the World, 802 Rhode Island Ave N.E., Washington, DC 20018 or First Presbyterian Church of Stamford, 1101 Bedford St, Stamford, CT 06905.

title: O Little Town of Litigation . . .
description: TWELVE days till Christmas, and the Baby Jesus is still in storage. Ditto for the Wise Men, Santa Claus, Frosty the Snowman, the Hanukkah menorah and the various other icons, religious and secular, that Jersey City assembles each year for its Christmas display in front of City Hall.

title: The View From/Ardsley ; Artist Sketches Scenes In Buttercream on Cakes
description: SURROUNDED by the tools of her trade in a sun-dappled workroom, with the muffled traffic of Route 9A in the background, an artist, Liv Hansen, applied the finishing touches to a miniature Christmas tableau that Currier & Ives would have envied, bringing to finely detailed life colorful Christmas stockings, vivid flames in a fireplace, holiday greenery, a homespun rag rug and even Santa's half-eaten cookie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSBARD, HELENE
description: GROSBARD - Helene. Beloved wife of the late Jack Grosbard. Devoted mother of Richard, Michael and Robert Grosbard. Loving grandmother of Erin, Joshua, Lee, Remy, Adam and Rita. Devoted sister to Carola Bien and Bronek Janiszewski. An ardent supporter of The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum.

title: Richness of Chocolate Rounds Off a Meal
description: OVER the holidays, nothing rounds off a good meal better than chocolate. A plate of macaroons laced with coconut and chocolate chunks or a sliver of dark chocolate cake topped with toasted pecans are my idea of desserts to get into the spirit of things. Only Scrooge would serve fruit and plain yogurt.

title: A Window of Opportunity
description: IT was an early December morning, still dark. Nevertheless they waited, more than 100 strong, funny hats on their heads and posters in their hands. Many of them had come from all over the country to see and be seen, and as the sun rose over midtown they were rewarded at last.

title: Stores Wait For That Last-Minute Rush to Buy
description: AT the Williams-Sonoma store in White Plains recently, free samples of gourmet herb and Parmesan pasta disappeared by midafternoon -- scooped up by eager Christmas shoppers with hearty appetites. Most of the pricey merchandise for sale, however, remained on the shelves, as it did in other stores at The Westchester mall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, JOSEPH
description: WOLF-Joseph. On Dec. 11, at age 85. Beloved husband of the late Sally Wolf. Loving father of Drs. Evelyn and Michael Rokito, Gilda and Richard Schwartz. Cherished grandfather of Dr. Andrew and Susan Rokito, Dr. Steven and Jodi Rokito, Melissa and Robert Unikel, Penny and Edward Salina, Marni and Samuel Gaer. Devoted greatgrandfather of Ariel, Shelby, Lindsay, Shane and Elexa. Renowned philanthropist and benefactor. President of J&W Newsprinters, Gerry Press and International Newspapers. Recipient of Associated Health Foundation and Harry Hirshfeld awards. Renowned Pythian and supporter of many temples and the State of Israel.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A scenery-steeped puzzle, a haunting western, a stage classic and a political thriller form an inviting cluster of vintage films on television this week.

title: For Fancy Titles, Press 1
description: You're calling a company, trying to obtain information about your account, and the operator tells you to wait for your ''personal care representative.'' Or you're trying to complain about that new gizmo you just bought, and you're put on hold for ''the chairman's office.'' Companies come up with all kinds of titles, many of them confusing, for the people you need to reach. What are these labels, and what do these workers really do? Each is the other's straight man in a thorny relationship set up by Frank's expression of thanks: a week with the beautiful if somewhat battered Glory (Uma Thurman), ''the gift that keeps on giving,'' as bittersweet as the film's unexpectedly soft heart -- SATURDAY at 6 P.M. on USA.

I don't care where the facts lead, because I'm going to follow them as far as and wherever they go.''

She escaped the Nazis by emigrating to Palestine in 1938. There she worked for the British forces as an ambulance driver stationed in Alexandria, Egypt. She was involved in the El Alamein campaign and received two battle stars. She was also an active member of the Irgun. After Israeli independence, she moved to New York where she became a fashion designer. She married Paul Goldman and raised three boys, Ross of Maplewood, NJ, Peter of Seattle, WA, and Kenny of Short Hills, NJ. A skier, bridge master, athlete, and great Mom, Lilli married Robert Winnerman in 1983. She had with Bob among the most fun and adventurous years of her life. Lilli's sense of adventure and thirst for life was an inspiration to all. Her spirit will live onwards in her six grandchildren, Hannah, Elliot, Sam, Addis, Claire and Gus. Services December 16, at 11:30 AM, at Bernheim, Apter, Goldsticker Funeral Home, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, NJ. Between 1978 and 1986 the Giannellis were residents of Bronxville, New York. Mr. Giannelli was a Partner of John T. Brady Construction Corporation in NYC until his retirement in 1973. He was a concerned citizen who contributed to many worthy causes hoping to make the world a better place for all. Through his example of love and devoted involvement with his family he has left a profound legacy. William was preceded in death by his loving wife of 55 years, Marie, on February 3, 1988. He is survived by his daughters, Mrs. Raymond Martin (Marilyn) of Boca Raton, FL and Mrs. Richard Schineller (Eileen) of Bronxville, NY and his 12 beloved grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Joseph's Catholic Church, Bronxville, NY on Wednesday, December 17 at 10:00 AM, followed by burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. A memorial Mass will be held in Boca Raton at St. Joan of Arc Church at a later date for friends and family. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURNEN, EDWARD C., JR., M.D.
description: CURNEN-Edward C., Jr., M.D. The Department of Pediatrics of the Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and the Alumni Association of Babies & Children's Hospital of New York pay tribute to their esteemed and beloved colleague who died on December 1, 1997, at 88 years of age in Woodbridge, CT. After serving as the first chairman of Pediatrics at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, Dr. Curnen joined the faculty at Columbia in 1960 as Carpentier Professor of Pediatrics and Chairman of the Department in which post he served until 1970. In addition to his research in infectious diseases, Dr. Curnen was a consummate pediatrician who manifested in his teaching and the care of children infinite wisdom, sensitivity and grace. After his retirement in 1974, the Edward C. Curnen, Jr., Award was established by his colleagues to be presented annually at the Alumni Association meeting to honor that house officer who best exemplified the ideas of humane and compassionate care that Dr. Curnen so manifestly displayed during his long distinguished career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTT, DAVID
description: OTT-David. Vice President, Ambulatory Services, Mount Sinai Hospital. The staff of the Adolescent Health Center expresses deep sorrow at the passing of our friend and colleague, David Ott. David was a visionary leader dedicated to assuring community access to high quality, comprehensive ambulatory health services for New York's poor adolescents. He challenged us to design creative and innovative new approaches, and supported our efforts to serve inner city teens in a holistic and caring manner. He brought an active and keen intellect to the challenges that our patient population can make to traditional health services. He also brought a wry and gentle humor. Working with him was always stimulating, challenging and enjoyable. David Ott was a very special person. We will miss him greatly. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Carol and his children Haley and Leslie. Angela Diaz Ken Peake Susan Grossman and the staff of the Mt. Sinai Adolescent Health Center

title: REYNOLDS METALS IN TALKS WITH BALL ON CAN BUSINESS
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its aluminum can business, which has sales of $1 billion a year, to the Ball Corporation as part of a plan to pay down debt and increase its share price. The Richmond-based company said it would keep its packaging and consumer unit, the maker of Reynolds Wrap aluminum foil, which it had considered selling with the can unit. The can unit, which makes 18 million aluminum cans a year, could fetch as much as $1.25 billion, analysts have said. Reynolds is the second-largest United States aluminum producer behind Alcoa. Reynolds's shares rose $2.0625, to $60.125, and Ball's shares rose 12.5 cents, to $37.25.

Pacific Scientific rose $6.5625, to $22, while Kollmorgen rose $1.625, to $18.50. The offer was reported in The Wall Street Journal. Kollmorgen, of Waltham, Mass., makes generators, tachometers and infrared-imaging systems. Pacific Scientific, of Newport Beach, Calif., makes motors and generators, electronic ballasts, fire-detection equipment and flight-control components.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENZER, MILTON
description: TENZER-Milton, 78, of West End, New Jersey, left this life on December 13, 1997. Sailing from Poland as a toddler, he grew up in Island Park, NY. Mr. Tenzer was a graduate of Cooper Union in electrical engineering. His career in research and development of electronic and telecommunications equipment spanned transatlantic cables, satellite communications, and fiber optics. Mr. Tenzer worked for the US Government as a civilian in the Army Signal Corps for over 30 years, then became vice-president for General Cable. He was an adjunct professor at Monmouth University, member of B'nai Brith, and active congregant of Temple Beth Miriam. Predeceased by his wife of over fifty years, Sophie Posner Tenzer. Mr. Tenzer will be deeply missed by his son, Stuart Tenzer, and brother Albert Tenzer (both of Pacific Palisades, CA); his daughters, Judith Tenzer Benn (of Ocean, NJ) and Ruth Tenzer Feldman (of Bethesda, MD); six grandsons; and loving companion, Helen Gallant (of Stockbridge, MA); as well as other relatives and friends. Services will be held on Wednesday, December 17, at 1:30 at Temple Beth Miriam, Elberon, New Jersey. title: Dance Fever No Matter the Message
description: When the Wailers began in 1961, they included Bob Marley, Peter Tosh, Junior Braithwaite and Neville O'Riley Livingston, who renamed himself Bunny Wailer. Mr. Braithwaite left the group in 1965; Marley and Tosh died in the 1980's. That leaves Bunny Wailer, who quit the Wailers in 1973, as the sole claimant to the Wailers' legacy. At the Beacon Theater on Sunday night, he treated that legacy as three elements: dance music, songs of liberation and Rastafarian gospel music, none entirely separate from the others. No matter what the message was, it arrived with an ebullient groove.

description: ON Thursday, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will meet, and short of Jupiter aligning with Mars, you can bet on its endorsing Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to use a large budget surplus for new discount passes on the city's subways and buses.

title: A Different Line From Iran
description: There are two power centers in Iran. One is the Government, chosen by voters and open to improved relations with the United States. The other is the clerical establishment, self-appointed and virulently anti-American. President Clinton was right yesterday to welcome President Mohammed Khatami's encouraging call for a dialogue with Washington, but the White House should not mistake the overture as a sign that Iran's powerful clerics have endorsed a more peaceful foreign policy. The journey back to normal relations with Iran, if it unfolds at all, will be slow and circuitous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBIN, DOROTHY
description: DUBIN-Dorothy. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Ellen, Robert and Nancy. Loving sister of Irving and Barbara Scharf. Cherished grandmother of Adam and Jonathan. Services were held.

title: 2 Sides Sum Up Cases In Terry Nichols Trial
description: Even though he was safely at home when the Oklahoma City Federal Building was blown up, Terry L. Nichols was an eager participant in its destruction, a Federal prosecutor said today in closing arguments in Mr. Nichols's trial.

title: PENTAGON IS URGED TO SEPARATE SEXES
description: A special panel appointed by Defense Secretary William S. Cohen has recommended that the Army, Navy and Air Force significantly roll back the integration of men and women in basic and advanced training, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOOKER, JANET ANNENBERG
description: HOOKER-Janet Annenberg. Died December 13, 1997. The widow of James Stewart Hooker, she is survived by her sons, Donald P. Kahn (Jeanne) and Gilbert S. Kahn, her brother, the Hon. Walter H. Annenberg and two sisters, Enid A. Haupt and Evelyn A. Hall. She is also survived by five grandchildren, Donald P. Kahn, Jr., Douglas T. Kahn (Dr. Margaret Carter), Steven D. Kahn, Alexandra Kahn (John Graubert) and Julie K. Brown, and five greatgrandchildren, Sophia and Isabel Carter-Kahn, Christina Graubert, Thomas M. Bender and Samuel A. Brown, Jr. She was first married to the late L. Stanley Kahn-a member of the New York Stock Exchange. In 1938 she married investment banker Joseph A. Neff who died in 1969. She was very active in New York Charities-especially the Metropolitan Opera where she donated the Lobby Colonnade in memory of her mother, Mrs. Moses L. Annenberg. In addition, she funded the redecoration of the Blue Room at The White House, and, with her brother and his wife, helped fund projects at both the State Department's Diplomatic Reception Rooms and Blair House. In 1977, Mrs. Hooker gave an historic emerald to the National Gem Collection at the National Museum of Natural History. In 1991 and 1992, she gave additional gems to the collection and was the major donor for the Janet Annenberg Hooker Hall of Geology, Gems and Minerals which opened in September 1997. Mrs. Hooker, a resident of Palm Beach, Florida, also owned a summer home, Fairholme, in Newport, Rhode Island. A Funeral Mass will be held on Thursday, December 18, at 10 AM, at the Church of St. John The Evangelist, 55th Street and First Avenue, New York City. Burial will be private. For more information call Frank E. Campbell, New York City, 212-288-3500.

title: 4 Times Executives Get New Jobs In Advertising and Circulation
description: The New York Times announced several executive changes in its advertising and circulation departments yesterday. The newspaper said the changes, effective Jan. 1, were intended to build on the paper's gains in those areas the last year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about President Clinton's visit to New York included an erroneous report from the White House press office about people who joined him for lunch at Katz's Delicatessen on the Lower East Side. Representative Nydia M. Velazquez, Representative Edolphus Towns and Aida Alvarez, the Small Business Administrator, were not in the group. (Reporters were not admitted to the restaurant.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, PHYLLIS
description: MILLER-Phyllis. On December 14, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Israel, devoted mother of Gail and Neil. Loving sister of Irene Henin, Betty Bilick, Mary Feinstein, Arthur and Arnold Kotick. Cherished grandmother of Alex, Allegra and Sylvie. Caring, full of life, committed activist, devoted family gatherer. Services are on Tuesday at 1:30 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Prosecutor Says French Balk at Seizing War Criminals in Bosnia
description: The chief prosecutor of the war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia complained to officials here today that French peacekeepers in Bosnia had made no moves to arrest indicted war criminals and asked the officials to issue stronger orders quickly.

title: Mets Take Gamble in Draft On a Young Left-Hander
description: The Mets' Steve Phillips called around to other general managers throughout baseball to get their feelings on Hector Mercado, a minor league pitcher eligible for yesterday's Rule 5 draft. Call it scouting for conventional wisdom.

title: Treasury Securities Fall in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday as stocks gained on upbeat news from Korea over the weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, THOMAS L.
description: JACOBS-Thomas L. December 12, 1997. Husband of Dr. Marianne DeNagy Buchenhorner. Services will be held on Wednesday, December 17, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street at 12 noon. Burial will be private.

title: Devils to Face Muzzatti, Not Richter, in the Goal
description: Looking to do anything that could help his team get a victory, Colin Campbell decided yesterday to rest goalie Mike Richter and start Jason Muzzatti tonight when the Rangers play the Devils at the Meadowlands.

title: Soft Sheen aims at women who really like to style their hair.
description: THE leader in the nation's estimated $1.6 billion ethnic hair care market is undertaking the industry's most aggressive product introduction in years with a brand aimed at women who redo their hairdos as often as every day.

title: Thompson Forming Marketing Unit
description: The J. Walter Thompson Worldwide unit of WPP Group is forming an integrated marketing unit in New York, named J. Walter Thompson Total Solutions Group, to oversee operations in fields like direct marketing, new media, loyalty marketing, promotions and ethnic marketing. Michael Graham, 52, chief executive at RTC Direct in Washington, a WPP direct marketing agency, was named to head Thompson Total Solutions as chief executive.

title: Ford Joins in a Global Alliance to Develop Fuel-Cell Auto Engines
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would invest $420 million (United States) in a global alliance with a German auto manufacturer and a Canadian alternative energy company to develop automotive engines and drive trains that produce power more efficiently and cleanly than today's cars.

title: SCOTTS BUYS LEVINGTON HORTICULTURE FOR $78 MILLION
description: The Scotts Company said yesterday that it had bought the closely held Levington Horticulture Ltd. for about $78 million in cash, expanding its product line in Britain. Scotts, based in Marysville, Ohio, the maker of Miracle-Gro fertilizer, said it expected the purchase to begin to add to earnings in its 1998 fiscal year. Levington's 1996 sales were $80 million. Sales at the company, which makes fertilizer for consumer and professional use, have grown 10 percent a year since 1995. Levington's brands, which include Evergreen lawn fertilizers and Tumbleweed pesticides, complement Scotts's products in Britain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORRY, NEIL
description: NORRY-Neil. The Board of Directors, Faculty and Staff of CLALThe National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership mourn the passing of Neil Norry, our esteemed past Chairman and Board member. He was deeply caring and committed to the Jewish community, and his advice and counsel will be greatly missed. CLAL extends deepest sympathy to his devoted wife, Sharon, his children and grandchildren. May they be comforted amoung the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Charles R. Bronfman, Chairman Rabbi Irwin Kula, President Rabbi Irving Greenberg, President Emeritus Donna M. Rosenthal, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Clinton Invites Lawmakers to Bosnia to Promote Longer U.S. Role
description: President Clinton is inviting Congressional leaders to join him on a Christmas visit to Bosnia in an effort to build support for a continued American presence there, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Russia Eases by U.S. to Win World Team Championship
description: With a last-round spurt of 4-0 against the Georgian Women's team, Russia won the Fourth World Team Championship, held Oct. 25 through Nov. 2 in Lucerne, Switzerland. That victory, the most one-sided of the 10-team competition, let the Russians slip past the Americans, who scored 23 points for second place to the Russians' 23 1/2.

title: Dozens Forced to Flee Fire in Dobbs Ferry
description: A fire that broke out on the top floor of a five-story apartment complex in Dobbs Ferry last night forced more than 60 families to spend the night away from their homes, the police said.

title: Speed Skater Gives Fear a Long Holiday
description: Overnight, a new type of skate had changed speed skating the way the jump shot had revolutionized basketball and the fiberglass pole had altered pole vaulting.

title: Trial Ordered in Case of Columbia Instructor Who Claims Bias
description: A three-judge Federal appeals court panel reversed a lower court on Friday and ordered a jury trial into charges that Columbia University discriminated against an instructor because he was not of Hispanic descent.

title: In Honor of a Disk Jockey Who Does It His Way
description: The 22d in a long line of heroes, cult favorites and ingenues at the extravagant bash that filled the Bottom Line on Friday night had only a small bone to pick with the honored guest. ''There's just one thing wrong with this evening,'' said the noted songwriter Jimmy Webb to Vin Scelsa, New York's longest-surviving free-form disk jockey, before beginning an evocative solo piano version of ''Galveston.'' ''It ain't on the radio!''

title: The Strum That Appeals To an Elite
description: One of New York's gifts to rock is a simple guitar strum that's as unmistakable as a native New Yorker's walk: casual but assertive, offhanded yet wary, unhurried but determined. It spans New York rock from the Velvet Underground in the 1960's through Television in the 1970's and Sonic Youth since the 1980's. And true to New York elitism, it has always gone with music that appeals to a minority, the bohemian and collegiate crowd. Now, the New York strum drives bands like Luna, which performed on Friday night at Irving Plaza. Luna carries its New York heritage in songs that conceal their chutzpah with understatement, yet can surge into a tumult of guitars.

title: Officials Acquitted in Bribe Case
description: A Federal court jury today acquitted two managers of the world's largest Coca-Cola bottling company who had been charged with bribing a worker to help undermine a 1994 unionization campaign.

title: Rice Returns, Montana Muses and 49ers Keep Winning
description: The only thing missing from San Francisco's 34-17 victory over the Denver Broncos tonight was a speech from Knute Rockne.

title: Africa's Child Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

Devoted proud and admired grandmother of Michael, Paul and Elizabeth. Adored best friend and mother-in-law of Natalie and Barbara Salmore. We thank her for always being there for us. Services were held at Union Field Hungarian Society Synagogue, Cypress Avenue and Cypress Hill Street, Glendale, New York.

title: A Vaccine That Experts Say Is Effective
description: The vaccine against anthrax is quite effective and would be expected to protect people from the bacterium if it were used in biological warfare, medical experts said yesterday.

title: William F. Knight, 93, Founder Of Orange Juice Plant in Florida
description: William Francis Knight, who established one of the nation's first orange juice processing plants, died on Nov. 24 at his home in Port Charlotte, Fla. He was 93.

title: Women Gain At The Top, But Slightly
description: The percentage of female corporate officers at Fortune 500 companies rose slightly last year to 10.6 percent from 10 percent the previous year, according to a survey by Catalyst, a nonprofit women's research group in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE LEEUW, LEON
description: DE LEEUW-Leon. Beloved husband, father, teacher and friend. Professor at Montclair State University. The world has lost a great artist and a true man of this century.

title: Ross Isn't Stopping Sanders Any Longer
description: It was the 10th game of the season last year, the Detroit Lions were playing a Monday night affair with the Chargers, and Bobby Ross, then San Diego's coach, was getting a first-hand look at the wonder that is Barry Sanders.

title: In Debate, Gay Men Aim to Find Middle Path; Dangerous Illusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Lifts Block On Publicis Bid
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday threw out a preliminary injunction blocking the French advertising agency Publicis S.A. from making a $269.4 million hostile bid for control of its former partner, True North Communications of Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOKSER, LEO
description: BOKSER-Leo. On December 14. Beloved husband of Esther. Dear father of Stephen and Stuart. Loving grandfather of Elyse, Seth, Leigh, Jeffrey and Amy. Brother of Jack and Max. Services today 11 AM, at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 312 Coney Island Avenue at Prospect Park Circle.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about infertility misstated the problem of Nancy Alisberg and her husband, Michael Albano. Ms. Alisberg's eggs had chromosomal anomalies that prevented them from implanting as embryos in her womb, not anomalies that would have caused birth defects.

title: FLUOR SAYS IT MAY SELL EQUIPMENT LEASING UNIT
description: The Fluor Corporation said yesterday that it was considering selling or restructuring its equipment leasing unit as part of a larger review of its construction company's businesses. Fluor said continued ownership of the American Equipment Company was not essential to the activities of its Fluor Daniel unit. The proceeds of any sale or restructuring would be used to repurchase the company's stock if market conditions remained favorable, Fluor said. Fluor, based in Irvine, Calif., said it remained committed to Fluor Daniel's construction, engineering, maintenance, technical services and coal businesses. Its shares rose $1.25, to $38.25.

title: Footlights
description: INSIDE

title: Clinton, Softening Slap at Senate, Names 'Acting' Civil Rights Chief
description: President Clinton today named Bill Lann Lee Acting Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, a calibrated act of defiance against the Republican Senate leadership.

title: Metro Business; Radio Group to Buy Concert Promoters
description: SFX Broadcasting, the New York radio company, said yesterday that it would spend about $240 million to buy four concert promoters.

title: Homemade Bomb Explodes Outside Planet Hollywood
description: A crude bomb exploded early yesterday morning outside the flagship Planet Hollywood restaurant on West 57th Street, and the police are investigating whether it was linked to the bombing of a downtown office building last month, law enforcement officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUNDEL, KATHRYN KEMP
description: ZUNDEL-Kathryn Kemp. Of Edison, New Jersey on December 12, 1997. Devoted wife of Richard R. Zundel. She was a member of the First Presbyterian Church of Metuchen and Metuchen Country Club, and a 1935 graduate of Smith College. Funeral private. For information Costello-Runyon Funeral Home, Metuchen, New Jersey.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Frankly we are somewhat confused by the signals Washington is sending to Africa these days. For years we were lectured about the virtues of democracy and the need for the rule of law, and we took this to heart. But in reality, if you want to get Washington's attention and respect, you are better off picking up the gun.''

description: HOCHBERG-Milton. Beloved husband of the late Ethel. Devoted father of Harriet and the late Marion Friedman. Dear brother of Vivian Swick and the late Howard Hochberg. Loving grandfather of David Friedman. Services were held on December 15, 1997. He will be missed by all.

A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, Thursday, Dec. 18 at 11:30 AM. Interment will be private. The family will receive friends at the Campbell establishment Wednesday, Dec. 17 at 79PM. In lieu of flowers, friends may wish to make a contribution to a charity of their choice.

title: Cable TV Cashes In On Current Film Crop
description: Readers of John Berendt's ''Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil'' have visualized these scenes but never seen them on screen. In the A&E documentary ''Midnight in Savannah'' are photographs and videotape of Jim Williams, the elegant antiques dealer who was tried four times in the murder of his thuggish young male lover. With his graying hair and dark mustache, he is a less handsome incarnation of Kevin Spacey, who plays him in the current Clint Eastwood film.

description: NITZBURG-Ruth. On December 14, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Leo. Beloved mother of Esther, Albert and mother-in-law of Ken. Loving sister of the late Eleanor Bergman. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALLACE, JOHN J. SR.
description: PALLACE-John J. Sr. Of Hampton Bays, N.Y. Formerly of Sunnyside, N.Y. Went home peacefully December 14, 1997. Longtime member of BPOE Southampton Elks #

title: An Unwelcome Mat for the U.N., Spurned by Iraq and Congo
description: Iraq told the chief United Nations arms inspector today that President Saddam Hussein would never open his palaces to inspection.

title: Where to Find New Designers' Labels
description: Just as designers are constantly seeking new places to sell their clothes, so are stores always on the lookout for new designers. How else can retailers differentiate their wares when the same big lines can be found in just about every store? And how else can they try to stay a step ahead of women's changing demands?

title: Physicists Report the 'Impossible': Teleporting a Particle's Properties
description: PHYSICISTS in Austria have achieved what was once considered impossible: the transfer of a physical property from one particle of light to another one, which could be billions of light-years away.

title: Albright in Africa: The Embraceable Regimes?
description: When Madeleine K. Albright flew to Africa last week to begin her first tour of the continent as Secretary of State, the aim was to open a new era in relations by embracing a ''new generation'' of leaders that Washington has cited as examples for others to follow.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Ideas pages on Saturday, with an article about heightened expectations for the new Getty Center in Los Angeles, referred imprecisely to the buildings shown and misstated the extent of the opening scheduled for today. The picture showed the entire Getty Center, not just the museum, and all of it is opening to the public.

title: Key Japanese Panel Devises $77 Billion Bank Rescue Plan
description: The ruling Liberal Democratic Party agreed Monday on a plan to use at least 10 trillion yen in public money to strengthen Japan's shaky banking system, the first solid progress in resolving this problem since four financial institutions collapsed last month.

title: Immigration Service Has Made Improvements, Auditors Find
description: Eight months ago, Government-hired auditors found that the Immigration and Naturalization Service had largely ignored its own set of sweeping new safeguards, meant to prevent immigrants with certain criminal records from becoming citizens.

title: YACHT RACING: WHITBREAD ROUND THE WORLD RACE -- A SAILOR'S JOURNAL; No Spinnakers, but at Least the Toilet Works
description: Nine boats restarted the 31,600-nautical-mile Whitbread Round the World Race last Saturday for the third leg, a 2,250-mile voyage from Fremantle to Sydney, Australia.

title: Honeywell Unit Is Sold
description: The General Signal Corporation has bought the North American control-valve business of Honeywell Inc. for an undisclosed price, adding high-pressure valves to its product line. The unit makes and designs valves used by the refining, petrochemical, pulp and paper, pharmaceutical and other processing industries. It employs 13 people in Montgomeryville, Pa.; Honeywell is based in Minneapolis. General Signal, based in Stamford, Conn., said the acquisition would allow its De Zurik unit, based here in Sartell, to offer high-pressure globe valves.

title: Better Weapons Emerge For War Against Mines
description: THEY lurk underground like alien predators in a science fiction film. From countless locations they spring unexpectedly, snatching an arm, or a hand, or a leg, or a life.

title: 2 Faces of Genetic Research: Compassion and Hubris
description: ''Cracking the Code'' is not a spy story. It's a space story: inner space. This first of three hourlong science programs under the overall title, ''Innovation'' looks into the promise and perplexities of dealing with genetically transmitted diseases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANTIN, KRYSTYNA
description: ANTIN-Krystyna. On December 14th, 1997. Adored and beloved wife of Sanford P. Antin, M.D. Daughter of Eleonora and the late Emil Hagel. Sister of Ronald and beloved aunt of Christopher, Elizabeth, Michael and Brittany of Vineland, N.J. Funeral Mass will be Tuesday, December 16, 1997 at St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89 St, at 11AM. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory can be made to the Columbia University Bone Marrow Transplant Research Fund.

title: Snow and Cold Hit Mexico, Causing Jump in Coffee Prices
description: Coffee prices soared yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York after snow and cold temperatures in Mexico raised concern that next year's harvest could be damaged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, PHILIP GOGGIN
description: LEE-Philip Goggin. Husband of Peggy F. Lee, retired from the EEOC, formerly of New York died December 14, 1997 in Charlottesville, VA. For infomation Teague Funeral Service, Charlottesville.

title: Horseshoe's One-Track Eye
description: THE horseshoe crab may have a lineage that goes back 250 million years or so, but its social life has a modern flavor. Millions show up for spring break on shores from Maine to Mexico, cavorting under the strobe light generated by the rocking and rolling waves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAFFET, NATHAN
description: TAFFET-Nathan. Beloved husband of Esta. Devoted father of Ronnie and Sandy. Father-in-law of Nancy. Loving grandfather of Scott and Andrew. Dear brother of Fay Fine and Stanley Taffet. Services Tuesday, at 12:30 P.M., at Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: MEDICAL-OFFICE SUPPLIERS SET $685 MILLION DEAL
description: Physician Sales and Service Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Gulf South Medical Supply Inc., a distributor of medical supplies in Ridgeland, Miss., for $685 million in stock. The combined company will be the leading distributor of medical products to the physician-office, extended-care and imaging-provider markets. It will have revenue of $1.3 billion and 112 service centers nationwide. Shares of Gulf South jumped $2.0625, to $31.125, while Physician Sales fell $4.6875 a share, to $18.3125. Physician Sales, based in Jacksonville, Fla., will swap 1.75 shares for each outstanding Gulf South share. The combined company is to be named PSS World Medical Inc., Physician Sales said.

title: HOCKEY; From Enforcer to Tender Heart
description: Only two things keep the Grim Reaper from being his brother's keeper 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

title: Tanjung Puting Journal; In Vast Forest Fires of Asia, Scant Mercy for Orangutans
description: Terrified orangutans have been fleeing their jungle homes as never before, driven by vast forest fires and choking smoke that have swept across their habitat in Borneo and Sumatra since the summer.

title: Observer; Not So Bad a Lie
description: The late Ambassador M. Larry Lawrence is back in Southern California after brief interment in Arlington National Cemetery. Friends of truth throughout America are gratified.

title: Handling the 'Out of Box Experience'
description: THREE big boxes emerge from the closet. The kids jump up and down and cry, ''A computer!''

title: Scientists Hasten to Find Vaccine to Stop New Flu Strain
description: With Hong Kong reporting two more cases of a new viral strain of influenza over the weekend, scientists are escalating efforts to develop a vaccine to avert a potential epidemic, United States health officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, LEON M.
description: GOODMAN-Leon M. On Saturday December 13, 1997 at his home in New York. Born January 6, 1908 in Philadelphia. Beloved husband of the late Minnie Gabriel Goodman and the late Gertrude Morgenstern Greenberg. Devoted father of David and Judith and dear grandfather of Joseph, Jeannette, Laura and Eve. The last surviving original member of the American Trotskyist movement. Interment private. Contributions may be made to the Workmen's Circle Home and Geriatric Center, 3155 Grace Avenue, Bronx, NY 10469.

title: Redskins' Blanton Out With Injury
description: The Washington Redskins learned yesterday that place-kicker Scott Blanton will not be able to play in a crucial game against the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday.

title: Dominicans, Scrabbling for Hope; As Poverty Rises, More Women Head the Households
description: On a white counter in Josefina Disla's tiny kitchen a place of honor is reserved for a small ceramic statue of Our Lady of Charity, who, legend has it, saved three drowning fishermen from a Caribbean storm in the 17th century. La Virgen de la Caridad, as she is known to believers, is said to save those who have lost all hope.

title: Judge Allows Another Airing Of Rape Claim
description: The judge presiding over the defamation lawsuit against three former advisers to Tawana Brawley reversed himself today, ruling that the advisers could defend themselves by arguing that the statements for which they are being sued were true. The change is likely to open the door to more witnesses and additional testimony.

title: UST TO PAY $259 MILLION FOR AFFILIATED COMMUNITY
description: The UST Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Affiliated Community Bancorp for $259 million in stock. UST, a bank company based in Boston, will exchange 1.41 shares for each Affiliated share, valued at $39.92 a share based on its closing price on Friday. The deal, combined with the purchase of Somerset Savings Bank, announced last week, will give UST $5.4 billion in assets and 83 branches. Affiliated's shares surged $4, to $36.625, while UST fell $1.15625, to $26.75. UST expects a charge of $12 million for takeover-related expenses. Affiliated Community, of Waltham, Mass., has $1.1 billion in assets and 12 branches. UST now has $3.7 billion in assets and 66 branches.

title: Schedule Leaves Cadets Marching in Place
description: The Cadets took a break for the holidays with a .500 record: seven victories, seven defeats over almost half the schedule for this Division I independent team.

title: Dialogue Without Depth
description: Imagine the following. It is August 1996. The anti-affirmative action initiative Proposition 209 is before California's voters, and the President is up for re-election. In one of numerous campaign events devoted to his commitment to racial justice, the President confronts a well-known backer of Proposition 209. ''Yes or no,'' Mr. Clinton demands, ''do you favor the Army abolishing the affirmative action program that produced Colin Powell?''

title: A Pianist Who Lays Bare Strata Rarely Perceived
description: To shed light on something is a phrase with both literal and figurative meanings. Murray Perahia's piano recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon rarely differentiated between the two. The light cast was strong and clear, and because of the light, matters were explained and listeners informed.

title: Overworked Doctors Must Respect Their Limits; Now Work Together
description: To the Editor:

title: Journal; Who's Sorry Now
description: If Bill Clinton had decided to hitch his star to a movie from 1970, at least he would have chosen ''Five Easy Pieces.''

title: Teva and Biovall in Deal
description: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries said today that it had entered into a marketing and product development agreement with the Biovall Corporation International of Ontario. Teva, an Israeli drug company, said it had received exclusive United States marketing rights for eight Biovall generic products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATLIN, HARRY
description: CATLIN-Harry. You broke your contract. You were supposed to wait for me. I've lost a dear, dear friend. So did a thousand others. There will never be anyone like you. To Fay, the kids and Roz, we will always remember. Frank I. Tashker

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRICH, MAX H.
description: KRICH-Max H. On December 13, 1997. Devoted husband of the late Ruth Weil Krich. Loving father of Edith K. Comins of Briarcliff Manor, NY, and Claire Hooton of East Hampton, NY. He is also survived by four grandsons and five greatgrandchildren. Interment private.

title: U.S. ARMED FORCES TO BE VACCINATED AGAINST ANTHRAX
description: Increasingly fearful of the threats posed by germ warfare, the Pentagon announced today that it would vaccinate every member of the armed services against anthrax, one of the deadliest biological agents known.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOLD, MILDRED
description: ARNOLD-Mildred. Of Westport, CT on December 14, 1997. In loving memory. Beloved wife of Norman for 56 years. Cherished mother of Charles, Susan and Phyllis. Adored gramma to Joshua, Mason and Isabelle. Mildred had an extraordinary approach to life that she carried to an honorable and dignified death. Her unique take on the world allowed her to endure the unbearable, to cut to the heart of things and to profoundly touch in an individual and special way everyone who knew her. We will miss you forever. Donations in lieu of flowers to YAI Institute for People with Disabilities, 460 West 34th Street, NYC 10001-2382.

title: Stubby Kaye, 79, Rotund Comic and Singer
description: Stubby Kaye, the cherubic comedian and singer who was Nicely-Nicely Johnson in the original ''Guys and Dolls'' and who joined Nat King Cole as an on-screen banjo chorus crooning the ballad of Cat Ballou, died Sunday in Rancho Mirage, Calif., where he lived. He was 79.

title: Hartford Agency Says Customers Should Pay Most of Reactor Bills
description: Despite evidence of serious mismanagement at Connecticut nuclear power plants, state regulators recommended today that customers continue to foot the bill for two nuclear reactors that have been closed for almost two years.

title: Judge Orders New Vote on Whether to Cut Union Chief's Salary
description: A Federal judge found yesterday that union leaders had intimidated members during a vote on whether to slash the salary of Gus Bevona, the highest paid union official in New York City, and the court ordered a new referendum on the issue.

title: Mental Care Has New Set Of Guidelines
description: Employers will have to comply for at least six months before they can obtain exemptions from a new law requiring broader insurance coverage of mental health services, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Dow Rises 84.29, but Nasdaq Index Dips
description: Cautious investors waded into the stock market yesterday, buying selectively and moving some broad market indexes higher after five consecutive sessions of declines.

title: Patterns
description: Better Things for Karan

title: Reading the Organic Rules
description: Yesterday the Department of Agriculture announced a proposed set of Federal standards for organic food production and processing. Organic food has become big business in the last few years, but the definition of what ''organic'' means has been erratic. Some states, like California, have strict certification procedures for organic farmers. Others have none. The new National Organic Program will now provide a single set of rules, following guidelines developed over seven years by the National Organic Standards Board in consultation with organic farmers and the public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAIO, VICTOR
description: SHAIO-Victor, 80. Died on December 13, 1997, at his home in New York after a long illness. He is survived by his wife, Anne, his son Alberto Shaio of Greenwich, CT., his three daughters, Flory Anzellini of Manalapan, FL., Diana Keevan of San Francisco, CA., and Joyce Mitrani of Bogota, Colombia, ten grandchildren, three great grandchildren and a stepdaughter, Elizabeth Uzielli of New York, NY. Also survived by his brother, Eduardo Shaio of Palma de Mallorca, Spain and his sister, Joyce Haim of Cannes, France. Mr. Shaio founded many industrial companies including Sedalana, Celanese Colombiana, and Petroquimica Colombiana, as well as Polifilm in Venezuela. In the United States, he was Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of New Energy Corporation of Indiana and past President of the Renewable Fuels Association. He was honored by all for his integrity, wisdom and courage. Mr. Shaio was a benefactor in Bogota, Colombia through the Shaio Clinic, a founder of the Universidad de los Andes and together with his father, built and donated the first Sefaradic temple in Bogota. Funeral service on Tuesday, December 16, 1 PM at Temple Emmanuel, Fifth Avenue and 65 Street, New York, NY. Interment Kensico Cemetery. In lieu flowers, contributions may be sent to Robert E. Barrett's Neurology Research Fund, Dept. of Neurology, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons.

title: Chronicle
description: Trinity College at the University of Dublin has been conferring doctoral degrees since its establishment 405 years ago, but never, until now, outside of Dublin.

title: Prospect Park Oasis
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STONE, ANNE
description: STONE-Anne. My dearest Anne. Ten long years since we lost you. Though it was not intended, our gift to you is the company of a kind and generous soul who helped us through. We love you both forever. Lucy

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Panel to Study Mercury At Industrial Sites
description: State environmental officials announced yesterday a panel to study mercury emissions at industrial sites.

title: By Design; Strapless Bras to the Rescue
description: So many of this season's party clothes bare the shoulders and are held up by the thinnest of straps that a strapless bra is a necessity for most women. Just in time, Wonderbra has a new long-line backless version that costs $35 at Lord & Taylor, Bloomingdale's and Macy's.

title: Suicide Rate Higher in 3 Gambling Cities, Study Says
description: The dramatic increase in legalized gambling in the United States may be leading to a significant increase in suicide rates among both residents of and visitors to communities where casinos are thriving, according to a new study on suicide and gambling.

title: Padres Get Brown at Marlins' Ongoing Fire Sale
description: One team is breaking apart a roster of champions, the other is trying to build one, and within those parameters the Florida Marlins traded Kevin Brown, their ace pitcher, to San Diego yesterday for three minor league prospects.

title: Shoddy Bricklaying Cited in Madison Ave. Hazard
description: New York's top building official said yesterday that shoddy workmanship was to blame for the bricks that tumbled from a Madison Avenue office tower more than a week ago, and that the street would remain closed for at least four more days as workers gingerly remove bricks from the defective wall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, JACK B.
description: ABRAMSON-Jack B. December 9, 1997, beloved husband of Rhoda, cherished father of Neil and Kenneth. Services were held Sunday Dec. 14, 1997 at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Tracing a Line From One Era to Another
description: Alan Feinberg's reputation rests largely on his eloquent championship of the contemporary piano literature, with a particular emphasis on American music. But he has also argued against imposing boundaries between styles and eras. Although his program on Saturday evening at the 92d Street Y was devoted mainly to his specialty, with works by Roger Sessions, George Edwards, Milton Babbitt and Charles Wuorinen, it also reached back to the 19th century for music by Beethoven and Chopin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKIER, JAMES A.
description: JACKIER-James A. On Sunday, December 14, 1997. Beloved husband of Rose Jackier. Loving father of Bobbi and Arthur Schain and H. Kenneth and Karen Jackier. Devoted grandfather of Eric, Diane and Michael. Service today 10:30 A.M. at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Le Count Place, New Rochelle, New York. Interment Sharon Gardens.

title: New Way of Doctoring: By the Book
description: IF you were to have a heart attack tomorrow morning, you and your doctor would suddenly have to make a series of rapid-fire decisions about your medical care, including what hospital you should check into, what tests, medications and procedures you should receive, and what specialists you should see.

title: Three Role Debuts in 'Nutcracker'
description: The New York City Ballet dangled three role debuts before ''Nutcracker''-weary balletomanes during the Saturday and Sunday matinees at the New York State Theater, and the results were enough to galvanize the most jaded of audiences.

title: YELLOW BOOK BUYS DONNELLEY UNITS FOR $122 MILLION
description: Yellow Book USA said yesterday that it had acquired telephone-directory publishing operations from the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation's Reuben H. Donnelley unit for $122 million in cash. The closely held Yellow Book will get businesses that publish 43 directories in five mid-Atlantic states and Washington, D.C. The deal makes Yellow Book, which already publishes about 200 directories, the largest independent publisher of yellow-page directories in the United States. About 380 Donnelley employees will be affected by the transaction. Yellow Book is owned by VS&A Communications II L.P., an equity fund affiliated with the investment bank Veronis, Suhler & Associates.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: The Baby Formula; Jets Are Getting a Lift From Their Rookies
description: They play with exuberance, often with daring, and they make things happen in strange ways. Fueled by a cadre of rookies, the Jets are 9-6 and need a final victory against the Detroit Lions to get into the playoffs.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WESTERN WATER CO., San Diego, a water seller, agreed to buy Vidler Water Co. from Global Equity Corp. for $98.9 million in stock.

title: Spain's Central Bank Cuts Benchmark Rate
description: The Bank of Spain cut its benchmark lending rate yesterday for the sixth time this year, to a record low of 4.75 percent, from 5 percent. The central bank adjusts rates by setting the yield on securities repurchase agreements at regular auctions. Yesterday it sold 2.623 trillion pesetas ($17.3 billion) of the agreements at 4.75 percent.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Korean Currency Surges After Restraints Are Lifted

title: Endgame Shaping Up In Bids for the N.F.L.
description: The temptation is to cease chronicling the National Football League television negotiations until the winners announce their deals and one network that bid the ranch loses because the other networks bid bigger ranches.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Offer to Help Riders On Popular Rail Line
description: New Jersey Transit made an offer yesterday to 50 towns along its popular Midtown Direct rail line, where parking lots at stations are often jammed with cars. The idea is to develop shuttle services to and from stations. N.J. Transit would provide small buses and $50,000 to run the service.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Four at U.S. Prison Arrested in Bribery Case
description: Two prison guards and two recreation workers at the Federal prison at Fort Dix were arrested yesterday on charges of taking bribes from inmates to smuggle drugs, alcohol and other contraband into the prison, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Leasing Company Guilty Of Money Laundering
description: A equipment leasing company from California has pleaded guilty to charges of money laundering that were filed after a five-year investigation into the resale of stolen computer parts, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Iranian Clerics Hint at Treason Trial for a Critic
description: Clerical authorities are hinting that they intend to press treason charges against a prominent theologian who challenged the credentials of Iran's religious leadership, signaling that they will not yield any of their power despite the hopes raised last spring when a moderate was elected President.

title: Ex-Officer Is Sentenced in Parking Lot Killing
description: A former New York City police officer was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison today for murdering a man in a dispute over a parking space in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Signs of Trouble for Big Accounting Merger
description: As partners at Ernst & Young and KPMG Peat Marwick vote this week on a merger that would create the world's largest accounting firm, the picture is far from one of wedded bliss.

description: To the Editor:

description: Larry Johnson shuffled his feet on defense, exploded to the basket on offense and did not limp back to the locker room after practice ended.

description: Overtures From Iran

title: German Venture Halts Sale of Digital TV Boxes
description: The European Commission said yesterday that the Kirch Group and Bertelsmann A.G. had agreed to stop selling the set-top decoder box used for their digital television venture until the partnership obtained regulatory approval from the commission. The commission had warned the companies on Dec. 1 that they could be fined for selling the devices without having received clearance for their venture, Premiere.

title: Straphangers Keep Fit
description: To the Editor:

title: New Position At Griffin Bacal
description: Griffin Bacal in New York has named Robert Moehl to oversee its creative output in the new post of executive vice president and executive creative director. Mr. Moehl, 50, will supervise day-to-day creative operations, reporting to Joe Bacal, 63, co-chairman and creative services director. Mr. Moehl joins Griffin Bacal, a unit of Omnicom Group in New York, after four years at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, part of MacManus Group, where he was senior vice president and executive creative director on accounts like Procter & Gamble.

title: Airlines Announce Plan to Install Improved Warning System
description: The major airlines announced today that they would install new satellite-based navigation equipment in the cockpits of 4,300 jets, to give pilots more warning when they are heading directly toward a mountain.

title: Irish Medical Company To Buy American Rival
description: The Elan Corporation, an Irish company that specializes in drug-delivery systems, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a United States rival, the Sano Corporation, for $375 million in stock. Both companies develop techniques, like patches or timed-release formulas, that make drugs easier to take.

title: WHX OFFERS $30 A SHARE FOR HANDY & HARMAN
description: The WHX Corporation offered yesterday to acquire the stake in the diversified manufacturer Handy & Harman it does not already own for $30 a share, or $360 million. The shares of Handy & Harman soared past the offering price, gaining $10.1875, or 45 percent, to $32.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange. WHX, the New York-based parent of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's No. 8 steelmaker, owns 4.9 percent of Handy & Harman, which makes electronics materials, specialty tubing and fasteners, in recent months. WHX's chairman said in a letter to Handy & Harman that he hoped for ''an amicable and productive dialogue'' on the offer.

title: Malaysia Taking Pledge of Austerity
description: For months, Malaysia resisted the pain, blaming foreign speculators, playing down its economic problems and leading analysts to brand it a country in denial.

title: Student, 19, Charged After Shooting Mishap
description: A high school student from Brooklyn was charged with weapons possession yesterday after he accidentally shot himself in the leg in the school cafeteria, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMWALD, ELEANOR
description: BAUMWALD-Eleanor. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle records with sorrow the passing of our beloved Member and Honorary Trustee. Heartfelt condolences to Irving and the entire family. Dorothy Fox, President Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi

title: If a Platypus Had a Dream, What Would It Mean
description: TO sleep, perchance to dream; but if so, what on earth might a duck-billed platypus dream about?

title: The Train Travelers' First Stop: Arias of the Soul
description: One of the strengths of the Manhattan School of Music is its opera department, which stages several productions a year, mostly of 20th-century works or neglected operas from the Baroque through Romantic eras. So although the principal aim of the Opera Theater, as the department's production arm is called, is to give students experience and exposure, it also contributes significantly to operatic life in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOTZKIN, ARTHUR
description: MOTZKIN-Arthur. The 92nd Street Y Board of Directors and Staff note with sadness the recent passing of Arthur Motzkin, beloved father of 92nd Street Y Nursery School Director Nancy Schulman. Our thoughts, prayers and condolences are extended to the family.

title: Even in Winter, Fluids Are Crucial
description: NOW that it is cold, you may get a little damp during a morning run or while doing circles on the ice or slaloms on the slopes, but nothing like the profuse sweat you work up in summer. And so you may think you do not have to drink much. Wrong! Though you may be less aware of water loss in winter, the need for adequate hydration is pretty much the same year-round.

title: Parreira's Bags Are Packed
description: The MetroStars are in negotiations with Saudi Arabia's federation over Coach Carlos Alberto Parreira, who is expected to leave the team with a year left on his contract to coach the Saudis in the World Cup in France this summer.

title: Jerome Mintz, 67, Author and Professor
description: Jerome R. Mintz, an author and professor emeritus of anthropology and Jewish studies at Indiana University, died on Nov. 22 at his home in Bloomington, Ind. He was 67.

title: U.S. Bancorp Seeks Piper Jaffray for $730 Million
description: U.S. Bancorp, the nation's 15th-biggest banking company, agreed yesterday to buy the Piper Jaffray Companies, a securities firm, for $730 million in cash to lock in Midwestern customers with a broader array of financial services.

title: In His Songs, Sibelius Tweaks the Conventions
description: ''Northern Lights,'' the two-week festival of music by Sibelius at Lincoln Center, continues to be as impressive for the involvement of the audiences attending the concerts as for the engrossing music being performed.

title: People
description: * Bernadette E. Murray was named executive vice president and senior account director at BBDO New York, part of Omnicom Group, succeeding Richard A. Pounder, who left to join Ammirati Puris Lintas, New York, part of the Interpublic Group, as executive vice president and managing director. Ms. Murray had been senior vice president for marketing at Brooks Brothers, New York, part of Marks & Spencer P.L.C.; she was succeeded by Derek Ungless as senior vice president and creative director.

title: The New Getty, Dream and Symbol; Opening Today, an Art Shrine With an Unconventional Spirit
description: What people will see as the Getty Museum, the most public part of the new $1 billion Getty Center, finally opens here, is one of the finest ''new'' museums to come into existence in the last quarter of the century -- new because its old premises, in the charmingly oddball Getty villa in nearby Malibu, were too small to show off much of what it had been buying recently. The poor little rich Getty that everyone loved to mock has quietly matured into an exquisite medium-size museum of European paintings, sculptures, drawings, photographs, manuscripts and decorative objects.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about the judge in the defamation trial of three former advisers to Tawana Brawley misspelled his given name. He is S. Barrett Hickman, not Barret.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINNERMAN, LILLI
description: WINNERMAN-Lilli. Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Lilli Winnerman. Wonderful wife of Stanley, loving mother of Ellen Kramer Diamond and Cindy Share. Devoted Bubbe of Lauren Diamond and loved mother-in-law of Todd Diamond and Jerry Share. Sister of David Eisenband. Services at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, L.I., on Wednesday, December 17 at 1 PM. Interment at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI. title: City Asks U.S. Appeals Panel To Stop Ads Naming Giuliani
description: Lawyers for the Giuliani administration argued yesterday that he should not be judged by his appearance on ''Saturday Night Live'' on NBC-TV and urged a Federal appeals panel to order the removal of bus advertisements that use Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's name.

title: Corrections
description: A brief art review in Weekend on Friday about Rodney Graham's exhibition at the 303 Gallery in Chelsea misidentified the format used to screen his work ''Vexation Island'' at the 1997 Venice Biennale, contrasting its clarity with that of the projection at the current show. A laserdisk video projection was used for both; the work was not shown on film at the Biennale.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about the F.B.I. Director's testimony before the House Committee on Government Reform and Oversight misidentified the committee member shown standing at the center. He was Richard Bennett, chief counsel for the committee, not Representative Christopher Cox, Republican of California.

title: Market Place; Court Ruling May Change Companies' Disclosure
description: In the annals of horrific takeovers, few compare with the misbegotten 1994 acquisition of Snapple by Quaker Oats. Quaker has since unloaded Snapple, losing $1.4 billion in the process.

title: I.M.F. to Consider Seeking More Capital
description: Seeking to insure that it has sufficient financial reserves to cope with a crisis in another big country, the International Monetary Fund will take up a proposal later this week from its managing director, Michel Camdessus, to request more capital from its 181 member nations.

title: Janet A. Hooker, Philanthropist, Dies at 93
description: Janet Annenberg Hooker, whose many philanthropies ranged from the support of musical organizations to the redecoration of The White House and the diplomatic rooms of the State Department in Washington, died Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 93 and had homes in Manhattan, Palm Beach, Fla., and Newport, R.I.

title: SOVEREIGN AND CARNEGIE AGREE TO $94 MILLION MERGER
description: Sovereign Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Carnegie Bancorp, a bank company, for $35.50 a share in stock, or $94 million. Carnegie, based in Princeton, N.J., has $423 million in assets and eight branches in New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Sovereign, based in Wyomissing, Pa., has assets of $17.4 billion and 180 branches in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware. The final purchase price may be adjusted depending on the share value of Sovereign's stock, which closed yesterday at $20.4375, down $1.1875. Shares of Carnegie rose $2.0625, to $34.0625.

title: Officer Accused in Louima Case Seeks Separate Trial
description: A longstanding rift among the police officers charged with brutalizing Abner Louima erupted again yesterday when the lawyer for Officer Justin A. Volpe asked that his client be tried separately from the three other officers charged in the case.

description: The Justice Department was given evidence that a powerful Venezuelan banking family had funneled improper campaign contributions to the Democratic Party in 1992, but Federal prosecutors have shown little interest in pursuing the case, Manhattan prosecutors said yesterday.

description: A Roman Catholic nun who was beaten on Sunday morning had facial reconstructive surgery yesterday as the police searched for her assailant.

title: Clinton Hails Iran Overture but Isolation Policy Is Unchanged
