title: Governor Pataki's Message to Judges
description: To deny reappointment to a sitting appellate judge because of displeasure with the judge's philosophy or decisions in particular cases tosses the vital principle of judicial independence to the wind. Unfortunately, Gov. George Pataki seems not to care. His imposition of an ideological test in rejecting Judge Francis Murphy for reappointment has ominous implications for New York State's justice system.

title: At Last, an Appointment for Mr. Lee
description: Over the weekend, Senator Orrin Hatch suggested that if Mr. Clinton named Bill Lann Lee as acting head of the civil rights division in the Justice Department, Republicans would not see the Lee appointment as such a slap in the face. Yesterday, the President adopted the idea. The outcome is good for the Justice Department, good for White House relations with the Senate and good for civil rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, MARILYN
description: FINKELSTEIN-Marilyn. On December 14, 1997. Beloved wife of Milton. Adored mother of David, Joan and husband Alan. Devoted grandmother of Sonia and Marina. title: Mummies May Be of Incan Elite, After Conquest of 'Cloud People'
description: AN examination of more than 200 well-preserved mummies that were discovered in Peru last year and excavated in August shows evidence that these were elite members of an Amazonian society in transition after the Incans conquered the region 500 years ago.

title: S.E.C. Staff Sees Plan as Flawed
description: The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission took the accounting profession to task yesterday for having forgotten investors in its quest to rewrite rules intended to keep auditors independent.

title: Executive Changes
description: AETNA INC., Hartford, the health insurer, promoted Richard L. Huber, its president and chief executive, to succeed Ronald E. Compton as chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, CHARLOTTE (NEE LARSEN)
description: KAPLAN-Charlotte (nee Larsen). On December 13, 1997. Wife of the late Jeremiah Kaplan. Mother of Ann Kaplan Fippinger, Susanna Lenzi, Margaret Allard and David Kaplan. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to the Alzheimer's Association, New York Chapter, 420 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10170.

title: MTV Selects Foote, Cone

The media assignments had been at the New York office of TBWA Chiat/ Day, owned by Omnicom Group, until April, when that agency began working for the ABC network unit of the Walt Disney Company.

title: Shift in Direct Course; Catalogue Merchandiser J. Peterman Now Moving Into Retail Stores, Too
description: First, let's dispense with the myths. Yes, J. Peterman, the catalogue executive so deliciously parodied on ''Seinfeld,'' is a real person. No, he does not share many of the television character's quirks and traits.

title: Chronicle
description: Whatever happened to WALTA WHITMAN KARSNER? Does she have any idea what an effect she had on DAVID RANDOLPH, the conductor of St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra, and consequently on the holiday music scene in New York?

title: Intel and Sun in Cross-Licensing Agreement
description: The Intel Corporation and Sun Microsystems Inc. plan to announce on Tuesday a broad cross-licensing agreement that will permit Sun's software to run on Intel's new family of 64-bit chips, Merced.

title: Hamed Entertains A Famous Visitor
description: The King of Pop met the Prince of pop yesterday at the Blue Velvet Gym in lower Manhattan. The singer Michael Jackson dropped in to watch Prince Naseem Hamed work out in preparation for his featherweight championship bout against Kevin Kelley on Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Murder Suspect Says He Felt 'Invincible' After Park Rape
description: Strolling away from the rocky corner of Central Park where his first victim, a 32-year-old piano teacher, lay beaten nearly to death and sexually assaulted, John J. Royster felt ''like I had accomplished something,'' he recalled in a videotaped confession played in court yesterday.

title: Closing Arguments Made In Oklahoma Bomb Case
description: Even though he was safely at home when the Oklahoma City Federal Building was blown up, Terry L. Nichols was an eager participant in its destruction, a Federal prosecutor said today in closing arguments in Mr. Nichols's trial.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Ireland Premier Calls Support By Clinton Vital to Ulster Pact
description: Ireland's Prime Minister, Bertie Ahern, said today that he hoped President Clinton would help push for a final agreement on a peace accord with Northern Ireland.

title: U.S. and Japan Resume Talks on Aviation Issues
description: The United States and Japan resumed talks in Tokyo yesterday aimed at reaching a new bilateral agreement to increase the number of flights between the two countries but reported little progress on the first day of the negotiations, which are scheduled to run three days.

title: Metro Business; Today's Man Clears Step
description: Today's Man Inc. of Moorestown, N.J., said yesterday that a Federal bankruptcy judge in Wilmington, Del., had approved a reorganization plan that would allow the company to emerge from Chapter 11 status in early 1998.

title: Metro Business; Credit Union Plans Move
description: The Municipal Credit Union, one of the oldest and largest credit unions in the country, is consolidating its lower Manhattan headquarters by merging two offices into one.

title: Panel's Advice on Troops Is Attacked
description: A panel's recommendation that the Army, Navy and Air Force separate men and women during much of their training faced pointed criticism today from some members of Congress and others who said it would undercut the role of women in the military.

title: Temptation; Finally, an Apple Tart That Truly Tastes French
description: AMERICAN bakers may complain that the butter and apples here are different from those in France, but somehow Jacqueline Zini, owner of the restaurant Chez Jacqueline in Greenwich Village, manages to turn out a tarte Tatin so perfectly Parisian that if it wasn't for the polite waiter, you might think you were in France.

title: Oklahoma Bombing Trial Goes to the Jury in Denver; 'Time for Justice' vs. Plea for Equal Justice
description: Thirty-two months after a truck bomb destroyed the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, the case of Terry L. Nichols went to a Federal jury here today shortly after 2 P.M.

title: Council Kills Plan to Use Private Building Inspectors
description: After a week of angry lobbying by tenant advocates, the City Council yesterday killed a plan that would have given privately hired engineers and architects -- instead of city inspectors -- the power to certify that landlords had fixed building violations like frayed wiring, leaks or rat infestation.

title: Washington Talk; Congress Is Away, but Partisanship Stayed in Town
description: Sometimes, the level of partisanship declines when Congress leaves town and the holidays approach. But not always.

title: Bass Selling 1,428 Pubs To Unit of Bankers Trust
description: Bass P.L.C. said yesterday that it would sell most of its franchised pubs to a unit of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation for $:564 million ($921 million) in cash to focus on its more profitable company-managed pubs. Bass -- the British beer, hotel and gambling company -- said proceeds from the sale of the 1,428 pubs, together with the proceeds from the sale on Monday of its Gala bingo operations for $:280 million, would let it return $:850 million ($1.39 billion ) to shareholders through a share issue.

title: Ratings in Jeopardy At 4 Indonesian Banks
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it might cut its credit ratings for three of Indonesia's four largest publicly traded banks as the collapse of the Indonesian currency, the rupiah, could lead to a surge in loan defaults. Bank Danamon, Bank Negara Indonesia and Bank International Indonesia have been put on a credit watch with negative implications, Standard & Poor's said. The smaller Bank Umum Nasional was also put on the credit watch list.

title: INSIDE
description: Pataki supports a proposal to give off-peak E-Z Pass discounts to truck drivers.

title: Five who left Lowe Direct to start Lieber, Levett thrive with billings of about $43 million.
description: A BREAKAWAY shop formed by five former top executives of Lowe Direct seems to be thriving in the crowded field of agencies that specialize in direct marketing and other sales pitches meant to build relationships with consumers and bolster relationships with customers.

title: Premier Parks Plans Expansion in Europe
description: Premier Parks Inc. said today that it would buy the Belgian amusement park operator Walibi S.A. for as much as $88 million in cash and stock, in a prelude to further expansion in Europe.

title: TV Notes; Comedy Host In Hot Water
description: Comedy Central, the all-comedy cable channel, had big plans for this week. Then its biggest star went and got himself suspended.

title: Incumbent Barely Wins Transit Union Election
description: In an election for control of the union that represents most of New York City's bus and subway workers, Willie James, the incumbent president, narrowly defeated Tim Schermerhorn, the head of a dissident group, the union said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 7 about criticism of the leadership of the Episcopal Bishop of New Jersey misstated the role of Jim Solheim, who commented on divisions in the diocese. He is not a spokesman for the Episcopal Church in New York; he is a spokesman for the Episcopal Church Center, the church's national office, which is in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REID, CHAUVET, PAM
description: REID - CHAUVET - Pam. Irre placeable friend and confidant. You were an inspiration to all who knew you. I feel lucky to have been your friend. You will be missed more than you will ever know. My deepest sympathy to Savannah, Romain and the entire Reid-Chauvet family. Faith Kates

title: 'Barbiere' Replacement
description: Joseph Volpe, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, announced yesterday that Vivica Genaux would sing Rosina in ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' tonight and again on Saturday afternoon. Ms. Genaux replaces Vesselina Kasarova, who has laryngitis.

title: CHRONICLE
description: By contrast, WILLIAM HAGUE, the leader of Britain's Conservative Party, who is scheduled to be married in London on Friday, said yesterday, ''Perhaps I should feel a bit guilty about leaving the arrangements mainly to my in-laws.''

title: Clinton Urges Education Aid for Minorities
description: President Clinton today made a passionate and detailed defense of affirmative action, arguing that not merit but differences in academic preparation and business contacts produce racial disparities in the United States.

title: No Support From Clinton For Director Of the F.B.I.
description: After years of praising his F.B.I. Director, President Clinton pointedly passed up an opportunity today to express confidence in Director Louis J. Freeh -- two weeks after Mr. Freeh urged Attorney General Janet Reno to seek an independent prosecutor in the campaign-finance case.

title: On Madison, A History Of Problems
description: Almost from the day it opened 27 years ago, the office tower at 540 Madison Avenue has been the subject of fierce disputes involving the owner, the contractor and the architect over flaws in the brick wall that tumbled into the street last week and is now being repaired at a cost of millions.

title: Making Books; A Time to Grub, With Finesse
description: The unruly congregation that is a Barnes & Noble bookstore at Sugar Plum time has been cleansed of every esthetic consideration in the desire to fill each available inch of space with books for sale and make 1997 a big year for the book industry. It was not, therefore, surprising that the store on Lexington Avenue between 86th and 87th Streets appeared to have enough books on its shelves and crammed into its corners and crannies to give one to every person on the Upper East Side.

title: Tidbit; Filled Up With Rice
description: FROM 1970 through 1987, an average of 25 to 30 percent of the rice consumed by Americans was in the form of beer. We're talking Budweiser and Miller. Good beer relies on malted barley or sometimes wheat, but almost any grain can be fermented and brewed. And rice is cheaper than wheat or barley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISEL, LOUIS
description: MEISEL-Louis, 72. Husband of Tracy Kennedy. Father of Andrea De Vries and Ellen Winer. Grandfather, World War II Vet, long time employee of New York Hospital; after a long battle with emphysema, on December 15, 1997.

title: Polaroid to Revamp and Cut 1,500 Jobs
description: The Polaroid Corporation said today that it would take a pretax charge of $310 million in the fourth quarter to cut 15 percent of its work force and sell a chemical plant in an attempt to reduce costs.

title: TV Notes; Connie Chung Is Back
description: Connie Chung returns to network news for the first time in more than two years tonight, with her first report for her new employer, ABC News. Her two-year stint as co-anchor with Dan Rather on ''The CBS Evening News'' ended in 1995.

title: Emissions Trading Will Lead to Less Pollution; Not If, but How Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, CAROLINE BEDELL, M.D.
description: THOMAS-Caroline Bedell, M.D., 93. On December 14, 1997. Wife of the late Henry M. Thomas, Jr. M.D. Mother of Henry M. Thomas III, Eleanor Carey Thomas and Mary Whitall Thomas Clevenger. A memorial service will be held at a later date at the Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions. Contributions may be made to Caroline B. Thomas Fund, Precursors Study, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Suite 2-600, 2024 East Monument Street, Baltimore, Maryland 21205

title: Woman Is Indicted In Death of Her Infant
description: A Harlem woman accused of leaving her infant son unattended while she spent nine days in jail, then returning home and dropping his dead body down a garbage chute, was indicted yesterday on two counts of second-degree murder, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said.

title: 2d Ex-Head of Baron Files a Guilty Plea
description: A. R. Baron & Company's former president and chief compliance officer, Mark Goldman, pleaded guilty yesterday to grand larceny and enterprise corruption -- a legal phrase for racketeering -- and agreed to spend at least one year in jail.

title: Amid Grandiosity, a Quiet Lyricism
description: Just as the Northern Lights exploration of Sibelius and other Finnish composers was winding to a close at Lincoln Center on Monday evening, the Philadelphia Orchestra settled into Carnegie Hall with a program that kept the northern accent of Romanticism in focus, but turned the spotlight both west and east of Sibelius's Finland. With the Russian conductor Yuri Temirkanov on the podium, the orchestra devoted the first half of its program to Grieg and the second half to Rimsky-Korsakov.

title: Northwest and Pilots Reported To Discuss Continental Alliance
description: Northwest Airlines executives and leaders of the carrier's pilots' union met yesterday to try to revive an alliance that would enable Northwest to take effective control of Continental Airlines, two people close to the talks said.

title: Business Travel; An experiment by United Airlines to further limit carry-on baggage is well received by passengers.
description: TWO weeks ago, UAL's United Airlines began a one-bag carry-on policy experiment for passengers in Des Moines who buy the lowest-fare tickets, and other carriers also tightened their carry-on policies. Since then, airlines say, there appears to be both more rigorous enforcement of the policies and wider compliance with them. But the true test, they add, will be determined when planes are no longer routinely jammed with passengers, and carriers and passengers alike relax their guard.

title: Paine Webber to Reorganize Nasdaq Unit
description: Paine Webber Inc. is reorganizing its Nasdaq stock trading unit as competition and regulation in the market increase, and seven traders, including the head of the unit, are leaving.

title: Mexican Oil Union Chief Paroled After 9 Years
description: Joaquin Hernandez Galicia, the onetime strongman of a powerful oil workers' union who spent nearly nine years in prison for crimes human rights monitors say were fabricated, was freed on parole today.

title: Japan Premier Seeks Billions In Tax Cuts
description: Breaking a pledge of fiscal austerity, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto called today for a two trillion yen cut in Japanese income taxes to help revive an economy that has stagnated for much of the decade.

title: Ms. Albright's Awkward African Tour
description: Secretary of State Madeleine Albright is usually a master of theatrical diplomacy, but she was rudely put off balance a few days ago by President Laurent Kabila of Congo. With Ms. Albright at his side, Mr. Kabila brusquely dismissed a question about a man jailed for circulating opposition literature. Unhappily, the incident captured the tone of Ms. Albright's uneven visit to seven countries in sub-Saharan Africa. Though the journey demonstrated American interest in the region, and Ms. Albright broadly defended democratic principles, she too often glossed over the abusive practices of leaders she met, most notably Mr. Kabila.

title: Bruno Proposes Cuts in Taxes to Spend State's Budget Surplus
description: In the opening bid of what will probably be a lively election-year fight over spending the state's 1998 budget surplus, the Republican Senate majority leader proposed a package of tax cuts today that would be worth $980 million a year by 2001.

title: To Go; Little Treasures Hidden Within Chelsea Market
description: ALTHOUGH it has been open almost a year, the block-long Chelsea Market, set in an old Nabisco factory near 15th Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues, still feels undiscovered and out of the way. Its main aisle, trimmed in rough brick and granite, with a rushing waterfall constructed of old pipes and girders, feels strangely serene, like some quiet urban woods where a surprise picnic awaits just behind the next tree.

title: Edna Kelly, Congresswoman From Brooklyn, Is Dead at 91
description: Edna Flannery Kelly, the first woman to represent Brooklyn in Congress and an expert in foreign affairs and social policy, died on Sunday at the home of her daughter in Alexandria, Va. She was 91.

title: Cowboys Are America's Mixed-Up Team
description: After six straight years of reaching the playoffs and three Super Bowl titles during that stretch -- the only noise the Dallas Cowboys will make this post-season will come in the form of news conferences about expected personnel moves.

title: Mayor Moves Agency Heads From 2 Posts In His Cabinet
description: Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, the Commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, the city's huge social-services agency, is being removed from her post by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and made executive director of Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center in the Bronx, city officials said yesterday.

title: St. John's Dismisses 6-9 Felton From Team
description: St. John's Coach Fran Fraschilla announced yesterday that forward James Felton, who was one of the country's top high school basketball players last season, had been kicked off the squad for repeated violations of undisclosed team policy.

title: Emissions Trading Will Lead to Less Pollution; What's 'Immoral'?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Praise of America's Own World-Class Ham
description: IF a prophet is without honor in his own country, sometimes a pig is, too. Or at least a ham.

title: $25 and Under; Inventive Mediterranean Fare That's Worth a Trip
description: SAMI KADER wanted to be a chef but thought he was a prisoner of his resume. Mr. Kader, who was born in Egypt and grew up in France, has been working in restaurants for 18 years, since he was 17, but always in the front of the house. Even though he could cite stints as maitre d'hotel or manager in fine restaurants like Petrossian, Remi, La Cote Basque and Fifty Seven Fifty Seven at the Four Seasons Hotel in Manhattan, he was reasonably certain that nobody would hire him to cook. He believed he needed his own place.

title: The Minimalist; Sweet and Fruity Wines Give Chicken a New Flourish
description: WHEN wine is added to simmering chicken, it's most often dry and white. The most common exception to this rule is in the classic French coq au vin, in which the wine is dry and red. Yet, a quick twist of these rules creates a chicken dish so simple that it's bound to become a minimalist favorite. The key is slightly sweet white wine, a liquid whose fruity complexity -- at its best both subtle and well defined -- adds a layer of flavor that no dry white wine could ever offer.

title: TV Notes; So Long, Tony
description: NBC, on a stealth campaign to drop its failing shows without really replacing them, killed off another one this week: ''The Tony Danza Show'' got the word that it was being canceled. The show performed poorly in two time periods on Wednesdays.

title: After Lima Crisis, Skeptics Deplore Japan's Response to Terror
description: There will be no party this year at the Japanese Embassy in Lima, Peru, to celebrate the birthday of the Emperor.

title: HUBCO TO ACQUIRE MSB BANCORP FOR $115 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Hubco Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the savings and loan holding company MSB Bancorp Inc. for $115 million in stock. Hubco will exchange $36.02 in stock for each share of MSB, the parent company of MSB Bank. After the closing, MSB will merge into Hubco's Bank of the Hudson unit. Shares of Hubco slipped 37.5 cents yesterday, to $36.25. Shares of MSB were up 75 cents at $34.50. Hubco, based in Mahwah, N.J., owns Hudson United Bank and had total assets of $3.11 billion on Dec. 31, 1996. MSB Bancorp, based in Goshen, N.Y., had total assets of $820.9 million on Dec. 31, 1996.

title: 4th-Quarter Earnings Fell 24% at Broker
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday that its earnings before taxes for its fourth quarter fell 24 percent, to $567 million, as Asian stock markets declined and the outlook for international investment banking business became somewhat less rosy.

title: Essay; State of the Union
description: I wandered over to the White House the other day to find out what President Clinton is going to propose in 1998. The State of the Union address in January imposes a deadline on policy makers; if his agenda is to have any philosophical shape, the speechwriters need guidance fairly soon on themes and specifics.

title: Panel Approves a Freeze On Some Property Taxes
description: A State Senate committee approved a bill yesterday that would freeze property taxes for 200,000 low-income elderly and disabled people at 1996 levels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORRY, NEIL
description: NORRY-Neil. The officers and staff of the Masorti Foundation for Conservative Judaism in Israel mourn the death of our founding President and Chair of our Council of Trustees. His insight, passion for Judaism and Israel and commitment to the Masorti Movement are an inspiration to us all. Our condolences to his wife, Sharon and family. May his memory be a blessing. Herschel Blumberg, President James S. Demb, Exec. Vice Pres.

title: Doctors' Taboos; Work, Work, Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Plot Ways to Atone For 2 Losses to Pistons
description: The Nets will be looking to settle a score or two -- Wednesday night at Continental Arena.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an obituary of the philanthropist Janet Annenberg Hooker was published in error. It showed her sister Lita Annenberg Hazen, a patron of medical research and cultural institutions who died in 1995.

title: Race, Reporters and Responsibility
description: Today within a school auditorium in Fairfax, Va., President Clinton's advisory board on race will conduct another in its dialogues that will probably evoke both constructive and contentious comments from speakers representing many aspects of social and business life in America. That is, with one exception -- the athletes who make their living in the National Basketball Association.

title: Room at the Inn: A Hudson Valley Christmas; At a picture-book small hotel, a young chef's sorcery enhances tradition.
description: MAYBE the song is right. Maybe there's no place like home for the holidays. But in a pinch, and not a very tight one at that, I would settle for spending Christmas in a small hotel where the staff is warm hearted, the decorations are decorous, the beds are first-class tickets to dreamland, the fires are tended by others, the cousins whose names I can never remember are half a continent away and the kitchen is run by a sorceress.

title: Top Secret's Out, and It's Not 'Barkansas'
description: It was President Clinton who broke the news to a waiting nation at a news conference today, disclosing that he had named his new chocolate Labrador puppy Buddy, after a great-uncle of Mr. Clinton who died this year.

title: Swiss Deal for Stakes In Vanadium Producers
description: Suedelektra Holding A.G., the Swiss commodities house, announced yesterday that it had purchased majority stakes in the South African chemical producers Vanadium Technology and Rhoex Ltd. from the Swiss trading house Glencore International. Suedelektra said it had paid $143.3 million for a 100 percent stake in Vanadium Technology and 81.7 percent of Rhoex. The company will make an offer of 6.20 rand ($1.27) a share for the remaining Rhoex shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREY, JEAN S.
description: GREY-Jean S. On December 15, 1997, of Syosset, Long Island. Beloved wife of the late Charles S. Devoted mother of Scott M. Grey and Shari Bethiel. Dear sister of Sydell Volk, Joel Schwartz and the late Leonard Schwartz. Cherished grandmother of Ian and Jonathan. Services on Thursday, at 11 A.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: An Old Master Who Transmutes the Trivial
description: If someone can point to a more winning performance this season than the one Eli Wallach is supplying nightly in ''Visiting Mr. Green,'' a new play by Jeff Baron at the Union Square Theater, nominations are being accepted. But be advised: Mr. Wallach is formidable competition.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Office Space? Web Site Is Latest Marketing Tool
description: A business person looking for office space in Westchester or maybe the East Side of midtown Manhattan has several alternatives. One would be to call brokers and endure all manner of sales pitches.

title: With Work, Peace Comes To Schools Once Divided
description: When Marvin Spratley became principal of Falls Church High School six years years ago, he inherited a school riven with racial and ethnic strife. Black students socialized only with each other, as did Korean, Vietnamese, Mexican, Dominican, and Haitian students, for beginners. Intergroup fights were common. Gang activity was rampant.

title: Food Stuff
description: Gifts Meant to Satisfy The Holiday Appetite

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL TO TAKE CHARGE FOR LOSSES IN BRITAIN
description: The Lincoln National Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $287 million after-tax charge in the fourth quarter to cover pension sales practices liabilities and reinsurance losses in Britain. The company expects $173 million of the loss will come from settling British regulators' allegations of improper pension sales in the late 1980's and early 90's. The remaining $114 million is for London reinsurance claims on policies written between 1993 and 1996. Shares of the company, a life insurer based in Fort Wayne, Ind., fell $1.1875, to $74.0625. Lincoln National also foresees an after-tax gain of $777 million from the sale of its 83.3 percent stake in the American States Financial Corporation, an Indianapolis-based property and casualty insurer, on Oct. 1.

title: U.N. Tells How Taliban Were Killed By the 100's
description: A United Nations team investigating reports from Afghanistan that more than 2,000 Taliban fighters held as prisoners were killed has found hundreds of bodies in wells and shallow graves, officials said today in Geneva.

title: Charles E. Smith, 60, Reference Publisher
description: Charles E. Smith, a publisher of scholarly books and reference works, died on Dec. 7 at his home in Colt's Neck, N.J. He was 60.

title: Limits on the Work-at-Home Life ; At Merrill Lynch, the Office Never Seems So Far Away
description: Millions of American workers, juggling the demands of children and other responsibilities, have sought the flexibility of working from home in recent years. But their arrangements have been mostly informal and ad hoc -- based on relationships, trust and a handshake with the boss.

title: He's a Champion Of Self-Promotion
description: The music was blaring at a trendy athletic club at Chelsea Piers one recent afternoon, and Prince Naseem Hamed was dancing to a pulsating disco beat.

title: Emissions Trading Will Lead to Less Pollution; Sacrifice Isn't Required
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan, Economic Power Aside, Seems Paralyzed by Asia Crisis
description: As a financial crisis sweeps through Asia and provokes fears of a global downturn, Japan is the one economic force powerful enough to pull the region back to vitality.

title: TV Notes; Hello, 'Biography'?
description: Charles Gibson, the longtime co-host of ''Good Morning America'' on ABC, is negotiating with the A&E cable network to take over as the primary host of the nightly series ''Biography.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, REGINA
description: HARRIS-Regina. On December 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Loving mother of Neal (Sharon). Cherished sister of Fran Zimmerman and the late Sylvia Baskin and Goldie Wernikoff. Services on Wednesday at 10 A.M., ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Sabbatical From Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: Abortion Retreat in New Jersey
description: Women's reproductive freedom suffered a setback this week when the New Jersey Senate voted narrowly to override Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's veto of a measure that attempts to ban so-called partial birth abortions. The one-vote margin gave New Jersey the dubious distinction of becoming the 17th state to flout the Constitution by approving vaguely worded legislation intruding on the discretion of women and their doctors to choose the safest abortion method. This latest product of the new abortion politics should not survive a serious review by the courts.

title: Brawley and Advisers Were Unhelpful in Rape Inquiry, Official Testifies
description: As the first witness finally left the stand and a new one was called, testimony in the defamation lawsuit against three former advisers to Tawana Brawley focused today on the efforts of investigators responding to her rape claim and the degree to which Ms. Brawley and her advisers did not cooperate with them.

title: And if It Quacks Like a Guitar . . .
description: Seated on a swivel stool in the middle of a dim Bottom Line stage on Saturday night, wearing black monkish clothes and an earphone that connected him to a bank of black boxes, Robert Fripp made sounds with his guitar. One could say he played his guitar, but that phrase hardly applied to Mr. Fripp's performance.

title: Room at the Inn: A Hudson Valley Christmas; For the holidays, dining well and warmly in the soft light of history.
description: THERE is a place where the snow lies deep along a winding river and old stone houses still stand, unchanged, since before the Revolution. A place where every inn seems to have beamed ceilings, abundant fireplaces and walls fragrant with history, and every landscape has towering pine trees and holly just waiting to be picked. Driving along, you see horses on hillsides, sheep in the meadows and children on sleds. It sounds like a distant dream, but all you have to do is follow the Hudson River as it winds its way north.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, CHARLOTTE
description: KAPLAN-Charlotte. The Officers, Directors, and staff of the New York City Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association mark with sadness the passing of Charlotte Kaplan, mother of our esteemed fellow Director and friend, Ann Kaplan Fippinger. To Ann, and all of the Kaplan family, we offer our heartfelt sympathy and support. At this difficult time, may memories of Charlotte when she was well provide solace and comfort for those who loved her. William Brachfeld & Marilyn Cohen, Co-Presidents John A. Jager, Exec. Director

title: Isles' Stellar Second Period Is Not Enough for a Victory
description: Frequently this season, the Islanders have shown glimpses of what they could be. But more times than not, those fleeting moments in which the team has looked like a contender have not been enough to earn them a victory.

title: A History of Concrete
description: To the Editor:

title: Off the Menu
description: Marketplace Offspring

title: The Wiz Files for Federal Bankruptcy Protection
description: Hurt by cutthroat price competition and sagging demand for home electronics, The Wiz Inc., the largest consumer electronics retailer in the New York region, said yesterday that it had filed for protection from creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: Francis Paudras, 62, Patron Of Jazz Pianist Bud Powell
description: Francis Paudras, a commercial artist, author, collector of jazz-related artifacts and patron of jazz musicians, including the pianist Bud Powell, died on Nov. 26 at his castle in Antigny, France. He was 62.

title: Calendar
description: To Sup Like a Seaman

title: Doctors' Taboos
description: To the Editor:

title: Bass and Drilling Concern in Buyout Talks
description: Lone Star Technologies of Dallas confirmed today that it was discussing with a Bass family investment group a possible buyout of the provider of oil drilling equipment.

title: Inaugural Festivities To Go On for 3 Days
description: Granted, it is the last time Rudolph W. Giuliani will ever be inaugurated as Mayor of New York City. Granted, he loves bunting, civic superlatives, the grand gestures of a grandiose city. But still, 11 inaugural parties and events, spread over 3 days, costing more than $400,000?

title: Coach Fraschilla Returns to Draddy
description: The Jaspers (2-2) will face their toughest test of the season tonight when the former Manhattan coach Fran Fraschilla returns to Draddy Gymnasium for the first time since taking over at St. John's last season.

title: Sips; An Infusion of Herbs and Fruits Spins Mystery Into That Martini
description: AT the Chelsea Bistro and Bar, giant bottles called bombonnes filled with liquids the color of jewels tower over the bar. They are infusions of fruits and herbs in alcohol, which the bartender, Marika Turano, right, uses to weave a little mystery and surprise into drinks.

title: Land Rights of Aborigines Set Off Australian Battle
description: The 21-month-old Government of Prime Minister John Howard has set itself on a collision course with Aboriginal peoples over one of this country's most visceral issues -- land rights -- opening the prospect of new elections next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, YETTA (NEE STURMAN)
description: BROWN-Yetta (nee Sturman). Died peacefully on December 15, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Loving mother of Ted Brown and June Barbanell. Adoring grandmother of Richard, Jennifer, Meredith. Great grandmother of Hamilton and Jessica. Private services were held.

title: Sanofi in Deal to Sell Its Ricci Product Line
description: Sanofi S.A., the French drug and beauty-products company, said yesterday that it and other shareholders had agreed to sell Ricci Group, which includes Nina Ricci fashions and fragrances, to Puig, a private Spanish company. Sanofi, which indirectly controls 56.7 percent of Ricci, did not disclose the price. Analysts said Sanofi probably received about 500 million francs ($86.2 million) for the stake.

title: Sports of The Times; Moving Vans Might Come For Rangers
description: FAMILY only counts if you're winning. Mired in gloom, the Rangers need to remember that. Real families are probably even more dysfunctional than any given clubhouse, but real families cannot make trades or dismiss somebody who isn't working out quite as easily as teams can.

title: Restaurants; Burned Menu. Weird Shrimp. It's a Party!
description: YOU won't eat well at Asia de Cuba. But you will have so much fun being there that you may not notice. The manic energy of the place makes every night feel like a party.

title: UNIVERSAL HEALTH SERVICES TO EXPAND INTO PUERTO RICO
description: Universal Health Services Inc. announced yesterday that it would acquire the closely held Hospital San Pablo Inc. and the chain of hospitals owned by that company, expanding Universal's hospital holdings beyond the 50 states. Universal, the third-largest hospital management company in the United States, has agreed to buy all shares of Hospital San Pablo, a chain that generates revenue valued at more than $100 million. title: ONE VALLEY BANCORP AGREES TO BUY FFVA FINANCIAL
description: One Valley Bancorp Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the FFVA Financial Corporation for about $204 million in stock. One Valley will swap 1.05 of its common shares for each FFVA common share. Based on One Valley's closing share price on Monday, the deal is valued at $42.98 a share. FFVA is the parent company of First Federal Savings Bank of Lynchburg, Va., which has assets of $567 million. One Valley, based in Charleston, W. Va., has $4.5 billion in assets and 89 sites in West Virginia and Virginia. Shares of FFVA rose more than 11 percent, gaining $4 to close at $39.125. Shares of One Valley fell $1.1875, to $39.75.

title: RJR Nabisco to Cut Almost 3,000 Jobs

One such dish that I came up with and that was especially popular was a boneless loin of lamb rolled in a combination of chopped black truffles with a little parsley.

So when a talented actor like David Margulies chooses to perform three of them, as he does in ''Bashevis: Tales of Isaac Bashevis Singer,'' just the description of a sunset's reflection in the glass door of a cafe is a quiet thrill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOOKER, JANET ANNENBERG
description: HOOKER-Janet Annenberg. Died December 13, 1997. The widow of James Stewart Hooker, she is survived by her sons, Donald P. Kahn (Jeanne) and Gilbert S. Kahn, her brother, the Hon. Walter H. Annenberg and two sisters, Enid A. Haupt and Evelyn A. Hall. She is also survived by five grandchildren, Donald P. Kahn, Jr., Douglas T. Kahn (Dr. Margaret Carter), Steven D. Kahn, Alexandra Kahn (John Graubert) and Julie K. Brown, and five greatgrandchildren, Sophia and Isabel Carter-Kahn, Christina Graubert, Thomas M. Bender and Samuel A. Brown, Jr. She was first married to the late L. Stanley Kahn-a member of the New York Stock Exchange. In 1938 she married investment banker Joseph A. Neff who died in 1969. She was very active in New York Charities-especially the Metropolitan Opera where she donated the Lobby Colonnade in memory of her mother, Mrs. Moses L. Annenberg. In addition, she funded the redecoration of the Blue Room at The White House, and, with her brother and his wife, helped fund projects at both the State Department's Diplomatic Reception Rooms and Blair House. In 1977, Mrs. Hooker gave an historic emerald to the National Gem Collection at the National Museum of Natural History. In 1991 and 1992, she gave additional gems to the collection and was the major donor for the Janet Annenberg Hooker Hall of Geology, Gems and Minerals which opened in September 1997. Mrs. Hooker, a resident of Palm Beach, Florida, also owned a summer home, Fairholme, in Newport, Rhode Island. A Funeral Mass will be held on Thursday, December 18, at 10 AM, at the Church of St. John The Evangelist, 55th Street and First Avenue, New York City. Burial will be private. For more information call Frank E. Campbell, New York City, 212-288-3500.

title: Attempt to Raze Homes In Newark Fails Twice
description: First explosives failed to do the job. Then there were problems with the crane. Some Newark officials wondered yesterday whether the Rev. William P. Hayes Homes would ever come down.

title: Nasty, Brutish And Idyllic
description: Isn't it amazing how children with few material advantages instinctively devise clever ways to amuse themselves? When they're not slaving under the thumb of their autocratic father on his vegetable farm in the south of France, seven illegitimate children find time to race homemade toy sailboats along the farm's irrigation ditches. Or, using teaspoons and a marble, they play a fast and furious variation of table tennis without a net.

title: Opposites Find a Common Ground
description: For nearly a decade, Neil Smith of the Rangers and Lou Lamoriello of the Devils have worked fewer than 10 miles -- and at least a world -- apart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, WALTER B.
description: HESS-Walter B. On November 25th, 1997 in Chicago. Beloved father of Barbara and Susan, dear brother of Jack Hess, cherished grandfather of Christopher and Jeremy. Interment private.

title: Johnson Returns, and the Knicks Respond
description: The coat and tie made Larry Johnson seem like another corporate body sitting at Madison Square Garden for the last three weeks.

title: A Private Eye; Escaping a Downcast Life With a Releve of the Spirit
description: The Snowflakes in the New York City Ballet's ''Nutcracker'' twirled on point, waving snowballs then wafting offstage, all smiles, tulle and sparkles, out of their confetti storm.

title: Broadway Beacon Set to Glow Again
description: Ignited in the incandescent Jazz Age, darkened by the fearful years of war and neglected as Times Square ebbed, the great glass globe atop the Paramount Building will light the skies again. This time, with music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, IRWIN
description: GOODMAN-Irwin, 79. Of Delray Beach, Florida. formerly of NYC. Survived by wife Claire, children Lonnie (Amy) and Lori (Paul Boyd) Goodman. Grandchildren, Adam, Lindsay, Isaac, Michael and Emmett. A brother Edwin and sisters, Ruth and Hannah. He was greatly loved and will be greatly missed. Service will be noon, Thursday, December 18, at The ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue,

title: Sotheby's to Tighten Procedures Regarding History and Sale of Art
description: While denying that it had knowingly auctioned smuggled art works, Sotheby's said yesterday that it would tighten its procedures in response to accusations of widespread improprieties involving the sale of illegally exported paintings and looted antiquities.

title: Devils Hand the Rangers Yet Another Bruising Loss
description: The Rangers-Devils game tonight began with Bill Guerin of New Jersey crashing into Aleksandr Karpovtsev of the Rangers during the first shift. Guerin knocked Karpovtsev down and knocked the stick from his hands. And Guerin got the worst of it.

title: Segregation Persists
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, MORRIS
description: SCHNEIDER-Morris, 87. Dec. 14, 1997, in Coconut Creek, Florida. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Father of Ellen and Stephen, and Lynn. Grandfather of Amy, Jodi, Harry and Jared. Services today, 9:30AM at Temple Beth El, Spring Valley. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York. Shiva will be at the home of Stephen and Ellen Wechsler, Nanuet.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANTOR, B. GERALD
description: CANTOR-B. Gerald. (12/17/16-6/3/96). My Darling Bernie, Happy Birthday. I will always remember how you touched my life. Love, Iris.

title: A Second Tough Call for Clinton on Bosnia Policy: Aid for the Serbs
description: With President Clinton signaling that he is likely to extend the deployment of American peacekeepers in Bosnia, the Administration neared another decision on Bosnian policy today that could be nearly as contentious: support for a $40 million aid package for the Serbian republic in Bosnia.

title: Tommy Hilfiger In Super Bowl Deal
description: Tommy Hilfiger USA has named Deutsch Inc. in New York to create its first Super Bowl commercial in a decision that may foreshadow the outcome of a review for the Hilfiger account, with billings estimated at $30 million.

title: Judge Blocks Bid For True North
description: In another twist to the bitter battle between True North Communications and its former partner, Publicis S. A., a Chancery Court judge in Delaware yesterday temporarily blocked a $269.4 million hostile bid by Publicis for True North, which a Federal appeals court had allowed to proceed only a day before.

title: Asian Bloc's Anniversary Celebration Becomes a Plea for Outside Help
description: Meeting in celebration of their 30th anniversary as a regional bloc, Southeast Asian leaders have swallowed their pride and pleaded for further economic help from abroad.

title: Credit Card Delinquencies Fall to 3.53%
description: The number of credit card holders who fell behind on payments declined in the third quarter, as banks continued to tighten lending standards, the American Bankers Association said today.

title: Looking Upward, With Anxiety
description: New Yorkers live out their lives under towers of brick and concrete, walking and sitting and playing next to buildings so tall that even a tiny object plummeting from their heights could maim or kill a human strolling at ground level. It is a wonder, really, that so few tragedies occur beneath the soaring, sometimes aging skyscrapers.

title: People
description: * Marjorie Valin was named to the new position of vice president for public affairs at the American Advertising Federation, Washington. She had been director for public relations and marketing and vice president of the educational foundation at the Flexible Packaging Association, Washington.

title: A Preacher Whose Fire Transcends Stereotypes
description: ''The Apostle'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 9. The film opens today at Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: Blacks Recruited by 'Rights' Drive to End Preferences
description: As migrant labor goes, the signature-gathering campaign against affirmative action in Washington state seemed to offer just what Arthur Tillis of Chicago said he was looking for: a chance to earn some Christmas money and see a different part of the country.

title: Small Move for the Jets Is Big Leap for Jenkins
description: Things can happen fast in pro football.

title: Dresdner Bank Head to Quit in 2 Weeks
description: The chief executive of Dresdner Bank A.G. announced today that he would quit in two weeks, months earlier than he had originally planned, apparently because of a widening scandal over tax avoidance that has already engulfed several top bank executives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDER, GERALD
description: FRIEDER-Gerald. Died in California, December 15, 1997 of cancer. Husband of Mary Ann. Father of Gabby and Tom. Grandfather of Laura, brother of Larry.

title: Thailand Warns Currency Speculators
description: The Bank of Thailand said yesterday that it would take action against companies that it believes are speculating in dollars. ''The central bank will monitor who is buying dollars in a speculative way and will take measures to stop that,'' said Chaiyawat Wibulswasdi, the governor of the central bank. He did not say what measures would be taken.

title: Study Shows New York Has Greatest Income Gap
description: After years of Wall Street setting records while manufacturing jobs slipped away, the income gaps between the rich and the poor, and between the rich and the middle class, are now larger in New York than in any other state, according to a report released today.

title: Microsoft's Legal Problems Grow As States Join in Antitrust Effort
description: Last Thursday, as a Federal district judge was ruling that the Microsoft Corporation had violated a 1995 antitrust agreement with the Justice Department, attorneys general from some of the nation's most populous states were concluding a secret three-day meeting in Chicago to assess their own strategy for a possible antitrust action against Microsoft's marketing practices.

title: Thyssen-Krupp Merger Is Encountering Delays
description: Thyssen A.G. said yesterday that it had postponed an extraordinary board meeting scheduled for Friday until negotiators resolved tax and valuation questions about its planned merger with Fried. Krupp A. G. Hoesch-Krupp.

title: COLLEGES: WOMEN'S ROUNDUP
description: AUSTIN PEAY 71, GEORGIA 66

title: Lion Escapes Florida Zoo and Is Hunted by Land and Air
description: She is not exactly a warm and cuddly cartoon character. Nala, a 400-pound lion that escaped from her zoo cage on Monday, is described as sociable, laid back and declawed, but zoo and law-enforcement officials searching tonight for her said she posed a certain amount of danger if threatened.

title: John Braisted Jr., 90, Lawyer And Staten Island Prosecutor
description: John M. Braisted Jr., Staten Island's District Attorney from 1956 until he stepped down at the end of 1975, died on Dec. 9 at the home of his son, James, in West Brighton, Staten Island, where he had stayed for six days. He was 90 and lived on Staten Island in Silver Lake for more than 65 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSTON, EDITH L.
description: ROSSTON-Edith L. 1916 to 1997. Passed away in Atlantis, Florida. Formerly of Larchmont, N.Y. Husband Bernard, daughter Susan Rosenberg of Marietta, Ga., sister Eleanor Katz of NYC, two granddaughters. Memorial Service 3PM, Thursday, December 18, Dorsey Funeral Home, Lakeworth, FL.

title: Echlin Plans Acquisition
description: Echlin Inc. has agreed to acquire the General Automotive Specialty Company so it could add the company's locks and switches to its auto-parts line. Echlin, based in Branford, said it would pay cash but declined to disclose the price. The closely held General Automotive Specialty, based in North Brunswick, N.J., has factories in Alabama and Mexico and annual sales of about $50 million. Echlin had annual sales of $3.57 billion in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the University of Notre Dame's increasing academic stature referred incorrectly to donations for the university's $13 million Keough Institute for Irish Studies. Donald R. Keough, the former president of Coca-Cola, gave most of the money, not all of it. (The university declined to specify the size of the gift.)

title: Circle of Life: School, Homework, Broadway and Sleep
description: Scott Irby-Ranniar is laid out flat, clutching his Gameboy and playing a furious game that he refuses to interrupt even when a reporter strolls into his dressing room. ''Oh, no,'' he shouts as he desperately manipulates buttons on the game. He dies. He rises again. He moves to a new level -- all in the computer realm, mind you.

title: About New York; Say a Prayer For The Rector Of Forest Hills
description: YOU get this urge to genuflect when you enter Robert Cospito's living room. Could it be because the place is hushed? Or is it because of the statues of St. Francis and St. Jude that command places of honor? Maybe it's because of the altar, tabernacle and hefty organ. Definitely those three.

title: Treasury Prices End Higher in Light Trading
description: Treasury prices ended higher in thin trading yesterday, getting a lift in the afternoon after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged in its final policy meeting of the year.

title: DONNELLEY TO TAKE TWO CHARGES TOTALING $103 MILLION
description: The R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company said yesterday that it would take two fourth-quarter charges totaling $103 million, or 70 cents a share, for costs of reorganizing its ownership in Stream International Holdings Inc. and exiting some businesses. Shares of Donnelley fell 37.5 cents, to $37.25. Donnelley said a charge of $60 million, or 41 cents a share, would cover the reclassification of some of its stake in Stream International, a provider of technical support services and software, as discontinued operations. The second charge of $43 million, or 29 cents a share, covers Donnelley's exit from an array of businesses.

title: 'Capeman' Postponed
description: The opening of ''The Capeman,'' the new Paul Simon musical at the Marquis Theater, has been put off for three weeks, from Jan. 8 to Jan. 29, the show's producers announced yesterday. This will ''allow more time to rehearse and introduce new material to the show,'' they said in a statement. The musical, based on the true story of a Puerto Rican teen-ager in New York convicted of murder, has been in previews since Dec. 1.

title: Pataki Praises Proposal To Lower Truckers' Tolls
description: Gov. George E. Pataki gave qualified support yesterday for a plan to offer toll discounts for truck drivers who use bridges and tunnels in New York City during off-peak hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISEMAN, IRMA
description: WISEMAN-Irma. Loving wife of the late Abraham. Dear mother of Sam Wiseman and Sydney Kimmelman, beloved grandmother of Michael, Elisa, Daniel, Jessica, Dori and Jonathan. Great grandmother of six little ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYLE, MAX
description: LYLE-Max. Born in New York City, January 30, 1906 to Ben and Sarah Levy, died Sunday, December 14, 1997. A resident of Mission Viejo, CA., Max was a graduate of N.Y.U. School of Law, practiced as an attorney in civil law and later as a naval engineer. His hobby was Chinese brush painting. Max is survived by his beloved wife of 65 years, Selda; son, Dr. Sanford Lyle, his wife Linda; sister, Ceilia Levy; grandchildren, Scott Lyle, David Lyle and his wife Deanna, Allison Eisendrath and her husband Steven; great grandchildren, Katelyn and Ryan Eisendrath, Danielle and Max Lyle. Burial occurred Tuesday, December 16, 1997, at Pacific View Memorial Park, Newport Beach, CA.

title: Paper Warehouse Deal
description: Paper Warehouse Inc. plans to buy Gibson Greetings Inc.'s Paper Factory unit for about $38.6 million in cash to create the largest operator of retail party stores in the United States. The combined retail chains would have 314 stores. Paper Factory operates 190 party-goods retail outlets in 40 states, while Paper Warehouse, based in St. Louis Park, Minn., has 73 company-owned stores and 51 franchise stores in the Midwest.

title: Post Buying Computer Trade Magazines
description: The Washington Post Company has agreed to acquire several computer-industry trade publications and two trade shows from Reed Elsevier Inc. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Fed, Seeing Few Signs of Inflation, Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
description: The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, acting after the latest Government reports on the economy showed inflation remains benign despite vigorous economic growth.

title: The Federal Bureau of Independence
description: The best spectacle in Washington these days is Louis Freeh's defiant ride as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Attorney General Janet Reno has rejected his advice to appoint an independent counsel in the campaign finance case, and the President has pointedly declined to endorse his performance, but Mr. Freeh is still reporting to work every day at the F.B.I. fortress on Pennsylvania Avenue. Such independence must be maddening to the White House.

title: ALLIANCE BANCORP AGREES TO BUY SOUTHWEST BANCSHARES
description: Alliance Bancorp Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Southwest Bancshares Inc. in a stock swap valued about $90 million. Alliance, of Hinsdale, Ill., and Southwest Bancshares, of Hometown, Ill., are savings and loan holding companies. After the merger, Alliance would run 20 offices in Chicago and its suburbs with $1.8 billion in assets. Alliance would exchange 1.1981 of its shares for each Southwest common share. The final value of the deal, currently $31.75 a share, would be based on Alliance's common stock price at the deal's closing. Southwest's shares were up $2 yesterday at $30. Alliance was unchanged at $27.

title: Bombing Jury Is Given More Leeway in Verdicts
description: The Federal jury deliberating the charges against Terry L. Nichols in the Oklahoma City bombing has been given more latitude than the jury that convicted his co-defendant, Timothy J. McVeigh, on identical charges in June and sentenced him to death.

title: ITEQ IN DEAL FOR MATRIX, AN OILFIELD SERVICES COMPANY
description: Iteq Inc. said late on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy the Matrix Service Company, which provides oilfield services, for about $95 million in cash and stock, expanding its product line of equipment to process liquids. Matrix shareholders would be offered a choice of tendering each of their shares for either $10 cash or 0.83 share of Iteq. The cash portion of the deal is not to exceed 50 percent or be less than 30 percent of the total price. Shares of Iteq, which is based in Houston, closed yesterday at $11.75, up 62.5 cents. Matrix, of Tulsa, Okla., rose $1.25, to $9.4375.

title: Defying Pressure Over Iran Deal, Russians Spurn U.S. Loan Pact
description: Defying American pressure to end its business dealings with Iran, Russia's huge natural gas company, Gazprom, has canceled an agreement with the United States Export-Import Bank.

title: Defense Team in Brawley Case Calls Lawyer's Remark Racist
description: Complaints about racism flared anew today at the defamation lawsuit against three former advisers to Tawana Brawley when the plaintiff's lawyer twice referred to defendants and their lawyers as ''these people,'' prompting them to accuse him of brandishing loaded language.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIX, EDGAR
description: STIX-Edgar. Died at home December 16. Loving and beloved husband of Carol, devoted father of Allen, Wayne, Roger and Gail. Father-in-law of Robert Way and Jane Share. Life-long resident of Scarsdale, New York, served in Submarine Force in World War II, dedicated his life to family and close friends to whom he was a wise, generous and dependable mainstay. Memorial Service will be at McMahon Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains on Friday, December 19 at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to Planned Parenthood of Westchester, 11 Skyline Drive, Hawthorne, New York 10532 or The Cancer Research Fund, 675 Third Avenue, New York, New York 10017.

title: Clinton on His Foreign Policy: A Rose-Tinted World
description: Although he acknowledged that work remained to be done, President Clinton gave a remarkably upbeat assessment of his Administration's foreign-policy achievements at his news conference on Tuesday, a kind of sneak preview of his 1998 State of the Union Message.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSON, GARY J.
description: BENSON-Gary J. Of Bernardsville, N.J., on December 15, 1997 after subsequent complications from a failed kidney transplant. Devoted husband of Susan Stilgenbauer. Loving brother of Glen and Gerald Benson. Son of Katherine Pershyn Benson. Friends and family are invited to the Benson residence December 19, 1997 at 7 PM for a memorial service. In lieu of flowers, donations to Attn: Carol Cahill, Morristown Mem. Hospital, CAPD Patient Fund, 100 Madison Avenue, Morristown, New Jersey 07960. The Cochran Funeral Home, 905 High St., Hackettstown, New Jersey 07840 for information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSTEIN, HOWARD
description: ROSENSTEIN-Howard. On Wednesday, December 17th, 1997, of Loch Sheldrake, NY, formerly of Maplewood, NJ. Dear brother of the late Herbert Rosenstein, brother-in-law of Harriet Rosenstein, cherished uncle of Bonnie Sue Notis, Barry Stuart and Dr. Peter Alan Rosenstein. Graveside service at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, New Jersey, Friday, December 19 at 2 PM. For info: the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, N.J.

title: Roger Brown Is Dead at 72; Wrote Key Psychology Texts
description: Roger Brown, who turned the attention of many psychologists to the question of how children learn language and who wrote two classic psychology textbooks, died on Dec. 11 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 72.

title: More Buses and Workers Are Proposed
description: New York City Transit plans to spend about $85 million for new buses and personnel to meet the expected increase in demand caused by the recently announced discount passes and fare cuts, agency officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOTZKIN, ARTHUR
description: MOTZKIN-Arthur. The staff of the 92nd Street Y Nursery School mourn the death of Arthur Motzkin, beloved father of our devoted director and dear friend, Nancy Schulman. We grieve with the entire Motzkin-Schulman family over the passing of this very special man.

title: Fearing Errors, U.S. Will Review Cutoff in Aid to Disabled Youths
description: The Clinton Administration said tonight that it would re-examine the cases of 60,000 poor children who were denied disability benefits in the last year because it had concluded that the Government might have made mistakes.

title: CAMDEN PROPERTY IN $392 MILLION DEAL FOR OASIS
description: Camden Property Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Oasis Residential Inc. for $392 million in stock. Camden, based in Houston, and Oasis, of Henderson, Nev., are apartment real estate investment trusts. The merger gives Camden a base for expansion in the Western and Rocky Mountain regions, the company said. Upon closing, Camden would have 51,377 apartment units and total assets of $2.3 billion. Camden's shares closed yesterday at $31.125, down 87.5 cents, and Oasis gained 50 cents a share, to $22.6875.

title: WHITMAN, PREPARING FOR SPINOFFS, DECLARES DIVIDENDS
description: The board of the Whitman Corporation declared a dividend yesterday of stock in the Hussmann Corporation and Midas International as part of a planned spinoff of the businesses as Whitman focuses on its Pepsi-Cola bottling operations. Whitman, which runs the world's largest independent Pepsi bottler, said its shareholders would receive one share of stock in its Hussmann refrigeration systems and services company for every two Whitman shares as well as one share in its Midas automotive muffler and brake-repair chain for every six Whitman shares held on Jan. 16. Shares of Whitman fell 18.75 cents yesterday, to $25.75. Earlier this month, the Internal Revenue Service said the spinoffs would be tax-free.

title: So Graceful, So Fragile: A Skater's Remarkable Recovery
description: Had someone suggested a year ago that she would rejoin the top female skaters in the world, that she would conquer a severe viral infection to become a contender for an Olympic medal, Tanja Szewczenko of Germany would have broken into laughter. Or tears.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIGGS, GEORGE PEARSON
description: BIGGS-George Pearson. Age 91, of Southport, CT., died on Monday, December 15th, 1997. He was a graduate of the Hill School and Yale University. Survivors include his wife, Jane Shaw Biggs of Southport; sons, G. Whitney Biggs and his wife, Pauline, of Southport; and James P. Biggs and his wife, Elinor, of Greens Farms; two stepsons, William Reiter of Riverton, Wyo., and Brian Reiter of Miami, FL.; a sister, Jessie P. Smith; and grandchildren, nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be Friday, December 19 at 11 AM, in Southport Congregational Church, Pequot Avenue, Southport. For more information, contact Spear Funeral Home, Fairfield, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIGIOVANNA, ANTHONY J.
description: DiGIOVANNA-Anthony J. Retired Justice of The Supreme Court of New York State. Died Dec. 16, 1997 at home. Survived by his beloved wife Tigelia, dear sister of Rose Liotta, devoted children John C. DiGiovanna, Nina La Bruna, Honorable Maria DiGiovanna, eight grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. Viewing at Duffy Funeral Home, 718-499-8700.

title: Public Eye; One second you're James Taylor, the next you're Freud
description: IMAGINE being in a room surrounded by a dozen floating smiley faces, a few busty ''Baywatch'' beauties, some vaguely threatening cartoon thugs and one boozy Dean Martin head. This is no nightmare, no acid flashback.

title: U.S. Assails Microsoft and Seeks New Oversight Role
description: The Federal Government today accused Microsoft of violating last week's antitrust ruling, and argued that prosecutors should be given a rarely used authority to review in advance new products by the software giant.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When PETER TIBORIS steps to the podium to conduct the Brooklyn Philharmonic in Carnegie Hall on Jan. 18, he will be using a baton once owned by Leonard Bernstein.

title: Sports of The Times; This Prince Better Not Be a Pauper
description: IN boxing's steady surrender to wrestling's show biz instead of biz, the houselights at Madison Square Garden will darken tomorrow night, music will thump and Prince Naseem Hamed will disco-dance through pseudo smoke along a 200-foot runway to the ring, somersault over the top rope and land on the canvas. Feet first, presumably.

title: Nextlevel Gets Orders Totaling $4.5 Billion
description: Nextlevel Systems Inc. said today that it had won $4.5 billion in orders from nine cable-television operators for a new generation of boxes that will bring higher-quality TV pictures and interactive services into the home.

title: On the Road to Monterrey; Success of Mexican Bus Companies Eludes Greyhound
description: In the borderland battle of the bus lines, Omar Rendon is the quarry. At 2:30 A.M. on a recent Saturday, he sat on a stoop at a border station here in the Rio Grande Valley, his Igloo cooler by his side as he stoically recounted his nearly weekly migration.

title: Money, Not Miracles, Is Reviving South Bronx; Shortsighted Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Vietnam Creditor Banks To Forgive $451 Million
description: Vietnam's creditor banks have agreed to write off $451 million in debt dating to the 1970's, clearing the way for the country to sell its first international bonds, officials said yesterday. Vietnam will pay the rest of the $851.9 million it owes a group of mainly Japanese commercial banks with the proceeds from the sale of 30-year Brady bonds it is planning for early next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINSTEIN, ANNE
description: FEINSTEIN-Anne. December 17, 1997, of Tamarac, FL., formerly of Brooklyn and Teaneck, NJ. Loving wife of Samuel with whom she shared a 57-year marriage and lifelong romance. Adored mother of Richard (Roberta), Paul (Joan) and Robert (Helene) Feinstein. Cherished grandmother of Rikki (fiancee-Howard), Ross, Evan and Jarrod. Services Friday, Dec. 19, 1997, 1PM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury.

title: Money, Not Miracles, Is Reviving South Bronx
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIM, STEPHEN
description: OPPENHEIM-Stephen. Congregation Kol Ami of White Plains records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member, and conveys sincere condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Cantor Annie Bornstein-Howard Mark Hershey, President

title: Rangers Get Respite From Their Recent Doldrums
description: Even in a dreary season of too many defeats, plentiful trade rumors, a few superstar slumps and constant rumors about the coach's job security, there are nights when a struggling team can feel good about itself.

title: Clinics Aim At Creating New Habits On Slopes
description: Robert Foppiano, a middle school teacher from New York City, was skiing for more than a decade before he took his first lesson. As a self-taught skier, he had always been able to get down the hill fast, but without much form.

title: Mistrial Declared in Dispute Over Billionaire's Empire
description: A Dallas probate court judge dismissed deadlocked jurors and declared a mistrial yesterday in a bitter battle between Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas billionaire, and two daughters for control of his business empire.

title: Trains Complete Holiday Landscape at Botanical Garden
description: EIGHT large-gauge model trains are chugging around a landscape of more than 6,000 square feet in the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. An arbitrary imagination has been at work here -- one that encompasses buildings in all five boroughs, London Bridge and a 30-foot Christmas tree. It is just the kind of fantasy world children like.

title: Behind Facade of Calamity, Life Goes On
description: The great paradox of The Building is that it may be safer to be inside it than outside it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Fraschilla Tastes Victory in His Return
description: When he was coach of Manhattan College, Fran Fraschilla relished these backyard skirmishes against St. John's, the neighbor who got all the attention. Now Fraschilla is discovering that life on the other side of the fence has its advantages.

title: Mets Make Investment In International Market
description: Like gold miners in the 19th century, major league teams are rushing into the international market for untapped veins of talent. Yesterday, the Mets signed what they believe is an 18-karat pitcher from South Korea.

title: Canadian Senate: Substantial Power but Not Much Attendance
description: They call Canada's Senate ''the red chamber,'' but no crimson carpet could match the embarrassed faces of senators since word of their generally woeful attendance records generated public outrage across the country.

title: Metro Business; Utility to Buy Back Shares
description: Orange and Rockland Utilities of Pearl River, N.Y., said yesterday that it had won regulator approval to spend $25 million to repurchase 4.3 percent of its shares.

title: For the Elderly, Drink a Day Can Be Dangerous
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page contents entry in The Metro Section yesterday about the proposed increase in the New Jersey cigarette tax misstated the amount. The tax would rise by 40 cents a pack, not 40 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOUILLOUD, MICHEL
description: GOUILLOUD-Michel. Scientist, Socialist. Died November 16, 1997 at Plantat in Quissac, France. He was loved by Patrice M. Regnier.

title: Conservatives' Voices Enter Clinton's Dialogue on Race
description: Shaking off criticism that it has been conducting a desultory monologue rather than a spirited dialogue on race, President's Clinton's race relations panel engaged in an often-testy debate here today over the use of vouchers to allow students to attend public or private schools of their choice.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about an opera fan who has closely followed the career of the tenor Richard Leech misstated the month of his 100th performance at the Metropolitan Opera. It was March 24, 1997, not May 24.

title: Frugal Koreans Rush to Rescue Their Rapidly Sinking Economy
description: Choi Jae Hyun came to the bank today carrying a small plastic bag containing American pennies and quarters, Canadian dollars, Malaysian ringgit and Chinese yuan. He and his colleagues at work had taken up a collection of the change and small bills left over from their overseas trips and sent Mr. Choi to exchange them for Korean won.

title: A Fresh Approach to Child-Neglect Cases
description: About three-quarters of the child-neglect cases in courts around the nation involve parents who abuse alcohol or drugs. So it only makes sense that the New York State court system has launched an experiment aimed at getting troubled parents into closely monitored treatment programs. The outcome of a year's treatment, typically administered while the abused child is placed in temporary foster care, will determine the best long-term disposition for the child.

title: Stewart Grand Prix Backed by M.C.I.
description: Two weeks ago, organizers of the international Formula One championship series asked Jackie Stewart, the former world champion, for guarantees that his team would have enough sponsorship funds in 1998 to complete its second season. But what the International Automobile Federation didn't know -- because Stewart wasn't at liberty to tell them -- was that the Scot's pockets were about to get a lot deeper.

title: For Betty Buckley, a Large Offstage Cast
description: When Betty Buckley goes onstage in ''Triumph of Love,'' she is, as always, a figure of strength and confidence. Whether playing the starchily repressed, secretly passionate Hesione in that new show or Norma Desmond in ''Sunset Boulevard'' -- or singing in a concert hall or a nightclub -- she is, at 50, a reigning diva of the musical theater. But, as Ms. Buckley is the first to admit, she does not do it all by herself.

title: Fighter Doesn't Mind Playing Second Fiddle
description: With the verbal volleys that have been lobbed back and forth between Kevin Kelley and Prince Naseem Hamed this week, it would be understandable if Junior Jones felt overshadowed. But he doesn't.

title: Judge Puts Off New Tests For Automobile Emissions
description: Gasoline retailers have obtained a court order blocking implementation of New York State's new automobile emissions testing program, which was to go into effect Jan. 2 in New York City and Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties.

title: Court Finds Evidence Against Tobacco Giant
description: Nearly 20 years ago, the world's second largest cigarette company apparently considered breaking ranks with industry colleagues and admitting that smoking caused disease because denials of that link were not credible, according to court papers unsealed yesterday in Minnesota.

title: Hubble Takes Gaudy Photos Of Dying Stars
description: In a preview of the Sun's fate in another five billion years, the Hubble Space Telescope has taken detailed pictures of stars in their death throes, spectacles of glowing gases expanding in striking and colorful patterns and scattering through the heavens the chemical raw material for successive generations of stars, planets and perhaps life.

title: Tobacco Lawyers' Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: About Section B
description: The Metro Section is printed in two parts today. Part 2, including holiday season fashion news, begins on page B17.

title: American Freed in Mexico
description: Vincent Carrozza, the American manager of the Princess Hotel in Acapulco who was kidnapped Dec. 9, has been freed, his company announced today in New York. The company did not reveal whether or how much ransom was paid.

title: When High Stakes Meet Accountability
description: Fran Fraschilla is an East Coast coach; Jerry Pimm is way out West. Fraschilla, 39, came of age in an era of egocentric athletes. Pimm, 59, the coach at California-Santa Barbara, had his values formed in the late 50's when players did what they were told. This week, each confronted the challenge of balancing discipline with the need to win.

title: A Zoo Lion Is Recaptured in Good Shape
description: A 400-pound lioness that escaped from her cage at a central Florida zoo on Monday was re-captured today in a nearby swamp ''in good shape,'' a law-enforcement official said.

title: Foreign Affairs; Mahathir's Wrath
description: There are many ways to depict Malaysia's economic crisis. My preference would be to stage it as an Off Broadway play. It would be called ''King Lear Meets the Hedge Funds.''

title: Steps to Revive Asia
description: In Japan, questions arose as to whether a tax-cut plan was bold enough. As the woes of Japan and South Korea mounted, President Clinton became increasingly involved in pushing revival plans. Business Day, pages D1 and D8.

title: Gambling Has a Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Meek Knicks Let Another Road Game Slip Away
description: The once unruly Knicks have turned into the perfect house guests these days.

title: Hoboken in Devils' Future?
description: John McMullen, the Devils' owner, has ''serious interest'' in an arena that could be built in Hoboken, N.J., and will clarify his position tomorrow at a news conference there.

title: In Each Neighborhood There Lies a Special Shop; E Shop's Emphasis Is Exotic Whimsy
description: Within a 10-block radius of the E Shop, owned by Jon Berry and the single-named Epperson, two designers who sell women's and men's clothing, live Edward Wilkerson, a senior designer at Donna Karan; Marc Baptiste, the photographer; Shaka King, the men's-wear designer; Montgomery Harris, the women's-wear designer; Shabaka, an artist and designer whose wares are sold in the 4W Circle gallery across the street; Therez Fleetwood, the designer and a creative consultant to Avon, and Margo T. Lewis, a fashion show producer and Parsons School of Design auditorium coordinator.

title: Allianz and Generali Agree to Carve Up AGF
description: Allianz A.G. and Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A., the largest insurers in Germany and Italy, have agreed to carve up AGF Assurances, France's third-largest insurer, AGF's chief executive, Antoine Jeancourt-Galignani, said yesterday. The agreement means Generali will not top Allianz's $10.4 billion offer for Assurances Generales de France. The battle started on Oct. 13 with Generali offering $9.5 billion for AGF.

title: U.S. Presses Palestinians To Rein In Radicals
description: As the Israeli Cabinet struggles to deliver what the Americans call a ''significant and credible'' plan to withdraw from the West Bank, Washington is pressing the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat for a detailed written plan to root out the military wing of the radical Hamas movement, senior American and Israeli officials say.

title: Gill Gives The Nets The Goods In the End
description: Last season's go-to man had almost become the Nets' forgotten man this season.

title: Host Marriott Acquisition
description: The Host Marriott Corporation said today that it would buy the Coronado Island Le Meridien in Coronado, Calif., for $54.4 million as it expands in California. The 300-room hotel, which is in the San Diego area, will be renamed the Coronado Island Marriott Resort and will be managed by Marriott International Inc. Host Marriott said it had spent more than $1.6 billion on acquisitions this year.

title: Market Place; A flamboyant businessman is accused of stock manipulation.
description: GORDON HALL had been king of the hill -- literally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, DONALD M.
description: ROSS-Donald M. Died peacefully on Wednesday, December 17, 1997. Beloved father of Lori Ross Weiss and Sheri Ross Mendes, and father-in-law to Jim Weiss and Joe Mendes. Loving grandfather of Emily, Hilary, Alissa and Phil. Brother of Richard Ross of Mount Vernon and Arthur Ross of Hawaii. Longtime companion and friend of Laura Hertzig. Services at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY, Friday, December 19, at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNTON, MARK
