description: LYNTON-Mark. Beloved husband of Marion, father of Michael and Lili, grandfather of Claire, Nina, Kate, Eloise, Maisie. Visitation December 18, 19 from 2 to 4, 48 W. 70 St., December 20, 21, 11:30 to 2:30 961 Fenimore Road, Larchmont.

title: Mormons and Polygamy
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TIMKEN CO., Canton, Ohio, the maker of roller bearings, agreed to pay $37 million for a 70 percent stake in SC Rulmenti Grei S.A., a Romanian state-controlled heavy-bearings maker.

title: U.S. Judge Assesses Cuba $187 Million in Deaths of 4 Pilots
description: The Cuban Government and its Air Force ''murdered'' four pilots for an exile group whose two unarmed civilian planes were shot down nearly two years ago, and must pay $187.6 million in compensatory and punitive damages to the families of three of the pilots, a Federal judge here ruled today.

title: Walt Disney's Widow, Lillian, Dies at 98
description: Lillian Disney, the widow of Walt Disney and a prominent patron of the arts, died on Tuesday at her home in the Holmby Hills section of Los Angeles after suffering a stroke on Monday. She was 98.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHN, MICHAEL
description: KUHN-Michael. Age 95, passed away on December 16, 1997, 17th of Kislev, in White Plains, New York; beloved husband of Gertha; father of Liane Novick, Ralph Kuhn and Eva Stern; grandfather of Stephen, Lisa, Gregg, Adam, Erika, Suzy and Oren; great-grandfather of Jessica, Daniel, Brett and Sarah. Gertha Kuhn will be sitting Shiva at her home, The Esplanade, White Plains. Opa, throughout your life you touched countless lives, you are missed, loved, and remembered.

title: Film Executive Is Charged In Sex Case
description: Four years ago, a wealthy former executive vice president at Warner Brothers named Sidney Kiwitt ventured from his suburban home in Ridgefield Park, N.J., to the streets of the Bronx, the police said. There, according to investigators, he met a prostitute named Marisol Sanders.

title: Stocks Fall as Lower Earnings Are Expected
description: Wall Street quickly brushed aside a rally in Asia yesterday, as news of unexpected fourth-quarter earnings shortfalls pushed most major stock market indexes lower for the first time this week.

title: Police Department Cuts the Detail Guarding Louima
description: The Police Department has cut the number of officers guarding Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant who said he was badly beaten by Brooklyn police officers, and he said yesterday that he was worried for his own safety and that of his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINZER, ESTELLE
description: LINZER-Estelle. On December 16. Beloved sister of Dulcie and Walter Schackman. Devoted aunt of Paul, Bruce and Daniel Schackman. Respected leader and friend of many in the UN/NGO community throughout her long affiliations with the United Nations Association of the United States and the Eleanor Roosevelt Center at ValKill. Contributions in her memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: In Each Neighborhood There Lies a Special Shop; Study in Contrasts At SoHo Boutique
description: For his Costume National store in SoHo, the Italian designer Ennio Capasa has created a wonderously strange amalgam of Beam-me-up-Scotty and warm cocooning. Black from floor to ceiling, the store is dotted with glowing cubes of white light: eight are on the ceiling and one huge encasement rises from the center like a futuristic shrine to fashion.

title: In Jamaica, Violence Is the Issue
description: Because elections here are notoriously violent, Jamaicans were hardly surprised when the campaign leading up to Thursday's parliamentary election began with a gun battle. As rival motorcades representing the country's two main political parties traveled through a divided district early this month, both were fired on, and a dozen people were wounded.

title: Big Gift to Israel Museum
description: The Israel Museum in Jerusalem said yesterday that it received a $42 million pledge from an American businessman to construct a visitor orientation center for its six-building complex, the largest single capital gift in the museum's 32-year history.

title: D'Amato Again Attacks Teachers Union on Tenure Issue
description: Stepping up his attacks on the teachers union, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato used separate appearances in the state capital today to challenge the Legislature to enact a controversial measure to end automatic tenure for public school teachers.

title: Her House Burning, a Socialite Dies Trying to Save a Guest
description: Generous to the last, Kitty Meyer struggled up the burning staircase of her multimillion-dollar, art-filled town house on the Upper East Side before dawn yesterday trying to save a house guest.

title: Gun Makers Learn From Tobacco Fight
description: In a battle that echoes the attack on the tobacco industry, advocates of gun control are hitting the nation's gun manufacturers with a torrent of litigation and legislation to force those companies to make safer guns and accept responsibility for the violence their products can cause.

title: New York Sues to Block 21 New Flights at La Guardia
description: The City's Corporation Counsel sued the Federal Government yesterday to stop it from adding 21 new flights a day at La Guardia Airport, arguing that the extra traffic at the already congested airport would compromise the safety of air travelers and Queens residents.

title: Nippon Life Buys American Express Stake
description: The Nippon Life Insurance Company is converting $355.6 million of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. preferred stock into 4.4 million common shares of the American Express Company, Lehman's former parent.

title: Judge Excludes Evidence In Royster Murder Case
description: A Manhattan judge ruled yesterday that bloody clothing recovered from the home of John J. Royster, who is accused of killing one woman and brutalizing three others in an eight-day crime spree last year, was inadmissible because it was seized in an illegal search of his apartment.

title: Compatriots Honor a Master
description: The Sibelius Festival at Lincoln Center, called Northern Lights, ended on Monday night, not with the composer's music but his legacy.

title: In Each Neighborhood There Lies a Special Shop; Etro's Madison Avenue Elegance
description: Despite the fact that it is housed in a six-story stucco and limestone building of classic elegance on a heavily trafficked shopping street, Etro has managed to keep a low profile.

title: Derivatives Rules Are Postponed
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board today delayed putting into effect sharply criticized rules on derivatives to give banks more time to adjust their computer and accounting systems, a board spokeswoman said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the writer E. L. Doctorow misstated the title of one of his plays. It is ''Drinks Before Dinner,'' not ''Drinks With Dinner.''

title: Yale Loses Lawsuit In AIDS Needle Case
description: A jury ordered Yale University to pay $12.2 million to a first-year medical intern who was infected with the AIDS virus after sticking herself with a needle in 1988. The jury said improper training led to the injury.

title: 5th Graders to Move Out Of a Troublesome School
description: After months of wrangling, the Atlantic City superintendent of schools and the State Education Commissioner have agreed on a plan to remove 465 fifth graders from a troubled middle school by Jan. 5.

title: A Prominent Mexican Vanishes, and Abduction Rumors Abound
description: One of Mexico's most renowned and feared political figures, a former chief of internal security, has dropped from public view, setting off widespread speculation that he has been kidnapped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MECHCATIE, REZA, M.D.
description: MECHCATIE-Reza, M.D. Born in Rasht, Iran on July 7, 1929, to the late Abdullah and Marzieh Mizrameshkatikhan, died in Rye, New York on December 16, 1997. A graduate of the University of Tehran and the University of Paris Medical School, Dr. Mechcatie was an internist and cardiologist with a private practice in Rye and was associated with United Hospital Medical Center for over 30 years. He is survived by his beloved wife Audrey Yearsley Mechcatie, his sons Oliver C. and Anthony P. Mechcatie, his daughter Elizabeth M. Vanegas, her husband Enrique and their children Sabina Grace and Maximilian. Dr. Mechcatie will be deeply missed by his family and friends, colleagues and patients, and will always be remembered for his dedication to his community. His family will receive friends at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, New York from 2:00 PM to 4:00 PM and from 7:00 PM to 9:00 PM on Friday, December 19, 1997. Funeral Services will be held Saturday, December 20, 1997, 1:30 PM at Christ's Episcopal Church, Rye, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to United Hospital Medical Center, 406 Boston Post Rd., Port Chester, New York 10573.

title: Money, Not Miracles, Is Reviving South Bronx; Dominican Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, LEON
description: LEWIS-Leon. Peacefully on December 17, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Elaine (nee Fleishman). Loving father of Bonnie Rodney and Barbara Lewis Kaplan. Devoted brother of Victor Lewis. Caring grandfather of Elizabeth Rodney, Emily Rodney, Julia Kaplan and Benjamin Kaplan. Beloved fatherin-law of Michael Rodney and Seth Kaplan. For further information contact John J. Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont, New York. Memorial donations to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial, Washington, DC or Museum of the Jewish Heritage, New York, New York.

title: Begrudging a Little, Bestowing a Lot
description: Lest you feared that Las Vegas was slowing down, here comes a peppy look at the town's high rollers, smart players, big stars and young prostitutes. Tonight's edition of ''48 Hours'' peers behind the scenes, around the suites, through the detection devices and into the cells where few ordinary fun makers are likely to find themselves.

title: Hopping Off Soon in Brooklyn: Tours by Double-Decker Bus
description: With guided tours and scheduled stops along Manhattan's major traffic routes, tour buses have become a popular way for tourists to visit the borough's many attractions, like the Empire State Building, the World Trade Center and Harlem churches.

title: The New Military Segregation
description: The armed forces should not remedy their gender-integration problems by segregating women. Separating the sexes during basic training, as recommended by a Pentagon advisory committee, would be a step backward for sexual equality in a military culture that should be pushed harder to make integration work.

title: Alitalia Chooses KLM As International Partner
description: Alitalia S.p.A. has chosen KLM Royal Dutch Airlines N.V. as its international partner, culminating a months-long search. After a meeting of the board of the Italian state holding company Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, Andrea Monorchio, chairman of IRI's internal audit committee, said KLM had been chosen over Air France and Swissair as its partner in an alliance to funnel passengers to each other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAILLARD, RICHARD
description: GAILLARD-Richard. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York wish to express their heartfelt condolences to Jane Gaillard, an esteemed member of our Board of Directors, upon the loss of her beloved father, Richard Gaillard. We extend our profound sympathy at this time to her family. Carol Raphael President and CEO Carl H. Pforzheimer III Chairman, Board of Directors

title: Kidnapped Queens Man Is Found Burned to Death
description: The body of a man kidnapped in central Queens on Monday was discovered last night in an abandoned car on Interstate 280 in Kearny, N.J., the police said. The badly burned body of the man, Eriberto Acevedo, 31, was found in the trunk of the car, which had been set on fire.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Dec. 3 described safety concerns about Canadian-made nuclear power plants sold abroad. It included an estimate that Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd., the manufacturer of a power plant type known as Candu, had received $10 billion in Canadian Government subsidies since 1952. The article should have pointed out that the estimate was made by an antinuclear group and that the company says it has received less than $4 billion.

title: Aikman Sees Future in Dallas
description: Troy Aikman said yesterday in a conference call with New York area reporters that he would like to play five or six more seasons with the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Milutinovic Could Coach in M.L.S.
description: After Bora Milutinovic was discharged as coach of Mexico's national soccer team yesterday, two things became apparent: he is expected to resurface next season in Major League Soccer and he will not play any role with the United States team during the 1998 World Cup in France.

title: State Court Rejects New Appeal in Murder Trial
description: A defendant's admission under a plea bargain that he tried to kill his girlfriend can be used against him later, in a murder case brought after the woman died, New York State's highest court ruled today.

title: Hambrecht & Quist's Chairman to Retire
description: William R. Hambrecht, who is 62, said yesterday that he would retire on Jan. 1 as chairman of Hambrecht & Quist, the San Francisco investment bank that he founded in 1968 with George Quist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMOND, RODNEY EARL
description: HAMMOND-Rodney Earl. Passed away on December 13, of lymphoma. Son of the late Earl and Eunice Hammond. Survived by brother, Richard; two nephews and a niece, and by close friends, Charles Beattie and Allan Weiss. Born on 13 April, 1933, in Sioux City, Iowa. Graduated Lemars High School in 1951. Bachelor's Degree from the University of Colorado Boulder. A naval aviator from June of 1955 until April of 1959. Funeral will be in Merrill, Iowa, on 3 January.

title: TV Cartoon's Flashes Send 700 Japanese Into Seizures
description: One moment they were happily munching on their dinner and watching their favorite cartoon show on television. The next moment, hundreds of children across the country were shaking and convulsing and being rushed to hospitals.

title: Acquisition by Four Media
description: The Four Media Company said today that it had agreed to acquire Visualize Inc., which operates as POP Studios. Financial terms were not disclosed. POP Studios, a provider of technical and creative services to TV and film companies, had 1996 revenues of about $32.5 million. Four Media, based in Burbank, provides similar services. The company had revenues of $84.5 million for the year ended Aug. 3.

title: Big Names May Be Out, But Strawberry Seems In
description: A coy George Steinbrenner initially cast doubt upon the possibility that the Yankees might obtain a marquee player, such as the All-Star second baseman Chuck Knoblauch from the Minnesota Twins, for a pile of prospects, but yesterday he added that it is too early to squash the potential for a sizable trade.

title: Guardian Royal To Buy Health Insurer
description: Guardian Royal Exchange P.L.C., a British insurer, said yesterday that it would buy the PPP Healthcare Group P.L.C., Britain's second-largest health insurer, for $:435 million ($718 million) to expand its health care coverage. Guardian will buy the health care provider from PPP Healthcare Foundation, a British charity. Combined with $:125 million paid to the foundation by PPP Healthcare Group in a dividend before the acquisition, the foundation will receive $:560 million in total.

title: Our Towns; Feeding The Luckless In Casino City
description: ABOUT three years ago, when the house she was renting on downtown Indiana Avenue went into foreclosure, Jean Webster moved into a wooden row house on a private lane near the casino zone. It was a small blessing, a quiet sanctuary between Kentucky and New York Avenues, away from the crazy traffic and troubles of the surrounding neighborhood. But then people began sleeping in an empty lot at the end of the block.

title: South Korea Delays Plans To Inject Money Into Banks
description: The Government postponed plans today to inject money into six of South Korea's biggest banks, meeting a demand of the International Monetary Fund one day before the agency was to decide whether to release the second installment of a $57 billion rescue package.

title: INSIDE
description: Microsoft Battle Escalates

title: For Finale, Giants Weigh Pride, Caution and Revenge
description: The Giants are conflicted. Fortunately for them, the Dallas Cowboys await to help them sort out their feelings.

title: Crisis Shakes Poise of Businesses
description: Sitting tiredly in his office, 36 floors above the streets of Seoul, Kim Yun Ho seethed with frustration.

title: America West Picks Riney for Account
description: America West Airlines in Phoenix said yesterday that it had named Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco to handle its account, with billings estimated at $24 million. The account had been handled since March 1995 by Team One Advertising in El Segundo, Calif., a unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. that resigned last month rather than participate in a review.

title: 'Capeman' Team Says Delay Doesn't Spell Trouble
description: After announcing this week that the Broadway opening of the Paul Simon musical ''The Capeman'' would be delayed for three weeks to Jan. 29, the producers were busily squelching rumors yesterday that the show was in trouble and that veteran directors were being brought in to save it.

title: INSIDE
description: The transit agency plans for a big jump in demand.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There's a Korean saying, that by gathering dust you can create a mountain.''

title: Reality and Rights in Central Africa
description: Madeleine Albright's agenda on her recent weeklong visit to Africa was seemingly straightforward: to announce that the United States will be more engaged with Africa.

title: Airline Wins Suit on Weight Limits of Attendants
description: New York's highest court ruled yesterday that Delta Air Lines did not violate state law when it refused to hire job applicants who exceeded the company's weight limitations for flight attendants, and said it did not discriminate against the applicants by asking their age and marital status.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, CLAIRE MARIE
description: CARROLL-Claire Marie. Dec. 14, 1997. Loving daughter of the late Joseph F. and Helen Joyce Carroll of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved sister of Joyce Carroll O'Neil and the late Joseph F. Carroll, Jr and Richard J. Carroll. Beloved aunt of Stephen L. and Pamela Carroll of Jacksonville, FL. She was associated professionally in the public relations field and actively supported many charitable organizations including serving on the executive committee of the auxillary of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. She was the past secretary and active member of the Turtle Bay Association. She also was an avid supporter of many Republican campaigns. Friends may call at the Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81 Street), Wednesday, from 6-9:00 P.M. Funeral Mass at Holy Family Church, on Thursday, December 18, 1997, at 10:00AM. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of NY, 153 W 11 St, NY, NY 10011

title: Salo Stops the Sabres As Isles Get a Shutout
description: Tommy Salo heard his name chanted time and again, and he deserved the adulation he received tonight from the crowd at Nassau Coliseum. Playing his 100th game in the National Hockey League, Salo came up with an inspiring performance that led the Islanders to a 4-0 triumph over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: The Pop Life
description: Stones Tour Ranks No. 1

title: WINSTAR PLANS TO ACQUIRE BULK OF MIDCOM ASSETS
description: Winstar Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to buy most of the assets of Midcom Communications Inc. for $92 million in cash. Winstar would acquire Midcom's long-distance business, with $80 million in annual revenue and 45,000 customers, and Pacnet Inc., Midcom's frame relay subsidiary with annual revenue of nearly $20 million. The agreement excludes Midcom's conference calling business and its facsimile broadcast services. The purchase would give Winstar, a New York-based provider of local and long-distance calling services, a 200-member sales force. The agreement must be approved by the bankruptcy court where Midcom, of Southfield, Mich., filed for Chapter 11 protection on Nov. 7.

title: TRW Planning A Satellite Deal
description: TRW Inc. said today that it was abandoning its Odyssey space-based telecommunications project and was instead buying a 7 percent stake in the London-based ICO Global Communications, using ICO's existing project to gain a foothold in the satellite communications business.

title: Citicorp Is Said To Be Acquiring AT&T Card Unit
description: Citicorp, the nation's second-largest bank, has emerged as the winning bidder for the AT&T Corporation's credit card business, offering $4 billion for the unit, bankers and advisers close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, LENORE
description: GOLDSTEIN - Lenore. Beloved wife of Paul; loving mother of Robert and Vivian; inspiring mother-in-law to Tom and Jan and adoring grandmother to Juliet. Elegant, dynamic, inspiration to young and old, with the highest cultural standard and a great lover of music, artist, writer with a boundless enthusiasm for life. Service today at Riverside Chapels, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave, 11:15 AM.

title: G.O.P. Convention Spent Past Its Limit, Federal Audit Says
description: Auditors for the Federal Election Commission contend that Republicans circumvented Federal spending limits on their convention last year, and they recommend that the Republican Party return $3.7 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of an article yesterday about the author of the novel upon which the coming Paramount film ''The Education of Little Tree'' is based omitted the final word. The movie's director and screenwriter, expressing worry about competition, said: ''It's tough enough going against 25 films opening in December. But going against 'Titanic.' Sure, it concerns me.''

title: Books to Tide Gardeners Over Till Spring
description: PERIPHERAL vision is as necessary to gardening as to any other sport. Three new books from the far edges of the garden world can give a sense of perspective to any gardener locked indoors this winter.

title: The Yen Rises On Hope for Japan Growth
description: The yen soared yesterday, knocking the value of the dollar down 2.8 percent after Japanese officials surprised the currency markets with a one-two punch.

title: At NATO, Russia Voices Opposition to Any Raids Against Iraq
description: The Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, told the United States and other NATO members here today that Russia remained opposed to the use of force to get Iraq to permit full international inspection of suspected storage sites for biological and chemical weapons stockpiles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCORMACK, MICHAEL J.
description: McCORMACK-Michael J. December 15, 1997. Beloved son of the late Michael and the late Bridget (nee Carey). Dear brother of James, Ann Gaffney and the late Margaret, Mary Teague, Agnes and Sister M. Rose de Lima, O.P. (Sparkill Dominicans). Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Wednesday 7-9 and Thursday 3-5 and 7-9. Requiem Mass Friday December 19, 12 noon, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84 Street. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: HEALTH CARE'S GIANT: Artful Accounting -- A special report.; Hospital Chain Cheated U.S. On Expenses, Documents Show
description: It was just a single number, one of thousands of hospital costs listed on a bulky document. But in it lay the heart of the scandal that has rocked the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation.

title: Mayor Vows to Contest Holiday Display Ruling
description: Speaking before a crowd of 300 cheering supporters, Mayor Bret D. Schundler of Jersey City vowed yesterday to fight a Federal court ruling that permanently barred the city from placing religious symbols in front of City Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSON, PHILIP E.
description: CARLSON-Philip E. April 18, 1943December 15, 1997. We mourn the loss of a special and caring man dedicated to the arts. Formerly of East 79th Street and a graduate of Parsons School of Design, Philip and his beloved wife Jane continued the love of the arts with their store. The Carlson Collection Home and Garden Furnishings in Clinton, Connecticut. The Swann Funeral Home, 80 East Main Street, Clinton, Connecticut, for further information.

title: Money, Not Miracles, Is Reviving South Bronx; Immigration's Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, IRWIN
description: GOODMAN-Irwin. All of us at Modell's Sporting Goods are shocked and devastated to learn of the sudden passing of our dear friend, mentor and valued executive for over twenty-five years. Our heartfelt condolences to Claire and the children. The Modell Family

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BINKOWITZ, BARRY, M.D.
description: BINKOWITZ-Barry, M.D. In these ten years you are gone, you have guided us with your light, your love, and your spirit. Forever, Mom & Dad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, BELLA
description: KAHN-Bella. Dearest Bella, we will always love and remember you. You were an elegant, grand lady and a unique human being. You lived life to the fullest and you did everything that you wished to do. Your 100th birthday was spectacular.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Winnie Mandela Stops Trying to Rekindle Political Career
description: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela's bid to re-ignite her political career came to an end today when, faced with the likelihood of a humiliating defeat, she announced that she would not accept a nomination to be deputy president of the African National Congress.

title: South Koreans Vote, Seeking Rescue From Economic Crisis
description: Voters began casting their ballots this morning for a new President to rescue this nation from its financial crisis and preside over a far-reaching industrial overhaul during the next five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, JULIUS
description: GROSS-Julius. On Dec. 17, 1997. Beloved husband of Lenore, father of Ronald and Ellen, brother of Bernice Fink and Edward Gross. Services Fri, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Plan for Database Privacy, But Public Has to Ask for It
description: In a move to head off restrictive legislation, more than a dozen companies that use cyberspace to disseminate personal information, including Social Security numbers, announced today that they would voluntarily limit access to it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, ELIZABETH (NEE SCHLEIFER)
description: BERMAN-Elizabeth (nee Schleifer). Formerly of New York City. Died in Washington, D.C. December 15, 1997 at the age of 102. Survived by her three daughters and their husbands, Adele and Bernard Rosen, Louise and Charles Davidoff, Norma and William Imershein, seven grandchildren and twelve great grandchildren.

title: Clinton's Personal Touch in Asian Rescue
description: As Asia's financial crisis has deepened, President Clinton has become personally involved in the effort to persuade Asian leaders to follow American-designed plans to stabilize their economies. In a blitz of phone calls, he has underscored the risks of much broader trouble for the world economy if Japan and South Korea in particular fail to act, American and Asian officials say.

title: INVACARE TO BUY A RIVAL HOME HEALTH CARE CONCERN
description: The Invacare Corporation, a provider of medical supplies to the home health care industry, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a smaller rival, the Suburban Ostomy Supply Company, for more than $130 million. The acquisition is expected to produce combined revenues of more than $860 million. Under the agreement, Invacare, based in Elyria, Ohio, would pay $11.75 for each of Suburban's shares outstanding. Suburban, of Holliston, Mass., had 11.1 million shares on average as of Aug. 30. Shares of Suburban rose 71.875 cents yesterday, to $11.59375. Shares of Invacare closed at $22.25, down 9.375 cents.

title: Personal Shopper; Deconstructing The Cuckoo
description: CUCKOOS are some tough old birds -- and very conservative. The basic cuckoo clock has not changed that much since the 18th century, when farmers in the Black Forest of Germany used to carve them as their winter activity. And today, most cuckoo clock factories are still in the region.

title: Fuji and Presstek Plan to Collaborate
description: The shares of Presstek Inc. rose 20 percent today after the company agreed to team up with the Fuji Photo Film Company to develop printing products in the first significant collaboration between the companies.

title: Colombia's Senate Passes Bill Giving Jail Leave to Traffickers
description: The Colombian Senate passed a law late on Tuesday night that would allow the most notorious drug traffickers in the nation's prisons to go home on weekends and holidays, and to take 15-day annual vacations.

title: Staid Leo Burnett intends to buy a stake in the hot, independent shop, Bartle Bogle Hegarty.
description: THE Leo Burnett Company, continuing ambitious efforts to remake itself, said yesterday that it would buy a significant minority stake in Bartle Bogle Hegarty, a feisty British agency regarded as one of the world's most creative independent shops.

title: Pilot Talks At Northwest Are Stalled
description: Discussions between Northwest Airlines and its pilots' union about a proposed alliance with Continental Airlines continued yesterday, but Northwest expressed frustration that the talks were making little progress.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JANIS, DENNIS
description: JANIS-Dennis. 12/18/54-12/19/93. Happy Birthday, Blooks. I miss you more than ever. Love, Nina

title: In Each Neighborhood There Lies a Special Shop
description: Right up there with the satisfaction of viewing a good movie that the critics did not paw all over is the thrill of finding an alluring boutique that is idiosyncratically appointed and not widely known. Typically, shoppers learn about these stores, which do not advertise much, if at all, in a way that creates an immediate emotional bond: they stumble upon them while heading elsewhere, or the store is recommended by a friend.

title: Prices Lower On Treasury Securities
description: Treasury securities traded lower yesterday, pushing the yield on the long bond back up to 6 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUXENBERG, MRS. QUEEN
description: LUXENBERG-Mrs. Queen. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York wish to express their heartfelt condolences to Paula Root, an esteemed member of our Board of Directors, upon the loss of her beloved mother, Mrs. Queen Luxenberg. We extend our profound sympathy to her family. Carol Raphael President and CEO Carl H. Pforzheimer III Chairman, Board of Directors

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A 'Messiah' in a Devout Setting
description: In terms of atmosphere, scholarly precision and sheer beauty of sound, the ''Messiah'' performances at St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue at 53d Street stand apart from the many others offered annually during the Christmas season in New York. Although no denomination can fully lay claim to the work itself, there is something about the vast stone arches, the intricate carvings and the red-robed, all-male choir at this Episcopal church that seems particularly appropriate to the English roots of this oratorio.

title: Garden Notebook; In Cooperstown, Candlelight Becomes the Solstice
description: ON Sunday, a candlelight evening will take place in this village in upstate New York. Kerosene lamps will glow along the walks and walls of the Farmers' Museum, and candles will flicker in the windows of its farmhouse and barns, in the period craft shops and at the nearby Fenimore House Museum. Brass bands, carolers from churches and schools, horse-drawn sleighs and steaming kettles of wassail will add to the cheer in this town, best known as the home of the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum. Scrooge would call it yet another quaint and cozy Christmas celebration for Americans in search of rural nostalgia.

title: CLINTON TO EXTEND G.I. ROLE IN BOSNIA
description: President Clinton has decided that American troops should stay in Bosnia past their mission's current departure deadline in June as part of an international peacekeeping force, Administration officials said today.

title: Guidelines Don't End Debate on Internet Privacy
description: In agreeing to let private information brokers and credit reporting companies be governed by voluntary privacy protection guidelines, the Federal Trade Commission is betting that companies that maintain vast computerized dossiers on people and businesses can police themselves in the face of ever more powerful information technologies.

title: F.B.I. to Brief 2 Lawmakers On Director's Memo to Reno
description: Officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have agreed to provide more information to House members about Director Louis J. Freeh's confidential memorandum recommending an independent prosecutor to investigate campaign finance abuses, a House committee chairman said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOOKER, JANET ANNENBERG
description: HOOKER-Janet Annenberg. Died December 13, 1997. The widow of James Stewart Hooker, she is survived by her sons, Donald P. Kahn (Jeanne) and Gilbert S. Kahn, her brother, the Hon. Walter H. Annenberg and two sisters, Enid A. Haupt and Evelyn A. Hall. She is also survived by five grandchildren, Donald P. Kahn, Jr., Douglas T. Kahn (Dr. Margaret Carter), Steven D. Kahn, Alexandra Kahn (John Graubert) and Julie K. Brown, and five greatgrandchildren, Sophia and Isabel Carter-Kahn, Christina Graubert, Thomas M. Bender and Samuel A. Brown, Jr. She was first married to the late L. Stanley Kahn-a member of the New York Stock Exchange. In 1938 she married investment banker Joseph A. Neff who died in 1969. She was very active in New York Charities-especially the Metropolitan Opera where she donated the Lobby Colonnade in memory of her mother, Mrs. Moses L. Annenberg. In addition, she funded the redecoration of the Blue Room at The White House, and, with her brother and his wife, helped fund projects at both the State Department's Diplomatic Reception Rooms and Blair House. In 1977, Mrs. Hooker gave an historic emerald to the National Gem Collection at the National Museum of Natural History. In 1991 and 1992, she gave additional gems to the collection and was the major donor for the Janet Annenberg Hooker Hall of Geology, Gems and Minerals which opened in September 1997. Mrs. Hooker, a resident of Palm Beach, Florida, also owned a summer home, Fairholme, in Newport, Rhode Island. A Funeral Mass will be held on Thursday, December 18, at 10 AM, at the Church of St. John The Evangelist, 55th Street and First Avenue, New York City. Burial will be private. For more information call Frank E. Campbell, New York City, 212-288-3500.

title: Strong Women in TV? They'd Sure Better Be; Progress, but Slowly, on Camera and Off
description: After years of struggling with the male-dominated television establishment, Bonnie Turner, an executive producer, said she was delighted that she had finally developed a female television character who was neither a victim nor overwhelmingly cute, but a fully developed woman with a realistic mix of strengths, quirks and weaknesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHONEY, KATHLEEN O.
description: MAHONEY-Kathleen O. Dec. 17, 1997, of Pleasantville, NY formerly of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved wife of the late Honorable J. Daniel Mahoney, Justice U.S. Court of Appeals, 2nd Circuit. Loving mother of J. Daniel Jr., Kieran, Francis, Mary Shipman, Eileen Curley and Elizabeth Mahoney. Fond sister of James O'Doherty and Sheila Fevarra. Devoted grandmother of 12 grandchildren. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc. Ascan Avenue (corner Metropolitan Ave.) Forest Hills, 7-9 PM Thursday and 2-5 and 7-9 PM Friday. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Saturday, December 20 at 9:30 AM. Interment Cemetery of the Gate of Heaven, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to Birth Right of Northern Westchester, 28 Everett Street, Ossining, NY 10562 or Daytop Village Foundation, Inc., 54 West 40 Street, NY, N.Y. 10018, would be appreciated.

title: Arts Abroad; The 2 Faces of 'Godot,' at the Start and the Millennium
description: The first English-language production of ''Waiting for Godot'' opened in London in the summer of 1955. The director, Peter Hall, then 24, was just out of university. This year, 42 years later, Mr. Hall staged his second production of the Beckett play, starring Ben Kingsley and Alan Howard, and in many respects it was in striking contrast to the original.

title: Panel Seeks to Simplify Grand Jury Duty Vagaries
description: Having improved the lot of New Yorkers called for jury service, court administrators announced this week that they would now train their gaze on a far more miserable civic responsibility -- grand jury duty.

title: Ralph Fasanella, 83, Primitive Painter, Dies
description: Ralph Fasanella, who worked as a union organizer, a machinist and a gas station owner but whose lasting fame will be as a late-blooming, self-taught painter of teeming urban panoramas, died on Tuesday at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers. He was 83 and lived in Ardsley, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLISON, KAREN HUBERT
description: ALLISON-Karen Hubert. On December 16, 1997, 49 yrs old, of breast cancer. It is with great sadness that we mark the loss of our dear friend, Karen, poet, writer, teacher, artist, chef, and loving mother. For thirty years and more, she has so generously shared herself with us and so many others. A wonderful, funny storyteller who fought for life until the very last moment. We will miss her most profoundly. Our hearts are with her family, Len, Halley, Luke, Matthew, & Wendy. Carol and Peter Marsh Joan Banach and Wayne Lavender

title: CHRONICLE
description: Senator ORRIN G. HATCH, the Republican of Utah, is known for his ability to sell ideas on the floor of the Senate, and on Tuesday, he demonstrated that he can also sell record albums -- his own -- on television.

title: For the Elderly, Drink a Day Can Be Dangerous
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Needs Its Park, Not a Golf Center
description: To the Editor:

title: Buzz Begins Again as Foley Practices
description: Following a private workout on Tuesday for Coach Bill Parcells, Glenn Foley returned to the Jets' practice field today after being out for a month with a knee injury.

title: Mayor Gives Unusual Report on His New Anti-Drug Strategy
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took the unusual step yesterday of carefully detailing the progress of his new antidrug strategy, appearing eager to show that the proposals that he announced during his re-election campaign represented more than just an expedient attempt to woo voters.

title: Turkish Wrongs and Rights
description: The European Union erred this week by rebuffing Turkey's longstanding membership application for poorly disguised reasons of ethnic and religious prejudice. Turks are right to be angered by a decision that had as much to do with historic Greek antipathy, German objections to Turkish immigrants and a parochial vision of Europe as it did with Turkey's real but solvable human rights problems.

title: Closing to Be Shorter at Harlem Subway Station
description: A Harlem subway station that New York City Transit had said would be closed for several months during the rebuilding of a subway tunnel will be closed for only eight weeks, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Metro Business; Sakura Plans Move To 101 Park Avenue
description: In one of the largest commercial leases of the year, Sakura Bank Ltd. of Tokyo, has signed a lease for 120,000 square feet on five floors of 101 Park Avenue, a building that covers the eastern block front from 40th Street to 41st Street. The space had been vacated by the Chase Manhattan Bank since its merger with Chemical Bank.

title: Fleeing Abuse to the Streets; Shelters Can't Keep Pace With Increase in Runaways
description: She will not go home again, the 15-year-old runaway told her caseworker, her guidance counselor and her therapist, in no uncertain terms.

title: Accord Lets Gay Couples Adopt Jointly
description: Homosexual couples in New Jersey will for the first time be able to adopt children jointly, just as married couples can, under an agreement reached today with state child welfare officials.

title: CITY COUNCIL VOTES STRICT LEGISLATION ON CIGARETTE ADS
description: The City Council passed the nation's toughest restrictions on outdoor cigarette advertising yesterday, voting overwhelmingly to approve a bill that would ban such advertising in most of New York City by barring the ads within 1,000 feet of schools, playgrounds and day care centers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUB, ERNEST
description: LAUB-Ernest. Died December 17, 1997. Beloved husband of Roslyn. Devoted father of Alane and Linda. Father-in-law of Neal Gartenberg. Grandfather of Adam and Scott. Your love, kindness, gentle wit and wisdom got us all through the ''trials and tribulations'' of life. You will be sorely missed and never forgotten. Services held at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York. Call 516-921-5757. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society in his name.

title: Annette Barbara Weiner, 64, Anthropologist and N.Y.U. Dean
description: Annette Barbara Weiner, an anthropologist and former dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences at New York University, died on Dec. 7 at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 64 and also had a residence in Wolcott, Vt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARENUS, FAYE G.
description: MARENUS-Faye G. On December 16, 1997 at age 67. Devoted wife of Joseph, loving mother of Judy and Mitchell, grandmother of Alyson, Michael, Jason, Laura and Michelle. Services will be today, Thursday, December 18, at I.J. Morris Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, Long Island, N.Y.

title: Investor Settles Libel Suit Against Business Week
description: In a settlement, Julian H. Robertson, the Wall Street investor, withdrew a libel suit against Business Week yesterday.

title: The Ramsey Case Revisited
description: The passage of time rarely has a salutary effect when it comes to solving crimes. Leads peter out, trails grow cold, witnesses' recollections fade, evidence becomes scattered and tainted. And, perhaps most pernicious of all, public outrage exhausts itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REID, CHAUVET, PAM
description: REID - CHAUVET - Pam. Irre placeable friend and confidant. You were an inspiration to all who knew you. I feel lucky to have been your friend. You will be missed more than you will ever know. My deepest sympathy to Savannah, Romain and the entire Reid-Chauvet family. Faith Kates

title: Louise L. Ottinger, 98, Philanthropist, Dies
description: Louise Loewenstein Ottinger, a New York philanthropist who supported the arts, community development and family planning, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 98.

title: AT HOME WITH: Thierry W. Despont; Court Architect to Industry's Sun Kings
description: THE world of Thierry W. Despont is a tightly controlled one where assistants blanch when a fax is misplaced, consultants duck behind confidentiality agreements and a woman is dismissed from her job with a kiss on the hand. Design's dauphin terrible understands that building a mystique is as central to his success as building Xanadus for the country's wealthiest homesteaders or creating galleries at the new Getty Museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEY, CHARLES A.
description: KENNEY-Charles A. The National Realty Club mourns the passing of Charles A. Kenney, a founding member, governor and one of the guiding lights of the organization, founded in 1947. Even when the real estate industry went through difficult times, Mr. Kenney was instrumental in stregthening our membership and bringing unity to our Club. Our deepest sympathy to his family and friends. Thomas K. Graf, President Stephen D. Barkin, Membership Chair Jerrold D. Fuchs, Programming Chair

title: Citta di Castello; White Truffles Are to Die For, but Not Like This
description: Two more truffle-hunting dogs died of poisoning in the wooded hills of northern Umbria on the day that Fabio Petruzzi, out hunting woodcock, almost lost his Lolla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUGDAN, ERNEST J.
description: MUGDAN-Ernest J. Of Queens, NY. Died peacefully at home, in his sleep, Dec. 17. Beloved father of Ursula and Walter; father-in-law of Vivienne; and grandfather of Willow & Elana. Memorial service at Community Church of Douglaston, 39-50 Douglaston Parkway, Douglaston, NY 11363, Saturday, January 3 at 2PM. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Community Church of Douglaston and/or the Fund for Animals, 200 W. 57 St., NY NY 10019

title: The Air As Stage, Bungees And All
description: A choreographer who requires a special taste rarely appeals to a broad public. But Elizabeth Streb's pieces do both, and this paradox is the secret to her success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSOFSKY, REBECCA
description: ROSOFSKY-Rebecca. Beloved mother of Ira and Linda, and Robert and Laurie, adored grandmother of Jonathan, Leah, Samuel, Anna and Gabriel, dear sister of Estelle Friedman. Graveside services Thursday 1 PM, at Montefiore Cemetery, Queens, N.Y.

title: Utility Given Permission To Lease Lines and Poles
description: GPU Inc., the state's second-largest electric utility, was granted permission yesterday to lease parts of its extensive infrastructure to telephone companies.

title: Accused Jet Hijacker Says He Led Open Life in Canada
description: When Felix Rolando Peterson-Coplin telephones his 6-year-old daughter in Kingston, Ontario, these days, he conceals the truth from her. ''Daddy's not there,'' he says, ''because I've been sick in the hospital.''

title: PITTSTON BURLINGTON TO ACQUIRE DISTRIBUTION SERVICES
description: The Pittston Burlington Group agreed yesterday to buy Distribution Services Ltd. and an affiliated company for $76 million in cash. Distribution Services, an ocean freight distribution and warehousing company, had 1996 revenues of about $180 million. Pittston Burlington said Distribution Services, a privately held company based in Los Angeles and Hong Kong, would operate as a separate entity within the Pittston BAX Global group, of Irvine, Calif. Pittston Burlington, the freight transportation and logistics management unit of the Pittston Company, had 1996 revenues of $1.5 billion.

title: Advice to the Love-Torn, From Freud to Landers
description: SHOULD YOU LEAVE?

title: British Parliament's First Muslim Is Accused of Election Fraud
description: A millionaire Glasgow businessman who this year became the first Muslim member of the British Parliament was charged today with electoral fraud and obstruction of justice.

title: Trade Secrets; Not Just for Widening a Hall or Updates on Who's the Fairest
description: FOUR hundred years ago, glass mirrors were as marvelous as starfish, toadstones and sapphires. Plato thought them reflections of the ideal; St. Augustine thought them reflections of the soul.

title: Brooklyn Needs Its Park, Not a Golf Center; Opposition Is Shut Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; South Korea is facing some difficult economic choices.
description: FOR the moment, Korea-watchers are relieved: both the currency and stock markets have regained some of the ground they lost in last week's nightmarish plunge. And all the candidates in today's presidential elections seem to have made their peace with the strings the International Monetary Fund has attached to its $57 billion-plus rescue package.

title: Bridge; A 4-2 Fit That Succeeds When a 5-5 Fit Would Not
description: The much-publicized David and Goliath battle between Netscape and Microsoft for the souls of Internet browsers is about to be repeated in a struggle for the souls of Internet bridge players. This time Microsoft is still in the role of Goliath, but David will be played by a young Californian, Matthew Clegg.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Weak Earnings Hurt Stocks As Asia News Is Ignored

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSON, PAULA ZLATIN
description: KARSON-Paula Zlatin. My sweet sister left us in body on December 14. May her sweet loving spirit and wisdom guide us forever. Thank you, Paula, for all those gifts of love. I will always love you. Your sister, Judith Share

title: Critical-Delivery Loans From the I.M.F.
description: The International Monetary Fund's executive board adopted a short-term loan program today that will rush funds to countries facing immediate debt-repayment problems or low foreign-currency reserves.

title: S.E.C. Examines Insider Trading at Oxford
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had requested documents in connection with at least $38 million of Oxford's shares sold by insiders months before the stock plummeted from near-record highs.

title: Senior Class; Living Independently, but Not Going It Alone
description: MARY E. ZOELLER, 65, is a technical writer with plenty of reservations about typical retirement communities.

title: DESIGNERS INSPIRATIONS -- Fantastic Flourishes Set the Table This Holiday Party Season
description: FOR the 40 designers, editors and shopkeepers who set lavish tables for the benefit ''Collection Rouge: Dining by Design,'' a bouquet of flowers flanked by a pair of candles would not do. Instead, at the event, which was for Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS and was held on Dec. 9 at the Metropolitan Pavilion in Manhattan, each table sported the kind of inspired madness that might brighten the holiday party scene at home (minus the eight-and-a-half-foot mannequin).

title: The Neediest Cases; Back With Her Children and Safe From Brutality
description: Back in Ecuador, Maria Ponce was the envy of her neighbors. With a generous inheritance from her grandfather, she built a handsome, red-tile-roofed house on a spacious plot of land in the coastal city of Manta. There was no need to work, which left her plenty of time to look after her four young children. Mrs. Ponce seemed to live a charmed life.

title: Sampras Honored
description: Pete Sampras, the No. 1 tennis player for a record five consecutive years, was named yesterday as the 1997 sportsman of the year by the United States Olympic Committee. He was the first tennis player to receive the award since it was established 24 years ago.

title: On Life's Rough-and-Tumble, via Mama's Tender Heart
description: Baby Jane Dexter may be the most talented singer within a time-honored genre of cabaret performer: the zaftig earth mother philosophizing about love and its sorrows. In an authoritative voice, she implies she has been to the places she sings about and that she has returned, bruised but unbowed, to share her insights. Ms. Dexter, who is appearing at Eighty-Eight's (228 West 10th Street, West Village) on Saturday evenings through the end of January, has a voice to match her leonine appearance and sagacious air: a large, dark contralto whose timbre is strikingly similar to Cher's.

title: Lacking Plans for a Pullout, Israeli Heads to U.S. Talks
description: After another brutal and inconclusive battle within his Cabinet, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu left today for a meeting with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in Paris without a formal proposal on further Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank.

title: Wiz Store Closings Are Across Northeast
description: The 17 stores that the Wiz Inc. will close as part of its bankruptcy filing are spread evenly throughout the Northeast and include one in midtown Manhattan, the electronics retailer's law firm said yesterday.

title: Consultants At Andersen Take Action
description: A growing rift between the accountants and consultants at Andersen Worldwide broke wide open yesterday, as the partners at Andersen Consulting announced that they were taking their case to an arbitrator so that they could go their own way.

title: Yale Must Pay $12.2 Million To a Physician Who Got H.I.V.
description: A young doctor who pricked her thumb with an H.I.V.-infected needle only seven weeks into her medical residency was awarded $12.2 million yesterday by a jury that ruled she had not been properly trained when she inserted a catheter tube into a dying AIDS patient at Yale-New Haven Hospital in 1988.

title: What 'Natural' Means
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GABEL, FAYE. DEAR FAYE
description: GABEL-Faye. Dear Faye, Happy Birthday. We miss you so much. Love, Iris, Michele, Suzy Monica and Randi

title: Judge Rejects Ordinance On City Permit for Parties
description: A Federal judge struck down a New Brunswick ordinance yesterday that required a city permit for parties of more than 50 people when admission was charged or contributions solicited.

title: F.T.C. Approves CUC International Merger
description: CUC International Inc. received Federal Trade Commission approval today to merge with HFS Inc. by agreeing to sell CUC's Interval International Inc. time-share unit.

title: Mystery Suitcase Causes Delays In Grand Central Evening Traffic
description: A nondescript suitcase left on a sidewalk on 42d Street in front of Grand Central Terminal last night paralyzed a wide swath of midtown Manhattan and delayed thousands of rush-hour commuters. The police, fearful that the suitcase contained a bomb, evacuated the lobby of the nearby Grand Hyatt Hotel, cordoned off East 42d Street and barred subway trains from stopping at Grand Central station for an hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, DORIS B.
description: NEWMAN-Doris B. Of Scarsdale on December 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence. Loving mother of Beth Newman, Barbara Morris and Milton Newman. Dear sister-in-law of Arthur Newman. Cherished grandmother of Lily Newman. The family will receive friends at their Bell Rd residence in Scarsdale, New York, Sunday, December 21, 2:30PM. For further information call Westchester Funeral Home Inc, 914-337-4585.

title: Voice of America Was Warned on China Interview
description: White House officials warned the Voice of America, a Government-financed agency, that it should consider not broadcasting an interview with a prominent Chinese dissident now in the United States because it could offend the Chinese Government, officials said today.

title: Is Japan's Rare, Bold Surprise Sufficient to Revive Economy?
description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, facing criticism for sticking to a strategy of fiscal austerity while Japan's economy stands on the brink of recession, stunned his critics today with a surprise package of tax cuts and public spending.

title: Money, Not Miracles, Is Reviving South Bronx; Still Plenty of Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: New Dun & Bradstreet Split Planned if the I.R.S. Agrees
description: Little more than a year after it transformed itself into three publicly traded companies as a way of increasing value for shareholders, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation is going to do it again.

title: Nothing Nice to Say? Do Come Sit Closer!
description: All right, so maybe it is the season of office parties. And maybe the prospect of yet another evening with a group of self-serving, randy materialists getting drunker and nastier by the minute isn't exactly what you had in mind as a holiday treat.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a proposal to lower tolls on bridges and tunnels operated by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority misstated the number of its board members appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki. While some appointments are made on the recommendation of other officials, the Governor formally appoints all 17, not 13.

title: Prosecutor Confirmed A Year After a Suicide
description: A new prosecutor will be sworn in today in Somerset County to succeed Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., who committed suicide last year after fleeing prosecution.

title: Uzi Narkiss, Israeli Army General, 72
description: Uzi Narkiss, an Israeli Army general who led the conquest of East Jerusalem in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, died today. He was 72 and had cancer.

title: Judge Strikes Down Ban on Casino Photos
description: A judge in Camden struck down on Wednesday a Federal regulation that prohibited casinos from including pictures or sounds of gambling in radio or broadcast television advertisements.

title: A Spectacle As Sweeping As the Sea
description: The long-awaited advent of the most expensive movie ever made, the reportedly $200 million ''Titanic,'' brings history to mind, and not just the legendary seafaring disaster of April 15, 1912. Think back also, exactly 58 years ago today, to the Dec. 19 New York premiere of another grand, transporting love story set against a backdrop of prideful excess, cataclysmic upheaval and character-defining trial by fire.

title: Clinton Calls for Keeping Troops In Bosnia With No New Exit Date
description: Abandoning his June deadline for withdrawing American forces from Bosnia, President Clinton called today for an open-ended commitment of troops in the international peacekeeping mission, arguing that it is helping to rebuild that nation's roads, schools, economy and political system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENENBOCK, BERTHA C.
description: FENENBOCK-Bertha C. Devoted wife of the late Morris. Loving mother of Bernard, Howard, Stephen and the late Judith. Survived by 11 grandchildren and 12 greatgrandchildren. Services '' Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. 10:30 AM. Sunday.

title: Chris Farley, 33, a Versatile Comedian-Actor
description: Chris Farley, a comedian and actor who hammed his way through skits and sketches on ''Saturday Night Live'' as everything from a frenzied motivational speaker to a giddy strip-club dancer, was found dead yesterday in his apartment in Chicago. He was 33.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Popularity Pays Off; Jets and Giants Cash In on a Winning Thing
description: In their season of exceeding expectations, the Jets and the Giants have learned that winning is not only a great deodorant, but also a dandy business strategy.

title: TIME WARNER IS ACQUIRING COMPANY THAT TRANSMITS WTBS
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Southern Satellite Services Inc., a Tele-Communications Inc. affiliate, for $213 million in cash, acquiring the company that transmits its WTBS superstation signal. By purchasing Southern Satellite, Time Warner is to receive all subscription fees for WTBS programming that cable operators have paid to Southern. Time Warner's revenue from WTBS has, until now, come largely from national advertising. The acquisition comes as Time Warner seeks to expand revenue from its booming cable systems and channels like WTBS, which is based in Atlanta, and Home Box Office.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Life of Thrift and a Generous Heart
description: Fourscore and eight years ago, when Alexandra Kliatscho won The New York Times's Lincoln Essay Competition at the age of 9, she spent her winnings on a tricycle. Had the contest been held four years later, after The Times established its Neediest Cases Fund, she would probably have shared her prize with the poor and the hungry she read about in the newspaper.

title: Taking a Hike: A Day in the Country in Queens
description: I catch sight of a few snow flurries as I leave my apartment in midtown Manhattan and a brisk wind is blowing in my face. Perfect weather for a winter hike, a great way to get my blood pumping without resorting to a treadmill. I'm dressed right -- down to a sweater, hat, thick gloves and wool socks -- so I don't really feel cold. And it will be a relief to get away from the pavement and out into the woods for a few hours.

title: New Video Releases
description: Pixote

title: Plan Allows Big Vehicles To Skirt Rules On Pollutants
description: New air quality regulations proposed this week by the Environmental Protection Agency would require cars, mini-vans, small sport utility vehicles and small pickup trucks to emit fewer smog-causing pollutants. But the regulations would not affect the already less stringent rules for big sport utility vehicles and pickups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNTON, MARK
description: LYNTON-Mark. Beloved husband of Marion, father of Michael and Lili, grandfather of Claire, Nina, Kate, Eloise, Maisie. Visitation on December 19, from 4 to 6PM, 48 West 70 Street, December 20, 11:30 to 2:00 PM, December 21, 3:30, 961 Fenimore Road, Larchmont.

title: Ambassador's Offense Wasn't a Little Lie ; Figure-Enhancing Stuff
description: To the Editor:

title: Resignation Sends Aetna Shares Tumbling
description: In another jolt to the health insurance business, shares in Aetna Inc., one of the largest health insurers, plunged nearly 12 percent yesterday after the company announced the abrupt departure of a key financial executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIX, EDGAR
description: STIX-Edgar. Died at home December 16. Loving and beloved husband of Carol, devoted father of Allen, Wayne, Roger and Gail. Father-in-law of Robert Way and Jane Share. Life-long resident of Scarsdale, New York, served in Submarine Force in World War II, dedicated his life to family and close friends to whom he was a wise, generous and dependable mainstay. Memorial Service will be at McMahon Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains on Friday, December 19 at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to Planned Parenthood of Westchester, 11 Skyline Drive, Hawthorne, New York 10532 or The Cancer Research Fund, 675 Third Avenue, New York, New York 10017.

title: Dutch Troops Seize Two War Crimes Suspects, Wounding One
description: Dutch paratroopers and marines from the NATO-led peacekeeping force in Bosnia detained two Bosnian Croat war crimes suspects today. Officials said that one of them, indicted on charges of involvement in one of the most grisly massacres of the war, was wounded when he resisted arrest.

title: Christmas Comes to Cuba
description: In anticipation of Pope John Paul II's visit next month, Fidel Castro will permit Christmas to be celebrated in Cuba for the first time in three decades. This symbolic gesture may foretell an eventual Cuban liberalization, not only in the practice of faith but also in the area of political and economic rights, which the Pope considers integral to the church's social teaching.

title: Israeli Reaction to Iran's Buildup Is Heightening Nuclear Fears in Mideast
description: The Middle East could end up living under the threat of nuclear confrontation, U.S. officials say, unless Washington succeeds in stopping the flow into Iran of material for weapons of mass destruction. For the Clinton administration, the problem of Tehran's buildup is complicated by Israel's response to it.

title: Kurdish Rebel Leader Renews His Call for Talks With Ankara
description: The leader of Kurdish guerrillas who have been fighting the Turkish Government for 13 years has made a renewed call for negotiations, but the Government remains opposed to any contacts with him.

title: Mets Get Cook and Still Seek Benes
description: The Mets landed an ornament from the Florida Marlins' fire sale yesterday, trading two minor leaguers for Dennis Cook, a veteran left-handed pitcher. But the Mets are also looking at Andy Benes, the most notable free-agent pitcher remaining on the market.

title: Determined Cone Is Eager to Get an Early Start
description: David Cone is so intent on defying those who doubt that he will be ready to start for the Yankees by the season opener that he is leaving New York for Tampa, Fla., today to begin a personal spring training, almost two months before pitchers are scheduled to report.

title: School Tax Law Splits 'Haves' and 'Have Nots'
description: Vermont these days is riven by revolution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, DOROTHY FLOOD, MD
description: FLYNN-Dorothy Flood, MD, 70, of Dallas, PA., and Point Lookout, NY, after a courageous three year battle with stomach cancer. Wife of the late Judge Joseph T. Flynn. Mother of Dr. Monica Flynn, San Antonio, TX., and Megan Flynn, Brookline, MA. Sister of Nancy McSherry, Valley Cottage, NY, Eileen Ronan, Memphis, TN., Joan Snyder, Salem, VA., and the late Claire Curtin of Bronxville, New York. A 1948 graduate of Cornell University and 1952 graduate of New York Medical College. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Cornell University. Funeral will be Monday from the Richard H. Disque Funeral Home Inc, 672 Memorial Highway, Dallas, PA 9:00 AM Mass 9:30 AM. Burial Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY, Tuesday at noon. Wake Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Wanted: Significant Victories
description: To Keith Van Horn, life in the National Basketball Association is still new, and life with the Nets is, too. For all that he has seen in his brief professional life, the Nets are contenders. He doesn't know the history, and from the little he has heard, he is not interested in learning it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, MARK F.
description: HUGHES-Mark F. The Board of Directors of the New York County Lawyers' Association mourns the passing of Mark F. Hughes, former president of the Association (1965-1967), who died Wednesday, December 10 at the age of ninetytwo. During his term, NYCLA established the William Nelson Cromwell Award which is presented at the Association's Annual Dinner. His commitment to NYCLA and the law will be missed.

title: Raising the Speed Limit
description: Both houses of the State Legislature overwhelmingly approved a bill yesterday to raise the speed limit on some state and Federal highways in New Jersey to 65 miles per hour, but Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is expected to veto it. Aides to the Governor, who recently had softened her opposition to the bill, said she opposed it because it did not include a provision for a trial period to study the effect of the higher speed limit.

title: Pivot Rules, a little-known maker of golf clothing, spends heavily to raise its profile.
description: PIVOT RULES INC., a small, publicly traded men's golfwear company, began an extensive campaign earlier this month to raise the profile of its relatively unknown brand.

title: GOLDMAN, SACHS IS ACQUIRING 9.5% STAKE IN IDB HOLDING
description: The Discount Investment Corporation, an Israeli holding company, said yesterday that it would sell a 9.5 percent stake in the IDB Holding Corporation to Goldman, Sachs & Company, the New York investment bank, for 280 million shekels ($79.2 million). Discount, whose interests include retailing, real estate, communications, and medical and electronic equipment, acquired 12.9 percent of IDB Holding from the Wertheimer family in August. The stake in IDB Holding was valued at $120 million at the time Discount acquired it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, CATALINA (KITTY)
description: MEYER-Catalina (Kitty). On December 17, 1997. Beloved wife of Alvin. Loving mother of Risa, Eric, Buf and Geoffrey. Dear sister of Lilian. Services Friday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Westchester Hills Cemetery. In lieu offlowers contributions may be made to The International Committee Against Mental Illness. Attention: Dr. Robert Cancro, Chairman, Department of Psychiatry. New York University Medical Center, 550 1st Ave, NY NY, 10016

title: Editorial Notebook; The Magnificent Horses of Shah-Jahan
description: The finest demonstration of horsemanship in New York City is the one now on view at the Metropolitan Museum. There, amid dimly lit rooms, an equestrian spectacle unfolds in a 17th-century manuscript called the Padshahnama, which means, roughly, ''King of the World.'' The Padshahnama is an incomplete chronicle of the life of Shah-Jahan, the 17th-century Muslim emperor who built the Taj Mahal and ruled over much of what is now India, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iran. The manuscript, illustrated by a compendium of Islamic painting, was given in 1797 to George III and preserved in what became the Royal Library at Windsor Castle.

title: Bubbles and Caviar
description: Holiday gift shopping may inspire a longing for baubles of a different sort. Caviar is a gift for the mouth, the sort of indulgence that may require you to invent a good reason for having it. Ordering a bottle of Champagne, for example, is a perfect reason, if only to determine for yourself whether sparkling wine or vodka goes better with caviar. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Agency Makes Sure It's Ginseng, Not Gin
description: The Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms has announced a crackdown on ginseng.

title: In the President's Words: Toward 'a Lasting Peace'
description: Following is a transcript of the White House news conference yesterday in which President Clinton announced a commitment in principle to extend the stay of American troops in Bosnia and Herzegovina beyond June 1998, the expiration date of the mandate for the NATO peacekeeping force now stationed there. The transcript was prepared by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company.

title: Newbold Noyes Jr., 79, Ex-Editor Of The Washington Evening Star
description: Newbold Noyes Jr., who as editor of The Washington Evening Star from 1963 to 1975 was the last member of four generations of his family to lead the newspaper, died yesterday in Sorrento, Me. He was 79.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a doctor who was awarded $12.2 million in a lawsuit against Yale University misstated her medical condition in some copies. The doctor, who had pricked herself with a contaminated needle, is infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. She has not developed AIDS.

title: Tugging at the Inextricable Bonds of Blood
description: There may be hope for the theater yet. Just when it seems that no one under 30 can be trusted to cherish drama, cultivate the spoken word or see any picture bigger than the screen of a video game, along come the playwrights of ''Thicker Than Water.''

title: Southerner Is Selected to Head Arts Endowment
description: For the second time in recent months, President Clinton has turned to his native South to select the head of a Federal cultural agency.

title: Low Overpass Stymies a Couple From Alabama
description: It was not exactly the way that Terry and Sharon Whittington of Ozark, Ala., married since November, had imagined their first trip to New York City.

title: Shouldn't We Help Parents Be Parents?
description: Guided by an admirable desire to address the nation's child care problem, President Clinton is preparing to announce two proposals that are socially irresponsible and morally wrong. He wants to create new tax breaks for corporations that provide day care for children of employees, and he wants to expand the tax credit for employed parents who use paid child care.

title: South Korean Election Results Hearten Emigres in New York
description: When Joseph Seok left South Korea 19 years ago, democracy and economic stability in the country seemed distant, unattainable dreams. So despite the country's recent economic downturn, yesterday's election of Kim Dae Jung, the longtime opposition leader whom Seoul's ruling party had repeatedly tried to have assassinated, greatly heartened Mr. Seouk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLISON, KAREN HUBERT
description: ALLISON-Karen Hubert. The Writers and Staff of Teachers & Writers Collaborative mourn Karen's death and send condolences to Len and their children. Karen was a gifted writer and exuberant teacher. She was dedicated to the writers - in - the - schools program and in its early days, and her innovative teaching strategies continue to inspire educators and writers through the essays and the book she wrote for us. She will be missed.

title: A Servant Deeply Devoted To a Family and a Parrot
description: Let estheticians argue about whether the productions of the Big Dance Theater are primarily choreographic or dramatic. What's beyond dispute is that this troupe directed by Annie-B Parson and Paul Lazar is rich in imagination. It skillfully blended movement, words and recorded musical collages in a double bill called ''Two Tales,'' which its directors have staged at Dance Theater Workshop. The production runs through Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNO, WILLIAM S.
description: BRUNO-William S. On December 18, at age 86, of Boca Raton and Somers, New York, formerly of Mamaroneck. Beloved husband of Miriam Gwertzman. Devoted father of Dr. Edwin J. Bruno and Carol B. Kaplan. Proud and loving grandfather of Rebecca, Abbie and Joshua Bruno and Jeremy Kaplan. Great-grandfather of Taylor. Dear brother of Howard Bruno and Dorothy Persinger. Funeral services to be held at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Sunday, December 21, at 12:30 PM, Delray Beach, Florida. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice by The Sea, Boca Raton, or to your favorite charity would be greatly appreciated.

description: An On the Road article in Weekend on Dec. 5, about visiting Detroit, misstated the site of the Cotopaxi volcano, the subject of a Frederic Edwin Church painting at the Detroit Institute of Arts. It is in Ecuador, not Mexico.

description: It's the time of year for amazing onscreen coincidences. And, of course, for making lists.

title: Painting the Character Instead of the Rank
description: The title of the show here at the National Gallery of Art, ''Lorenzo Lotto: Rediscovered Master of the Renaissance,'' is slightly misleading. Lotto has not precisely had to be rescued from oblivion, like Vermeer or La Tour. They were completely forgotten and then, of course, had their reputations soar when their art jibed with modern sensibilities.

title: Bill to Require Reports On Water Is Approved
description: Water suppliers would have to provide detailed annual reports on water quality to customers under a bill that the State Senate passed yesterday and sent to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: Guilty Plea in Smuggling of Immigrants
description: She did not look the part of the depraved mastermind of a slavery ring. But in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday, Adriana Paoletti Lemus, a petite, angelic-looking 29-year-old who investigators say used her beauty to further her operation, conceded that the formal charges were all true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, ARNOLD M. (SONNY)
description: SILVERSTEIN-Arnold M. (Sonny). On December 17, 1997. Beloved husband of Mary E. Lasky. Loving father of Michael and Jeffrey. Dear brother of Roselle Selikoff. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Friday December 19., at 11:30AM. Interment Willowbrook Cemetery, Westport, Connecticut.

title: Man in the News: Kim Dae Jung; Freedom Fighters' Conquering Hero
description: When he was awaiting execution on death row in 1980, Kim Dae Jung wrote anguished letters to one of his sons, apologizing that no parents would allow their daughter to marry him, that no business dared give him a job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOOKER, JANET ANNENBERG
description: HOOKER-Janet Annenberg. Died on December 13, 1997. The widow of James Stewart Hooker, she is survived by her sons, Donald P. Kahn (Jeanne) and Gilbert S. Kahn, her brother, the Hon. Walter H. Annenberg and two sisters, Enid A. Haupt and Evelyn A. Hall. She is also survived by five grandchildren, Donald P. Kahn, Jr., Douglas T. Kahn (Dr. Margaret Carter), Steven D. Kahn, Alexandra Kahn (John Graubert) and Julie K. Brown, and five great grandchildren, Sophia and Isabel CarterKahn, Christina Graubert, Thomas M. Bender and Samuel A. Brown, Jr. She was first married to the late L. Stanley Kahn-a member of the New York Stock Exchange. In 1938 she married investment banker, Joseph A. Neff who died in 1969. She was very active in New York Charities-especially the Metropolitan Opera where she donated the Lobby Colonnade in memory of her mother, Mrs. Moses L. Annenberg. In addition, she funded the redecoration of the Blue Room at The White House, and, with her brother and his wife, helped fund projects at both the State Department's Diplomatic Reception Rooms and Blair House. In 1977, Mrs. Hooker gave an historic emerald to the National Gem Collection at the National Museum of Natural History. In 1991 and 1992, she gave additional gems to the collection and was the major donor for the Janet Annenberg Hooker Hall of Geology, Gems and Minerals which opened in September 1997. Mrs. Hooker, a resident of Palm Beach, Florida, also owned a summer home, Fairholme, in Newport, Rhode Island. A Funeral Mass was held. For information call Frank E. Campbell, New York City, 212-288-3500.

title: M.T.A. Approves Unlimited Transit Passes
description: After a final round of quibbling yesterday from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's appointees, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority unanimously approved a package of monthly, weekly and daily transit passes aimed at transforming the way New Yorkers use their mass transit system.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged 58 defendants yesterday with penny-stock manipulation in one of the largest stock fraud cases ever.
