title: Hiding Behind the Rule of Law
description: Conciliatory remarks by President Mohammed Khatami of Iran earlier this month spurred hope in the West for a more open Iran. Only a few days before Mr. Khatami's gesture, however, the United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution calling for Iran to ''stop executions for nonviolent crimes and establish human rights for women and minority religions.'' The United Nations special investigator, Maurice Danby Copithorne, concluded that improvements in human rights under President Khatami have been ''so modest as to represent little substantive improvement.'' As if to confirm these findings, Ibrahim Yazdi, a former Foreign Minister and the head of an opposition group, was imprisoned on Dec. 14 without an explanation or charges.

title: Whitman Seen Halting Speed Limit Bill
description: Both houses of the State Legislature overwhelmingly approved a bill today that would raise the speed limit on some state and Federal highways in New Jersey to 65 miles per hour. But Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who recently had softened her opposition to the increased speed limit, is expected to veto the legislation.

title: Angry Koreans Elect Longtime Dissident
description: Enraged by the financial crisis that has humbled their nation, Koreans overturned their political establishment on Thursday and elected as their new President Kim Dae Jung, a legendary pro-democracy campaigner whom past dictators had repeatedly tried to murder.

title: INSIDE
description: A woman admits to leading a slavery ring of deaf Mexicans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, DR. NANCY L.
description: HOROWITZ-Dr. Nancy L. Of White Plains, NY. Wife of Jed M. Horowitz. Daughter of Louis Ciolino & the late Sally Ciolino. Mother of Gemma and Sally Horowitz. Sister of John Ciolino and Barbara McCormick. Funeral service on Friday 2:30 P.M., at the BallardDurand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York. Interment Kensico Cemetery. Friends may call at the funeral home Friday 2-2:30PM. Memorial contributions to the American Cancer Society or the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Abroad at Home ; 'That's The Way It Is'
description: Catherine Caza asked the immigration judge, Rex J. Ford, what would happen to her 7-year-old American daughter if she was deported.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS OUTBIDS MAPLE LEAF FOR SCHNEIDER
description: Smithfield Foods Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Schneider Corporation for stock worth $119.4 million, outbidding Maple Leaf Foods Inc. for the maker of Canada's best-selling processed meat. Smithfield, which makes John Morrell meats, plans to issue 3.852 million shares for Schneider's 6.4 million shares, options and class A stock. The offer values Schneider common shares at $24 (Canadian) each, or $2 a share more than Maple Leaf's offer. The shares of Smithfield, based in Norfolk, Va., fell 50 cents yesterday, to $31, while Schneider fell 75 cents, to $23 (Canadian). The Schneider family, which controls about 74 percent of the company's stock, has agreed to the terms of the acquisition.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Giles Lyon

title: One Dissenter At Fed Urged Rate Increase
description: Federal Reserve policy makers faced with fragile markets, Asia's crisis and concerns about inflation -- had one dissenter in their decision to leave short-term interest rates unchanged at their meeting on Nov. 12.

title: With Approving Nod, I.M.F. Wires $3.5 Billion to South Korea
description: The International Monetary Fund released a further $3.5 billion tonight of the $21 billion it has pledged to keep South Korea afloat, giving its approval to Seoul's handling of the crisis so far and a vote of confidence to the President-elect, Kim Dae Jung.

title: Residential Real Estate ; On John St., From Offices to Housing
description: Five short blocks along John Street in the Manhattan financial district have become a focus for converting old office buildings to housing.

title: Bayer Says Lease Delay Could Cancel Investment
description: Bayer A.G. of Germany said yesterday that it would cancel an investment of $1.5 billion in a chemical plant in Taiwan if it failed to win approval for the lease this month.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; Boy, 7, Dies After Fall From Brooklyn High-Rise
description: A 7-year-old Brooklyn boy who was apparently looking at a children's troupe performing across the street slipped and fell several stories from a high-rise building yesterday, the police said. The boy died at Coney Island Hospital.

title: U.N. Takes Up Iraqi Refusal On Inspections
description: The Security Council resumed discussion today on Iraq's refusal to open all sites requested by United Nations arms inspectors, but there was no indication that Council members were prepared to take any action to end the standoff.

title: METROMEDIA IS SELLING THEATER GROUP TO SILVER CINEMAS
description: Metromedia International Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Landmark Theater Group to Silver Cinemas Inc. for about $65 million. Landmark had 138 movie screens at 50 locations in the United States as of April. Metromedia, based in East Rutherford, N.J., is a communications, entertainment and media company. Silver Cinemas, based in Dallas, owns and manages theaters specializing in second-run movies. In April, Metromedia sold most of its entertainment assets to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. and has been focusing on its telecommunications business.

title: 16 Years Later, Man Accused of Killing Doctor for $5 Is Acquitted
description: The arrest of Patrick R. McDowell on murder charges in 1994, nearly 13 years after the shooting death of Dr. John Chase Wood Jr., thrust Detective Jerry Giorgio into the limelight.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was an offer she couldn't refuse: JOAN STAPLETON, an 18-year veteran at The New Republic who has been the publisher of the magazine since 1989 and its president since 1995, is stepping down from both posts to marry CHARLES FREDERICK TOOLEY, the mayor of Billings, Mont. She will remain with the political opinion weekly as director of national advertising, but will work out of Billings.

title: Last Days of Kim Philby: His Russian Widow's Sad Story
description: The fourth and last wife of the British master spy Kim Philby has written her memoirs of life with the most famous mole in the history of espionage.

title: Pollution's Slippery Slope
description: To the Editor:

title: Facing a Rear View Aimed at Insights
description: Consider the back. It is not in first place but in second. It is vulnerable to stabs. When you end up facing a back, you may be experiencing abandonment, betrayal or rudeness, or simply waiting in line. The human back, sometimes achingly lovely, is ever incurably aching. Yet backs are an inseparable part of most things, including us, and we are quite attached to ours.

title: Plastic Surgery, Unsupervised, Leads to a Fine For a Hospital
description: One of the nation's most esteemed teaching hospitals, Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan, has been forced to close down its program to train plastic surgeons after two senior residents were caught performing clandestine operations -- from liposuction to eyelid lifts -- without the required supervision of senior doctors.

title: Con Man Who Used 8 Names Is Convicted of $20,000 Scheme
description: In the annals of con men in New York City, Courtney I. Saunders must hold a special place. Hired 14 years ago as a deputy administrator in the Human Resources Administration, he offered an impressive resume: graduate of Amherst College and the Columbia Law School and partner in a major Washington law firm.

title: New Jersey Legislature Votes to Double State Cigarette Tax
description: The New Jersey Legislature voted overwhelmingly today to increase the state's cigarette tax by 40 cents a pack, making cigarettes more expensive in New Jersey than in any other state in the region. The proceeds, about $205 million a year, will help pay for hospital treatment for uninsured patients and for school construction.

title: Top Hill Journal; At Polls in Jamaica, Kissing Cousin From America
description: Cousins Trevor and Enid were waiting to greet him when he arrived here, and Aunt Doris over in Montego Bay was expecting, and got, a courtesy call. Today was election day in Jamaica, but for Gen. Colin L. Powell, a day spent monitoring the fairness of the vote in the country where his parents were born ended up also being something of a homecoming.

title: Ideas From the Air, Wrapped in Paper
description: ''A Decade of Collecting: Recent Acquisitions in Contemporary Drawing'' includes almost half of the 200 works on paper made since the mid-1980's that are owned by the Museum of Modern Art. So it is a fair index of the museum's preferences in this area and, by default, a snapshot of one aspect of recent art.

title: The Met, Sold Out for One Debut, Hears Another
description: The circumstances of the mezzo-soprano Vivica Genaux's debut on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera could not have been more difficult.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a database industry plan for computer privacy misstated the kind of information that will be available to the general public. Fourteen information companies will now automatically bar the general public distribution of a person's Social Security number, date of birth, unlisted telephone number and mother's maiden name from nonpublic sources like credit bureaus. (Such information may still be available if it comes from a public source.) To eliminate more basic information -- name, address and alias -- a consumer must contact each company and make a request.

title: U.S. Acts to Meet Water Needs in the West
description: Opening the way for a new market in vital water for growing Western states, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt today announced a Federal rule that for the first time would allow interstate sales of water from the Colorado River, even as he warned once more that California must work harder to reduce its dependence on the river.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the philanthropist Janet Annenberg Hooker on Tuesday misstated the ownership of The Philadelphia Inquirer in 1974, when Ms. Hooker married James Stewart Hooker, an executive there. The paper was owned by the Knight chain, which merged that year to form Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc.; it was not an Annenberg paper at the time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAPS, JONIE
description: TAPS-Jonie. On Dec 16, 1997. Survived by loving wife, Wilhelmina, daughter Susan, sister Betty Wilhelm, grandchildren, great-children. Memorial in Santa Fe, NM.

description: DiGIOVANNA-Justice Anthony J. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife and to the other members of his family. Beatrice Shainswit, President

title: Trial Unites the Families Of Victims and Accused
description: As the trial of Terry L. Nichols in the Oklahoma City bombing case dragged on for 12 weeks here, the families who lost loved ones in the bombing not only shared their grief and sympathy with one another, but also with the mother of the accused.

title: In Hong Kong, Runs on Banks and Cakes
description: First it was bank runs. Then cake runs. And then arcade runs.

title: Gigante Sentenced to 12 Years And Is Fined $1.25 Million
description: Saying he was mixing punishment for Vincent Gigante's past as a ruthless Mafia kingpin with leniency for his present ''age and frailty,'' a Federal judge sentenced the mobster yesterday to 12 years in prison for his conviction on murder-conspiracy and racketeering charges. He also fined him $1.25 million.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. The shows' regular schedules are listed below; call the theaters for holiday schedule information. + means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth last weekend for last Friday and Saturday nights' performances. ++ means tickets were available for last Saturday night only.

title: Trying to Ease Impasse, Clinton to Meet Netanyahu and Arafat
description: After making only incremental progress in another round of meetings with Israeli and Palestinian leaders, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that President Clinton would meet each side separately next month in Washington to try to break the impasse.

title: Persistence And Passion In a Russian Program
description: Kurt Masur is, above all, a robust musician: energetic, frank, confident. In his work with the New York Philharmonic, he takes the straight path. He may thereby miss the indirection in Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet'' score, the sense of Romantic music walking a keen tightrope over modernism, but, as Wednesday evening's performance at Avery Fisher Hall showed in a generous selection of numbers from the ballet, Mr. Masur's way has powerful merits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINZER, ESTELLE
description: LINZER-Estelle. The Eleanor Roosevelt Center at Val-Kill (ERVK), Hyde Park, New York, mourns the loss of former Board President Estelle Linzer. She worked and traveled with Eleanor Roosevelt at the American Association for the United Nations (now UNA-USA) from 1953 until Mrs. Roosevelt's death in 1962. She was a vital link to Mrs. Roosevelt's legacy and an inspiration to the ERVK's programs. We admired her modesty and her dignity. ERVK Board of Directors, staff and friends

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Films Offering Cheer and Chills

title: Time to Flee A Husband, A Homeland, A Holocaust
description: Words and movement seldom mix well. But Gabrielle Lansner overcame the difficulties in ''Holocaust Stories,'' a program drawn from the writings of Cynthia Ozick and Bertolt Brecht, performed on Wednesday night at the Here Theater.

title: Lester Tuchman, Internist and Professor, 93
description: Lester R. Tuchman, a New York internist, medical researcher and emeritus professor of clinical medicine at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, died on Wednesday at his home in Cos Cob, Conn. He was 93.

title: More Shadows Over City Hall
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's administration appears intent on proving its critics right about its lack of openness. Earlier this month, a nonprofit New York City good-government group issued a report that complained about the difficulty of getting data on city government operations. In response, a top Giuliani official appeared to try threatening the group's financial supporters.

title: Judge Rules Government Covered Up Lies on Panel

Magaziner, the chief architect of President Clinton's ill-fated health plan, and the judge ordered the Government to pay a penalty of more than $285,000.

title: A. T. Ulasewicz, 'Bagman' Of Watergate, Is Dead at 79
description: Anthony T. Ulasewicz, the ''bagman'' whose deadpan accounts of delivering money to buy the silence of Watergate conspirators both fascinated and delighted Senate investigators, died on Wednesday in Glens Falls, N.Y. He was 79.

title: Stocks Fall Sharply in Japan On Debt and Economy Fears
description: Japanese stocks fell more than 5 percent today after a food-trading company, Toshoku Ltd., sought court protection from heavy debts, raising fear that more bankruptcies and business failures would plague an already frail economy.

title: Optimistic Foley Says He Is Ready to Play Sunday
description: Glenn Foley today pronounced himself ready to return to play quarterback for the Jets. If so, it would give Coach Bill Parcells a viable option to pull the starter, Neil O'Donnell, if he should falter Sunday against the Detroit Lions.

title: A Mouse Full of Mischief And Culinary Tricks
description: The year's best performance by an actor with twitchy whiskers and a tail can be seen in ''Mouse Hunt,'' Dreamworks' bright comedy about one shrewd rodent and two not so shrewd people. As the family film least insulting to its audience's intelligence this season, ''Mouse Hunt'' has its share of grown-up appeal along with mouse mischief guaranteed to have children giggling.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WILLIAM D'OLIER LIPPINCOTT, an advertising sales executive at The New Yorker, is to succeed Ms. Stapleton as publisher of The New Republic.

title: Once Again, of God, Man And Everything in Between
description: The debaters on Sunday night's ''Firing Line'' take pains to avoid pitting Charles Darwin squarely against God. But for many Americans, that's what the debate -- ''Resolved: The Evolutionists Should Acknowledge Creation'' -- is all about, and religion slips in here, too.

title: Writer Who Cried Plagiarism Used Passages She Didn't Write

description: If there were such a thing as reincarnation, the 19th-century French painter Rosa Bonheur (1822-1899) would surely spring back to life as a lion. Fond of these lordly beasts, she kept a pet one named Fathma, and her undated oil painting ''Lioness,'' a big regal cat looking guardedly out at the world, could quite possibly be a self-portrait.

title: R. V. Jones, Science Trickster Who Foiled Nazis, Dies at 86
description: R. V. Jones, a secret hero of British intelligence in World War II, whose genius for scientific tricks baffled German bombers and saved thousands of lives, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at Woodend Hospital in Aberdeen, Scotland. He was 86.

title: STARWOOD LODGING IN $2.1 BILLION DEAL WITH VNU
description: The Starwood Lodging Corporation, which outbid the Hilton Hotels Corporation last month for control of the ITT Corporation, reached agreement yesterday to sell ITT World Directories Inc. to VNU N.V., a Dutch publishing company, for $2.1 billion. Analysts said that taxes and related transaction costs, including the payment of $150 million to $200 million to the BellSouth Corporation, a former owner of World Directories, would pare about $700 million off the price. The sale is contingent on Starwood's acquiring ITT. ITT shareholders are scheduled to vote on the takeover on Jan. 26.

title: The Question for ABC: What Price Football?
description: Imagine ABC without ''Monday Night Football.'' No Hank Williams production numbers. No Al, Frank and Dan. The scenario is possible if CBS loads its moneybags during National Football League negotiations for a run at the 27-year-old series. The conventional view is that ''M.N.F.'' is too meaningful to lose, that ABC cannot battle its rivals in prime time without ''M.N.F.,'' even if it means sustaining big losses on a huge rights fee.

description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. said yesterday that it will move its headquarters to Bridgewater, N.J., from Britain.

title: ENGELHARD PLANS 4TH-QUARTER CHARGES OF $96 MILLION
description: The Engelhard Corporation said yesterday that it would take fourth-quarter charges totaling $96 million, or 67 cents a share, to restructure a joint venture and two businesses. In October, Engelhard said it was looking at ways to eliminate the drag on earnings of its Paris-based Engelhard-CLAL joint venture, which makes products derived from precious metals; its emission controls business, and its petroleum catalyst business. The company, a maker of specialty chemicals and engineered materials, also said it planned to resume a five-million-share repurchase plan. Engelhard shares fell $1.1875, to $17.9375. The announcement came after the close of trading.

description: In the dead of the Arctic night on Dec. 9 flashes of light as bright as nuclear blasts lighted up the southern tip of Greenland, and Danish scientists have begun a search for what they believe was a gigantic meteor impact.

title: Youth Symphony in Old and New Works
description: The New York Youth Symphony, a training orchestra for musicians between the ages of 12 and 22, presents a series of concerts at Carnegie Hall every season. By charging low ticket prices -- $5 for general admission -- the orchestra regularly packs the hall. And generally it performs at a level that leaves listeners admiring the devotion of both the young players and the conductors who work with them.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Two years ago, Keens Chophouse changed its name. Nobody knew what a chophouse was anymore. So it became Keens Steakhouse. It is so old that guidebooks published 70 years ago exhorted their readers to visit the restaurant for its atmosphere as well as for its food. Imagine what it is like to walk in now, 112 years after its opening, and find this replica of a smoky old English inn largely unchanged.

title: Doubts Cited on Brawley
description: For the first time in the defamation trial of three former advisers to Tawana Brawley, jurors heard a witness say today that he had doubted her statements of rape and abduction 10 years ago and that he believed she had been complicit in the events that led to her being found in a garbage bag smeared with feces.

title: ALLIANT FOODSERVICE AGREES TO BUY ATLANTIC FOOD
description: Alliant Foodservice Inc. a privately held food service distributor based in Deerfield, Ill., reached an agreement yesterday to acquire Atlantic Food Services of Manassas, Va. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Alliant, the former Kraft Foodservices, was purchased in 1995 by Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, the New York investment firm. Atlantic, which is also privately held, had revenues of $178 million in the year that ended on June 30. It serves 2,000 customers in a five-state region around Washington. The acquisition will be the fifth for Alliant in the last 17 months and will leave the company with more than 11,000 employees in 46 distribution centers. The company, which had revenues of about $4.5 billion in 1996, provides service to restaurants, hotels and contract management operations.

title: An Asia Sublimely Mixed: Ugly, Lovely, New, Old
description: The Magnum photographer Hiroji Kubota doesn't shy away from ambitious projects. For his 1985 book of photographs on China, he crisscrossed that country from late 1978 through early 1984. For a 1992 book commemorating the 500th anniversary of Columbus's arrival in the Americas, he bought an American camper and spent 700 days traveling throughout the United States. For ''Out of the East,'' to be published next spring by W.W. Norton, he spent the last four years photographing in 16 Pacific Rim countries and territories.

title: Hamed-Kelley: Time to Talk the Talk Now
description: Prince Naseem Hamed and Kevin Kelley have waged a war of words all week, leading up to tonight's featherweight world championship fight at Madison Square Garden. Hamed said he was going to knock out Kelley in the third round. Kelley said it was not going to get to the third round, because he was going to take Hamed out in the first round.

title: Europe's Biggest Retailer Buys Warehouse Stores
description: Metro A.G. of Germany, Europe's largest retailer, said yesterday that it would buy the European warehouse stores of SHV Makro N.V. for 4.8 billion marks, or $2.7 billion, in cash and shares. Metro also warned that its 1997 operating profit would fall 25 percent.

This year, the sales saved $40 million, said Nicholas Fargo, chief of staff for Mayor Bret D. Schundler.

title: Christmas, and Beyond, in Bosnia
description: By extending the stay of American troops in Bosnia, President Clinton may help preserve an unsteady peace. But the use of NATO peacekeepers alone cannot solve the political, economic and ethnic problems that make Bosnia such a troubled land. It would be a good deal easier for Americans to support Mr. Clinton's decision if they thought he had a realistic exit strategy and were more confident that Europe would take greater responsibility for Bosnia's future security and civilian needs.

title: Thicker Than Water, Oil, Whatever
description: The full title ''Horton Foote's 'Alone' '' is the first sign that this Showtime film offers something rare. Writers are not often billed as star creators, and then only if they are commercial behemoths, a Stephen King or a Tom Clancy. But no one deserves top billing more than Mr. Foote, who in his long career as a playwright and screenwriter has never looked down on the movies; he has brought the same honesty and eloquence to films like ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' and ''Tender Mercies'' as he has to the theater, most recently in his profoundly moving play ''The Young Man From Atlanta'' (which won the 1995 Pulitzer Prize).

title: Raytheon to Settle Suit
description: The Raytheon Company and its former unit Amana will pay $10 million to settle a class-action lawsuit contending that Amana sold defective furnaces and water heaters, a lawyer representing Raytheon and Amana said yesterday. The lawsuit, filed in Polk County District Court in Iowa, said that Amana sold furnaces and water heaters with defective heating devices in Iowa between 1983 and 1990. The settlement calls for payments of $4.4 million in litigation fees and of up to $5.6 million for as many as 10,600 consumers, the lawyer, Stephen J. Holtman, said. The litigation expenses also reflected an earlier $3 million that Amana spent on restitution to about 4,000 customers in the class, he said. Mr. Holtman would not disclose how the payments would be split between the two companies.

title: Collegiate Wrestling Deaths Raise Fears About Training
description: Amateur wrestling, perhaps the simplest and purest of all sports, has been shaken by the deaths of three college wrestlers in six weeks. The deaths, all of which occurred during strenuous weight-loss workouts, have set off a national debate over training techniques, the use of controversial nutritional supplements and the risks involved in sudden, large-scale weight loss.

title: Shaken, Not Stirred, Bond Is in Business
description: No need to feel badly if the right watch, drink, cell phone, etc., don't turn you into James Bond. They don't really do it for Pierce Brosnan in ''Tomorrow Never Dies,'' either. Despite Mr. Brosnan's best efforts to be lethally debonair, the Bond franchise has sacrificed most of what made this character unique in the first place, turning the world's suavest spy into one more pitchman and fashion plate. This latest film is such a generic action event that it could be any old summer blockbuster, except that its hero is chronically overdressed.

title: South Korea Picks a President

After 40 years of fighting dictators and suffering exile, imprisonment, torture and attempted assassination, Mr. Kim will now lead his nation through its worst economic crisis. He brings a record of courage and conviction to the job, and the support of Korean workers, who are headed for rough times.

title: Sports of The Times; Van Horn Is Drawing Comparisons
description: KEITH VAN HORN made a timely cut. Sam Cassell bounced the perfect pass. The defender, Jerome Williams, was a split-second late. Too late. Van Horn took one elongated step along the left baseline and elevated, right arm outstretched to the rim. And one. Nets 99, Detroit 96. They would not trail again.

title: Acquisitions by Group 1
description: Group 1 Automotive Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire four automotive dealership groups for about $36 million in cash and $20 million in Group 1 common stock. The groups' combined 1996 revenues were more than $470 million. After completing the acquisitions, Group 1 will own 48 dealership franchises and nine collision service centers in Texas, Oklahoma, Florida and Georgia.

description: Andreas Gursky

title: Reveling In Both Body And Mind
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater loves to celebrate, and its celebrations often make the troupe seem a big family. That was the case on Wednesday night at the City Center when the company honored Masazumi Chaya for 25 years of service to the organization. The Japanese-born performer and teacher joined it as a dancer in 1972 and became associate artistic director in 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN PEACE
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. Five years since you left us. You were so special and so loved. Your wisdom and goodness will always be in our hearts. We love you. Audrey, Irik and Jaar-mel

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

description: The state's highest court today upheld the conviction of a 15-year-old boy charged with interfering with an undercover police sting operation at a drug den in Jamaica, Queens.

title: U.S. Publishes First Guide To Treatment of Infertility
description: In its first clinic-by-clinic guide to the confusing and often emotionally wrenching world of infertility treatment, the Government reported today that high-tech methods of conception failed 70 percent to 80 percent of the time.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEINBOCK, MARY
description: STEINBOCK-Mary. December 19, 1989. Remembered with love. Carol

title: Loophole for Trucks
description: New air quality rules proposed this week by the Environmental Protection Agency would require many vehicles to emit fewer smog-causing pollutants but would not affect the less stringent rules for big sport utility vehicles and big pickups.

title: Venezuela Sells Control Of State Steelmaker
description: Venezuela sold a controlling stake in the state-run steelmaker Siderurgica del Orinoco to a group including Usiminas of Brazil, Siderar of Argentina and Sivensa of Venezuela for $1.2 billion in cash. The group is acquiring a 70 percent stake in Latin America's sixth-largest steelmaker and assuming $584 million in debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSON ZLATIN, PAULA
description: KARSON ZLATIN-Paula. My sweet sister left us in body on December 14. May her sweet loving spirit and wisdom guide us forever. Thank you, Paula, for all those gifts of love. I will always love you. Your sister, Judith Share

title: Clinton Plans to Lower Another Barrier to Trade With Vietnam
description: The Clinton Administration, citing Vietnam's progress in allowing free emigration, intends to move toward more normal trading relations with Hanoi, officials said today.

title: THE TRIAL ROOM: A special report.; System of Disciplining Police Assailed From Inside and Out
description: The security camera captured it all: Two off-duty police officers entered the vestibule of a midtown Manhattan bank late one night in 1993, and one urinated in a trash can. When a homeless man asked him to stop, the officer shoved him, a fight broke out and the officer's face was cut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASANELLA, RALPH
description: FASANELLA-Ralph. The Officers and staff of 1199 National Health & Human Service Employees Union mourn the passing of a true artist of the people in the tradition of Paul Robeson and Woody Guthrie. Ralph was a dedicated labor union organizer who fought in Spain with the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. A self-taught painter, he was ''discovered'' after thirty years in obscurity. His hero was the American worker whose ''wails'' and joys ring through his art. His dream was of an America with strong, humane unions concerned with all the needs and interest of its members-for Bread and Roses, too. We in 1199 were proud to be his friend. We extend our condolences and sympathy to his wife Eva and the family. Dennis Rivera, President Moe Foner, Director 1199's Bread & Roses Cultural Project

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYRNE, FRANCIS (FRANK)
description: BYRNE-Francis (Frank). Native of Kilcar, County Donegal. On Dec. 18, 1997. Devoted husband of Marie (nee Boyle). Loving father of Mary, Francis and Eileen. Beloved grandfather of Meagan and Michael. Adored father-in-law of Christine. Reposing Quinn-Fogarty Funeral Home, 162-14 Sanford Ave., Flushing, N.Y. Visitation Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10:15 A.M., St. Andrew Avellino R.C. Church. Interment Mount St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Cancer Care or The Columbian Fathers would be greatly appreciated.

title: Moynihan and Maloney Seek Aid to Maintain Governors I.
description: As political officials try to determine what to do with Governors Island, two of New York City's top legislators have asked the Federal Government to help maintain the island's 19th-century village, which is protected as a landmark.

title: Algerian Rights Advocate Says Military and Rebels Share Blame
description: Without a free press inside Algeria, or any other independent accounting, no one can say for sure how many tens of thousands of Algerians have been killed in the last five years of civil war, or who is behind the relentless wave of massacres, ambushes and disappearances.

title: MY MANHATTAN ; Where the Third 'R' Stands for Repose
description: For years I would walk past it on 79th Street without even knowing that it was a library. It seemed, I suppose, just another elegant Upper East Side brownstone on an unusually handsome block between Madison and Park Avenues, perhaps a little grander than most. Then one day someone told me about it, this old-fashioned, private but egalitarian library. I went in and joined that day, and I've used it faithfully ever since. If anything, because I find myself increasingly ill at ease these days with the computerized nature of most larger libraries, I now use it more than ever. Truman Capote, who went there a great deal as a young man newly arrived in New York, thought of it as a place where he could take shelter; Wendy Wasserstein, who wrote significant parts of two of her plays there, uses the word heaven. I, in much the same way, think of the New York Society Library as more of a sanctuary than a library.

title: SYSTEM BLACKOUT DISRUPTS FLIGHTS AROUND COUNTRY
description: A brief and supposedly impossible power failure at an air traffic control center near Kansas City, Kan., tore the heart out of the Federal Aviation Administration's national network for several hours this morning, forcing hundreds of planes to be diverted or delayed, and inconveniencing tens of thousands of passengers.

title: Teamsters' Union Is Ordered to Pay Its Own Way in New Election
description: A Federal judge directed the teamsters' union yesterday to pay for the coming election that was ordered after last year's outcome was nullified.

title: Using Theaters For Promotion
description: Altogether, ''Hugo Pool,'' which opened in theaters in New York and Los Angeles last week, is an example of an emerging breed of small independent movies that have a legitimate place on the big screen but that are up there primarily to raise awareness for the video release.

title: On My Mind ; Settlement Is Not Forever
description: Beneath all the negotiations, arguments, deals and delays about an Israeli-Palestinian settlement is a fundamental conclusion that both sides share but Americans and Europeans generally have not grasped.

title: Kodak Raises Its Job-Cut Total Sharply
description: The Eastman Kodak Company drastically raised the company's planned number of job eliminations to 16,600 yesterday, saying the 10,000 figure announced only a month ago was just an estimate and that managers had since found more positions they could cut.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; Death Penalty Not Sought In Slaying of Cabby
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that they would not seek the death penalty for a young woman and a teen-ager who are charged in the shooting death on Nov. 14 of a livery-cab driver.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; Man Is Charged in Abuse Of Girl, 6, in Brooklyn
description: A 6-year-old girl in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, was repeatedly sodomized over the last six months by a 47-year-old man living with her and her mother, the police said. The man, Carmello Roldan, was arrested Wednesday at 11 P.M. near 86th Street and Fifth Avenue and charged with attempted rape, sodomy, endangering the welfare of child and sexual abuse, the police said.

description: Aetna Stock Falls 10%; Top Financial Officer Exits

description: This growing old together had left the Knicks set in their ways. Not that there isn't some comfort in predictability.

title: Nielsen Makes Acquisition
description: The A. C. Nielsen Corporation has acquired Entertainment Data Inc., a provider of information for the film industry, for $26 million. Entertainment Data, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., provides overnight box-office information in the United States and also has operations in Britain, Germany, Spain and France. A. C. Nielsen is a market data company in Stamford, Conn.

title: Classics That Sizzle
description: I went the other day to see ''The Wings of the Dove,'' a film version of Henry James's 1902 novel, in which Helena Bonham Carter removes her clothes and pretends to have sex with her co-star, Linus Roache. The movie was preceded by a trailer for ''Swept From the Sea,'' whose advertising slogan is, ''From Joseph Conrad comes a timeless tale of passion!''

title: Owner to Dismantle Flawed Madison Ave. Facade
description: The developer Harry Macklowe said yesterday that he would dismantle the entire south facade of his 39-story tower at 540 Madison Avenue, brick by brick, rather than risk having another section of the wall break away from the building and tumble into the street.

title: James Bond and Robin Hood Battle for Glory at the Table
description: There is a long tradition in England of entertaining bridge books with fictional characters. First there was S. J. Simon and Victor Mollo, and today, David Bird and the Kings.

title: EMERITUS UNIT SWEETENS ITS ARV ASSISTED BID
description: The Emeritus Corporation said yesterday that its EMAC Corporation unit had begun a sweetened hostile cash tender offer of $17.50 a share for a rival, ARV Assisted Living Inc. The Emeritus offer totals about $313.2 million, including assumed debt. Emeritus owns 1.08 million shares, or about 6.8 percent of ARV Assisted Living's shares. ARV Assisted Living has 49 assisted-living communities and dominates the California market, where Emeritus wants to expand. Emeritus has 115 communities in 19 states. ARV Assisted Living shares rose $1.3125, to $15.5625, in Amex trading. Emeritus shares rose 18.75 cents, to $13.625. In October, the Seattle-based Emeritus made an offer of $286 million, but ARV Assisted Living rejected the bid.

title: About New York ; A Few Lessons In the Fine Art Of Parenthood
description: A few months ago, during one of those quiet moments she savors in her tiny Bed-Stuy apartment, Tamiko Little sat down on the living room windowsill and saw past and future collide in one searing moment. Across the street, a woman cried hysterically, watching helplessly as the police handed her two children to child welfare workers sitting in a van. Ms. Little turned away and flipped the channels on her television set, looking for some comedy that would bring elusive relief.

title: Occidental Pipeline-Unit Sale Realigns Natural Gas Industry
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation's agreement to sell its Midcon gas pipeline unit to KN Energy Inc. for $3.49 billion in cash will help move Occidental further into its core oil business and will quadruple KN's assets.

description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs; Botha Again Ignores Truth Panel's Subpoena
description: Former President P. W. Botha again defied South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission today, ignoring a third subpoena to appear before the panel to answer questions about how many apartheid-era atrocities were sanctioned by the government.

title: IPC TO BE ACQUIRED BY CABLE SYSTEMS HOLDING
description: IPC Information Systems Inc., a maker of financial trading systems, will be acquired by Cable Systems Holding L.L.C. and its Cable Systems International Inc. unit, IPC said yesterday. IPC Information said the acquisition, which was structured as a leveraged recapitalization, was valued at $253 million, including debt. Cable Systems will purchase between 54 percent and 90 percent of IPC's outstanding shares for $21 each. Shareholders will have the option to receive $21 a share in cash or retain a portion of their equity in the recapitalized company. If Cable Systems purchases 90 percent of IPC, the total cash consideration would be $204 million. In Nasdaq trading, shares of IPC rose $1.5625, to $19.9375.

description: FASANELLA-Ralph. The officers and members of the United Electrical Workers (UE) mourn the passing of co-worker Ralph Fasanella. As a UE member and organizer, Ralph was dedicated to our union's principles. His depiction of UE scenes in his paintings is a source of pride, but we also rejoice in the love of humanity which informs all of his work. John H. Hovis Jr. General President Robert L. Clark General Secretary-Treasurer Robert B. Kingsley Director of Organization

description: A Sussex County man who shot his ex-wife yesterday morning turned a gun on himself outside a mall in Mount Olive Township last night, the police said.

description: BRUNO-William S. On December 18, at age 86, of Boca Raton and Somers, New York, formerly of Mamaroneck. Beloved husband of Miriam Gwertzman. Devoted father of Dr. Edwin J. title: State Leaders on Education Back Year-Round Schooling
description: Seeking to help New York City resolve its school overcrowding, the State Education Commissioner and the Board of Regents today proposed a far-reaching plan that would allow districts to adopt a year-round school calendar.

title: World News Briefs; More Recuperation Is Ordered for Yeltsin
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, whose health is almost always worse than he says it is, planned to return to his desk in the Kremlin today. Instead his doctors announced that Russia's ailing President, who is suffering from a viral infection, would have to spend an extra week in a sanatorium.

title: Unabom Trial Yields Further Hint of Defense Rift
description: The Federal judge at the Unabom trial of Theodore J. Kaczynski held an unusual closed-door meeting with the defendant and his lawyers today, without any prosecutors present.

title: F.D.A. Panel Recommends Approval of a Chiron Drug
description: For the Chiron Corporation, the F.D.A. giveth and the F.D.A. taketh away.

title: U.S. Braces for Wider Trade Gaps and New Confrontations
description: After years in which the strong economy has dampened confrontations over international trade, the issue is set to flare again against a backdrop of turmoil in Asia as imports surge and exporters find it more difficult to sell their goods abroad.

title: Anthony Ulasewicz, 'Bagman' Of Watergate, Is Dead at 79
description: Anthony T. Ulasewicz, the onetime New York City police detective who injected merriment into the Senate Watergate hearings a quarter-century ago by telling of his adventures and misadventures as a ''bagman,'' died on Wednesday in Glens Falls, N.Y. He was 79.

description: In percent

title: The Rangers Have Reasons to Fear the Lowly Lightning
description: Even though Tampa Bay has the worst record in the National Hockey League, the Rangers have reason to fear the Lightning. In their first visit here this season, the Rangers played one of their worst games, losing by 6-3. In five meetings between the teams last season, two of them here, the Lightning won all five.

title: N.F.L.: WEEK 17
description: WASHINGTON

title: Lipinski's Imperfect Lutz Is Good Enough for First
description: Tara Lipinski may have landed an imperfect lutz tonight, but at least she performed the jump by putting only her skates and not her hands on the ice. And she avoided the trash talk that threatened to turn this Olympic figure-skating preview into a professional wrestling match.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by Reuters on Dec. 12 about Russian sales of uranium for commercial uses referred incorrectly to an American company involved in the Russian uranium trade. The United States Enrichment Corporation, which has a contract to buy enriched uranium from dismantled nuclear weapons, is not one of the three Western companies involved in a contested agreement to buy Russian natural uranium. And United States Enrichment is a Government-owned company that plans to be, but has not yet been, privatized.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMAN, SEYMOUR
description: SELIGMAN-Seymour. Beloved husband of Lottie; father of Raymond, Susan and Pat; grandfather of Brian, Paul, Jordyn, Jared, Scott and Maggie; brother Edward; Uncle. Friend to all. Services at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway in Fresh Meadows, New York, Sunday, 12 Noon.

title: Washington Wrestles With Its Opera Ambitions
description: When Placido Domingo took over as artistic director of the Washington Opera two years ago, he knew the company had ambitious plans. Just how ambitious, he didn't ''exactly'' know, he said recently. He soon learned that there were ambitious plans to build a new opera house in downtown Washington at the considerable cost of $200 million.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Upholds California Term Limits Law
description: Upholding a measure that has dramatically reshaped electoral politics in the nation's most populous state, a Federal appeals court ruled today that legislative term limits approved seven years ago by California voters do not infringe politicians' constitutional rights, and that voters were well aware they were adopting lifetime limits on lawmakers' service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICCOLI, REVEREND ANDREW
description: NICCOLI-Reverend Andrew. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the retired parochial vicar of Most Precious Blood Church, 32-23 36th St., Long Island City, On December 18. Reposing in Thomas M. Quinn & Sons Funeral Home, 32-20 Broadway, Long Island City, Sunday, Dec. 21, 2-5 P.M. Mass of Transferral Sunday, Dec. 21, 7:30 P.M., Most Precious Blood Church. Funeral Mass, Monday, December 22, at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: At Last, Vindication For an Unflagging Jets Fan; Frustration and Futility Are Part Of the Game, So Is Loyalty
description: These last awful -- really, really awful -- years, Judy Grubin had been noodging her husband about the Jets tickets. ''Enough is enough!'' she would complain.

title: The New York State of Mind Is Wreathed in Good Cheer
description: Jennifer Calhoun has driven a carriage in Central Park for 15 years, and not since the boom years of the 1980's has business been so good. And it seems that everyone who steps into her white carriage, festooned with red bows, is laden with Big Brown Bags from Bloomingdale's or bags with the wooden-soldier emblem of Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: U.N. Agrees to Create Position Of Deputy Secretary General
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan won a major round today in his campaign to bring a new management style to the United Nations when the General Assembly agreed to create the position of Deputy Secretary General.

title: Mayor Defends Calls By Budget Director
description: Waving away widespread criticism, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said at a news conference yesterday that he was ''proud'' of his Budget Director, Joseph J. Lhota, for calling securities firms that underwrite city bonds and urging them not to make donations the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group that has often criticized the administration.

title: NCR WILL SELL THREE PLANTS TO SOLECTRON
description: The NCR Corporation has agreed to sell manufacturing plants in three cities to the Solectron Corporation for about $100 million, the companies said yesterday. The companies also said Solectron would produce computers and retail equipment for NCR for at least five years. Solectron will hire about 1,200 NCR manufacturing employees. NCR said the sale allowed it to focus on combining software and professional services with hardware. The plants are in Columbia, S.C., Atlanta and Dublin, Ireland. They produce NCR's computer servers, retail scanners and cash registers. Solectron, based in Milpitas, Calif., provides manufacturing services for other companies. NCR is based in Dayton, Ohio.

title: The Real John Quincy Adams
description: The opinions of history often seem bewildering, as verdicts about Presidents can attest. For instance, George Washington and Thomas Jefferson have become victims of some historians playing social reformer, a popular role in academe. Washington and Jefferson have been portrayed as weak-willed mortals who owned slaves and who believed white males to be God's supreme creature.

title: Hamed Beats Kelley in 4th in Battle of Knockdowns
description: Prince Naseem Hamed took seven minutes to enter the ring last night. With strobe lights flashing, disco music pulsating and confetti raining down, a raucous crowd of 11,954 at Madison Square Garden cheered wildly for the prancing featherweight. Meanwhile, Kevin Kelley of Queens waited, steaming and stewing inside the ring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, HARRY
description: RICH-Harry. The Board of Directors and membership of the National Council of Jewish Women wish to express their heartfelt condolences to our esteemed National President, Nan Rich, on the loss of her father-in-law, Harry Rich of Miami, Florida. We extend our profound sympathy to her husband, David and their family. The Board of Directors National Council of Jewish Women

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELTRI, MICHELANGELO
description: VELTRI-Michelangelo. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our esteemed colleague and friend, Michelangelo Veltri, who led more than one hundred performances with the company over nearly one quarter of a century. We shall miss him, and extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: D. R. HORTON SET TO BUY CONTINENTAL HOMES
description: D. R. Horton Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Continental Homes Holding Corporation for $40.55 a share in stock, based on Thursday's closing price, a total of $305 million. D. R. Horton, based in Arlington, Tex., will also assume $278 million of Continental's debt. The combined company will have revenue of $1.6 billion and sell more than 10,000 single-family homes annually in 21 states, primarily in the Southern United States. It will be the nation's fourth-largest home builder. D. R. Horton's shares fell $2.0625, to $17.1875, on the New York Stock Exchange, where Continental's shares rose $4.625, to $39.6875. Continental is the former home-building arm of the American Continental Corporation, a company once controlled by Charles H. Keating Jr., who was accused of savings-and-loan fraud.

title: 3 Are Charged In a Slaying Over Drugs
description: Three young men, none older than 20, were charged yesterday with torturing an 18-year-old woman to the point of unconsciousness and then throwing her from the roof of a high-rise apartment building on the Lower East Side. Law enforcement officials say they killed her over an outstanding drug debt.

title: A Plunge in Asia Unnerves Wall Street
description: In some of the wildest volatility since the market's plunge nearly two months ago, stocks plummeted early yesterday in near-record volume before rebounding. Investors sold on news of a big bankruptcy in Japan, which sent Japanese stocks tumbling and set off a wave of market declines worldwide. Business Day, page D1.

title: How a Spy Left Taiwan in the Cold
description: A United States spy whose role was cultivated for two decades rose to the top of Taiwan's secret nuclear weapons program and, at a crucial moment, stole vital documents that stopped the program in its tracks, according to former intelligence officials.

title: Flamenco Klezmer? Bold Spectacle Meets Friendly Sing-Along
description: At ''Flamenco Klezmer Festival,'' a concert on Thursday night at Town Hall, the two genres may have met backstage. Three klezmer bands -- the Klezmatics, Kapelye and Cayuga Klezmer Revival -- shared the first half of the concert; then came the Roberto Castellon Jr. Ensemble ensemble backing two flamenco dancers and a singer. There was one collaboration: Rex Benincasa, the drummer from the flamenco ensemble, sat in with the Klezmatics on a song from Morocco. But a concert that was billed as an encounter between two traditions that share some Gypsy and Jewish roots wound up revealing not their kinship, but the distance between them.

title: Pressed by Environmentalists, Pataki Drops Prison Plan
description: Under intense pressure from some of the state's largest environmental groups, the Pataki administration said yesterday that it had abandoned plans to build a 750-cell maximum-security prison in the quaint Adirondack hamlet of Tupper Lake.

title: INSIDE: Arts & Ideas
description: Multiculturalism takes aim at math to make it friendlier. PAGE B7

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: CONNECTICUT ; Traffic Charges Loom For Convicted Rapist
description: Alex Kelly, who is serving a 16-year sentence for rape, could face another 16 years in prison on charges that he fled the scene of an accident last year and left his injured girlfriend on the road.

title: Rowland Withdraws State Police Nomination
description: With the acting head of the Connecticut State Police facing allegations that he abused his power and was insensitive to women and gay people, Gov. John G. Rowland said yesterday that he was withdrawing his nomination of the official for permanent appointment to the post.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEY, F. DONALD
description: KENNEY-F. Donald. Suddenly on Dec. 17, 1997. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave. at 76 St, Monday, December 22, 10:00 A.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the National Academy of Design, NYC, or St. Bonaventure University, Olean, New York.

title: Hambros to Dissolve; Banking Unit Sold
description: Hambros P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it would dissolve its 158-year-old business, selling its investment banking unit to Societe Generale of France and disposing of other holdings after it failed to match the profits of its larger rivals. Hambros said it would sell its 1,400-employee bank to Societe Generale for $:300 million ($491 million) and give up control of its insurance and real estate holdings to shareholders. It will entertain offers for its fund management and venture capital units.

title: Owen Barfield, 99, Word Lover And C. S. Lewis Associate
description: Owen Barfield, a writer and philosopher of language and the last surviving member of the Inklings, a group of Oxford intellectuals who held passionate discussions about Christianity and mythology at C. S. Lewis's house between the world wars, died at home in East Sussex, England, on Sunday, friends said. He was 99.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, MARTIN
description: BERKOWITZ-Martin. December 18th, 1997. Beloved husband of Joan, loving father of Larry and the late Steven and Alan, adored grandfather of Danny, Stacy and Andrew. Devoted brother of Bryant and Enid, loving uncle and cousin. Services 12:30PM, Sunday at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Inquiries to ''Riverside Nassau North Chapels'' at 516-487-9600.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Newbold Noyes Jr., a former editor of The Washington Evening Star, misspelled the surname of the Houston businessman who bought control of The Star's parent company in 1975. He is Joe L. Allbritton, not Albritton.

title: Masaru Ibuka, 89, Engineer And Sony Co-Founder, Dies
description: Masaru Ibuka, a low-key engineer who co-founded one of Japan's greatest postwar successes, the Sony Corporation, died yesterday at his home in Tokyo.

title: Laura Ashley Names New Finance Director
description: Laura Ashley Holdings P.L.C. said yesterday that it had appointed a new finance director and agreed to new loan terms with its banks as part of the clothing company's reorganization to reverse slumping profit. Richard Pennycook, finance director at the pub chain J. D. Wetherspoon P.L.C., will become Laura Ashley's finance chief as of March 16.

title: Rijo and Sanders Reject Offers
description: Jose Rijo, who hasn't pitched in the major leagues since 1995 because of elbow injuries and operations, and Deion Sanders, the football player, last night rejected the Cincinnati Reds' salary arbitration offers. The Reds have until Jan 8 to sign those free agents or lose negotiating rights until May 1.

title: Jimmy Rogers, 73, Guitarist Specializing in Electric Blues
description: Jimmy Rogers, one of the most significant figures in the history of electric blues, died yesterday at Holy Cross Hospital in Chicago. He was 73 and lived in Chicago.

title: Sports of The Times; Keeping Success In Perspective
description: THEY say that Barry Sanders is the National Football League's answer to Michael Jordan. For the Jets' sake, for the sake of the fans and a great story, let's hope not. Jordan, as New York fans will painfully testify, is a killer in big games like this.

title: Foley's Possible Relief Role Creates Puzzle for Parcells
description: Bill Parcells painted a picture of a pained coach today in trying to decide how to use Glenn Foley, the injured quarterback he favors over the starter Neil O'Donnell.

title: Benes's Contract Still Up in Air
description: Andy Benes will have to wait at least two more weeks to find out if he has a five-year, $30 million contract with the St. Louis Cardinals. A hearing before baseball's new impartial arbitrator, Dana Eischen, was held yesterday but was not finished and will resume Jan. 2.

title: Raines and Lloyd Re-Sign
description: Left fielder Tim Raines signed a one-year contract with the Yankees yesterday for $900,000 with incentives that could raise his salary to $1.3 million; the left-hander Graeme Lloyd agreed to a two-year deal for $1.8 million, and the newly acquired third baseman Scott Brosius was signed for one year at $2.5 million. But the Yankees stopped negotiations with Darryl Strawberry, who rejected their offer of salary arbitration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, IRWIN R.

Walter H. Annenberg and two sisters, Enid A. Haupt and Evelyn A. Hall. She is also survived by five grandchildren, Donald P. Kahn, Jr., Douglas T. Kahn (Dr. Margaret Carter), Steven D. Kahn, Alexandra Kahn (John Graubert) and Julie K. Brown, and five great grandchildren, Sophia and Isabel CarterKahn, Christina Graubert, Thomas M. Bender and Samuel A. Brown, Jr. She was first married to the late L. Stanley Kahn-a member of the New York Stock Exchange. In 1938 she married investment banker, Joseph A. Neff who died in 1969. She was very active in New York Charities-especially the Metropolitan Opera where she donated the Lobby Colonnade in memory of her mother, Mrs. Moses L. Annenberg. In addition, she funded the redecoration of the Blue Room at The White House, and, with her brother and his wife, helped fund projects at both the State Department's Diplomatic Reception Rooms and Blair House. In 1977, Mrs. Hooker gave an historic emerald to the National Gem Collection at the National Museum of Natural History. In 1991 and 1992, she gave additional gems to the collection and was the major donor for the Janet Annenberg Hooker Hall of Geology, Gems and Minerals which opened in September 1997. Mrs. Hooker, a resident of Palm Beach, Florida, also owned a summer home, Fairholme, in Newport, Rhode Island. A Funeral Mass was held. For information call Frank E. Campbell, New York City, 212-288-3500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCHMAN, LESTER R., M.D.
description: TUCHMAN-Lester R., M.D. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center deeply mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague Lester R. Tuchman, M.D., Clinical Professor Emeritus in Medicine, whose association with Mount Sinai spanned seven decades. After earning his medical degree at Columbia University, Dr. Tuchman joined Mount Sinai in 1927 as House Surgeon and became known for his leadership among the attending staff and his devotion to Mount Sinai and its Alumni, who honored him in 1966 with their highest award, the Jacobi Medallion. He played a pivotal role in the establishment of our academic affiliation with Elmhurst Hospital Center, a relationship which he guided as Elmhurst's Director of Medicine during the formative years that were the foundation for what has become one of the most productive associations of its kind, significantly enhancing the delivery of health care services in Queens. An outstanding internist, he was known for both his devotion to his patients and for his clinical skills as well as for his dedication to the dissemination of medical knowledge, exemplified by his many years of service as editor of The Mount Sinai Journal of Medicine, his teaching, and the establishment in his name and honor of the Lester R. Tuchman Scholarship and Student Loan Fund at Mount Sinai by the Esther Simon Charitable Trust. He will be remembered fondly and he will be sorely missed. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his children, Lucy, Jessica and Alma, to his sisters, Martha and Lucille, and to the entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, M.D., President Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice-President Wendy Z. Goldstein, Director Alan L. Schiller, M.D., President, Medical Board

description: Hanukkah, the Feast of Lights, begins at sundown on Tuesday, celebrating a moment of Jewish revival: the successful revolt by the forces of Judah Maccabee against the oppressive Syrian king Antiochus 2,200 years ago.

title: Seoul Hires Two Firms On Wall St. For Advice
description: Still trying to avoid a financial meltdown, South Korea today hired Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Smith Barney as advisers and said it would guarantee up to $20 billion in overseas borrowing by domestic banks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNTON, MARK
description: LYNTON-Mark. Beloved husband of Marion, father of Michael and Lili, grandfather of Claire, Nina, Kate, Eloise, Maisie. Visitation on December 19, from 4 to 6PM, 48 West 70 Street, December 20, 11:30 to 2:00 PM, December 21, 3:30, 961 Fenimore Road, Larchmont.

title: Dismissed Worker Kills 4 and Then Is Slain
description: A dismissed state highway employee armed with an AK-47 assault rifle killed four of his former co-workers at a maintenance yard yesterday in Orange, a Los Angeles suburb, before being shot to death by the police in a fierce gun battle.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a front page article yesterday about the election of Kim Dae Jung as President of South Korea omitted two lines on the continuation in some copies. The sentence should have read: ''It is difficult to exaggerate the historical resonance of the scenes this morning as Mr. Kim -- the man who was nearly hanged as a traitor -- stood before a forest of microphones and accepted his election.''

title: American Fashion Ends Fling at the Piers and Moves Its Big Shows Back to Bryant Park
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that the twice-a- year fashion shows would return to Bryant Park this spring after top designers harshly criticized the shows held last month at the Chelsea Piers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report and headline on Tuesday about John O'Quinn, a personal-injury lawyer from Houston, misstated the charge to which he pleaded guilty in a case involving a 1994 USAir crash. Mr. O'Quinn pleaded guilty to the misdemeanor charge of practicing law without a license in South Carolina; he did not plead guilty to improper solicitation of victims after the crash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROLNICK, MURIEL
description: GROLNICK-Muriel, 70. Of Huntington, New York, and Aventura, Florida, of cancer on December 19, 1997. Beloved and loving wife of Lester Grolnick; adored sister of Tobye Gerber and Robert Steinman, mother of the late Don Grolnick, and mother-in-law of Jeanne O'Connor Grolnick. One of the finest women in the world. Memorial Service to be held are at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island, at 3:00 PM on Sunday, December 21. For information, call 516-921-5757. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Cancer Care.

title: Senator Asks How Long Rights Choice Will Remain
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, countered the White House today for naming a civil rights-enforcement official he does not like by saying that the man should probably be limited to four months in office.

title: Albright Quest: A Silver Lining in the Middle East
description: Before Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's meeting on Thursday with the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, American officials told the Israelis that it would be better not to bring a specific proposal for a withdrawal from the West Bank, American and Israeli officials said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MACERICH INC., Santa Monica, Calif., a real estate investment trust, acquired the Citadel, a shopping mall in Colorado Springs, for $108 million.

title: In Private Meetings, F.B.I. Chief Suggests That He May Leave
description: Publicly, Louis J. Freeh has said he has no intention of resigning as Director of the F.B.I., but privately he has been expressing much less certainty about how long he will stay at the helm of the agency, in part because of his recent struggles with the White House and the Justice Department over the appointment of an independent counsel in the campaign finance case, associates said today.

title: Group Cancels Cruise to Cuba For Papal Visit
description: The Archbishop of Miami today canceled plans for American Catholics to travel on a cruise ship to Cuba for the Pope's visit next month, calling the means of transportation ''a source of serious tension in our community.''

title: Eddie Chapman, 83, Safecracker and Spy
description: Eddie Chapman, a notorious British safecracker who hoodwinked German intelligence in World War II -- winning the Nazis' Iron Cross for bravery while serving as a double agent for Britain -- died on Dec. 11 at a nursing home in Brickett Wood, near London. He was 83.

title: Journal; Let Them Entertain You
description: It was only five days after Kenny McCaughey told the world that he would not turn his septuplets into ''a big show'' and put them on ''display'' that he displayed them on NBC's big show, ''Dateline.'' It took only a few weeks more for the McCaugheys to hitch their star to a show-biz agent. On Wednesday it was announced they had signed with Wes Yoder of Nashville's Ambassador Agency, which represents Christian recording artists like Susie Luchsinger and Rebecca St. James as well as such secular stand-up comics as Oliver North, Alan Keyes and Gary Bauer.

title: Cigarettes and Free Speech
description: Reducing the number of teen-agers who get hooked on smoking is an important goal. But in passing new restrictions on outdoor cigarette advertising to protect children this week, the New York City Council came uncomfortably close to banning a whole category of commercial speech, thus trampling on principles of free expression.

title: Why Judge Feminism if We Can't Even Define It?; Army Is a Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORBAN, JOETTA
description: NORBAN-Joetta. On December 18, 1997, in New York City, at the age of 83. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Norban. Loving mother of Linda Lane and Wendy Carduner. Devoted grandmother of Lisa, Julie, Stacey, Jason, Marc and Eric. Adoring great-grandmother of Alex, Madison, and her newborn grandson. Dear mother-in-law of Jules and Andrew. As long as we are here, you will be here with us, in our lives and hearts. The funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held in January. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to Dr. Valentine Fuster, Director of the Cardiovascular Institute, Mount Sinai Medical Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORG, ESTHER EISEN
description: TORG-Esther Eisen. Wednesday, December 17, 1997 in Orlando, Florida. Beloved wife and sweetheart of the late Arthur. Daughter of Jacob and Adele Eisen. Funeral services on Sunday at 10 A.M., Riverside Memorial, Mount Vernon, New York, ph. (914) 664-6800. She now rests with the fathers.

title: Landlord Denies Wrongdoing In Disappearance of Tenants
description: The lower Manhattan landlord who is the focus of a police investigation into the disappearance of two of his tenants denied any wrongdoing yesterday and said he did not know the whereabouts of the tenants, Michael Sullivan and Camden Sylvia.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We will be ambassadors. It will give big encouragement to Kenya and to Africa. South Africans, Nigerians, they might want to try this. Ethiopians will say, 'If the Kenyans are doing this, why not try it too?' ''

description: BASEBALL

title: Daimler Delaying Debut of Small Car
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. has delayed the production of a new class of very small cars to solve a stability problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANTERNIK, MEYER
description: GLANTERNIK-Meyer. Beloved husband of the late Laura. Devoted father of Aileen and Alvin Murstein and Henry and Karen. Adored grandfather of Andrew and Barbara; Amie, Diana and Julia. Adoring great-grandfather of Kimberly. Services Sunday 9:45 AM, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Drunk Leading the Drunk
description: Last spring the National Interfraternity Council began a campaign to persuade fraternities to ban alcohol and other intoxicants from fraternity property and to begin scheduling alcohol-free social events. The council gave the impression that fraternity leaders were making headway against the heavy drinking around which their culture has revolved. But a study in the January issue of the Journal of Studies on Alcohol shows that fraternity leaders themselves are the nub of the problem.

title: Emergency Rooms Shut; Inadequate Care Cited
description: State health officials suspended most emergency-room services at two hospitals in southern New Jersey yesterday, saying that 11 patients or more were given inadequate care, resulting in at least one death.

title: World News Briefs; British Press Authority Imposes Code on Privacy
description: The Government commission that oversees the behavior of the press in Britain published a new code of conduct today seeking to curb invasions of privacy, intrusions into grief, harassment of photo subjects and exploitation of children.

title: The Subjective Underbelly Of Hardheaded Math
description: At the end of the earnestly titled recent book ''What is Mathematics, Really?,'' the mathematician Reuben Hersh engages in what might be called a thought experiment. He contemplates a list of philosophers and divides them into two opposing political camps.

title: TELESYSTEM BUYING NATIONAL BAND THREE
description: Telesystem International Wireless Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy National Band Three Ltd. of Britain and Terrafon Bundelfunk of Germany for a total of $100 million. Telesystem, based in Montreal, said the companies are specialized mobile radio operators with more than 105,000 subscribers in total. Telesystem said National Band is currently owned by Geotek Communications Inc., based in Montvale, N.J. For the first 11 months of 1997, National Band generated sales of about $28.5 million. Terrafon has more than 40,000 subscribers.

title: Twilight of the Mandela Era
description: With an uncharacteristically militant valedictory speech, South Africa's President, Nelson Mandela, who is 79, this week marked the beginning of the end of his era. He gave up the presidency of the African National Congress and said his leadership of the nation was now largely ceremonial. His successor in the A.N.C. and South Africa's likely next president in 1999 is Thabo Mbeki, who as Deputy President has been handling most governing duties. Mr. Mandela's speech, while alarming in tone, expressed grievances that are splitting the A.N.C. and could explode nationwide if not addressed by Mr. Mbeki.

title: Ignoring African Abuses Is No Foreign Policy; Congo's Progress
description: To the Editor:

description: BARNEY'S VERSION

title: The Social Register: Just a Circle of Friends
description: TUCKED away below the only convenience store on Fishers Island, N.Y., the Tidal Wave Beauty Salon is not easy to find. Like the discreet old-money families who have been summering at this resort off the tip of Long Island for generations, the salon doesn't need to shout its existence.

title: Melissa Kaufman, Marc Edelman
description: Melissa Jill Kaufman and Marc F. Edelman, teachers on Long Island, were married last evening at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst. Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HSU, DR. KONRAD C.
description: HSU-Dr. Konrad C. Professor at Columbia University. On December 19, 1997. Beloved husband of Toni. Loving father of Konrad, Jr., loving grandfather of 12 and great grandfather of six. Reposing at Chun Fook Funeral Home, 134-35 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY. Visiting Sunday, 2-7 PM and Monday, 10 AM-12 noon. Religious services Sunday, 12 noon, at Chun Fook Funeral Home, Flushing. Interment Kensico Cemetery.

title: Rangers Tie the Lowly, And for Them It's a Plus
description: For a team that dresses in red, white and blue and sometimes wears Lady Liberty on its collective chest, it is appropriate that the Rangers are occasionally led by their all-American line and the supporting cast of Yanks behind them. In a 2-2 tie with Tampa Bay today, their goals were scored by Tim Sweeney and Kevin Stevens, both from Massachusetts. Helping to set up both goals was Pat LaFontaine, who was born in St. Louis and raised in suburban Detroit.

title: Q&A/Nancy Hadley ; The Orchestration of 21 Communities
description: NANCY HADLEY is the executive director of the Community Foundation for Greater New Haven. With assets of $180 million, it distributes about $5 million a year in grants and other assistance to support education, community and economic development, health, the arts, food and shelter and the environment in the New Haven region. The group ranks first in the nation among community foundations in investment performance in the trust category.

title: Twin Cyranos With Little in Common but a Nose
description: ONE IS GNOMISH AND pliable, with the remarkable ability to vanish into any character he portrays, from Shylock to the artist Stanley Spencer. The other is a bearish, Byronic figure with an air of princely grandeur that wafts over his every performance, whether it is the paranoid military man of ''The Father,'' the jaded matinee idol of Noel Coward's ''Present Laughter'' or even Count Dracula.

description: It was a week of disturbing news about the quality of supervision in two of America's leading teaching hospitals.

title: Is Tyson Chicken?
description: ' Mike Tyson is a good boxer, but he is not the best fighter,'' says Royce Gracie (pictured), a Brazilian who is a three-time winner of the Ultimate Fighting Championship. ''I am the best fighter.''

title: Aiding Workers With 401(k)'s
description: Fidelity Investments, the country's largest provider of 401(k) plans to companies, will begin providing financial education programs for employees of client companies in 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEY, F. DONALD
description: KENNEY-F. Donald. Suddenly on Dec. 17, 1997. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave. at 76 St, Monday, December 22, 10:00 A.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the National Academy of Design, NYC, or St. Bonaventure University, Olean, New York.

title: Neuberger and Albee Curate Each Other
description: COLLECTORS as a breed are not noted for their modesty, and the two sharing the limelight in the Neuberger Museum at Purchase College here have plenty not to be modest about. Roy R. Neuberger and Edward Albee were invited to assemble ''Eye to Eye,'' as long as each chose works from the other's collection.

title: December 14-20; A Holding Action In the Pentagon Gender War
description: The latest shot in the military's gender wars caught even the Pentagon by surprise. After six quiet months of study, a committee appointed by Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen recommended last week that the Army, Navy and Air Force separate men and women for more -- though not all -- of boot camp and advanced training.

title: Reigning Cats and Dogs; The Puppy as Political Prop
description: HERE'S the dirty little secret about the White House. Many Presidents have owned cats, but they've kept it quiet. The face Presidents like to show the public is that of a pooch. In Warren G. Harding's campaign literature, he posed with his ever-present Airedale under the slogan, ''Return to Normalcy.''

title: New York Relying on Construction Industry to Police Itself
description: Over the last two decades, driven by budget cuts and what it calls the impossibility of overseeing the city's vast construction projects, New York City has largely handed over the regulation of the building industry to the industry itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENARD, JOSEPH
description: RENARD-Joseph. December 3, 1997. Playwright, actor, author. His friends will miss his wit. Memorial/ Theater for the New City, Dec. 21.

title: A New 'Anne Frank' Still Stuck in the 50's
description: WHEN FRANCES GOODRICH and Albert Hackett adapted ''Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl'' for the 1955 Broadway stage production, they wrote a play in terms that would speak to audiences of the mid-1950's. The war against Nazi Germany had been over only 10 years. Israel was a new state, aged seven. Elie Wiesel's ''Night'' would not be published in English for another five years. Adolf Eichmann was alive and well and living in South America and, thus, Hannah Arendt hadn't yet had occasion to write ''Eichmann in Jerusalem: A Report on the Banality of Evil.''

title: Arts Endowment Gives 4 Grants to State Groups
description: Four New Jersey organizations are to share $111,500 in 1998 grants from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Habitats/36 Gramercy Park East; To Get a View of the Park, First Get a Roommate
description: JEREMY SPARROW wanted an apartment on Gramercy Park, and since there is only one rental building left there he flagged his broker months before he had to move.

title: A Pilgrim's Progress To Literary Shrines
description: READING ''The Canterbury Tales'' with my son, who is studying Chaucer in 10th-grade English, I realize -- a few lines into the General Prologue -- that the idea of a pilgrimage seems to him no less bizarre than any other archaic, peculiar 14th-century custom: the idea, for example, that one could get a reduced sentence in Purgatory by purchasing holy relics from the Pardoner.

title: Signs for the Hearing, Lessons From the Deaf
description: THE students sat in a circle, completely silent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENARD, NEAL
description: RENARD-Neal. Died peacefully on Dec. 18, in Florida. Beloved husband of Pauline. Devoted father of Susan and Bruce Renard. Loving stepfather of Adrienne and Jeffrey Saporta, Janet and Bruce Adler, and Rita and Dick Singer. Grandfather of Cutler. A funeral was held on Dec. 19. He will be missed by all.
