description: EACH year it's inspirational but hard work to transform the Brookfield Craft Center, housed in a former grist mill, from classrooms to show space for the Holiday Arts and Crafts Exhibition and Sale (displayed through Dec. 31).

description: BASKIN-Herbert ''Colonel''. Beloved husband of Libby. Devoted father to Susan, Ellen, Martin, David and Lois. Adoring grandfather to Charlotte, Julia, Nathan, William, Zachary, Jesse, Rebeccah and Sam. Loving brother to Rhoda. Cherished brother-in-law, father-in-law, uncle, cousin and friend. He lived a life of dignity and viewed the world with an open mind and open heart. He took pride in everything; his family, his city (New York), his business (Baskin Floor Coverings), his military service (Lt. Col. US Army Reserves). He left us too soon. He will always be with us. Services Sunday, December 21, 1 PM, Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY. 516-487-9600.

title: Gentrification With a Twist: Keeping Nautical Tranquillity
description: Head from the Bronx River Parkway to the Pelham Parkway and cross the City Island Bridge. Abruptly you enter a marine village that seems to belong miles and miles from New York City. At first glance, City Island, a slow-paced community of 4,500, seems to be ruled by the commerce of the sea, with scores of pleasure boats and many seafood restaurants.

title: IN BRIEF; Posthumous Science Award To a Princeton Astronomer
description: Last week, Martin Schwarzschild, a Princeton University astronomer, was posthumously awarded the National Medal of Science by President Clinton. Dr. Bruce Draine, chairman of the university's astrophysical sciences department, accepted the award on his behalf.

title: Is '98 the Year of the Hellebore Makeover?
description: ALTHOUGH six more weeks will pass before the spring mailing of seed and nursery catalogues, many pundits would have us believe that the perennial of the future is already chosen: hellebore.

title: After Seeking Rate Cut, Suffolk Angers Pataki With Lilco Fight
description: Gov. George E. Pataki went out on a limb this year when he pushed for a partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company. With Suffolk officials pleading for relief from Lilco's soaring electric rates, he set aside his aversion to big government to strike a deal that he said would be a boon to Long Island, a crucial Republican stronghold.

title: Blue Sky, Noisy Bar and a Tuscan Menu
description: SIENA RISTORANTE in Stamford sports a blue sky ceiling, white stucco walls graced with Italian ceramics and etchings, a wood floor with a section near the front windows that is a mosaic of polished marble. It is all very attractive, but there is one drawback: with lots of action at the bar in the rear, the decibel level can get high. Fair warning.

title: Fashions in Glasses, Sights for Sore Eyes
description: IN ANTIQUITY, ESKIMOS PERFECTED goggles to reduce the glare from snow, and in the late Middle Ages the elite in China and Italy wore spectacles to sharpen their sight. By the 18th century, eyeglasses were being improved technically and esthetically so that most people who had to wear them were able to see better, to look better or, in the case of tinted lenses, not to be seen at all.

title: Sports of The Times; A Look Toward '98: Key Phrase for Jets Is 'What We Need'
description: IN a rambling discourse on the Jets' season finale against the Detroit Lions, Bill Parcells was talking about his pass rush, but he used one phrase that will pertain to how all areas of the Jets are assembled for next season.

title: To Add a Festive Touch, Make a Bread Pudding
description: AN easy but festive holiday dish that might even take advantage of leftovers? It is not impossible if you consider bread puddings. Whether it is sweet or savory, simply based on a custard or made with added vegetables or fruit, served warm or chilled, bread pudding is best made with stale bread.

description: He shimmied. He shook. But in the end, Prince Naseem Hamed rocked Madison Square Garden, and Kevin Kelley, in his American debut.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC; Four Scoops of Musicianship, Sprinkled With Wit
description: QUARTETTO GELATO HAS A flavor all its own. Imagine the casual attire and freewheeling energy of the Kronos Quartet married to the deadpan delivery of Jack Benny. Add repertory that encompasses tangos, opera arias, Gypsy music, traditional folk songs like ''Danny Boy'' and Mozart's Oboe Quartet. Most of all, toss out preconceived notions of the classical quartet.

title: Like Mother, Like Daughter, And Acted Out
description: EARLY IN ''THE WINTER GUEST,'' a British film that opens on Thursday, a strong-willed and slightly eccentric woman named Elspeth pronounces herself horrified by the new, short haircut worn by her daughter, Frances. Releasing gallons of pent-up anxiety and sounding a well-rehearsed theme from the past, Elspeth rounds on Frances, lamenting the loss of her daughter's long, lush hair and demanding to know why she doesn't take better care of herself.

description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he had given salary raises of 3 percent to his deputy mayors and commissioners. The move increases the salaries of deputy mayors to $142,140, from $138,000, and those of most commissioners to $136,990, from $133,000.

title: In Ireland, Gesture of Religious Healing Inflames the Faithful
description: Mary McAleese, who was elected President of Ireland in October after promising to ''build bridges'' to help end sectarian conflict between Roman Catholics and Protestants, has set off a religious furor here in the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republic and in the Protestant-dominated British province of Northern Ireland.

title: Chiodi Prevails
description: Ron Chiodi of Stratton Mountain, Vt., fought his way through fast-falling darkness on the shortest day of the year yesterday to win an Olympic qualifier halfpipe competition in Carrabassett Valley, Maine, by seven-tenths of a point. Cara-Beth Burnside of Orange, Calif., took the women's event by two-tenths of a point.

title: Holtz Could Be Emerging as the Mr. Fix-It the Colts Need
description: The Indianapolis Colts' franchise is in trouble. The team, while playing well in recent weeks, is still a disappointing 3-12. General Manager Bill Tobin and Coach Lindy Infante may lose their jobs.

title: Reviving the Concerns Of an Earlier Time
description: THE obligation to re-examine its history is essential to the mission of any serious theater, especially on a commemorative occasion. But it is of no avail for the Crossroads Theater Company to pair the observance of its 20th year -- noteworthy indeed -- with the 25th anniversary of ''Don't Bother Me, I Can't Cope,'' a real, live non-event.

title: What Ivanov Needs in the 90's Is an Anti-Depressant
description: WHAT IS THE MATTER with ''Ivanov''? Using David Hare's colloquial version of Chekhov's play, the cast at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center create recognizable characters -- Kevin Kline in the title role; Jayne Atkinson as his tubercular wife, Anna; Max Wright as their neighbor Lebedev, and Hope Davis as Lebedev's young daughter, Sasha. We know these people or their counterparts in modern life.

title: Jazz Saxophonist With a Double Life
description: AT age 70, James P. Hill leads a double life. By day he serves as executive director of Youth Theater Interactions, one of the county's most successful and long-lived youth programs. He works in a windowless office no bigger than a closet, aware of, but at a comfortable distance from, the steel drum band practicing down the hall and the class in Haitian dancing under way in the next room.

description: AS a little girl, Veronica Pettiford dreamed of becoming a doctor or a lawyer. She never dreamed she would become a Christmas decoration.

title: Cornell's Pumpkin Posits Another Mystery: Is It Real?
description: In October, the Cornell University campus was abuzz with speculation about the skill, technique and bravery of the prankster who placed an enormous pumpkin atop the school's historic 173-foot bell tower.

title: December 14-20; Shhh!!!
description: They call it the Secret Service for a reason, the chief of the protective agency has sternly reminded his troops. The chief, Lewis C. Merletti, stung by four former agents' accounts of President John F. Kennedy's philandering in a newly published book, ''The Dark Side of Camelot,'' warned all present and former Secret Service agents to be silent as the grave -- and to take their memories with them when they go there. One of the former agents, reasserting his right to free speech, shot back: ''I liked J.F.K. He was one of the nicest guys I ever met. But he was reckless, morally. And for 35 years I kept my mouth shut.'' TIM WEINER

title: Streetscapes/Pendleton Place; 3 Houses That Recall 19th-Century Staten Island

Three of the family's buildings are left in recognizable form, and in the last two decades different owners have taken each down a different path of restoration. Together, they make an interesting study of varying opinions of what is important about a house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, ROZANNE M.

Distinguished Teaching Professor with The State University of New York and retired professor of sociology and anthropology at the Cortland campus, died on Thursday, Dec. 18. Brooks founded the Sociology Department in 1964 and, as chair until 1973, added anthropology to the curriculum. She retired in 1992 after 36 years of service to the College and established an award for dedicated teaching faculty. The College will hold a Memorial Service in early Spring.

title: Two Lives in Dance, Two Interpretations
description: DO YOU UNDERSTAND A BALLET BETTER if you know what its choreographer eats for breakfast? The idea -- that details of an artist's private life illuminate the work -- is hardly new, but neither has it been uncontested. Literary critics, especially in academe, have long questioned the value of considering a writer's biography. In the 1930's and 1940's, the text alone was the thing for the New Critics. In today's post-structuralist times, the meaning of a text is itself brought into question.

title: December 14-20; A Lion's Night Out
description: The story began as an animal park's worst nightmare, but the ending was nevertheless a happy one: Nala the lioness was captured safely two days after escaping from her cage at a roadside zoo near Orlando, Fla. The 400-pound animal, named after a character in Disney's movie ''The Lion King,'' had bolted as zoo workers raised the floor of her cage to try to keep her dry from recent heavy rains. This set law officers off on a search by air and land, and they went door-to-door to warn residents to stay indoors -- and keep their pets with them. But the declawed Nala, described as ''social and laid back'' by her handlers, stuck to the swampy woods behind Jungleland Wildlife Park in Kissimmee, where she was subdued with tranquilizer darts for a groggy homecoming. title: ATTENTION, CRAZED SHOPPERS

These items and more (including very desirable ones like Versace gowns marked down 50 percent) are available at the Unclaimed Baggage Center, the final resting place for the contents of lost airline luggage. Housed in a city-block-size store in Scottsboro, Ala., the U.B.C. buys items in bulk from airlines that have waited 100 days to hear from the rightful owners of lost stuff and abandoned bags. Bryan Owens, the company's president, says that some customers camp out to be first at events like the November ski blowout, and that the goodie-ransacking energy can be shocking. But then, that's what parents say after their children open presents. ''It is a little bit like Christmas every day for us,'' Owens says.

title: When the Watchers Speak
description: The watchful Secret Service agents are often an irritant to residents of the White House. Lyndon Johnson complained about them to Rufus Youngblood, the agent who threw his body over Johnson when John Kennedy was shot in Dallas. Bill and Hillary Clinton reportedly suspected that their first Secret Service protectors were gossiping about the private life in the White House. The Secret Service wants to make Presidents as comfortable as possible with the agents' constant companionship for reasons of security and self-preservation. More than one resident of the White House has threatened to replace the Service with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. So it was not surprising that the Service hierarchy reacted negatively when several former agents told tales about President Kennedy's extracurricular sex life to the author Seymour Hersh. The Secret Service's director, Lewis Merletti, called the agents' disclosures ''troubling and counterproductive,'' and urged former agents never to discuss anything they had seen on duty.

Kahn, Alexandra Kahn (John Graubert) and Julie K. Brown, and five great grandchildren, Sophia and Isabel CarterKahn, Christina Graubert, Thomas M. Bender and Samuel A. Brown, Jr. She was first married to the late L. Stanley Kahn-a member of the New York Stock Exchange. In 1938 she married investment banker, Joseph A. Neff who died in 1969. She was very active in New York Charities-especially the Metropolitan Opera where she donated the Lobby Colonnade in memory of her mother, Mrs. Moses L. Annenberg. In addition, she funded the redecoration of the Blue Room at The White House, and, with her brother and his wife, helped fund projects at both the State Department's Diplomatic Reception Rooms and Blair House. In 1977, Mrs. Hooker gave an historic emerald to the National Gem Collection at the National Museum of Natural History. In 1991 and 1992, she gave additional gems to the collection and was the major donor for the Janet Annenberg Hooker Hall of Geology, Gems and Minerals which opened in September 1997. Mrs. Hooker, a resident of Palm Beach, Florida, also owned a summer home, Fairholme, in Newport, Rhode Island. A Funeral Mass was held. For information call Frank E. title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Endgame
description: In Paolo Maurensig's short novel THE LUNEBURG VARIATION (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19), human history is likened to chess and its habitual cruelties are seen to resemble the rigidity of the game, and even in some sense to be shaped or contained by it. The notion that life is a form of obsessive play is not new, but seldom has it been pursued with such single-mindedness as in this cerebral, fatalistic narrative, fluently translated from the Italian by Jon Rothschild, in which ruthless checkmates are chillingly identified with Hitler's ''final solution.'' The book's title refers to a variation in Black's strategy that introduces an element of creative chaos into White's illusion of order; it is invented by Tabori, a chess master who is an inmate at the concentration camp at Bergen-Belsen. The ploy receives its name not from Tabori but from his captor, who at once admires and despises it. At the beginning of the narrative -- which is really the story's end -- this former Nazi, now an important citizen of Vienna, is found dead at the center of a garden shaped to look like a chessboard. From the outset, we are given to understand that the apparent suicide is in fact an execution born of vengeance. The chess pieces alongside this construction are topiary bushes formed to look like bishops or knights. It is a fine irony that when the king dies, in this remotest of endgames, the pieces that should be defending him are helplessly rooted to the ground. William Ferguson

description: It's easy to play football when you're 6 foot 4 and 250 pounds. It's not so easy when you're 5 foot 9 and 135 pounds and you play defensive tackle. One of the great things about high-school football is that it represents the last hurrah for a unique breed of athlete: the feisty kid who manages to hang in there and play even if he lacks what coaches call ''the key attributes'' -- like size, strength and speed. We call them the Meggetts, in honor of Dave Meggett, the former New York Giant who, at 5 foot 7, has long defined bighearted scrappiness at the pro level. This year's honorees all come from New York-area schools, and as their coaches make clear, they all deserve a rousing salute. Here's a look.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Audi A6; A Wintertime Wonder Tries for a Hat Trick

A decade ago, the German auto maker -- a subsidiary of Volkswagen A.G. -- was battling consumer groups' accusations that its flagship 5000 model tended to accelerate without warning. After inquiries by government agencies in the United States, Canada and Sweden, the assertions were found to be without merit.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Scarry Story
description: Perhaps the most popular -- but least appreciated by adults -- author and illustrator of books for very young children from the 1950's through the 80's was Richard Scarry (1919-94). To grown-ups his work, like ''Richard Scarry's Best Word Book Ever'' (1963), looked clumsy and cluttered and full of chunky anthropomorphized animal figures. To children around the world the books were (and are) almost pure magic, full of important information about the stuff of everyday life. Walter Retan, Scarry's editor, and Ole Risom, his art director, have compiled an affectionate homage, THE BUSY, BUSY WORLD OF RICHARD SCARRY (Abrams, $39.95). The narrative is dull -- Scarry's was not an adventurous life -- but the captions to the copious illustrations of Huckle Cat, Lowly Worm and the gang, and the discussion of technique and intent, are filled with analytic insight. The authors point out that it was Scarry's gift to create ''situations to demonstrate word meanings rather than simply identifying objects.'' He drew stories and then added text to fit the pictures. The heroine of ''In the City'' is a tiny mouse who has bought a book at a bookstore and plans to join friends for a lemonade across town -- that is, on the opposite page. The text tells the toddler: ''Show with your finger the way she will go. Remember to have her look both ways before she crosses a street.'' Having heard the words just once, perhaps while sitting in an adult lap, how many children over how many years have sat poring over the picture, studying vehicles, stores, creatures and activities? And remembered to look both ways? Richard Scarry's legacy is glorious. Eden Ross Lipson

title: Tel Aviv
description: The predicament of Tel Aviv is that it must forever live in the shadow of Jerusalem. People talk literally of ''going up'' from the muggy seaside city to ''Heavenly Jerusalem'' perched on a cool Judean hilltop 35 miles inland. There's the difference in age of some 3,950 years, give or take a few centuries, and there's the difference in moral reputation between the unabashedly sybaritic Tel Aviv and the Holy City of three great faiths.

title: The Enigma of Murder

And I am thinking about David Berkowitz again, trying to recall that thrilling current of terror that licked through the city 20 years ago. Murder always tops the charts. It takes your breath away. But as much as we want to make some sense of something so irrevocable, it almost never teaches us anything.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLIVINGTON, KENNETH A., PHD.
description: KLIVINGTON-Kenneth A., PhD. Trustees, staff, and partners of the Fetzer Institute join family and friends in mourning the death and celebrating the life of Dr. Kenneth A. Klivington who died November 27, 1997, after a two-year struggle with cancer. Ken was 57 and is survived by his wife Marie Rose (Pat) of Kalamazoo, Michigan; son Jason Klivington of Portland, Oregon; and mother Evelyn Louise Klivington of Newbury, Ohio. Dr. Klivington was Senior Scientific Advisor of the Fetzer Institute having previously served as its Vice President-Science. His previous appointments include Assistant to the President, Scientific Planning, the Salk Institute; Vice President, Research and Development and Director of Research, Electro-Biology, Inc, Fairfield, New Jersey; Program Officer and Administrator, Sloan Research Fellowships. Other previous responsibilities include Senior Staff Officer and Consultant, National Academy of Sciences, National Research Council; consultant for corporate executive programs with The Diebold Group, Inc, New York; Director of Research and Development, Fisher/Jackson Associates, New York; and Assistant Research Neuroscientist, Department of Neurosciences, University of California, San Diego. His remains have been entrusted to the University of Michigan anatomical donation program for education and research purposes. A memorial service at the Fetzer Institute is being planned. Memorial contributions may be made to the West Michigan Cancer Center, 200 North Park Street, Kalamazoo, MI. 49007.

description: AT THE BEGINNING OF ''The Postman,'' which he stars in and directed, Kevin Costner sets the stage for the futuristic story with a quintessentially Hollywood image of the American West: a barren stretch of parched earth whose vastness dwarfs a hot, dusty stranger and his pack mule as they meander along.

title: Lipinski Shakes Off Her Doubts (and Doubters) to Win an Olympic Preview
description: Tara Lipinski of the United States and Ilya Kulik of Russia urgently needed to skate a clean long program, Lipinski to prove that she could climb back to the top, Kulik to show that he finally made the ascent from vast potential to dependable accomplishment.

title: Home-Style Italian
description: ONE problem, and really the only problem, with the Park Avenue Bistro is that the bread is no better than the bread at most neighborhood restaurants, which is maddening. So much good bread in New Jersey (Dom's, Giordano's, Fresh Fields), and so little of it finds its way into restaurants.

title: Coupons to Condiments: Goodies for Shareholders
description: WHEN the annual meeting of McCormick & Company, the maker of spices and condiments, comes to an end, shareholders depart with more than the managers' promise to work hard. They walk away with a goody bag chock full of McCormick products.

title: Storm's Hamilton Makes Double Overtime His Stage
description: Zendon Hamilton took a game into his hands last night.

title: Pumping Pencils; Rockaway Groups, in Fact, Were Glad to Get Whale
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/New Jersey; As Retailers Expand, New Shopping Centers Rise
description: WITH a healthy retail climate and a roster of national retail chains expanding in or entering New Jersey developers are scrambling to put up new shopping centers to accommodate such tenants as anchors.

title: Word & Image; A Case of Sheep v. Coyotes
description: Unless you are planning to lace the carcasses of a few sheep with poison to trap coyotes that prey on your flock, you might think you have no stake in the recent decision from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. But a case arising from concern for Montana's wildlife has prompted a First Amendment claim by television news crews. They contend that they have a right to barge into your home with the cops and to broadcast whatever happens, whether or not the police behave legally or have proved you guilty of a crime.

title: BETTER WATCH OUT
description: * Everyone knows Santa frowns on naughty behavior. Increasingly, so do legalistic adults. * Last month, a Colorado school, in a district with a drug policy that views unfamiliar sweets as controlled substances, suspended a 6-year-old boy who shared a lemon drop with a friend on the playground. * In Waukesha, Wisc., after a group of 12- and 13-year-old boys gave their classmate a ''wedgie'' -- that is, grabbed his underwear and yanked up -- they were slapped with disorderly conduct citations. * Katie Rose, 11, who held a make-believe wedding with 10-year-old Cody Finch, sued him in a New Mexico domestic-violence court in April after he allegedly punched her. * Upbeat news: According to new guidelines from the U.S. Department of Education, ''a kiss on the cheek by a first grader does not constitute sexual harassment.''

title: Ignoring African Abuses Is No Foreign Policy; Accountability a Must
description: To the Editor:

title: Anthony J. DiGiovanna, 92, Former State Supreme Court Justice
description: Anthony J. DiGiovanna, a retired Justice of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, died Tuesday at his home in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. He was 92.

title: Crackdown On Carry-Ons
description: CRUNCH time is approaching on the carry-on luggage issue. Two major airlines, Northwest and United, are sidling toward tighter restrictions on what passengers can take aboard as other airlines watch attentively. And a recent safety conference in Washington about injuries caused by objects flying out of overhead bins produced some alarming information.

title: Sealing Mount Garbage; Closing Staten Island's Fresh Kills Dump Is an Operation of Staggering Complexity
description: When Ray Maggi casts his gaze across the mounds of trash at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, he feels a certain sense of ownership that might puzzle most New Yorkers.

title: Probing Beneath The Facade
description: WHEN scores of two-pound bricks broke loose from a 34th-floor wall of a Madison Avenue office tower earlier this month, some punched holes in the roofs of adjoining buildings while others crashed and shattered, raining concrete shrapnel onto the street below. The rest remained suspended in a safety net overhead -- an eerie tableau that showed a weakness in Local Law 10.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the relationship between President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore referred incorrectly to a member of the Cabinet. William Daley is Secretary of Commerce, not Transportation.

title: P.R. Bauble of the Week
description: To prove the claim that the February/March issue of Bride's is the heaviest consumer magazine ever, 4.1 pounds, the publisher sent journalists a scale.

title: MR. SNAFOO
description: In July, after learning that the Walt Disney Company was reviving Mr. Magoo for a film, the National Federation of the Blind passed a resolution to ''take whatever action appropriate to protest'' the bumbling, nearsighted dolt. Why? ''The message is that lack of sight means incompetence,'' says Marc Maurer, the federation's president. Tensions have eased -- Maurer met with Disney officials, who vaguely pledged future sensitivity -- but the threat of a protest persists when the movie, starring Leslie Nielsen, opens Christmas Day. ''Magoo is not blind,'' insists a Disney spokesperson. ''As soon as he puts glasses on, he can see.'' Counterpoint? ''He's so blind,'' Maurer says, ''that he mistakes fire hydrants for little children and pats their heads.''

title: Some Chances to Do Last-Minute Listening
description: FOR those who have finished their last-minute shopping, this can be a time for some last-minute listening. Today at 4 P.M. the Festival of Lessons and Carols comes to Grace Episcopal Church in White Plains, and tomorrow at 8 P.M. a program of Songs of Peace and Joy takes place at the Helen Hayes Performing Arts Center in Nyack.

title: Strangers Behind a Counter
description: The store smelled like old chicken. But the poultry and hot dogs were cleared out weeks ago because business has been worse than the stink.

title: Larry McMurtry's Dream Job
description: Kudos to Larry McMurtry for making his dream a reality (''Larry McMurtry's Dream Job,'' by Mark Horowitz, Nov. 30).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHER, LILLIAN
description: FISHER-Lillian. We can't say how much we miss you, but we must tell you the wonderful news. Amy will have a Lilly this year!!! We love you, Mort, Amy, Susan and the family.

title: 'Homeowner Tax Cuts'
description: To the Editor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLOSS, BENOLA
description: SCHLOSS-Benola. Beloved wife of the late Richard. Devoted mother of Richard J. (Julia). Loving grandmother of Reina Warren and Duncan Schloss. Great-grandmother of Silva. Loved sister of Aimee Cahn, also of the late Ruth Cornell. Memorial tribute Sunday, 11 AM, Temple Shaaray Tefila, 79th Street and Second Avenue.

title: The Year of the Gimmick
description: IT HASN'T COME DOWN TO detective Andy Sipowicz breaking into song and dance on ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.'' Yet.

title: Jewelry Factories Aren't Sparkling to the Nose, Neighbors Say
description: There's a stink on West 29th Street these days, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. Literally.

title: If It's Only a Party, Does It Matter Who Pays?
description: When Governor Whitman is officially sworn in for a second term next month at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, taxpayers will cover the cost, as they have for previous governors.

title: Sorry, Wrong Conversation
description: ONE evening last month, Gale Hayman found herself at a dinner party in Manhattan, her second home after Washington. She turned to her dinner partner to discuss something that had been on her mind earlier in the day in Washington: President Clinton's conference on race.

title: Tux Time Warp
description: James Hall and Mark Greener combed through the formal wear at the Fan Club at 22 West 19th Street, laughing at the occasional 1970's powder blue dinner jacket. ''I have three black-tie events to go to, and I've had it with rentals,'' Mr. Hall said. The expense of a new tuxedo and the ordeal of renting have sent flocks of men (and some women) to vintage-clothing shops like the Fan Club. ''For under the price of one rental, you can put together an entire ensemble, and it's yours to keep,'' said Bingo Sanatra, a salesman at Star Struck, 47 Greenwich Avenue (Charles Street).

title: HEALTH CARE'S GIANT: Working Under a Cloud -- A special report.; How Scandal Put an End To the Flag-Waving
description: THE people who work at the Columbia/ HCA division office in Winter Park, Fla., watch what they say to one another. They self-consciously do not speak of the Government's huge fraud investigation of their company or anything related to it. They know that any colleague they talk to might at some point be subpoenaed and that any conversation -- even their jokes -- could end up being regurgitated before a grand jury. So goes work when the law is peeking in the window.

title: Tour Troupe Fights Prejudice Through Wonder of Theater
description: THE two high-school football players were congratulating each other on their recent victory, when a cheerleader approached and invited only one of them to a celebration party at her home that evening. When the football player in turn invited his teammate to join them, the festive mood changed suddenly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EUSTER, LOUIS
description: EUSTER-Louis. On Dec. 18, 1997 of Harrison, NY. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Shreefter. Caring father of Toni Dwyer and Sona Euster. Cherished grandfather of Ethan and Cara Sherrard. Beloved companion of Angela Goffredi. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, December 21, 1997 at 1PM at the McMahon Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, New York. Shiva will be observed at the Euster residence, 14 Bardion Lane. Harrison, New York, following the memorial service through Tuesday. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The United States Holocaust Museum, Attn Tribute Committee, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place SW, Washington DC 20024, or Habitat For Humanity of Westchester, POB 351, White Plains, New York 10603-0351. In memory of Mr. Euster, The Yellow Barn will be closed on Sunday, December 21

title: It's History in the Making, and the Jets Are Only a Step Away
description: Aaron Glenn said he had never watched other teams in the playoffs while he sat at home the last three Januarys, recuperating from more Jets losses than he wanted to recall.

title: When to Deck, and Undeck
description: When do you put up your holiday decorations? How long do you keep them up?

title: Karen Allison, 49, Restaurateur With Vision
description: Karen Hubert Allison, who with her husband, Len Allison, lived out every cook's fantasy of turning a home into a restaurant and later earned three stars for the establishment, Huberts, in Manhattan, died on Tuesday in Maui, Hawaii. She was 49 and had lived in Maui since 1995.

title: The Office Phone Vs. the Tug of Home
description: WHEN her father died, Lisa Deuel Lachot had many telephone calls to make at work.

title: Putting a Fund's Past Performance on the Back Burner
description: THE numbers in the advertisements always look great. Over the last year, you read, the XYZ fund has grown at an average annual rate of more than 35 percent. Over the last five years, it is up more than 20 percent, surpassing the Standard and Poor's 500-stock index.

title: DIARY
description: SOUTH KOREA

title: December 14-20; It Can't Go Wrong. (Wrong!)
description: Air traffic control centers have extensive equipment to assure that they are never without electricity. But a technician testing that equipment pulled out the wrong circuit board in Kansas City on Thursday, and suddenly controllers were facing blank screens and silent radios.

title: Cisneros Indictment
description: To the Editor:

title: He Got the Story, Then The Story Got Him
description: It's a slow monday morning at La Prensa, as slow as it gets at a daily newspaper with an editorial staff of eight. Jesus Barraza, the editor in chief, is sitting at his desk reviewing his story options when a reporter rushes in and whispers an urgent message.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS; Salsa Lovers Say Law Is a Killjoy
description: Salsa boomed from the jukebox at La Caridad on a recent Saturday night, but few people were there to hear it. And no one was dancing.

title: Zimbabwe Faces Showdown On Unfinished Issue of Land
description: Hermanus Vorster, whose ancestors trekked over the Vumba Mountains into this valley in 1918, fumbled through the boxes in his small office and produced the deed by which his great-grandfather bought Gwindingwi Farm in 1920. It is stamped with the ornate crest of the British South Africa Company and has a hand-drawn sketch of the hills on it, inked in faint browns and greens.

title: December 14-20; For the Pope at Christmas
description: Just in time for Christmas, Pope John Paul II got gifts from two improbable sources. B. B. King, the 72-year-old American blues artist, gave his beloved electric guitar ''Lucille'' to the pontiff at an audience for singers and musicians who were to perform in the Vatican's fifth annual Christmas concert. ''Happy Christmas and thank you very much,'' the Pope replied, giving the performer a small cross. In Havana, meanwhile, the official Cuban news organizations announced a gift of sorts from President Fidel Castro -- the granting of a public holiday on Christmas Day this year as a special, one-time-only gesture to the Pope, who is scheduled to visit in late January. The Pope had asked a year ago for Christmas to be restored in Cuba.

title: Talking to Iran; Phone's Ringing. Wonder Who's on the Line.
description: THE last time an American President tried to talk to his counterpart in Iran, this is what happened:

title: Prudential Chief Knew About Payment, Lawyer Testified
description: A lawyer for the Prudential Insurance Company of America told Florida investigators that the company's top executive approved a $1.46 million payment to a mid-level official who had threatened to go public with details of how insurance agents had long cheated customers nationwide, according to transcripts of sworn statements released late Friday by state officials.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about public attitudes toward the women's movement misstated a result of a recent CBS News poll. A plurality, not a majority, of women polled said they thought working women made worse mothers than those who stayed at home; a plurality of men said it made no difference.

title: Color, So Much the Essence of What Happens in a Painting
description: COLOR is to painting what words are to writing -- almost. Some paintings are more colorful than others, and for his show, ''Colors: Contrasts and Cultures,'' at the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport, the curator Benjamin Ortiz has rounded up some especially peacocky examples. Still, color is so much the fabric of almost any painting it is hard to separate it out for meaningful analysis.

title: David Sacks, Marcella Rosen
description: Marcella Rosen and David G. Sacks were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Lawrence A. Hoffman performed the ceremony at the couple's apartment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZFELD, SAUL
description: HERZFELD-Saul. December 19, 1997, in his 95th year. Beloved husband of the late Libby. Cherished father of Abby and Alvin Litt, Miriam and Carl Kanter, and grandfather of Sarah and Eli Litt. Dear brother of Lillian Herzfeld and Ida Cummings. Devoted companion of Freda Zucker. Services Monday, December 22 at 12 noon, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapels, 152 2nd Ave. at 10th St.

title: Too Low to Go
description: It might seem odd to think of long baggy shorts as rebel wear. But when the National Basketball Association fined the Minnesota Timberwolves and the Portland Trail Blazers $25,000 each last month after seven players wore shorts deemed too long, the cool quotient for below-the-knee hemlines rose a notch.

title: What's in a Name? A Biblical Heritage
description: EARLY settlers in Connecticut had a wealth of English names brought with them as well as the Indian ones they found upon arrival, by which to name their new villages. Then, too, there were biblical references to call upon, perhaps employed in an effort to invoke the Deity's assistance in a wild new land.

title: The Last Best Friends Money Can Buy
description: Much as the subject terrifies me, at 80, I thoroughly enjoyed Ted Conover's article ''The Last Best Friends Money Can Buy'' (Nov. 30). It was thoughtful and compassionate. Thanks for writing on an issue of vast importance to us all.

title: Mortimer's Chat: The Right Table, the Right Vacation
description: THE SETTING: Behind the brown awning at Lexington and 75th Street sits a bastion of power brokers, celebrities and ladies who lunch, all of whom have angled for tables where they can eat chicken hash and drink bottled water.

title: A Long-Stay Hotel, Upscale
description: Not so long ago on the Upper West Side, the words ''extended-stay hotel'' suggested a cheap place where people who had few other options might eke out an existence in a 10-by-10 room.

title: Consider the Consequences Before Giving a Gift
description: ADVERTISERS push it. Pet stores bank on it. Children plead . . . The temptation to give a pet as a gift around the holidays is everywhere. But there is more to that fuzz ball than soft blinking eyes and a wagging tail.

title: INSIDE
description: Progress Seen on Drugs

title: The Eagle Platinum Coin Is Selling, but Not Soaring
description: THE United States Mint began to sell its first platinum coins in late September, when the white precious metal was in its best rally since 1990.

title: A City and Its River Make a Classroom for Camden Students
description: To Gracelyn Johnson, Camden's best learning environment is its environment. Ms. Johnson, a science teacher at Camden High School, is this year's recipient of the Cartledge Award for Excellence in Environmental Education, presented in Washington earlier this month by the nonprofit Conservation Fund and by Union Camp Corporation of Wayne, the paper products manufacturer.

title: Time to Address State Pension Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants Pull Out Corks for New Year's
description: THE home-for-the-holidays theme usually ends on Dec. 31, when large numbers of friends and family head for wining, dining and dancing hot spots offering happy times.

title: Your Twinn
description: In 1993, the My Twinn Doll Company of Denver started producing the My Twinn Doll, a cuddly tyke custom-designed from a photograph of any girl aged 3 to 12. The company makes no claims about the psychological impact of a mirror-image toy, but one satisfied parent insists that the dolls are ''important adjuncts to self-esteem.'' Don't adults need that, too? Sure they do. And now they can have it, for $129.95 to $169.95, depending on wardrobe selections and other options.

title: Sports of The Times; Old-Fashioned Way Works Over and Over for Princeton
description: GO to a Princeton basketball game and you feel as if you've stepped into a time capsule. To some, it may be scary, like watching an old black-and-white horror film, with a stalking werewolf. To others, it might be a delight, like Alice tumbling into Wonderland and coming upon a trove of lost treasures -- like the backdoor play executed time and again with such precision it would make a safecracker envious; like defense as sticky as peanut butter; like maintaining roles as unselfishly as beavers building a dam.

title: Still Snipping Buttons Off All the Stuffed Shirts
description: IT IS A TRUISM THAT THE CLASSICAL-MUSIC world takes itself seriously, perhaps too seriously at times. Indeed, performers, musicologists and audiences have fostered the notion that they are dedicated to an elevated stratum of artistic endeavor. But like many truisms, this one tells only part of the story. There is also a capacity for self-effacing humor in classical circles, the best proof of which is the comedy tradition that includes everything from Anna Russell's farcical reductions of operatic plots and Victor Borge's melding of pianism and slapstick to the work of newer troupes like Le Quatuor, a Parisian string quartet that uses incongruous medleys and tight choreography to poke fun at the sobriety of the concert world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBLATT, BENJAMIN
description: GOLDBLATT-Benjamin. On December 19, 1997. Devoted and loving husband, father, grandfather and brother. Pioneering sales manager of Exquisite Form Industries for 45 years. His devotion to family and distinctive sense of humor will not be forgotten. Service Sunday, December 21, 10:30 AM, Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALTMAN, BOB
description: ALTMAN-Bob. I remember with love and affection all the good years we had together. Eddie

title: Mets Keep Everett Off Open Market
description: Carl Everett will remain with the Mets, for the time being. But Joe Oliver, the free-agent catcher the team was trying to lure, is headed elsewhere.

title: Guides Facing: (a) New Exam (b) More Rigor
description: In what may be the latest sign of the changing urban landscape, the Department of Consumer Affairs has decided to rewrite the licensing examination for prospective tour guides. The reason? The test, which is at least two decades old, is out of date.

title: New York as We Know It Turns 100
description: The City of New York -- the five-borough version, that is -- will observe its 100th birthday next year, and befitting a city of its significance, size and age, the celebrations will be big, diverse and yearlong.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: OFF-LINE RESEARCH

title: The Silence
description: ''YOU have a guest,'' Sister Susan Marie said.

title: In the Nation's Capital, A Crowd of Monuments
description: THE United States Marine Corps War Memorial more familiarly known as the Iwo Jima Memorial -- has stood since 1954 on a ridge in Arlington, Va., just over the Potomac River from here. Now a group wants to build a memorial to the Air Force only a stone's throw away. And that has sparked the latest battle in Washington's war over monuments.

title: MARKET WATCH ; If 2+2=5, It May Be Too Good To Be True
description: Here's a great way to get rich. You buy several small companies from their owners, who think they aren't worth much. Then you sell stock to public investors who think the companies together are very valuable.

title: Pam Grier Finally Escapes the 1970's
description: IN THE FUNKY, UNINHIBITED DAYS OF hot pants and disco fever, Pam Grier was burning up the box office as the statuesque, shotgun-wielding star of black action films like ''Coffy,'' ''Foxy Brown'' and ''Sheba, Baby.'' Crowned the queen of the blaxploitation genre, Ms. Grier always portrayed strong, resourceful women, no matter how skimpy her clothes or awful her dialogue, in these low-budget, urban potboilers of the early 1970's.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; Haul Seiners Have It All Wrong
description: THE article ''Baymen Offer to Modify Seining for Stripers'' [Dec. 7] presented an incomplete and, regrettably, a biased view of the haul seine issue.

title: Southwell's Modest Majesty
description: MAYBE its modest size and seclusion in unsung Midlands farmland explain why Southwell Minster is among England's least-known cathedrals. Roughly 15 miles northeast of Nottingham, this gem of Norman and Gothic architecture dominates a peaceful green in England's smallest cathedral town, population about 7,500.

title: QUICK BITE/Tenafly; Just Like Fine Wine: Chocolates to Thrill the Palate
description: The inside of this shop glistens like a jewel box, with soft light twinkling from thousands of bottles of high-end wine. But the center of attention, especially in holiday shopping season, is a huge, festive display case off to one side of the wine racks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, THELMA PAUL SIEGARTEL
description: FRANKEL-Thelma Paul Siegartel. On Wednesday, December 17th, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Morris Siegartel and Jack Frankel. Mother of Gail Werner (Ralph) of Chevy Chase, Maryland. Grandmother of Richard Greenberg (Penny) of Chicago, Illinois, Michael Greenberg (Robin) of Durham, North Carolina, Sharon Margolin (Abe) of Roslyn, Long Island, Carol Shea (Timothy) of Maynard, Massachusetts, David Waldman (Cheryl) of Pittsford, Massachusetts, Maurice Werner of Washington, D.C., and Fred, Paul and Susan Werner of Chevy Chase, Maryland. Graveside Services will be held on Sunday, December 21, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Elmont, New York at 3:30 PM. Shiva will be observed at the home of Gail Werner, Monday, December 22 thru Thursday, December 25 at 8 P.M. Memorial contributions to: Adas Israel Congregation, Washington, D.C. or the United Jewish Appeal.

title: Fairfield University Wants the Word Out
description: THERE is one particular commentary about Fairfield University that is bedeviling its administration.

title: New Editor, New Ideas, Same Name
description: It was on Dec. 5 that Elinor Ruth Tatum learned she had been made the publisher and editor-in-chief of The Amsterdam News. ''I was in shock,'' she said.

title: Flying on Wheels
description: DARK and stormy nights haven't stopped Larry Ring, a theater lighting technician, from faithfully commuting by bicycle between the Atlantic City Hilton and his apartment in the city's North Inlet section.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the first Conservative Jewish high school on Long Island misidentified three benefactors. They are Herman and Gertrude Gross (not Stein) and Susan Aberbach (not Auerbach).

title: Tyne Daly Takes On Five Roles
description: TYNE DALY, who has often been described as strong and enduring, was feeling weepy, she said; it happened to be the day her first born turned 30. ''And I'm missing more birthdays,'' she added more weepily, referring to her daughter's two children -- all in Los Angeles.

title: Commercial Property/Lodging; For Many City Hotels, Some Guests Are Permanent
description: THIS is a profitable time to be in the hotel business, with occupancy levels nationwide nearing record levels. It's an even better time to be in the hotel business in New York, where most hotels are effectively full from Monday to Friday. Average occupancy this year was a record 85.5 percent, according to a survey by Coopers & Lybrand's lodging and gaming consulting practice. And average daily room rates rose 9 percent to $175 this year, as hotel operators took advantage of booming demand.

title: The World; Searching in Vain for Rwanda's Moral High Ground
description: TWO images burn in memory after a year's worth of violence between the the Hutu and Tutsi ethnic groups in Central Africa.

title: Brewers' Pitchers, Hitters in Name Only
description: As the Milwaukee Brewers march bravely into their new world of the National League, they are armed with pitchers who have batons for bats. ''I just sent out my Christmas cards and told them I hope they're all taking batting practice,'' Phil Garner, the Brewers' manager, said.

title: Cracks Prompt Evacuation of Residents
description: Sixteen families were evacuated from a four-story apartment building in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn yesterday afternoon after residents found cracks on their walls and called the Fire Department.

title: The Sky, and the Moon, for the Most-Frequent Fliers
description: WHEN the 23 million members of United Airlines' frequent-flier program awaken on Jan. 1, they will face not only a new year but also changes in the program's rules. Members who redeem miles for certain free flights will be required to stay over a Saturday night during their travel, and upgrades will be allocated differently.

title: The Last Best Friends Money Can Buy
description: Most middle-class families with frail, elderly family members cannot afford the luxury of the kind of round-the-clock, in-home care described in your article. This is the untold story. Unable or unwilling to go against the wishes of our elderly family members, who beg not to be put in nursing homes, we are trying to balance their care with the care of our young children, the need to bring in two incomes, etc.

title: In Charge of What?
description: You're calling a company, trying to obtain information about your account, and the operator tells you to wait for your ''personal care representative.'' Or you're trying to complain about that new gizmo you just bought, and you're put on hold for ''the chairman's office.'' Companies come up with all kinds of titles, many of them confusing, for the people you need to reach. What are these labels, and what do these workers really do? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Richard Weiss Jr., Lauren Parisier
description: Lauren Ann Parisier, a daughter of Elaine and Dr. Simon C. Parisier of New York, was married last evening to Richard Carl Weiss Jr., a son of Dr. Norma Svedosh of Princeton, N.J., and Dr. Weiss of Norristown, Pa. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein performed the ceremony at the Plaza in New York.

title: Learning About Violence From Those Who Know Best
description: Maureen L. seems in control of her life and her emotions, but looks can be deceiving. After being married to a man who beat her and verbally abused her for 10 years, she married another one in 1990. Even she cannot explain exactly how she ended up in the same dangerous place twice.

title: Washington Discovers Christian Persecution
description: The sour expression on his gray and lined face suggests that His Eminence Lufti Laham, the visiting patriarchal vicar for the Orthodox Melkite Church in Jerusalem, disapproves of Nina Shea -- her message, her demeanor, even her presence on the same dais.

title: Bits of Mischief
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NARKISS, UZI
description: NARKISS-Uzi. The Jerusalem Foundation Inc. mourns the passing of General Uzi Narkiss who commanded the troops that achieved the liberation of Jerusalem and restored Jewish Sovereignty to the Holy City. A man of deep humanity, he was truly committed to Jewish and Zionist education, and a great friend of all those who seeked to make Jerusalem a city of peace. May his family and friends be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Alvin H. Einbender, Chairman Kenneth J. Bialkin, Vice Chairman Stephen Reiner, Treasurer Michael Neiditch, Pres.

title: Science Fiction
description: Forty years is a long time to wait for a sequel. ''A Canticle for Leibowitz,'' by Walter M. Miller Jr., began appearing in The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction in 1957 and was published as a book in 1960. Miller did not invent the post-nuclear holocaust novel. But his apocalyptic vision of a new Dark Ages triggered by atomic war set the standard for this daunting subgenre, which invites readers to confront their worst fears of humanity's self-destruction.

title: His methods often rankle, but they work
description: This is Bill Parcells:

title: Getting Credit for Being White
description: Margaret Talbot's ''Getting Credit for Being White'' (Nov. 30) provided a chilling overview of the current state of American higher education. The vapid, narcissistic hooey currently being offered in place of a curriculum at institutions that once were academically respectable and deservedly prestigious is appalling. Don't these academics have anything real to worry about?

title: Microsoft Warming To the Government It Ignored for Years
description: A far-off speck on a map, the nation's capital always seemed irrelevant to William H. Gates and his prodigies at Microsoft as they reaped billions of dollars and conquered the software industry from their outpost in Redmond, Wash.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: December 14-20; The New Computer Talk: Mum's the Word.
description: The nation's biggest information companies hoisted a flag in the wars over computer privacy. They said they would voluntarily and automatically remove some personal information -- a person's Social Security number, date of birth, unlisted telephone number and mother's maiden name -- from non-public sources in the data bases now sold to the public. Such information will still be available through public records and to law enforcement agencies.

title: The year closes as it began, with big marketers shuffling multimillion-dollar assignments.
description: THE year is ending as it began, with a flurry of changes by big advertisers. The most recent shifts involved advertising, interactive media and direct marketing accounts with billings of more than $325 million.

title: Bill Gates, Meet Your Adversary, the Antitrust Chief

title: Amtrak's Survival Wager
description: Thomas Downs's abrupt retirement as chairman and chief executive of Amtrak this month is a worrisome sign that the national passenger rail system is still mired in difficulties despite a $2.3 billion rescue package recently signed into law in Washington. The turmoil suggests that Amtrak may have trouble winning the big bet it made with Congress and the Administration. Amtrak has promised that by 2002 it will cover its operating costs without a cent of Federal operating subsidy or propose a plan for orderly liquidation. With Mr. Downs out as chief executive and Amtrak soon to be run by a new board and monitored by a fiscal oversight panel, both required under a new law, it is far from clear that Amtrak can win this wager.

Our natures and our lives, our fortunes and our sacred desires are about to be transformed. All it needs are faith and Internet access.

No, the naughty nanny who chops off the head of one of her charges is simply one of the numerous oddballs, dilettantes and reprobates who wander through Aleksandr Vvedensky's rarely performed 1938 play, an early absurdist work that sneers at the social conventions and institutions that keep unruly human impulses in check.

Recognizing this humane principle, New Jersey welfare officials agreed last week to change a rule that impeded adoptions by unmarried couples, including homosexual partners who do not have the choice of marrying. The rule prohibited unmarried couples from adopting a foster child jointly in a single legal proceeding. The new policy will relieve them from having to go through the onerous and expensive process twice, once for each member of the couple.

description: There is an old story, worth recalling, about a woman who was playing with her bridge teacher. She raised his one no-trump opening to two no-trump with a hand that proved to contain three high-card points. When asked why she had not passed, she reminded him of what he had said the previous week, ''One no-trump is the hardest contract to make.''

And there were the other things that happened, events, said Ray Lucas, ''that won't let any of us sleep tonight.''

Through repeated meetings with Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and useful public exhortations, Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has nudged the parties toward constructive action. They must now act on that impulse and end the public arguments that erupted over the weekend about historic claims to the West Bank.

title: Foreign Affairs; Berlin Wall, Part 2
description: Watching the recent political developments in Southeast Asia reminded me of a conversation I had last month with an American executive in Moscow. The U.S. businessman told me he had been approached by a Russian who was interested in setting up a joint venture. The American asked the Russian one question: Do you pay your taxes? No? Well, said the American, if you don't pay your taxes, we can't be partners because we're a public company; if one of our subsidiaries doesn't pay its taxes, it shows in our annual audit. So the Russian now has a choice: pay his taxes in Moscow or miss out partnering with a cutting-edge U.S. firm.

But a glittering skyline does little to brighten the faces of children who suffer hardship through the holidays.

title: Facing Up to Global Warming
description: The global warming accord was barely signed in Kyoto, Japan, earlier this month when critics pronounced its chances of Senate ratification to be nil. If that is true, then the Senate has clearly misread the American public, which in every survey has expressed an appetite for decisive action. The Senate's attitude also defines what could be President Clinton's biggest challenge in the new year -- leading the Senate where the public wants it to go.

I came back the next day -- and they said she had died at 7.''

title: Death Penalty Will Stand, Court Rules
description: A state appellate court unanimously upheld essential elements of New York's capital punishment law yesterday, rejecting arguments that its plea bargain provisions effectively coerce defendants into pleading guilty rather than risking a death sentence.

title: Colin Powell's Promotion: The Real Story
description: In his recent town meeting on race relations in Akron, Ohio, President Clinton engaged in an exchange about the Army ''affirmative action program'' that led to the promotion of Colin Powell to brigadier general. As the session wound down, the writer Abigail Thernstrom challenged the President. ''Americans believe in affirmative action,'' she charged. ''They don't believe in preferences.'' The President then walked toward Ms. Thernstrom, stood over her and asked: ''Abigail, do you favor the U.S. Army abolishing the affirmative action program that produced Colin Powell? Yes or no? Yes or no?''

title: CISCO SYSTEMS TO BUY LIGHT SPEED, A SOFTWARE MAKER
description: Cisco Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Light Speed International Inc., a closely held maker of software for communications companies, for $160 million in stock. Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., is the nation's biggest maker of computer networking equipment. Under the agreement, Cisco will swap 2.7 million to 3.3 million of its shares for all of the shares outstanding of Light Speed, which is based in Sterling, Va. Costs associated with the acquisition will lower Cisco's second-quarter profits by 11 cents, to 15 cents a share, Cisco said. In the first quarter, ended Oct. 25, Cisco earned $336.5 million, or 48 cents a share, on sales of $1.8 billion.

description: After more than a month of jury selection, nine women and three men were chosen to determine whether Theodore J. Kaczynski was the Unabomber, and if he was, whether he should be put to death.

description: On the night last August when authorities assumed custody of Carl Everett's children, the general manager of the Mets, Steve Phillips, repeatedly refused to comment on any aspect of the case. description: Stock prices rose yesterday for the first time in four days, led by Intel and other computing shares that had recently lagged behind the market.

title: Russian Oil Producer Posts 8% Drop in Net
description: Lukoil Holding, Russia's largest oil producer, said yesterday that its net income fell 8 percent in the first nine months of the year, to 2.408 trillion rubles ($419.2 million), or 3,597 rubles (62 cents) a share, compared with 2.609 trillion rubles, or 3,898 a share, in the period a year earlier. The results are unaudited and are calculated according to Russian accounting standards.

title: In Surprise Move, Mayor Rejects Nominee for Police Review Panel

title: RELIANT BUILDING PRODUCTS ADDING VINYL-WINDOW MAKER
description: Reliant Building Products Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Care-Free Window Group, a maker of vinyl windows, for $123 million. Care-Free, based in East Lansing, Mich., is owned by Linsalata Capital Partners, a Cleveland-based investment firm. The combined company will have sales exceeding $300 million and more than 3,500 employees, Reliant said. Reliant, which makes aluminum and vinyl windows, is controlled by the investor Robert Bass's Keystone Inc. Reliant, based in Dallas, said it would finance the agreement with equity from the investment group and with loans. Its windows are sold under the Alenco, Gapco and Living brands. Care-Free windows are sold under the Care-Free, Klimatite, Alpine and Ultra names.

title: EASTERN ENTERPRISES IN STOCK DEAL FOR GAS DISTRIBUTOR
description: Eastern Enterprises said yesterday that it would buy the Essex County Gas Company in a stock swap valued at $80.5 million, or $47.50 a share. Essex County, based in Amesbury, Mass., distributes natural gas to about 42,000 residential and commercial customers in northeastern Massachusetts. Eastern Enterprises, of Weston, Mass., is a natural gas distributor and barge operator. Under the agreement, Eastern Enterprise will swap 1.184 shares for each share of Essex County. Shares of Essex County surged $7 yesterday, to $46. Eastern Enterprises shares edged up $1.3125 cents, to $43.

title: Dangerous Inertia in Japan
description: Whether the financial turmoil in East Asia remains a regional problem or spreads across the world depends in no small measure on Japan. So far, Japan has barely been able to maintain its own balance. Instead of bold steps to deregulate financial institutions and disclose the extent of Japanese problems, Tokyo's bureaucrats have employed half-measures. Japan must set an example of reform, otherwise the rot in financial institutions throughout the area is not likely to be excised.

We decided that paying more than $10 per tombstone would be gross vulgarity. Money had almost always been in tight supply with the persons being honored. In their time they would have laughed themselves hoarse at news that some fool had squandered $10 worth of piney twigs on a burial plot.

title: The Neediest Cases; Nothing Left Except a Pile of Dreams

A narrow passageway through the detritus connects her bedroom to the bathroom. The bathtub is filled with garbage bags of brightly colored fabric, raw material for a dress shop that might have been.

title: Fair Treatment for Haitians
description: President Clinton's decision to shield thousands of Haitian refugees from immediate deportation gives them the protections that Congress recently granted to refugees from Central America. Congress left the Haitians out last month when it corrected overly stringent provisions in the 1996 immigration act that made it much harder for Central Americans who had fled civil wars to fight deportation even though many had lived in this country for years. Those harsh rules, which increased residency requirements from 7 to 10 years and eliminated hardship to the immigrants themselves as a basis to challenge deportation, could have pushed out hundreds of thousands of refugees.

Both works are based on the actual events of an 1839 rebellion aboard a slave ship and their consequences. Dreamworks, in turn, accused Ms. Chase-Riboud of having plagiarized an earlier book called ''Slave Rebellion.'' A Federal judge has refused Ms. Chase-Riboud's request to halt release of ''Amistad,'' but her lawsuit for copyright infringement will continue.

title: DYNATECH STOCK SURGES ON NEWS OF MANAGEMENT BUYOUT
description: Shares of the Dynatech Corporation soared nearly 28 percent yesterday after the company said a group of its executives and key employees and the New York investment firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc. would acquire it for $49 a share, or about $900 million. Shares of Dynatech, the telecommunications electronics company based in Burlington, Mass., rose $10.1875, to $46.9375. The investor group will give Dynatech shareholders $47.75 in cash for each of their shares, along with stock that will give them a 5.3 percent stake. After the deal closes, some 300 Dynatech employees will own about a 25 percent stake in the company and Clayton, Dubilier will hold about 70 percent.

Though this is a looser and less even comedy, it shows off Mr. Brooks's gift for the right-on zinger and his sweet, rueful way of enjoying his characters' stubborn tics.

title: More Orgasms, More Years of Life?

title: HOMESTAKE PLANS TO ADD AUSTRALIAN MINING COMPANY
description: The Homestake Mining Company, moving to lower its cost of producing gold, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Plutonic Resources Ltd. of Australia for $640 million in stock. The purchase would allow Homestake, based in San Francisco, to increase its 1998 production by about 25 percent, while cutting its production costs. Plutonic shareholders would receive 64.3 million shares, or about 30 percent of Homestake's shares outstanding. Plutonic operates five mines in Western Australia and has substantial potential reserves as well as land for exploration. It is expected to account for about 75 percent of Homestake's earnings next year.

title: TI GROUP AND EG&G PLAN TO SWAP EQUIPMENT BUSINESSES
description: TI Group P.L.C. and EG&G Inc. said yesterday that they would swap industrial equipment units, giving TI high-pressure seals and giving EG&G semiconductor-making equipment and $55 million in cash. Britain's TI will pay $100 million for EG&G's Sealol Industrial Seal unit, which makes seals used by pharmaceutical and petroleum companies. The unit is based in Cranston, R.I., and will be added to TI's John Crane unit, of Morton Grove, Ill. And EG&G, based in Wellesley, Mass., will pay $45 million for TI's Belfab chip equipment business, expanding its sales of metal bellows. Belfab had 240 employees and sales of $27 million last year. Sealol employs 750 people and had $88.8 million in sales last year, TI said.

title: For the Holocaust 'Second Generation,' an Artistic Quest

The piece, ''Punch Me in the Stomach,'' was performed at the New York Theater Workshop in 1992 and later made into a documentary film.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, ESTHER
description: PETERSON-Esther. Consumers Union, publisher of ''Consumer Reports'' Magazine, mourns the death of Esther Peterson, a great woman, and a great consumer leader and activist. During her entire life, Esther served the public interest: in the women's movement, the labor movement, and the consumer movement. Fighting for a good cause filled her with energy and happiness. She was a strong leader and ally: you couldn't fool her, you couldn't scare her, you couldn't stop her when she was fighting for what she believed in. As Consumers International's representative to the UN, she lobbied the UN successfully to adopt the UN Guidelines for consumer Protection. They've become the basis for many consumer protection laws around the world, especially in Third World Countries. In the process, Esther became a standard-bearer for the world consumer movement at the UN. Her death is a great loss to her country, to the consumer movement and to all her causes. James Guest, Chair, Board of Dir Rhoda Karpatkin, President Consumers Union of U.S.

In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Cabrini Hospice or NYC Gay Men's Chorus. Our Marky Mark was smart, generous, honest, caring, a wonderful traveling companion and the most loyal friend we will ever know. He was our hero; he never complained, always faced the future bravely. Sleep well, dear Moose, in a world without pain, and know that you will live within us as long as we live. We love you very much and we will miss you. Jacques, Irma, Al, Brad, Tom and Jay.

title: Smarter Than She Is? Hah!
description: Having rested extensively on his laurels, Quentin Tarantino returns to feature-film directing after ''Pulp Fiction'' with what might as well be two new crime tales, both called ''Jackie Brown.'' The better of these, halfway visible, is a quick and lean adaptation of Elmore Leonard's ''Rum Punch'' replete with pop asides, shrewd maneuvering and all the casually hip hallmarks of the Tarantino style. But you'll have to look hard to find it within the slower, talkier, more sluggish ''Jackie Brown'' that actually appears on screen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILES, FRANCES
description: MILES-Frances. 76. Formerly of Manhasset, New York, widow of Edward F. Miles Jr., died of cancer December 22, 1997. She was mother to Mary Jackson, of Raleigh, NC, Edward F. Miles of Alexandria, VA, the late Francine Hyland of Manhasset, NY, Michele Dunn of Wilton, CT, and Christine Miles of Southampton, NY. She had 13 granchildren, and seven great grandchildren. Funeral Mass at St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset, NY on January 6, 1998 at 9:45AM. Interment will follow at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Judge Allows Couple to Visit Russian Girls, Paving Way for Reunion
description: After seven months of forced separation from the two girls they adopted in Russia and were then accused of abusing on the flight home, an Arizona couple has been told that they can begin gradually spending more time alone with the children and be reunited with them at the end of March.

title: The Adirondacks and the Whitney Estate
description: There are no easy environmental deals, but the land purchase Gov. George Pataki announced on Monday was particularly complex and particularly desirable. New York State has agreed to buy nearly 15,000 acres of Adirondack wilderness from the Whitney family for $17.1 million. In addition, a further 36,000 acres have been protected from development for 10 years.

title: Health Agency Investigates a Fever in Kenya
description: The World Health Organization and local medical officials are dispatching a team of doctors to northeastern Kenya on Wednesday to investigate an outbreak of a mysterious disease with symptoms similar to those of the deadly Ebola fever.

title: Despite Prodding, Israeli Leaders Vow Firm Stand on West Bank
description: Wearing a military-style jacket, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu led members of his Cabinet on a helicopter tour of the West Bank today, apparently to dramatize their commitment to Israeli security while they wrestle with the American demand for a ''credible'' withdrawal.

title: A Despised U.S. Envoy Stands Proud
description: After nearly five years, the United States Ambassador, Peter W. Galbraith, will leave Zagreb next month, reviled by the Croatian press, which once granted him celebrity status; under a cloud in Washington for his role in the clandestine delivery of Iranian weapons to the Bosnian Muslims, and ostracized in Government circles here as President Franjo Tudjman's most dogged critic.

title: The Owner of La Caravelle Does Champage His Way
description: ORDER a glass of Champagne, without specifying a brand, at La Caravelle, one of New York's oldest and best-loved French restaurants, and you will almost certainly be served -- La Caravelle. Emulating top Paris restaurants like Lucas-Carton and Taillevent, Andre Jammet, the owner of La Caravelle, decided to offer his patrons a Champagne bottled expressly for him. The Champagne is made by La Goutte d'Or, a cooperative in Vertus, a town in the part of the Champagne region known as the Cotes des Blancs because it is where most of the chardonnay grapes that go into Champagne are grown. La Caravalle is not a blanc des blancs, or all-chardonnay blend, but chardonnay is an important factor in the wine. It adds a touch of elegance and lightness to an otherwise full-bodied wine. La Caravelle, the Champagne, sells for $58 a bottle or $12 a glass at La Caravelle, the restaurant. Which puts it below the brand-named nonvintage bruts. Veuve Clicquot sells for $89 at the restaurant, Moet & Chandon for $85, Mumm Cordon Rouge for $72 and Perrier-Jouet for $62. La Caravelle is certainly the best place to drink the Champagne of the same name. But not the only place. Morrell & Company, the wine merchant at 535 Madison Avenue (between 54th and 55th Streets), sells it for $22.50, quite reasonable for a Champagne of this quality. FRANK J. PRIAL

title: PBS Works on Morning Foreign News
description: Serious news watchers regularly lament the decreasing coverage of international affairs on television news programs. And public television station managers often ask why PBS has no regular newscast, aside from the analytically oriented ''News Hour With Jim Lehrer.''

title: GE CAPITAL TO BUY LENDER FROM SWISS BANK
description: GE Capital Services agreed yesterday to buy a consumer credit and auto lender from the Swiss Bank Corporation for an undisclosed amount, its second acquisition in Switzerland this year. Bank Prokredit, bought by Swiss Bank in 1979, has 24 branches in Switzerland. The General Electric Company's finance unit agreed to buy Bank Prokredit from Swiss Bank to expand its finance business in Switzerland. GE Capital, based in Stamford, Conn., earlier this year bought Bank Aufina Ltd., an auto leasing and lending business, from Union Bank of Switzerland. Shares of General Electric fell $2.8125, to $71.0625.

title: Mexican Gunmen Slay 45 In Southern Indian Village
description: A band of gunmen charged into a southern mountain village on Monday spraying rifle fire and swinging machetes and killed 45 Indians, including 15 children, Red Cross officials said today. Thirteen others were wounded.

title: A 2d Challenge In Divorce Case
description: Gary C. Wendt, the chairman and chief executive of GE Capital Holdings, followed the lead of his ex-wife yesterday and also filed a motion to reopen and reargue their divorce case in Connecticut Superior Court. Lorna J. Wendt had gone to court on Monday seeking to change the judge's mind on how he split an estate potentially worth as much as $130 million.

title: Teheran Journal; One Wife Is Not Enough? A Film to Provoke Iran
description: She is the talk of Teheran, an infertile woman who persuades her husband to take a second wife in order to bear a child -- a practice permissible in Islam but increasingly seen here as a wrong.

title: TV Notes; Comedy Tonight
description: If network television is in so much trouble, why do so many stars still want regular shows?

description: When Jules and Rose Setnor look back on their more than 60 years together, what especially warms their hearts is the memory of their alma mater, Syracuse University.

title: Experts Say Jurors Saw Reckless but Lesser Partner in Crime
description: In finding Terry L. Nichols guilty of conspiracy and involuntary manslaughter but not first- or second-degree murder, jurors essentially decided that he was a lesser, if reckless, partner with Timothy J. McVeigh in the chain of events that led to the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City in 1995, legal experts said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXBERG, STANLEY
description: WAXBERG-Stanley. Died on December 21st, 1997 in Florida. Beloved husband of Ella Nicole Waxberg.

description: FOR Antonin Careme, the great 19th-century chef, pastry was a branch of architecture, and one of the crowning glories of civilization.

title: Devils Give a Goal Away And Must Settle for a Tie
description: With robotic execution tonight, the Devils took a conservative approach and a one-goal lead into the third period against the Capitals. It left them with no margin for error.

title: RECKITT & COLMAN TO BUY 4 AMERICAN CLEANING BRANDS
description: Reckitt & Colman P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy four American household cleaning brands from S. C. Johnson & Son Inc. for about $:96 million, or $159.7 million. The brands -- Spray 'n' Wash, Glass Plus, Vivid and Yes -- have estimated sales in 1997 of $:78 million , and are expected to produce a profit of $:10 million, the company said. Reckitt & Colman, based in London, makes consumer goods including cleansers, toiletries and over-the-counter pharmaceuticals. S. C. Johnson & Son, a privately held company based in Racine, Wis., makes consumer products.

title: Lights of Celebration . . . and Words of Faith; Pastors Prepare the Hardest Sermon
description: On the night before Christmas, churches tend to be packed with people who can claim at least a passing familiarity with the story of Jesus' birth: the guiding star, the Wise Men, the baby in the manger.

description: SULLIVAN-Eileen. Loving wife of Michael.
