Interment Resurrection Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: WITH KOREA CRISIS WORSE, U.S. SEEKS WAY TO LIMIT HARM
description: Faced with devastating evidence that a two-month-long attempt to restore stability to South Korea's economy is failing, the Clinton Administration is scrambling for other options to contain the country's financial damage.

title: Edwin Neilan, U.S. Chamber's Ex-Head, 92
description: Edwin P. Neilan, a tough-talking former head of the United States Chamber of Commerce who campaigned against what he considered excessive Government spending, died on Saturday in his hometown of Corpus Christi, Tex. He was 92.

title: Hong Kong Builder Sees Shares Crumble
description: Shares of Hopewell Holdings Ltd., a builder based in Hong Kong, fell yesterday to a record low on concern over the fate of the company's projects amid Asia's financial problems. Hopewell shares fell 1 cent (Hong Kong), to $1.80 (Hong Kong). They have lost two-thirds of their value this year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RUE McCLANAHAN, the film, stage and television star known for her roles in ''Maude'' and ''Golden Girls,'' will celebrate Christmas by getting married tomorrow afternoon to MORROW WILSON, an actor and television producer.

title: PGA Allows Golfer To Use Cart, for Now
description: Casey Martin will be allowed to use a golf cart during the first two Nike Tour events of the year, the PGA Tour said.

title: Another Brokerage Firm In Bankruptcy in Japan
description: The Maruso Securities Company, a midsize Japanese brokerage firm, filed for voluntary bankruptcy yesterday after it was unable to obtain new loans amid a worsening scarcity of credit. The privately held brokerage firm based in Tokyo has debt of 44.5 billion yen ($342 million), the company said at a news conference. It was the fifth Japanese brokerage firm to collapse this year.

title: 'Carlos' the Terrorist Is Convicted In France of Decades-Old Murders
description: The international terrorist who calls himself Carlos was convicted and sentenced to life in prison this morning for the murder of two French police agents and a Lebanese informant in a shooting in a Latin Quarter apartment here 22 years ago.

title: White Truffle Fever Makes the Season Glow
description: THE aroma is penetrating, distinctive, seductive. At La Grotta, a restaurant outside this Tuscan hill town, a waiter has begun shaving slivers of fresh white truffle over a humble plate of fried eggs. Instantly, heads go up around the dining room, and diners signal the staff -- yes, they'd like tartufi bianchi, too, please, on plain risotto, on buttery strands of egg pasta or simply shaved in abundance over crusts of toasted bread.

description: BASEBALL

description: Treasury prices ended slightly higher yesterday, lifted in part by a late tumble in the stock market.

The account had been divided between Ogilvy One Worldwide, New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group, and Targetbase Marketing, Irving, Tex., part of M/A/R/C Group.

title: CHRONICLE
description: THOR HEYERDAHL's latest expedition will take him not on an ocean voyage, but to Maine.

title: Three Killings Leave Anxiety In a Building
description: The five-story walk-up at 2769 University Avenue in the Bronx does not look like a bad building: the halls are kept clean, the front door locks, and many apartment doors are festooned with Christmas decorations.

title: To Queens From Uzbekistan: A Hanukkah Tradition
description: IN parts of Queens, the flavor of Hanukkah has nothing to do with traditional breads like hallah or pastries like rugelach. Instead, it has a Moslem touch to it -- a reflection of the life in the former Soviet Republic of Uzbekistan, where Moslem and Jew have shared the same cuisine for eons.

title: Oxford Health Receives Fine Of $3 Million
description: After completing another phase of its extensive review of Oxford Health Plans, one of the New York region's largest managed-care companies, the New York State Insurance Department released a harsh critique of Oxford's management yesterday and fined the company $3 million for violating state insurance regulations. The department also ordered the company to refund roughly $500,000 to some customers.

title: Neither Snow, Nor Rain, Nor Descent to Anarchy . . .
description: Every truly awful movie epic has a point of no return, a moment when the accumulated bad lines and bogus sentimentality become so cloying that the best defense against a mounting queasiness is an awed amusement. If you have a low tolerance for mawkish jingoism, Kevin Costner's post-apocalyptic Western, ''The Postman,'' offers a new opportunity for levity every few minutes after its first hour.

title: PC Docs Acquisition
description: PC Docs Group International said today that it planned to buy Fulcrum Technologies Inc. for about $30 million (Canadian) or $20.9 million (United States) in stock. The Toronto-based PC Docs said it would issue about four million shares in the transaction. Both are software companies. The deal has been approved by Datamat Ingegneria S.p.A., which owns 62 percent of Fulcrum.

title: Department of Correction Gets New Commissioner
description: Bernard B. Kerik, the First Deputy Correction Commissioner and a former police officer, was named Commissioner of the City Department of Correction yesterday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTNOY, FRIEDA
description: PORTNOY-Frieda. On December 22, 1997. Cherished grandmother of Thomas, Debra, Eric and David and dear great-grandmother of David and Alex. Graveside service Wednesday, 1 P.M., at Mt. Judah Cemetery, Ridgewood, New York.

title: Influenza Virus Is Found In Live Chickens for Sale
description: At least 14 live-animal markets in New York City have been quarantined -- or temporarily closed -- since mid-November after state inspectors discovered chickens for sale that were infected with a strain of influenza found only in poultry.

description: A Commercial Eggnog With Help From Seaweed

title: CHRONICLE
description: The rapper COOLIO, who normally sings songs like his Grammy Award-winning ''Gangsta's Paradise,'' changed his tune yesterday, singing traditional Christmas carols as he made the rounds in Los Angeles, his hometown, bearing gifts for needy families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, BLANCHE ANGELUS
description: WARREN-Blanche Angelus, 89 on December 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Bob and Ted. Cherished grandmother of Ted Jr., Jim, Peter and Chris. title: Nemesis Returns To Haunt The Giants
description: Returning to Giants Stadium this weekend brings back memories for Randall Cunningham. The memories date him like a ghostly image. But if his image is that of seasons past, the Giants are well aware that the 34-year-old quarterback is still dangerous in the present.

title: The Enemy Within
description: Coming seven months before a long-promised return to democratic rule, the announcement of an aborted coup on Sunday by associates of Gen. Sani Abacha, the Nigerian leader, has underscored the instability of Africa's most populous country and added to already widespread doubts about the country's shaky transition program.

title: Bay Apartment Deal
description: Bay Apartment Communities Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire a 663-apartment community in Woodland Hills, Calif., for $64.2 million. Bay Apartment, based in San Jose, is a real estate investment trust. Including its acquisition of the property, Viewpointe Apartments, it owns 51 apartment-home communities with 14,066 units. The company plans to spend an additional $8.4 million to refurbish the property, in the western San Fernando Valley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEREN, RENE DORIS
description: KEREN-Rene Doris. December 23, 1997. Wife of the late Ronald. Loving mother of Jeff. Unique mother-in-law of Maureen. Lover of books and antiques. Service on Friday 9:30AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: NICHOLS CONVICTED OF PLOT AND MANSLAUGHTER COUNTS BUT NOT OF ACTUAL BOMBING
description: Terry L. Nichols was convicted today of conspiring to bomb the Oklahoma City Federal Building, but in a nuanced verdict, a Federal District Court jury acquitted him of actually committing what was the worst terrorist act on United States soil.

title: Among Families of Victims, Anger and Acceptance Mix
description: The people hurt the deepest in the bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building here said they could not live with an acquittal, or even a hung jury, in the murder trial of Terry L. Nichols. To re-live the bombing over and over in a courtroom was agony, but to see him walk free, some said, would have been like being blown up all over again in this city, where people hang stockings on mantles beneath pictures of dead children.

title: PLAYTEX TO BUY CHILDS UNIT FOR $182 MILLION
description: Playtex Products Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Personal Care Group Inc., the maker of Binaca breath spray and Diaparene baby-care products, from J. W. Childs Equity Partners L.P. for $182 million in cash and stock. Besides Binaca and Diaparene, Personal Care, based in Montvale, N.J., makes Wet Ones, Chubs, Ogilvie and Mr. Bubble products. J. W. Childs is a unit of the investment management firm J. W. Childs Associates L.P. The purchase price consists of $91 million in cash and 9.3 million shares of Playtex common stock. Playtex is based in Westport, Conn. Shares of Playtex rose 31.25 cents, to $9.875.

title: TV Notes; Evening News Gains Viewers
description: While broadcast television continues to lose viewers steadily each season as more people tune in cable shows, one segment of the broadcast business is bucking that trend by holding its own.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Nonprofit Agencies Help Fill a Tower
description: What to do with the office building at 633 Third Avenue, which was 70 percent vacant, was the problem that the Travelers Insurance Company faced in 1994 when it took it back in foreclosure. Sell it as is? Invest more money, rent it, and sell the building when its value was enhanced?

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Daimler Aerospace Sells Armored Car Division
description: Daimler-Benz Aerospace, the defense and aerospace arm of Daimler-Benz A.G., said yesterday that it had sold its armored vehicle division to an unidentified investors group. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The division, to be renamed MBB Security Cars G.m.b.H., will produce armored cars and other protected vehicles for Daimler as well as for other auto makers. The company said the decision to spin off and sell the division was part of its strategy to concentrate on its main aerospace operations.

title: U.S. Argument In S.& L. Case Draws Rebuke
description: A Federal judge has angrily rejected what may have been the Government's final effort to avoid paying huge penalties to the savings and loan industry because of a sudden change in accounting rules in 1989 that left dozens of financial institutions struggling.

title: Corinne Chubb, 85, Philanthropist to Newark
description: Corinne Roosevelt Alsop Chubb, who helped guide the Victoria Foundation, a family trust that fosters social services, education and the arts in Newark, since its inception in 1934, died on Dec. 9 at her farm in Chester, N.J. She was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MENDELSON, MYER, DR.
description: MENDELSON-Myer, Dr. First Yahrzeit. We shall light a candle; never curse the dark. A Friend

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Bush Theater in London misstated the given name of the British Prime Minister who was mocked in one of its productions. He was Harold Wilson, not Howard.

title: Carnival for the Senses In a Huge Warehouse
description: Taking in the sights and sounds of ''The Field of Mars,'' a visual feast that turns a 40,000-square-foot warehouse on the Brooklyn waterfront into a fun house for the senses, is a little like chasing a 2-year-old around an apartment: you're at the mercy of a devilish intelligence that may, at any particular moment, try your patience, tire you out or tickle you no end.

title: High-Fat Diet for Men Is Linked to Fewer Strokes
description: A long-term study has found that men who eat more fat, including more saturated fat, are less likely than men on lower-fat diets to suffer a stroke.

title: $25 and Under; From a Brick Oven, a Turkish Answer to Pizza
description: IF ever a man could be said to have built his business with his bare hands, it would be Riza Atas. In the 12 years since he came to the United States from Turkey, Mr. Atas has done a lot of construction work, but his last job was his most important: designing and building Cafe Istanbul, his own little restaurant, which opened in Brooklyn about two months ago on Emmons Avenue across the street from the Sheepshead Bay inlet.

title: Penn State Bars Enis From the Citrus Bowl
description: Curtis Enis, Penn State's all-America running back, admitted yesterday that he had accepted a $400 suit from a sports agent. That was a violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, and the university declared him ineligible for the Jan. 1 Citrus Bowl against Florida in Orlando, Fla.

title: Class Notes
description: If there was ever consensus among the sixth graders at Public School 157 in the South Bronx, it was this: Songs like ''Respect'' and ''Get Ready'' and ''Soul Man,'' with the distinctive Motown sound, were decidedly uncool.

title: Talk of Japan Intervention Depresses Dollar
description: The dollar declined against the yen yesterday on speculation that the Japanese central bank would sell dollars to strengthen the yen in coming days, taking advantage of thin holiday trading. The dollar also eased against European currencies.

title: Metro Business Briefs; Unemployment Rate Drops in New York
description: New York City's unemployment rate fell in November below 9 percent for the first time in more than a year, to 8.7 percent, caused by a surge in seasonal hiring and a decrease in the number of people searching for jobs, the New York State Department of Labor said yesterday.

title: State Allows Reopening Of 2 Emergency Rooms
description: Emergency rooms at two hospitals in southern New Jersey were reopened yesterday after state officials said they were satisfied that steps had been taken to correct a variety of problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HAROLD
description: COHEN-Harold, on December 23, 1997, of Somerset, NJ (formerly Lynbrook, NY). Loving husband of Betty, beloved father of Irene and Sandra, loving grandfather of Eric, Emily, Beth and Joshua Paul. Graveside services on Dec. 24th, 11:30AM, Old Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY.

title: The Dalai Lama, Toddler To Grown Man in Exile
description: To call ''Kundun'' the most visually stunning religious storybook ever filmed is not to say it's a great movie. A glittering historical pageant infused with gorgeous, pulsing music by Philip Glass, this account of the early life of the 14th Dalai Lama unfolds like a sustained hallucination in the mind of its central character. But since the movie follows him only to 1959, when the occupying Chinese crushed a Tibetan revolt, forcing the region's political and spiritual leader to flee to India, it feels like the first chapter of a much larger, more complex historical drama.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Fractured Family Is United Again
description: Attigwa Aikens knows a thing or two about Christmas. She has seen the television commercials that show joyous family gatherings. She has heard plenty about the holiday rituals -- the exchanging of gifts, the singing of carols and the abundance of good cheer.

title: Corrections
description: A film review of ''The Winter Guest'' yesterday referred incorrectly to the author and co-adapter of the play on which the film is based. Sharman Macdonald is a woman, not a man.

title: Eating Well; Can Pizza Prevent Cancer and Ketchup Cut Heart Risk?
description: IT has to be cause for celebration when scientists discover that a food people love is also good for them. Unlike broccoli, whose detractors include a former President of the United States, tomatoes are beloved by just about everyone. And recent research indicates that a nutrient found in tomatoes, especially cooked tomatoes, is a strong antioxidant and may reduce the risk of heart disease and certain cancers.

title: TV Notes; Up and at 'em for CBS
description: While the unexpected comeback of Dan Rather on the ''CBS Evening News'' has become one of the most discussed topics in the television industry, a similar surprise has occurred in the morning competition. The long moribund and all-but-written-off ''This Morning'' on CBS is displaying signs of renewed life.

title: Day-Care Subsidy Only Benefits Employed; Government Must Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Fernandez Is Out Of Australian Open
description: Mary Joe Fernandez withdrew from next month's Australian Open and a warm-up tournament because of a recurring wrist injury, the WTA Tour said.

title: Chinese Democracy Campaigners Push for Free Labor Unions
description: A loose-knit group of veteran democracy advocates has started a campaign to promote independent labor unions among China's workers, who face vast layoffs as the Government strives to close money-losing enterprises.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Ghosts of Past, Present and Future
description: The specters floating around this holiday season are not all tied to revivals of ''A Christmas Carol.'' Meet the new ghosts of popular music, past, present and future, all likely to haunt the charts for a while.

title: Teams Are on the Go At Tournament Time
description: Travel broadens, and holiday tournaments match teams that would otherwise never play each other. Three of the four top teams in the polls will be in action on Saturday and Sunday; the exception is Boston University, which is on leave until a Dec. 30 home date with Princeton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKLAR, HERMAN
description: SKLAR-Herman. Beloved husband of Irma. Devoted father of Alan and Sandy and Eric and Sherry. Dear brother of Ruth Zimmerman, Sidney Sklar and Harvey Sklar. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Hospice Care Network or American Cancer Society.

description: To the Editor:

title: Isringhausen Weighs Elbow Surgery
description: Jason Isringhausen, who was limited to six appearances for the Mets last season because of injury, is facing the prospect of missing the 1998 season. The right-hander will spend the holidays considering whether to have reconstructive surgery on his right elbow to relieve the intermittent pain being caused by a damaged ligament.

title: 'Messiah' Mavens Find That Its Ambiguities Reward All Comers
description: It may seem entirely natural to us that Handel's ''Messiah'' is heard everywhere at this time of year, whether complete or represented by its emblematic ''Hallelujah'' chorus. title: OCEAN ENERGY AND UNITED MERIDIAN TO MERGE
description: Ocean Energy Inc. and the United Meridian Corporation agreed yesterday to merge, creating the ninth-largest American company exclusively exploring for oil and gas and giving them the resources to pursue deep-water projects in the Gulf of Mexico and off the coast of West Africa, The agreement, structured as a merger of equals, would result in a company with a stock market value of about $2.3 billion and annual revenue of $560 million. Shares of Ocean Energy rose $1.75, to $51.75, while United Meridian fell $2.625, to $29.625. The merged company will be called Ocean Energy Inc. and will be based in Houston, where United Meridian has its headquarters, the companies said. Ocean is now based in Baton Rouge, La.

title: Beatings and Worry In a Life of Music
description: On a recent gray morning in a gray airport far from home, Ali Akbar Khan, the giant of Indian classical music, sat slumped in a chair, his anxious eyes fixed on the little plane idling on the snowy runway outside. He was worried, he said, about the welfare of his sarod, the fretless lute of which he is regarded as the undisputed master and which had not yet been loaded onto the plane. The sarod, carved out of a 250-year-old tree from his family's ancestral home, had been battered before on his frequent trips. Once, it even ended up at the wrong airport.

title: The Chef
description: THE most popular dessert I've ever created started out as a mistake. About 10 years ago, I regularly served a small rich chocolate cupcake as part of a petits fours platter. It was a ridiculously simple recipe, but easy to overcook. One day, I overcompensated and removed the cakes from the oven far too early. I would have realized that in a second, but got distracted before I had a chance to check them. By the time I turned around, someone else had cut into one, and the hot, undercooked interior had spilled out onto the plate. After I was done screaming, I realized that the effect was beautiful.

title: INNKEEPERS TO ACQUIRE 6 RESIDENCE INNS
description: Innkeepers USA Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire six Residence Inns in the Pacific Northwest in separate transactions for nearly $94 million. Innkeepers, based in Palm Beach, Fla., is a hotel real estate investment trust. Residence Inns are extended-stay, limited-service hotels run by Marriott International, which is based in Bethesda, Md. Four of the properties are in the Seattle area. The other two are in Portland, Ore. Shares of Innkeepers rose 25 cents, to $14.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BELLSOUTH TO REORGANIZE MANAGEMENT STRUCTURE
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it was reorganizing its management structure to create separate focuses on the telephone and wireless businesses. It plans to create a Communications Group to oversee the company's traditional telephone operations and new services, which include long distance and video. Jere Drummond, now president of the BellSouth Telecommunications telephone unit, will be president and chief executive of the Communications Group, which will also include data services and networks. Shares of BellSouth rose $1, to $56.3125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORBETT, PAUL D.
description: CORBETT-Paul D. (former President of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Publishers, New York, and Chairman of Academic Press now Harcourt Brace Canada). At Toronto Ontario, Canada on Monday December 22, 1997 at Scarborough Grace Hospital after an extended illness. The son of Edward and Anna Rae Dickson Corbett of Edmonton and Toronto, Mr. Corbett attended the University of Alberta and was graduated from Trinity College of the University of Toronto. He served as Captain in the Canadian Armored Corps during 1944-45. A man of books-both as reader and publisher-Mr. Corbett began his career with W.J. Gage; he then moved on to the University of Chicago Press and subsequently to Harcourt Brace, New York, where he was head of the College Department and Director and President of the Company. Mr. Corbett is survived by his wife of fifteen years, Alice Gallagher Corbett of New York. His first wife Eileen Pepall Corbett died in 1974. He will also be loved and remembered by his sons Bruce Pepall Corbett of Richmond Hill and Jonathan Harry Corbett of Uxbridge; his daughters-in-law, Rinske and Denny; his grandchildren-Tirza, Risa, Nicholas and PJ; and his sister Joan Fairfield of Thornbury. Service and committal will be held in the chapel of the Morley Beford Funeral Home, 159 Eglinton Ave., W. (at Lascelles Blvd) Toronto Ontario Saturday, December 27, at 1 P.M. If anyone wishes to make a donation in Mr. Corbett's memory, the family requests that it be sent to Scarborough Grace Hospital, 3030 Birchmount Avenue, Scarborough, Ontario M1W 3W3.

By two billion or so decimal places -- a world record at the time -- they had found no discernible pattern, so they turned their attention to other problems in number theory, mathematical physics and computers.

title: The Award May Be Erratic But His Goals Are Clear
description: The British composer Simon Bainbridge is, at 45, the youngest recipient so far of the Grawemeyer Award for Music, the most valuable composition prize in the world, worth $150,000. In the dozen years of its existence, the Grawemeyer has gone to some of the most prominent composers around (Witold Lutoslawski, Gyorgy Ligeti, Harrison Birtwistle, Toru Takemitsu), though some of the winners have been more surprising choices, and one could equally make a list of distinguished composers the prize has failed to recognize.

title: Walgreen Profits to Be Cut
description: The Walgreen Company said today that costs associated with complying with new accounting rules would lower fiscal first-quarter profits by $43 million, or 5 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation had predicted profits of 18 cents a share for the quarter, compared with 15 cents a share in the period a year earlier. The results a year earlier reflect a 2-for-1 stock split that doubled the number of shares. The drugstore chain is based in Deerfield.

title: Suspected Gang Member Sought in Fatal Stabbing
description: Law enforcement officials said yesterday that they had issued an arrest warrant for a member of a Yonkers gang suspected of murdering a college student in a street fight nearly four years ago. Another gang member, who has already been charged in the case, has pleaded guilty to Federal racketeering charges, the officials said.

title: APPLE SOUTH TO SELL 264 RESTAURANTS
description: Apple South Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its 264 Applebee's restaurants and concentrate on expanding its other restaurant chains. The restaurant operator based in Madison, Ga., said it had agreements to sell 92 restaurants for $208.4 million and plans to sell the rest during the next 12 to 18 months. Applebee's International Inc. is buying 32 restaurants for $93.4 million. Apple South, which is the largest Applebee's franchisee, has been buying other restaurant chains in the last two years to decrease its reliance on one restaurant concept. Apple South expects its fourth-quarter earnings to be lower than expected because of the selling of its Applebee's restaurants. Shares of Apple South fell $3.1875, to $13.4375 yesterday.

title: International Dissonance Aside, Harmony in Cuba
description: It has been two years since the last Havana Jazz Festival, and in those two years what was the best-kept secret in jazz has become its worst-kept secret. The five-day festival, which ran through today, spread over the city's clubs and dance halls, was loaded with fans from the United States, some here legally but many defying the embargo to come and soak up the music. By the end of the weekend, people were calling the central command post of the festival, Hotel Rivera, by the name New York.

title: Stocks Flat in Japan
description: Stocks were trading in a narrow range here this morning. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 8.99 points, or six-hundredths of 1 percent, at 14,790.41. Japanese financial markets were closed on Tuesday in observance of Emperor Akihito's birthday. On Monday, the Nikkei fell 515.49 points, or 3.37 percent.

title: Political Prisoner to President
description: In the days since his election, Kim Dae Jung has shown that he intends to govern South Korea in the same courageous spirit that marked his long, often painful effort to fight repression and one-party rule in his homeland. One of his first decisions was to endorse the pardon of two former Korean military rulers, including one who tried to have him killed. That gesture of reconciliation set the tone for the President-elect.

description: President Clinton's message to the Bosnian people this week was simple: we brought you peace, and now it is up to you to do something with it. Take your destiny in your own hands! A beautiful message, indeed, but so American -- and, therefore, not of much use in Bosnia.

title: The Nichols Verdict
description: The jury in the Oklahoma City bombing trial reached a surprising, sometimes inconsistent but defensible verdict yesterday when it found Terry Nichols guilty of conspiring to use a bomb against the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building but not guilty of actually using the weapon or destroying the building. That underlying judgment also makes plausible though not entirely convincing the jury's decision to find Mr. Nichols guilty only of involuntary manslaughter, not of first- or second-degree murder, in the deaths of eight Federal agents killed in the blast.

title: There's Been No Rush for Medical Savings Accounts, but Idea Is Gaining Favor
description: Republicans believe medical savings accounts are a sensible way to cut health insurance costs for the Government and private employers, to provide more affordable coverage for those who are uninsured and to help consumers save money.

title: Spielberg Is Yet Another 'History Painter'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sparks's Workout Gives Giants Glimmer of Hope
description: The Giants' hopes of getting Phillippi Sparks back for Saturday's National Football Conference opening-round playoff game against the Minnesota Vikings received a boost with his performance on the practice field today.

title: Street Musician's Fee Is Ruled Excessive
description: Calling music a form of expression protected by the First Amendment, a Federal district judge in Manhattan has ruled that the New York City Police Department violated the free-speech rights of a street musician by charging excessive permit fees.

title: London Pubs Sip The Tonic Of Youth
description: WITH platform shoes, warm-up pants, a head wrap and a tie-dyed T-shirt knotted at the waist, the goateed and mustachioed waiter at the Engineer, one of London's new-wave pubs, was making a fashion statement aimed directly at his customers.

title: Trial of Ecuadorean Breached Consular Treaty, Judge Rules
description: Hudson County prosecutors violated an international treaty when they arrested, tried, and ultimately obtained a murder conviction against an immigrant from Ecuador without advising Ecuadorean diplomats in the United States, a Superior Court judge ruled today.

title: Critics Say United Way Plan Can't Meet Goals for Children
description: Since United Way of New York City announced an ambitious campaign last month to raise $50 million to help 250,000 disadvantaged children, an unusual amount of contention has developed about whether the charity can achieve its goals.

title: Papal Visit to Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: 25 Arrested in Gambling Sweep
description: It was about as businesslike as an illegal sports betting ring could get, investigators say: Gamblers calling one of five wire rooms in New York City even had their conversations recorded for quality control -- and to avoid any nasty disputes over the terms of a wager.

title: More on the Verdict
description: * Experts say jurors felt recklessness didn't mean intent. Page A12.

title: J. Masucci, 62, International Salsa Promoter
description: Jerry Masucci, the owner of Fania Records and a seminal figure in the founding of New York salsa and its spread to other countries, died on Sunday in Buenos Aires, his main residence. He was 62.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCGUIRE, MURIEL MARGARET
description: MCGUIRE-Muriel Margaret. Dearest Mom, Merry Christmas 1997! As I lovingly recall all our past years, my heart aches and I weep for joy. Love, Sissy.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Economic Data Suggest a Slowing Trend
description: More evidence of slackening economic growth emerged today even as the Government reported that orders for relatively costly factory goods posted the biggest gain in almost five years in November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMIDT, WALTER
description: SCHMIDT-Walter. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Walter Schmidt, associated with The Times from December 31, 1951, until retiring November 1, 1975.

title: Revenge of a Vixen
description: With a $5 million judgment awarded by a jury in Los Angeles, the actress Hunter Tylo is proclaiming her victory over the producers of ''Melrose Place'' as a landmark in the history of women's rights. Ms. Tylo, whose lawyer has a habit of comparing her to Rosa Parks and Susan B. Anthony, got pregnant and was dropped from the cast of one of television's steamiest soap operas in 1996 even before she could begin playing the role for which she was hired, that of a slinky vixen bent on seducing the screen husband of Heather Locklear, the show's star. The jury found that Ms. Tylo was plenty sexy, pregnant or not, and should not have been dismissed.

title: After Years of Pain, Janis Rebuilds Career
description: After decades spent battling the severe arthritis and accompanying depression that crippled his once-glorious career, the pianist Byron Janis is flush with optimism.

title: Essay; Holiday Message
description: The good news is that the Food and Drug Administration has approved a pill that may cure baldness in men. The bad news is that baldies who start popping it run the risk of impotence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AIN, INA
description: AIN-Ina. Our deepest condolences to our dear friend, Stuart, and the entire family. Her tragic death leaves a void in all our lives. Honie and Jerry Berko

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JOHN L.
description: MILLER-John L. We are saddened by the loss of a founding member of the North Shore University Hospital family. Years before North Shore became a reality, this civic leader sprearheaded a drive to build a community hospital. As superintendent of the Great Neck School System, he understood the need for a fine, local medical facility and worked for decades to insure its completion and success. He contributed a host of skills, helping to shape the medical facility that has become the premier health-care system in the region. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his family members. Saul Katz and Roy J. Zuckerberg, Co-chairmen, Board of Trustees John S. T. Gallagher and David R. Dantzker, M.D., Co-President and CEO North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: By the Book; His Primer for Dummies? Well, Maybe Smart Ones
description: I AM not sure which planet Charlie Trotter comes from, but I imagine it to be a place where the food is divine and there are people toiling endlessly, earnestly and perhaps happily in the kitchen. But this is Earth, and most people do not have that kind of time.

title: Calendar
description: Gingerbread Architecture

title: Health Care Insurance Broadened for Children
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed into law yesterday a measure that will provide free or subsidized health insurance starting next year to more than 100,000 children who have no coverage.

title: A Future Leader's Moment Of Truth
description: The election of Kim Dae Jung as President of South Korea is as astonishing, in its own way, as that of Nelson Mandela in South Africa. Each was labeled a dangerous subversive by his country's ruling establishment; each was jailed for years and faced death for his beliefs, and each survived to become his nation's leader.

title: Skyscraper Museum Finds Itself Homeless
description: A VICTIM of the lower Manhattan real estate boom it helped to stimulate, New York's wonderful Skyscraper Museum is being forced to vacate its space on the ground floor of 44 Wall Street. Friends and supporters will gather on Tuesday evening from 7 to 9 P.M. to honor the museum and to salute Carol Willis, the brilliant and energetic woman who created the Skyscraper Museum in 1996 from nothing but her imagination, her passion for New York architecture, and her belief in the importance of history and the value of the public realm. (Bring your own wine and cheese: the low-budget, high-content museum survives on small grants and Ms. Willis takes no salary.)

title: First Civilian Spy Satellite Soars Into Space, Launched in Russia by a U.S. Company
description: The world's first civilian spy satellite was fired into space yesterday, introducing an era when anyone with a credit card can peer down on the globe to view secret military bases or the backyards of neighbors with high fences.

title: Of Family, and an Improbable Road to Parenthood
description: In David Ogrin's household, babies and birdies are always welcome.

title: SFX BROADCASTING TO BUY PACE FOR $130 MILLION
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Pace Entertainment Corporation for about $130 million. SFX will also buy the two-thirds of Pavilion Partners, which owns 11 amphitheaters, that it does not already own from Viacom Inc. and Sony Music Entertainment for an undisclosed price. Pace, with revenue of about $250 million this year, is the largest presenter of touring theatrical shows. Shares of the New York-based SFX, the nation's seventh-largest radio broadcaster, fell 37.5 cents, to $79.50. Pace owns two other amphitheaters and produces motor sport events.

title: Public Eye
description: FEW phrases can more quickly strike terror into the heart of the average American parent, hunkered down under the Christmas tree, than this: ''Some assembly required.'' Worse, as is the case with Compaq computers, the Bose Wave radio, most furniture from Ikea and many toys, if the instructions bear few words or none, only pictures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, EILEEN
description: SULLIVAN-Eileen. Loving wife of Michael. Sister of Peter Johnson, Bernice Yella, Dr. Marie Johnson Wittek, Patrick, William, Stephen, Michael Murphy and the late Joseph and Gerard Johnson. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's Church, 371 6th Av, Greenwich Village, Friday 10:30AM. Interment Resurrection Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: FILM REVIEW ; The Embers of Long Marriage, Still Warm Despite Flames Elsewhere
description: Maybe there's a more ruefully beautiful screen actress than Julie Christie. But that's hard to imagine while watching her radiant performance in ''Afterglow,'' Alan Rudolph's sinuous romance about a great-looking, long-married couple with a lively extracurricular agenda. Ms. Christie, who won a best actress award from the New York Film Critics Circle for her soulful and alluring work here, is as haunting as ever in the role of a middle-aged woman who chooses to live emotionally apart from her philandering husband. Even in circumstances vastly more conventional than those of her ''McCabe and Mrs. Miller'' days, Ms. Christie still conveys the same wounding wisdom, the same readiness to drift into a dream.

title: Fassel Caps Big Season And Is Named Coach of Year
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel said he dreamed big before the football season began.

title: IVAX SELLING PLANT TO GOLDSTAR FOR $21 MILLION
description: The Ivax Corporation is selling its Golden Glades pill-making factory and other assets to the closely held Goldstar Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Miami for $21 million. Ivax said the sale was part of its effort to divest itself of its nondrug assets and cut costs. The Miami-based maker of generic and branded drugs said it expected to save about $5 million to $6 million through the sale of the soft gelatin capsule-making plant, as it reduces excess manufacturing capacity. Ivax said it would receive $7 million in cash when the sale was completed, with the rest 18 months later. Ivax shares rose 6.25 cents, to $7.625.

title: Rangers Giving Kovalev the Rookie Treatment
description: A 4-1 victory over the worst team in the National Hockey League gave the Rangers an end to their three-game home losing streak at Madison Square Garden and a pleasant sendoff for their two-day holiday break. But when they regroup tomorrow to resume their schedule in Buffalo, they will again confront the many doubts and slumps that have contributed to an 11-16-12 record and what will be an uphill climb toward playoff contention in the second half of the season.

title: Knicks Preach Respect For Ewing
description: A simple question about ball movement after today's practice was all it took. Just like that, Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy found the perfect opportunity to question the public reaction to the loss of Patrick Ewing.

title: IN A SHIFT BY U.S., AID WILL BE SPED TO SOUTH KOREANS
description: In an about-face, the Clinton Administration joined other major industrial nations today in supplying South Korea with $10 billion in emergency aid and in asking major commercial banks to extend the deadlines by which Korean banks must repay their debts.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mistake-Free Form Eludes Devils
description: For the third straight game, the Devils got away from the disciplined, mistake-free hockey they have relied upon to win. And so, for the third straight game, they did not prevail.

description: HARRIS-Lewis K. Dear Lewis-love, it's one year today, and we miss you more than ever. Love, Essie

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ANNER, JOHN LLOYD, JR.
description: ANNER-John Lloyd, Jr. Died Christmas Night 1937, 60 years ago. His memory is kept alive by his wife, 4 children, 16 grandchildren, and 10 great grandchildren.

description: HAYDEN-Luke S. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Luke S. Hayden, a member of the Society and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Metro Business; Kennedy Newsstand Lease
description: Although it will not open to its first passengers until May, the new Terminal 1 at Kennedy International Airport has selected one of its most visible commercial tenants, a Troy, N.Y., company that will operate five newsstands in the terminal featuring an amalgam of foreign publications and Internet access.

title: Man Sought in Attempted Rapes in Queens
description: A man who the police believe may be a serial rapist has tried to kidnap two women in central Queens in the last three weeks, officials said yesterday. The suspect, who has not been arrested, has tried to force women into his van at gunpoint.

title: Arts Abroad; An American in Paris (as an Organist-Choirmaster)
description: Advent and Easter are hectic times for a church organist-choirmaster, and Edward J. Tipton, running himself ragged as Christmas relentlessly approached, hoped he would not come down with the flu, at least until after New Year's.

description: Cinderella found a heartthrob of a prince in Newark when American Ballet Theater opened a holiday-week run on Tuesday night at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center.

title: Security Officers Are a Focus in Mexico Massacre
description: Attorney General Jorge Madrazo Cuellar, who is leading the investigation into the killings of 45 unarmed Indians in a southern mountain village on Monday, said today that federal agents are questioning top security officials in the area.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVY, KENNETH
description: LEVY-Kenneth. 12/25/89. So precious the time. Your Loving Family

title: No-Walking Zones Tested To Fight Midtown Gridlock
description: New Yorkers like to think of their city as a pedestrian's paradise, a place where jaywalking is almost considered an inalienable right in a gas-guzzling world. But with crowding in midtown Manhattan nearing crisis proportions and traffic often at virtual standstill, the city is taking action: it is forbidding pedestrians from even crossing the street at 10 of midtown's busiest intersections.

title: On Wings of Lust, England's Sprites Revisit Their Past; Victorian Escapism at a London Show
description: Long before Fifth Avenue buses and Japanese tour groups, it was fairies who traveled in packs.

title: Metro Matters ; 26 Reasons To Chuckle About Politics
description: THE holidays are awkward for political reporters. It isn't just that as a blood sport, politics tends to lose its focus with so many of its players decamped to warmer climes; it is that the whole spirit of the season is inimical. Universalized, ''Peace on Earth and good will toward men'' would leave practically nothing to write about and certainly no audience to read it. (It is safe to say that those who follow the news out of Albany and City Hall are not doing so for its inspirational content.)

title: Vibrant Colors Are the Co-Stars
description: Lavishly colorful interiors play leading roles in two new films. ''Ma Vie en Rose'' (''My Life in Pink'') tells a modern story of gender identity, a girl trapped in a boy's body. The movie (above) is set in a prosperous suburb of Brussels. Charming and garish room settings are comic-book colorful, and evoke the magic optimism of childhood. Reminiscent of Christian LaCroix's interiors palette, the colors are chromatic, yet vibrant.

description: Winter Window Boxes

title: The Neediest Cases; An Open House That Reflects Its Owner's Open Heart
description: Lola Stanley has never met a foster child she did not want to adopt. Over the last decade, Mrs. Stanley, 47, has accumulated a family of nine children, two cats and one dog, all of whom share a rambling seven-bedroom house in the Castle Hill section of the Bronx.

title: Locality Refunds Agency For False Damage Claims
description: The borough of Seaside Heights agreed yesterday to pay more than $160,000 to settle false claims made to the Federal Emergency Management Agency for damages caused by a storm in December 1992.

title: Two Players Short, Penn State Knows Game Must Go On
description: As Curtis Enis's roommate, Penn State cornerback Shino Prater shared in the all-America running back's anguish when he was declared ineligible for the Citrus Bowl game against Florida for accepting a suit from an agent. And Prater wanted to talk about it today.

title: Yankees to Pay $4.4 Million as Lion's Share of Teams' 1997 Luxury Tax
description: The 1997 season became more expensive for the Yankees and four other teams this week. They officially learned the amount of luxury tax they will have to pay, and, as expected, the Yankees owe the biggest share of the $12 million the five teams will pay.

title: FILM REVIEW ; Tall, Dark and Hairy (Thirsty Too)
description: Why would three red-blooded American boys be champing at the bit to visit Paris? To visit the Louvre? No way. The only thing on the minds of these three smirking teen-age airheads who find more trouble than they could ever have anticipated in ''An American Werewolf in Paris'' is accumulating ''sex points'' on their competing mental scorecards.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about menorahs displayed in a Brooklyn store window misstated the timing of Hanukkah. The scene on Tuesday, during the day, occurred on the eve of the festival; its first day ran from sundown Tuesday to sundown yesterday.

title: Treasury Securities Fall in Price
description: Treasury prices fell in a shortened session yesterday, the first decline in bonds in five sessions.

title: Metro Business; Brooklyn Union Sells Unit
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company said yesterday that had it sold its Gas Energy and Gas Energy Cogeneration units to the Calpine Corporation of San Jose, Calif. for about $100 million.

title: The Welcome Chill of Christmas
description: A Dickensian Christmas is incomplete without a taste of the supernatural. ''A Christmas Carol'' is all haunting, of course, and even the riotous Christmas Eve party at Dingley Dell in ''The Pickwick Papers'' -- a miracle of wassail and music -- is accompanied by a tale of goblins and a sexton digging a grave in a churchyard on that same eve many years before. We moderns are more categorical than Dickens, better pleased, perhaps, to distinguish among our emotions and to file them away under the proper holiday. But Dickens had a point. A good scare was a way to intensify the pleasure of the season, making the plenitude that always accompanied Mr. Pickwick, for instance, seem that much more plenteous, making security itself that much more secure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOSCHANDER, EMANUEL
description: HOSCHANDER-Emanuel. Passed away on December 23. Son of the late Professor Jacob and Bertha Hoschander. Beloved husband of Rhoda (Arond). Adored father of Michal and Ronald Malen. Loving grandfather of Susannah, Abigail and Yacov Malen. Devoted brother of Grace Gerenstein. A man of integrity and dignity, and devotion to family and Judaism. In his unassuming way he enriched the lives of many. May his memory be for a blessing.

In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset on Friday from 3-5 and 7 to 9PM. Funeral service Saturday at Community Church of Great Neck, 2 Stoner Ave, Great Neck, at 2PM. Interment Warwick Cemetery, Warwick, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in Dr. Miller's memory may be made to Community Church of Great Neck, or North Shore University Hospital.

title: Les Harrison, 93, a Pioneer Of Professional Basketball
description: Les Harrison, a professional basketball pioneer who founded and coached the Rochester Royals, a dominant team of the late 1940's and early 1950's, died Tuesday at Highland Hospital in Rochester. He was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUMONT, SOPHIE
description: LAUMONT-Sophie. On December 23. Beloved daughter of Anne and Philippe, sister of Julia and Laura, granddaughter of Colt and Jake Adams, niece of Brooks Adams and Lisa Liebmann and Katie and Nikitas Venizelos, Claude and Edward Janeway Jr, cousin of Kyriaco, Jake, Anna, Emily and Selena Venizelos and Annie and Margaret Janeway. Receiving at Frank E. Campbell, December 25 from 57. Service on Friday, December 26. 11am, St. James Chapel, Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Contributions in her memory can be made to The Cystic Fibrosis Association of Greater N.Y. or The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Dec. 21 about Dr. Irving S. Wright, who pioneered the use of an anticoagulant to treat blood clots that can cause heart attacks and strokes, included a survivor incorrectly and misstated the address of the proposed Irving Sherwood Wright Center on Aging, a project of his at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Dr. Wright's wife, Lois Elliman Wright, died in 1993. The center is to be on First Avenue near East 77th Street, not Second Avenue and 72d.

title: New Convention Center Is Backed by Whitman
description: Economically depressed Wildwood got a present from the state yesterday, when Governor Whitman signed a bill paving the way for construction of a new $58 million convention center.

title: More Toys Are Reflecting Disabled Children's Needs
description: Carol Connell had heard about Sing and Snore Ernie, Beanie Babies and all the other hot holiday toys. Yet she was at a loss for what to buy her nephew, Joe Longhini, who is 4 and has cerebral palsy.

title: A Keeping-It-Simple Toy
description: For families weary of war games and computer wizardry, there is endearing relief in the low-tech Roy Toy log cabin kit, $16 at Zona, 97 Greene Street (near Spring Street). The toy, with pine logs stained with nontoxic dyes, has been made in Machias, Me., by three generations of the Dennison family. By mail, a cabin kit is $10; a castle, $25, (800) 530-0003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MELVIN
description: SMITH-Melvin, 70. Died Sunday, December 21, 1997. New City, N.Y. resident, formerly of Yonkers, NY, retired attorney. Son of the late Sol and Henrietta Epstein Smith. Educated in NYC and was a graduate of Brooklyn Law School, member of NYS Bar Association and B'Nai B'rith, Army Veteran. Survived by his wife Judy, three daughters Melinda of Brooklyn, Donna Gilligan of New City and Debbie Reardon of Cincinnati, his brother Lawrence of Bardonia, NY and one grandchild. Memorial contributions may be made to the Huntington Disease Society of America, Nyack, New York 10960.

description: Korean Aid Is Accelerated As U.S. Changes Strategy

description: But how will it affect his career?

title: One Killed and 2 Injured In Attack in Saddle Brook
description: One youth was killed and two others were injured early yesterday after a group of young men broke into the home of a man they believed had sexually assaulted a girlfriend of one member of the group some months earlier, prosecutors said.

title: Leading Lights, Whose Destiny Was to Be Dimmed
description: PAUL RUDOLPH and Aldo Rossi, two giants of 20th-century architecture, died in 1997. Rudolph and Rossi belonged to different generations. They were of different nationalities. Esthetically, their work was poles apart.

title: GENSIA SELLS MAJORITY STAKE IN MEDICAL PRODUCTS UNIT
description: The drug company Gensia Sicor Inc. said yesterday that it had sold a majority interest in its Gensia Automedics medical products unit to a private investor group led by Galen Associates and including Wellcome Trust. Terms were not disclosed. Gensia said the sale would allow it to focus on its pharmaceutical businesses. Gensia Sicor kept a 19 percent stake in the unit. The company said it had transferred all its medical products businesses to Gensia Automedics. The assets include interests in the Genesa System, which is used to diagnose coronary artery disease. Gensia, based in San Diego, expects costs associated with the deal will lower earnings for the fourth quarter by $10 million.

title: Indonesian Currency Slides 12% vs. Dollar
description: The Indonesian rupiah tumbled as much as 12 percent yesterday on expectations that the burden of repaying foreign loans will deepen the country's debt crisis. The Indonesian rupiah sank for a third day to 6,005 to the dollar, the lowest since the country's capital account was liberalized in 1971.

title: Lawsuit Against Calipari Dismissed
description: A New Jersey Superior Court judge dismissed a lawsuit yesterday charging that John Calipari, the Nets' coach, intentionally humiliated Dan Garcia, a Newark Star Ledger beat reporter, by using an ethnic slur and threatening to punch him during a confrontation at the team's training facility in Mahwah, N.J.

title: Massacre Hobbles Tourism in Egypt
description: This should be high season in Egypt, with foreign tourists flocking to the Pyramids of Giza and other Pharoanic sites that for more than a century have made Egypt a favorite wintertime destination.

title: Stocks Down, With the Dow Falling 31.64
description: Stocks fell modestly in an abbreviated trading session yesterday.

title: Survey Finds Wide Range of Fees for Checking Accounts
description: When Citibank last month raised by 200 percent the minimum balance it requires for free checking, it sparked criticism from New York City officials and state legislators.

title: Clinton Will Seek More Money To Aid and Shelter the Homeless
description: President Clinton said today that he would ask for a record $1.15 billion in the next Federal budget to aid and shelter the homeless and help them become self-sufficient.

title: Just to Be Sociable, Visit the Post Office
description: Last month, the town planners Andres Duany and Elizabeth Plater Zyberk celebrated the opening of their Town Center at Windsor, Fla., a posh polo community near Melbourne. Now, Windsor boasts classical parks, an amphitheater and a jewel of a post office (left), all designed by Scott Merrell. Making the post office the center of a town where cars are forbidden was essential to Windsor's plan. To pick up their mail and dividend checks, residents are obliged to walk the streets and meet their neighbors -- a paradigm shift in a community where residents might otherwise retreat to air-conditioned isolation.

title: Canada Rig Concerns Join
description: Canada's Petro Well Energy Services Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Crown Well Servicing Ltd. for stock valued at about $11.2 million (Canadian), or $8 million (United States). Both companies make drilling rigs. Petro Well, based in Calgary, has 11 rigs and one under construction. Crown, based in Edmonton, Alberta, has 11 rigs. Under the agreement, expected to close by Jan. 30, Petro Well will exchange 9.5 million shares of its common stock for all of the Crown shares outstanding. Petro Well has about 10.3 million shares outstanding.

title: Russians Fear Oil Spills (but Need Oil Money, Too)
description: Valery Timoshenko, a quiet man and a film maker, prefers to be behind the camera. But there he was in front of it, gesticulating at what he called the scene of a future crime.

title: Toshiro Mifune, Actor, Dies at 77; The Primal Hero of Samurai Films
description: Toshiro Mifune, the most internationally celebrated of Japanese film actors, whose work, particularly for the director Akira Kurosawa, galvanized generations of performers in the United States and around the world, died yesterday at a hospital in Mitaka, near his home in Tokyo. He was 77.

title: Nichols Could Face Death for Role in Blast
description: A Federal judge ruled today that prosecutors could ask a jury next week to sentence Terry L. Nichols to death, even though jurors did not conclude that Mr. Nichols intended to kill anyone when he conspired to build the massive bomb that destroyed the Federal Building in Oklahoma City.

description: Automobile production, one of South Korea's best hopes for increasing exports and bringing in foreign currency, is in danger of stalling.

title: Malnutrition's 20-Cent Treatment
description: Four years ago, scientists putting together studies from around the world realized that giving children with vitamin A deficiency a 2-cent capsule two or three times a year cut their death rate from diarrhea and other infectious diseases by a quarter. Today, 60 percent of the world's children get vitamin A. At a cost of about 20 cents or less to deliver each capsule, this is one of the most cost-effective methods of preventing disease ever found. The vitamin A project is one of several nutrition programs detailed in this year's report on the State of the World's Children from Unicef. Every year, says Unicef, nearly 12 million children under 5 die, more than half because of malnutrition. Fortunately, many proven, cheap ways to prevent malnutrition are in use, and Unicef's report gives them needed attention.

title: Economic Scene; Hidden in the Glitter of a Bountiful Economy, Problems Remain
description: Joblessness is lower than it has been for a quarter-century. Inflation is less than 3 percent and appears to be falling. Corporate earnings have been powering a sustained boom in the stock market that has added trillions of dollars to the wealth of the middle class.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WUNDERMAN, IRVING
description: WUNDERMAN-Irving. Of Westport, Connecticut, died of cancer at the Norwalk Hospital on Dec. 19 at the age of eighty. Beloved husband of Margaret, devoted father of Eric, Oren and Naomi Neuwirth and proud grandfather of five. A memorial service will be held at 12 noon, January 6 at the Collins Funeral Home in Norwalk. Donations may be made to Norwalk Hospital Dialysis Fund, Maple Street, Norwalk, CT. 06856 in lieu of flowers.

title: The Pop Life; From Movie To Album To Movie to Holiday CD
description: Christmas movie season is always accompanied by Christmas soundtracks, the music industry's last desperate attempt to rake in extra profits after having released the superstar albums it stockpiles for November. Typically, Christmas soundtracks are slapdash collections of music from the young bands that a record label plans to promote in the next year along with a few substandard unreleased songs from established acts to entice CD buyers. Though the songs typically have little to do with the movie they are affiliated with, they are forced on hapless directors who have been convinced that their film needs a music marketing tie-in to succeed at the box office. This month, however, there are a few soundtracks that serve as more than promotional tools, that have a personality and identity of their own and are conceived of by a director or composer with an idiosyncratic musical vision. Here are three of the season's best.

title: ROADWAY SHARES DROP AFTER IT SAYS EARNINGS WILL SLOW
description: Shares of Roadway Express Inc. tumbled nearly 15 percent yesterday after the trucking company indicated its fourth-quarter profits would fall short of Wall Street's expectations. Roadway reported after the financial markets closed Tuesday that its earnings for the latest period would ''show only modest improvement'' over the 52 cents a share earned in the period a year earlier. Analysts had predicted the company would earn 81 cents a share in the quarter. In the period a year earlier, Roadway, which is based in Akron, Ohio, earned $10.6 million on revenue of $782.1 million. The company said the slackening earnings growth was mainly caused by the extremely heavy flow of freight, which increased labor costs. Its shares fell $3.6875, to $21.375.

title: PSINET CUTS OFFER FOR ISTAR INTERNET BY 38%
description: Psinet Inc. lowered its takeover offer for Istar Internet Inc. yesterday by 38 percent, to $21.8 million (Canadian), or $15.3 million (United States), in cash in the wake of a 61 percent drop in Istar's stock price since a Nov. 10 agreement between the companies. Psinet will bid 75 cents (Canadian), or 52.5 cents (United States), a share for the money-losing Istar. Its original bid was $35 million (Canadian), or $24.5 million (United States), in convertible preferred shares. Istar's shares tumbled to 61 cents (Canadian) from $1.59 (Canadian) after Psinet made its offer. Yesterday, Istar's shares rose 11 cents (Canadian), to 72 cents (Canadian), while Psinet fell 31.25 cents, to $4.84375.

title: HANDY & HARMAN URGES SHAREHOLDERS TO REJECT WHX BID
description: The metal products manufacturer Handy & Harman said yesterday that it had urged its shareholders to reject an unsolicited $360 million takeover bid from the WHX Corporation. Handy & Harman said WHX's offer was inadequate and was an attempt to take advantage of Handy & Harman's overfunded pension plan and precious-metals inventory. WHX, the parent of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, offered $30 a share for Handy & Harman, of which it already owns 4.9 percent. The offer, which it made directly to shareholders, will expire Jan. 16. Both companies are based in New York. Shares of Handy & Harman rose $1.50, to $34.875, while WHX shares fell 12.5 cents.

title: 30 Firms to Pay $900 Million In Investor Suit

title: Honda Predicts Output Will Rise 3.3% in 1998
description: The Honda Motor Company forecasts its global production will rise 3.3 percent next year as it starts building its popular Odyssey mini-van in Canada and shifts the production of its Acura luxury sedan to the United States. The company said yesterday that it would increase North American production capacity to more than one million vehicles by 2001 from 790,000 now. By next autumn, it will begin producing 120,000 mini-vans a year at its Canadian plant and will roll out its first Acuras built in the United States.

title: Foreign Affairs; Falling Bodies
description: Thinking about the economic crisis in Southeast Asia reminds me of that joke about being on the 30th floor of a hotel, looking out your window and suddenly seeing a man falling past your room. ''How you doing?'' you ask him as he sails by. ''Fine,'' he says. ''So far.'' And so it is with the Asian economies. This crisis has just begun. Korea and its neighbors are still far from having hit bottom. Their crises are still confined largely to stock markets and currencies. But soon bankruptcies will mount, real estate prices will plummet and the real economy, real jobs and real people will hit the pavement. Even then the story won't be over. Because what's happening in Southeast Asia today is also a China crisis, an education crisis and a political crisis.

title: The Annual Sermon, Retold

The congregation at this hour was made up mostly of parents with young children, hung-over teen-agers and silver-haired retirees who hoped to avoid the crush of the earlier, more elaborate Christmas services. There was no crush here. Even though every pew was filled, the church felt vacant. A single baritone sang. A weary-looking harpist plucked out the old hymns.

title: TRW AGREES TO SELL UNIT TO WIN BDM DEAL APPROVAL
description: TRW Inc. agreed yesterday to sell a Pentagon engineering and technical assistance business as a condition of antitrust clearance for its $975 million acquisition of BDM International Inc. description: The Reds re-signed outfielder Melvin Nieves to a one-year contract, avoiding salary arbitration. The Reds acquired Nieves, 25, from the Detroit Tigers for pitcher Donne Wall and a minor league catcher, Paul Bako, on Nov. 11. Nieves spent most of the 1997 season as the Tigers' starting right fielder, hitting .228 with 20 home runs and 64 runs batted in during 116 games. But he led the Tigers with 157 strikeouts in 1997, the fifth-highest total in the majors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, BERNARD
description: SCHWARTZ-Bernard. The entire NYU Law School community Mourns the tragic death of Proffessor Bernard Schwartz. A member of the NYU Law School family since he came to us as a student in 1944, he joined our faculty in 1947 and has served us in that capacity since that time. A world renowned scholar whose works has been translated into dozens of languages, he will be missed by everyone at NYU, by generations of students, and by lawyers everywhere. Our hearts go out to his wife, Aileen, also a graduate, and to his son Brian. John Sexton, Dean Martin Lipton, Chair, Board of Trustees

title: 2 Japanese Racketeers Face Extortion Charges
description: Tokyo District Court yesterday indicted two corporate racketeers on separate charges of threatening to disrupt shareholders meetings at the Toshiba Corporation and the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation. Takeyoshi Kikuchi is accused of extorting 6 million yen, or $46,000, in payoffs from Toshiba, which makes electrical equipment, in return for insuring that the company's June 1995 general shareholders meeting would not be disrupted.

title: MEDAPHIS REPORTS DOWNWARD REVISION IN 1995 EARNINGS
description: The Medaphis Corporation said yesterday that as a result of a restatement, it had decreased its fiscal year 1995 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization by about $2.8 million. Results for the fiscal year 1996 and the first nine months of 1997 were also restated to account for the December 1995 acquisition of Medical Management Sciences Inc. as a purchase accounting transaction. The restatement will have no effect on earnings in the fiscal year 1996 or 1997 or in any future years. Balance sheet assets, primarily good will, will increase by about $160 million. Medaphis, which is based in Atlanta and provides business management software and services, said the financial restatements would not have any cash impact on the company.

title: MUSIC REVIEW ; Enticing the Young to Handel, With Soul, Sax and Synthesizer
description: Handel's ''Messiah'' has to be the most popular work of the classical music repertory. The plethora of ''Messiah'' performances at Christmastime attests to the music's genuine hold on the public.

title: A Relic Whose Time Is Passing; Tiny European Bourses Like Antwerp Face Euro Threat
description: The stock exchange in this Flemish port is open every weekday, but it is busiest on Tuesday and Thursday. That's when not only its own stocks are traded, but also others that are listed on the big board in Brussels.

title: Panel Will Study Effects Of Ticket-Scalping Rules
description: Do consumers benefit when ticket scalping is banned? That will be the question before a new commission established by legislation signed into law yesterday by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. The nine-member panel, consisting of legislators, consumer advocates and ticket brokers, will have four months to do its work. In the meantime, existing antiscalping rules will remain in effect.

title: Sports of The Times; For Players, Good Cheer Hits Home
description: AT a time of year when religious and holiday festivities intermingle like flavorful rum punch, one of the constants that make up the spirit of the season, whether it be Christmas, Hanukkah, Ramadan or Kwanzaa, is family. And the world of sports, in a sense, is all about family.

title: PATH Bomb Scare Delays Commuters
description: A military ammunitions container left at a turnstile in the Hoboken, N.J., PATH station yesterday prompted the police to evacuate the station and halt service between Hoboken and Manhattan for two hours at the height of the morning rush. About 20,000 commuters had to take ferries or buses instead.

title: Resorts Adopt Bar-Code System
description: It started with a bar code on a loaf of bread at the grocery store. But now skiers can think of themselves as the next commodity, although fairly cognitive ones, who carry their own scanning codes through lift lines.

title: Miracle at the Getty: Angelenos on Buses
description: AFTER 12 years and $1 billion, the new Getty Museum is accomplishing the impossible: getting Angelenos out of their cars.

title: IN PANAMA ACCORD, G.I.'S WOULD STAY
description: The United States and Panama have reached a tentative agreement that would permit American troops to remain in Panama after the United States relinquishes control of the canal in 1999, officials of both Governments said today.

title: King Denies That He Asked For a Unification Bout Fee
description: Don King denied yesterday that he had done anything to scuttle a possible heavyweight unification fight between Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis during negotiations with Time Warner Sports. King also said he did not ask for a guarantee of between $5 million and $8 million to promote the bout.

title: In Mexican Village, Signs of Death Hang Heavy
description: The last time Manuel Santiz saw his wife was just before noon on Monday, moments before the shooting started in this deep-green mountain town in southern Mexico. When he heard the shots, he began to run, down a steep hill and toward a river. Later he learned that along the path he used to escape, a band of gunmen had shot many of the 45 people who died in a massacre on Monday.

title: 7-Year-Old French Misfit's Ideas on Sexual Identity
description: ''Ma Vie en Rose'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 3. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: As Korea Faces Economic Crisis, Emigrants Feel a Sad Vindication
description: Heung Choi and her husband, Eung, came to America in 1974, long before South Korea's economic miracle. Then, as they struggled and built a new life running a small bookstore in Manhattan, they saw South Korea blossom with sudden riches, and found themselves wondering about the immigrant's path they had chosen.

title: 1. Ring Up the Club. 2. Ring Out the Old. 3. Ring In the New.; Rock and Pop
description: For club owners, Christmas really comes on New Year's Eve. That's when bars are packed, seats are full and would-be revelers still clamor at the door. All of those clubgoers are intent on starting the year with music they love in a crowd of fellow fans. Whether they're fond of rockabilly or hip-hop, swing or salsa or electronica, they can find what they're looking for in Manhattan on New Year's Eve. Places that regularly present live music call on their favorite acts, and many places that don't still find room to set up musicians and sound systems. Obeying the law of supply and demand, prices go up -- way up -- on New Year's Eve, though most clubs offer little extras like party hats or a glass of champagne at midnight. For New Year's Eve, it's smart to make reservations or buy advance tickets; clubs do fill up, and some events (like Phish's annual show at Madison Square Garden) are already sold out. Below, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times preview the live music taking place on New Year's Eve. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURTON, JOHN R.
description: BURTON-John R. Of Palm City Florida died Tuesday, December 23rd, at home after a brief illness. He was 80 years old. Originally from southwestern Virginia, Mr. Burton achieved a distinguished corporate legal career in New York City. He was an authority on the Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 and appeared before the U.S. Supreme Court and Ohio Supreme Court. A graduate of Roanoke College in 1937 and Case Western Reserve Law School in 1940, Mr. Burton joined the New York law firm of Reid & Priest upon graduation and was a partner from 1949-1970. He specialized in legal matters relating to corporate financing, utility affairs and international business throughout Latin and South America, Mr. Burton was President and Chief Executive Officer and Director of Private Export Funding Corporation, New York, between 1970-73. He then joined American Electric Power Service Corporation as senior level legal counsel and Vice President, Director and Secretary of AEPSC. He was admitted to the Bars of Ohio, New York and Virginia. He retired in 1987 to Palm City, Fla., and was a member of the Palm City Presbyterian Church. Mr. Burton also served with the U.S. Navy during W.W. II in both the European and Pacific theaters. Mr. Burton is survived by his wife Elizabeth of Palm City, Florida; three daughters, Sara, of Esmont, Virginia; Julie, of Rowayton, Conn., and Terry Cox, of St. Louis, Mo; his mother, Ida M. Burton, of Richlands, Va; his brother, William Burton, of Bluefield, Va; his sister, Helen Gisi, of Pine Mountain, Georgia; three grandchildren and one great-grandson. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 PM on Saturday, January 10, 1998 at Palm City Presbyterian Church, Palm City. In lieu of flowers the family asks that a donation be sent to a charity of your choice.

title: IN THE THEATER DISTRICT WITH -- Nathan Lane; Ebullient, With a Side of Quiet
description: Nathan Lane slouched into his booth at the Brooklyn Diner on West 57th Street in Manhattan, looking slightly rumpled and worn out. ''I had a meeting with my business manager,'' he said, a wry smile seeping across one side of his unshaven face. ''I need a bagel.''

title: TENNIS: Breakfast of Champions ($4.96, Hon); Pete Sampras Is Wild, All Right, Like Maple Syrup
description: It was morning, Pete Sampras was craving the first carbo-load of the day, and that could mean only one thing. It was time for the world's No. 1 tennis player to fold himself into his alter ego, ''the Beast,'' a black Porsche Turbo S with 430 mechanized horses lurking beneath its hood and a reliable radar detector hidden in its dash, and race to the Waffle House, accelerating at one point to an immoderate 110 miles an hour.

title: Giants' Backs Continue Rotation
description: All through this surprisingly successful season, the Giants have played running back by committee. The healthy backs play while the bruised ones mend.

title: City Where the Beats Were Moved to Howl
description: Growing up in New Jersey, I plotted getaways. At 17, in June 1959, just after I was expelled from high school, I dyed my hair black, caught a New York-bound train and checked into a Y.W.C.A. near Times Square under an assumed name. To my eyes, Times Square looked like a party, a party for all the people not invited to the other parties -- this was the place where anonymity turned into excitement. When the detectives my stepfather had hired found me in my room at the Y a few days later, I was armed with ''On the Road,'' ''Howl'' and a Gideon Bible, verging on what I hoped was existentialist psychosis and planning my career as a Beat outcast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHTER, OSCAR
description: RICHTER-Oscar, 93. On December 24. Beloved husband of Amelia. Devoted father of Marvin and Ellen. Devoted father-in-law of Raphael and Rita. Beloved grandfather of Lisa, Jacqueline, Caroline, Susan and Judith. Services on Friday, December 26, at 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Year's Best Films: Risks Furnish Rewards
description: Guts and glory: 1997 was a year of big risk-taking on screen, and some of the chanciest ventures proved most rewarding. Though at midsummer we seemed to be slogging through the worst set of studio films in movie history, the year's high points happily balanced its losses. And brought splendid surprises: Who could have imagined the return of the sweeping old-fashioned epic? Or that the year's hottest indie filmmaker would be not a film student or clerk maxing out his parents' credit cards but a ''Godfather'' star?

title: Holyfield a Proud Champion in a Shameful Year
description: Evander Holyfield's right ear has healed nicely. But the scar on boxing is indelible.

title: Costly Football Stadiums Bring Booms or Busts to Campuses

description: PALL-William B. December 23 at age 51. Loving husband of Olivia. Proud, dedicated, doting father of Alexander and Caitlin. Devoted son of David and the late Josephine Pall and dear stepson of Helen Pall. Loyal brother of Ellen Pall, Jane Block, Abigail Weinshank, and the late Stephanie Pall. Son-in-law of Sir Gordon and Lady Wolstenholme. Brother-in-law of Richard Dicker, Fred Weinshank, and Sarah Plumley. Beloved uncle and cousin of many. He loved his family and his friends, and delighted in art, literature, music, humor, animals and beauty in all its forms. He will be sorely missed. Service Sunday, December 28. For information call Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY, 914-693-4700. In lieu of flowers, donations in Bill's memory may be made to the art department of Alex and K.K.'s school-Rippowam Cisqua, PO Box 488, Bedford, New York 10506.

title: A Goatherd's Destiny Off Exit 69
