description: President Clinton's visit this month to Charlotte Gardens, 89 suburban-style homes in the Crotona Park East section of the Bronx, focused attention on how much has changed in the South Bronx since the 1970's. It also served as a reminder that the rebuilding is not over.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHELLBACH, LEWIS CARL
description: SCHELLBACH-Lewis Carl, 62. Of Manhasset. Beloved husband of Anne, dear father of L. Carl Jr., Beth Young, Kate Rogers, Peg Fraser and Peter, loving father-inlaw to their spouses and Pahqi to twelve grandchildren. A skilled investment manager, he was made partner of Garrison, Bradford & Associates this year. He battled cancer for more than five years before dying early Christmas morning, 1997. Plans for a memorial service have not been made.

title: Younger and Hipper, but Still Cranky
description: ''The Sunshine Boys'' may be one of Neil Simon's most foolproof plays, but when a television version has been sitting on the shelf for two years, as this one has, you have to wonder what went wrong. The casting comes out of a quirky dream, with Woody Allen and Peter Falk as the feuding retired comedy team reunited for one more bickering go-round. As it turns out, this version of the geriatric ''Odd Couple'' is not a disaster; it is uneven and at times disappointingly dull.

title: 1. Ring Up the Club. 2. Ring Out the Old. 3. Ring In the New.; Rock and Pop
description: For club owners, Christmas really comes on New Year's Eve. That's when bars are packed, seats are full and would-be revelers still clamor at the door. All of those clubgoers are intent on starting the year with music they love in a crowd of fellow fans. Whether they're fond of rockabilly or hip-hop, swing or salsa or electronica, they can find what they're looking for in Manhattan on New Year's Eve. Places that regularly present live music call on their favorite acts, and many places that don't still find room to set up musicians and sound systems. Obeying the law of supply and demand, prices go up -- way up -- on New Year's Eve, though most clubs offer little extras like party hats or a glass of champagne at midnight. For New Year's Eve, it's smart to make reservations or buy advance tickets; clubs do fill up, and some events (like Phish's annual show at Madison Square Garden) are already sold out. Below, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times preview the live music taking place on New Year's Eve. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: FOR years, investors may have wondered what business Bausch & Lomb hoped to make its focus: sports optics, dental care or its popular brand of contact lenses and solutions.

description: Reflecting demand for office space in Manhattan, the Amerada Hess Corporation has renewed its lease for the top five floors of 1185 Avenue of the Americas, committing to a 15-year extension more than a year before its lease expired.

title: Utilitarian Still Lifes, Diffident Self-Images
description: Mainline still life painting has generally focused on nice things, nicely arranged. If there are flowers, they are still in bloom. If there are pears, they have not gone sleepy. If meat or fish are in question, they come straight from the market. The furniture, even if not fancy, is good and solid.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT SCHIFFER had a surprise for his fiancee, VICTORIA CONTINO, for her 39th birthday this week: a wedding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXWELL, ELLA
description: MAXWELL-Ella. On Dec. 22, 1997 of Franklin Lakes, NJ. Cherished mother of Vera Maxwell Holder and William R.J. Maxwell. Motherin-law of Andrea Hope Maxwell and Michael D. Holder. She was preceded in death by her husband John Knott Maxwell. Funeral services will be held at St. Bernard's Episcopal Church, 60 Washington Ave., Bernardsville, New Jersey, Saturday at 3:00 PM. Interment is in Church Cemetery. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions in her name to the American Cancer Society, 20 Mercer Street, Hackensack, New Jersey 07601.

title: Mirrors, Maybe, But Not Smoke
description: Where there's smoke, there's ire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, LAWRENCE A.
description: MEYERS-Lawrence A. Of Longboat Key and New York. Died on the Key, December 17, 1997, at age 93. A New York banker for 45 years, he was ''Larry'' to countless friends and clients of Trade Bank and Trust Co. and National Bank of North America. He retired in 1973 from NBNA as Executive Vice President, Chief Loan Officer, and member of the Board of Directors. He served on the Arts Acquisition Committee of New York Board of Trade and on the Board of Postgraduate Center for Mental Health. He is survived by his wife Muriel, daughter Vicki Oleskey and granddaughter Allison; son Roger, and his wife Becky, and grandsons Robin and Cameron. Service was private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, KATHARYN BURKITT
description: LEVY-Katharyn Burkitt. Born July 15, 1917. Died December 24, 1997. Beloved wife of Robert. Adored mother of Michael, Lina, Maidy, and Bill. Cherished motherin-law of Marline, Theo, Michael and Patricia. Proud grandmother of Joseph, Kyla, Katie and Katelin. Loving sister of Jeff Burkitt and the late James Burkitt. You were our great good fortune. Visitation Frank E. Campell, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC, today, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Accounts
description: * Van Melle Inc., Erlanger, Ky., to Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, New York, to handle the account of Airheads candies, previously at GSD& M, Austin, Tex., part of GGT Group, which resigned. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: A Sailor's Journal; Gaining Respect in the Face of Adversity
description: The nine boats in the 31,600-nautical-mile Whitbread Round the World Race arrived in Sydney, Australia, Tuesday after a 2,250-nautical-mile third leg from Fremantle. EF Language of Sweden beat Swedish Match by only five minutes and stands first over all. Katie Pettibone, an American on the all-women crew of EF Education, which came in ninth, will be filing periodic reports until the race's return to Southampton, England, in May. This is her 10th report.

description: A police officer shot and killed a 23-year-old man after chasing him into a grocery store in Canarsie yesterday in an episode that began after the police heard gunfire from the roof of an apartment building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, JANET W.
description: SIEGEL-Janet W., 66. Of Prairie Village, Kansas, formerly of New Rochelle, New York. Died of cancer Wednesday, December 24, 1997, at Menorah Medical Center. Graveside services 1:30 PM, Friday, December 26, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Family suggests contributions to Gan Israel, C/O Rabbi Ben Zion Friedman, Chabad House; Kehilath Israel Synagogue; or Beth Israel Abraham and Voliner Synagogue, all of Overland Park, KS. Surviving are husband Avrom H. Siegel of the home; sons Matthew A. Siegel, Leawood, KS, Joshua L. Siegel of Granite Springs, NY, and Jeremy I. Siegel, Brookfield, CT, and daughter Rachel D. Collens, Pelham Manor, NY; brother Leonard Weiner, Poughkeepsie, New York; and six grandchildren.

title: A Christmas Day of Firsts: The Workers; Santa Wasn't The Only One Busy at Work Before Dawn
description: It was a few minutes before 6 on Christmas morning. There was no sign yet of the dawn, and most of the world was fast asleep. But Carolyn Ziptko and Ralph Rzekiec were already busily at work, making coffee, checking the change in the cash register and arranging the doughnuts, bagels and muffins on the shelves of the Dunkin' Donuts on Park Avenue in the commercial heart of Rutherford, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SIDNEY
description: SCHWARTZ-Sidney. Of Whitestone, on December 25th, at age ninety-four. Beloved husband of Beatrice, devoted father of Hugh and Stephen, father-in-law of Maria Rose and Dora, loving grandfather of Jeffrey and Debbie, Beverly and Andy, Laura and Frederick, and five great-grandchildren. Practiced dentistry until age 81, past President of the Free Synagogue of Flushing, past Chancellor Commander in the Knights of Pythias, and past Noble Grand of The Odd Fellows. Funeral Service 12:00 Noon today, ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills, with interment to follow at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Dolphins Hoping to Avoid A Third Loss to the Patriots
description: Clutching four weeks' worth of fan mail, Miami Dolphins linebacker Zach Thomas today mulled one of pro football's long-held maxims -- that it's hard to beat a good team twice in a season, much less three times.

title: Sports of The Times; Willie Naulls Saw, Heard, Responded
description: HE grew up in Watts and knew harrowing times. It is virtually a cliche now, unless you experience it. People close to him suffered drug addiction, others were sent to prison and some were murdered in the violence that is now too often numbingly commonplace. But he survived, got out, thrived.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, BERNARD
description: SCHWARTZ-Bernard. The entire NYU Law School community Mourns the tragic death of Proffessor Bernard Schwartz. A member of the NYU Law School family since he came to us as a student in 1944, he joined our faculty in 1947 and has served us in that capacity since that time. A world renowned scholar whose works has been translated into dozens of languages, he will be missed by everyone at NYU, by generations of students, and by lawyers everywhere. Our hearts go out to his wife, Aileen, also a graduate, and to his son Brian. John Sexton, Dean Martin Lipton, Chair, Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLITZ, DOROTHY
description: BLITZ-Dorothy. Passed away on December 24. Beloved wife of 66 years to Murray. Devoted mother of Marvin and Lenore Lerner. Cherished grandmother of Jill, Douglas, Jonathan, Erica, Kenneth and Caroline. Loving greatgrandmother of Matthew and Talia. Services Friday, December 26, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Education Peril Is Seen in Increase of Part-Time College Teachers
description: The number of part-time instructors at colleges and universities has nearly doubled since 1970, and the trend to hiring part-timers as a cost-saving measure now ''threatens the quality of higher education,'' according to a report to be distributed on tomorrow at the annual convention of the Modern Language Association of America in Toronto.

title: The Talk of the Year
description: The aphorisms, quips, comments and phrases that make news during the year provide a snapshot album of contemporary culture and character. For 1997, that album tells us that Americans haven't moved far from the frank materialism of the 1980's. Despite effusions of public piety, we displayed a touch of fin de siecle decadence and a powerful concern for money.

title: Japan Presses Banks to Give Koreans Time
description: Japan's Finance Ministry and central bank are putting pressure on commercial banks to support the latest international rescue effort for South Korea by extending loans as they come due next week.

title: Many Shows and Many Indias
description: If you like New York City, chances are you'll like India. Midtown Manhattan at lunchtime and an Indian village on market day are surprisingly alike. Cars and bikes charge by; personal space is at a premium; the noise level is high, the sheer variety of people exhausting. There are days when it's just too much, and you'd rather be anywhere else. But when you leave, if you leave, you can't wait to return.

title: In Celebration of the Everglades
description: On his way to Japan a couple of weeks ago to salvage the international conference on global warming, Al Gore made a brief detour on behalf of another environmental objective close to his heart. In a setting that was part political rally, part country fair, the Vice President and a gaggle of Federal and state officials gathered in the colorful little fishing village of Everglades City to mark the 50th anniversary of Everglades National Park and give fresh momentum to the campaign to save a once-wondrous ecosystem from further decay.

title: To Sex-Segregated Training, Still Semper Fi
description: On a rain-spattered rifle range in this storied, swampy place, Louesa Sizemore and the rest of a platoon of recruits came as close as the United States Marine Corps is now prepared to go in letting male and female enlistees train together.

title: Lots of Wares, No Warehouse
description: In the often frustrating hunt for one video or another, the shortest route to an elusive tape often leads to the right mail-order operation. Some of them specialize in genres, while the biggest make a stab at carrying it all. In Brooklyn Heights, however, one small company lays claim to having it all while carrying nothing.

title: Mother Leaves 8-Month-Old On the Street, Then Flees
description: A Brooklyn woman with a history of neglecting her children left her 8-month-old son in a stroller outside a former police station house in Prospect Heights early Christmas morning, officials said. The woman attached a note to the child, giving both his name and that of the father, the police said.

title: Editorial Notebook; The Courageous Women of Iran
description: Each morning as the sun slides above the horizon, a small group of daring women gather on a hilltop in Mellat Park, a tidy green oasis in northern Teheran. They come to exercise a newly won right, doing calisthenics in a public spot. As the women beat their arms and their dark coats billow in the morning chill, they look like a flock of ravens about to take flight.

title: 1. Ring Up the Club. 2. Ring Out the Old. 3. Ring In the New.; Rock and Pop
description: For club owners, Christmas really comes on New Year's Eve. That's when bars are packed, seats are full and would-be revelers still clamor at the door. All of those clubgoers are intent on starting the year with music they love in a crowd of fellow fans. Whether they're fond of rockabilly or hip-hop, swing or salsa or electronica, they can find what they're looking for in Manhattan on New Year's Eve. Places that regularly present live music call on their favorite acts, and many places that don't still find room to set up musicians and sound systems. Obeying the law of supply and demand, prices go up -- way up -- on New Year's Eve, though most clubs offer little extras like party hats or a glass of champagne at midnight. For New Year's Eve, it's smart to make reservations or buy advance tickets; clubs do fill up, and some events (like Phish's annual show at Madison Square Garden) are already sold out. Below, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times preview the live music taking place on New Year's Eve. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Bernard Schwartz Dies at 74; Legal Scholar and Historian

He was 74.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWEY, GRACE MURIEL
description: DEWEY-Grace Muriel. Died in Manchester Center, Vermont, on December 24. She was born in Chicago, Illinois. She worked as a professional singer and dancer. Her professional name was Muriel DeForrest. She moved to New York City when she was offered a contract by Florence Ziegfeld to appear in his Midnight Frolic. She was married to the late Dr. Martin Dewey, D.D.S., M.D., 1925. Mrs. Grace Muriel Dewey moved to Vermont later in her life to be closer to her surviving nephew, Howard Pienie and his family of Greenwich, New York. Funeral services will be held Saturday, December 27, 11 AM, at The Zion Episcopal Church, Manchester, VT. Entombment will follow on Monday, December 29, at the Rosehill Cemetery in Chicago. For those who desire, memorial gifts may be made in her memory to either the Salvation Army or Boys Town in care of Brewster Funeral Service, PO Box 885, Manchester Center, Vermont 05255.

title: For Type A's Prone to Climbing Walls
description: In the last five years indoor rock-climbing gyms have multiplied like gourmet coffee shops. There are six in Manhattan and a handful more within a 50-mile radius: plywood or (if you're lucky) fiberglass walls, from 20 to 50 feet high, with movable hand holds that can be changed to create new routes. The vertical crowd is no longer restricted to sinewy out-there dudes. At the Manhattan Plaza Health Club on West 43d Street, near Ninth Avenue, I climbed with a freelance computer consultant and the editor of a Polish newspaper. Next to us two 40-ish men in yarmulkes climbed while minding a 17-month-old girl. She sat at the base of the wall sucking a carabiner, the large metal ring climbers use to clip themselves to the rope.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARISH, BARBARA
description: BARISH-Barbara. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center are profoundly saddened by the premature death of our beloved friend and esteemed colleague, Barbara Barish, Vice President, Academic Administration, Mount Sinai School of Medicine. A graduate of the University of Rochester, with an MBA in Health Care from Bernard Baruch College, Barbara Barish joined Mount Sinai's staff in 1980 as a financial administrator for Support Services, and later served as a special projects coordinator in the Nursing Department, before her appointment as Associate Dean for Operations in 1985, the first administrator to be recruited for the establishment of the Dean's Office of Mount Sinai School of Medicine separate from that of the President's Office. Since that time, she has played a pivotal role in numerous administrative and organizational enhancements that have contributed to the success of the School of Medicine, with broad responsibilities ranging from resource allocation to faculty recruitment and appointments as well as oversight of many school-wide programs, including Ethics In Research and departmental evaluations. Respected for her knowledge and skill, she also was as warm and personable as she was talented, a woman of intellect and wit with whom it was a joy and a privilege to be associated. She will be remembered fondly, and her loss dearly felt. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband, our colleague at Mount Sinai, Stuart, to their sons, Michael and David, to her mother, Esther Meyer, and to the entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, MD, President Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice President Wendy Z. Goldstein, Director

Beloved grandmother of Geoffrey and Shana Carey. Beloved sister of Stanley Gardner (Blossom). She was strong, caring, independent. You will be in our hearts forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JAMES G.
description: KENNEDY-James G. The American Irish Historical Society mourns the death of the Chairman of our Executive Council. For over a quarter century his generosity preserved our landmark home, and will assure future generations access to our priceless archives and library. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Rita, his son, James and his grandchildren. Kevin M. Cahill, M.D. President-General

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, SYLVIA RAUCH EDELSTEIN
description: COOPER-Sylvia Rauch Edelstein, eighty, on December 24th, 1997. Beloved mother of Philip and the late Mary, grandmother of Marcy and Kate, aunt of Jackie, Phyllis, Marty and Ellen. Will be dearly missed by her family and friends. Born in the same year as President Kennedy, 1917, she lived a life that espoused to the fullest a famous Kennedy statement: ''Ask not what your country can do for you, but what you can do for your country.'' As a librarian and teacher for fifty years she gave a great deal to our nation's youth. Many children and adults were positively influenced by her love of learning and her willingness to give of herself. Sylvia lost two husbands and a young daughter, yet she perservered and lived long enough to have two beautiful grandchildren, whom she dearly loved. We who loved her, mourn her passing but celebrate her life of service and sacrifice. Donations may be made to the New York City Public Library.

title: Honors, Yes, But a Problem
description: Curtis Hanson, the director of ''L.A. Confidential,'' should be the happiest filmmaker in town. His drama about crime and corruption in Los Angeles in the 1950's has swept most of the top end-of-year awards. The National Board of Review, the New York Film Critics and the Los Angeles Film Critics have named ''L.A. Confidential'' the best film of the year and Mr. Hanson (above) best director. It's almost inevitable that Mr. Hanson, whose career has been transformed by the film and who is being offered virtually every high-profile script in town, will be nominated for an Academy Award together with his film.

title: Anguished Mexican Village Buries Its Dead
description: The men of several small villages began digging the graves after dawn this Christmas morning. They dug two trenches, each 50 feet long. Others hauled the coffins -- small white ones for the children, black and blue boxes draped with bunting for the adults -- to a clearing surrounded by banana plants. During the open-air Mass for the 45 massacre victims, survivors spoke the names aloud: ''Ana Perez Luna, Ignacio Perez Jimenez, Rosalia Gomez Perez.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNELL, THOMAS F.
description: FINNELL-Thomas F., 87. Of Bridgewater, N.J., on Tuesday, December 23, 1997. He was born May 11, 1910, in Bridgeport, CT. During his long career in the hotel industry in New York, Mr. Finnell held management positions at the Empire, Pennsylvania, New Yorker and Whitehall Hotels and served as General Manager of the Taft, the Consulate and the Park Lane when in first opened. He retired in 1972 and had resided since in St. Petersburg, FL, Hilton Head Island, SC, and Dallas, TX, before moving to New Jersey to be near his daughter. He was the husband for 54 years of the late Mary McSweeney and grandfather of the late Elisabeth Sheehan. He is survived by one son, Thomas F. Finnell, Jr., of Wardsboro, VT., one daughter, Mary Ellen Sheehan of Mendham, NJ; and two grandsons, James M. Sheehan of Arlington, VA., and Christopher Sheehan of Mendham, NJ. Services will be held at St. Joseph's Shrine, Stirling, New Jersey, Saturday, December 27, at 1:30 PM. Memorial gifts may be made to the American Heart Association, 2550 Route 1, North Brunswick, New Jersey 08902.

title: William Smalley, 74, Linguist for the Hmong
description: William A. He was 74 and lived in Hamden, Conn.

title: 1. Ring Up the Club. 2. Ring Out the Old. 3. Ring In the New.; Rock and Pop
description: For club owners, Christmas really comes on New Year's Eve. That's when bars are packed, seats are full and would-be revelers still clamor at the door. All of those clubgoers are intent on starting the year with music they love in a crowd of fellow fans. Whether they're fond of rockabilly or hip-hop, swing or salsa or electronica, they can find what they're looking for in Manhattan on New Year's Eve. Places that regularly present live music call on their favorite acts, and many places that don't still find room to set up musicians and sound systems. Obeying the law of supply and demand, prices go up -- way up -- on New Year's Eve, though most clubs offer little extras like party hats or a glass of champagne at midnight. For New Year's Eve, it's smart to make reservations or buy advance tickets; clubs do fill up, and some events (like Phish's annual show at Madison Square Garden) are already sold out. Below, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times preview the live music taking place on New Year's Eve. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Nice Matin is controlled by two families and its employees. Its shares are not publicly traded.

title: Drug Cases Are Upended By the Police In Chicago
description: In this city famous for regarding the law as a dare, the hustle can reach the level of art form. Now comes a Chicago-style way for suspects to beat the rap: get hooked by police officers who may not be so pure themselves.

title: Shots From Hunters Hit 3 Ocean County Houses
description: At least three homes near wooded sections of Berkeley and Manchester Townships in Ocean County were hit by stray bullets during the weeklong deer-hunting season in early December, causing concern among public officials.

title: A New Barbie in Puerto Rico Divides Island and Mainland
description: Krista Aponte has 40 dolls in her Barbie collection, but her grandmother gave her a special Barbie on Thursday. She has long, wavy brown hair and coffee-colored eyes, wears a white cotton dress with lace ruffles and pink ribbon, and her box says in English and Spanish, ''Hola, I live in Puerto Rico, a beautiful place often called the island of enchantment.''

description: From 1961 to 1974, the Central Intelligence Agency, carrying out the foreign policy of the United States, enlisted the mountain tribes of Laos as guerrillas in the Vietnam War.

title: McGwire Wears His Heart on 19-Inch Biceps
description: Mark McGwire enjoyed an idyllic childhood in Claremont, Calif., running, jumping, playing baseball while protected in the loving cocoon of his family.

title: Finance Minister Says Japan's Crisis Is Over
description: Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka declared Japan's financial crisis over yesterday, and investors responded by pushing the key stock index to its second-lowest close of the year. The benchmark Nikkei average of 225 issues fell 497.50 points, or 3.25 percent, to 14,802.60, led by banks and exporters. That is just three points more than its lowest close for the year, which was set on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JAMES G. SR.
description: KENNEDY-James G. Sr. At home on December 24, 1997. James G. Kennedy Sr., Chairman of the Board of James G. Kennedy & Co., Inc., began his career as a plasterer for the old Davis, Brown Company. He was born in Manhattan's Harlem and attended Townsend Harris High School. ''Back then, it was a high school for City College,'' he recalled. Mr. Kennedy completed an accelerted threeyear program at Townsend and then took courses at the Mechanical Institute, New York City. After several years as a plasterer, James Gerard Kennedy founded James G. Kennedy & Co., Inc. in 1935. After serving his country as a highly-decorated World War II veteran with the Army Corps of Engineers, his first significant project involved a major renovation for Bankers Trust company at 14 Wall Street. The Kennedy Company has since done multiple major renovations for the same client for over 60 years. A landmark project in the company's history was actually made into a motion picture by the New York Telephone Company. The film was titled ''The Miracle of Second Avenue.'' It told the story of how ''Ma Bells'' main switching center, devastated by fire, was restored to 100% working order in record time-with the help of James G. Kennedy & Co., Inc. under the leadership of its President, James G. Kennedy, Sr. Mr. Kennedy's career has been marked by ongoing involvement in industry, civic and religious activities. He has served as the President of The Building Contractors Association (''BCA'') of the City of New York, and has been a Committee Member and a member of the Board of Directors of the BCA. Mr. Kennedy also helped to maintain the integrity of the famous Heisman Trophy when he served as a Governor of the Downtown Athletic Club (home of the Heisman Trophy) in New York City. As Chairman of the Executive Council of the American Irish Historical Society, he was responsible for the reconstruction of the entire Fifth Avenue headquarters of the Society. Mr. Kennedy has been honored by The American Jewish Committee as ''Man Of The Year,'' and in 1989 he was honored by The Dominican Academy as ''A Catholic Gentleman'' for his generosity in constructing the James G. Kennedy Science Center at the school. Mr. Kennedy is also a Knight of Malta. Mr. Kennedy married the former Rita Masset in Manhattan's St. Partrick's Cathedral. They will celebrate their 50th wedding anniversary next year. Mr. Kennedy is survived by his wife Rita, son James G. Kennedy Jr. Funeral Mass today 10 AM at Sts. John and Paul Church in Larchmont, NY. For information please call the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. (914) 834-0144.

title: Mexico Charges 16 in Killing of 45 Villagers
description: The Mexican authorities announced tonight that they had charged 16 men with first-degree murder in the killing of 45 people in a tiny village in southern Mexico.

description: Margaret Thorsborne cannot forget the two stone-curlews -- their necks outstretched, their wings beating above the pitiless crunch of steel treads -- trying to chase away the bulldozer on the development site along the southern edges of town.

title: New Law Extends Power Of State Securities Unit
description: The first major revision of New Jersey's securities laws since 1986 was signed into law on Wednesday. The measure broadens the enforcement powers of the New Jersey Bureau of Securities and brings state statutes into line with Federal laws enacted last year.

title: Princeton Prevails After A Big Scare
description: Bill Carmody, the Princeton coach, did not hide his feelings.

title: Blaze Erupts in Bronx; 30 Treated for Smoke
description: As many as 30 people were treated for smoke inhalation and one firefighter suffered minor injuries after a fire erupted in 42-story apartment building in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx last night, fire officials said.

title: Consumer Chief Lambastes Circuit City Return Policy
description: Circuit City, a national electronics chain that has been expanding rapidly in New York City and its suburbs, said that it was assessing a 15 percent penalty on products returned to the store after being opened.

title: Journal; Soak the Rich
description: ''Did people really give each other the finger in 1912?'' asked a skeptical teen-age film critic as we emerged, highly satisfied customers, from ''Titanic.'' Well, in truth, that gesture was hardly the only deviation from historical verisimilitude in Hollywood's $200 million re-creation of the century's most beloved spectacle of mass death. My favorite was a painting in a stateroom that looked much like Picasso's ''Les Demoiselles d'Avignon.'' If it indeed went down with the ship, then the picture at the Museum of Modern Art is the curatorial hoax of the century.

title: 12 Years Of Farewells
description: Eight days ago I left my job as director of the world's first AIDS hot line, after 12 years. Because AIDS killed more than 100 of the staff members and volunteers I worked with, I retired as the longest-serving employee in the history of Gay Men's Health Crisis. Sorting through those years is, needless to say, a bittersweet exercise.

title: As Asia Teeters, IMF's Critics Call for New Battle Plans
description: BANGKOK  Despite an agreement to accelerate $10 billion in aid to South Korea, economists warn that economic conditions in Asia have deteriorated so steeply that radical new policies may be needed to pull the region from beneath its mountain of debt.

description: ROSE-William B. Age 72. Of Mahwah, died Thursday, December 25, 1997, at his residence. Born in Staten Island, he lived in Franklin Lakes before moving to Mahwah eleven years ago. Mr. Rose was the Director of Distribution and Traffic for Witco Chemical Corp of Greenwich, Connecticut before his retirement in 1990. He was a World War II Navy Veteran. He was a member and past President of the Traffic Club of New York, and a member of the National Defense Executive Reserve, U.S. Department of Transportation. Member of Grace United Methodist Church, Wyckoff. Surviving are his wife, Elizabeth, nee Longair, one son, William B. Jr. of Martinsville, New Jersey, two daughters, Barbara Rose Anderson of Chevy Chase, Maryland and Beth Anne Coolidge of North Andover, Massachusetts, four grandchildren. title: Company Briefs
description: EYEMAKERS INC., Dallas, said it would acquire 29/49 Optical Inc., a retail optical chain based in Holiday, Fla., for an undisclosed amount of cash and convertible preferred stock.

title: Legal Experts' Group Says China Is Clamping Down on Tibetans
description: An independent group of legal experts says the rights of Tibetans have deteriorated sharply in the last three years.

title: CLAYTON, DUBILIER SELLING STAKE IN UNIT
description: Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc. plans to sell a minority stake in its electrical equipment distribution business for about $300 million, four years after buying it from the CBS Corporation for $340 million. The CDW Holding Corporation, parent company of the business formerly called Westinghouse Electric Supply, or Wesco, filed Wednesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering in which Clayton, Dubilier will be the only seller of shares. Clayton, Dubilier, a New York-based buyout firm, did not disclose exactly how much of CDW it will offer, although the filing said it ''will retain the power to control the company's corporate policies.'' The company is now the No. 2 electrical equipment distributor in the United States with a 4 percent market share, behind Graybar Electric Company's market share of just under 5 percent.

title: Arafat Is Making an Offer That Netanyahu Can Refuse
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, has announced that he will present his own ''comprehensive plan'' to save the peace with Israel when he meets with President Clinton next month, including a proposal to station international peacekeeping troops between Israel and the West Bank.

title: Avian Flu Transmitted To Doctor, Officials Say
description: Health workers reported yesterday the first evidence of probable human-to-human transmission of a new viral strain of influenza in Hong Kong, but said it was not necessarily a harbinger of a lethal epidemic.

title: When Poetry Means Much More Than Lovely Rhyme
description: The urban Muse was on the move the other night: 15 ''slam poets'' -- competitive-minded junior high school versifiers -- journeyed here on Dec. 16 from East of the River, the threadbare cusp of the city, to have it out in a mainline bookstore five blocks from the White House.

title: KOOR OF ISRAEL SELLING ITS EDIBLE OIL HOLDING
description: Koor Industries Ltd. of Israel has agreed to sell its 72 percent stake in Shemen Industries Ltd., an edible oil manufacturer, to a group of investors for $24.8 million. The sale, announced on Thursday and expected to close on Monday, reflects Koor's strategy to shed holdings outside its main businesses of electronics, telecommunications, agrochemicals and building materials. Koor, based in Tel Aviv, will record a capital gain of 32 million shekels, or $9 million, from the sale in the fourth quarter. Shemen, based in Haifa, manufactures cosmetics, oil, soaps and detergents.

title: IVAX AND NAPRO CANCER DRUG APPROVAL UNCERTAIN
description: The Ivax Corporation and Napro Biotherapeutics Inc. said yesterday that they might not win final United States regulatory approval of their Paxene cancer drug until 2004 because of exclusive marketing rights granted to the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company for its version of the same drug. After the market closed, Ivax, which is based in Miami, and Napro said the Food and Drug Administration granted a tentative approval for their version of Bristol-Myers' Taxol drug to treat the AIDS-related skin cancer Kaposi's sarcoma. Because Bristol-Myers won a period of marketing exclusivity for Taxol, though, final approval may not be granted until Aug. 4, 2004, the companies said.

title: Cafe des Artistes Owner to Pay Staff During Renovation
description: George Lang, the owner of the Cafe des Artistes, the landmark restaurant off Central Park West that was closed by fire on Tuesday, gathered his apprehensive employees yesterday afternoon and assured them they would be paid their usual salaries until the restaurant could reopen, he hoped by February.

title: Students at Carnegie Hall (After Practice, of Course)
description: The annual winter migration of gifted student string players to Carnegie Hall produces a phenomenon known as the New York String Orchestra, when young musicians chosen from across the country come together for 11 days of coaching and performing in two concerts. Of these, the first took place on Christmas Eve, conducted by Jaime Laredo, who is a member of the distinguished team of musicians passing on their expertise. He was evidently eager to show off how much he and his players had achieved in their short time together, and there were invigorating moments in their hour of music by Bach, Handel, Mozart and Tchaikovsky.

title: Wrong Turn on City Traffic?
description: Strolling past Rockefeller Center on the day after Christmas delivers a walloping reminder about New York City. More people want to be there than the laws of time and space permit. Workers who did not qualify for a long weekend vied for control of the sidewalks with gawkers admiring the fabled Christmas tree, tourists determined to take each other's pictures in the center of the pedestrian traffic flow, a man playing ''Jingle Bells'' on a flute for spare change, and skateboarders trying to execute a curbside flip. Except for the skateboarders, whom we would sacrifice in a second, who is to say which claims for turf have the top priority?

title: How Does Music Turn the Century?; Schoenberg Could One Day Sound as Remote as Gregorian Chant
description: For timeliness combined with venerability, few anniversaries in the new year can top the 900th birthday of the German nun and mystic Hildegard of Bingen. In the last few years Hildegard's music, writings and nostrums have ridden a crest of worldwide popularity that even such a visionary as she could scarcely have imagined, let alone desired. For the music world especially, this sudden leap into antiquity, part of a larger boom in medieval chant, lends an unexpected piquancy to the approach of the new millennium.

title: LET IT SNOW
description: * Avalanches killed 35 people in North America last season; usually, back-country skiers, snowboarders and, increasingly, snowmobilers are the victims. * Forget about getting out of harm's way, even on a snowmobile. Avalanches have been clocked at up to 200 miles per hour.* In 1975 in Bird Creek, Alaska, an avalanche flattened a Ford Econoline van; the van's remains were no thicker than four inches in most places. * Ski patrollers often use World War II or Korean War-era ordnance to touch off pre-emptive avalanches. * The Department of Transportation in Washington State has its own tank, complete with loud cannon. * In 1996, Tom Abell of Kodiak, Alaska, returned to the spot where he and a friend (who died) were buried by snow the year before. Abell got buried again, and survived. ''The second time was a real heart-beater,'' he says.

title: CLINTON TO SEEK ADDITIONAL MONEY FOR FOOD SAFETY
description: The Clinton Administration, responding to public alarm over the safety of meat and produce, will propose a significant increase in spending for food inspection and safety research in the budget to be presented to Congress early next year, Administration officials have said.

title: To Hell and Back
description: 'I am now very far from home,'' Aziz wrote in French on a piece of notebook paper on a plane from Dakar, Senegal, to New York. ''The people around me are probably going to a luxury room in a four- or five-star hotel. The question in my head is where am I going? Why am I here? How do I talk to people?'' This letter was the first of more than 60 that Aziz has written since leaving his country -- to his family, to dead or vanished friends, to himself. He knew that, like all the others, it would never be sent.

title: Happy Highlights From a Well-Traveled Palate: Another Year of Dining Out
description: IN my life, in which eating plays such a large role, the highlights of the year are hard to distinguish from the eating highlights. In either case, the peak was the dinner I ate at Dennis Foy's in Bay Head with my daughter, who entered on skates. Probably no other restaurant in New Jersey with such a liberal dress code serves as splendid a tian, or small cake of fresh crab meat. Unfortunately, Mr. Foy's open-air paradise operates only from Memorial Day to Labor Day, but it's something to think about in drearier seasons.

title: Cover to Cover

title: Food; Comfort And Joy
description: When he came to manhattan in 1986, Jean-Georges Vongerichten didn't seem like just another French hotel chef. Granted, he was working at the Lafayette restaurant in the Drake Swissotel. And granted, he was from Alsace. But Vongerichten's reliance on herb-infused oils instead of butter and cream, his use of Asian techniques and bossy flavors like ginger and lemongrass were not just anathema to La Grande Cuisine, they were blasphemy!

title: The Seinfeldian Universe
description: America, for better or worse, is a place where a television sitcom can become a cultural and commercial bench mark. ''Seinfeld'' managed to reach that status in a nine-year run, often atop the prime-time ratings. As the idiosyncratic show heads toward sunset, its improbable success says something about the state of entertainment in America.

title: What Does The Koran Say About Nasreen's Nose Ring?
description: Although you used the name of my late husband, Jim Morrison, as a shorthand cultural reference, you neglected to mention, in the article by Geraldine Brooks (''What Does the Koran Say About Nasreen's Nose Ring?'') or anywhere else in your issue, the most ancient faith in which he and I were married and which we both ardently espoused. I refer to paganism, also known as witchcraft or wicca. Today, the Craft (the pre-Christian religion of Celtic Europe) is enjoying a resurgence.

title: Writing, Drawing and the Links Between Them
description: PREHISTORIC cave art may have been free of writing, but at least since the development of hieroglyphics, words and images have always gone together. The bond is especially strong in prints, the most efficient artistic medium for sending messages. At the Zimmerli Art Museum on the Rutgers University campus here, a 35-work print exhibition titled ''Word and Image/Word as Image'' sums up notable contemporary developments in this vital relationship.

description: SAIGON, as most of the 5 million people who live here still call this place, was supposed to become Hanoi after the Vietnamese Communists won the war in 1975. Instead, Hanoi has become Saigon.

title: The Broncos Finally Exorcise a Playoff Demon by Defeating the Jaguars

If they played well for 60 minutes, they told themselves, they could not be touched.

title: Everybody Dance!
description: CARIOCAS, the people who live in Rio de Janeiro, celebrate New Year's Eve with a party that's also a ritual. Dressed in white, they gather on the beaches with offerings to Yemanja, the African-Brazilian deity of the sea. Naturally, there's music: sacred rhythms for devotees and dancers. The beach becomes both temple and dance hall, a club open to all. But through the year, Rio de Janeiro is bursting with music that's an intoxicating tangle of traditions and modernity. Endless recombinations of Indian, African, Portuguese, Caribbean and North American influences have made Brazil a fountainhead of music that is sophisticated and exuberant, subtle and overwhelming.

title: Brooklyn Could Have Been A Contender
description: It is a little late to be running a correction, but The New York Times owes one to the people who gathered at Brooklyn's City Hall on New Year's Eve 100 years ago. They met on that miserably cold, rainy night for an ''observance'' -- they specifically refused to call it a celebration -- of their city's merger with New York at midnight. Brooklyn's Mayor got a long round of applause for his efforts to prevent New York City, which then consisted of just Manhattan and the southwestern Bronx, from annexing its neighbors to create the boroughs of Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island. The evening's featured speaker was another leader of the resistance, St. Clair McKelway, the editor of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle. Sharing Manhattan's tax revenues appealed to many Brooklynites (enough, at least, to vote for the merger), but McElway feared his industrious city would be corrupted by marrying for money.

title: The World; Turks Reinvent Their World

This little-noticed, 3,300-page, $1 million report was designed to assess threats that the world may face in the next millennium. The Air Force invited hundreds of its cadets and students to contribute, alongside futuristic bigwigs like Edward Teller and the creators of ''Terminatorand ''Robocop.'' title: The Shadows Winter Brings
description: The high ground in Columbia County has been covered with snow since mid-November. Every cold night the snow tenses, and every warm day it relaxes, sponging moisture into the still-unfrozen soil. In a pasture on one small farm, the horses have strewn a green carpet of hay underfoot, and a pair of crows feed at its edge. The snow has buried nearly everything in that pasture, but what it hasn't buried it has thrown into silhouette, denuding it of color. The tops of the tallest grasses and weeds protrude from the whiteness, their shapes revealed with peculiar clarity. On sharp days when there has been light wind and a new inch or two, the weed stems cut a V in the snow. When the wind has been especially strong, the weed tops leave a distinctive print, a brush mark, on the surface.

title: ART REVIEWS ; Elevation of the Everyday, as Glorified by Pop

What's often forgotten is the more radical gesture by which Pop artists turned art into something very much like an everyday, mass-produced object.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, CHARLES FRANCIS
description: ROBBINS-Charles Francis, C.F.A. of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, NJ, died in St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston, NJ, Thursday, Dec. 18, 1997. He was 76 years old. Mr. Robbins was the great-grandson of A.G. Spalding, baseball pitcher and founder of the athletic goods company, and son of Charles Francis Robbins, Chairman of A.G. Spalding Brothers. He was born in East Orange and was a lifelong resident of Llewellyn Park, West Orange. Mr. Robbins was Senior Vice President of I.B.J. Schroder Bank & Trust Company, New York, NY until he retired in 1990. Prior to that he was for 30 years a Vice President at the Marine Midland Bank in New York, NY and in the Trust Department of the Grace National Bank. He was goalie and captain of the hockey team at The Hotchkiss School in 1940. He graduated in the Class of 1944 at Yale University where he was an undergraduate member of Elihu, captain of the hockey team and majored in history. He served in the Marine Corps in World War II, was a Trustee of Llewellyn Park, The Metropolitan Y.M.C.A. of the Oranges, an Elder of the First Presbyterian Church in Orange (NJ), Honorary member of Orange Lawn Tennis Club and a member of Rock Spring Golf Club. Mr. Robbins was President of the Orange Orphan Society from 1987-1997, and directed the M.E.N.D. Pantry, giving thousands of bags of groceries to the needy. He was a trustee of The Morristown-Baird School from 1959-1970, and for thirty years a Director of World Impact, Newark. Mr. Robbins was a longtime Public Member of The New Jersey Insurance Underwriters Association in Newark. He was the husband of Margaret MacIlvaine Robbins, father of Reta Robbins (Schacht) M.D., Rev. Charles F. Robbins, Virginia Robbins (Lennan) M.B.A., Keith Spalding Robbins, M.S., M.S., Thomas Scott Robbins, C.F.P., Ch.F.C., brother of William Brown Robbins and Walter Spalding Robbins, and survived by nine grandchildren. Memorial Service in The First Presbyterian Church of Orange, Main Street at Scotland Road, Orange, NJ (973) 678-1719 on Saturday, January 10, 1998 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Metropolitan Y.M.C.A. of the Oranges, 23 Babcock Place, West Orange, NJ 07052 would be appreciated. The Farmer Funeral Home, Roseland, NJ.

title: CODE HAPPY
description: To most Manhattanites, the introduction next year of a new area code (646) is an unavoidable pain. To Linc Madison, an area-code buff based in San Francisco, new digits are a source of endless pleasure. Madison, a 34-year-old telecommunications consultant, displays on a Web site his encyclopedic knowledge of codes and their 50-year history. He also likes to play trivia games like, say, calculating the number of code zones you would drive through on imaginary trips from Fredericksburg, Va., to Salem, Mass. ''If you made that trip in 1947, you would go through 11 area codes. If you do it today, you're up to 26,'' he says authoritatively. Madison admits that this is an acquired taste. How does it go over around the family table at holiday time? ''My father is interested somewhat,'' he says. ''But my brother is bored silly.''

''He knows everybody in L.A.,'' says Brett Wagner, a former doorman at the popular nightspot Jones Hollywood and a part-time actor. title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Something Like Hell
description: When Chaim Skibelski is shot dead and tossed into a pit along with all the other Jewish citizens of a small town in wartime Poland, his trials are only beginning. Scrambling up from this mass grave, the spectral Chaim wanders the countryside (at times guided by his murdered rabbi, who has turned into a crow), his afterlife a remarkable journey of discovery that leads a long way from a peaceful, nurturing eternity. At first harrowing, Joseph Skibell's debut novel, A BLESSING ON THE MOON (Algonquin, $21.95), proceeds to startle and challenge as it refuses to exploit the ready pathos of the Holocaust, testing its hero's endurance and the reader's expectations. Chaim's journey illuminates the horror of history through the energy and wisdom of fantasy and myth; scene after scene is rich with emotion, humor and invention. Daring in its haunting, often painful honesty, dense in thoughtful observation and unsparing incident, the novel aims for literary status while at the same time proving itself an unlikely page-turner. An act of commemoration (as many as 18 members of the author's family perished in the Holocaust), ''A Blessing on the Moon'' is also a confirmation that no subject lies beyond the grasp of a gifted, committed imagination. Patrick Giles

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCH, JERRY
description: MARCH-Jerry. 68. Professor Emeritus. Jerry March, a recently retired professor of Organic Chemistry at Adelphi University in Garden City, died December 25, 1997 of pancreatic cancer. Dr. March was born on August 1, 1929 in Brooklyn, NY. He received a B.S. from City College in 1951, a Master's Degree from Brooklyn College in 1953, and a Ph.D. from Penn State University in 1956. Dr. March taught at Adelphi University for 41 years. His seminal reference-Advanced Organic Chemistry-is known worldwide and has been a mainstay among chemists for 30 years. He co-authored several other texts on chemistry as well as contributing to The Encyclopedia Britannica. For several years he was asked to participate in the nomination of Nobel Prize Laureates. He had a life-long love of music and opera and participated in many amateur theater and singing groups. For the past decade, he volunteered time to Recording for the Blind. He is survived by his wife, Beverly, of Garden City, NY; children, Gale Ackerman, David March and June Price; grandchildren, Justin, Jennifer and Jessica Ackerman, Nancy Hutchins, Rachel, Nathan and Ben Price; and brother Fred March. He ultimately wanted to be known as a teacher-a profession to which he dedicated his life. Memorial service to be held at Adelphi University in Garden City, NY is being planned for January.

title: Development Plan Should Stay Residential
description: It was a shock to read how such a community-spirited person as Long Island's Jim Tsunis can be associated with this Johnny-come-lately Economic Redevelopment Committee, which proposes nothing less than pushing aside the most successful joint effort in community development this state has seen in years [''Plan for Ex-Mental Health Complex,'' Dec. 7]. This committee's proposal is clearly an 11th-hour developers' Christmas wish. The residents of Melville and Dix Hills surrounding this 460 acres in the middle of an official state Special Groundwater Protection Area strongly oppose commercial development at his site. After working for two years with state and Huntington Town officials, at the cost of $500,000, an impressive plan to build senior citizen and single family residences is ready to receive bids to implement it. Huntington's showcase of commercial development is on the impressive Route 110 corridor, not in the middle of a residential neighborhood. And new residences are much more certain to generate taxes at this site than any commercial property will, at least judging by the tax and power subsidies the state was prepared to offer in connection with the infamous ''Olympus project.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Art's Greatest Hits
description: ''One early morning of an exceptionally beautiful day, I got the idea of retracing every step of my life as an art expert -- from 1951 -- and writing down the works of art that had bowled me over visually and emotionally,'' Thomas Hoving writes in GREATEST WORKS OF ART OF WESTERN CIVILIZATION (Artisan, $50). From 1967 to 1977 Hoving was the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he was noted for his blockbuster exhibitions; another kind of blockbuster mentality -- that of hyperbole -- marks this book. While some of his choices are obvious and unavoidable -- like Michelangelo's ''David'' and Picasso's ''Demoiselles d'Avignon'' -- there are surprises like works by Fragonard, George Bellows and Balthus, and a little-known Jay DeFeo painting, ''The Rose,'' which Hoving calls ''one of the most expressive statements in the entire last third of the 20th century.'' Another surprising inclusion is Gainsborough's ''Blue Boy''; but when Hoving says ''that impossibly blue costume'' may be ''perhaps the most invigorating passage of paint in all of the 18th century,'' many readers will be persuaded. In the end, Hoving's erudition and enthusiasm make his book fascinating; he has the ability to make the reader see what he sees. Robin Lippincott

title: Men of Yore in Black
description: This may come as a shock to some New Yorkers, but black was chic before there was a SoHo. Baldassare Castiglione, an Italian soldier, diplomat and author, decreed it so in the Renaissance. In his 1528 book ''Libro del Cortegiano'' (''The Courtier''), Castiglione described the ideal courtier. The book, considered the bible of ducal and royal courts, became famous and was much translated (excerpt above from Sir Thomas Hoby's 1561 English version). The courtier, Castiglione declared, was modest, well spoken and wise. He spoke Italian, French and Spanish, and never lied, gossiped or flattered others foolishly. He was a warrior on foot and horseback. He sang, danced and painted. And he wore black. Now, if those modern-day courtiers who have adopted the wardrobe could just bone up on the part about gossip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, HENRY BEDINGER
description: MITCHELL-Henry Bedinger. Died Sunday, December 21, 1997, in Houston. Born in Glens Falls, NY, on September 7, 1916, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John F.B. Mitchell of New York. He graduated from Princeton University in 1937 and Harvard Law School in 1940. Mr. Mitchell was a veteran of World War II serving in the United States Army. Between the years of 1950 and 1951, Mr. Mitchell worked in Turkey as part of the Marshall Plan, then joining the Cleary, Gottlieb law firm in Washington, DC until 1955. At that time Mr. Mitchell joined Standard Vacuum Oil, later to be known as ESSO Eastern, Inc., now EXXON, until his retirement in 1981, when he held the position of Senior Counsel. After his retirement, he pursued his interests as an avid landscape photographer, birdwatcher, and Italian traveler. Mr. Mitchell is survived by his loving wife of 37 years, Diana and their son, Jamie, along with his other sons, Henry, Paul and Edward; daughter, Francesca and one granddaughter, Christine; brother, John F.B. Mitchell of Stonington, CT; sister, Mary McClintock of New York and Salisbury, CT. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM on Monday, December 29, 1997, at Palmer Memorial Episcopal Church, 6621 Main St., with the Rev. James Nutter officiating. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGHANI, MOOSA
description: HAGHANI-Moosa. Adored father and grandfather, brother, uncle, true friend to many, creative entrepreneur and lion-heart, passed away on the morning of December 26, in London, with his family by his side. He was 84. Born in Teheran, he graduated valedictorian from the American College and began his long and many faceted business career with the Anglo Iranian Oil Company. He made his way to NYC on a long and adventure-filled journey aboard a Dutch trading ship in 1940-41, in the thick of WW II's Pacific Theater. He was amongst the original handful of Iranian immigrants to arrive in NYC and he quickly established various trading and manufacturing businesses during and after the war. He was responsible for bringning his large extended family to America, and was called upon to act as mentor and guardian to hundreds of young students sent to the United States by his friends and family in Teheran. His business later involved bringing many large multi-national corporations to Iran, which helped the country's rapid economic development in the 1960's and '70's. He eventually returned to live in Iran in 1976, and was very proud of the improvement in the standard of living that the country experienced since he left. He then left Iran again during its Revolution and thereafter spent his time between London and NYC. He was a founder of the Iranian Jewish Center in London and a prominent figure in the Iranian Jewish community around the world. He was known to go to extraordinary lengths to help those in need and this won him a special place in the hearts of many. His inherited love of Persian poetry propelled him through life at difficult times, and gave him a fount of wisdom he shared with us all. He lived a full and eventful life. He did much good in his life. He will be deeply and forever missed by his family and friends. He is survived by his daughter Monica, his son Victor, six grandchildren, three sisters and his brother, who all loved him greatly. His funeral will be Tuesday morning at 9 AM, at the Riverside Chapel in Great Neck, and there will be a commemorative ceremony at 4 PM, on Sunday, January 4, at the Park East Synagogue in NYC.

title: The Exception That Proves The Rule of the 6-Card Suit

Not only did South play in four hearts after East had made a weak jump overcall in that suit, but he emerged with an overtrick and prevented East from making a single heart trick.

Recalling how she was cast in the new film ''Titanic'' as the spirited 101-year-old survivor of the disaster, she said the director, James Cameron, had been searching for an actress of the 1930's who was -- she laughed -- ''still viable, not alcoholic, rheumatic or falling down.'' Ms. Stuart was determined to get the part, she said, and when the casting director asked if she would read for Mr. Cameron without makeup, she was tempted to reply, ''I'll read for him without clothes!''

The moves will result in a fourth-quarter charge of about $22.8 million, or 17 cents a share. Shaw, of Dalton, Ga., gets about 75 percent of its revenue from selling carpets to other retailers. It was expected to earn 17 cents a share before gains and charges, according to a survey by I.B.E.S. International.

Ametek said Rotron's 1997 sales were expected to rise about 9 percent from 1996, to around $70 million. Ametek, based in Paoli, Pa., makes electrical and electronic components. EG&G, of Wellesley, Mass., which provides electronic systems, components and services, said the sale would allow it to focus on larger business units. title: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL TO SELL 3 UNITS AND TAKE CHARGES

Great Lakes, a specialty chemicals company in West Lafayette, Ind., said yesterday that it would sell its furfural business; Chemol, its Budapest-based distribution unit, and its environmental services division. The sales will result in a fourth-quarter charge of about $96 million, or $1.60 a share. The company will also take a charge of about $55 million to write down assets, close plants and settle pending litigation. Its shares rose $1.5625 yesterday, to $43.625.

title: When a Novel Flu Is Involved, Health Officials Get Jumpy

And virologists around the world have been burning the midnight oil for several weeks, studying the strain and attempting to make a vaccine for it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDRICH, DUANE C.
description: ALDRICH-Duane C., 54. A nationally respected lawyer in the field of labor and management relations and a leading member of the law firm, Kilpatrick Stockton LLP died on December 27, 1997, in Atlanta, after a brief illness. A partner in the Kilpatrick & Cody law firm since 1973, Mr. Aldrich had begun his practice there upon graduation from law school in 1968. Mr. Aldrich had chaired the firm's Labor Section for more than 20 years, expanding its practice throughout the United States. He was known for his insight into the most difficult and challenging issues of federal labor and employment laws. At the time of his death, he was also a member of Kilpatrick Stockton's Executive Committee. Mr. Aldrich was born on March 10, 1943 at Fort Bragg, NC, grew up in Wellsley, MA and graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy in 1961, from Harvard College in 1965 (AB magnum cum laude) and from the Harvard Law School in 1968 (LLB). At the time of his death, he was serving on the American Bar Association Committee for Practice and Procedure under the National Labor Relations Act, and its Committee for Equal Employment Opportunity Law. He had authored numerous articles published in professional journals, had spoken at numerous seminars on labor relations and had served as program director for the Southeastern Labor Law Institute. He was a member of The Capital City Club, and The Harvard Club, and was active in the Exeter Alumni Association. His law partners describe him as an exceptional lawyer, a scholar, a pragmatist, a people's person, and a leader with a strong hand and a deep reservoir of warmth and kindness. Business leaders, professional colleagues, friends and family members turned to him for assistance in dealing with crises of all kinds. He was trusted and he was loved by family and friends. Surviving are his wife Rebecca Day Aldrich, three daughters, Jessamine Shaw Aldrich of Santa Monica, CA, Abigail Suzanne Aldrich and Elizabeth Peyton Aldrich, both of Atlanta, his mother Mrs. Elizabeth Cannon Aldrich of Cambridge, MA and eight siblings: Peter C. Aldrich of Cambridge, MA, Mrs. Elizabeth Aldrich Kaspar of Provence, France and Geneva, Switzerland, John C. Aldrich of Winchester, MA, Mrs. Ann Aldrich Hechtman of Dallas, TX., Stephen C. Aldrich of Arlington, MA., Mrs. Amy Aldrich Geogan of Norwell, MA, Mark C. Aldrich of Carlisle, PA and San Sebastian, Spain and Mrs. Sarah Aldrich Murray of Deerfield, MA. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, December 30, 1997 at 2:00 p.m. at The Cathedral of Christ the King, in Atlanta, Georgia. The interment will be at Arlington Cemetery in Sandy Springs, GA. Friends may make donations to the Duane Aldrich Memorial Fund of The Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, New Hampshire.

He is survived by his wife, Marilyn F. (nee Wilson) of Linwood; one daughter, Nancy Fitzgerald of Northfield; one son, Christopher Francis Ryan of Brooklyn, New York; one sister, Barbara Haynes of Hilton Head, South Carolina and one granddaughter. description: KORIN-Samuel B. Died Sunday, December 28, 1997 in Boynton Beach, Fla. Born in New York on January 2, 1924 to the late Benjamin and Bella Korin. He graduated Magna Cum Laude from New York University in 1952 and Columbia University Graduate School of Business as a Samuel Bronfman Fellow in 1953. He was employed by IBM for 34 years from 1953 through 1987. In 1962 he represented the U.S. Department of Commerce as a Trade Mission member to the United Kingdom. The culmination of his varied career with IBM was his role as founding Director of IBM's Manufacturing Technology Institute, for which he received the U.S. Senate Productivity Award from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan in 1984. He focused on the relationship between industry and education serving on 6 University advisory boards, and Congressman Benjamin Gilman's Technology Advisory Committee. In 1987 he became Director of Polytechnic University's Graduate Center in Hawthorne, N.Y. As an activist, he was involved in the Young Zionists and the Ecology movement. He was an early ham radio enthusiast (W2GBO), a sailor, and loved to travel. He is survived by his beloved wife of 45 years, Esther and their children, Jonathan, Robert and Judy; grandchildren Lisa, Benjamin, Mike, Anne, Daniel, David and Michael; daughters-in-law Mary and Kathy; and sister Elaine. Memorial contributions may be made to the International Myeloma Foundation, 2120 Stanley Hills Drive, Los Angeles, Calif. 90046.
