title: Dubious Honors and Deserved Recognition for '97
description: MAY I have the virtual envelopes, please? On the assumption that no major new technology is likely to arrive in the last few hours of year-end revelry, we hereby present the Iffy Technology Awards for 1997. The Iffies get their name from the fact that, like almost everything else in personal computing, they are subject to revision, upgrade or obsolescence at any moment and are not guaranteed, even if you download all the latest drivers.

title: In an On-Line Salon, Scientists Sit Back and Ponder
description: AT his Web site, called Edge, John Brockman, a literary agent for many scientists and an author himself, tries to achieve what he calls ''electronic discourse at the highest level'' with people of ''the third culture'' -- scientists and other researchers who, he says, ''are taking the place of the traditional intellectual in rendering visible the deeper meaning of our lives, redefining who and what we are.''

title: Firefighters Pull a Woman, 91, From a Flame-Filled Apartment
description: With flames rapidly filling the room, firefighters saved a bedridden 91-year-old woman from a fire that broke out in her apartment early yesterday in the Bronx. They were not, however, able to save her 95-year-old husband.

title: A Different Denouement For Carroll This Time
description: With the good humor that has marked his roller-coaster tenure as a professional head football coach, Pete Carroll today recounted his own tale of two cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHTER, ROBERT ALAN
description: BUCHTER-Robert Alan. Died on December 21, 1997 after a brief illness. Mr. Buchter was a principal in the architectural firm of Knappe and Johnson of Garden City, New York since 1957 where he practiced until his death. Under his direction the firm designed numerous schools, churches and other public facilities. Mr. Buchter was born in New York City and attended Flushing High School and Cornell University. Before joining Knappe and Johnson in 1957, he practiced architecture in Pennsylvania and Connecticut. He served in the Navy, where he met his wife, Monie, who died in 1994. He is survived by his brother Ted of St. Augustine, Florida and sons, Jonathan of Cleveland Heights, Ohio and Eric of St. Petersburg, Florida. No services are planned.

title: Devils Strike Quickly to Support Brodeur
description: It was billed as the battle of the heavyweight goalies. It turned into a first-round knockout for Martin Brodeur as the Devils perforated the white-hot Dominik Hasek for three goals in the game's first 13 minutes tonight, then coolly made them stand for a 3-1 victory over the Buffalo Sabres before a crowd of 16,039 at the Marine Midland Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LOUIS H., ESQ.
description: LEVINE-Louis H., Esq. On December 28, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Goldie, dear father of Honey and Leonard Slavit, Morton and Susan Levine. Grandfather of Ira and Diana Slavit, David and Robin Slavit, Gail Slavit, Richard and Pattie Levine and Gary Levine. Great-Grandfather of Gillian, Michael, Danielle, Evan, Roni, Meredith, Taylor and Mallorie. Services on December 31 at 11:30AM, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, Hewlett, New York.

title: Grand Jury to Begin Hearings on Fatal Shooting of Brooklyn Man by Officer
description: A grand jury will begin hearing evidence on Monday in the the fatal shooting of an unarmed Brooklyn man, William J. Whitfield, by a police officer on Thursday.

title: AT LUNCH WITH -- Michelle Yeoh; Bond Meets His Match (No, Not Love Match)
description: Looking perfectly nonthreatening in a trim chalk-striped Ralph Lauren suit and Bulgari jewelry, Michelle Yeoh, Asia's best-known female kung fu star, looked up from her lobster Caesar salad (''light on the dressing, please'') and spoke in flawless English that was as precise as a well-executed fly kick.

title: LESSONS LEARNED: Welfare Reform's First Months -- A special report.; Success, and Frustration, as Welfare Rules Change
description: When, at last, President Clinton walked into the Rose Garden on Aug. 22, 1996, to ''end welfare as we know it,'' he brought many dramas to a close: six decades of anti-poverty policy; five years of ideological warfare; a standoff with Congress that had produced two vetoes, and a battle that had split his Cabinet and his party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBROFF, CHARLOTTE WEISMAN.
description: DUBROFF-Charlotte Weisman. One week short of 103. Cherished wife of the late Dr. Nathan Dubroff. Dear mother of Florence Shelley. Grandmother of Carolyn Shelley LeBel and William Shelley. Great-grandmother of Natasha and Melissa LeBel. A beacon to us all. To celebrate her life, a ceremony of remembrance at the Shelley home in New Rochelle, January 1, from 2 to 5.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Either it's on all the time and nobody pays attention to it, or maybe it comes on and nothing happens, and you say,'well, should I believe it or not.' ''

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELI WALLACH, who plays a curmudgeonly Jewish widower in ''Visiting Mr. Green'' at the Union Square Theater, will perform another role on his way to the show tonight. He will light the 9-foot-tall Hanukkah menorah put up at the north end of Union Square by the Lubavitch movement's Chabad of Union Square.

title: A Sure Hand in Navigating the Unfamiliar
description: It is axiomatic that pianists who specialize in new music need a technique big enough to negotiate dense rhythmic and harmonic thickets. But even more crucial, if less fully appreciated, is an imagination vivid enough to address both musical and commercial necessities. The purely musical concern, of course, is finding and conveying the immediately appealing qualities of music that is both difficult and unfamiliar. The commercial one, if that term can be applied to such a manifestly uncommercial line of work, has to do with finding a way to stand apart from the competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBO, GUSTAVO F, JR.
description: LOBO-Gustavo F, Jr. Of Orlando, Florida, formerly of New York City. On December 28, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Vera Hinchy Lobo. Loving father of Patricia Aitcheson. Also survived by four grandsons and one great granddaughter. Mr. Lobo was a former president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and a former chairman of Olavarria and Company of New York. Reposing at the Flynn Memorial Home, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, on Tuesday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday 11 A.M., at St Eugene's Church, Yonkers. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens.

title: On Curbing Pedestrians
description: To the Editor:

title: Guilty Plea in $445,000 Welfare Fraud
description: For more than seven years, Jose Rodriguez used at least eight different identities -- some borrowed from dead relatives, others taken from living people without their knowledge, and still others created by him -- to obtain hundreds of thousands of dollars in Government benefits to which he was not entitled, court papers show.

title: Birth of the Upside-Down Wood
description: Can a small, underfinanced golf-club manufacturer with a good product but no conventional distribution system, and no budget to advertise or promote its product, make money competing against the likes of the large companies? If the little guy is Adams Golf, the answer is yes. But can the mom-and-pop business make more than a few million bucks?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POOR, ARTHUR
description: POOR-Arthur. On our 50th wedding anniversary, I love you, Art Poor.

title: Knicks in Playing-Time Tug-of-War
description: Coach Jeff Van Gundy could treat his team like a simmering pot, stirring it up just because he's standing in front of the burner.

title: Dollar Moves Mostly Higher As Korea Worries Ease a Bit
description: The dollar rose against most currencies yesterday after United States stocks rallied on optimism that South Korea would avert financial collapse.

title: Mayor Opposes Bid By McCaughey Ross
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that it would not be a good idea for Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross to run against Gov. George E. Pataki in next year's gubernatorial election.

title: Sports of The Times; If the Knicks Had Reed, Who Knows?
description: WILLIS REED is behind the scenes these days, which is mighty difficult for a man his size and one who remains the most accomplished basketball name on either side of the Lincoln Tunnel. He is the Nets' senior vice president, a job that has as much to do with basketball as Al Gore's.

title: Too Few Teaching Jobs, or Too Many Ph.D.'s?; Early-Admissions Scam
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Flouts Court Order, U.S. Charges
description: The Justice Department accused Microsoft yesterday of ''disobedience'' and of ''jerry-rigging its own products'' in response to a Federal judge's order to allow the makers of personal computers to license Microsoft's Windows operating system without being forced to also load its Internet browsing software.

title: Bucs, and Lynch, Come to Hit, Hit, Hit
description: Playoff time reminds us how wonderful those 300-yard passers are. How splendid it is to see a 100-yard running back. How trick plays can swing a game. How a successful onside kick can change a season.

title: Town Stunned as Mayor's Private Pain Becomes Public
description: As far as bank robberies go, this one seemed disturbing enough, with a perpetrator wearing sunglasses and a black baseball cap, brazenly announcing to a teller: ''This is a holdup. I have a bomb on me.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Banks to Let South Korea Delay Loan Repayments

title: 3 Indonesian Bankers Told to Restrict Travel
description: Indonesian police imposed a travel ban on three former directors of Bank Indonesia accused of corruption involving an estimated 1.5 trillion rupiah ($280 million). ''They're not officially under arrest, but we're conducting an intensive investigation,'' said Hamami Nata, the head of the Jakarta police.

title: Novi Sad Journal; Cynics in Their 20's, Bred in the Balkan Inferno
description: Every age has its voice. The time before the wars that rent Yugoslavia was one of bombastic nationalistic cant. During the war came the strident calls for patriotism, blood and vengeance. In peace, those who provided the fodder for the conflict, already labeled ''the doomed generation,'' have begun to speak with a dark cynicism of the societies that sent them to battle.

title: Rallye Wins Control Over Food Retailer
description: Rallye S.A. won control of Casino Guichard-Perrachon S.A. yesterday after a rival, Promodes S.A., withdrew from a four-month battle for Casino, France's third-biggest publicly traded food retailer. Promodes first made an offer on Sept. 1. Promodes agreed to drop legal action aimed at blocking Rallye's bid of 23.6 billion francs ($3.9 billion) after Rallye agreed to let Promodes expand in foreign markets with Casino and jointly purchase nonfood products.

title: Van Horn Scores 32 And Leads Comeback
description: Keith Van Horn figures to enjoy many superb games like this. Games when he takes control. Games when he makes scoring look easy. Games when his team needs leadership, and he responds.

title: By Design; The Delicate Makeup Balance
description: New Year's Eve parties are the dressiest events on the calendar for many women, affording opportunities for all-out glamour.

title: On Curbing Pedestrians
description: To the Editor:

title: China to Set Up Secondary Boards
description: China's two exchanges will set up secondary boards for poorly performing listed stocks in an attempt to prevent them from dragging down the indexes. The share prices of the downgraded companies will also be restricted to daily swings of 5 percent, down from the normal 10 percent limit on listed companies, the official media reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILL, BRENDAN
description: GILL-Brendan. The Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sadness the passing of Brendan Gill, a great New Yorker and dear friend of the Whitney Museum. For fifteen years, Brendan served as a Trustee of the Museum, and during that time his energy, wit and wise counsel were essential to the Museum's life. An Honorary Trustee of the Whitney, Brendan was co-chair of the Museum's Library Fellows and an active member of the Whitney National Committee. Along with all who cherish the special qualities that distinguish New York and those who struggle to maintain the unique beauty of this city, we will miss Brendan's fierce intelligence and generous spirit. We extend our heartfelt sympathies and condolences to his loving and devoted wife Anne, to his children and grandchildren. Brendan will be deeply missed by all of us. New York has lost one of its treasures. Flora M. Biddle, Hon. Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Gilbert C. Maurer, President David A. Ross, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHT, NATHAN
description: LICHT-Nathan. Age 79. On December 27, 1997, at home, after a long illness. Born in NYC on June 24, 1918. Devoted husband of Helen (nee Applebaum), loving father of Jonathan and Nora Licht Sewall. Survived by brother Mike Licht and sister Rose Wolk. Business partner for many years with his brothers Mike, Lou, Harry and Murray, in Lane Realty, Forest Hills, New York. Once named by Newsday as one of the top fifty L.I. businessmen. Hardworking, generous and quiet, his actions spoke louder than words. Survived also by loving caretaker and friend, Burnus McKnight. Funeral was held Sunday. Gifts may be sent to the Alzheimer's Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, ARTHUR
description: MILLS-Arthur. The Board, Volunteers, and Friends of Early Stages deeply mourn the passing of our beloved Arthur Mills. Through Arthur's commitment to young people and to the performing arts, he created Early Stages as a program of the Mayor's Office. The program continues Arthur's dream to give opportunities for many thousands of children to experience live performances, often for the first time. Arthur's remarkable courage, fortitude and spirit will always be remembered and cherished. Our sincere sympathy to his family, colleagues and many friends. Early Stages

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column on Wednesday about setbacks to utilities misidentified the company whose proposed merger with the Northern States Power Company was called off earlier this year. It was the Wisconsin Energy Corporation, not Wisconsin Public Service.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Bomb Jury Hears Testimony In Sentencing Phase of Case
description: Jerry Flowers, an Oklahoma City policeman, crept into the darkened heart of the shattered Oklahoma City Federal Building and looked up at nine floors that had pancaked.

title: Japanese Stocks Surge
description: Stocks surged in a shortened session today. After a half- day of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 483.52 points, or 3.27 percent, at 15,528.74. On Monday, the Nikkei fell 27.38 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent. The market will close on Wednesday for New Year holidays and reopen on Monday.

title: D'Amato Attacks Schumer in Caustic Letter
description: In a taste of the fierce Senate campaign shaping up for next year, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has once again attacked one of his potential opponents, calling Representative Charles E. Schumer a ''stuffed-shirt liberal.'' He warned in a letter to supporters that ''the whole liberal bunch is going to gang up on me and see who can beat on Al D'Amato the hardest'' in the election.

title: Daneyko Is Making Progress
description: Ken Daneyko made it home for the holidays. His next step is to make it all the way back to his career with the Devils.

title: Young Set No Timetable For Leaving His Position
description: Giants General Manager George Young, who is expected to leave his post with the team to accept a high-ranking job in the front office of the National Football League, said yesterday that he had set no timetable for making his plans public.

title: California Delays Power Competition
description: The board of governors of the California Independent System Operator today unanimously approved a new target date of March 31 for electricity competition to start in the state.

title: Powell Gained From Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Manslaughter Charge In Death of a Teen-Ager
description: A Saddle Brook man was charged with manslaughter yesterday after he shot and killed a teen-ager and wounded two adults who had attacked him, believing he had raped a friend of theirs, prosecutors said.

title: Stocks Surge, Led by Banks; Dow Up 113
description: Stocks in the United States were buoyed yesterday by the news that leading commercial and investment banks were cooperating to avert a short-term financial crisis in South Korea.

title: Looking for an Opposition in Japan
description: Japan is in disarray politically and economically, lurching through a financial crisis as its Prime Minister plumbs new depths of unpopularity. So where is the main opposition party in the world's second largest economic power?

title: Rev. Albert Nevins, 82, Writer Who Spread Catholic Message
description: The Rev. Albert J. Nevins, the author of many books and documentaries for young people and adults, a past president of the Catholic Press Association and a founder of the Catholic Institute of the Press, died on Dec. 15 at St. Teresa's Residence in Maryknoll, N.Y. A Maryknoll priest for 55 years, he was 82 and lived in Tampa, Fla.

title: Home Resales Off Last Month After 3 Rises to Record Levels
description: Home resales fell two-tenths of 1 percent in November, breaking a string of three months in which they rose to records.

title: Microsoft and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: The Neediest Cases; A More Satisfying Form of Giving
description: Call it the tyranny of the holiday season: the tradition of gift-giving at Christmas and Hanukkah fills some people with more dread than joy. It can seem impossible to match each recipient with the perfect gift, and the resulting bills can inspire months of regret.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEIKLEJOHN, ROBERT PICKENS
description: MEIKLEJOHN-Robert Pickens, of Monroe Twp., N.J. on December 26, 1997. Formerly of Greenwich, CT. Ten years service with W. Averell Harriman in his successive capacities including U.S. Minister in charge of Lend Lease supplies for Great Britain, U.S. Ambassador to the Soviet Union and Secretary of Commerce of the United States. He was a participant in the Teheran, Yalta and Potsdam conferences and responsible for the official White House record of Teheran and Yalta. After years of diplomatic service he was a Vice President of Allied Chemical and Dye Corp., a division of General Dynamics. He is survived by his wife Madelaine Coletti Meiklejohn, a son Robert H. Meiklejohn of Fairfield, CT, a daughter Carol Ann Westervelt of Chester, N.J. He is predeceased by his daughter Blanche Alexander. He is also survived by five grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held 2 PM Saturday at the Lester Memorial Home, 16 West Church St., Jamesburg, N.J. Memorials may be sent to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, Columbia University, 710 West 168 St., New York, New York, 10032.

title: Cleaning Birds After Oil Spills Often Proves Futile
description: FEW things in nature are sadder to watch than the slow death of sea birds drenched in oil, and after each major spill countless bird lovers labor long and hard to clean and save as many avian victims as possible. But new studies show that such efforts are largely in vain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGELSON, DAVID
description: FOGELSON-David. The board & staff of The American Federation of Arts extend condolences to AFA trustee Ellen Liman on the death of her father, David Fogelson, whose philanthropic spirit lives on through the dedicated work of his family. Robert M. Meltzer, Chairman Jan Mayer, President Serena Rattazzi, Director

title: Pact Reached On Emissions Of Pollutants
description: After years of wrangling, New York State and electric power producers announced agreement today on how to cut emissions of major smog components to meet Federal clean air standards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREISBERG, BARRETT G.
description: KREISBERG-Barrett G. The Trustees of The Harkness Foundation for Dance mourn the untimely passing of our esteemed colleague Barry Kreisberg. Barry served the Foundation with distinction and dedication for twentyfive years. We extend our deepest sympathy to his loving wife Luisa who has been steadfast in her support of his Foundation activities, his son Joel, daughters-in-law and his cherished grandchildren. Theodore S. Bartwink Etta Brandman William A. Perlmuth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDMAN, HANNAH
description: SEIDMAN-Hannah. The Woodmere Club deeply regrets the passing of our good friend and member, Hannah Seidman. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKINSON, JOSEPHINE (COLGATE)
description: WILKINSON-Josephine (Colgate). Of Hightstown, NJ, formerly of West Orange, NJ, December 25, at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence Wilkinson, mother of Edith Allen of Arlington, MA and Russell Wilkinson of Princeton, New Jersey and New York City. Also survived by 3 grandchildren. Burial private; memorial service to be announced at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to YWCA of Essex and West Hudson, 395 Main Street, Orange, New Jersey 07050.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREISTER, LORETTA
description: TREISTER-Loretta. On December 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Melvin. Devoted mother of Shelley Claar. Dear sister of Carrol Herskowitz. Loving grandmother of Courtney and Jamie Claar.

title: To Go; Tasty Bargains and Italian Bounty
description: DON'T wear a backpack as you prowl the narrow aisles of AGATA & VALENTINA , one of those glorious specialty food stores that dot New York City. If you dare turn around, you're likely to knock over something that's been stacked, piled or displayed in what seems like the very last bit of available space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILWORTH, J. RICHARDSON
description: DILWORTH-J. Richardson. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art deeply mourn the passing of our beloved former Chairman, J. Richardson Dilworth, one of the Institution's most devoted and valued leaders. His more than three decades of exemplary and devoted serviceas longtime Trustee and Trustee Emeritus, Vice President, Vice Chairman, and Chairman of the Board-were marked by wisdom, judgement, and generosity. A Fellow for Life since 1961, he was elected as Benefactor in 1980, and served as Chairman from 1983 to 1987, presiding over an era of major growth in Museum programs, building, collections, and attendance. A guiding light and an indomitable force, he will be deeply missed. Arthur Ochs Sulzburger, Chairman William H. Luers, President Philippe de Montebello, Director

title: Nurse With Tender Touch Is Held in 6 Killings
description: They were old men and women, dying quiet deaths in a small-town hospital in the middle of America, a cycle that seemed as natural as the seasons that inevitably turn to frost.

title: Food Stuff
description: A French Tradition For Epiphany

title: Confidence Of Consumers Is Surging
description: Unruffled by Asia's crisis and buoyed by the exceptionally promising job market, American consumers approach 1998 with the most confidence about their economic future that they have expressed in nearly three decades.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Order a cup of espresso at the Four Seasons or Montrachet or TriBeCa Grill or any of 237 other restaurants in New York, Chicago, San Francisco or Los Angeles that have cups and saucers designed by ROBERT RAUSCHENBERG and you may well help out his favorite charity, his own foundation called Change.

title: A 'Grimes' Tenor's Debt to 2 Masters
description: Every tenor who sings the title role of Benjamin Britten's ''Peter Grimes'' has to acknowledge two great interpreters who made it their own. There was, of course, Peter Pears, who created the role at the 1945 premiere. For him, Grimes, a fisherman in a small coastal town in England of the 1830's, was a pathetic loner troubled by illicit yearnings and flush with unrealistic fantasies of a stable home life with the town's widowed schoolteacher. His only refuge was his dreamy reveries.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MIRAGLIA, LUCY NICODEMA
description: MIRAGLIA-Lucy Nicodema. It has been 2 years now, your legacy is still alive. I think of you everyday. Your loving son, Richard John Russell

title: Sips; A Cold Bubble Bath Before the Popping
description: CHAMPAGNE loves a deep chill. It is what accentuates the wine's crisp taste and tingle and keeps the bubbles rising to the top of the glass. But how you get the wine to that perfect temperature -- somewhere between 37 and 45 degrees -- is decidedly a matter of style.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAMELA ANDERSON LEE, the former star of ''Baywatch'' and her husband, TOMMY LEE, the drummer of Motley Crue, are parents again. Ms. Lee gave birth to their second child, a boy named DYLAN JAGGER Monday morning at their home in Malibu, Calif., The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Harmac Pacific Calls Offer Inadequate
description: Harmac Pacific Inc. urged shareholders today to reject a takeover bid of $52 million (United States) from Pope & Talbot Inc. and said it was reviewing alternatives that included finding another buyer.

title: Required: Boots and Air Guitars
description: Beat culture has split into so many shards that it's not surprising that one of its great consumers has become the white upper middle class. Always looking for a way out of their cushy surroundings, the children of the privileged have adopted various experiences over the years; the most recent is following the band Phish around. At Madison Square Garden on Monday night the band started the first of three sold-out concerts, and the show was a form of ritual, a furious dance party that lasted more than three hours.

title: For Those Who Just Have to Be There Tonight, Here Is What to Expect
description: There will be 500,000 people, 30,000 balloons (they almost didn't make it), 3,000 pounds of confetti, 4,600 police barricades and if official resolutions are to be believed, no champagne.

title: Giants to Spend the Off Season In Search of a Big-Play Receiver
description: In the 10 victories of their 17-game season, during their march to a division title, and even in the middle of their staggering playoff loss to the Minnesota Vikings, one important thing was missing from the Giants: big-play potential on offense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GASSMAN, RON
description: GASSMAN-Ron. December 29, 1997, Bedford, New York. Temple Shaaray Tefila mourns the sudden passing of Ron Gassman, Ron was a Founding Member, Past President, Director and Dear Friend of our congregation. Our hearts are with his wife Marian, and daughter Lauren as we mourn this tragic loss. Funeral Wednesday at 11AM at the Temple. The Board of Trustees

title: PLATINUM TECHNOLOGY SHARES RISE ON INTEL INVESTMENT
description: Shares of Platinum Technology Inc. rose yesterday after the software company said the Intel Corporation had invested in it, forming an alliance to help develop products to manage computer systems. The shares rose $4.171875, to $28.171875, in Nasdaq trading. Intel said it had bought less than 5 percent of Platinum, although it declined to specify the amount. The move comes as Platinum strives to return to profitability after losing money the last two years, leading it to cut its work force by 400, or about 9 percent. Platinum, based in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., makes software that companies use to link various kinds of computers and manage networks. Intel and Platinum plan to collaborate on marketing their software products.

title: Shareholders of True North Communications approve a $440 million acquisition of Bozell.
description: SHAREHOLDERS of True North Communications Inc. approved its $440 million acquisition of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt Inc. yesterday, ending a bitter two-month battle in a long-running feud between True North and its former partner, Publicis S.A. of France.

title: Millions Warming to a New Way to Greet the New Year
description: In a revealing sign of an aging nation and a more conservative time, a family oriented, alcohol-free celebration called First Night is becoming an increasingly popular alternative to the traditional excesses of New Year's Eve.

title: Study First, Play Later
description: Dean Smith, the University of North Carolina basketball coach, retired this year as the collegiate game's most victorious coach and one of its most respected leaders. At a time when college sports were plagued with phony transcripts and athletes who earned millions for their schools but not an education for themselves, Mr. Smith ran an exemplary program that produced a basketball dynasty yet graduated more than 90 percent of its players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, JEAN L. (NEE JOHNSON)
description: COOK-Jean L. (nee Johnson). Died on Monday, December 29, 1997 in Hackettstown, N.J. Born in Moline, IL. on March 25, 1921. Daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Karl Johnson of Denver. Mrs. Cook was a graduate of the Vogue School of Design, Chicago, IL., and was a designer for Marshall Fields in Chicago. Her volunteer services included The Women's Auxiliary of Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J., New Eyes for the Needy, Millburn, N.J. and President of the Panther Valley Garden Club. Mrs. Cook was an Elder of the Central Presbyterian Church, Summit, N.J. and chaired the worship and music programs. She is survived by her loving husband of 52 years, Charles, retired Headmaster of The Browning School. Survived by her sons, Charles and John; and her grandchildren Diana, Justin, Stephen, and Charles; brothers Dr. Karl Johnson and Vaughn Johnson and her sister, Lois Reeves. Her daughter Beatrice died in 1993. A memorial service will be held at 2 PM, Saturday, January 3, 1998, at the Central Presbyterian Church, 10 Maple St, Summit, N.J. with the Rev. Riley Jensen officiating. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions be made to the Central Presbyterian Church music program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, SHELLY
description: TOBIN-Shelly. A dear, close friend will be sorely missed. Heartfelt condolences to Sunny and family. Abe Frischer

title: U.S. Approves a General Electric Purchase
description: The General Electric Company got Justice Department approval today for its $600 million purchase of Stewart & Stevenson Services Inc.'s gas turbine unit by agreeing to license a new joint venture to perform maintenance and overhaul work.

title: Diary Is Moving
description: Starting next week, Metropolitan Diary moves to Mondays in The Metro Section.

title: Israeli Jew From Outlawed Group Is Convicted of Insulting Islam
description: A Jewish militant who provoked rioting in Hebron and outrage in the Muslim world when she put up posters depicting the prophet Mohammed as a pig was convicted today of committing an act of racism and trying to offend religious feelings.

title: ALCOA CANCELS PLAN TO BUY REYNOLDS METALS MILL
description: The Aluminum Company of America ended plans yesterday to buy an Alabama aluminum rolling mill from the Reynolds Metals Company for $250 million after the Department of Justice sued on Monday to block the sale on antitrust concerns. In a letter to the Richmond-based Reynolds Metals, Alcoa's chairman and chief executive, Paul O'Neill, said the letter of intent was ''no longer operative.'' The plant in Muscle Shoals, Ala., produces 450,000 tons of aluminum-can sheet a year.

title: The Minimalist; Rediscovering Chestnuts
description: WHEN chestnuts were abundant in the United States, before the blight that virtually wiped out the trees in the early part of this century, most cooks not only knew how to cook them but looked forward to the yearly windfall. When ripe, chestnuts rapidly carpet the ground under the trees and are easily gathered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCBRIDE, LEONARD J.
description: MCBRIDE-Leonard J. The Glee Club of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick records with profound sorrow the recent death of our beloved tenor, Leonard J. McBride, a Member since 1947. Bro Joseph P. Reilly, FSC, Pres. Edward P. Donnellan, Vice-Pres.

title: Honors
description: * Lynn Picard, senior vice president for advertising at Lifetime Television, New York, which is owned by the Hearst Corp. and the Walt Disney Co., was named chairwoman of the National Sales Advisory Board of the Cable Advertising Bureau. She succeeds Dave Cassaro, senior vice president for advertising sales at E! Entertainment Television, New York, owned by Time Warner Inc.

title: British Petroleum Buys Polystyrol Unit
description: Huels A.G., the chemical unit of the German utility Veba A.G., said yesterday that it had sold its polystyrol business to the German unit of the British Petroleum Company P.L.C., making British Petroleum one of the largest producers of polystyrol. British Petroleum said it would pay $200 million for the business.

title: Bits and Bytes
description: Real Uses for CD-ROM's

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Tinier and Tastier Than Littlenecks
description: COCKLES -- small, sweet briny bivalves -- pack more flavor than littleneck clams. But because they've become widely available only in recent months, they are relatively unfamiliar to many cooks and can be slightly daunting.

title: Judge Honored Law In Extradition Case
description: To the Editor:

title: China Cracks Down on Dissent in Cyberspace
description: China adopted elaborate new rules today restricting use of the Internet, a medium that is fast fraying the Government's monopoly on information.

title: A Conservative Group Sues on Medicare Rule
description: A new Federal law scheduled to take effect on Thursday has set off a dispute over the right of elderly people to choose their own health care and to negotiate fees with their doctors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, CECILE
description: SUSSMAN-Cecile. Suddenly and peacefully, at home, on November 25, 1997 in her 90th year. Beloved by daughters JoAnn and Ethel, sisters Dotty and Mickey, companion Pearl, ''granddaughter'' Stacy, sonin-law Jeff, granddaughter Becky, great-grandson Jacob, and Buddy. Loving comrade and widow of Jack. Long time dedicated, innovative teacher in the NYC public schools. Indomitable, compassionate, full of dignity, common sense and humor. Renowned chocoholic. Positive and young in mind and outlook, with wide ranging interests and devotion to progressive causes. Great listener and supportive, inspiring friend and mentor to countless relatives and friends of all ages around the world, which will be a poorer place without her wise and loving presence. Memorial gathering in April. Donations may be made in Cele's memory to: Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, 799 Broadway, New York City 10003.

title: Hash Good Enough To Make From Scratch
description: TRADITIONALLY, hash, the quintessential comfort food, has been the perfect answer for leftovers -- as long as they included an ample supply of boiled potatoes and some sort of meat.

title: Two Persevering Skiers Win and Earn Spot on U.S. Team
description: Two little-known cross-country skiers, one who had to pay for his training and another who was considered too old, qualified for the United States Olympic team by winning races at the United States Ski Team Gold Cup today on Mount Van Hoevenberg.

title: Securities Firm Disavows Report on Indonesia Debt
description: Indosuez WI Carr Securities yesterday disavowed a report by its acting head of research in Jakarta, Indonesia, that estimated Indonesia's foreign debt at $200 billion. The report raised the ire of Indonesia's President, Suharto. The $200 billion figure is almost double the official $118 billion Government estimate. The firm's report of Dec. 22 was carried in the press on Dec. 24.

title: Soft Shot, Soft Voice: Harper Can Still Lead
description: There is something about Derek Harper that is as calming as soup on a cold day. He can change teams, slip a new uniform on, but he is still a soothing voice of reason wherever he goes.

title: Wine Talk; Let's Lift a Glass To the Grapes of '97
description: THIS was a fascinating year in the wine business. And not just because the grape harvest was so good in so many places. It was a year of consolidation and new directions, a year that may even lead to cheaper prices. It was a year of silver anniversaries, too; a lot of people decided to become winemakers in 1972.

title: No Room for Tankers
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong to Inspect Mainland Farms for Bird-Flu Virus
description: Hong Kong officials declared today that chickens imported from mainland China are the probable source of the bird-flu outbreak that has left four people dead here, and announced that they had worked out an elaborate new inspection system with mainland authorities to screen poultry imports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LOUIS H., ESQ.
description: LEVINE-Louis H., Esq. On December 28, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Goldie, dear father of Honey and Leonard Slavit, Morton and Susan Levine. Grandfather of Ira and Diana Slavit, David and Robin Slavit, Gail Slavit, Richard and Pattie Levine and Gary Levine. Great-Grandfather of Gillian, Michael, Danielle, Evan, Roni, Meredith, Taylor and Mallorie. Services on December 31 at 11:30AM, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, Hewlett, New York.

title: Nike to Feature A New Slogan
description: Nike Inc. said yesterday that as expected it would supplement its long-running theme, ''Just do it,'' with a new slogan, ''I can.''

title: GEC Alsthom Says Stock Sale Will Proceed
description: GEC Alsthom said yesterday that the initial public offering of 52 percent of its shares would go ahead as planned in the first half of 1998 and denied that its railway project in South Korea might be delayed because of the country's financial turmoil. The Express, a British newspaper, said GEC Alsthom, a British-French engineering company, might halt its planned stock market listing, amid a Government review of a planned high-speed rail link in South Korea. The paper cited no sources.

title: Another Week For Barriers In Midtown
description: Despite heated and escalating criticism from pedestrians and their advocates, the Giuliani administration announced yesterday that it would extend by a week, until at least Jan. 12, its experiment to ease vehicular gridlock in midtown by blocking off pedestrian crosswalks.

title: New York Gained Empire, but Lost Democracy; Colonies' First City
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bashful Fiennes And a Vivid Heiress In a Quirky Tale
description: Without doubt, there is no more eccentric story to be found on-screen right now that ''Oscar and Lucinda,'' in which love, glass, Christianity and gambling somehow collide. As directed exquisitely by Gillian Armstrong in a headstrong spirit that recalls her debut feature, ''My Brilliant Career,'' this elliptical tale makes up in visual beauty whatever it lacks in universal meaning.

title: Data From 'Black Box' Reveal Forces That Jolted a Jetliner
description: Passengers on a Boeing 747 over the Pacific on Sunday night were pushed into their seats by turbulence that jarred the plane with a force that was nearly 50 percent greater than that felt during normal takeoffs.

title: REPUBLIC PLANS A CHARGE OF $100 MILLION TO $150 MILLION
description: Republic Industries plans to take a pretax charge of $100 million to $150 million in the fourth quarter to cover costs of merging its Autonation used-car chain with its new-car dealerships. Republic Industries, the world's largest seller of cars and light trucks, said the charge would be more than offset by a gain from the sale of its electronic security business to the Ameritech Corporation for about $250 million. The company, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and is led by its billionaire chairman, H. Wayne Huizenga, says that putting the 25 Autonation used-car stores under the management of new-car dealers will help to make the used-car stores profitable by the second half of 1998. Shares of Republic Industries rose 81.25 cents, to $20.9375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBEL, JOSEPH MEARSON
description: LOBEL-Joseph Mearson. Beloved father of Brian Mearson Lobel and Gail Lobel Shields. Cherished grandfather of Alexander Joseph and Chelsea Anne Shields. Loving father-in-law of Ellen Mulhall and Robert Shields. Lived with love, we wish him peace and hold close his memory. Service 10AM Friday, January 2, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions to Make a Wish Foundation.

title: Arts in America; East Joined West, and Always the Train Was Met
description: Anyone inclined to think that masterful marketing is a more or less recent invention will discover on wandering through ''Inventing the Southwest'' at the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art here that an English immigrant and onetime dishwasher named Fred Harvey set the standard a century ago.

title: Center Part Of a Sextet Drops In In Mid-Set
description: At their best, the Jazz Passengers upend the formula of a regular jazz gig. Burning fast and furiously, leading listeners into slugged delirium, is not their style, nor do they practice chamberlike seriousness. They do something more like offhand coffee-break conversation, with private jokes and loony non sequiturs. The chatter starts the moment they arrive onstage, gets into the solos and the rhythms and even the written themes and gradually spreads out to the audience.

title: Commercial Real Estate; High-Profile Dance School Is Losing Some Exposure
description: For years, one of the best theatrical spectacles on Broadway has cost nothing more than an upward glance -- to the big windows of the Broadway Dance Center at 55th Street, where each plate-glass expanse frames a vibrant vignette: ballet dancers stretching gracefully at the barre, jazz dancers whirling in a choreographed frenzy, tap dancers polishing the parquet.

title: New York Gained Empire, but Lost Democracy; Unwelcome Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: CITIZENS FINANCIAL TO BUY SUBURBFED FOR $55 MILLION
description: Citizens Financial Services agreed yesterday to buy the Suburbfed Financial Corporation for about $55 million, sending Suburbfed's shares up 41 percent. In the transaction, each share of Suburbfed, based in Flossmoor, Ill., would be exchanged for 3.6 shares of yet-to-be-issued Citizens stock. To issue stock, Citizens will convert from a company owned by its customers to one owned by investors. Shares of Suburbfed jumped $13.75, to $47.50. Suburbfed's 12 branches are in Illinois and Citizens' 12 branches are in Indiana. As of Sept. 30, Suburbfed had assets of $432.6 million and Citizens had assets of $746.9 million.

title: Dow Rises 123.56, on a 2d Vibrant Day
description: The stock market rallied again yesterday, as investors went on an end-of-the-year buying spree in the hope that the economic crisis in Asia would not seriously disrupt United States corporate profits in the coming year.

title: By the Book; Some 1,400 Ways To Cook Vegetarian
description: DEBORAH MADISON'S new book, ''Vegetarian Cooking for Everyone,'' is an epic, containing 1,400 recipes and weighing four and a half pounds. Beneath the endless stream of recipes lies an unwritten tale of vegetarian cooking in America, from the lentil croquettes and Cheddar souffles of the early days to a modern, sophisticated but simple dish of mixed beans with parsley and Parmesan.

title: Temptations of a Balanced Budget
description: By some estimates, the Federal budget is headed for surplus for the first time in many years. The surplus, if it occurs, is likely to be temporary because Medicare costs will begin to soar within a decade. Even so, the prospect of a more or less balanced budget has inspired a lot of politicians to start waving tax cuts in front of the voters. Premature cuts can only hurt the poor. When the economy slows, Congress is far more likely to cut the housing, day care and training on which the poor rely before they rescind their ill-advised tax cuts.

title: Woman Fatally Struck by Bus On 3d Avenue at Rush Hour
description: A 54-year-old financial analyst died hours after being struck by a tour bus on the Upper East Side yesterday during the evening rush hour, the police said. She was dragged for at least half a block before a pedestrian waved down the driver, who was unaware that he had struck her, the police said.

title: FOOTBALL: The Hunter Being Hunted; Woodson Will Be the Focus at the Rose Bowl
description: The photo opportunity seemed to have little purpose, except to demonstrate that football players would be willing to interrupt their preparations for the Rose Bowl if given the chance to eat hamburgers. Leaders of the teams from Michigan and Washington State stood on a makeshift stage at a restaurant in nearby Universal City and listened to their names being called, except for one, who was reminded once more how his life has changed forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KETCHAM, STELLA
description: KETCHAM-Stella. We join together in mourning a woman whose generosity helped shaped the most sophisticated healthcare network on Long Island. As a founder of North Shore University Hospital, Stella Ketcham, along with her husband, Garry, helped to establish a facility that today serves the entire metropolitan region. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her niece. Saul Katz and Roy J. Zuckerberg Co-Chairmen, Board of Trustees John S.T. Gallagher and David R. Dantzker, MD Co-Presidents and CEOs North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, FAYE
description: GREENWALD-Faye. Oliver Wendell Holmes wrote, ''Where we love is home, home that our feet may leave but not our hearts.'' You were our home. Our hearts are broken. Children Len & Pat Greenwald and Ellen & Bob Ginsberg Grandchildren Jennifer Greenwald, Dara & Joe Mechanic, David Greenwald and Leah Ginsberg Great granddaughters Victoria and Olivia Mechanic

title: Outdated Drug Laws
description: New York's Governor, George Pataki, showed compassion and a sense of proportion recently when he commuted the sentences of three people serving time for drug offenses. All three were first-time, nonviolent offenders who had received mandatory prison sentences of 15 years to life under the drug laws enacted during Nelson Rockefeller's tenure. These 1973 laws, some of the nation's most rigid, also prompted earlier Democratic governors to commute drug sentences that were patently unjust.

title: ATRION TO BUY SOME PRODUCT LINES FROM QUEST MEDICAL
description: The Atrion Corporation, a medical-products maker in Arab, Ala., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire certain product lines of Quest Medical Inc.'s cardiovascular and intravenous fluid delivery operations for $24.5 million. The acquired product lines -- which are sold through hospitals, telemarketing, independent sales representatives, distributors and direct mail -- have annual revenue of $14.5 million. The acquisition includes a myocardial protection system used during open- heart surgery, pressure control valves, pre-bypass and arterial line filters and more than 50 intravenous fluid delivery systems. Atrion also plans to acquire 27 patents from Quest Medical. Quest Medical is based in Dallas.

title: National News Briefs; Police Find No Motive In Slaying of Designer
description: Five and a half months after the fashion designer Gianni Versace was shot to death outside his Miami Beach home, the police said today that they still lacked a motive for the crime and could not fully account for the movements of the suspected killer, Andrew P. Cunanan, who committed suicide nine days after Mr. Versace's death.

title: Fuji Deal Ending; Concord Stock Dives
description: Shares of the Concord Camera Corporation tumbled today after the Fuji Photo Film Company of Japan said it would end an agreement allowing Concord to use Fuji technology in its disposable cameras.

title: National News Briefs; Man Who Impersonated Congressman Is Captured
description: An Illinois man who was wanted by the police in at least two states for crimes including theft schemes in which he impersonated a member of Congress has been captured.

title: Art's Origins Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Staples Sets a Stock Split
description: Staples Inc. said today that its board declared a 3-for-2 stock split on or about Jan. 30, the fifth consecutive annual split it has declared. Holders of record at the close of business on Jan. 20 are eligible to take part. The stock gained $2.3125, to $27.8125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: To Masters of Language, A Long Overdue Toast
description: Each vocation or avocation has its Babe Ruths and Baryshnikovs, and so it is with the Linguistic Society of America.

title: Tyson's Guilty Plea Adds Drama to Espy Trial
description: The pending trial of former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy on charges of accepting illegal gifts has taken on greater political significance with the likelihood that Donald Tyson, the poultry millionaire and longtime supporter of President Clinton, will testify against Mr. Espy.

title: Sports of The Times; Football Isn't A Science; It's a Game
description: AFTER the Jets lost to Detroit in the last regular-season game a week ago Sunday evening, Bill Parcells, the Bully Boy of East Rutherford, was asked a question in the news conference immediately afterward that didn't quite appeal to him. The lines on his face hardened, as though he had just sucked a lemon, or was imitating Mr. Magoo.

title: Board Recommends Steps To Curb Power Failures
description: State regulators recommended a series of steps yesterday including more frequent tree-trimming -- to help GPU Energy reduce power failures during destructive storms. The recommendations were first drafted in October after a series of failures caused nearly 330,000 GPU customers to lose electrical service.

title: Gold Loses Its Luster
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Prices Fall Slightly In Quiet Day
description: Treasury prices fell yesterday after a strong report on consumer confidence suggested that the economy might not slow as much as expected.

title: 'The Boxer' Seeks Hope Amid Ulster's Suffering
description: Serious filmgoers have learned to take special notice of the week between Christmas and New Year's. It's the time for especially distinguished year-end sleepers (''The Madness of King George,'' ''In the Name of the Father''), and this year it brings two beauties: an exotic Australian romance steeped in religion and gambling (''Oscar and Lucinda,'' reviewed on page 5), and ''The Boxer,'' Jim Sheridan's tender, wrenching Belfast drama.

title: Times Square Grit Peeps Through Glitz; New Year's Eve Ball Will Drop In the Midst of a Metamorphosis, But Old Haunts and Ways Linger
description: You have to pause. You have to resist the pull of the human river surging through Times Square these days, and you have to raise your eyes. There, above a franchise pizzeria's red-and-green marquee at the northeast corner of Broadway and 46th Street, four small statues stand in defiance of Disney and the rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESTON, DIXON
description: PRESTON-Dixon. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Dixon Preston, associated with The Times from 1963, until retiring in 1982.

title: Fugitive in Murder Case Is Arrested 6 Years Later
description: A man wanted in a six-year-old Brooklyn murder case was arrested in Houston this month and returned to New York yesterday to stand trial, the police said.

title: Cloudy Visibility on France's Road to Recovery
description: The announcement by the Japanese automobile maker Toyota early this month that it would build an assembly plant employing 2,000 workers in the rust-belt town of Valenciennes in northern France seemed a hopeful omen that even a European welfare state could still be a good investment.

title: Job Cuts at Alliance
description: The Alliance Entertainment Corporation said today that it would consolidate its Santa Fe Springs, Calif., warehouse operation with its Coral Springs, Fla., operation in a move that will eliminate 150 jobs. Coral Springs will become the company's headquarters. The jobs cut will be distribution and warehouse positions in Santa Fe Springs, Alliance said. In July, Alliance, a distributor of prerecorded music and related products, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: BMW to Retain DeWitt Media
description: BMW of North America said yesterday that it had retained DeWitt Media in New York to handle its national media planning and buying account, with billings estimated at $80 million.

title: Temptation; Sugary Breakfast in Asia Is Spicy Bite in the West
description: AT first glance, roti canai, an appetizer at Malaysia Restaurant in Chinatown, looks as ordinary as tortillas and dip. But one taste will tell you that the flaky pancakes smothered with spicy coconut-curry sauce are anything but ordinary.

title: UConn's Sales Healthy Again and Ready
description: Nykesha Sales is feeling much better -- physically and mentally -- and just in time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISEN, FLORENCE
description: EISEN-Florence. Died December 30, 1997 after a long illness. Wife of Milton, deceased. Mother of Cary, Michela and Mark. Service Friday, 1 P.M., Mount Hope Cemetery, Yonkers, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIDENBAUM, SARAH
description: MAIDENBAUM-Sarah. Beloved wife of the late Harry, loving mother of Elaine and Burt Marsh and Howard and Eppie Maidenbaum. Adored grandmother of David, Joan, Donald and Meg, Debbie, Sue, Jeffrey and Marla, Jody and Michael. Cherished great-grandmother of Adam, Jason, Rebecca, Alan, Andrew, Daria, Keith, Harris, Alexandra and Nikki. Beloved sister of Nat and Freddie, Alex and Pauline, Irving and Ceil Feldman and the late Morris Feldman. She was a very caring, loving and charitable woman, so contributions to your favorite charity in her memory will be greatly appreciated. Services Wednesday, 10 A.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Kenya's Flawed Election
description: Kenya's second multiparty election is proving to be as troubled as its first one five years ago. President Daniel arap Moi won then with a disputed 38 percent plurality after a violent campaign. Despite reforms, this year's balloting ended yesterday with claims by both President Moi and opposition leaders that the national Electoral Commission had rigged the vote. Final results have not been announced, but some lessons are already evident.

title: Calendar
description: How Many Matzoh Balls?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUNSTEIN, JULIUS (HAL)
description: BRAUNSTEIN-Julius (Hal). Age 79, on December 20, 1997. Beloved husband of Dorothy (nee Kleiman). Devoted father of Marilyn and David Finkler and Stanley and Barbara Braunstein. Proud grandfather of Allison and Michael. Services were held in Florida.

title: $25 and Under; At a Popular Brasserie, It Helps to Have a Strategy
description: THE red-hot glow has not dimmed since Waterloo Brasserie opened last summer, drawing young, stylish crowds for Belgian dishes like mussels and fries. Even now, customers arrive into the night, undaunted by the restaurant's annoying policy of not taking reservations for parties smaller than six. They gather at the bar, sampling the fine list of Belgian beers and emitting a haze of cigarette smoke that settles over the open, high-ceilinged dining room.

title: Manning Is the Big Star; Frost Is the Big Mystery
description: Peyton Manning of Tennessee finished second in the Heisman Trophy balloting and is considered by many to be the best college quarterback in the country. Nebraska quarterback Scott Frost, after transferring from Stanford two years ago, is just now getting his team's fans to appreciate him.

title: Concern on Japan's Economy Pushes Dollar Higher vs. Yen
description: The dollar rose against the yen yesterday as speculation that Japan's efforts to revive its faltering economy would prove insufficient left investors wary of buying Japanese financial assets.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Respite for Children, and a Break for Parents
description: For seven years, Leila Parker was snapped awake every night by her daughter's unintelligible screams. Dazed, she would run to Melodie's bedside, where she could do nothing but watch her mentally retarded child swing tiny fists at invisible foes. Over and over, Ms. Parker whispered, ''Mommy is here,'' but while Melodie's eyes were open, she was not conscious during her seizures, and she took no solace in her mother's presence.

title: TV Notes
description: 'Seinfeld' Leaves A Broader Gap

title: CALIFORNIA'S BAN TO CLEAR SMOKE INSIDE MOST BARS
description: In the biggest assault yet on cigarette smoking in the United States, bars, casinos and nightclubs across California will be forced to ban smoking at the stroke of midnight on Jan. 1, as part of a virtual ban on indoor smoking in public places.

title: INSIDE
description: Consumer Confidence Grows

title: Devils' Defense Falls Apart as Brodeur Sits With Flu
description: Martin Brodeur fell ill with the flu just hours before the game. Mike Dunham, who started in goal, fell down on the job in the second period. And nothing fell into place for the Devils on offense or defense tonight as the Chicago Blackhawks fired in six straight goals and won, 6-2, at Continental Arena.

title: New York Gained Empire, but Lost Democracy; 5 Boroughs, 4 Counties
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: When the curtain goes down Saturday evening on ''Side Show,'' the Broadway musical about the Siamese twins Daisy and Violet Hilton, it will mark the end of the run for cast and crew but a dream come true for a member of the audience, EVAN W. GADDA of Reno.

title: Movie Clock Today
description: An extra edition for the holiday weekend. The Arts, page E18.

title: Unreported Flaws Cited After Building Collapses
description: Just a half block from the center of tonight's New Year's Eve celebration, a narrow six-story building collapsed shortly before the morning rush yesterday, throwing tons of rubble into 42d Street and raising questions about whether recent signs of structural problems with the building had been properly addressed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, JEANNE
description: KAPLAN-Jeanne. Beloved mother and grandmother who died surrounded by those who love her. Her indominateable spirit has rejoined her daughter Nancy in GAN-EDEN. She is survived by her children Cynthia and Bruce Halpern and Kitty and Michael D'Alto and her grandchildren Nancy, Adina, Michael, David and Danielle. Services at Sinai Chapel, Horace Harding Expressway, 162nd St, Wednesday 11am.

title: Judge Honored Law In Extradition Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Give Cloutier A Chance, Ready or Not
description: Dan Cloutier, the Rangers' new backup goalie, was a first-round draft choice at age 18, but he is a patient young man. Now 21 years old, he has on his resume a four-year apprenticeship at the Junior A level and almost a season and a half in the professional minor leagues.

title: Tech Still Tops at Home
description: LOUISIANA TECH 75, ARIZONA 64

title: INSIDE
description: You can't buy penny candy anymore. But for 15 cents, you can be mayor.

title: Child Care Sacred as France Cuts Back the Welfare State
description: Martine Susini performs the thankless tasks of any day-care director: picking up tricycles here, cleaning tiny hands there, stopping to check on milk bottles or the state of the mini toilets. Yet here in France she is known as Madame la Directrice and her job holds considerable prestige.

title: Giuliani Rewards Two Democrats With Senior Positions
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday rewarded two Democrats who supported his re-election with high-paying cabinet positions, naming Assemblyman Jules Polonetsky as Consumer Affairs Commissioner and Councilman Antonio Pagan as Employment Commissioner.

title: Tired Nets Can't Keep Up With the Pacers
description: The Nets have been much like a late-running horse. They often spot their opponents a big early lead, then usually respond by roaring back down the stretch.

title: For Just 15 Cents and Some Solemn Words, a Mayor Becomes a Mayor Again
description: It took mere minutes and cost 15 cents, but it's official now: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was sworn in yesterday for his second term as New York City's 107th mayor, effective at midnight on New Year's Eve.

title: Business Travel; Hong Kong's huge new airport, Chek Lap Kok, is set to open in April, tourist slump and all.
description: THE airport event of the coming year will be the opening of Hong Kong's huge Chek Lap Kok terminal in April -- a date picked long before the city's current tourist slump and chicken flu crisis. The airport, which occupies reclaimed land near the rugged peaks of Lantau Island, is as large as all of Kowloon, one of Hong Kong's three main districts.

title: Clinton Defense of Aide May Hurt Nominee
description: In his defense of a White House aide, Ira C. Magaziner, who has been accused by a Federal judge of giving ''misleading'' testimony in a lawsuit, President Clinton has inadvertently given Congressional Republicans a weapon to use against his nominee to a top Justice Department job.

title: Danilo Dolci, Vivid Voice Of Sicily's Poor, Dies at 73
description: Danilo Dolci, an advocate of nonviolent social reform whose writings and poetry chronicled Sicily's beauty and sense of despair, died today in a hospital in Sicily of heart failure. He was 73.

title: In South Korea, Underground Banking Thrives as Other Lenders Say 'No'
description: On a narrow back street, squeezed between a curb-side locksmith and a small video game arcade, lies one of this city's banking centers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMORE, HAROLD D. (RET. MAJOR U.S. ARMY)
description: GILMORE-Harold D. (Ret. Major U.S. Army). Composer, musician and teacher. Of Centerport, N.Y. On December 29, 1997. Beloved husband of Anne. Devoted father of Geoffrey D., Samuel L., Priscilla A. and Arthur H. Loving grandfather of seven. Brother of Flora Mitchell. Funeral services Friday, 11AM, The Congregational Church of Huntington. Donations in his memory to The Congregational Church of Huntington, 30 Washington Drive (P.O. Box 134), Centerport, N.Y. 11721 appreciated.

title: At a Secret Chefs' Dinner in France, A Tiny Songbird Lands on the Plate
description: IN a darkened room one evening this month in Bordeaux, many of the world's most famous chefs and restaurateurs sat with napkins over their heads and faces. The crunching sounds from under the napkins was unmistakable: the guests were eating.

title: Florida Bank Acquisition
description: The Bankunited Financial Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Central Bank, a smaller Florida bank, for $22.3 million in stock. Bankunited, based here, operates 17 offices in Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach Counties. Central Bank, based in Miami, operates four offices in Miami-Dade County. Bankunited will issue about 1.48 million shares of its class A stock to Central Bank.

title: Broadway Zoning Plan Faces Many Questions
description: Changing the zoning regulations in the Broadway theater district to encourage new plays, stimulate theater construction and coordinate development of Eighth Avenue is a proposal enthusiastically embraced by theater owners, producers and many union officials.

title: Simone Duvalier, the 'Mama Doc' of Haiti
description: Simone Duvalier, who rose from a childhood of poverty and abandonment to become the wife of one Haitian dictator, mother of another and a power in her own right, died of undisclosed causes in a clinic outside Paris on Friday. She was in her mid-80's and had lived in France since being forced into exile almost 12 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROONEY, SR. MARY MELITA
description: ROONEY-Sr. Mary Melita. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity and elementary school teacher on Dec. 29, 1997. Survived by her sister-in-law, Dorothy, and her cousins, Sr. Angela Rooney, Msgr. Hugh J. Rooney and Ann Rooney. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday 9:30 A.M., at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, New York. Interment is at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, New York 10471.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, JOHN JAMES
description: NICHOLS-John James. On Dec. 28, 1997, of Rye, NY. Devoted husband of Kathleen, beloved father of Kathleen Sasano of Rockville Centre, Jay of Hong Kong, Robert of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Alyson Attinello of Randolph, NJ. Dear grandfather of five grandchildren. The family will receive friends Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian burial at the Church of the Resurrection, Friday, 10 AM. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery.

title: Gilbert Fitzhugh, 88, Dies; Ex-Metropolitan Life Chief
description: Gilbert W. Fitzhugh, a former chairman and chief executive of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died on Monday at the Meadow Lakes Health Care Center in Hightstown, N.J. He was 88 years old and had been ailing for several years with Alzheimer's disease, said his son, Gilbert Van Ingh Fitzhugh.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about a Texas magistrate's freeing of a Rwandan who had been arrested at the request of a United Nations war crimes tribunal appeared in some copies with a passage omitted. The affected section, including a quotation from Marcel C. Notzon, the magistrate, should have read: '' 'It is undisputed that no treaty exists between the United States and the Tribunal,' he said. 'The absence of a treaty is a fatal defect in the Government's request that the extraditee be surrendered.' ''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

Overseas Union, one of Singapore's four largest banks, raised its prime to 7 percent from 6.5 percent. Overseas Chinese Banking and United Overseas, also among Singapore's biggest four banks, raised their prime rates on Monday by a half a percentage point to 7 percent.

Nielsen Corporation, a market-research firm, said yesterday that costs associated with job cuts, primarily in Japan, would reduce its fourth-quarter earnings by $36 million before taxes. A. C. Her creative leadership of the Metropolitan Opera/Metropolitan Opera Guild Membership Committee for more than a decade inspired the expansion of our programs to build audiences for the Met and to stimulate broad nationwide support for our activities.
